{"tularemia": [{"archive_id": "6679138", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden (06): outbreak, hares", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6679138", "date": "2019-09-17 14:33:34", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (06): OUTBREAK, HARES\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Sep 2019\nFrom: Erik Agren <erik.agren@sva.se> [edited]\n\n\nSince mid-2019, the National Veterinary Institute (SVA) has received an increased number of reports and submitted cases of dead hares, with the largest numbers originating from counties north of the river Dalilven (approx. Lat. 60A 73N). An increase in the number of reports submitted through the online form for reporting wildlife diseases rapporteravilt.sva.se indicated an ongoing outbreak already in July [2019].\n\nTularemia could be confirmed in multiple cases by pathology and confirmed with PCR or immunohistochemistry in dead hares submitted for diagnostic examination at SVA. Of 266 reports of dead hares, representing 320 carcasses for this year [2019] so far, 257 were reported from July [2019] to this date. Of 84 hares examined at SVA (almost equal number of European brown hare _Lepus europeaus_ and Mountain hare _Lepus timidus_) 22 were positive for tularemia; 16 cases from north of Dalilven, and 6 cases from south of this river.\n\nThe southernmost case was in the southern county of Blekinge, an unusual finding of tularemia so far south in the country. Tularemia cases in hares are also more common in the same counties where increased numbers of human cases are reported. A geographical correlation between cases of tularemia in hares and cases in humans has been observed.\n\n--\nErik Agren, Veterinary Officer\nSwedish National Veterinary Institute (SVA)\n<erik.agren@sva.se>\n\n[Special thanks to Dr. Agren for providing this valuable information that complements previous posts on this outbreak. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Of 84 hares examined at SVA (almost equal number of European brown hare _Lepus europeaus_ and Mountain hare _Lepus timidus_) 22 were positive for tularemia; 16 cases from north of Dalilven, and 6 cases from south of this river. From: Erik Agren <erik.agren@sva.se> [edited]\n\n\nSince mid-2019, the National Veterinary Institute (SVA) has received an increased number of reports and submitted cases of dead hares, with the largest numbers originating from counties north of the river Dalilven (approx. \n\n--\nErik Agren, Veterinary Officer\nSwedish National Veterinary Institute (SVA)\n<erik.agren@sva.se>", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Blekinge", "country": "Sweden"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7326726", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Canada: (ON) muskrat, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7326726", "date": "2020-05-12 09:57:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - CANADA: (ONTARIO) MUSKRAT, ALERT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 11 May 2020 5:40 PM EDT\nSource: Simcoe Reformer [edited]\nhttps://www.simcoereformer.ca/news/local-news/infectious-muskrats-in-long-point\n\n\nAdd to the list of healthcare woes in Norfolk an outbreak of rabbit fever [tularemia] in Long Point [Ontario].\n\nThe Haldimand-Norfolk Health Unit issued an alert about the contagious outbreak Monday [11 May 2020]. The latest aggressive pathogen has been detected in the muskrat population of southwest Norfolk.\n\nRabbit fever is caused by tularemia bacteria. The bacteria are carried by deer flies and ticks and can sicken humans and animals such as muskrats, rabbits, and beavers. In people, the bacteria typically attack the skin, eyes, lymph nodes, and lungs, the health unit said in a news release.\n\nSymptoms include the sudden onset of a high fever, chills, fatigue, headache, muscle pain, and nausea.\n\n'There were 4 human cases reported across Ontario between 2007 and 2017,' the health unit says. 'With treatment, death is rare.'\n\nInfection is possible after handling a contaminated animal, ingesting contaminated food or water, being bitten or licked by an infected insect or animal, or inhaling contaminated water droplets from contaminated soil.\n\nThe health unit is monitoring the situation at Long Point and is working with the Ministry of Health and other agencies to ensure appropriate measures are in place to protect the public.\n\n[Byline: Monte Sonnenberg]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the Gram-negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_(type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies. Wild rodents are also frequently infected and occurrence of human cases are usually linked to these host species.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ontario, Canada: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/66484]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nInfection is possible after handling a contaminated animal, ingesting contaminated food or water, being bitten or licked by an infected insect or animal, or inhaling contaminated water droplets from contaminated soil. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the Gram-negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nThe health unit is monitoring the situation at Long Point and is working with the Ministry of Health and other agencies to ensure appropriate measures are in place to protect the public. \n\n'There were 4 human cases reported across Ontario between 2007 and 2017,' the health unit says. ' \n\nTularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere. TULAREMIA - CANADA: (ONTARIO) MUSKRAT, ALERT\n********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-05-11 00:00:00", "2020-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norfolk", "country": "Norfolk Island"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6657269", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden (03): increase", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6657269", "date": "2019-09-04 17:21:42", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (03): INCREASE\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Aug 2019\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/tularemia-significant-rise-in-sweden-92551/\n\n\nTularemia: significant rise in Sweden\n-------------------------------------\nAs of [Mon 26 Aug 2019], about 560 human cases have been reported, much more this time of year than usual and even more than 2015 when 859 people across the country suffered from the illness. Most cases of illness are reported from central Sweden (the Dalarna region, Gavleborg and Orebro), but an increasing number of reports are also starting to come in from other regions, especially in northern Sweden.\n\nSince the number of illness cases is usually highest in September in Sweden, the outbreak is expected to grow further in the coming weeks.\n\nInfections in Sweden are mainly seen in forest and field hares and rodents, but the disease has been reported in several other species, including other mammals, birds, amphibians, insects, and ticks.\n\nTularemia, or harpest as it is known as in Sweden, is one of the most common native zoonoses in people in Sweden. People are infected mainly through mosquitoes, but also through direct contact with sick or dead animals and by inhalation of, for example, infectious dust.\n\nThe number of reported cases of harpest in humans varies from year to year, in recent years there have been reported between about 100 to over 800 cases per year. More than 90 percent of reported human cases have fallen ill in Sweden.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This outbreak, primarily in central Sweden, continues to increase in size.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares). Wild rodents are also frequently infected, and occurrence of human cases is usually linked to these host species. _F. tularensis_ is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ naturally infects several mammalian wildlife species in northern Europe, in particular, mice, rabbits, hares, beavers, voles, lemmings, and muskrats. The ticks _Dermacentor reticularis_ and _Ixodes ricinus_ are vectors for the bacterium, although previous research has suggested that mosquito bites are the most frequent route of transmission to humans in Sweden.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread via contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors.\n\nThe manifestations of infection in this growing outbreak in parts of Sweden are not stated. If vector borne, the most common form would be ulceroglandular with an ulcer at the introduction site and enlarged lymph nodes in that area. If waterborne, oropharyngeal would be most common. Among flying vectors, deer flies are often brought up but mosquitoes are also relevant as shown in this Swedish publication:\n\nReference\n---------\nThelaus J, Andersson A, Broman T, et al: _Francisella tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ occurs in Swedish mosquitoes, persists through the developmental stages of laboratory-infected mosquitoes and is transmissible during blood feeding. Microb Ecol. 2014; 67(1): 96-107; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3907667/\n\n'Abstract\n--------\nIn Sweden, mosquitoes are considered the major vectors of the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_, which causes tularemia. The aim of this study was to investigate whether mosquitoes acquire the bacterium as aquatic larvae and transmit the disease as adults. Mosquitoes sampled in a Swedish area where tularemia is endemic (Orebro) were positive for the presence of _F. tularensis_ deoxyribonucleic acid throughout the summer. Presence of the clinically relevant _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_ was confirmed in 11 out of the 14 mosquito species sampled. Experiments performed using laboratory-reared _Aedes aegypti_ confirmed that _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_ was transstadially maintained from orally infected larvae to adult mosquitoes and that 25% of the adults exposed as larvae were positive for the presence of _F. tularensis_-specific sequences for at least 2 weeks. In addition, we found that _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_ was transmitted to 58% of the adult mosquitoes feeding on diseased mice. In a small-scale in vivo transmission experiment with _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_-positive adult mosquitoes and susceptible mice, none of the animals developed tularemia. However, we confirmed that there was transmission of the bacterium to blood vials by mosquitoes that had been exposed to the bacterium in the larval stage. Taken together, these results provide evidence that mosquitoes play a role in disease transmission in part of Sweden where tularemia recurs.'\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nThelaus J, Andersson A, Broman T, et al: _Francisella tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ occurs in Swedish mosquitoes, persists through the developmental stages of laboratory-infected mosquitoes and is transmissible during blood feeding. In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread via contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. Among flying vectors, deer flies are often brought up but mosquitoes are also relevant as shown in this Swedish publication:\n\nReference\n \nAs of [Mon 26 Aug 2019], about 560 human cases have been reported, much more this time of year than usual and even more than 2015 when 859 people across the country suffered from the illness. The number of reported cases of harpest in humans varies from year to year, in recent years there have been reported between about 100 to over 800 cases per year. _holarctica_ was transstadially maintained from orally infected larvae to adult mosquitoes and that 25% of the adults exposed as larvae were positive for the presence of _F. tularensis_-specific sequences for at least 2 weeks. \n\nInfections in Sweden are mainly seen in forest and field hares and rodents, but the disease has been reported in several other species, including other mammals, birds, amphibians, insects, and ticks. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. \n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subspecies _ People are infected mainly through mosquitoes, but also through direct contact with sick or dead animals and by inhalation of, for example, infectious dust. Sweden (04): further increase, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6659382", "date": "2019-09-05 21:36:26", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (04): FURTHER INCREASE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 Sep 2019\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/sweden-tularemia-count-nears-700/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the tularemia, or harpest situation in Sweden, a little over 120 people have become ill with tularemia over the past week, bringing the total to around 690 in 2019.\n\nCompared to the previous weeks, there is a slight slowdown in the number of new cases, while compared to previous years there are still an unusually high number of people who fall sick with the bacterial infection, according to Folkhalsomyndigheten.\n\nMost new cases of illness are reported from the Dalarna and Gavleborg region, which together now have over 400 cases, while the number of new cases from Orebro counties has decreased.\n\nAccording to the CDC, tularemia is a disease that can infect animals and people. Rabbits, hares, and rodents are especially susceptible and often die in large numbers during outbreaks. People can become infected in several ways, including: tick and deer fly bites, skin contact with infected animals, drinking contaminated water and inhaling contaminated aerosols or agricultural and landscaping dust.\n\nSymptoms vary depending how the person was infected. Tularemia can be life-threatening, but most infections can be treated successfully with antimicrobials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of tularemia in Sweden continues to grow. Past reports have suggested that the outbreak is mosquito-borne but none of the reports have included clinical details of the cases. If an insect bite was responsible, one would see glandular or ulceroglandular disease, but if the outbreak was waterborne, then oropharyngeal infection with draining lymphadenopathy might be seen. ProMED would appreciate clinical information about the cases. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The number of cases of tularemia in Sweden continues to grow. Compared to the previous weeks, there is a slight slowdown in the number of new cases, while compared to previous years there are still an unusually high number of people who fall sick with the bacterial infection, according to Folkhalsomyndigheten. Most new cases of illness are reported from the Dalarna and Gavleborg region, which together now have over 400 cases, while the number of new cases from Orebro counties has decreased. For about 1/4 of the disease cases no path of infection is indicated, while mainly animal contact and in some cases drinking water is indicated as route of infection for the remaining cases.\n\n--\nRikard Dryselius\nFolkh\u00e4lsomyndigheten\n<rikard.dryselius@folkhalsomyndigheten.se>\n\n[ProMED thanks Rikard Dryselius for this clinical information. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\nRikard Dryselius\nFolkh\u00e4lsomyndigheten\n<rikard.dryselius@folkhalsomyndigheten.se>\n\n[ProMED thanks Rikard Dryselius for this clinical information.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7680849", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (WY) wild rabbit, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7680849", "date": "2020-08-15 17:00:47", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA: (WYOMING) WILD RABBIT, ALERT\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Aug 2020\nSource: KGAB News [edited]\nhttps://kgab.com/rabbit-in-laramie-county-tests-positive-for-tularemia/\n\n\nA rabbit in Laramie County has tested positive for tularemia, health officials announced Thursday [13 Aug 2020]. The animal was found in Hillsdale, according to the Cheyenne-Laramie County Health Department.\n\nTularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is a rare infectious disease that typically attacks the skin, eyes, lymph nodes and lungs. The disease mainly affects rabbits and rodents, but it can also affect humans and pets.\n\nPeople can become infected in several ways, including through tick and deer fly bites and skin contact with infected animals. Tularemia can be life-threatening, but most infections can be treated successfully with antibiotics.\n\n[Byline: Joy Greenwald]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _Francisella tularensis subsp. Tularemia can be life-threatening, but most infections can be treated successfully with antibiotics. \n\n The animal was found in Hillsdale, according to the Cheyenne-Laramie County Health Department.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hillsdale", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Laramie County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7757997", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Ukraine: (KS) hare, 1st rep, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7757997", "date": "2020-09-08 12:48:24", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - UKRAINE: (KHERSON) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 7 Sep 2020\nSource: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2020; 33(37) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=35674\n\n\nTularemia, Ukraine\n------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 7 Sep 2020 from Dr Olga Shevchenko, Deputy Head, State Service of Ukraine on Food Safety and Consumer Protection, Ministry of Agrarian Policy and Food of Ukraine, Kyiv, Ukraine\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 14 Aug 2020\nDate of confirmation of the event: 4 Sep 2020\nReport date: 7 Sep 2020\nDate event resolved: 4 Sep 2020\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Dudchany, Novovorontsovka, Kherson\nDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Aug 2020\nOutbreak status: resolved (4 Sep 2020)\nEpidemiological unit: forest\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 4 / 0 / 4 / 0\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nKherson Regional State Laboratory of State Service of Ukraine on Food Safety and Consumer Protection (regional laboratory)/ Brown hare (European hare) / bacterial examination / 4 Sep 2020 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. Tularemia cases in hares are also more common in the same counties where increased numbers of human cases are reported. A geographical correlation between cases of tularemia in hares and cases in humans has been observed. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of Ukraine: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/67449]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Total animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 4 / 0 / 4 / 0\n\nEpidemiology\n Summary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Dudchany, Novovorontsovka, Kherson\n Information received on [and dated] 7 Sep 2020 from Dr Olga Shevchenko, Deputy Head, State Service of Ukraine on Food Safety and Consumer Protection, Ministry of Agrarian Policy and Food of Ukraine, Kyiv, Ukraine\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\n Date event resolved: 4 Sep 2020\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease in the country\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\n Source: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2020; 33(37) [edited]\nhttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=35674\n\n\nTularemia, Ukraine\n TULAREMIA - UKRAINE: (KHERSON) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n******************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Date of confirmation of the event: 4 Sep 2020\nReport date: [The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-09-04 00:00:00", "2020-09-07 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Kyiv", "country": "Ukraine"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6677932", "headline": "PRO> Tularemia - USA (03): (CO) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6677932", "date": "2019-09-17 10:12:12", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (03): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Sep 2019\nSource: Colorado Hometown weekly [edited]\nhttps://www.coloradohometownweekly.com/2019/09/13/rabbit-found-in-lafayette-tested-positive-for-tularemia/\n\n\nA rabbit in Lafayette has tested positive for tularemia, public officials announced Friday [13 Sep 2019]. The animal was found along the 4900 block of 95th Street, according to Boulder County health officials.\n\nTularemia is caused by the bacteria _Francisella tularensis_ and is typically found in animals, especially rabbits, rodents, and hares.\n\nSymptoms in humans include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, and more. Symptoms can also include abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, and more.\n\nTularemia can be treated when detected in early stages, officials said.\n\nPeople can become infected with tularemia through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies, or through skin contact with infected animal tissue. Bacteria can also be inhaled when an infected animal is broken into small particles and spread through the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.\n\n'It's always important to avoid contact with wild animals because of the risk of many diseases,' said Lane Drager, Boulder County Public Health Consumer Protection Program coordinator, in a statement. 'Although tularemia is rare, it is still a risk, especially considering the number of wild rabbits in our communities.'\n\nFive people in Colorado have been diagnosed with tularemia in 2019. So far, 3 rabbits have been tested positive in the state.\n\nOfficials said no residents have come into contact with the animal in Lafayette, but a resident's dog did. Officials said the resident took appropriate measures when collecting the rabbit.\n\nPublic officials recommend the following precautions:\n- Stay out of areas inhabited by wild rabbits and rodents. If you must enter areas frequented by wild animals, always wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n- Prevent your pets from hunting or eating wild rodents or rabbits.\n- Avoid all contact with wild rabbits and rodents, including squirrels; do not feed or handle them.\n- Never touch sick or dead animals with your bare hands. If an animal must be moved, place it in a garbage bag using a long-handled shovel, and place the bag in an outdoor garbage can.\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes; keep your pets from doing the same.\n- Don't mow over animal carcasses, and consider using a dust mask when doing landscape work.\n- Avoid ticks. The best protection for pets, especially cats, is to keep them indoors. If outdoors with pets, keep them out of heavily wooded areas, which are ideal habitats for ticks.\n- See a healthcare provider if you become ill with a high fever and/or swollen lymph nodes.\n- Contact a veterinarian if your pet becomes ill with a high fever and/or swollen lymph nodes.\n\nFor more information about tularemia, visit http://cdc.gov/tularemia or http://boco.org/Tularemia. You can also call Boulder County Public Health to report a rabbit die-off.\n\n[Byline: Kristina Pritchett]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The bacterium that causes tularemia is highly infectious and can enter the human body through the skin, eyes, mouth, or lungs. Symptoms of infection vary depending on the route of entry. Usual sources of infection are described below. Transmission of tularemia from person to person has not been reported.\n\nFrom the CDC Tularemia webpage:\n\nSigns and symptoms\nThe signs and symptoms of tularemia vary depending on how the bacteria enter the body. Illness ranges from mild to life-threatening. All forms are accompanied by fever, which can be as high as 104 deg F/ 40 deg C. Main forms of this disease are listed below:\n\n- Ulceroglandular: This is the most common form of tularemia and usually occurs following a tick or deer fly bite or after handing of an infected animal. A skin ulcer appears at the site where the bacteria entered the body. The ulcer is accompanied by swelling of regional lymph glands, usually in the armpit or groin.\n- Glandular: Similar to ulceroglandular tularemia but without an ulcer. Also generally acquired through the bite of an infected tick or deer fly or from handling sick or dead animals.\n- Oculoglandular: This form occurs when the bacteria enter through the eye. This can occur when a person is butchering an infected animal and touches his or her eyes. Symptoms include irritation and inflammation of the eye and swelling of lymph glands in front of the ear.\n- Oropharyngeal: This form results from eating or drinking contaminated food or water. Patients with oropharyngeal tularemia may have sore throat, mouth ulcers, tonsillitis, and swelling of lymph glands in the neck.\n- Pneumonic: This is the most serious form of tularemia. Symptoms include cough, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. This form results from breathing dusts or aerosols containing the organism. It can also occur when other forms of tularemia (e.g., ulceroglandular) are left untreated and the bacteria spread through the bloodstream to the lungs.\n- Typhoidal: This form is characterized by any combination of the general symptoms (without the localizing symptoms of other syndromes).\n\nTularemia can be difficult to diagnose. It is a rare disease, and the symptoms can be mistaken for other, more common, illnesses. For this reason, it is important to share with your healthcare provider any likely exposures, such as tick and deer fly bites or contact with sick or dead animals.\n\nBlood tests and cultures can help confirm the diagnosis. Antibiotics used to treat tularemia include streptomycin, gentamicin, doxycycline, and ciprofloxacin. Treatment usually lasts 10-21 days depending on the stage of illness and the medication used. Although symptoms may last for several weeks, most patients completely recover.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ is highly infectious when grown in culture, and laboratory-acquired infections have been documented. The isolation of _F. tularensis_ from clinical specimens, especially if unanticipated, can generate concern among laboratory workers about possible exposure.\n\nManagement options for potentially exposed workers include a 'fever watch' or antimicrobial prophylaxis. During a fever watch, workers monitor their temperature with instructions to seek immediate treatment for tularemia if they develop a fever (usually defined as a single oral temperature above 101 deg F or 38.5 deg C).\n\nThere are no set criteria for determining who should be managed by fever watch and who would benefit from immediate prophylaxis.\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/\n\nColorado health officials have recorded 11 human cases of tularemia since May2015, putting the state on pace for one of the most widespread years for the disease in more than 2 decades.\n\nIn 2014, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment recorded 16 human cases, representing the 2nd-highest number of cases since 1983, when there were 20.\nhttps://www.denverpost.com/2015/06/24/colorado-health-officials-tularemia-cases-on-record-breaking-pace/\n\nSo while we may not know the number for this year [2019], 3 in a short period of time clearly indicates we need to be aware of situations representing potential exposure. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLafayette, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34735]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nFrom the CDC Tularemia webpage:\n\nSigns and symptoms\n \n\nPeople can become infected with tularemia through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies, or through skin contact with infected animal tissue. TULAREMIA - USA (03): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\n \n\nPublic officials recommend the following precautions:\n- Stay out of areas inhabited by wild rabbits and rodents. \n\nTularemia is caused by the bacteria _Francisella tularensis_ and is typically found in animals, especially rabbits, rodents, and hares. \n\nSymptoms in humans include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, and more. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The bacterium that causes tularemia is highly infectious and can enter the human body through the skin, eyes, mouth, or lungs. Source: Colorado Hometown weekly [edited]\nhttps://www.coloradohometownweekly.com/2019/09/13/rabbit-found-in-lafayette-tested-positive-for-tularemia/\n\n\nA rabbit in Lafayette has tested positive for tularemia, public officials announced Friday [13 Sep 2019]. https://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/\n\nColorado health officials have recorded 11 human cases of tularemia since May2015, putting the state on pace for one of the most widespread years for the disease in more than 2 decades. During a fever watch, workers monitor their temperature with instructions to seek immediate treatment for tularemia if they develop a fever (usually defined as a single oral temperature above 101 deg F or 38.5 deg C). \n- Contact a veterinarian if your pet becomes ill with a high fever and/or swollen lymph nodes. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< This is the most common form of tularemia and usually occurs following a tick or deer fly bite or after handing of an infected animal. All forms are accompanied by fever, which can be as high as 104 deg F/ 40 deg C. Main forms of this disease are listed below:\n\n- Ulceroglandular: TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\n \n- Avoid all contact with wild rabbits and rodents, including squirrels; do not feed or handle them. [Byline: Kristina Pritchett]\n\n--\n \n\nTularemia can be treated when detected in early stages, officials said. In 2014, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment recorded 16 human cases, representing the 2nd-highest number of cases since 1983, when there were 20.\n \n\nFive people in Colorado have been diagnosed with tularemia in 2019. \n\nThere are no set criteria for determining who should be managed by fever watch and who would benefit from immediate prophylaxis. \n- Don't mow over animal carcasses, and consider using a dust mask when doing landscape work. \n- Never touch sick or dead animals with your bare hands. \n\nTularemia can be difficult to diagnose. Although tularemia is rare, it is still a risk, especially considering the number of wild rabbits in our communities.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-09-13 00:00:00", "1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lafayette", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6732811", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden (07): Eurosurveillance report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6732811", "date": "2019-10-17 17:32:30", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (07): EUROSURVEILLANCE REPORT\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 17 Oct 2019\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttps://www.eurosurveillance.org/content/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.42.1900603?emailalert=true\n\n\nCitation:\nDryselius R, Hjertqvist M, Makitalo S, Lindblom A, Lilja T, Eklof D, Lindstrom A. Large outbreak of tularaemia, central Sweden, July to September 2019. Euro Surveill. 2019; 24(42): pii=1900603. https://doi.org/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.42.1900603.\n\nIn 2019, Sweden is experiencing its largest outbreak of tularemia in over 50 years. The outbreak started in July [2019], and as at 6 Oct 2019, a total of 979 cases have been reported. Here, we report the demographic features of cases and geographical distribution of the outbreak. We also provide evidence that the predominant route of transmission is via mosquito bites and want to make visitors aware of risks in endemic areas.\n\nIdentification of the outbreak\n-----------------------\nIn the last week of July 2019, the county medical officer (CMO) of Gavleborg county, central Sweden, received information from healthcare providers about an increasing number of people visiting healthcare centers with fever and presenting swollen inguinal and axillary lymph nodes. By 31 Jul 2019, there were 18 reported cases of tularemia; all were residents of or visitors to a small town in the county, Ljusdal. According to healthcare providers in Ljusdal, a majority had spent time near a lake and a golf course adjacent to the town. As a major golf competition with visitors from all over Sweden had been held between 23 and 27 Jul 2019, the CMO issued a press release on 31 Jul 2019 announcing the outbreak and put information on the Swedish national healthcare website (1177 Vardguiden) to alert healthcare in regions not used to diagnosing the disease. On 2 Aug 2019, the Swedish National Veterinary Institute (SVA) published a news item about a suspected outbreak of tularemia among hares (_Lepus_ species), as a large number of dead hares had been detected and that tularemia had been identified in hares from several locations around Sweden.\n\nDuring the 1st week of August 2019, an unusually large number of human tularemia cases were reported to the Public Health Agency of Sweden (PHAS) from other locations, mainly in neighboring counties to Gavleborg in central Sweden. On 12 Aug 2019, the PHAS published a news item on its website about the outbreak. At that time, the number of reported tularemia cases had reached over 80 in the county of Dalarna, where a major cycling competition with more than 20 000 national and international participants was taking place between 10 and 16 Aug 2019. A case definition for tularemia was as follows:\n\nTularemia case definition, Sweden\n---------------------------\nFor a confirmed case, at least one of the following 3:\n- Isolation of _Francisella tularensis_;\n- Detection of _Francisella tularensis_ nucleic acid; or\n- _Francisella tularensis_-specific antibody response\n\nFor a probable case, both of the following 2:\n- Clinical picture compatible with tularemia; and\n- Epidemiological link\n\nDescriptive epidemiology\n-----------------\nAs at week 40 2019 (6 Oct 2019), a total of 979 tularemia cases were reported to PHAS, 98% of which were registered since 24 Jul 2019, over 4 times more than the average number for the corresponding periods between 2000 and 2018 (Figure 1 [For figures and tables, see original URL. - Mod.LL]). Of the reported cases, 734 were laboratory confirmed mainly based on serology (n\u2009=\u2009404) or PCR (n\u2009=\u2009285).\n\nBetween 1 Jan and 6 Oct each year during the period 2000-2018, 4422 tularemia cases were reported, of which 2557 (58%) were male and 1865 (42%) were female, with median ages of 50 years for both sexes. A significantly larger proportion of females above the age of 50 years were infected with tularemia in 2019 compared with the period between 2000 and 2018 (chi-squared test: p less than 0.001). For 752 of 979 tularemia cases in 2019, a specific municipality could be designated as the probable place of infection based on the information given in clinical reports. Fifteen municipalities reported 10 or more cases, and 13 were located in central Sweden. In 2 municipalities, over 100 cases were reported (Figure 3).\n\nDalarna county was the most affected by the tularemia outbreak and, according to reports from healthcare centers, 268 of 326 cases (82%) had the ulceroglandular form of tularemia; information was missing for 58 cases. A similar dominance of ulceroglandular tularemia has also been reported from local healthcare centres in Gavleborg county with patients having inflamed and sometimes infected mosquito bites. There have also been 4 reports of pneumonic cases. Of 979 tularemia cases reported nationally until 6 Oct 2019, 719 (73%) had a cause of infection specified as insect bites, which is higher than the corresponding period 2000-2018 (2729/4422 cases; 62%).\n\nEnvironmental investigation and findings in wildlife\n---------------------------------------------------\nMosquitoes were collected around the golf course in Ljusdal on 15 and 16 Aug 2019. A total of 550 mosquitoes were trapped, and of those, 373 (68%) belonged to the known tularemia vector _Aedes cinereus_ (Table 1). All other species found, except _Culiseta morsitans_, have previously been shown to be implicated in tularemia transmission [1]. Mosquitoes were divided into species pools based on their trapping location; in total, there were 24 pools. Molecular analyses showed that one of 8 pools of _Aedes cinereus_ containing 103 specimens that were collected near the tee to hole 14 and known to be a particularly mosquito-infested area among golfers tested positive for _Francisella tularensis holarctica_.\n\nIn Sweden, dead hares are routinely collected and analyzed by the SVA [2]. In 2019, 54 dead hares with tularemia were collected, while the mean annual number of dead hares with tularemia between 2007 and 2018 was 9 (Figure 4).\n\nDiscussion and conclusion\n------------------------\nTularemia is caused by the highly contagious bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which can infect humans as well as more than 250 animal species [3]. Tularemia is widely spread throughout the northern hemisphere, and cases have been reported from all European countries except Iceland, Ireland, and the United Kingdom [4]. From some parts of Sweden and Finland, where tularemia occurs endemically, the highest incidence in Europe is reported [5].\n\nSweden has reported cases of endemic tularemia since 1931 [6]. There has always been a variation in the number of human cases between different years, ranging from 0 cases in 1990 to 2700 cases in 1967. During the 2000s, the number of reported cases varied from 26 in 2001 to 859 in 2015, with a resulting incidence of 0.29 and 8.72 cases per 100 000 inhabitants, respectively. However, no cyclical patterns or general trends were observed (personal communication Pontus Jureen, PHAS, 30 Sep 2019). The number of reported tularemia cases thus far in 2019 is higher than what has been reported in any single year since the end of the 1960s, and it is more than is reported from the whole of Europe during a normal year [4].\n\nHistorically, more males were reported with tularemia infection than females, with the age group 40-69 years most affected for both sexes; this pattern is seen in outbreak years as well years with a low number of reported infections (data not shown). This may be a reflection of the age distribution of people in rural areas working outdoors, e.g., doing farm and garden work [7]. In the current outbreak, a larger proportion of women aged 50 years and older has been observed, but the reasons for this deviating pattern is unknown. It is possible, for example, that with 2019 being a good mushroom year, more women in this age group were attracted to tularemia-risk areas to pick mushrooms.\n\nEver since the 1st tularemia cases were reported in 1931 until the early 1990s, the endemic area was in the northern part of central Sweden and extended along the Gulf of Bothnia [8]. Since the end of the 1990s, the geographical distribution of cases has expanded with a spread both to the west and towards the southern parts of central Sweden [9]. This expanded area has since remained endemic for tularemia and experienced larger outbreaks in its northern part in 2012 and 2015, in its central part in 2010, and in its southern part in 2000 and 2003. An expansion of the endemic area further south is not unlikely in the future, supported by the numerous dead hares with tularemia detected up to September 2019 by SVA, where at least 8 had been found in Gotaland located south of the endemic area [10].\n\nTularemia can be transmitted to humans through arthropod vectors, direct contact with infected animals, or by inhalation of contaminated dust. Due to the mode of transmission, different clinical forms are distinguished. In neighboring Norway and elsewhere in Europe, ingestion of contaminated water from streams, ponds, lakes, and rivers is the main mode of infection [4,11]. In Sweden, however, most cases are infected by mosquito bites, but transmission by ticks and rain flies also occurs [12]. Typically, mosquito-transmitted ulceroglandular tularemia starts to become evident late July or August, reaching a peak at the end of August or in September before declining up to December. Large mosquito populations are a risk factor for outbreaks of tularemia [13]. In this outbreak, the time of onset of symptoms in cases, e.g., reports of ulceroglandular tularemia plus inflamed or infected mosquito bites, suggests that the predominant mode of transmission was via mosquitoes. This is supported by the detection of _Francisella tularensis_ in the mosquito species _Aedes cinereus_ near the golf course in Ljusdal. The weather conditions in 2019, with a relatively wet spring and a mild summer and autumn, may have resulted in a favorable year for mosquito populations, meaning that transmission of tularemia between mosquitoes and their host animals may have been longer and more favorable than normal. However, it was not possible to investigate this further, as mosquito densities in high-risk areas are not monitored, nor are the populations of potential animal hosts. Interestingly, however, the outbreaks of tularemia in central Sweden in 2003 and 2010 and in northern Sweden in 2012 and 2015 were all preceded by wetter springs than normal in the high-risk areas.\n\nAs at 14 Oct 2019, the number of new cases of tularemia has dropped drastically, returning to average seasonal levels for the previous 3 weeks. However, due to the unusually high number of cases concentrated to areas with large numbers of external visitors, the 2019 tularemia outbreak has prompted intense communication between local and central authorities and attracted a great deal of media attention in Sweden. With this rapid communication, we aim to raise awareness for the risk of contracting tularemia through mosquito bites in endemic areas in Sweden and to raise awareness regarding protective measures such as wearing covering clothing and use of insect repellent. We also aim to raise awareness of tularemia among healthcare providers in non-endemic areas, as they may encounter patients who have acquired tularemia infection visiting high-risk areas such as in central and northern Sweden.\n\nReferences\n-----------\n1. Outbreaks of tularemia in a boreal forest region depends on mosquito prevalence. J Infect Dis. 2012; 205(2): 297-304. https://doi.org/10.1093/infdis/jir732. PMID: 22124130.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Eurosurveillance report nicely summarizes this large outbreak of _F. tularensis_, primarily spread through infected mosquitoes. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "For a confirmed case, at least one of the following 3:\n- Isolation of _Francisella tularensis_;\n- Detection of _Francisella tularensis_ nucleic acid; or\n- _Francisella tularensis_-specific antibody response\n\nFor a probable case, both of the following 2:\n- Clinical picture compatible with tularemia; and\n- Epidemiological link\n\nDescriptive epidemiology\n As at week 40 2019 (6 Oct 2019), a total of 979 tularemia cases were reported to PHAS, 98% of which were registered since 24 Jul 2019, over 4 times more than the average number for the corresponding periods between 2000 and 2018 (Figure 1 [For figures and tables, see original URL. \n\nDalarna county was the most affected by the tularemia outbreak and, according to reports from healthcare centers, 268 of 326 cases (82%) had the ulceroglandular form of tularemia; information was missing for 58 cases. The number of reported tularemia cases thus far in 2019 is higher than what has been reported in any single year since the end of the 1960s, and it is more than is reported from the whole of Europe during a normal year [4]. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Of 979 tularemia cases reported nationally until 6 Oct 2019, 719 (73%) had a cause of infection specified as insect bites, which is higher than the corresponding period 2000-2018 (2729/4422 cases; 62%). On 2 Aug 2019, the Swedish National Veterinary Institute (SVA) published a news item about a suspected outbreak of tularemia among hares (_Lepus_ species), as a large number of dead hares had been detected and that tularemia had been identified in hares from several locations around Sweden. However, due to the unusually high number of cases concentrated to areas with large numbers of external visitors, the 2019 tularemia outbreak has prompted intense communication between local and central authorities and attracted a great deal of media attention in Sweden. In 2019, 54 dead hares with tularemia were collected, while the mean annual number of dead hares with tularemia between 2007 and 2018 was 9 (Figure 4). At that time, the number of reported tularemia cases had reached over 80 in the county of Dalarna, where a major cycling competition with more than 20 000 national and international participants was taking place between 10 and 16 Aug 2019. During the 1st week of August 2019, an unusually large number of human tularemia cases were reported to the Public Health Agency of Sweden (PHAS) from other locations, mainly in neighboring counties to Gavleborg in central Sweden. We also aim to raise awareness of tularemia among healthcare providers in non-endemic areas, as they may encounter patients who have acquired tularemia infection visiting high-risk areas such as in central and northern Sweden. Historically, more males were reported with tularemia infection than females, with the age group 40-69 years most affected for both sexes; this pattern is seen in outbreak years as well years with a low number of reported infections (data not shown). A case definition for tularemia was as follows:\n\nTularemia case definition, Sweden\n Source: Eurosurveillance [edited]\nhttps://www.eurosurveillance.org/content/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2019.24.42.1900603?emailalert=true\n\n\nCitation:\nDryselius R, Hjertqvist M, Makitalo S, Lindblom A, Lilja T, Eklof D, Lindstrom A. Large outbreak of tularaemia, central Sweden, July to September 2019. \n\nBetween 1 Jan and 6 Oct each year during the period 2000-2018, 4422 tularemia cases were reported, of which 2557 (58%) were male and 1865 (42%) The outbreak started in July [2019], and as at 6 Oct 2019, a total of 979 cases have been reported. In this outbreak, the time of onset of symptoms in cases, e.g., reports of ulceroglandular tularemia plus inflamed or infected mosquito bites, suggests that the predominant mode of transmission was via mosquitoes. By 31 Jul 2019, there were 18 reported cases of tularemia; all were residents of or visitors to a small town in the county, Ljusdal. An expansion of the endemic area further south is not unlikely in the future, supported by the numerous dead hares with tularemia detected up to September 2019 by SVA, where at least 8 had been found in Gotaland located south of the endemic area [10]. For 752 of 979 tularemia cases in 2019, a specific municipality could be designated as the probable place of infection based on the information given in clinical reports. Ever since the 1st tularemia cases were reported in 1931 until the early 1990s, the endemic area was in the northern part of central Sweden and extended along the Gulf of Bothnia [8]. As at 14 Oct 2019, the number of new cases of tularemia has dropped drastically, returning to average seasonal levels for the previous 3 weeks. As a major golf competition with visitors from all over Sweden had been held between 23 and 27 Jul 2019, the CMO issued a press release on 31 Jul 2019 announcing the outbreak and put information on the Swedish national healthcare website (1177 Vardguiden) to alert healthcare in regions not used to diagnosing the disease. \n\nSweden has reported cases of endemic tularemia since 1931 [6]. The weather conditions in 2019, with a relatively wet spring and a mild summer and autumn, may have resulted in a favorable year for mosquito populations, meaning that transmission of tularemia between mosquitoes and their host animals may have been longer and more favorable than normal. A significantly larger proportion of females above the age of 50 years were infected with tularemia in 2019 compared with the period between 2000 and 2018 (chi-squared test: p less than 0.001). There has always been a variation in the number of human cases between different years, ranging from 0 cases in 1990 to 2700 cases in 1967. A similar dominance of ulceroglandular tularemia has also been reported from local healthcare centres in Gavleborg county with patients having inflamed and sometimes infected mosquito bites. During the 2000s, the number of reported cases varied from 26 in 2001 to 859 in 2015, with a resulting incidence of 0.29 and 8.72 cases per 100 000 inhabitants, respectively. ------------------------\nTularemia is caused by the highly contagious bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which can infect humans as well as more than 250 animal species [3]. It is possible, for example, that with 2019 being a good mushroom year, more women in this age group were attracted to tularemia-risk areas to pick mushrooms. With this rapid communication, we aim to raise awareness for the risk of contracting tularemia through mosquito bites in endemic areas in Sweden and to raise awareness regarding protective measures such as wearing covering clothing and use of insect repellent. In the last week of July 2019, the county medical officer (CMO) of Gavleborg county, central Sweden, received information from healthcare providers about an increasing number of people visiting healthcare centers with fever and presenting swollen inguinal and axillary lymph nodes. Tularemia is widely spread throughout the northern hemisphere, and cases have been reported from all European countries except Iceland, Ireland, and the United Kingdom [4]. In 2019, Sweden is experiencing its largest outbreak of tularemia in over 50 years. This expanded area has since remained endemic for tularemia and experienced larger outbreaks in its northern part in 2012 and 2015, in its central part in 2010, and in its southern part in 2000 and 2003. Interestingly, however, the outbreaks of tularemia in central Sweden in 2003 and 2010 and in northern Sweden in 2012 and 2015 were all preceded by wetter springs than normal in the high-risk areas. TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (07): EUROSURVEILLANCE REPORT\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nTularemia can be transmitted to humans through arthropod vectors, direct contact with infected animals, or by inhalation of contaminated dust. Of the reported cases, 734 were laboratory confirmed mainly based on serology (n\u2009=\u2009404) or PCR (n\u2009=\u2009285). \n\nIdentification of the outbreak\n Date: Thu 17 Oct 2019\n Fifteen municipalities reported 10 or more cases, and 13 were located in central Sweden. Large mosquito populations are a risk factor for outbreaks of tularemia [13]. From some parts of Sweden and Finland, where tularemia occurs endemically, the highest incidence in Europe is reported [5]. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108] In Sweden, however, most cases are infected by mosquito bites, but transmission by ticks and rain flies also occurs [12]. Typically, mosquito-transmitted ulceroglandular tularemia starts to become evident late July or August, reaching a peak at the end of August or in September before declining up to December. \n\nEnvironmental investigation and findings in wildlife\n In 2 municipalities, over 100 cases were reported (Figure 3). A total of 550 mosquitoes were trapped, and of those, 373 (68%) belonged to the known tularemia vector _Aedes cinereus_ (Table 1). Since the end of the 1990s, the geographical distribution of cases has expanded with a spread both to the west and towards the southern parts of central Sweden [9]. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This Eurosurveillance report nicely summarizes this large outbreak of _F. tularensis_, primarily spread through infected mosquitoes.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-08-02 00:00:00", "2019-08-12 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-10-14 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "1865-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "1440-02-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1931-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1177-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-09-30 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-09 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dalarna county", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Forsman M", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gotaland", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Iceland", "country": "Iceland"}, {"location": "Ljusdal", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Karta", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Dalarna", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "Norway"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6622351", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden (02): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6622351", "date": "2019-08-14 14:12:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (02): ALERT\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Aug 2019 16:01 CEST +02:00\nSource: The Local [edited]\nhttps://www.thelocal.se/20190812/rabbit-fever-hundreds-infected-as-outbreak-grows-in-sweden\n\n\nSwedish health authorities have warned an outbreak of rabbit fever (tularemia) is expected to grow, with hundreds of people affected so far.\n\nA total of 212 confirmed cases have been reported to The Public Health Agency of Sweden (Folkhallsomyndigheten) so far in 2019, sharply increasing from late July 2019. That is twice as many as in a normal year.\n\nBut Sweden has not yet seen the end of it, the authority warned on [Mon 12 Aug 2019]. 'Since the number of cases (of rabbit fever) is usually at its highest in September, the outbreak is expected to grow further in the coming weeks,' it wrote in a statement.\n\nMost cases have been reported in Dalarna, Gavleborg, and Orebro counties in central Sweden, but in the past week Vasterbotten and Norrbotten have also seen an increase, often limited to a specific area.\n\nMany of those affected by the disease have been infected via mosquito bites.\n\n[Byline: Emma Loefgren]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares). Wild rodents are also frequently infected, and occurrence of human cases is usually linked to these host species. _F. tularensis_ is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ naturally infects several mammalian wildlife species in northern Europe, in particular, mice, rabbits, hares, beavers, voles, lemmings, and muskrats. The ticks _Dermacentor reticularis_ and _Ixodes ricinus_ are vectors for the bacterium, although previous research has suggested that mosquito bites are the most frequent route of transmission to humans in Sweden.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread via contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors.\n\nThe manifestations of infection in this growing outbreak in parts of Sweden are not stated. If vector borne, the most common form would be ulceroglandular with an ulcer at the introduction site and enlarged lymph nodes in that area. If waterborne, oropharyngeal would be most common. Among flying vectors, deer flies are often brought up but mosquitoes are also relevant as shown in this Swedish publication:\n\nThelaus J, Andersson A, Broman T, et al: _Francisella tularensis_ subspecies holarctica occurs in Swedish mosquitoes, persists through the developmental stages of laboratory-infected mosquitoes and is transmissible during blood feeding. Microb Ecol. 2014; 67(1): 96-107; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3907667/\n\n'Abstract\n--------\nIn Sweden, mosquitoes are considered the major vectors of the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_, which causes tularemia. The aim of this study was to investigate whether mosquitoes acquire the bacterium as aquatic larvae and transmit the disease as adults. Mosquitoes sampled in a Swedish area where tularemia is endemic (Orebro) were positive for the presence of _F. tularensis_ deoxyribonucleic acid throughout the summer. Presence of the clinically relevant _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_ was confirmed in 11 out of the 14 mosquito species sampled. Experiments performed using laboratory-reared _Aedes aegypti_ confirmed that _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_ was transstadially maintained from orally infected larvae to adult mosquitoes and that 25% of the adults exposed as larvae were positive for the presence of _F. tularensis_-specific sequences for at least 2 weeks. In addition, we found that _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_ was transmitted to 58% of the adult mosquitoes feeding on diseased mice. In a small-scale in vivo transmission experiment with _F. tularensis_ subsp. _holarctica_-positive adult mosquitoes and susceptible mice, none of the animals developed tularemia. However, we confirmed that there was transmission of the bacterium to blood vials by mosquitoes that had been exposed to the bacterium in the larval stage. Taken together, these results provide evidence that mosquitoes play a role in disease transmission in part of Sweden where tularemia recurs.'\n- Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Sweden:\nhttp://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/europe/Swedish-political-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "Among flying vectors, deer flies are often brought up but mosquitoes are also relevant as shown in this Swedish publication:\n\nThelaus J, Andersson A, Broman T, et al: _Francisella tularensis_ subspecies holarctica occurs in Swedish mosquitoes, persists through the developmental stages of laboratory-infected mosquitoes and is transmissible during blood feeding. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread via contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. _holarctica_ was transstadially maintained from orally infected larvae to adult mosquitoes and that 25% of the adults exposed as larvae were positive for the presence of _F. tularensis_-specific sequences for at least 2 weeks. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. \n\nA total of 212 confirmed cases have been reported to The Public Health Agency of Sweden (Folkhallsomyndigheten) so far in 2019, sharply increasing from late July 2019. \n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subspecies _ Mosquitoes sampled in a Swedish area where tularemia is endemic (Orebro) were positive for the presence of _F. tularensis_ deoxyribonucleic acid throughout the summer. In addition, the health area of rural Palencia has reported 5 cases, while Eras del Bosque and Jardinillos, in the capital, have reported 2 case.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia are not stated and it would not be surprising if oropharyngeal tularemia is occurring as this outbreak, given its size, may be waterborne.\n\nOutbreaks of water-transmitted tularemia include 64 cases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49 cases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2), an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to contamination of a water supply (3), improperly prepared water for washing in the Czech Republic (4), and a Swedish outbreak associated with a contaminated well used for drinking water (5). Additionally, during the period 1936 to 1963, there were approximately 30 outbreaks of water-borne tularemia reported from the then Soviet Union (6).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1.
