Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "Czechia"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moravkova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saldana", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Nocarova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chlumcany", "country": "Czechia"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Pazdiora P", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6612595", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden: outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6612595", "date": "2019-08-08 19:59:25", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN: OUTBREAK\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Aug 2019, 10:47 AM CEST\nSource: The Local SE [edited]\nhttps://www.thelocal.se/20190807/harpest-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-mosquito-borne-disease\n\n\nThere have been several reported cases of tularemia or rabbit fever, known as 'harpest' in Sweden, this summer [2019], mostly in the north and centre of the country.\n\nThe animals most likely to carry the disease are wild hares, hence the name rabbit fever, and rodents, but it can also be transferred to humans via mosquito bites and occasionally tick bites. It's also possible for the infection to be transmitted by inhaling dust or drinking water that is contaminated by urine or feces from animals with the disease, according to Swedish healthcare service 1177. The disease cannot be carried from human to human.\n\nIt is too early to measure the exact extent of the disease this year [2019], since statistics from the Public Health Agency won't be available until later. But the Swedish Veterinary Institute has warned of several findings of dead animals that had been infected with the disease, and a 'suspected outbreak'.\n\nA total of 33 people in the Gavleborg region have been affected by rabbit fever since the start of July [2019], according to regional healthcare authorities. In most cases, the patients had been infected in the Ljusdal area, and one case related to a patient who became sick after cleaning out a barn.\n\nAt least 12 people have been affected by rabbit fever in the Dalarna region alone, a doctor in communicable diseases told SVT Dalarna, and he said the figure was expected to increase.\n\n'It looks like there will be a lot of cases this year [2019], more than last year [2018],' doctor Anders Lindblom said, adding: 'Not everyone [who is affected by rabbit fever] seeks medical care and reports the illness.'\n\nAt least a further 5 people have confirmed cases of rabbit fever in Norrbotten too. Sweden had a large outbreak of rabbit fever in 2015, when 859 people across the country suffered from the illness, the majority of them in Norrbotten and Vasterbotten. In 2018, 107 cases were reported across Sweden, with Dalarna the most severely affected region.\n\nSymptoms of rabbit fever typically begin with swelling or tenderness in the lymph node and a skin lesion at the site of any bite or direct contact, followed occasionally by symptoms that can include a skin rash, nausea, and headaches.\n\nThe best way to protect yourself from infection is to avoid mosquito bites as much as possible (either by using repellents, or wearing long, loose clothing when going outside between dusk and dawn), and being especially careful if you need to touch a dead animal such as a rodent or hare, using precautions such as a face mask and gloves.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares). Wild rodents are also frequently infected, and occurrence of human cases is usually linked to these host species. _F. tularensis_ is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ naturally infects several mammalian wildlife species in northern Europe, in particular, mice, rabbits, hares, beavers, voles, lemmings, and muskrats. The ticks _Dermacentor reticularis_ and _Ixodes ricinus_ are vectors for the bacterium, although previous research has suggested that mosquito bites are the most frequent route of transmission to humans in Sweden.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread via contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[Tularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSweden: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'It looks like there will be a lot of cases this year [2019], more than last year [2018],' doctor Anders Lindblom said, adding: 'Not everyone [who is affected by rabbit fever] seeks medical care and reports the illness.' \n\nSymptoms of rabbit fever typically begin with swelling or tenderness in the lymph node and a skin lesion at the site of any bite or direct contact, followed occasionally by symptoms that can include a skin rash, nausea, and headaches. \n\nA total of 33 people in the Gavleborg region have been affected by rabbit fever since the start of July [2019], according to regional healthcare authorities. The animals most likely to carry the disease are wild hares, hence the name rabbit fever, and rodents, but it can also be transferred to humans via mosquito bites and occasionally tick bites. \n\nThe best way to protect yourself from infection is to avoid mosquito bites as much as possible (either by using repellents, or wearing long, loose clothing when going outside between dusk and dawn), and being especially careful if you need to touch a dead animal such as a rodent or hare, using precautions such as a face mask and gloves. In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread via contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nAt least 12 people have been affected by rabbit fever in the Dalarna region alone, a doctor in communicable diseases told SVT Dalarna, and he said the figure was expected to increase. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. \n\nAt least a further 5 people have confirmed cases of rabbit fever in Norrbotten too. \n\n\nThere have been several reported cases of tularemia or rabbit fever, known as 'harpest' in Sweden, this summer [2019], mostly in the north and centre of the country. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "1177-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Norrbotten", "country": "Sweden"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6618402", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (02): (CO) wild rabbit, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6618402", "date": "2019-08-12 13:08:55", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT, ALERT\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 9 Aug 2019 8:22 PM MDT\nSource: Loveland Reporter Herald [edited]\nhttps://www.reporterherald.com/2019/08/09/tularemia-found-in-rabbit-in-northern-larimer-county/\n\n\nThe Larimer County Department of Health and Environment reported Friday [9 Aug 2019] that tularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever,' has been found in a rabbit in northern Larimer County.\n\nTularemia-causing bacteria from the droppings or urine of sick animals, usually rabbits, can contaminate soil and spread the disease, according to a news release from the health department.\n\nA recent die-off of rabbits suggested a possible tularemia outbreak among the animals in that area, the agency said.\n\n'Because tularemia is naturally occurring in Larimer County, precautions should always be taken to prevent infection, public health director Tom Gonzales said in the release. 'It is important to keep children and pets away from wild animals.'\n\nIn recent years, most human tularemia cases along the Front Range have been attributed to activities involving soil and vegetation, the health department said. The county has seen 18 human cases since 2009; 35 animals have tested positive for the disease since 2009.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted to people who handle infected animals; from the bite of infected insects (most commonly ticks and deer flies); by exposure to contaminated food, water, or soil; by eating, drinking, putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth before washing after outdoor activities; by direct contact with breaks in the skin; or by inhaling particles carrying the bacteria (through mowing or blowing vegetation and excavating soil).\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans may include fever, chills, headache, swollen and painful lymph glands and fatigue.\n\nTularemia can be treated with antibiotics, and the health department recommended anyone with any of these early signs seek medical attention as soon as possible.\n\nThe agency also advises people wear gloves when gardening; wear dust masks when mowing or blowing vegetation or moving soil; wear insect repellent to deter biting insects; wear shoes on grassy lawns; and never touch dead animals with bare hands.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298. The child had always been previously in good health.\n\nA tick bit her at the left shoulder, during a trip to a Dutch island was reported in June 2019. The tick was completely removed the following day, but she developed fever and rash 2 days later. No other signs or symptoms followed until 15 Jul 2019 (approx. 30 days after the tick bite) a supraclavicular swelling appeared. This initially showed intact skin, but progressive increased in size and the overlying skin developed hyperemia. Three days after latter a left axillary swelling occurred as well. Since the child was temporarily in Italy, she was admitted at the Meyer Children's University Hospital in Florence.\n\nSerology test for tularemia carried out at Meyer Children's Hospital and at Careggi Hospital in Florence were both positive. The molecular test carried out at the Microbiology Laboratory of the National Institute for Infectious Diseases 'L. Spallanzani' in Rome detected the presence of _Francisella tularensis_ in surgical drainage. Further microbiological and molecular investigations are ongoing.\n\n--\nLuisa Galli, Leila Bianchi, Antonella Vulcano and Barbara Bartolini\nPaediatric Infectious Diseases Unit Meyer Children's University Hospital\nand\nMicrobiology Laboratory, National Institute for Infectious Diseases 'L. Spallanzani'\nRome\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Bartolini and colleagues for this 1st hand report.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the glandular, ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nItaly: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75\nNetherlands: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/104]", "summary": "\n\n--\nLuisa Galli, Leila Bianchi, Antonella Vulcano and Barbara Bartolini\nPaediatric Infectious Diseases Unit Meyer Children's University Hospital\nand\nMicrobiology Laboratory, National Institute for Infectious Diseases 'L. 'People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals such as rabbits or rodents or are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies. Provide your own protection against insect bites and improve your pet's safety by not letting them roam loose or scavenge rodents.'\n\nTularemia is a rare infection caused by the bacteria _Francisella tularensis_ that can spread through insect bites, with deer flies and ticks being the primary vectors in New Mexico. It can also be spread through handling infected animal tissues in situations such as hunting, trapping and skinning of rabbits or other rodents or during the clean-up of rodent carcasses while gardening.\n\nDogs and cats can be infected if they are allowed to roam and scavenge dead animals or are not protected from tick bites. Tularemia can also make dogs and cats sick: If they are not diagnosed and treated by their veterinarian, they can give the disease to people. Direct inoculation from an animal bite is very rare but can occur if the animal is infected.\n\nTularemia symptoms in people may include sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscles aches and joint pain. Other symptoms may include swollen and painful lymph glands especially in the anatomical region where the bacteria 1st gained entry into the body.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The clinical manifestations of tularemia in these 2 cases are not stated.\n\nTularemia is a bacterial infection that affects, aside from people, more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles and fish. It is listed as a category A bioterrorism agent because of the potential for fatality, airborne dissemination, and societal disruption if released. The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-spore-forming, Gram negative coccobacillus antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n'Tularemia can cause serious illness in both people and pets, so I would encourage people in Santa Fe County to follow precautions to avoid getting infected,' said Department of Health cabinet secretary, Kathy Kunkel. ' \n\nTularemia is a rare infection caused by the bacteria _Francisella tularensis_ that can spread through insect bites, with deer flies and ticks being the primary vectors in New Mexico. People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals such as rabbits or rodents or are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies. \n\nDogs and cats can be infected if they are allowed to roam and scavenge dead animals or are not protected from tick bites. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors. \n\nTularemia is a bacterial infection that affects, aside from people, more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles and fish.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6611184", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain: (CL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6611184", "date": "2019-08-07 18:08:09", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN: (CASTILE AND LEON)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 6 Aug 2019\nSource: Cope [in Spanish, machine trans. edited]\nhttps://www.cope.es/emisoras/castilla-y-leon/palencia-provincia/palencia/noticias/ascienden-los-casos-confirmados-tularemia-palencia-20190806_474318\n\n\nThe leaders of Castile and Leon, through its territorial delegation in Palencia, has confirmed that as of yesterday, 5 Aug 2019, there are already 16 cases of tularemia in the province. There are 29 other probable cases that are under study.\n\nAccording to the last part issued from the regional administration, the detection of 3 other cases in Paredes de Nava is underway. Two cases that have been detected have occurred in the area of Palencia Rural and Saldana. In all of them it is stated that tularemia is due to environmental exposure, and none of them have required hospitalization.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in these cases are not stated.\n\nVoles (http://www.voles.com/) are likely to be the reservoir here. They are often called meadow mice, or field mice, and occupy a wide variety of habitats, depending on the species. Generally, voles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants, or litter. They are active both day and night and throughout the year. Voles eat a variety of plants and animals. They frequently forage on grasses, forbs, roots, bulbs, tubers, bark, snails, and insects. To find food, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow openings. Several adults and young can live in these runway systems. This intricate network of tunnels and burrows provides voles with excellent shelter from the weather and protection from predators. Voles store seeds and other plant matter in underground chambers. A picture of a vole can be found at http://news-service.stanford.edu/news/2004/september22/gifs/Yellowstone_vole.jpg.\n\nPalencia is a province of northern Spain, in the northern part of the autonomous community of Castile and Leon in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula. It is bordered by the provinces of Leon, Cantabria, Burgos, and Valladolid. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nPalencia, Castille and Le\u00f3n, Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16299]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n TULAREMIA - SPAIN: (CASTILE AND LEON)\n*************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nPalencia, Castille and Le\u00f3n, Spain: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16299] \n\n--\n The leaders of Castile and Leon, through its territorial delegation in Palencia, has confirmed that as of yesterday, 5 Aug 2019, there are already 16 cases of tularemia in the province. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in these cases are not stated. \n\nPalencia is a province of northern Spain, in the northern part of the autonomous community of Castile and Leon in the northwest of the Iberian Peninsula. Date: Tue 6 Aug 2019\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cantabria", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Valladolid", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Leon", "country": "Nicaragua"}, {"location": "Palencia Rural", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Le\u00f3n", "country": "Nicaragua"}, {"location": "Burgos", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6620535", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain (02): (CL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6620535", "date": "2019-08-13 16:45:45", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN (02): (CASTILE AND LEON)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Aug 2019\nSource: La Vanguardia [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.lavanguardia.com/vida/20190812/464008536428/se-elevan-a-23-las-personas-afectadas-por-tularemia-en-provincia-de-palencia.html\n\n\nThe detection of 3 new cases of tularemia in Villarramiel, Osorno and Palencia, brings to 23 the number of people affected by this disease associated with the overpopulation of voles in the province of Palencia, where they are studying 32 other possible cases.\n\nThe Epidemiology Surveillance Network of the Junta de Castilla y Le\u00f3n confirmed on [Mon 12 Aug 2019] 3 new cases of tularemia in the province of Palencia, where 23 people have been affected since 3 Jul 2019, as reported by the territorial delegation of the Board in Palencia. The last confirmed cases have been detected in the Palencia towns of; Villarramiel, where there are already 4 people affected by tularemia; the basic health area of rural Palencia where the 2nd case has been detected; and Osorno, which recorded the 1st confirmed case of this sickness.\n\nIn total, the Epidemiology Surveillance Network has confirmed 12 cases of tularemia so far in August [2019] were added to the 11 confirmed throughout the month of July [2019]. The most affected localities are Paredes de Nava, with 11 confirmed cases, and Villarramiel with 4, while the basic areas of Salda\u00f1a, Palencia and Cervera de Pisuerga have confirmed 2 cases each and Villada and Osorno a single case in each locality. Only one of the people affected, in Cervera de Pisuerga, has needed hospital admission but has already been discharged.\n\nIn addition there are 32 other suspicious cases that are being studied while an active search for this disease, associated with overpopulation of voles, continues.\n\nThe Health Service does not expressly cite the overpopulation of voles that are currently in the province of Palencia, mainly in the region of Tierra de Campos, as a cause of this disease and points out that 'environmental exposure could be the main factor.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia are not stated and it would not be surprising if oropharyngeal tularemia is occurring as this outbreak, given its size, may be waterborne.\n\nOutbreaks of water-transmitted tularemia include 64 cases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49 cases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2), an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to contamination of a water supply (3), improperly prepared water for washing in the Czech Republic (4), and a Swedish outbreak associated with a contaminated well used for drinking water (5). Additionally, during the period 1936 to 1963, there were approximately 30 outbreaks of water-borne tularemia reported from the then Soviet Union (6).\n\nReferences:\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: [Outbreak of tularemia in the Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl):68-72. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=12718181\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, Ninu E, Lamanna A and Luzi S.l: A waterborne tularemia outbreak. Eur J Epidemiol 1987; 3:35-8. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=3582597\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: [An epidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk Province. Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol] 1997; 2:33-7. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=9245138\n4. Pazdiora P, Mor\u00e1vkov\u00e1 I, Nocarov\u00e1 D, Velkoborsk\u00e1 M and Valeckov\u00e1 K: [A water-borne epidemic of tularemia in Chlumcany] Epidemiol Mikrobiol Imunol. 2002; 51:23-5. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=11881296\n5. Tarnvik A1, Sandstrom G and Sjostedt A. Infrequent manifestations of tularemia in Sweden. Scand J Inf Dis. 1997; 29:443-46. Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=9435029\n[& 2003 ProMED post, ref.below]\n6. Pollitzer, R. History and incidence of tularemia in Soviet Union -- a review. Institute for Contemporary Russian Studies, Fordham University, Bronx, New York, 1967.\n- Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nCastilla y Leon: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1468]", "summary": "\n\nOutbreaks of water-transmitted tularemia include 64 cases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49 cases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2), an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to contamination of a water supply (3), improperly prepared water for washing in the Czech Republic (4), and a Swedish outbreak associated with a contaminated well used for drinking water (5). \n\nThe Health Service does not expressly cite the overpopulation of voles that are currently in the province of Palencia, mainly in the region of Tierra de Campos, as a cause of this disease and points out that 'environmental exposure could be the main factor.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The Epidemiology Surveillance Network of the Junta de Castilla y Le\u00f3n confirmed on [Mon 12 Aug 2019] 3 new cases of tularemia in the province of Palencia, where 23 people have been affected since 3 Jul 2019, as reported by the territorial delegation of the Board in Palencia. The detection of 3 new cases of tularemia in Villarramiel, Osorno and Palencia, brings to 23 the number of people affected by this disease associated with the overpopulation of voles in the province of Palencia, where they are studying 32 other possible cases. The last confirmed cases have been detected in the Palencia towns of; Villarramiel, where there are already 4 people affected by tularemia; the basic health area of rural Palencia where the 2nd case has been detected; and Osorno, which recorded the 1st confirmed case of this sickness. The most affected localities are Paredes de Nava, with 11 confirmed cases, and Villarramiel with 4, while the basic areas of Salda\u00f1a, Palencia and Cervera de Pisuerga have confirmed 2 cases each and Villada and Osorno a single case in each locality. TULAREMIA - SPAIN (02): (CASTILE AND LEON)\n******************************************\n Abstract available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=3582597\n3. In total, the Epidemiology Surveillance Network has confirmed 12 cases of tularemia so far in August [2019] were added to the 11 confirmed throughout the month of July [2019].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-08-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 03:35:00-08:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 02:33:00-07:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Smolensk Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "Czechia"}, {"location": "Villarramiel", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6152385", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Germany: (BY) rabbit hunters", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6152385", "date": "2018-11-18 17:22:55", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - GERMANY: (BAVARIA) RABBIT HUNTERS\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Nov 2018\nSource: Valparaiso Daily [edited]\nhttps://www.ccdiscovery.com/rabbit-fever-suspected-in-bavaria-with-nine-hunters-in-the-hospital\n\n\nIn Bavaria, 9 hunters apparently have been infected with the causative agent of rabbit fever. According to information from the district administrative office in Swan village, the men had, on 27 Oct 2018, shot 8 eight rabbits and eviscerated and packed them. Eight of the men have been hospitalized since 4 Nov 2018 at the Amberg hospital, the district office spokesman Hans Prechtl confirmed. The 9th hunter was admitted 5 days later.\n\nTularemia (rabbit fever) is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. People can become infected through close contact with diseased animals or their tissues, writes the Bavarian state office for health and food safety. It is risky dealing with the carcasses when killed animals are eviscerated and skinned. Rabbit fever is primarily an occupational disease of hunters, but also of chefs, butchers, and veterinarians.\n\nAccording to the Robert Koch Institute, each year only a few dozen cases are reported. In the year 2017, 52 people in Germany were afflicted, 13 of them in Bavaria. The disease is compulsorily reportable. To protect against the disease, the Bavarian state office recommends only eating wild game dishes that have been well cooked and avoiding unprotected contact with wild animals or carcasses.\n\nIn the Bavarian hunters, the pathogen is still not officially proven, said press secretary of the County Office Hans Precht. A 2nd blood sample was currently being examined at the Robert Koch-Institute in Berlin. The diagnosis is 'very highly' [sic].\n\nAll the men have improved. The 1st of them will probably be discharged this Thu 15 Nov 2018.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University fact sheet on tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals. Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative coccobacillus in the family _Francisellaceae_. A total of 4 subspecies are currently recognized. Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (also known as type A) has been found almost exclusively in North America. It is the most virulent species, particularly in humans. _F. tularensis_ subsp _holarctica_ (type B) is much more widely distributed in the northern hemisphere, but it is less virulent. The 2 remaining species, _F. tularensis_ subsp. _mediasiatica_ and _F. tularensis_ subsp _novicida_, have been recognized in limited geographical regions, are rarely found in people, and seem to cause relatively mild disease when they occur. Additional subspecies have also been proposed. With rare exceptions, tularemia occurs only in the northern hemisphere. This disease has been reported from North America, Europe, parts of Asia and the Middle East, and northern Africa.\n\n'Among the northern hemisphere, _F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. Contrarily, _F. tularensis holarctica_ is widely distributed in the northern hemisphere. This species is responsible for nearly all cases of tularemia outside North America. It co-exists with _F. tularensis tularensis_ in North America. _F. tularensis mediasiatica_ occurs in a limited area of Central Asia, and _F. tularensis novicida_ has been reported from North America, Australia and Spain.\n\n'Humans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. Hunting or skinning animals, or contact with meat when preparing food, are important routes of exposure. Respiratory infections sometimes occur in farmers who are exposed through activities such as piling hay. Cases have been reported after mowing lawns, possibly from running over an animal carcass. Human infections have also been linked to handling infected animals or being bitten by them. Person-to-person transmission has not been reported.'\n\nThe manifestations of tularemia in the hunters have not been stated. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nBavaria, Germany: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3744]", "summary": "The 2 remaining species, _F. tularensis_ subsp. _mediasiatica_ and _F. tularensis_ subsp _novicida_, have been recognized in limited geographical regions, are rarely found in people, and seem to cause relatively mild disease when they occur. \n\n'Humans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University fact sheet on tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals. \n\n'Among the northern hemisphere, _F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _F. tularensis mediasiatica_ occurs in a limited area of Central Asia, and _F. tularensis novicida_ has been reported from North America, Australia and Spain. Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative coccobacillus in the family _Francisellaceae_. \n\nTularemia (rabbit fever) is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. _F. tularensis_ subsp _holarctica_ (type B) is much more widely distributed in the northern hemisphere, but it is less virulent. To protect against the disease, the Bavarian state office recommends only eating wild game dishes that have been well cooked and avoiding unprotected contact with wild animals or carcasses. Liechtenstein: (RU) hare, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6143364", "date": "2018-11-13 16:58:28", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - LIECHTENSTEIN: (RUGGELL) HARE, OIE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 13 Nov 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(46) [edited]\n<www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=28583>\n\n\nTularemia, Liechtenstein\n------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Nov 2018 from Dr med vet Peter Malin, chief veterinary officer, Ministerium f\u00fcr Gesundheit, Amt f\u00fcr Lebensmittelkontrolle und Veterin\u00e4rwesen, Schaan, Liechtenstein\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 5 Nov 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 9 Nov 2018\nReport date: 9 Nov 2018\nDate event resolved: 9 Nov 2018\nReason for notification: first occurrence of a listed disease in the country\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Ruggeller Riet, Ruggell, Unterland, Liechtenstein\nDate of start of the outbreak: 5 Nov 2018\nOutbreak status: resolved (9 Nov 2018)\nEpidemiological unit: other\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: unknown details of hare population\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCenter for Zoonoses, Animal Bacterial Diseases and Antimicrobial Resistance (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / pathogenic agent isolation on culture / 9 Nov 2018 / Positive\nCenter for Zoonoses, Animal Bacterial Diseases and Antimicrobial Resistance (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / real-time PCR / 9 Nov 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting: the event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares). Wild rodents are also frequently infected, and occurrence of human cases is usually linked to these host species. _F. tularensis_ is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. However, there is a known natural focus of tularemia in Central Europe, which is considered an endemic area. The tick implicated there is _Dermacentor reticulatus_.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nRuggell, Liechtenstein: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58605]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Epidemiological unit: other\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Summary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Ruggeller Riet, Ruggell, Unterland, Liechtenstein\n Center for Zoonoses, Animal Bacterial Diseases and Antimicrobial Resistance (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / pathogenic agent isolation on culture / 9 Nov 2018 / Positive\nCenter for Zoonoses, Animal Bacterial Diseases and Antimicrobial Resistance (Regional Reference Laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / real-time PCR / 9 Nov 2018 / Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\n \nAffected population: unknown details of hare population\n\nEpidemiology\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2018; 31(46) [edited]\n<www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=28583>\n\n\nTularemia, Liechtenstein\n Date event resolved: 9 Nov 2018\n Date of confirmation of the event: 9 Nov 2018\n Date of start of the event: 5 Nov 2018\n Outbreak status: resolved (9 Nov 2018)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-11-09 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Unterland", "country": "Austria"}, {"location": "Schaan", "country": "Liechtenstein"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5936471", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (06): (IL) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5936471", "date": "2018-07-30 12:26:58", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (06): (ILLINOIS) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 28 Jul 2018 7:00 AM CDT\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/local/2018-07-28/tularemia-confirmed-rabbit-found-dead.html\n\n\nThe bacterial disease tularemia has surfaced again in Champaign county [Illinois], this time in a dead rabbit found in Urbana, authorities said.\n\nThe rabbit in Urbana was diagnosed with clinical signs of tularemia at the University of Illinois College of Veterinary Medicine this month [July 2018], according to the Champaign-Urbana Public Health District.\n\n'Additionally, there are reports of other rabbits found dead in the neighborhood,' the district said in an alert. 'This indicates presence of this disease in the area.'\n\nThere haven't been any known new human cases of tularemia in the local community, according to Champaign-Urbana Public Health District Administrator Julie Pryde.\n\nAlso called rabbit fever, tularemia is a disease of both animals and humans that is transmitted by an infection of a highly-infectious bacteria.\n\nThe bacterium isn't spread from person-to-person, but it can enter the body through the eyes, mouth, lungs, and skin through bites of infected ticks, handling of infected animals, or breathing it in.\n\nAmong the known cases of tularemia in Champaign county in recent years there have been a human death in 2014, as well as infections of cats in years that include 2011, 2012, and 2013.\n\nPryde said it isn't unusual for rabbits to have tularemia. It becomes more concerning if the disease strikes more rabbits than usual, or if there is a large die-off of rabbits or signs that it's turning up in cats, she said.\n\nAmong the other animals that have also been known to become ill with tularemia are muskrats, prairie dogs, and other rodents, according to the health district. Domestic cats are very susceptible and can transmit the bacteria to people.\n\nUntreated, tularemia can be fatal, but the disease is treatable with antibiotics, and most people recover.\n\nSymptoms in people can include sudden fever, chills, headache, fatigue, and a skin ulcer at a bite site. Both pets and people who develop symptoms should get immediate medical attention.\n\nTo be on the safe side, Pryde advised, avoid direct contact with dead animals. 'In general, if you find a dead rabbit, do not touch it,' she said.\n\nUrbana Animal Control Officer Amy Anderson said the safest way to dispose of a dead animal such as a rabbit is to wear gloves, pick it up with a shovel, double-bag the animal, and place it in the trash. Then disinfect the shovel, she said.\n\nExperts also advise avoiding running over dead animals with tractors and lawn mowers if possible. Risk of contact with the bacteria can further be reduced by wearing masks and protective clothing when doing yard work and using insect repellent when outdoors.\n\n[Byline: Debra Pressey]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Urbana, Illinois, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15354]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere. \n\nAlso called rabbit fever, tularemia is a disease of both animals and humans that is transmitted by an infection of a highly-infectious bacteria. \n\nUrbana Animal Control Officer Amy Anderson said the safest way to dispose of a dead animal such as a rabbit is to wear gloves, pick it up with a shovel, double-bag the animal, and place it in the trash. \n\nThe bacterium isn't spread from person-to-person, but it can enter the body through the eyes, mouth, lungs, and skin through bites of infected ticks, handling of infected animals, or breathing it in. This indicates presence of this disease in the area.'\n\nThere haven't been any known new human cases of tularemia in the local community, according to Champaign-Urbana Public Health District Administrator Julie Pryde. In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nThe rabbit in Urbana was diagnosed with clinical signs of tularemia at the University of Illinois College of Veterinary Medicine this month [July 2018], according to the Champaign-Urbana Public Health District. \n\nPryde said it isn't unusual for rabbits to have tularemia. \n\nUntreated, tularemia can be fatal, but the disease is treatable with antibiotics, and most people recover. The bacterial disease tularemia has surfaced again in Champaign county [Illinois], this time in a dead rabbit found in Urbana, authorities said. \n\nExperts also advise avoiding running over dead animals with tractors and lawn mowers if possible.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-07-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Champaign county", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Urbana", "country": "Dominican Republic"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5902451", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (CO) pneumonia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5902451", "date": "2018-07-12 21:56:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIA\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 11 Jul 2018\nSource: Times Call [edited]\nhttp://www.timescall.com/top-stories/ci_32001943/larimer-county-confirms-human-tularemia-case\n\n\nA Larimer County, [Colorado], resident has been confirmed as having the 1st human case of tularemia this season and is believed to have been exposed while gardening at home, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment. The resident developed a lung infection from tularemia, which can be transmitted to people through insect bites, contaminated soil, or contact with an infected animal, according to a press release from the health department.\n\nAll warm-blooded animals, including pets and livestock, are susceptible to tularemia, though the bacterium normally occurs in rabbits, hares, muskrats, beaver, and small rodents. The bacterium that causes tularemia is in the urine and droppings of sick animals, contaminating the soil through that means. When a person turns up soil while gardening, mowing, or even blowing leaves, the bacteria can be inhaled, causing a pneumonic form of tularemia, the department stated.\n\nThe organism also can be transferred through contaminated food and water or even by putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth after outdoor activities. Other ways to contract tularemia are through insect bites and by handling dead animals, according to a news release. Bacteria in animals can persist in soil or water for weeks, and it takes only a small amount to cause a transmission.\n\nByline: Pamela Johnson\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or via an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _D. variabilis_ (dog tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person, essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nCitations\n----------\n1. Foshay L. Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937; 60(1): 22-38. doi:10.1001/archinte.1937.00180010025002; abstract available at https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/542763.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W. Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am. 2010; 24(1): 43-55. doi: 10.1016/j.idc.2009.10.012; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20171544.\n\nLarimer County is located in the north central part of the state and can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larimer_County,_Colorado. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLarimer County, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The resident developed a lung infection from tularemia, which can be transmitted to people through insect bites, contaminated soil, or contact with an infected animal, according to a press release from the health department. Source: Times Call [edited]\nhttp://www.timescall.com/top-stories/ci_32001943/larimer-county-confirms-human-tularemia-case\n\n\nA Larimer County, [Colorado], resident has been confirmed as having the 1st human case of tularemia this season and is believed to have been exposed while gardening at home, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment. \n\nAll warm-blooded animals, including pets and livestock, are susceptible to tularemia, though the bacterium normally occurs in rabbits, hares, muskrats, beaver, and small rodents. \n\nByline: Pamela Johnson\n\n--\n Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. When a person turns up soil while gardening, mowing, or even blowing leaves, the bacteria can be inhaled, causing a pneumonic form of tularemia, the department stated. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLarimer County, Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298] Citations\n----------\n1. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIA\n Other ways to contract tularemia are through insect bites and by handling dead animals, according to a news release. \n\nThe organism also can be transferred through contaminated food and water or even by putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth after outdoor activities. \n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. The bacterium that causes tularemia is in the urine and droppings of sick animals, contaminating the soil through that means. Bacteria in animals can persist in soil or water for weeks, and it takes only a small amount to cause a transmission. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _D. variabilis_ (dog tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or via an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\n Date: Wed 11 Jul 2018\n Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1937-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6016232", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (MA) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6016232", "date": "2018-09-08 17:18:58", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (08): (MASSACHUSETTS) FATAL\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: thu 6 Sep 2018\nSource: Vineyard Gazette [edited]\nhttps://vineyardgazette.com/news/2018/09/06/tularemia\n\n\nThe recent death of a Martha's Vineyard seasonal resident with an apparent case of tularemia has sparked renewed discussion on the island about the ongoing need for public education around tick-borne illnesses.\n\nA woman told the Gazette in an email that her father died last week [week of 27 Aug 2018] at Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, and that tularemia was confirmed as the cause. He fell ill after he had been cutting brush on his Oak Bluffs property, his daughter said. He did not seek medical treatment on the island and went back to western Massachusetts, where he sought treatment when his symptoms grew worse, she said.\n\nTularemia is a tick-borne illness that can be transmitted by a tick bite and also from infected dead animals, causing a pneumonia-like illness that can be fatal. Spokesmen for the state Department of Public Health and Cooley Dickinson said this week that they could not confirm or comment on the case, citing laws that protect patient confidentiality. Public-health officials on the Vineyard said the recent case should not be cause for alarm but rather an opportunity to raise awareness about prevention, diagnosis, and early treatment, especially as tick-borne illnesses become more prevalent.\n\n'This case should not be looked at as Armageddon,' said Dr. Sam Telford, professor of infectious diseases and global health at Tufts University who has extensively studied tick-borne illnesses and is widely considered the top expert on the Vineyard. He said island medical practitioners have become expert by now at diagnosis. 'It is well entrenched on Martha's Vineyard and no longer a surprise,' he said. 'The people at the hospital are well versed in this: they can smell tularemia when it comes in the door.' Dr. Telford said between 3 and 15 cases of tularemia have been documented on the Vineyard every year going back to 1999. 'It is a little late in the season; typically, we see tularemia cases early in the summer,' he added.\n\nAccording to data tracked by Island Health Care in Edgartown, which contracts with island towns for public-health services, in 2017 there were 6 reported cases of tularemia. So far in 2018, 4 cases have been reported, according to Lila Fischer, a public-health nurse with the agency. Healthcare providers in Massachusetts are required to report suspected and confirmed cases of tularemia immediately to the Department of Public Health, which also directs them to send isolates to the state public-health laboratory for analysis. Isolates are samples of bacteria isolated from a specimen.\n\nNationwide, tularemia is a relatively rare disease, according to the CDC, which has tracked its incidence since 1950. Between 2006 and 2016, there were an average of 172 reported cases per year across the country, with the highest incidence in Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, and Oklahoma, where there are 25-35 cases per year in each state. In New England, tularemia is extremely rare apart from Martha's Vineyard, which state statistics show reached a high of 16 confirmed and probable cases in 2008. The majority of cases, according to the state DPH, have been people who work outdoors, especially landscapers.\n\nTularemia can be contracted in one of several ways. The disease is carried by certain ticks including the common dog tick (also called the wood tick). A person can also become infected after touching, handling, eating, or being bitten by an infected animal, or having contact with water or soil that has been contaminated by an infected animal. The most serious form is pneumonic tularemia, which usually results from breathing dusts or aerosols containing the organism. Between 2000 and 2010, more than 40 people on Martha's Vineyard were diagnosed with the pneumonic variety, according to a Department of Public Health update issued in May 2010.\n\nThe last known death from tularemia on Martha's Vineyard was in 2000, when a 43-year-old landscaper from Chilmark contracted the pneumonic form and failed to seek medical attention in time. Investigators suspected that he may have inhaled the remains or feces of an infected rodent while mowing a lawn near Squibnocket.\n\nSymptoms may include fever, swollen glands, body aches, coughing, and chest pains. In the case of tularemia caused by a tick bite, the area of entry may be inflamed and sore. Symptoms usually occur within 3-5 days of exposure but can take as long as 21 days to show up. Early treatment with antimicrobials usually cures the disease in a few days. The disease is confirmed with a blood test and cultures.\n\nPublic-health officials recommend that people who work outdoors check for dead animals before using any lawn-mowing or brush-cutting equipment, avoid touching dead animals with bare hands, and use a dust mask. Anyone who spends time outdoors is reminded to take precautions against tick bites, including wearing long, light-colored pants tucked into socks or boots and using insect repellent and permethrin-treated clothing, and checking their body for ticks after possible exposure. Anyone who has symptoms is urged to seek early treatment and, if off island, advise healthcare providers of the risks.\n\nDr. Telford praised the work of the tick-borne illness prevention program led by island biologist Dick Johnson and the educational website developed by the island boards of health. 'There's plenty of stuff to be worried about on Martha's Vineyard,' he said. 'Tularemia is not something that should cause people to become hysterical... we need to protect against tick bites; this patient was doing yard work, so that's a signal. It all boils down to the fact that ticks are keeping these infections around in nature, and we need to something about it.'\n\n[Byline: Julia Wells]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human infection with _Francisella tularensis_, a Category A bioterrorism agent, continues to be a problem on Martha's Vineyard, a 100-square-mile [259-square-kilometer] island off the southern coast of Cape Cod, MA. A substantial number of the cases are pneumonic, occurring in landscapers and gardeners, related to the aerosolization of infective bacteria, and that is likely the case here. Most of the fatalities in tularemia are related to the pneumonic form. As with Rocky Mountain spotted fever, if the infection presents in low-prevalence areas, morbidity and mortality rates can be higher.\n\nTelford and colleagues (1) have investigated the genetic diversity of _F. tularensis_ obtained from Martha's Vineyard ticks. Between 2001 and 2003, 0.7 percent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) harbored the tularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of genotypic diversity, suggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of the infection on the island. The authors review information regarding the island's tularemia, which appears to have been a relatively recent introduction into Massachusetts. They state that prior to 1937, only one case of the infection was recognized, related to contaminated rabbit meat from the midwestern USA. In 1937, however, more than 20 000 cottontail rabbits from the midwestern states of Missouri and Kansas were introduced into the mainland state and Martha's Vineyard for sporting purposes (2). Cases began to occur starting several years later.\n\n1. Goethert HK, Shani I, Telford SR. Genotypic diversity of _Francisella tularensis_-infected _Dermacentor variabilis_ ticks on Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts. J Clin Microbiol. 2004; 42: 4968-73.\n2. Belding DL, Merrill M. Tularemia in imported rabbits in Massachusetts. N Engl J Med. 1941; 1085-87. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nMassachusetts, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/224]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nTularemia is a tick-borne illness that can be transmitted by a tick bite and also from infected dead animals, causing a pneumonia-like illness that can be fatal. According to data tracked by Island Health Care in Edgartown, which contracts with island towns for public-health services, in 2017 there were 6 reported cases of tularemia. \n\nDr. Telford praised the work of the tick-borne illness prevention program led by island biologist Dick Johnson and the educational website developed by the island boards of health. USA (07): (CO, OR) beaver, marmot 20180802.5943799\n[2] Oregon\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nA ProMED-mail Rapporteur and Sylvia Miller DVM of Miller Farm & Veterinary Service in Washington state, USA, have pointed out that Crater Lake on Teton Pass, where the dead marmot was found, is located in the state of Wyoming, not in Oregon.\n\nThe state of Wyoming can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64397. A Wyoming county map can be seen at https://www.mapofus.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/WY-county.jpg.\n\nWe thank the ProMED-mail Rapporteur and Dr Miller for bringing this to our attention and apologize for any inconvenience this mistake in the subtitle may have caused. The correct text follows. - Mod.ML\n\n[2] Wyoming\nDate: Fri 27 Jul 2018\nSource: Jackson Hole News & Guide [edited]\nhttps://www.jhnewsandguide.com/the_hole_scroll/article_58864548-cb34-5bee-8e4d-ff21c41be70f.html\n\n\nA dead marmot in Crater Lake on Teton Pass [Wyoming] tested positive for tularemia this week [23-27 Jul 2018], a disease that can be serious and potentially deadly for humans. It's also known as 'rabbit fever' or 'deer fly fever' and frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents.\n\nThe marmot was found by a U.S. Forest Service employee. Crater Lake will not be closed but warning signs telling people to not let their pets swim in the water, not to drink the water and to wear bug spray will likely be posted.\n\nPeople can become ill with tularemia after being bitten by ticks, deer flies or horse flies. It can also be transmitted by handling infected animals, or through ingestion or contact with untreated, contaminated water or insufficiently cooked meat.\n\nDan Forman, the county's emergency veterinarian and chairman of the Teton District Board of Health, called tularemia 'unprecedented for our region.'\n\n'We're having more tick-borne diseases that we feel will most likely be a growing trend in this area with changes in our climate patterns,' Forman said. 'We feel this is a trend that will continue.'\n\nAccording to State Public Health Veterinarian Karl Musgrave, there are no reported cases of tularemia in Teton County's humans, at least back to 2015. It's hard to tell how the marmot became infected, he said.\n\n'Tularemia can be in water, we know that,' Musgrave said. 'It can also be in ticks, it can be in deer flies. So we don't really know how the marmot got it.'\n\nIn 2017, there were 2 human cases reported, both in Park County, and in 2016, there were 7. 2015 was a busy year, with 21 human cases reported.\n\n'We have tularemia periodically across the state,' said Kim Deti, Wyoming Department of Health spokeswoman. 'It's never very many cases, but it can be a pretty serious one so it's something to not overlook.'\n\nWyoming was actually the first state to document a human getting tularemia from an animal -- from a beaver, near Sheridan, in 1939.\n\nSymptoms of the disease include fever, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, skin ulcers and diarrhea. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, progressive weakness and pneumonia.\n\nIt's recommended you seek medical care if you think you may have been exposed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. Wild rodents are also frequently infected, and occurrence of human cases are usually linked to these host species. _F. tularensis_ is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO, OREGON) BEAVER, MARMOT, CORRECTION\n*******************************************************************\n \n\nWyoming was actually the first state to document a human getting tularemia from an animal -- from a beaver, near Sheridan, in 1939. In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nPeople can become ill with tularemia after being bitten by ticks, deer flies or horse flies. \n\nSymptoms of the disease include fever, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, skin ulcers and diarrhea. \n\nIn 2017, there were 2 human cases reported, both in Park County, and in 2016, there were 7. ML\n\n[2] Wyoming\n >\n\n\nre: Tularemia - USA (07): (CO, OR) beaver, marmot 20180802.5943799\n \n\n'We're having more tick-borne diseases that we feel will most likely be a growing trend in this area with changes in our climate patterns,' Forman said.
