' \n\n'We have tularemia periodically across the state,' said Kim Deti, Wyoming Department of Health spokeswoman. \n\n--\n \n\nThe state of Wyoming can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64397.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1939-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "OREGON", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Park County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Teton County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Sheridan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Crater Lake", "country": "Antarctica"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5866489", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (04): (IL) wild rabbit, human", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5866489", "date": "2018-06-21 13:23:50", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (ILLINOIS) WILD RABBIT, HUMAN\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 18 Jun 2018\nSource: Patch.com [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/illinois/tinleypark/human-case-rabbit-fever-reported-cook-county\n\n\nThe Illinois Department of Public Health [IDPH] has confirmed a human case of tularemia in Cook County. Also known as 'rabbit fever,' the Cook county case has been tied to rabbit exposure. A wild rabbit found in Tinley Park tested positive for tularemia over the weekend [16-17 Jun 2018 - see prior ProMED-mail post Tularemia - USA (03): (IL) wild rabbit 20180619.5863284 for details.- Mod.MPP].\n\nThe state public health department was unable to confirm a specific individual, location or time that could identify the patient, citing federal confidentiality laws. IDPH is prohibited from providing private health information. The patient being treated for tularemia is reportedly from Tinley Park and was handling baby wild rabbits, according to a source.\n\nCook County Animal and Rabies Control issued an alert to residents over the weekend [16-17 Jun 2018] confirming that a wild rabbit found in Tinley Park underwent testing at the University of Illinois College of Veterinary Medicine in Champaign came back positive for tularemia.\n\nThe rabbit was found 13 Jun 2018 in the 7500 block of West 161st Place in Tinley Park. According to the CDC, tularemia is a disease of animals and humans caused by the bacterium _ Francisella tularensis_. Symptoms range from mild to life-threatening, and all forms are accompanied by fever, which can be as high as 104 deg F [40 deg C]. Although tularemia can be life-threatening, most infections can be treated successfully with antimicrobials.\n\nRabbits, hares, and rodents are especially susceptible and often die in large numbers during outbreaks. Tularemia has been reported in every state except for Hawaii. Humans can become infected through several routes, including:\n- tick and deer fly bites;\n- skin contact with infected animals;\n- ingestion of contaminated water;\n- inhalation of contaminated aerosols or agricultural dusts;\n- laboratory exposure\n\nTularemia exposure can be prevented by taking the following steps:\n- use of insect repellent;\n- wearing gloves when handling sick or dead animals;\n- avoiding mowing over dead animals\n\nResidents are advised to keep pets and children away from deceased animals, particularly rabbits. Monitor your pets when out walking so they don't approach or eat deceased animals. If you find a dead rabbit or rodent on your property, contact Cook County Animal and Rabies Control at 708-974-6140 for further removal instructions.\n\n[Byline: Lorraine Swanson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Tinley Park, Illinois, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2972\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _D. variabilis_ (dog tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Foshay L. Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937; 60(1): 22-38. doi:10.1001/archinte.1937.00180010025002; abstract available at https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/542763.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W. Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am. 2010; 24(1): 43-55. doi: 10.1016/j.idc.2009.10.012; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20171544.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "Humans can become infected through several routes, including:\n- tick and deer fly bites;\n- skin contact with infected animals;\n- ingestion of contaminated water;\n- inhalation of contaminated aerosols or agricultural dusts;\n- laboratory exposure\n\nTularemia exposure can be prevented by taking the following steps:\n- use of insect repellent;\n- wearing gloves when handling sick or dead animals;\n- avoiding mowing over dead animals\n\nResidents are advised to keep pets and children away from deceased animals, particularly rabbits. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n TULAREMIA - USA (04): (ILLINOIS) WILD RABBIT, HUMAN\n***************************************************\n A wild rabbit found in Tinley Park tested positive for tularemia over the weekend [16-17 Jun 2018 - see prior ProMED-mail post Tularemia - USA (03): (IL) wild rabbit 20180619.5863284 for details.- Mod.MPP]. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Tinley Park, Illinois, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2972\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. [Byline: Lorraine Swanson]\n\n--\n \n\nReferences\n---------- [16-17 Jun 2018] confirming that a wild rabbit found in Tinley Park underwent testing at the University of Illinois College of Veterinary Medicine in Champaign came back positive for tularemia. \n\nThe rabbit was found 13 Jun 2018 in the 7500 block of West 161st Place in Tinley Park. \n\nThe state public health department was unable to confirm a specific individual, location or time that could identify the patient, citing federal confidentiality laws. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Date: Mon 18 Jun 2018\n \n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1937-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Illinois", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cook County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tinley Park", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5943799", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (07): (CO, OR) beaver, marmot", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5943799", "date": "2018-08-02 14:33:13", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO, OREGON) BEAVER, MARMOT\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Tularemia - USA (07): (CO, OR) beaver, marmot, corr 20180803.5945049\nThe subtitle for item [2] Oregon is incorrect. Crater Lake on Teton Pass, where the dead marmot was found, is located in the state of Wyoming, not in Oregon.\nProMED apologizes for the error. - Mod.ML]\n\nIn this report:\n[1] Colorado\n[2] Oregon\n\n******\n[1] Colorado\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2018\nSource: 9 News.com [edited]\nhttps://www.9news.com/article/news/health/dead-beaver-in-rmnp-tests-positive-for-tularemia/73-579327386\n\n\nA dead beaver found in the Lily Lake area of Rocky Mountain National Park has tested positive for tularemia, an uncommon but serious infectious disease, Kyle Patterson with RMNP said in a release.\n\nTularemia is often spread through insects and ticks or by handling infected or dead animals, like rabbits, beavers and other rodents.\n\nThe disease can also be spread to humans and can cause serious symptoms like fever, chills, joint pain, muscle aches and chest pain. In early stages, it can be successfully treated with antibiotics.\n\nTips on preventing infection include using insect repellent, washing hands, and giving wildlife space.\n\nTularemia was also detected in the Lily Lake area in 2015, Patterson said.\n\nIn June [2018], a rabbit found near South Table Mountain Park in Jefferson County died from tularemia. That was the 1st reported animal case of the disease in Colorado this year [2018].\n\nThough tularemia is rare in Colorado, there are about 200 human cases of the disease in the U.S. each year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Oregon\nDate: Fri 27 Jul 2018\nSource: Jackson Hole News & Guide [edited]\nhttps://www.jhnewsandguide.com/the_hole_scroll/article_58864548-cb34-5bee-8e4d-ff21c41be70f.html\n\n\nA dead marmot in Crater Lake on Teton Pass tested positive for tularemia this week [23-27 Jul 2018], a disease that can be serious and potentially deadly for humans. It's also known as 'rabbit fever' or 'deer fly fever' and frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents.\n\nThe marmot was found by a U.S. Forest Service employee. Crater Lake will not be closed but warning signs telling people to not let their pets swim in the water, not to drink the water and to wear bug spray will likely be posted.\n\nPeople can become ill with tularemia after being bitten by ticks, deer flies or horse flies. It can also be transmitted by handling infected animals, or through ingestion or contact with untreated, contaminated water or insufficiently cooked meat.\n\nDan Forman, the county's emergency veterinarian and chairman of the Teton District Board of Health, called tularemia 'unprecedented for our region.'\n\n'We're having more tick-borne diseases that we feel will most likely be a growing trend in this area with changes in our climate patterns,' Forman said. 'We feel this is a trend that will continue.'\n\nAccording to State Public Health Veterinarian Karl Musgrave, there are no reported cases of tularemia in Teton County's humans, at least back to 2015. It's hard to tell how the marmot became infected, he said.\n\n'Tularemia can be in water, we know that,' Musgrave said. 'It can also be in ticks, it can be in deer flies. So we don't really know how the marmot got it.'\n\nIn 2017, there were 2 human cases reported, both in Park County, and in 2016, there were 7. 2015 was a busy year, with 21 human cases reported.\n\n'We have tularemia periodically across the state,' said Kim Deti, Wyoming Department of Health spokeswoman. 'It's never very many cases, but it can be a pretty serious one so it's something to not overlook.'\n\nWyoming was actually the 1st state to document a human getting tularemia from an animal -- from a beaver, near Sheridan, in 1939.\n\nSymptoms of the disease include fever, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, skin ulcers and diarrhea. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, progressive weakness and pneumonia.\n\nIt's recommended you seek medical care if you think you may have been exposed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. Wild rodents are also frequently infected, and occurrence of human cases are usually linked to these host species. _F. tularensis_ is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nCrater Lake, Wyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64397\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED maps available at:\nCrater Lake, Wyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64397\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209] TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO, OREGON) BEAVER, MARMOT\n*******************************************************\n A dead beaver found in the Lily Lake area of Rocky Mountain National Park has tested positive for tularemia, an uncommon but serious infectious disease, Kyle Patterson with RMNP said in a release.\n\n \n\nThe disease can also be spread to humans and can cause serious symptoms like fever, chills, joint pain, muscle aches and chest pain. \n\nWyoming was actually the 1st state to document a human getting tularemia from an animal -- from a beaver, near Sheridan, in 1939. \n\nThough tularemia is rare in Colorado, there are about 200 human cases of the disease in the U.S. each year. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< [2] Oregon\n\n******\n \n\n--\n \n\n--\n [There is a correction of this report: Tularemia - USA (07): (CO, OR) beaver, marmot, corr 20180803.5945049\n ML]\n\nIn this report:\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nPeople can become ill with tularemia after being bitten by ticks, deer flies or horse flies. \n\nSymptoms of the disease include fever, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, skin ulcers and diarrhea. Switzerland (3): bird of prey attack", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5764355", "date": "2018-04-23 14:15:38", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWITZERLAND (03): BIRD OF PREY ATTACK\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 23 Apr 2018 [published online 1 Mar 2018]\nSource: Schweiz Arch Tierheilkd [edited]\nhttps://sat.gstsvs.ch/fileadmin/datapool_upload/IgJournal/Artikel/pdf/SAT_03_2018_Ehrensperger.pdf\n\n\nThe following publication illustrates an unusual source of tularemia reported in Switzerland:\n\nEhrensperger F, Riederer L and Friedl A:Tularemia after attack of one buzzard on a jogger: A 'One Health' case report. Schweiz Arch Tierheilkd 2018; 160:185-188, https://doi.org/10.17236/sat00153 [in German, abstract in English]\n\nSummary:\nA female jogger was attacked by a common buzzard (_Buteo buteo_) and was scratched lightly at the back of the head. One week later she was taken ill with high fever and headache which was later diagnosed as ulceroglandular tularemia in regional lymph nodes, caused by _Francisella tularensis_. Recovery was only achieved after several weeks of systemic antimicrobial treatment (gentamicin/ciprofloxacin).\n\nTularemia is a well known zoonotic disease, called 'rabbit fever', mainly affecting rabbits and hares, but also small rodents. Human infection occurs often following tick bites or bloodsucking insects, or in hunters or slaughterers handling infected animals. Bites by mice have also been reported as a cause of tularemia.\n\nFor the first time we report this case of tularemia as a result of an attack by a bird of prey. We assume that the bird acted as a vector just carrying the _F. tularensis_ on its claws or beak, but we cannot exclude an infection of the bird itself. Several other joggers had also been attacked by a common buzzard in the same area shortly after the above described event and one of these also became infected with _F. tularensis_.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCatherine O'Connor\nEpidemic Intelligence team, Public Health England\n<catherine.oconnor@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED very much thanks Catherine O'Connor for submitting the citation related to this unusual mode of transmission of _F. tularensis_. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSwitzerland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/105]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nCatherine O'Connor\nEpidemic Intelligence team, Public Health England\n<catherine.oconnor@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED very much thanks Catherine O'Connor for submitting the citation related to this unusual mode of transmission of _F. tularensis_. As depicted in the following chart, disease rates in this country (per 100 000 population) are currently 10-fold those reported by bordering countries [1-3]. See graph at: https://www.gideononline.com/2018/04/21/tularemia-in-switzerland/.\n\nReferences\n-----------\n1. Gideon e-Gideon multi-graph tool, https://www.gideononline.com/cases/multi-graphs/\n2. Apr 2018\nSource: Gideon.com [edited]\nhttp://www.gideon.com TULAREMIA - SWITZERLAND (02): 2017, COMMENTARY\n**********************************************\n Communicated by:\nDr. Steve Berger\n Gideon e-books, https://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/tularemia-global-status/\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Tel Aviv", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5863284", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (03): (IL) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5863284", "date": "2018-06-19 13:39:29", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (03): (ILLINOIS) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 16 Jun 2018\nSource: Cook County Government News [edited]\nhttps://www.cookcountyil.gov/news/tularemia-found-wild-rabbit-caution-urged\n\n\nA wild rabbit found [13 Jun 2018] in Tinley Park [Cook county] has tested positive for tularemia. Cook County Animal and Rabies Control urges residents to avoid touching live or dead wildlife.\n\nTularemia is a disease of animals and humans caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Rabbits, hares, and rodents are especially susceptible, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThe bacterium is present in some wildlife in northeast Illinois. Some animals, such as wild rabbits, muskrats, and beavers, may be carriers, but are unaffected by the bacterium. Generally, wild animals do not exhibit signs.\n\nA person can be infected with tularemia through a tick bite or exposure to infected animals, such as rabbits.\n\nTo avoid exposure:\n- do not handle wild animals;\n- keep pets away from wild animals;\n- be alert for dead rabbits, especially when mowing the grass. Do not mow over a dead rabbit;\n- if you find a dead rabbit, call Cook County Animal and Rabies Control, (708) 974-6140;\n- if you find a sick rabbit or other animal in your yard, leave it alone and keep pets away, then contact a licensed wildlife rehabilitator;\n\nSymptoms of disease in humans include: fever, flu-like symptoms; rashes or red lesions on skin.\n\nIn pets, symptoms can include: fever, enlarged lymph nodes in the head and neck, abdominal pain, jaundice, lethargy.\n\nIf you or your pet experience these symptoms, seek medical attention and contact Cook County Animal and Rabies Control at (708) 974-6140.\n\n[Byline: Lorraine Swanson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is largely confined to the northern hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the southern hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals, or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Tinley Park, Illinois, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2972\nIllinois county map: https://geology.com/county-map/illinois-county-map.gif]", "summary": "Do not mow over a dead rabbit;\n- if you find a dead rabbit, call Cook County Animal and Rabies Control, (708) 974-6140;\n- if you find a sick rabbit or other animal in your yard, leave it alone and keep pets away, then contact a licensed wildlife rehabilitator;\n\nSymptoms of disease in humans include: fever, flu-like symptoms; rashes or red lesions on skin. \n\nTo avoid exposure:\n- do not handle wild animals;\n- keep pets away from wild animals;\n- be alert for dead rabbits, especially when mowing the grass. TULAREMIA - USA (03): (ILLINOIS) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\n \n\nA person can be infected with tularemia through a tick bite or exposure to infected animals, such as rabbits. PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Tinley Park, Illinois, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2972\nIllinois county map: https://geology.com/county-map/illinois-county-map.gif] In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals, or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nTularemia is a disease of animals and humans caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-06-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tinley Park", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois county", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5775458", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (02): (KY) sentinel rabbit infected, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5775458", "date": "2018-04-30 11:35:14", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (KENTUCKY) SENTINEL RABBIT INFECTED, ALERT\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 28 Apr 2018 5:24 PM CEST\nSource: LEX 18 [edited]\nhttp://www.lex18.com/story/38065180/health-dept-warns-after-rabbit-fever-case-in-butler-co\n\n\nKentucky health officials have taken action to close a 240-acre [about 97 ha] field trial facility in Butler county near Morgantown. The move comes after officials say a captive wild rabbit there tested positive for tularemia. The disease, also known as 'rabbit fever,' is transmissible to people and pets. It can even be fatal if left untreated. Health officials are encouraging people who spend time outside in Butler county to guard against exposure to the bacterial disease.\n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends using insect repellent, wearing long pants and sleeves, removing any ticks, and avoiding drinking untreated surface water. Anyone who suspects they have come into contact with the bacteria should seek medical care.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[I very much doubt that this captive rabbit was in this field by accident. It is probably that the Kentucky department of health had their suspicions about this field and penned this rabbit and others to check whether the ticks in this field were infected. But I suspect that they will still have to collect ticks, identify them, and check for _ Francisella tularensis_, but that's what graduate students are for.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nButler county, Kentucky, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64046\nFor a description of Butler County go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler_County,_Kentucky\n\nFrom the San Diego County Department of Health\nhttps://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/deh/pests/tularemia.html:\n\n'Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. This bacterium is found in wild rodents and rabbits. It is spread through tick bites, direct contact with infected living or dead animals, or by drinking water that has been contaminated with the bacteria. In California, the American dog tick and the Pacific Coast tick can transmit tularemia. Tularemia has been reported in many areas of the country. In California, it is most frequently seen in the northern areas of the state. It is very rare in San Diego.'\n\nAlthough more common in Midwestern US states, the history of tularemia actually starts in California where, in Tulare county, the disease was characterized as a plague-like disease in the California ground squirrel by McCoy and Chapin (1) in 1912. Initially called _Bacterium tularensis_, the organism's genus was changed to _Francisella_ for Edward Francis (2) who published in 1919 that 'deer fly fever', 'rabbit septicemia' and the 'plague-like disease of ground squirrels' were all the same disease.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. McCoy GW, Chapin CW: _Bacterium tularensis_ the cause of a plague-like disease of rodents. Pub Health Bull 1912; 53.\n2. Francis E: A disease of man of hitherto unknown etiology. Pub Health Rep 1919; 34: 2061.\nMods.LL/MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Apr 2018 5:24 PM CEST\nSource: LEX 18 [edited]\nhttp://www.lex18.com/story/38065180/health-dept-warns-after-rabbit-fever-case-in-butler-co\n\n\nKentucky health officials have taken action to close a 240-acre [about 97 ha] field trial facility in Butler county near Morgantown. \n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nButler county, Kentucky, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64046\n Initially called _Bacterium tularensis_, the organism's genus was changed to _Francisella_ for Edward Francis (2) who published in 1919 that 'deer fly fever', 'rabbit septicemia' and the 'plague-like disease of ground squirrels' were all the same disease. TULAREMIA - USA (02): (KENTUCKY) SENTINEL RABBIT INFECTED, ALERT\n****************************************************************\n Although more common in Midwestern US states, the history of tularemia actually starts in California where, in Tulare county, the disease was characterized as a plague-like disease in the California ground squirrel by McCoy and Chapin (1) in 1912. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< For a description of Butler County go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler_County,_Kentucky\n\nFrom the San Diego County Department of Health\n \n\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends using insect repellent, wearing long pants and sleeves, removing any ticks, and avoiding drinking untreated surface water. https://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/deh/pests/tularemia.html:\n\n'Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1912-03-25 00:00:00", "2053-03-25 00:00:00", "1919-03-25 00:00:00", "2061-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KENTUCKY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Diego", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "midwestern US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kentucky", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Tulare county", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Butler County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Morgantown", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Butler county", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5760078", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Switzerland: 2017", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5760078", "date": "2018-04-20 16:44:51", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWITZERLAND: 2017\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Apr 2018 08:53\nSource: Swiss Info [edited]\nhttps://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/society/rodent-plague_rare-bacterial-infection-spreading-in-switzerland/44055676\n\n\nRodent plague, a bacterial infection, (also called rabbit fever) is spreading among people in Switzerland. A growing number of incidents with tick bites has been recorded over the past few years. The Federal Health Office counted 130 confirmed cases of tularemia in 2017, according to Swiss public radio, SRF. This is 4 times more than usual.\n\nThe authorities called on doctors to report all such cases. A decision on coordinated campaign measures will be taken later this year [2018]. Experts say the disease can be treated with antibacterials, but it can be deadly if not detected in time.\n\nThe best precaution against rodent plague is for humans to protect against tick bites, according to the Federal Health Office.\n\nThe relatively little-known disease in rabbits and other wild animals is apparently transmitted to humans by contact with infected animal tissue and ticks. Typical symptoms include fever, headaches, muscle pain, enlarged lymph nodes and ulcers on the skin, according to medical sources.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person essentially in contrast to another Category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _Francisella tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nReferences\n1. Foshay L. Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937; 60: 22-38.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W. Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am. 2010; 24: 43-55.\n\nA map of Switzerland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/105. - Mod.LL]\n\n.................................................ll/ec/lm", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). The relatively little-known disease in rabbits and other wild animals is apparently transmitted to humans by contact with infected animal tissue and ticks. The infection does not spread from person to person essentially in contrast to another Category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted. \n\nReferences\n1. \n\n--\n \n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Typical symptoms include fever, headaches, muscle pain, enlarged lymph nodes and ulcers on the skin, according to medical sources. \n\n\nRodent plague, a bacterial infection, (also called rabbit fever) is spreading among people in Switzerland. The best precaution against rodent plague is for humans to protect against tick bites, according to the Federal Health Office. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _Francisella tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. TULAREMIA - SWITZERLAND: 2017\n Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Source: Swiss Info [edited]\nhttps://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/society/rodent-plague_rare-bacterial-infection-spreading-in-switzerland/44055676 LL]\n\n.................................................ll/ec/ The Federal Health Office counted 130 confirmed cases of tularemia in 2017, according to Swiss public radio, SRF. **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1937-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5260441", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (07): (AK) snowshoe hares", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5260441", "date": "2017-08-19 11:00:50", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (ALASKA) SHOWSHOE HARES\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017\nSource: Alaska Public [edited]\nhttp://www.alaskapublic.org/2017/08/14/tularemia-reported-around-fairbanks-palmer-vets-urge-quick-diagnosis-treatment-for-pets/\n\n\nThe state Department of Fish and Game is warning pet owners in the Interior and Southcentral Alaska about a recent spike in reports of tularemia - sometimes called 'rabbit fever.' The disease is treatable, but it's essential to get an animal to a veterinarian as soon as possible when they're showing signs, like high fever.\n\nState Wildlife Veterinarian Kimberlee Beckmen said her office is getting the word out about tularemia after a recent rash of reports of animals sickened by the disease around Fairbanks and Palmer.\n\n'Just in the last 2 weeks, there's been a very significant increase in the number of reports,' Beckman said. 'In fact I had 5 reports in just 2 days, earlier this week [week of Sun 13 Aug 2017].'\n\nBeckmen advises pet owners to keep a close eye on their animals for any signs of the disease, because it can kill quickly.\n\n'Many people, if their dog is just acting lethargic, maybe has a little fever, they might wait 1-2 days to go in [to the veterinarian],' Beckman said. 'But we want people to know this is really an urgent matter, to get on antibiotics, sooner rather than later.'\n\nBeckman cited the example of 2 household cats in North Pole that died last week [week of Sun 6 Aug 2017], soon after their owner noticed one of them was sick.\n'The 1st one died and was diagnosed,' Beckman said. 'And yet, in the same household, the 2nd cat became ill, and wasn't treated in time. So they lost their other cat.'\n\nBob Gerlach, the State Veterinarian, said pet owners should look for signs that may not be so easy to detect, especially in younger animals.\n\n'Generally, pets can show mild infection and show no signs,' Gerlach said. 'Or may show some fever, lack of appetite, lethargy and just not feeling good.'\n\nFish and Game experts say pet owners shouldn't allow cats and dogs to eat hares, voles and other small mammals that could contract tularemia. Pets that show any signs of the disease should be examined and treated as soon as possible, the experts say.\n\nBeckmen said cats and dogs usually contract tularemia by eating the flesh of a sickened animal - usually, the snowshoe hare. She said humans, in turn, can come down with the disease through their household pets. She said it doesn't happen often; the most recent reported case in the Interior was 2 years ago, when a North Pole man got sick after skinning an infected hare.\n\n'It can be very, very serious,' Beckman said. 'I know of one case where a person who got it from taking a hare out of their cat's mouth, and had some serious, permanent heart damage.'\n\nBeckmen said hares, rabbits and other small mammals come into contact with the bacteria that causes tularemia through ticks that latch on to them. She said the growing number of tick species in this part of the subarctic contributes to the increase in reports of animals contracting the disease.\n\nIn Alaska, hares and other mammals most often are exposed to the bacteria that cause tularemia through the bite of a hare tick. But, Beckmen says in recent years other ticks have been showing up in the Interior that also could transmit the bacteria. (Alaska Department of Fish and Game)\n\n'The hare ticks and vole ticks are normal and we've always had those,' Beckman said. 'But what's new is that we have dog ticks. And for about the past 10 years probably those were introduced and they've become established.'\n\nBeckmen also said there are a lot more snowshoe hares this year [2017] because the species is nearing the peak of its population cycle.\n\n'There's a very high number of hares, which happens on a 7-to 10-year cycle,' Beckman said. 'So we expect to see a lot more tularemia during a 'hare high.' '\n\nGerlach, the state vet, said livestock usually aren't susceptible to tularemia. But he said they can come into contact with the bacteria, especially in the wild, where it can live for long periods in the soil.\n\n[Byline: Tim Ellis]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ sub sp tularensis_ (Type A) (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_) and is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation, arthropod-borne transfer, or direct contact through the skin and mucous membranes. Organisms are found in the blood and tissues of infected animals and can survive for long periods on fomites including food and water.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals, or contaminated water.\n\nTularemia is difficult to prevent since it can be in the environment or be spread by insects. Prevention measures include keeping pets indoors and away from wildlife. Do not feed animals raw meat, especially that from wild animals. Control ticks and biting flies. There are several good products, both oral and topical for controlling ticks and fleas and biting flies. Check with your veterinarian about which product is recommended in your area.\n\nLastly, this agent is a category A bioterrorism agent. - Mod.TG\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/FastFacts/pdfs/tularemia_F.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]", "summary": "\n\nBeckmen said hares, rabbits and other small mammals come into contact with the bacteria that causes tularemia through ticks that latch on to them. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nBeckmen said cats and dogs usually contract tularemia by eating the flesh of a sickened animal - usually, the snowshoe hare. \n\nBob Gerlach, the State Veterinarian, said pet owners should look for signs that may not be so easy to detect, especially in younger animals. \n\n'Many people, if their dog is just acting lethargic, maybe has a little fever, they might wait 1-2 days to go in [to the veterinarian],' Beckman said. ' \n\nFish and Game experts say pet owners shouldn't allow cats and dogs to eat hares, voles and other small mammals that could contract tularemia. \n\nBeckmen also said there are a lot more snowshoe hares this year [2017] because the species is nearing the peak of its population cycle. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ sub sp tularensis_ (Type A) (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_) and is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. State Wildlife Veterinarian Kimberlee Beckmen said her office is getting the word out about tularemia after a recent rash of reports of animals sickened by the disease around Fairbanks and Palmer. \n\nBeckman cited the example of 2 household cats in North Pole that died last week [week of Sun 6 Aug 2017], soon after their owner noticed one of them was sick. \n\n'Just in the last 2 weeks, there's been a very significant increase in the number of reports,' Beckman said. ' \n\nBeckmen advises pet owners to keep a close eye on their animals for any signs of the disease, because it can kill quickly. She said the growing number of tick species in this part of the subarctic contributes to the increase in reports of animals contracting the disease. \n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation, arthropod-borne transfer, or direct contact through the skin and mucous membranes. So we expect to see a lot more tularemia during a 'hare high.' '\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "TG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5628959", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (CA) infected ticks", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5628959", "date": "2018-02-15 20:28:34", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA: (CALIFORNIA) INFECTED TICKS\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 13 Feb 2018, 3:17 PM ET\nSource: Patch.com [edited]\nhttps://patch.com/california/encinitas/health-warning-ticks-found-san-diego-have-rabbit-fever\n\n\nSan Diego health officials on [Tue 13 Feb 2018] announced that ticks found in the region tested positive for [_Francisella tularensis_ the etiologic bacterium causing] tularemia, a potentially dangerous bacterial disease also known as 'rabbit fever.' The discovery prompted officials to urge the public to protect themselves and their pets from ticks when hiking or walking in grassy, backcountry areas, on trails and in the wild.\n\nTicks are tiny, 8-legged parasites related to spiders. They crawl out on leaves and vegetation and extend their hooked front legs to latch onto passing animals and people, then bite and feed on blood. Even though tick diseases are rare in San Diego County, they have also been known to carry other diseases including Lyme disease and spotted fever illnesses, officials said in a press release.\n\nVector Control officials said they have been finding increased numbers of ticks in 2018 around the county, although the ones collected in Sorrento Valley were the only ones that have tested positive for any disease. The County's Vector Control Program monitors the population of vectors -- animals like ticks, fleas, rodents and mosquitoes -- that can transmit diseases to people.\n\nTularemia can be successfully treated with antimicrobials, but can be dangerous and even fatal. County public health officials said anyone who is bitten by a tick should not panic, but carefully remove it. They said if a person develops a rash or fever within several weeks of being bitten they should see a doctor, tell them about the tick bite, when they were bitten and where they think it happened.\n\nHealth officials offered the following tips to help you protect yourself, your family and pets from ticks:\n- Wear insect repellent\n- Stay on designated pathways\n- Avoid grass and brush\n- Frequently check your clothing, body and companions for tick\n- Leave pets at home or keep them leashed\n\n[Byline: Hoa Qu\u00e1ch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This is from the San Diego County Department of Health\nhttps://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/sdc/deh/pests/tularemia.html:\n\n'Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. This bacterium is found in wild rodents and rabbits. It is spread through tick bites, direct contact with infected living or dead animals, or by drinking water that has been contaminated with the bacteria. In California, the American dog tick and the Pacific Coast tick can transmit tularemia. Tularemia has been reported in many areas of the country. In California, it is most frequently seen in the northern areas of the state. It is very rare in San Diego.'\n\nAlthough more common in Midwestern US states, the history of tularemia actually starts in California where, in Tulare county, the disease was characterized as a plague-like disease in the California ground squirrel by McCoy and Chapin (1) in 1912. Initially called _Bacterium tularensis_, the organism's genus was changed to _Francisella_ for Edward Francis (2) who published in 1919 that 'deer fly fever', 'rabbit septicemia' and the 'plague-like disease of ground squirrels' were all the same disease.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. McCoy GW, Chapin CW: _Bacterium tularensis_ the cause of a plague-like disease of rodents. Pub Health Bull 1912; 53\n2. Francis E: A disease of man of hitherto unknown etiology. Pub Health Rep 1919; 34: 2061\nMod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSan Diego County, California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787]", "summary": "\n\nHealth officials offered the following tips to help you protect yourself, your family and pets from ticks:\n- Wear insect repellent\n- Stay on designated pathways\n- Avoid grass and brush\n- Frequently check your clothing, body and companions for tick\n- Leave pets at home or keep them leashed\n\n[Byline: Hoa Qu\u00e1ch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nSan Diego health officials on [Tue 13 Feb 2018] announced that ticks found in the region tested positive for [_Francisella tularensis_ the etiologic bacterium causing] tularemia, a potentially dangerous bacterial disease also known as 'rabbit fever.' Initially called _Bacterium tularensis_, the organism's genus was changed to _Francisella_ for Edward Francis (2) who published in 1919 that 'deer fly fever', 'rabbit septicemia' and the 'plague-like disease of ground squirrels' were all the same disease. \n\nVector Control officials said they have been finding increased numbers of ticks in 2018 around the county, although the ones collected in Sorrento Valley were the only ones that have tested positive for any disease. Even though tick diseases are rare in San Diego County, they have also been known to carry other diseases including Lyme disease and spotted fever illnesses, officials said in a press release. Although more common in Midwestern US states, the history of tularemia actually starts in California where, in Tulare county, the disease was characterized as a plague-like disease in the California ground squirrel by McCoy and Chapin (1) in 1912. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nSan Diego County, California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787] The County's Vector Control Program monitors the population of vectors -- animals like ticks, fleas, rodents and mosquitoes -- that can transmit diseases to people.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00", "1919-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "1912-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tulare county", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "midwestern US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Diego", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5127076", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (06): (CO) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5127076", "date": "2017-06-23 19:11:17", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (06): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 22 Jun 2017 12:20 PM MDT\nSource: News Channel 13 abc [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/health/rabbit-tests-positive-for-rabbit-fever-in-ne-colorado-springs/557268081\n\n\nA wild rabbit found in the northeast part of Colorado Springs has died of tularemia infection, also known as rabbit fever, according to El Paso County Public Health.\n\nThe rabbit was tested after someone recently found several dead rabbits near a property off Austin Bluffs Parkway and Stetson Hills Boulevard.\n\nSo far, there have not been reports of human tularemia infection.\n\nSigns of infection in people include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be treated with antibiotics. If you have any of these early signs, contact your doctor.\n\nTularemia most often happens by an infected insect bite, most commonly ticks and deer flies.\n\nEl Paso County Public Health is asking residents to keep an eye out on wild animals for your safety as well as your children and pets. If you do spot a dead, wild animal there are steps you should take to dispose of it.\n\n[Byline: Holly Morrison]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There have been reports of Tularemia in rabbits in CO a few weeks ago.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals, or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Date: Thu 22 Jun 2017 12:20 PM MDT\nSource: News Channel 13 abc [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/health/rabbit-tests-positive-for-rabbit-fever-in-ne-colorado-springs/557268081\n\n\nA wild rabbit found in the northeast part of Colorado Springs has died of tularemia infection, also known as rabbit fever, according to El Paso County Public Health. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There have been reports of Tularemia in rabbits in CO a few weeks ago. TULAREMIA - USA (06): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\n In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals, or contaminated water. \n\nThe rabbit was tested after someone recently found several dead rabbits near a property off Austin Bluffs Parkway and Stetson Hills Boulevard.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado Springs", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "El Paso County Public Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stetson Hills Boulevard", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5098241", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (MN) feline exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5098241", "date": "2017-06-11 18:20:25", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (MINNESOTA) FELINE EXPOSURE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 10 Jun 2017 04:41PM CDT\nSource: KMSP [edited]\nhttp://www.fox9.com/news/260128831-story\n\n\nIt's a rare disease in Minnesota, with only 3 reported human cases in 2016, but Minnesota Department of Health warns cases of tularemia could be on the rise. 'It's still uncommon, but over the last several years we are starting to see more and more cases,' said Kirk Smith with the Minnesota Department of Health.\n\nLast week [week of 28 May-3 Jun 2017], health officials reported the 1st tularemia case of 2017 in Burnsville after an infected cat passed the bacterium to a person. The disease can be transmitted by infected animals, wood ticks, deer flies and contaminated water or soil. Cats are a common transmitter to humans, typically contracting the disease from a squirrel or rabbit. Squirrels and rabbits usually getting the disease from infected wood ticks, which is where the bacteria often originates\n\n'As the years go on here it's become more common in animals and the environment and consequently in humans as well,' said Smith.\n\nSymptoms of tularemia can include ulcers or sores at the sight of the infection, swollen lymph nodes, high fever and body aches. Tularemia is fatal in up to 5 percent of cases, but treatment with antibacterial therapy normally results in a full recovery.\n\n[Byline: Jack Highberger]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness, but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of one to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of exposure. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza, and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/354.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. Squirrels and rabbits usually getting the disease from infected wood ticks, which is where the bacteria often originates\n\n'As the years go on here it's become more common in animals and the environment and consequently in humans as well,' said Smith. [week of 28 May-3 Jun 2017], health officials reported the 1st tularemia case of 2017 in Burnsville after an infected cat passed the bacterium to a person. The disease can be transmitted by infected animals, wood ticks, deer flies and contaminated water or soil. \n\nSymptoms of tularemia can include ulcers or sores at the sight of the infection, swollen lymph nodes, high fever and body aches. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. TULAREMIA - USA (05): (MINNESOTA) FELINE EXPOSURE\n*************************************************\n It's a rare disease in Minnesota, with only 3 reported human cases in 2016, but Minnesota Department of Health warns cases of tularemia could be on the rise. ' The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza, and sore throat.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Burnsville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5082066", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Veillonella - USA: (ID)  tularemia not", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5082066", "date": "2017-06-04 05:13:54", "main_text": "VEILLONELLA - USA: (IDAHO) TULAREMIA NOT\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Jun 2017\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2017; 66: 564-565 [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6621a4.htm\n\n\nNotes from the field: Veillonella misidentified as _Francisella tularensis_ -- Idaho, 2016\n---------------------------------------------------------------\nIn October 2016, the Idaho Bureau of Laboratories, Division of Public Health, was notified by hospital A's clinical laboratory (a member of the Idaho Sentinel Laboratory Network) that a bacterial isolate cultured from a hospitalized patient's knee joint fluid aspirate had been identified with 96 per cent confidence as _Francisella tularensis_ (a Tier 1 select agent*) by an in-house automated microbial identification system (AMIS). The isolate was submitted to the Idaho Bureau of Laboratories for confirmatory testing using Laboratory Response Network (LRN) reference methods. Hospital A laboratory personnel reported that the isolate had been manipulated on the open bench and certain laboratory workers had potentially been exposed. The Division of Public Health, hospital A, and Eastern Idaho Public Health initiated an investigation to confirm _F. tularensis_, assess potential laboratory exposures, and determine the source of infection. The investigation determined that the infectious agent was veillonella and not _F. tularensis_.\n\nThe patient, a man aged over 75 years, had a multiyear history of chronic unilateral knee pain, during which time he had received a series of 3 intra-articular injections of hyaluronate sodium 2 years previously, and several intra-articular injections of triamcinolone with bupivacaine, the last of which occurred 15 days before he sought care at hospital A for a swollen knee. Gram staining of an intra-articular aspirate obtained that day from the affected knee showed Gram-variable cocci. The aspirate was cultured under aerobic and anaerobic conditions. Slow-growing colonies of Gram negative cocci were observed from the anaerobic culture, with limited growth in aerobic conditions. Because an anaerobic AMIS panel was not available, isolates from the aerobic culture were processed for identification and antimicrobial susceptibility on the AMIS using a panel specific for aerobic organisms. Identification of _F. tularensis_ by the AMIS triggered notification of the Division of Public Health and revision of the patient's antimicrobial regimen from vancomycin, piperacillin, and tazobactam to ciprofloxacin. Eastern Idaho Public Health interviewed the patient and determined that he lived in a rural area and reported no recent exposure to potential sources of naturally occurring _F. tularensis_ (for example, ill animals, arthropod bites, contaminated water, or use of lawn mowers or string trimmers near dead animals).\n\nThe Idaho Bureau of Laboratories and Eastern Idaho Public Health provided the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] guidance on tularemia laboratory exposure (1) to hospital A and assisted staff members in assessing potential exposures of laboratory personnel. Among 24 employees interviewed by hospital A, 19 were considered to have potential exposure; all 19 elected to start antimicrobial prophylaxis because of a high level of concern regarding risk and the approximately 48 hours required for confirmatory testing.\n\nUsing LRN real-time polymerase chain reaction methods, the Idaho Bureau of Laboratories tested the isolate for _F. tularensis_ and _Brucella spp_.; no _F. tularensis_ or _Brucella spp_ DNA was detected. Subsequent partial 16S ribosomal RNA (rRNA) gene sequencing identified a _Veillonella sp_. According to Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute guidelines, Veillonella species-level identification could not be reported because the 16S rRNA gene fragment had a more than 99 per cent sequence identity for both _V. parvula_ and _V. dispar_ without a less than 0.8 per cent difference between them (2). Partial RNA polymerase subunit B gene (rpoB) sequencing conducted on the isolate found a more than 99 per cent sequence identity to V. parvula_, suggesting this as the most likely species of the isolate (3). After identification of _Veillonella sp_., the patient's antimicrobial regimen was changed to piperacillin, tazobactam, and ertapenem sodium; personnel who were receiving prophylactic antimicrobials for potential _F. tularensis_ exposure were informed that continuation of prophylaxis was not recommended or necessary. The Division of Public Health reviewed MedWatch data and did not identify any reports of veillonella infection associated with hyaluronate sodium, triamcinolone, or bupivacaine. The source of this patient's infection was not determined.\n\n_Veillonella spp._ are small, slow-growing, nonmotile anaerobic Gram negative cocci found as part of the normal flora of gastrointestinal, respiratory, and vaginal tracts. Although _Veillonella spp._ are classified as anaerobes, anaerobic organisms (including _Veillonella spp._) have been observed growing in aerobic conditions for a limited time after isolation before becoming nonviable (4). Often considered contaminants of clinical specimen collection, _Veillonella spp._ have been rarely isolated from monomicrobial cultures of invasive infections. Predisposing factors for invasive infection have not been fully studied, but might include local or systemic immune suppression and localized anaerobic conditions produced by tissue necrosis, diminished blood supply, or prolonged infection with aerobes (5).\n\nThis is the 1st published report of misidentification of _Veillonella sp._ as _F. tularensis_ by an AMIS and of isolation of _Veillonella sp._ from a nonprosthetic knee. Hospital and public health staff members responded appropriately to the preliminary misidentification of the isolate as _F. tularensis_; however, accurate identification would have obviated the need for time-intensive response activities, use of prophylactic antimicrobials by hospital staff members, and inappropriately targeted antimicrobial therapy for the patient. Clinical laboratories are advised not to use a commercial AMIS if a select agent is suspected in a clinical sample (6) and to consult with their LRN-biologic laboratory for guidance and sample referral. Clinicians should consider _Veillonella spp._ when receiving laboratory reports of _F. tularensis_ generated by AMISs. Because _Veillonella spp._ are typically resistant to recommended or alternative antimicrobial therapies for tularemia (i.e., streptomycin, gentamicin, tetracyclines, ciprofloxacin, and other fluoroquinolones), antibacterial coverage for both _Veillonella spp._ and _F. tularensis_ could be considered until final microbial identification is available.\n\n[authors: Carter KK, Peterson EM, Voermans RL, et al]\n\n* Tier 1 select agents are biologic agents and toxins that present the greatest risk for deliberate misuse with significant potential for mass casualties or devastating effects to the economy, critical infrastructure, or public confidence, and pose a severe threat to public health and safety.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Tularemia fact sheet: managing potential laboratory exposures to F. tularensis. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health and Human Services, CDC; 2015. https://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/resources/lab/tularemialabexposurefactsheet.pdf\n2. Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute. Interpretive criteria for identification of bacteria and fungi by DNA target sequencing; approved guideline. CLSI document MM18-A. Wayne, PA: Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute; 2008.\n3. Beighton D, Clark D, Hanakuka B, Gilbert S, Do T. The predominant cultivable Veillonella spp. of the tongue of healthy adults identified using rpoB sequencing. Oral Microbiol Immunol. 2008;23:344-347.\n4. Tally FP, Stewart PR, Sutter VL, Rosenblatt JE. Oxygen tolerance of fresh clinical anaerobic bacteria. J Clin Microbiol. 1975;1:161-164.\n5. Brook I. Spectrum and treatment of anaerobic infections. J Infect Chemother. 2016;22:1-13.\n6. Snyder JW, ed. General introduction, recommendations and biochemical procedures. In: American Society for Microbiology. Laboratory response network (LRN) sentinel level clinical laboratory protocols for suspected biological threat agents and emerging infectious diseases. Washington, DC: American Society for Microbiology; 2016. https://www.asm.org/images/PSAB/LRN/Intro316.pdf\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Several important points can be made here:\n\n1. A variety of anaerobes, such as veillonella, can grow initially aerobically only to become non viable.\n2. Injection of sterile body cavities with corticosteroids can produce infections with unusual organisms.\n3. Automated microbiological identification systems, even with a high degree of confidence, can misidentify organisms.\n4. Identification of Tier 1 organisms should always be confirmed by genetic or newer technology such as Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215.]", "summary": "In October 2016, the Idaho Bureau of Laboratories, Division of Public Health, was notified by hospital A's clinical laboratory (a member of the Idaho Sentinel Laboratory Network) that a bacterial isolate cultured from a hospitalized patient's knee joint fluid aspirate had been identified with 96 per cent confidence as _Francisella tularensis_ (a Tier 1 select agent*) by an in-house automated microbial identification system (AMIS).
