Germany: (RP) grape harvesters, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4647007", "date": "2016-11-22 12:30:06", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - GERMANY: (RHINELAND-PALATINE) GRAPE HARVESTERS, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Nov 2016\nSource: Mainz-Bingen District press release [in German, submitter SZ, edited]\nhttp://www.mainz-bingen.de/deutsch/aktuelles_presse/pressemeldungen/20161120_hasenpest.php Six human cases of Tularemia\n\n\nThe health authorities of the Mainz-Bingen district [Rhineland-Palatinate] are investigating several cases of human tularemia infection. The disease can be transmitted from animals; human to human transmission is not known. The disease can be efficiently treated but cases can be severe.\n\nAll 6 patients had been harvesting grapes at the beginning of October 2016 in the northern part of the district. A couple of days later high temperature combined with a severe overall feeling of sickness was observed. The cases are unusual because infections with the pathogen (_Francisella tularensis_) are very rare in Germany and clusters of infection are even rarer.\n\nHumans become infected through direct contact with diseased animals, their organs or excretions. The pathogen can be transmitted through contaminated food as well.\n\nThe health authorities' investigation is assisted by the state lab (LUA). The focus of the investigation is on how the patients harvesting grapes could have become infected. In addition, the federal Robert-Koch-Institut (RKI) is performing tests on samples collected from the vineyard. The focus is on food, hare/rabbit droppings, and environmental samples.\n\nTularemia is caused by the pathogen _F. tularensis_. The 1st signs usually are sores at the site of infection inoculation, followed by influenza-like symptoms with fever, swelling of local lymph nodes, chills, and headache. The infection can be treated with antimicrobials.\n\nMedical practitioners in the Mainz-Bingen district are alerted and are asked to consider tularemia in patients with fever or swelling of lymph nodes, especially when the reason for symptoms cannot be established. They are required by law to notify the health authorities of suspect cases.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University, fact sheet on tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals. Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative coccobacillus in the family _Francisellaceae_. A total of 4 subspecies are currently recognized. Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (also known as type A) has been found almost exclusively in North America. It is the most virulent species, particularly in humans. _F. tularensis_ subsp _holarctica_ (type B) is much more widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere, but it is less virulent. The 2 remaining species, _F. tularensis_ subsp. _mediasiatica_ and _F. tularensis_ subsp _novicida_, have been recognized in limited geographical regions, are rarely found in people, and seem to cause relatively mild disease when they occur. Additional subspecies have also been proposed. With rare exceptions, tularemia occurs only in the Northern Hemisphere. This disease has been reported from North America, Europe, parts of Asia and the Middle East, and northern Africa.\n\n'Among the Northern Hemisphere, _F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. Contrarily, _F. tularensis holarctica_ is widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere. This species is responsible for nearly all cases of tularemia outside North America. It co-exists with _F. tularensis tularensis_ in North America. _F. tularensis mediasiatica_ occurs in a limited area of Central Asia, and _F. tularensis novicida_ has been reported from North America, Australia and Spain.\n\n'Humans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. Hunting or skinning animals, or contact with meat when preparing food, are important routes of exposure. Respiratory infections sometimes occur in farmers who are exposed through activities such as piling hay. Cases have been reported after mowing lawns, possibly from running over an animal carcass. Human infections have also been linked to handling infected animals or being bitten by them. Person-to-person transmission has not been reported.'\n\nProMED-mail would like more information regarding whether pneumonia was present, whether any regional lymph node enlargement was present and additional information about the epidemiology here and how the diagnoses were made (culture or serology). Clusters of cases may be related to aerosol exposure or common ingestion of contaminated foodstuff or water.\n\nMainz-Bingen is a district (kreis) in the east of Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany. The state (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhineland-Palatinate) itself is located in western Germany and borders Belgium, Luxembourg, and France, and the German states of North Rhine-Westphalia, Hesse, Baden-W\u00fcrttemberg, and Saarland. It can be seen on a map of the country at http://www.worldatlasbook.com/germany/maps/germany-regions-map-printable.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/56717.]", "summary": "Castleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\nhttp://www.cvlonghorns.de\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University, fact sheet on tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Humans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. The 2 remaining species, _F. tularensis_ subsp. _mediasiatica_ and _F. tularensis_ subsp _novicida_, have been recognized in limited geographical regions, are rarely found in people, and seem to cause relatively mild disease when they occur. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\n The cases are unusual because infections with the pathogen (_Francisella tularensis_) are very rare in Germany and clusters of infection are even rarer.\n\n Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp. Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative coccobacillus in the family _Francisellaceae_. Six human cases of Tularemia\n\n\nThe health authorities of the Mainz-Bingen district [Rhineland-Palatinate] are investigating several cases of human tularemia infection. _F. tularensis mediasiatica_ occurs in a limited area of Central Asia, and _F. tularensis novicida_ has been reported from North America, Australia and Spain. \n\nMedical practitioners in the Mainz-Bingen district are alerted and are asked to consider tularemia in patients with fever or swelling of lymph nodes, especially when the reason for symptoms cannot be established. Among the Northern Hemisphere, _F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. \n\nProMED-mail would like more information regarding whether pneumonia was present, whether any regional lymph node enlargement was present and additional information about the epidemiology here and how the diagnoses were made (culture or serology). \n\nTularemia is caused by the pathogen _F. tularensis_. It co-exists with _F. tularensis tularensis_ in North America. _F. tularensis_ subsp _holarctica_ (type B) is much more widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere, but it is less virulent.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "North Rhine - Westphalia", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Saarland", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Luxembourg", "country": "Luxembourg"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Hesse", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Rhineland - Palatinate", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Baden - W\u00fcrttemberg", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4463335", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (12): (CO) human ex dog susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4463335", "date": "2016-09-03 17:16:46", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (12): (COLORADO) HUMAN ex DOG SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Sep 2016\nSource: Wet Mountain Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.wetmountaintribune.com/home.asp?i=956&p=6\n\n\nLocal public health office issues tularemia warning\n---------------------------------------------------\nA person who resides in south east Custer County [Colorado] tested positive for tularemia the week of 22 Aug [2016] and that has prompted the Custer County Public Health Agency to alert county residents to take certain precautions. The individual is thought to have acquired the illness from her pet puppy. Residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares -- in the area.\n\nPublic Health would ask that if anyone notices a die-off of rodents to please notify the public health office. Tularemia is a bacterial infection most commonly transmitted to humans by the handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (most commonly ticks and deer flies), by eating or drinking contaminated food or water, and by the inhalation of airborne bacteria.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans are fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. If tularemia is caused by the bite of an infected insect or from bacteria entering a cut or scratch, it usually causes a skin ulcer and swollen glands. Eating or drinking food or water containing the bacteria may produce a throat infection, stomach pain, diarrhea and vomiting. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antimicrobials, therefore should you have any of these early signs, seek medical attention as soon as possible.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to the veterinarian promptly. As in humans, tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013. The clinical manifestations of human tularemia depend on the route of entry of the organism into the body. Airborne _Francisella tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease ('gland' in this case referring to lymph nodes). The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza (inflammation of the mucous membranes lining the nasal cavity), and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness. Some illnesses manifest as an undifferentiated febrile illness which is called the typhoidal form. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8692.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: Wet Mountain Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.wetmountaintribune.com/home.asp?i=956&p=6\n\n\nLocal public health office issues tularemia warning\n The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza (inflammation of the mucous membranes lining the nasal cavity), and sore throat. A man in Wichita Falls was recently diagnosed with tularemia - also known as Rabbit Fever. Health officials say it's a rare bacterial infection for this area that comes from tick and deer fly bites, skin contact with infected animals like rabbits and rats, and ingesting contaminated water.\n\nThe Wichita Falls Health Department says they spoke to the man and got some background information including any contact he had with rodents or rabbits and any travel he did to areas in the USA that have the disease.\n\nSymptoms of the disease are normally flu-like - fever, swollen glands and general discomfort. Health officials say they are not sure how he got the disease. They will be meeting shortly to review the case. He told them he had accidentally run over some rabbits while mowing his yard and health officials say he may have come into contact that way.\n\n'The thing that we really want to impress on people - even if this isn't a local transmission - we have the rodent issue this year. There are a lot of rabbits in the area. So if you have a dead animal in your yard do not to handle that with your hands. Be sure to use a plastic bag, a shovel and to put that in the trash and be sure to wash your hands good if you come into contact with any dead animal.'\n\nTularemia can be deadly if the symptoms aren't caught early and the disease progresses. Health department officials say the good news is it can be treated with antimicrobials. The disease cannot be transmitted from person to person - only animal to person. You have to have some contact with either a tick or fly bite or an infected animal.\n\nAccording to family members, the Wichita Falls man with the disease has been transferred to Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas for further treatment.\n\n[Byline: Ava Van Valen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Boulder County Public Health officials investigated last week the 1st case in Boulder County of tularemia, saying a 65-year-old is suspected of contracting the disease after showing symptoms of a fever, swollen lymph nodes and a skin lesion.\n\nThe man reportedly mowed his lawn and worked with a woodpile before showing symptoms. Officials released a warning to the public, saying residents should be cautious while working outside of dead animals. Tularemia is transmitted by contact with dead animals, particularly through tick and deer fly bites, or skin contact with infected animals. Rabbits and rodents are most commonly carriers of the disease.\n\nOfficials listed some top tips for avoiding contracting the disease:\n- Use a long-handled shovel to pick up dead animals, double bagging them to dispose of their bodies.\n- While working outside, use DEET-infused insect repellants.\n- Wash any cuts or scratches incurred from outdoors work as quickly as possible.\n- Don't let pets drink from groundwater.\n- Never mow over animal carcasses.\n\nSee a doctor immediately if you quickly contract a fever or swollen lymph nodes after outside work.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013. TULAREMIA - USA (11): (COLORADO) ULCEROGLANDULAR\n************************************************\n \nA Boulder resident is suspected of being the 1st to contract tularemia in 2016, prompting warnings from health officials. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013. Boulder [Colorado] investigates 1st resident with tularemia in 2016\n The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza (inflammation of the mucous membranes lining the nasal cavity), and sore throat.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boulder County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4396768", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (10): (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4396768", "date": "2016-08-07 18:12:57", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (10): (WYOMING)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 1 Aug 2016\nSource: Rock Springs Rocket Miner [edited]\nhttp://wyomingbusinessreport.com/tularemia-case-prompts-warning/\n\n\nWith the recent report of a man in Sweetwater County contracting tularemia, Sweetwater County Health Officer Jean Stachon asks people to be aware and take precautions. 'This is the season for tularemia and other diseases like giardia,' Stachon said. 'The rule of thumb is don't take a rabbit before it freezes.'\n\nTularemia can be a serious disease and, in rare cases, deadly, according to the Wyoming Department of Health. Also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, it frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents and has been associated with rabbit and rodent die-offs. People may acquire tularemia when bitten by infected ticks, deer flies or horse flies. It can also be transmitted by handling infected animals, or through ingestion or contact with untreated, contaminated water or insufficiently cooked meat.\n\nSymptoms of tularemia can include fever, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, skin ulcers and diarrhea. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough and progressive weakness and pneumonia. Stachon said people should be aware of the symptoms; anyone who suspects their illness may be tularemia should review their activities and where they have been recreating. People recreating outdoors should be aware and take precautions, she added.\n\nThough life-threatening if not treated, tularemia responds quickly to antimicrobials, and because the symptoms mimic other illnesses, people are encouraged to tell their doctor if any tularemia exposure is possible, according to the state health department.\n\n[Byline: Ann Jantz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person, essentially in contradiction to another Category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted.\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _Francisella tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nReferences:\n1. Foshay L: Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937;60: 22-38.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W: Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am 2010;24: 43-55.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThough life-threatening if not treated, tularemia responds quickly to antimicrobials, and because the symptoms mimic other illnesses, people are encouraged to tell their doctor if any tularemia exposure is possible, according to the state health department. \n\nSymptoms of tularemia can include fever, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, skin ulcers and diarrhea. TULAREMIA - USA (10): (WYOMING)\n*******************************\n A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nReferences:\n1. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, it frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents and has been associated with rabbit and rodent die-offs. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. \n\nTularemia can be a serious disease and, in rare cases, deadly, according to the Wyoming Department of Health. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough and progressive weakness and pneumonia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweetwater County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4388644", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (09): (CO) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4388644", "date": "2016-08-02 16:25:56", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (09): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 26 Jul 2016\nSource: Mesa County Health Department News [edited]\nhttp://www.mesacountyhealth.com/2016/07/rabbit-from-area-southwest-of-fruita.html\n\n\nAnother Mesa County rabbit has tested positive for tularemia from an area southwest of Fruita. This area is a popular recreational space for hikers, bikers and rafters.\n\nThe bacterial disease is transmitted through direct contact with infected animals, such as rabbits, squirrels, muskrats and other rodents through tick and deer fly bites.\n\nThis is the 2nd rabbit to test positive for tularemia, this summer [2016]. The 1st rabbit was from the east side of the Redlands. The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and Mesa County Health Department urge residents to take precautions while spending time in these areas and anywhere else wildlife is active.\n\n[Byline: Katie Goddeyne]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. \n\nThe bacterial disease is transmitted through direct contact with infected animals, such as rabbits, squirrels, muskrats and other rodents through tick and deer fly bites. TULAREMIA - USA (09): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\n In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nThis is the 2nd rabbit to test positive for tularemia, this summer [2016].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mesa County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Fruita", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4366704", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (MN) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4366704", "date": "2016-07-25 11:13:21", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (08): (MINNESOTA) FELINE\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jul 2016\nSource: KARE 11 [edited]\nhttp://www.kare11.com/news/local/spike-in-rare-cat-disease-puts-twin-cities-pet-owners-on-alert/279956255\n\n\nThe dog days of summer poses a new threat for cats in the Twin Cities [Minneapolis-Saint Paul, Minnesota]: experts are seeing a spike in a rare disease typically contracted by cats that hunt.\n\nAccording to veterinarians at the University of Minnesota Veterinary Medical Center, they've treated 8 confirmed or suspected cases of tularemia. Officials typically see only a few cases each year. '5 of those cats did not make it and 3 did, including one that we treated here,' said Dr Jennifer Granick, who works in the Small Animal Internal Medicine Department at the University of Minnesota Veterinary Medical Center.\n\nGranick said the disease is caused by a bacterial infection often carried by rabbits, which means hunting cats are at the greatest risk of catching the disease. But ticks and flies can also transmit the disease through bites.\n\nGranick notes pet owners should look out for the classic signs, including high fevers and disinterest in eating. If caught early enough, the disease can be cured with a combination of antibiotics.\n\nAs for dogs and people, both can also contract the disease. However, dogs rarely show signs of the disease, and only a couple people are diagnosed with the disease every year. Experts recommend people beware any signs of the disease in their cats and get medical attention if they see those signs in themselves.\n\nFinal recommendation from experts: try to keep your cats indoors. But veterinarians also recognize that's not possible for all cats. Given that, they encourage owners to monitor their cats' outdoor activity -- to try to curb hunting -- and also use flea and tick preventions.\n\n[Byline: Karla Jult]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia (caused by a bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_) is a rare but potentially fatal disease that occurs in wild and domestic animals. Rabbits and wild rodents are the primary species affected (hence the nickname) but other species, including humans, can also contract the disease.\n\nDogs do become infected with the causative organism, but it appears that resulting illness, if it occurs, does not produce clinical signs or is mild. On the other hand, domestic cats are very susceptible to tularemia and have been known to transmit the bacteria to humans. It's also important to note that cats don't need to be clinically sick in order to transmit the disease.\n\nThe bacterium that causes tularemia can be found in the organs or body fluids of infected animals. Once in the environment, the organisms can survive for weeks to months in the soil, vegetation, or water and then serve as a source of infection for other animals or humans. Animals typically get tularemia by ingesting contaminated food (raw meat from infected animals) or by drinking contaminated water. They can also inhale the aerosolized bacteria, have it enter their bodies through mucus membranes or breaks/cuts in skin, or become infected by biting flies or ticks.\n\nClinical signs in cats\n----------------------\nThe signs of a tularemia infection can vary remarkably; they range from no signs at all, to mild fever and enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) to death. When they're sick, cats may also be anorexic, dehydrated, or listless with ulcers, abscesses, jaundice, pneumonia, and/or enlargement of their livers or spleens. Outdoor cats may be particularly good at not showing clinical signs until the disease is quite advanced.\n\nDiagnosis and treatment\n-----------------------\nIf your veterinarian is suspicious your cat might have tularemia, then special serologic blood tests looking for antibodies against the bacteria are likely to be run. Unfortunately, because it takes time for your cat's immune system to mount a detectable response, these tests may not be diagnostic during the 1st few weeks of illness. A definitive diagnosis can also be made if the organism can be cultured from tissue specimens on special culture media.\n\nOnce infection with tularemia is diagnosed or suspected, antibiotics are usually effective in treating the illness -- especially when given early in the disease. Recovery from the infection does produce long-lasting immunity.\n\nEfforts are underway to develop safe and effective vaccines for pets and people.\n\nPrevention of tularemia\n-----------------------\nThe only way to completely protect your cat from infection is to keep your animal free of ticks and other biting insects. Also, keep your animal indoors away from the opportunity to hunt or to encounter the organism in the environment. It is important, however, to remember that you are also at risk. The most common source of infection for people is the bite of an infected tick, so take care when gardening, clearing weeds/brush, or even mowing lawns.\n\nAdditional information regarding tularemia may be found in the moderator's comments of ProMED-mail post 20160603.4262502.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.pethealthnetwork.com/cat-health/cat-diseases-conditions-a-z/tularemia-rabbit-fever-cats/page/0/1. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16848.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOnce infection with tularemia is diagnosed or suspected, antibiotics are usually effective in treating the illness -- especially when given early in the disease. Granick said the disease is caused by a bacterial infection often carried by rabbits, which means hunting cats are at the greatest risk of catching the disease. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia (caused by a bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_) is a rare but potentially fatal disease that occurs in wild and domestic animals. \n\nClinical signs in cats\n The dog days of summer poses a new threat for cats in the Twin Cities [Minneapolis-Saint Paul, Minnesota]: experts are seeing a spike in a rare disease typically contracted by cats that hunt. Experts recommend people beware any signs of the disease in their cats and get medical attention if they see those signs in themselves. \n\nDogs do become infected with the causative organism, but it appears that resulting illness, if it occurs, does not produce clinical signs or is mild. However, dogs rarely show signs of the disease, and only a couple people are diagnosed with the disease every year. The signs of a tularemia infection can vary remarkably; they range from no signs at all, to mild fever and enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) to death. TULAREMIA - USA (08): (MINNESOTA) FELINE\n****************************************\n \n\nPrevention of tularemia\n Outdoor cats may be particularly good at not showing clinical signs until the disease is quite advanced. \n\nAdditional information regarding tularemia may be found in the moderator's comments of ProMED-mail post 20160603.4262502. [Byline: Karla Jult]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nFinal recommendation from experts: try to keep your cats indoors. \n\nDiagnosis and treatment\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Minneapolis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4333270", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (AZ) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4333270", "date": "2016-07-08 13:06:55", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (ARIZONA) FATAL\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 8 Jul 2016\nSource: Arizona Daily Sun [edited]\nhttp://azdailysun.com/news/local/rabbit-fever-death-confirmed-in-coconino-county/article_f00711cf-ff4a-5ef3-8622-1bba095b05bc.html\n\n\nAn individual in the Flagstaff area that contracted tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, has died from the illness, the Coconino County public health department announced Thu 7 Jul 2016. This is the first confirmed case of tularemia in Coconino County in 2016 and the first fatal case in more than a decade. There have been 4 human cases of tularemia in Coconino County since 2005, 2 confirmed cases in 2005 and 2 in 2015, none of which were fatal.\n\nTularemia is a bacterial disease that infects rabbits and other mammals. It does not spread from person to person but can be transmitted to humans through the skinning and cleaning of game animals, usually rabbits, through deer fly and tick bites, by eating or drinking contaminated food or water or by pets who have contracted the disease.\n\nIn Arizona, tularemia activity occurs in elevations above 3000 feet. The disease can be severe and fatal if not treated properly and immediately with antimicrobial therapy.\n\nA person infected with tularemia may show a variety of symptoms, including an ulcer or sore at the site of exposure, painful swelling of regional lymph nodes (usually in the armpit, elbow, groin, or neck area), fever, chills, headache, muscle aches and nausea. Tularemia-like symptoms appear 1 to 14 days, but usually 3 to 5 days, after skinning game, or after being bitten by deer flies or ticks. People can also develop pneumonia and may have symptoms including chest pain, bloody sputum and trouble breathing.\n\nThe Coconino County Public Health Services District recommends the following illness prevention guidelines:\n- Avoid contact with wild animals.\n- Do not handle sick or dead animals.\n- Wear protective equipment, such as gloves and mask when hunting and handling animals.\n- Protect against insect bites when hiking, camping or working outdoors. Wear insect repellent containing DEET or treat clothing with repellent containing permethrin.\n- Do not drink untreated water.\n- Avoid exposure to rodent burrows, fleas and ticks. Stay out of areas wild rodents inhabit.\n- Prevent pets from roaming loose. Pets can pick up the infected fleas or ticks from wild animals, and then pass fleas on to their human owners. De-flea pets routinely.\n- Take sick pets (dogs and cats) to a veterinarian.\n- Seek care from a health care provider if experiencing symptoms.\n\n[Byline: Emery Cowan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe infection does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another Category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _Francisella tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nReferences\n1. Foshay L: Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937;60: 22-38.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W: Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am 2010;24: 43-55. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/207.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n It does not spread from person to person but can be transmitted to humans through the skinning and cleaning of game animals, usually rabbits, through deer fly and tick bites, by eating or drinking contaminated food or water or by pets who have contracted the disease. The infection does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another Category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted\n\n_F. tularensis_ infection can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. \n\nThe Coconino County Public Health Services District recommends the following illness prevention guidelines:\n- Avoid contact with wild animals. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. \n\n\nAn individual in the Flagstaff area that contracted tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, has died from the illness, the Coconino County public health department announced Thu 7 Jul 2016. Tularemia-like symptoms appear 1 to 14 days, but usually 3 to 5 days, after skinning game, or after being bitten by deer flies or ticks. \n\nReferences\n1. \n- Wear protective equipment, such as gloves and mask when hunting and handling animals. [Byline: Emery Cowan]\n\n--\n \n- Do not handle sick or dead animals. \n- Avoid exposure to rodent burrows, fleas and ticks. Pets can pick up the infected fleas or ticks from wild animals, and then pass fleas on to their human owners. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Coconino County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4350932", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (07): (CO) wild rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4350932", "date": "2016-07-17 14:19:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Jul 2016\nSource: KRDO [edited]\nhttp://www.krdo.com/news/Pueblo-County-rabbit-tests-positive-for-Tularemia/40732732\n\n\nPueblo County [Colorado] rabbit tests positive for tularemia\n------------------------------------------------------------\nRabbit fever has again been confirmed in Pueblo County.\n\nA rabbit that was collected from the Hatchet Ranch area in the southwestern part of the county has tested positive for tularemia.\n\n'Pueblo residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares, and on the ground where these animals may be active,' said Vicki Carlton, program manager in the Environmental Health and Emergency Preparedness division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. 'Although there are no human cases of tularemia identified in Pueblo so far this year [2016], Colorado has experienced human tularemia cases in people who have been exposed to contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria,' she said.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics; therefore should you have any of these early signs, contact your medical provider.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to a veterinarian promptly. Tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\nRecommended precautions include:\n\n- Avoid handling wild animals.\n\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n\n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. Do not mow over animal carcasses.\n\n- Leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals.\n\n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets.\n\n- If a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Wear insect repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a long-handled shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a garbage bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands with soap and water afterwards.\n\n- Wear proper footwear outdoors where dead animals have been found.\n\n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping.\n\n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities.\n\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters.\n\n- If you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps: Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits. Cook the meat of wild rabbits thoroughly to a temperature of 165 degrees F or higher.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information is quoted from 'Tularemia Surveillance' (last modified on 24 Jul 2015) on the APHIS-USDA National Wildlife Disease Program (NWDP) website, available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/wildlifedamage/programs/SA_NWDP/CT_Tularemia.\n\n'Tularemia has been identified as a disease of concern to human, wildlife and domestic animal populations within the United States. It, like plague, is considered a 'Category A' disease by the Department of Homeland Security, meaning it could potentially be used as a bioterrorist agent.\n\nLocation\nTularemia is found most often in the South-Central and Western US, mostly in rural areas. It is also found internationally, throughout the Northern Hemisphere in places like Japan, Russia and Scandinavia.\n\nDisease Agent\nTularemia is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nAffected Species\nTularemia mostly affects, and is reservoired within, a variety of mammals including (but not limited to) beavers, water voles, rabbits, hares, skunks and coyotes.\n\nThe disease is not contagious from human to human, but can be spread by the bites of fleas, ticks and other arthropods that have fed on infected wildlife, or by contact with the carcass of the infected animal. Reported human cases of tularemia in the United States currently average about 200 yearly, a dramatic reduction from the over 1000 cases per year that occurred in the 1930s and 1940s.\n\nNWDP Activities\nNWDP biologists and their collaborators are currently sampling aquatic rodents and other susceptible species across the US to detect the presence of tularemia antibodies in their blood. Due to the focus on early detection, local health professionals can be alerted when tularemia is present in a region and take this into consideration when examining certain symptoms.\n\nIn humans, tularemia 1st emerges as a flu-like illness. Depending on the method of exposure to the bacterium, infected individuals may also experience lesions, swollen lymph glands and even the development of pneumonia. When these symptoms are positively identified as tularemia, they can be treated with prescription antibiotics.' - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/903.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nAffected Species\nTularemia mostly affects, and is reservoired within, a variety of mammals including (but not limited to) beavers, water voles, rabbits, hares, skunks and coyotes. \n\nNWDP Activities\nNWDP biologists and their collaborators are currently sampling aquatic rodents and other susceptible species across the US to detect the presence of tularemia antibodies in their blood. \n\nThe disease is not contagious from human to human, but can be spread by the bites of fleas, ticks and other arthropods that have fed on infected wildlife, or by contact with the carcass of the infected animal. \n\nRecommended precautions include:\n\n- Avoid handling wild animals. \n\nDisease Agent\nTularemia is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Although there are no human cases of tularemia identified in Pueblo so far this year [2016], Colorado has experienced human tularemia cases in people who have been exposed to contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria,' she said. \n\nLocation\nTularemia is found most often in the South-Central and Western US, mostly in rural areas. \n\n'Tularemia has been identified as a disease of concern to human, wildlife and domestic animal populations within the United States. \n\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information is quoted from 'Tularemia Surveillance' (last modified on 24 Jul 2015) on the APHIS-USDA National Wildlife Disease Program (NWDP) website, available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/wildlifedamage/programs/SA_NWDP/CT_Tularemia. Pueblo residents are advised that tularemia-causing bacteria may be present in some of the mammals -- especially rabbits, rodents and hares, and on the ground where these animals may be active,' said Vicki Carlton, program manager in the Environmental Health and Emergency Preparedness division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. ' TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO) WILD RABBIT\n********************************************\n \n\nA rabbit that was collected from the Hatchet Ranch area in the southwestern part of the county has tested positive for tularemia. \n\n--\n \n\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters. \n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2015-07-24 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Pueblo City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4318916", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (04): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4318916", "date": "2016-06-30 16:00:13", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 Jun 2016\nSource: Broomfield Colorado News Center [edited]\nhttp://www.broomfield.org/index.aspx?NID=671\n\n\nA Broomfield resident has tested positive for tularemia. Tularemia is a disease of animals and humans caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Although tularemia is a potentially serious disease, it is treatable with common antimicrobials. The Broomfield resident has been treated after being evaluated by a health care provider and is recovering. Tularemia is not known to be spread from person to person. People become infected with tularemia by: breathing in the bacteria; contact with contaminated soil; handling infected animal carcasses; being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect; or by eating or drinking contaminated food or water.\n\n'In recent years, there has been a significant increase in cases believed to be the result of exposure to bacteria contaminated soil,' said Jason Vahling, Broomfield County public health director. 'People should take precautions when gardening or landscaping because when a person mows, blows leaves, or turns up the soil, the bacteria can be aerosolized and inhaled,' said Vahling.\n\nAccording to the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, this is the 3rd reported human case of tularemia in Colorado in 2016, and a 4th is under investigation. In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013.\n\nDepending on the exposure, symptoms may include: abrupt onset of fever, skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Patients can also have chills, headache, muscle aches, cough, or difficulty breathing. Symptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure to the bacteria, but can take as long as 14 days.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The clinical manifestations of human tularemia in this case are not stated and depend on the route of entry of the organism into the body. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza (inflammation of the mucous membranes lining the nasal cavity), and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness. Some illnesses manifest as an undifferentiated febrile illness which is called the typhoidal form. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n People become infected with tularemia by: breathing in the bacteria; contact with contaminated soil; handling infected animal carcasses; being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect; or by eating or drinking contaminated food or water. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza (inflammation of the mucous membranes lining the nasal cavity), and sore throat. \n\n'In recent years, there has been a significant increase in cases believed to be the result of exposure to bacteria contaminated soil,' said Jason Vahling, Broomfield County public health director. ' In 2015, 52 cases of human tularemia were reported in Colorado, more than 10 times the typical number of 0-4 cases reported annually from 1954-2013. TULAREMIA - USA (04): (COLORADO)\n********************************\n Depending on the exposure, symptoms may include: abrupt onset of fever, skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The clinical manifestations of human tularemia in this case are not stated and depend on the route of entry of the organism into the body.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Broomfield County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Broomfield", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4317126", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Netherlands", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4317126", "date": "2016-06-30 15:25:13", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NETHERLANDS\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Jun 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/tularemia-in-the-netherlands-two-people-infected-in-1st-half-of-2016/\n\n\nAt least 2 people have been infected with tularemia, or hare plague in the Netherlands during the first 6 months of 2016, according to a Wageningen UR report Monday [27 Jun 2016] (computer translated).\n\nThe report notes that the 1st individual, from the province of Utrecht, most likely contracted the serious bacterial infection while skinning a hare. The 2nd patient with tularemia in 2016 is from the province of South Holland in the Vijfheerenlanden region. This patient had no known contact with hares. The report notes that human tularemia has not been seen in the Netherlands since 2011.\n\nAlso known as rabbit fever and deer fly fever, tularemia is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. This bacterium is found in nature in rabbits, rodents, beavers, squirrels and several domestic and farm animals.\n\nPeople commonly get infected from the bites of infected ticks (wood, dog) and deer flies. Hunters are at risk of infection following skinning, dressing and eating infected animals. Drinking contaminated water has been implicated in tularemia infection. People also contract it through inhaling dust and hay that have rodent feces and carcasses. There have been cases where people got infected from a domestic cat. It is believed that cats get the organism from contaminated prey and their mouth and claws become infected. Certain animal-associated occupations are also associated with the disease: farmers, veterinarians, sheepherders and shearers.\n\nThe disease in people depends on how it is acquired. After infection, incubation can be a couple of days to weeks, with non-specific symptoms like fever, chills, headache, sore throat and diarrhea. The way the organism enters the body frequently dictates the disease and degree of systemic involvement. The 6 syndromes are ulceroglandular, glandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal, typhoidal and the one with the highest mortality rate, pneumonic tularemia.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University, Fact Sheet on Tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals. Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative coccobacillus in the family Francisellaceae. A total of 4 subspecies are currently recognized. Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp. tularensis (also known as type A) has been found almost exclusively in North America. It is the most virulent species, particularly in humans. _F. tularensis_ subsp. holarctica (type B) is much more widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere, but it is less virulent. The 2 remaining species, _F. tularensis_ subsp. mediasiatica and _F. tularensis_ subsp. novicida, have been recognized in limited geographical regions, are rarely found in people, and seem to cause relatively mild disease when they occur. Additional subspecies have also been proposed.\n\n'With rare exceptions, tularemia occurs only in the Northern Hemisphere. This disease has been reported from North America, Europe, parts of Asia and the Middle East, and northern Africa. A single human case, caused by _F. tularensis novicida_, was acquired in Australia.\n\n'Among the Northern Hemisphere, _F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. Contrarily, _F. tularensis holarctica_ is widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere. This species is responsible for nearly all cases of tularemia outside North America. It co-exists with _F. tularensis tularensis_ in North America. _F. tularensis mediasiatica_ occurs in a limited area of Central Asia, and _F. tularensis novicida_ has been reported from North America, Australia and Spain.\n\n'Humans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. Hunting or skinning animals, or contact with meat when preparing food, are important routes of exposure. Respiratory infections sometimes occur in farmers who are exposed through activities such as piling hay. Cases have been reported after mowing lawns, possibly from running over an animal carcass. Human infections have also been linked to handling infected animals or being bitten by them. Person-to-person transmission has not been reported.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/104.]", "summary": "\n\n'Humans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University, Fact Sheet on Tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals. \n\nAlso known as rabbit fever and deer fly fever, tularemia is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp. Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative coccobacillus in the family Francisellaceae. _F. tularensis mediasiatica_ occurs in a limited area of Central Asia, and _F. tularensis novicida_ has been reported from North America, Australia and Spain. \n\nPeople commonly get infected from the bites of infected ticks (wood, dog) and deer flies. Among the Northern Hemisphere, _F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. \n\n\nAt least 2 people have been infected with tularemia, or hare plague in the Netherlands during the first 6 months of 2016, according to a Wageningen UR report Monday \n\nThe report notes that the 1st individual, from the province of Utrecht, most likely contracted the serious bacterial infection while skinning a hare. Hunters are at risk of infection following skinning, dressing and eating infected animals. tularensis (also known as type A) has been found almost exclusively in North America. A single human case, caused by _F. tularensis novicida_, was acquired in Australia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-06-27 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Vijfheerenlanden", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Utrecht", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4289092", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia - USA (NM) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4289092", "date": "2016-06-15 14:41:39", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA - USA (NEW MEXICO): ALERT\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 June 2016\nSource: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.abqjournal.com/791345/tularemia-plague-in-pets-higher-than-average.html\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health has confirmed 10 cases of plague and 19 cases of tularemia in dogs and cats - 'higher than average' this year - in multiple counties.\n\nPlague-positive pets have been reported in Los Alamos, Rio Arriba, Sandoval, Santa Fe, Taos and Torrance counties; while pet positive tests for tularemia have been reported in Bernalillo, Los Alamos, Sandoval and Santa Fe counties.\n\nPlague and tularemia are bacterial diseases of rodents and rabbits. Human contraction of plague is generally from flea bites, while human contraction of tularemia is from deer fly bites, Department of Health veterinarian Dr. Paul Ettestad said Mon [14 Jun 2016]. These illnesses also can be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including pets.\n\nEttestad said the contraction rate of both plague and tularemia this year 'is higher than average, but not on a record pace.' In New Mexico, plague and tularemia are more prevalent in the spring and early summer.\n\n'We are seeing recent die-offs of rabbits in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' Ettestad said. 'People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents or fleas outdoors. Exposure to tularemia can occur from bites from deer flies or handling infected animals or pets which have been exposed,' he said.\n\nSymptoms of plague and tularemia in humans are similar and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, weakness, swollen lymph nodes and possible infection at the bite site, Ettestad said. Likewise, he noted, signs of plague and tularemia in cats and dogs are similar, and include fever, lethargy, loss of appetite and possible swelling in the lymph node under the jaw.\n\nThe only sure way to distinguish the difference between these is through laboratory testing, he said. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. According to statistics compiled by the Department of Health for 2015, 4 people in New Mexico contracted plague, with 1 fatality in Santa Fe County, and 8 cases of tularemia were confirmed, with no fatalities. There were also 63 confirmed cases of tularemia in dogs and cats in 2015, and 18 confirmed pet plague cases.\n\n[Byline: Rick Nathanson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fleas and ticks are the guilty party in spreading these diseases to other animals, including our pets and us. Protecting our pets and ourselves from fleas and ticks is primary. Flea and tick collars around your ankles when hiking these areas can be helpful. For pets there are generally once-a-month treatments available that work very well.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations, with some species being particularly susceptible. Free-ranging carnivores, including feral cats, are particularly exposed to plague as they prey on its reservoir.\n\nTularemia is a bacterial septicemia that affects, aside from people, more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles and fish. It is listed as a category A bioterrorism agent because of the potential for fatality, airborne dissemination, and societal disruption if released. The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a nonspore-forming, Gram-negative coccobacillus antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors.\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but people who prepare or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. Case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. - Mod.TG\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nSymptoms of plague and tularemia in humans are similar and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, weakness, swollen lymph nodes and possible infection at the bite site, Ettestad said. 'People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents or fleas outdoors. \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but people who prepare or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. The New Mexico Department of Health has confirmed 10 cases of plague and 19 cases of tularemia in dogs and cats - 'higher than average' this year - in multiple counties. There were also 63 confirmed cases of tularemia in dogs and cats in 2015, and 18 confirmed pet plague cases. \n\nEttestad said the contraction rate of both plague and tularemia this year 'is higher than average, but not on a record pace.' Human contraction of plague is generally from flea bites, while human contraction of tularemia is from deer fly bites, Department of Health veterinarian Dr. Paul Ettestad said Mon [14 Jun 2016]. \n\n'We are seeing recent die-offs of rabbits in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' Ettestad said. Likewise, he noted, signs of plague and tularemia in cats and dogs are similar, and include fever, lethargy, loss of appetite and possible swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. According to statistics compiled by the Department of Health for 2015, 4 people in New Mexico contracted plague, with 1 fatality in Santa Fe County, and 8 cases of tularemia were confirmed, with no fatalities. \n\nTularemia is a bacterial septicemia that affects, aside from people, more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles and fish. Plague-positive pets have been reported in Los Alamos, Rio Arriba, Sandoval, Santa Fe, Taos and Torrance counties; while pet positive tests for tularemia have been reported in Bernalillo, Los Alamos, Sandoval and Santa Fe counties. Exposure to tularemia can occur from bites from deer flies or handling infected animals or pets which have been exposed,' he said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-06-14 00:00:00", "2016-06-13 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Bernalillo", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Los Alamos", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sandoval", "country": "Bolivia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4342491", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (06): (NM) increased range", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4342491", "date": "2016-07-13 14:47:09", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (06): (NEW MEXICO) INCREASED RANGE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Jul 2016\nSource: New Mexico Department of Health [edited]\nhttps://nmhealth.org/news/disease/2016/7/?view=443\n\n\nThe City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department, the New Mexico Department of Health, and the Bernalillo County Health Protection Section announced today [12 Jul 2016] that 2 cases of human tularemia have been confirmed from Bernalillo County, with one of the individuals likely being exposed in the bosque [In the predominantly arid or semi-arid southwestern United States, the bosque is an oasis-like ribbon of green vegetation, often canopied, that only exists near rivers, streams, or other water courses. It derives its name from the Spanish word for woodlands. - Mod.LL]. These are the 1st 2 laboratory confirmed human cases in New Mexico in 2016.\n\nThe cases include a 74-year-old man and a 71-year-old woman. The woman is currently hospitalized but is improving, while the man has fully recovered. Health authorities are investigating both cases, with a special emphasis on the case that appears to have resulted from exposure in the bosque. It is believed that the illness was the result of a bite from an infected deer fly in the area.\n\n'Tularemia exposure in the Rio Grande bosque area appears to be a new development for us that we are taking seriously,' said Dr Mark DiMenna, Deputy Director at the City's Environmental Health Department. 'We have historically warned Bernalillo County residents in the East Mountains and along the northern and eastern reaches of the city limits about tularemia risks, but this may represent a new area to be concerned about.'\n\nWhile the possibility of tularemia transmission in the bosque is a concern, City health officials urge appropriate precautions rather than avoiding use of the bosque. Avoiding sick or dead rodents and preventing deer fly bites are key measures to reduce risk. 'We would like to ask people who are using the bosque trails to report any dead or dying animals they see to us through 311,' added Dr DiMenna. 'We will submit those animals for testing as we investigate the extent of tularemia in the area.'\n\n'Tularemia can cause serious illness in both people and pets. We urge New Mexicans to follow the same precautions they would to avoid contracting plague, which includes not handling sick or dead animals,' said Department of Health Secretary Lynn Gallagher. 'People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals such as rabbits or rodents or if they are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies.'\n\nIn 2014 there were 5 human cases of tularemia in New Mexico, and in 2015 there were 6 human cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recognized vectors of _Francisella tularensis_ in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). Many cases are acquired, without a vector, by direct or indirect exposure to infected animals including aerosols from lawn mowers and water from direct contamination. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1843. Bernalillo County in central New Mexico can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "The City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department, the New Mexico Department of Health, and the Bernalillo County Health Protection Section announced today [12 Jul 2016] that 2 cases of human tularemia have been confirmed from Bernalillo County, with one of the individuals likely being exposed in the bosque [In the predominantly arid or semi-arid southwestern United States, the bosque is an oasis-like ribbon of green vegetation, often canopied, that only exists near rivers, streams, or other water courses. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIn 2014 there were 5 human cases of tularemia in New Mexico, and in 2015 there were 6 human cases. \n\nWhile the possibility of tularemia transmission in the bosque is a concern, City health officials urge appropriate precautions rather than avoiding use of the bosque. \n\n'Tularemia exposure in the Rio Grande bosque area appears to be a new development for us that we are taking seriously,' said Dr Mark DiMenna, Deputy Director at the City's Environmental Health Department. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Recognized vectors of _Francisella tularensis_ in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).
