TULAREMIA - USA (06): (NEW MEXICO) INCREASED RANGE\n**************************************************\n People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals such as rabbits or rodents or if they are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Health authorities are investigating both cases, with a special emphasis on the case that appears to have resulted from exposure in the bosque.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Rio Grande", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4295395", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (03): (CO) pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4295395", "date": "2016-06-18 14:43:10", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (03): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 17 Jun 2016 12:49:08 PM MDT\nSource: Fort Collins (CO) Reporter-Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.reporterherald.com/news/ci_30027950/larimer-reports-first-human-case-tularemia\n\n\nThe Larimer County [Colorado] Department of Health and Environment announced [Fri 17 Jun 2016], that a [Fort Collins] resident, who has not been identified, developed a lung infection in late May 2016 and was hospitalized. He or she is now home recovering from the infection, which is commonly referred to as rabbit fever because of the animal that most commonly carries the bacterium.\n\nPeople can become infected by handling infected animals, through an insect bite, from contaminated food, or by the droppings or urine of a sick animal. The bacterium in the animal waste can turn to aerosol, and when people mow or turn up the soil, they can inhale the infection.\n\nHealth officials believe that is how the Fort Collins resident contracted tularemia, according to a written release. 'This person did a lot of lawn mowing and gardening,' said Katie O'Donnell, spokeswoman for the health department.\n\nTularemia varies in severity from mild illness to even death, though fatalities from the condition are rare, according to health officials. Signs of infection include fever, chills, headache, fatigue, and swollen and painful lymph glands. If the condition is contracted from an insect bite, it often causes a skin ulcer and swollen glands, according to the Larimer health department. If it is contracted through food or water, it may result in a throat infection, mouth ulcers, stomach pain, diarrhea, and vomiting. Inhaling the infection can lead to chest pain and coughing. The condition can be treated with antimicrobials, so residents with these symptoms are encouraged to seek medical attention.\n\nThe frequency of human cases appears to be increasing. The Colorado Department of Health and Environment reports 94 total confirmed cases from 2005 through 2015. Of those, 52 occurred in 2015. Larimer County has 12 total reports during that same 10-year period, according to the state health department. 9 of those were in 2015, O'Donnell said.\n\nThe bacterium that causes tularemia naturally occurs in rabbits, hares, small rodents, voles, muskrats, and beavers. Therefore, any signs of these species dying off throughout a neighborhood indicate a possible outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Pamela Johnson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 17 Jun 2016\nSource: Larimer County Department of Health and Environment [edited]\nhttps://www.larimer.org/news/newsDetail.cfm?id=4243\n\n\nThe Larimer County Department of Health and Environment has confirmed the 1st human case of tularemia in a county resident in 2016. This patient developed a lung infection, and may have been exposed while mowing the yard or gardening at home in an urban subdivision. Soil can be contaminated by tularemia-causing bacteria from the droppings or urine of sick animals, most often rabbits. When a person mows, blows leaves, or turns up the soil, these bacteria can aerosolize and be inhaled, causing pneumonic tularemia.\n\nAll warm-blooded animals are susceptible to tularemia, including livestock and pets such as dogs, cats, and birds, however these bacteria normally occur in nature in rabbits and hares, as well as in small rodents, voles, muskrats, and beavers. A recent die-off of rabbits or rodents in a neighborhood suggests a possible tularemia outbreak among the animals in that area. The bacteria these animals shed can persist in the soil or water for weeks, and it takes very few bacteria to cause an infection.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted to people, such as hunters, who have handled infected animals. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (most commonly ticks and deer flies); by exposure to contaminated food, water, or soil; by eating, drinking, putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth before washing after outdoor activities; by direct contact with breaks in the skin; or by inhaling particles carrying the bacteria (through mowing or blowing vegetation and excavating soil). In recent years, most human tularemia cases along the Front Range have been attributed to activities involving soil and vegetation.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans may include fever, chills, headache, swollen, and painful lymph glands, and fatigue. If tularemia is caused by the bite of an infected insect or from bacteria entering a cut or scratch, it usually causes a skin ulcer or pustule and swollen glands. Eating or drinking food or water containing the bacteria may produce a throat infection, mouth ulcers, stomach pain, diarrhea, and vomiting. Inhaling the bacteria may cause an infection of the lungs with chest pain and coughing.\n\nTularemia can be effectively treated with antimicrobials. Should you have any of these early signs, seek medical attention as soon as possible. Untreated tularemia can lead to hospitalization and may be fatal if not diagnosed and treated appropriately.\n\nGardeners, landscapers, mowers, outdoor workers, and others participating in leisure activities outside are advised to:\n- wear gloves when gardening or planting trees, and always wash hands before eating or putting hands to mouth, nose, or eyes;\n- wear a dust mask when mowing or blowing vegetation, or excavating or tilling soil;\n- wear an insect repellent effective against ticks, biting flies, and mosquitoes (DEET, picaridin, or IR3535 are good choices);\n- wear shoes, rather than going barefoot, on grassy lawns, especially if dead rabbits or rodents have been seen in the neighborhood;\n- never touch dead animals with bare hands\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks veterinarian Dr Bob Peterson (<bpeterson@hqrllc.com>) who also contributed this report.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/821. Larimer County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe following is extracted from\nPedati C, House J, Hancock-Allen J, et al: Notes from the Field: Increase in Human Cases of Tularemia -- Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming, January-September 2015.\nMMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2015 Dec 4;64(47):1317-8; http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6447a4.htm:\n\n'Approximately 125 cases have been reported annually in the USA during the last 2 decades. As of 30 Sep 2015, a total of 100 tularemia cases were reported in 2015 among residents of Colorado (n = 43), Nebraska (n = 21), South Dakota (n = 20), and Wyoming (n = 16). This represents a substantial increase in the annual mean number of 4 (975 percent increase), 7 (200 percent), 7 (186 percent) and 2 (70 percent) cases, respectively, reported in each state during 2004-2014.\n\n'Patients ranged in age from 10 months to 89 years (median = 56 years); 74 were male. The most common clinical presentations of tularemia were respiratory disease (pneumonic form, [n = 26]), skin lesions with lymphadenopathy (ulceroglandular form, [n = 26]), and a general febrile illness without localizing signs (typhoidal form, [n = 25]). Overall, 48 persons were hospitalized, and 1 death was reported, in a man aged 85 years. Possible reported exposure routes included animal contact (n = 51), environmental aerosolizing activities (n = 49), and arthropod bites (n = 34); a total of 41 patients reported 2 or more possible exposures.\n\n'Although the cause for the increases in tularemia cases in Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming is unclear, possible explanations might be contributing factors, including increased rainfall promoting vegetation growth, pathogen survival, and increased rodent and rabbit populations. Increased awareness and testing since tularemia was reinstated as a nationally notifiable disease in January 2000 is also a possible explanation for the increase in the number of cases in these 4 states. Health care providers should be aware of the elevated risk for tularemia within these states and consider a diagnosis of tularemia in any person nationwide with compatible signs and symptoms. Residents and visitors to these areas should regularly use insect repellent, wear gloves when handling animals, and avoid mowing in areas where sick or dead animals have been reported.'\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nTularemia does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nGardeners, landscapers, mowers, outdoor workers, and others participating in leisure activities outside are advised to:\n- wear gloves when gardening or planting trees, and always wash hands before eating or putting hands to mouth, nose, or eyes;\n- wear a dust mask when mowing or blowing vegetation, or excavating or tilling soil;\n- wear an insect repellent effective against ticks, biting flies, and mosquitoes (DEET, picaridin, or IR3535 are good choices);\n- wear shoes, rather than going barefoot, on grassy lawns, especially if dead rabbits or rodents have been seen in the neighborhood;\n- never touch dead animals with bare hands\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (most commonly ticks and deer flies); by exposure to contaminated food, water, or soil; by eating, drinking, putting hands to eyes, nose, or mouth before washing after outdoor activities; by direct contact with breaks in the skin; or by inhaling particles carrying the bacteria (through mowing or blowing vegetation and excavating soil). The most common clinical presentations of tularemia were respiratory disease (pneumonic form, [n = 26]), skin lesions with lymphadenopathy (ulceroglandular form, [n = 26]), and a general febrile illness without localizing signs (typhoidal form, [n = 25]). As of 30 Sep 2015, a total of 100 tularemia cases were reported in 2015 among residents of Colorado (n = 43), Nebraska (n = 21), South Dakota (n = 20), and Wyoming (n = 16). Possible reported exposure routes included animal contact (n = 51), environmental aerosolizing activities (n = 49), and arthropod bites (n = 34); a total of 41 patients reported 2 or more possible exposures. \n\nPeople can become infected by handling infected animals, through an insect bite, from contaminated food, or by the droppings or urine of a sick animal. Source: Larimer County Department of Health and Environment [edited]\nhttps://www.larimer.org/news/newsDetail.cfm?id=4243\n\n\nThe Larimer County Department of Health and Environment has confirmed the 1st human case of tularemia in a county resident in 2016. TULAREMIA - USA (03): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\n All warm-blooded animals are susceptible to tularemia, including livestock and pets such as dogs, cats, and birds, however these bacteria normally occur in nature in rabbits and hares, as well as in small rodents, voles, muskrats, and beavers. \n\nThe bacterium that causes tularemia naturally occurs in rabbits, hares, small rodents, voles, muskrats, and beavers. \n\nTypical signs of infection in humans may include fever, chills, headache, swollen, and painful lymph glands, and fatigue. Residents and visitors to these areas should regularly use insect repellent, wear gloves when handling animals, and avoid mowing in areas where sick or dead animals have been reported.' Soil can be contaminated by tularemia-causing bacteria from the droppings or urine of sick animals, most often rabbits. If tularemia is caused by the bite of an infected insect or from bacteria entering a cut or scratch, it usually causes a skin ulcer or pustule and swollen glands. Date: Fri 17 Jun 2016 12:49:08 PM MDT\nSource: Fort Collins (CO) Reporter-Herald [edited]\n The bacteria these animals shed can persist in the soil or water for weeks, and it takes very few bacteria to cause an infection. \n\nTularemia can be transmitted to people, such as hunters, who have handled infected animals. This represents a substantial increase in the annual mean number of 4 (975 percent increase), 7 (200 percent), 7 (186 percent) and 2 (70 percent) cases, respectively, reported in each state during 2004-2014. \n\nTularemia varies in severity from mild illness to even death, though fatalities from the condition are rare, according to health officials. Health care providers should be aware of the elevated risk for tularemia within these states and consider a diagnosis of tularemia in any person nationwide with compatible signs and symptoms. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Although the cause for the increases in tularemia cases in Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming is unclear, possible explanations might be contributing factors, including increased rainfall promoting vegetation growth, pathogen survival, and increased rodent and rabbit populations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2049-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-01-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-06-17 00:00:00", "2015-09-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2043-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3995341", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Ukraine: (KR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3995341", "date": "2016-02-04 18:20:56", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - UKRAINE: (CRIMEA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jan 2016\nSource: Vchaspik.ua [trans. Mod.NP, edited, abbreviated]\nhttp://vchaspik.ua/region/366948v-krymu-vpervye-za-20-let-zaregistrirovan-sluchay-opasnogo-zabolevaniya\n\n\nIn Crimea for the 1st time in 20 years, 2 cases of dangerous zoonotic disease tularemia have been recorded. Cases developed as a result of contact with source of infection, a hare, shot on the territory of the Saksky area near by village of Dobrusina during the hunting season.\n\nThe incident was reported by the territorial Department of the Yevpatoria Interregional Department of Rospotrebnadzor for the Republic of Crimea and Sevastopol.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of disease in this case is not stated. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/22750.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< TULAREMIA - UKRAINE: (CRIMEA)\n*****************************\n \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-22 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Republic of Crimea", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "Dobrusina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Crimea", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4262502", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (02): (MN) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4262502", "date": "2016-06-03 13:27:14", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (MINNESOTA) FELINE\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 May 2016\nSource: University of Minnesota, Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory [edited]\nhttp://www.vdl.umn.edu/news/second-feline-case-tularemia-diagnosed-vdl\n\n\n2nd feline case of tularemia diagnosed at VDL\n---------------------------------------------\nSince April 2016 the University of Minnesota Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory (VDL) has confirmed 3 cases of tularemia in Minnesota.\n\nTularemia is a naturally occurring disease of wildlife, particularly rabbits, squirrels, and other rodents. It is a disease that both people and animals can get through tick and fly bites or contact with infected animals.\n\nTularemia is rare in Minnesota, between 0 and 3 cases are identified in people and 0 to 5 cases are identified in animals annually. To date this year [2016], the 3 cases have been identified in a cottontail rabbit and 2 cats -- all in the Twin Cities [Minneapolis-Saint Paul] metropolitan area.\n\nCats are the most commonly affected domestic animal in Minnesota; outdoor cats that hunt rabbits are at highest risk. Infected cats often have a high fever, mouth ulcers, depression, and loss of appetite. Dogs rarely show signs, but can have a skin abscess at the site of infection, loss of appetite, and fever.\n\nSigns and symptoms of tularemia in people usually involve fever, swollen lymph nodes, and skin or mouth ulcers. Tularemia is treatable with antibiotics. Symptoms may also include skin or mouth ulcers, diarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, cough, and weakness. It cannot be transferred person to person. People who have had contact with animals such as wild rabbits and have symptoms consistent with tularemia, should consult their healthcare provider and notify the Minnesota Department of Health.\n\nAccording to Jeff Bender, DVM, MS and professor at the College of Veterinary Medicine, tularemia can be prevented by avoiding contact with wild animals, wearing gloves when picking up dead animals, and using insect repellent to reduce the chance of tick and fly bites. Cat owners are encouraged to keep their cats indoors. Outdoor cats, as in the recent cases are often hunters, and are at increased risk for tularemia.\n\nPet owners' who have concerns that their pet has been exposed, should contact their veterinarian.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a bacterial septicemia that affects more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, and people. It is listed as a category A bioterrorism agent because of the potential for fatality, airborne dissemination, and societal disruption if released.\n\nEtiology\n--------\nThe causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a nonspore-forming, Gram-negative coccobacillus antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It can be cultured readily on blood supplemented with cysteine but must be differentiated from other Gram-negative bacteria on blood agar. The taxonomic status of _Francisella_ has been revised and debated, but recent consensus establishes the subspecies _F. tularensis tularensis_, associated with type A tularemia, _F. tularensis holarctica_, which causes type B tularemia, and a 3rd type, C, associated with _F. novicida_, which has low virulence and is less common than the other 2. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be as high as 30 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and occurs in both the Old and New Worlds.\n\nEpidemiology and transmission\n-----------------------------\nAmong domestic animals, sheep are the commonest host, but clinical infection has also been reported in cats, dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk because of predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, whereas cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domesticated animals. Important wild animal hosts for _F. tularensis tularensis_ include cottontail and jackrabbits, whereas the most common vectors are the ticks _Dermacentor andersoni_ (the wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (the lone star tick), _D. variabilis_ (the American dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (the deer fly). Animal hosts of _F. tularensis holarctica_ are lagomorphs, beaver, muskrat, voles, and sheep. Ticks, flies, fleas, and exposure to contaminated water sources are all associated with transmission of this subspecies, which has also been found to persist naturally in a water-associated amoeba.\n\nNatural foci of infection exist in North America and Eurasia. Although found in every state except Hawaii, tularemia is most often reported in the south central and western USA (for example, California, Missouri, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Montana).\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors.\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but people who prepare or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. Case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people.\n\nClinical findings\n-----------------\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. The most severely and commonly affected livestock species are sheep. Type A tularemia is particularly pathogenic for lagomorphs, and cats and nonhuman primates have been reported to be infected. The clinical presentation depends on host species, subspecies of the bacteria, and route of infection. Sheep and cats may be subclinically infected or develop bacteremia, fever, and respiratory infection. Cats may also develop ulceroglandular or oropharyngeal disease, presumably through exposure to infected prey items. Clinical signs include increased pulse and respiratory rates, coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria with lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 per cent mortality.\n\nThe most consistent lesions are miliary, white to off-white foci of necrosis in the liver and sometimes in the spleen, lung, and lymph nodes. Organisms can be readily isolated from necropsy specimens by use of special media. The infective dose required to transmit this pathogen is extremely low; thus, risk of infection during necropsy or to laboratory personnel is significant, and special procedures and facilities are essential.\n\nDiagnosis\n---------\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague and pseudotuberculosis) or acute pneumonia. When large numbers of sheep show typical signs during periods of heavy tick infestation, tularemia or tick paralysis should be suspected. Tularemia should be considered in cats with signs of acute lymphadenopathy, malaise, oral ulcers, and history of recent ingestion of wild prey.\n\nDiagnosis of acute infection is confirmed by culture and identification of the bacterium, direct or indirect fluorescent antibody test, or a 4-fold increase in antibody titer between acute and convalescent serum specimens. A single titer of greater than or equal to 1:80 by the tube agglutination test is presumptive evidence of prior infection. When tularemia is suspected, laboratory personnel should be alerted as a precaution to reduce the risk of laboratory-acquired infection. In some jurisdictions, tularemia in animals is reportable to public health authorities.\n\nTreatment and control\n---------------------\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels. Gentamicin should be continued for 10 days. Because tetracycline and chloramphenicol are bacteriostatic, they should be continued for 14 days to minimize the risk of relapse. Early treatment is important to minimize risk of fatality. Because of the substantial sylvatic (wildlife and tick) component of the _Francisella_ life cycle, control is limited to reducing arthropod infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment.\n\nCan I get tularemia?\n--------------------\nYes. Humans can get tularemia by direct contact with infected animals, inhaling (aerosol) the bacteria in contaminated environments, eating (oral) contaminated food or water or from the bite of an infected insect (vector). Signs usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure. Disease varies depending route of exposure to the bacteria. Initially flu-like signs, such as fever, chills, nausea, headache, and joint pain occur. Glands (or lymph nodes) may become swollen and painful and may break open and drain pus.\n\nOther signs include skin rash, sore throat, or swelling of the eyes. If the lungs become infected, coughing, chest pain, shortness of breath, and severe pneumonia can occur\n\nHow can I protect my animal from tularemia?\n-------------------------------------------\nTularemia is difficult to prevent since it can be in the environment or be spread by insects. Prevention measures include keeping pets indoors and away from wildlife. Do not feed animals raw meat, especially that from wild animals. Control ticks and biting flies.\n\nHow can I protect myself from tularemia?\n----------------------------------------\nAvoid contact with wildlife, especially sick animals. Do not handle dead wildlife without gloves. Wash your hands after touching any animal and especially before you eat. When outside, wear insect repellents that contain DEET. Cook all meats and foods thoroughly. Wash fruits and vegetables before eating them. Only drink water from a safe source.\n\nIn short: Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nTularemia does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted (borrowed from my colleague, Mod.LL).\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/generalized_conditions/tularemia/overview_of_tularemia.html and http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/FastFacts/pdfs/tularemia_F.pdf. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16848.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but people who prepare or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Humans can get tularemia by direct contact with infected animals, inhaling (aerosol) the bacteria in contaminated environments, eating (oral) contaminated food or water or from the bite of an infected insect (vector). According to Jeff Bender, DVM, MS and professor at the College of Veterinary Medicine, tularemia can be prevented by avoiding contact with wild animals, wearing gloves when picking up dead animals, and using insect repellent to reduce the chance of tick and fly bites. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. \n\nTularemia is rare in Minnesota, between 0 and 3 cases are identified in people and 0 to 5 cases are identified in animals annually. The taxonomic status of _Francisella_ has been revised and debated, but recent consensus establishes the subspecies _F. tularensis tularensis_, associated with type A tularemia, _F. tularensis holarctica_, which causes type B tularemia, and a 3rd type, C, associated with _F. novicida_, which has low virulence and is less common than the other 2. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. \n\nSigns and symptoms of tularemia in people usually involve fever, swollen lymph nodes, and skin or mouth ulcers. It is a disease that both people and animals can get through tick and fly bites or contact with infected animals. The infective dose required to transmit this pathogen is extremely low; thus, risk of infection during necropsy or to laboratory personnel is significant, and special procedures and facilities are essential.\n\n TULAREMIA - USA (02): (MINNESOTA) FELINE\n****************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a bacterial septicemia that affects more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, and people. \n\nCats are the most commonly affected domestic animal in Minnesota; outdoor cats that hunt rabbits are at highest risk. \n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. People who have had contact with animals such as wild rabbits and have symptoms consistent with tularemia, should consult their healthcare provider and notify the Minnesota Department of Health. \n\nCan I get tularemia?\n Tularemia should be considered in cats with signs of acute lymphadenopathy, malaise, oral ulcers, and history of recent ingestion of wild prey. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague and pseudotuberculosis) or acute pneumonia. \n\nEpidemiology and transmission\n When tularemia is suspected, laboratory personnel should be alerted as a precaution to reduce the risk of laboratory-acquired infection. \n\nClinical findings\n \n\nTreatment and control\n \n\n--\n \n\nTularemia does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another category Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. \n\nEtiology\n -------------------------------------------\nTularemia is difficult to prevent since it can be in the environment or be spread by insects. Sheep and cats may be subclinically infected or develop bacteremia, fever, and respiratory infection. Diagnosis of acute infection is confirmed by culture and identification of the bacterium, direct or indirect fluorescent antibody test, or a 4-fold increase in antibody titer between acute and convalescent serum specimens.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Minneapolis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4252246", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (MN,AK) feline, canine, lagomorph", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4252246", "date": "2016-05-29 12:53:48", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA: (MINNESOTA, ALASKA) FELINE, CANINE, LAGOMORPH\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Minnesota: feline, lagomorph (rabbit)\n[2] Alaska: canine, lagomorph (hare)\n\n******\n[1] Minnesota: feline, lagomorph (rabbit)\nDate: Fri 27 May 2016\nSource: KMSP, Fox 9 [edited]\nhttp://www.fox9.com/news/146841554-story\n\n\nThere are now 3 confirmed animal cases of tularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever' in Minnesota, according to the University of Minnesota Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory. A 2nd cat has been diagnosed with the infectious disease.\n\nTularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever,' is a naturally occurring disease found in wildlife, specifically in rabbits, squirrels, and rodents. People and animals can get the disease from fly or tick bites or contact with infected animals.\n\nThe disease is rare in Minnesota. So far this year [2016], 3 cases have been identified in a cottontail rabbit and 2 cats in the Twin Cities [Minneapolis-Saint Paul] metro area. Usually, zero to 5 animal cases happen annually.\n\nOutdoor cats that hunt rabbits are at the highest risk. Infected cats often have a high fever, mouth ulcers and loss of appetite.\n\nPeople who have had contact with animals like wild rabbits and are showing these symptoms should contact their doctor and Minnesota Department of Health.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Minnesota can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16848. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Alaska: canine, lagomorph (hare)\nDate: Sat 28 May 2016\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/alaska-reports-tularemia-in-sick-hares-48103/\n\n\nA sick hare with signs of tularemia was killed by a North Pole [suburb of Fairbanks] resident on [11 May 2016]. The disease was present based on observations during a necropsy performed today [28 May 2016] by ADF&G [Alaska Department of Fish and Game] wildlife veterinarian, Dr Kimberlee Beckmen. In addition, a Fairbanks veterinarian reported a suspected case of tularemia in a dog from the Chena Hot Springs area last week. The dog was found eating a hare 2 days prior to becoming severely ill with fever.\n\n'Outbreaks of tularemia in dogs and cats that come in contact with sick hares occur in the Fairbanks North Star Borough every May and June,' said Dr Beckmen, 'but this year's [2016] cases are about 2 weeks earlier than usual'. Tularemia is most often diagnosed in hares and pets in the Interior between Memorial Day [last Monday in May] and Labor Day [first Monday in September] because it is spread by ticks which are active during the summer.\n\nLast summer [2015], a North Pole man became ill after skinning an infected hare. In 2015, Colorado saw the largest outbreak in state history with 11 human cases in May alone and New Mexico also documented a significant outbreak of human cases.\n\nTularemia is an infection caused by the _Francisella tularensis_ bacteria. It most often kills hares but can also make people, dogs, and cats seriously ill. While it can be fatal if untreated, it is easily cured if diagnosed quickly and the correct antibiotics are prescribed. The commonest signs in people and pets are lethargy with high fever and swollen lymph nodes.\n\nHares are the primary host and the disease is spread by hare and squirrel ticks that have always been present on wildlife in Alaska. The species of tick known to carry the bacteria prefer to live on hares and rodents, but will occasionally bite dogs, cats, or people. 2 species of dog ticks have become established around urban areas in Alaska and are also capable of spreading the disease.\n\nWhile tick bites are one possible cause, pets most often get tularemia from mouthing or catching a sick hare. Interior residents, including trappers, can become infected by handling the hares or from the pet's saliva, even before the pet exhibits signs of illness.\n\n'Although cases of tularemia in humans are rare, they can be avoided by adhering to safety precautions. Do not allow your pets to roam free or have access to sick hares. Dogs and cats that go out of doors can be treated with a veterinary product that will kill ticks within 24 hours so that disease transmission doesn't occur from ticks feeding on pets,' said Dr Beckmen.\n\nIf your pet does come in contact with a dead hare, wear gloves or use a plastic bag to take the animal away from the pet and wash hands thoroughly after handling anything coming out of the pet's mouth. Thoroughly wash any scratches, bites, or wounds made by pets or wildlife immediately with soap and water, and seek medical attention, especially if fever, redness, swelling or flu-like symptoms appear afterward. Double-bag and dispose of dead hares in the trash or bury where dogs and scavengers cannot get to them.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Alaska can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nIt seems a bit early for the tularemia season. This article mentioned that it is only 2 weeks ahead yet there have been other earlier reports indicating there were wildlife cases.\n\nTularemia is a bacterial septicemia that affects more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles, fish, and people. It is listed as a category A bioterrorism agent because of the potential for fatality, airborne dissemination, and societal disruption if released.\n\nEtiology\n--------\nThe causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a nonspore-forming, Gram negative coccobacillus antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It can be cultured readily on blood supplemented with cysteine but must be differentiated from other Gram negative bacteria on blood agar. The taxonomic status of francisella has been revised and debated, but recent consensus establishes the subspecies _F. tularensis tularensis_, associated with type A tularemia, _F. tularensis holarctica_, which causes type B tularemia, and a 3rd type, C, associated with _F. novicida_, which has low virulence and is less common than the other 2. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be as high as 30 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and occurs in both the Old and New Worlds.\n\nEpidemiology and transmission\n-----------------------------\nAmong domestic animals, sheep are the commonest host, but clinical infection has also been reported in cats, dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk because of predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, whereas cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domesticated animals. Important wild animal hosts for _F. tularensis tularensis_ include cottontail and jackrabbits, whereas the most common vectors are the ticks _Dermacentor andersoni_ (the wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (the lone star tick), _D. variabilis_ (the American dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (the deer fly). Animal hosts of _F. tularensis holarctica_ are lagomorphs, beaver, muskrat, voles, and sheep. Ticks, flies, fleas, and exposure to contaminated water sources are all associated with transmission of this subspecies, which has also been found to persist naturally in a water-associated amoeba.\n\nNatural foci of infection exist in North America and Eurasia. Although found in every state except Hawaii, tularemia is most often reported in the south central and western USA (for example, California, Missouri, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Montana).\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors.\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but people who prepare or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. Case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people.\n\nClinical findings\n-----------------\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. The most severely and commonly affected livestock species are sheep. Type A tularemia is particularly pathogenic for lagomorphs, and cats and nonhuman primates have been reported to be infected. The clinical presentation depends on host species, subspecies of the bacteria, and route of infection. Sheep and cats may be subclinically infected or develop bacteremia, fever, and respiratory infection. Cats may also develop ulceroglandular or oropharyngeal disease, presumably through exposure to infected prey items. Clinical signs include increased pulse and respiratory rates, coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria with lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 per cent mortality.\n\nThe most consistent lesions are miliary, white to off-white foci of necrosis in the liver and sometimes in the spleen, lung, and lymph nodes. Organisms can be readily isolated from necropsy specimens by use of special media. The infective dose required to transmit this pathogen is extremely low; thus, risk of infection during necropsy or to laboratory personnel is significant, and special procedures and facilities are essential.\n\nDiagnosis\n---------\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague and pseudotuberculosis) or acute pneumonia. When large numbers of sheep show typical signs during periods of heavy tick infestation, tularemia or tick paralysis should be suspected. Tularemia should be considered in cats with signs of acute lymphadenopathy, malaise, oral ulcers, and history of recent ingestion of wild prey.\n\nDiagnosis of acute infection is confirmed by culture and identification of the bacterium, direct or indirect fluorescent antibody test, or a 4-fold increase in antibody titer between acute and convalescent serum specimens. A single titer of greater than or equal to 1:80 by the tube agglutination test is presumptive evidence of prior infection. When tularemia is suspected, laboratory personnel should be alerted as a precaution to reduce the risk of laboratory-acquired infection. In some jurisdictions, tularemia in animals is reportable to public health authorities.\n\nTreatment and control\n---------------------\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels. Gentamicin should be continued for 10 days. Because tetracycline and chloramphenicol are bacteriostatic, they should be continued for 14 days to minimize the risk of relapse. Early treatment is important to minimize risk of fatality. Because of the substantial sylvatic (wildlife and tick) component of the francisella life cycle, control is limited to reducing arthropod infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment.\n\nCan I get tularemia?\n--------------------\nYes. Humans can get tularemia by direct contact with infected animals, inhaling (aerosol) the bacteria in contaminated environments, eating (oral) contaminated food or water or from the bite of an infected insect (vector). Signs usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure. Disease varies depending route of exposure to the bacteria. Initially flu-like signs, such as fever, chills, nausea, headache, and joint pain occur. Glands (or lymph nodes) may become swollen and painful and may break open and drain pus.\n\nOther signs include skin rash, sore throat, or swelling of the eyes. If the lungs become infected, coughing, chest pain, shortness of breath, and severe pneumonia can occur\n\nHow can I protect my animal from tularemia?\n-------------------------------------------\nTularemia is difficult to prevent since it can be in the environment or be spread by insects. Prevention measures include keeping pets indoors and away from wildlife. Do not feed animals raw meat, especially that from wild animals. Control ticks and biting flies.\n\nHow can I protect myself from tularemia?\n----------------------------------------\nAvoid contact with wildlife, especially sick animals. Do not handle dead wildlife without gloves. Wash your hands after touching any animal and especially before you eat. When outside, wear insect repellents that contain DEET. Cook all meats and foods thoroughly. Wash fruits and vegetables before eating them. Only drink water from a safe source.\n\nIn short: Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nTularemia does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted (borrowed from my colleague, Mod.LL).\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/generalized_conditions/tularemia/overview_of_tularemia.html and http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/FastFacts/pdfs/tularemia_F.pdf. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Alaska can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-28 00:00:00", "2016-05-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Fairbanks", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hot Springs", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minneapolis", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3865365", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Denmark: (HS) hare, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3865365", "date": "2015-12-15 19:56:22", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - DENMARK: (CAPITAL) HARE, OIE\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 15 Dec 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(51) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=19353\n\n\nTularemia, Denmark\n----------------------\nInformation received on 15 Dec 2015 from Dr Per Starcke Henriksen, Chief Veterinary Officer, Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Fisheries, Glostrup, Denmark\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\nDate of start of the event: 17 Nov 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 11 Dec 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 23 Nov 2012\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country.\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\n\nOutbreak 1: Almindingen, Bornholm, East\nDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Nov 2015\nOutbreak status: Resolved (11 Dec 2015)\nEpidemiological unit: Forest\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\n\nAffected population: A wild European hare found dead near Ekkodalen in Almindingen on Bornholm.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: In relation to tularemia, Denmark is assumed to be a low endemic area of _F. tularensis holarctica_ (type B). This assumption is based on the human cases of tularemia in Denmark.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nStatens Serum Institut (national laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 11 Dec 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting: The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University, Fact Sheet on Tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals.\n\nTularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative coccobacillus in the family Francisellaceae. Four subspecies are currently recognized. Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp. tularensis (also known as type A) has been found almost exclusively in North America. It is the most virulent species, particularly in humans. _F. tularensis_ subsp. holarctica (type B) is much more widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere, but it is less virulent. The 2 remaining species, _F. tularensis_ subsp. mediasiatica and _F. tularensis_ subsp. novicida, have been recognized in limited geographical regions, are rarely found in people, and seem to cause relatively mild disease when they occur. Additional subspecies have also been proposed.\n\nWith rare exceptions, tularemia occurs only in the Northern Hemisphere. This disease has been reported from North America, Europe, parts of Asia and the Middle East, and northern Africa. A single human case, caused by _F. tularensis novicida_, was acquired in Australia.\n\n_F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. _F. tularensis holarctica_ is widely distributed in the Northern Hemisphere. This species is responsible for nearly all cases of tularemia outside North America. It co-exists with _F. tularensis tularensis_ in North America. _F. tularensis mediasiatica_ occurs in a limited area of Central Asia, and _F. tularensis novicida_ has been reported from North America, Australia and Spain.\n\nHumans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. Hunting or skinning animals, or contact with meat when preparing food, are important routes of exposure. Respiratory infections sometimes occur in farmers who are exposed through activities such as piling hay. Cases have been reported after mowing lawns, possibly from running over an animal carcass. Human infections have also been linked to handling infected animals or being bitten by them. Person-to-person transmission has not been reported.' - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/111.]", "summary": "Epidemiological unit: Forest\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\n\nAffected population: A wild European hare found dead near Ekkodalen in Almindingen on Bornholm. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Date of previous occurrence: 23 Nov 2012\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\n Measures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\n TULAREMIA - DENMARK: (CAPITAL) HARE, OIE\n****************************************\n Summary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nHumans acquire _F. tularensis_ from various sources including lakes and streams, food contaminated by the carcasses of infected animals or their excretions, laboratory cultures or clinical samples, and tissues from infected animals. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for Food Security & Public Health, Iowa State University, Fact Sheet on Tularemia, available at http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/tularemia.pdf:\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that can affect many mammals. Total outbreaks: 1\n\nOutbreak 1: Almindingen, Bornholm, East\n Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: In relation to tularemia, Denmark is assumed to be a low endemic area of _F. tularensis holarctica_ (type B). \n\n_F. tularensis tularensis_ is seen almost exclusively in North America and has very rarely been isolated in Europe. Source: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(51) [edited]\n \n\nControl measures\n \n\n--\n \n\nEpidemiology\n Date of start of the event: 17 Nov 2015\n Date of confirmation of the event: 11 Dec 2015\n Although all 4 cause tularemia, they tend to be associated with different animal hosts, and their propensity to cause severe disease varies. _F. tularensis_ subsp.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-12-11 00:00:00", "2015-12-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "hare", "country": "Ethiopia"}, {"location": "Bornholm", "country": "Denmark"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3670429", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (17): (WY, NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3670429", "date": "2015-09-25 17:15:50", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (17): (WYOMING, NEBRASKA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this post:\n[1] Wyoming\n[2] Nebraska\n\n******\n[1] Wyoming\nDate: Thu 24 Sep 2015\nSource: Wyoming Tribune Eagle [edited]\nhttp://wyomingnews.com/articles/2015/09/24/news/19local_09-24-15.txt\n\n\nA person in Laramie County [Wyoming] has been diagnosed with a potentially fatal bacterial disease called tularemia. Officials at the Cheyenne-Laramie County Health Department are urging people to take precautions to avoid contracting the disease.\n\nThe disease causes symptoms that range from sore throat to diarrhea, and swollen and painful lymph glands. If the bacteria are inhaled, people can suffer chills, headaches, joint pain and pneumonia.\n\nAn unusually high number of cases have occurred in Wyoming this year. So far in 2015, 16 cases have been reported in Wyoming, well above the state's average of 1 or 2 cases a year. A man from Big Horn County died from the disease.\n\nThe unidentified Laramie County man was diagnosed with tularemia in the last week or so, according to Kim Deti, spokeswoman for the Wyoming Department of Health. She wrote in an email Wednesday, 23 Sep 2015, that she did not know the man's medical condition, but she did not think he was hospitalized.\n\nHigher numbers of cases of the disease have been reported in Colorado too. In Weld County, Colorado, 5 people have been infected with the disease so far in 2015, according to Eric Aakko, public information officer for Weld County's Department of Public Health and Environment. No one in the county has died from it, he wrote. The county typically sees zero cases or one case a year.\n\nThe local health department wants people to be alert, deputy director of City-County Health Gary Hickman said. He also is the director of the agency's environmental health division. '(Tularemia) is around all the time,' Hickman said. The disease has a tendency to peak when rodent populations are up, which is what has happened this year. 'We are in a big year with rodent populations,' he said.\n\nTularemia, also called rabbit fever and deer fly fever, often affects rabbits, hares and rodents. It has been associated with rabbit and rodent die-offs. People can get tularemia if they are bitten by infected ticks, deer flies or horseflies. The disease can be transmitted if people handle infected animals, through ingestion, contact with untreated and contaminated water, or with meat that is not properly cooked, the city-county agency's release said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Nebraska\nDate: Fri 18 Sep 2015\nSource: Beatrice Daily Sun [edited]\nhttp://beatricedailysun.com/news/state-and-regional/state-seeing-increase-in-tularemia-cases/article_2dfdd5c9-8c0d-53d6-af60-853243df9207.html\n\n\nIn 2015, a disease called tularemia has been widely reported in Nebraska and neighboring states. 18 cases have been reported to the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services so far in 2015 which represents a 25-year high. Many of the cases are in the Panhandle. Age range of people affected is 3-82 years old. 11 people have been hospitalized.\n\nTularemia is a disease that can affect animals and people. It is caused by a bacterium found in animals, insects, soil and water. Rabbits, rodents and hares are especially susceptible. Tularemia can be transmitted to people through insect bites, skin contact, contaminated food or water, or inhaling contaminated particles.\n\nTularemia can cause a wide range of symptoms including certain flu-like symptoms, an open sore and swelling at the site of a tick bite or swollen lymph nodes. Symptoms usually appear 3-5 days after exposure to the bacteria, but can take up to 14 days to appear. Tularemia can be a potentially serious disease but most infections can be treated with antimicrobials. Tularemia is not spread person-to- person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As has occurred with plague, another zoonosis, this has been a banner year for tularemia as well. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The disease can be transmitted if people handle infected animals, through ingestion, contact with untreated and contaminated water, or with meat that is not properly cooked, the city-county agency's release said.
