[2] Nebraska\n\n******\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n--\n \n\nTularemia, also called rabbit fever and deer fly fever, often affects rabbits, hares and rodents. 18 cases have been reported to the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services so far in 2015 which represents a 25-year high. \n\nAn unusually high number of cases have occurred in Wyoming this year.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-09-24 00:00:00", "2015-09-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Laramie County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weld County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3775022", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Canada: (ON)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3775022", "date": "2015-11-08 04:30:13", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - CANADA: (ONTARIO)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 6 Nov 2015\nSource: Northern Life [edited]\nhttp://www.northernlife.ca/news/localNews/2015/11/06-tularemia-sudbury.aspx\n\n\nLaboratory results have confirmed tularemia in an adult resident in the Greater Sudbury area. This is the 1st human case of tularemia in the Sudbury and District Health Unit's service area since 2003, said a press release. It is believed that the individual became infected through contact with wild game.\n\nTularemia is a disease of animals and humans caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. It is naturally occurring in Ontario wildlife populations, especially in rabbits, hares, voles, muskrats, beavers, and squirrels and in ticks and small domestic animals.\n\nHumans can become infected through several routes, including:\n- bites or licks of an infected animal\n- handling or cleaning the carcass of an infected animal, especially the skin or meat\n- eating inadequately cooked wild game\n- inhalation or exposure beneath the skin to contaminated soil\n- drinking contaminated water\n- bites of an infected tick or deer fly\n\nHunters are at higher risk of exposure because of the handling of wild game carcasses. Transmission of tularemia from person to person has not been reported.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Francisella tularensis_ infection in this case are not stated nor is the animal suspected to be the reservoir.\n\nTularemia is caused by _F. tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States, an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation, as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as acanthamoeba), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In 1 case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of 1 to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of exposure. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza (inflammation of the mucous membranes lining the nasal cavity), and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29468.]", "summary": "\n\nHumans can become infected through several routes, including:\n- bites or licks of an infected animal\n- handling or cleaning the carcass of an infected animal, especially the skin or meat\n- eating inadequately cooked wild game\n- inhalation or exposure beneath the skin to contaminated soil\n- drinking contaminated water\n- bites of an infected tick or deer fly\n\nHunters are at higher risk of exposure because of the handling of wild game carcasses. \n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation, as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as acanthamoeba), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Francisella tularensis_ infection in this case are not stated nor is the animal suspected to be the reservoir. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. TULAREMIA - CANADA: (ONTARIO)\n*****************************\n \n\nTularemia is a disease of animals and humans caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. \n\nTularemia is caused by _F. tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3612365", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (16): (AZ) rabbits", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3612365", "date": "2015-08-30 20:12:51", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (16): (ARIZONA), RABBITS\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 28 Aug 2015\nSource: Prescott News [edited]\nhttp://www.prescottenews.com/news/current-news/item/26066-tularemia-found-in-dewey-area-rabbits\n\n\n3 Dewey-area rabbits have tested positive for tularemia by Arizona Game & Fish (AGF), who were responding to reports by residents of a rabbit die-off.\n\nTularemia is treatable, and is a naturally occurring illness in the United States, with about 200 human cases reported each year, most cases occurring in the western and south-central states. It is caused by a bacterium found in animals (especially rodents, rabbits and hares), and is passed to both domestic animals and people.\n\n'It's not unusual to see 1-2 cases of tularemia in animals annually in Yavapai County. The state only averages one human case of tularemia per year,' says Stephen Everett, Epidemiologist for Yavapai County Community Health Services (YCCHS).\n\nPeople and pets who spend time outdoors can contract tularemia if they are bitten by infected deerflies, ticks, or other insects, or by handling infected rodents or rabbits. Family pets with outdoor roaming privileges can carry ticks into the home and may expose humans to tick-borne illnesses. Rarely, tularemia can spread to humans through contaminated food or water or by inhaling the airborne organism. It is not known to spread from person to person.\n\n[Byline: David McAtee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n['The causative bacterium of tularemia, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-sporulating, Gram-negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has also been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beavers, muskrats, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from 1 life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [abnormally frequent urination] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death.\n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular.\n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.'\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/207.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. \n\nPeople and pets who spend time outdoors can contract tularemia if they are bitten by infected deerflies, ticks, or other insects, or by handling infected rodents or rabbits. \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. \n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as laboratory personnel) is currently under review. It is caused by a bacterium found in animals (especially rodents, rabbits and hares), and is passed to both domestic animals and people. \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Source: Prescott News [edited]\nhttp://www.prescottenews.com/news/current-news/item/26066-tularemia-found-in-dewey-area-rabbits\n\n\n3 Dewey-area rabbits have tested positive for tularemia by Arizona Game & Fish (AGF), who were responding to reports by residents of a rabbit die-off. Tularemia is treatable, and is a naturally occurring illness in the United States, with about 200 human cases reported each year, most cases occurring in the western and south-central states. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia. TULAREMIA - USA (16): (ARIZONA), RABBITS\n****************************************\n \n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. In domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has also been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n\n [Byline: David McAtee]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yavapai County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3609784", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden: (NB, VB) hare", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3609784", "date": "2015-08-30 14:49:59", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN: (NORTBOTTEN, VASTERBOTTEN), HARE\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Aug 2015\nFrom: Erik Agren <erik.agren@sva.se> [edited]\n\n\nTularemia is considered endemic in Sweden but occurs usually only as sporadic cases. Some years, such as in 2012 and now 2015, there is a larger outbreak of disease in hares and humans, usually late in the summer season.\n\nSince July this year [2015], an unusually high number of dead mountain hares (_Lepus timidus_) have been noted in the coastal area of northern Sweden, in the counties of Norrbotten and Vasterbotten. In the past month, the Swedish National Veterinary Institute (http://www.sva.se) has received over 120 reports of single or multiple dead hares from this area, with a focus around the city of Lulea [map at http://www.lonelyplanet.com/maps/europe/sweden/].\n\nTen hares submitted so far to SVA from the area were all positive for tularemia in the PCR-analysis. A high number of human cases of tularemia have also been registered in the same region (ref. Public Health Agency of Sweden).\n\nSVA performs wildlife disease surveillance and has research projects regarding tularemia in wildlife, so the public is encouraged to report sick or dead hares or rodents to SVA. Also, in neighboring areas of northern Finland (Uleaborg area), the veterinary institute EVIRA reports many cases of tularemia (http://www.evira.fi).\n\n--\nErik Agren\nVeterinary Officer, Department of Pathology and Wildlife Diseases, National Veterinary Institute, Uppsala, Sweden\n<erik.agren@sva.se>\n\n[According to Sweden's reports to the OIE, the most recent outbreak of tularemia in domestic animals (rabbits) was recorded in 2006. No information on infections in wild animals (hares) has been reported in the annual reports to the OIE.\n\nDuring the last 5 years, tularemia has been ranked 3rd among the 10 zoonoses diagnosed in humans, as reported to the OIE, with the following figures (human cases):\n2010 - 484; 2011 - 350; 2012 - 590; 2013 - 118; 2014 - 150.\n\nThe full list of zoonoses in Sweden for 2014 is presented for comparative assessment (no deaths reported in 2014):\n\nCampylobacteriosis - 8288\nSalmonellosis - 2213\nTularemia - 150\nListeriosis - 125\n_Escherichia coli_ O157 - 56\nEchinococcosis/hydatidosis - 21\nBrucellosis - 16\nAvian chlamydiosis - 12\nLeptospirosis - 6\nQ fever - 2\nTrichinellosis - 1\nBotulism - 1\n\nThe following [edited] summary on tularemia in animals is derived from OIE's manual (chapter 2.1.18, updated 2008):\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 C [98.6 F]. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs [rabbits & hares] in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia. It may be water- or arthropod-borne, is less virulent to humans and rabbits, and does not ferment glycerol.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes. On post-mortem examination, lesions may include caseous necrosis of lymph nodes and multiple greyish-white foci of necrosis in the spleen, liver, bone marrow and lungs. The spleen is usually enlarged. It is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. Special precautions, including the wearing of gloves, masks and eyeshields are, therefore, recommended when handling infective materials. The facility should meet the requirements for Containment Group 3 pathogens.'\n\nWe are grateful to Dr Agren for the submission of the current information from North Sweden. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/108.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Trichinellosis - 1\nBotulism - 1\n\nThe following [edited] summary on tularemia in animals is derived from OIE's manual (chapter 2.1.18, updated 2008):\n\n'Tularemia is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. \n\nDuring the last 5 years, tularemia has been ranked 3rd among the 10 zoonoses diagnosed in humans, as reported to the OIE, with the following figures (human cases):\n2010 - 484; 2011 - 350; 2012 - 590; 2013 - 118; 2014 - 150. Veterinary Officer, Department of Pathology and Wildlife Diseases, National Veterinary Institute, Uppsala, Sweden\n<erik.agren@sva.se>\n\n[According to Sweden's reports to the OIE, the most recent outbreak of tularemia in domestic animals (rabbits) was recorded in 2006. O157 - 56\nEchinococcosis/hydatidosis - 21\nBrucellosis - 16\n The full list of zoonoses in Sweden for 2014 is presented for comparative assessment (no deaths reported in 2014):\n\nCampylobacteriosis - 8288\n \n\nSVA performs wildlife disease surveillance and has research projects regarding tularemia in wildlife, so the public is encouraged to report sick or dead hares or rodents to SVA. Tularemia - 150\nListeriosis - 125\n_ TULAREMIA - SWEDEN: (NORTBOTTEN, VASTERBOTTEN), HARE\n*****************************************************\n Leptospirosis - 6\nQ fever - 2\n In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nTen hares submitted so far to SVA from the area were all positive for tularemia in the PCR-analysis. \n\n--\n It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. In the past month, the Swedish National Veterinary Institute (http://www.sva.se) has received over 120 reports of single or multiple dead hares from this area, with a focus around the city of Lulea [map at http://www.lonelyplanet.com/maps/europe/sweden/].", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "botulism", "brucellosis", "q fever", "salmonellosis", "tularemia", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Lulea", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "North Sweden", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Uppsala", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "http://www.evira.fi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3842058", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (18)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3842058", "date": "2015-12-05 12:17:47", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (18)\n********************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 4 Dec 2015\nSource: CDC, Morbid Mortal Week Rep 64(47);1317-8 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6447a4.htm?s_cid=mm6447a4_w\n\n\nIncrease in Human Cases of Tularemia -- Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming, January-September 2015\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTularemia is a rare, often serious disease caused by a gram-negative coccobacillus, _Francisella tularensis_, which infects humans and animals in the Northern Hemisphere (1). Approximately 125 cases have been reported annually in the USA during the last 2 decades (2). As of 30 Sep 2015, a total of 100 tularemia cases were reported in 2015 among residents of Colorado (n = 43), Nebraska (n = 21), South Dakota (n = 20), and Wyoming (n = 16) (Figure [for figure, see original URL - Mod.LL]). This represents a substantial increase in the annual mean number of 4 (975 percent increase), 7 (200 percent), 7 (186 percent) and 2 (70 percent) cases, respectively, reported in each state during 2004-2014 (2).\n\nPatients ranged in age from 10 months to 89 years (median = 56 years); 74 were male. The most common clinical presentations of tularemia were respiratory disease (pneumonic form, [n = 26]), skin lesions with lymphadenopathy (ulceroglandular form, [n = 26]), and a general febrile illness without localizing signs (typhoidal form, [n = 25]). Overall, 48 persons were hospitalized, and 1 death was reported, in a man aged 85 years. Possible reported exposure routes included animal contact (n = 51), environmental aerosolizing activities (n = 49), and arthropod bites (n = 34); a total of 41 patients reported 2 or more possible exposures.\n\nClinical presentation and severity of tularemia depends on the strain, inoculation route, and infectious dose. Tularemia can be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals (e.g., rabbits or cats); ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; inhalation from aerosolization (e.g., landscaping, mowing over voles, hares, and rodents, or other farming activities); or arthropod bites (e.g., ticks or deer flies) (1,3). Human-to-human transmission has never been demonstrated (1,3).\n\nInfected persons can develop a range of symptoms that display several clinical forms. These include fever and chills with muscle and joint pain (typhoidal), cough or difficulty breathing (pneumonic), swollen lymph nodes with or without skin lesions (ulceroglandular or glandular), conjunctivitis (oculoglandular), pharyngitis (oropharyngeal), or abdominal pain with vomiting and diarrhea (intestinal) (2,3). Symptoms typically begin within 3-5 days of exposure, but can take up to 14 days to appear. Case fatality rates range from less to 2 percent to 24 percent, depending on the strain (1-3). Streptomycin is considered the drug of choice on the basis of historical use and Food and Drug Administration approval; however, it sometimes can be difficult to obtain and is associated with frequent ototoxicity (3). Gentamicin, doxycycline, and ciprofloxacin are also used (2,3).\n\n_F. tularensis_ is commonly isolated in culture or detected by polymerase chain reaction from patients' blood specimens, but can also be identified in specimens from skin lesions, spinal fluid, lymph nodes, and respiratory secretions (2). In addition, a serologic diagnosis can be made by demonstrating a fourfold increase between immunoglobulin G titers from patients in the acute and convalescent stages of infection. Specimens suspected of containing _F. tularensis_ should be handled at biosafety level 2 at a minimum. Biosafety level 3 containment is recommended when handling live cultures (2,3).\n\nAlthough the cause for the increases in tularemia cases in Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming is unclear, possible explanations might be contributing factors, including increased rainfall promoting vegetation growth, pathogen survival, and increased rodent and rabbit populations. Increased awareness and testing since tularemia was reinstated as a nationally notifiable disease in January 2000 is also a possible explanation for the increase in the number of cases in these 4 states (4). Health care providers should be aware of the elevated risk for tularemia within these states* and consider a diagnosis of tularemia in any person nationwide with compatible signs and symptoms. Residents and visitors to these areas should regularly use insect repellent, wear gloves when handling animals, and avoid mowing in areas where sick or dead animals have been reported.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Penn RL. Francisella tularensis (tularemia) [Chapter 229]. In: Bennett JE, Dolin R, Blaser MJ, eds. Mandell, Douglas, and Bennett's Principles and Practice of Infectious Disease. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier Saunders; 2015.\n2. CDC. Tularemia -- United States, 2001-2010. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2013;62:963-6.\n3. World Health Organization. WHO guidelines on tularemia. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization; 2007. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/resources/whotularemiamanual.pdf.\n4. CDC. Summary of notifiable diseases, United States, 1998. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 1999;47 (No. 53).\n\n*As part of this investigation, all bordering states were contacted, and no others reported a similar 2-fold to 3-fold increase above baseline for tularemia cases in 2015.\n\n[Authors: Pedati C, House J, Hancock-Allen J, et al]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nTularemia does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another Category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "[Authors: Pedati C, House J, Hancock-Allen J, et al]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The most common clinical presentations of tularemia were respiratory disease (pneumonic form, [n = 26]), skin lesions with lymphadenopathy (ulceroglandular form, [n = 26]), and a general febrile illness without localizing signs (typhoidal form, [n = 25]). Possible reported exposure routes included animal contact (n = 51), environmental aerosolizing activities (n = 49), and arthropod bites (n = 34); a total of 41 patients reported 2 or more possible exposures. This represents a substantial increase in the annual mean number of 4 (975 percent increase), 7 (200 percent), 7 (186 percent) and 2 (70 percent) cases, respectively, reported in each state during 2004-2014 (2). As of 30 Sep 2015, a total of 100 tularemia cases were reported in 2015 among residents of Colorado (n = 43), Nebraska (n = 21), South Dakota (n = 20), and Wyoming (n = 16) (Figure [for figure, see original URL - Mod. Tularemia can be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals (e.g., rabbits or cats); ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; inhalation from aerosolization (e.g., landscaping, mowing over voles, hares, and rodents, or other farming activities); or arthropod bites (e.g., ticks or deer flies) (1,3). As part of this investigation, all bordering states were contacted, and no others reported a similar 2-fold to 3-fold increase above baseline for tularemia cases in 2015. \n\n_F. tularensis_ is commonly isolated in culture or detected by polymerase chain reaction from patients' blood specimens, but can also be identified in specimens from skin lesions, spinal fluid, lymph nodes, and respiratory secretions (2). --------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTularemia is a rare, often serious disease caused by a gram-negative coccobacillus, _Francisella tularensis_, which infects humans and animals in the Northern Hemisphere (1). Increased awareness and testing since tularemia was reinstated as a nationally notifiable disease in January 2000 is also a possible explanation for the increase in the number of cases in these 4 states (4). http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6447a4.htm?s_cid=mm6447a4_w\n\n\nIncrease in Human Cases of Tularemia -- Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming, January-September 2015\n \n\nTularemia does not spread from person to person essentially in contradiction to another Category A bioterrorism agent, _Yersinia pestis_, in which the pneumonic form can easily be transmitted. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. These include fever and chills with muscle and joint pain (typhoidal), cough or difficulty breathing (pneumonic), swollen lymph nodes with or without skin lesions (ulceroglandular or glandular), conjunctivitis (oculoglandular), pharyngitis (oropharyngeal), or abdominal pain with vomiting and diarrhea (intestinal) (2,3). TULAREMIA - USA (18)\n********************\n Case fatality rates range from less to 2 percent to 24 percent, depending on the strain (1-3). Health care providers should be aware of the elevated risk for tularemia within these states* and consider a diagnosis of tularemia in any person nationwide with compatible signs and symptoms. Residents and visitors to these areas should regularly use insect repellent, wear gloves when handling animals, and avoid mowing in areas where sick or dead animals have been reported. Although the cause for the increases in tularemia cases in Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, and Wyoming is unclear, possible explanations might be contributing factors, including increased rainfall promoting vegetation growth, pathogen survival, and increased rodent and rabbit populations. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-01-25 00:00:00", "2049-03-25 00:00:00", "2043-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-09-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3608721", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (15): (CO) rabbits", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3608721", "date": "2015-08-28 15:41:04", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (15): (COLORADO) RABBITS\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 27 Aug 2015\nSource: KKTV.com [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/Rabbit--323158751.html\n\n\nMore rabbits have tested positive for rabbit fever, also known as tularemia. The rabbits didn't have contact with any people.\n[Apart from those who picked them up for testing. - Mod.JW]\n\nThey were found in the Pueblo West area on the following streets [i.e., in the city of Pueblo, in Pueblo County]:\nLinden Avenue\nKirkwood Drive\nSiesta Drive\nSpalding Avenue\nBeardsley Place.\n\nThe Pueblo Health Department says there have been widespread die-offs throughout Pueblo West. They're advising everyone in the area.\n\nRabbit fever is a bacterial infection most commonly transmitted to humans by handling sick or dead animals what are infected. People can also get it if they are bitten by an infected insect.\n\nHere's important information the Pueblo County Health Department shared.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics, therefore should you have any of these early signs, contact your medical provider.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows signs of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to a veterinarian promptly. Tularemia is easily treated if diagnosed early in dogs and cats.\n\nRecommended precautions include:\n- Avoid handling wild animals.\n- When outdoors near places where wild rabbits or rodents are present, wear insect repellent containing DEET.\n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. Do not mow over animal carcasses.\n- Leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals.\n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets.\n- If a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Wear insect repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a long-handled shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a garbage bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands with soap and water afterwards.\n- Wear proper footwear outdoors where dead animals have been found.\n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping.\n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities.\n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters.\n\nIf you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps:\n- Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits.\n- Cook the meat of wild rabbits thoroughly to a temperature of 165 deg F or higher.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium of tularemia, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-sporulating, Gram-negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has also been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beavers, muskrats, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from 1 life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [abnormally frequent urination] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death.\n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular.\n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3463.]", "summary": "JW]\n\nThey were found in the Pueblo West area on the following streets [i.e., in the city of Pueblo, in Pueblo County]:\nLinden Avenue\nKirkwood Drive\nSiesta Drive\nSpalding Avenue\nBeardsley Place. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIf you hunt, trap or skin animals, take additional steps:\n- Use impervious gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially rabbits. \n\nRecommended precautions include:\n- Avoid handling wild animals. \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. TULAREMIA - USA (15): (COLORADO) RABBITS\n****************************************\n \n\nRabbit fever is a bacterial infection most commonly transmitted to humans by handling sick or dead animals what are infected. \n\nTypical signs of infection in humans include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. \n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as laboratory personnel) is currently under review. \n\n--\n The rabbits didn't have contact with any people.\n \n- Routinely use a tick and flea prevention treatment on pets. \n- Do not drink unpurified water from streams or lakes or allow your pets to drink surface waters. \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. \n- Wear gloves while gardening or landscaping, and wash your hands after these activities. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. \n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. \n- Do not go barefoot or wear sandals while gardening, mowing or landscaping. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium of tularemia, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-sporulating, Gram-negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. \n- Use a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work. \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Pueblo", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3599260", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (14): (WY) fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3599260", "date": "2015-08-25 05:59:42", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (14): (WYOMING), FATALITY\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 23 Aug 2015\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttp://www.sheridanmedia.com/news/wyoming-news81301\n\n\nA 74-year-old Big Horn County man died on Sun 16 Aug 2015 after a 39-day struggle with tularemia. Experts believe he may be the 1st person in Wyoming to die from the disease in 2015. The disease, sometimes called rabbit fever, is spread to humans by rodents and rabbits, as well as ticks and deer flies. The wildlife disease occurs almost every year in Wyoming. However, there appear to be more cases in Wyoming in 2015, in part due to booming cottontail rabbit populations.\n\nOfficials have confirmed that 11 people have been infected with the disease in Wyoming in 2015. State Epidemiologist Dr. Tracy Murphy tells the Casper Star-Tribune that deaths are uncommon. The disease is treatable with antimicrobials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia can present in a variety of ways depending on the route of acquisition. Even before the antimicrobial era, pneumonia due to inhalation of _Francisella tularensis_ seemed to account for most of the deaths related to the infection (1). A good review of the subject written by Thomas and Schaffner can be found in reference 2.\n\nReferences\n1. Foshay L: Cause of death in tularemia. Arch Intern Med. 1937;60: 22-38.\n2. Thomas LD, Schaffner W: Tularemia pneumonia. Infect Dis N Am 2010;24: 43-55. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n TULAREMIA - USA (14): (WYOMING), FATALITY\n*****************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nReferences\n1. \n\n--\n \n\nOfficials have confirmed that 11 people have been infected with the disease in Wyoming in 2015. Date: Sun 23 Aug 2015\n A 74-year-old Big Horn County man died on Sun 16 Aug 2015 after a 39-day struggle with tularemia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3553047", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (11): (WY) rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3553047", "date": "2015-08-02 13:17:14", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (11): (WYOMING), RABBIT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 31 Jul 2015\nSource: CBS 5 [edited]\nhttp://www.kgwn.tv/home/headlines/Rabbit-Fever-Confirmed-in-Platte-County-Rabbits-320276041.html\n\n\nTularemia, a bacterial disease of wildlife that can be transmitted to humans and their pets, has been diagnosed in 2 cottontail rabbits a few miles northeast of Guernsey in Platte County.\n\nA landowner along Whelen Canyon Road discovered about 20 dead rabbits and contacted the Wyoming Game and Fish Department. Two of the rabbits were sent to the Game and Fish's Wildlife Diseases Laboratory, and both tested positive for tularemia.\n\nTularemia is fairly common in rodents and rabbits and occasionally spills over into other host species, including humans. It occurs almost every year somewhere in Wyoming but is not cause for alarm. Wheatland Game Warden David Ellsworth said that like most other wildlife diseases, tularemia is more likely to occur during periods of high populations, which cottontail rabbits are experiencing now.\n\nAccording to the Wyoming Department of Health, humans typically become infected through the bites of ticks and deerflies but may also become infected by handling infected animal carcasses, eating or drinking contaminated food or water, or by inhaling infected aerosols. Dogs and cats can also contract tularemia by eating infected animals, drinking contaminated water or through tick and deer fly bites. With small game seasons coming up in the fall, Ellsworth cautions hunters to avoid harvesting rabbits that appear sick, use gloves when handling harvested game, and cook game thoroughly before consumption. Tularemia is active during periods of warm weather when insect vectors are present, but the disease generally dies off after a hard frost.\n\nTularemia epidemics are not uncommon and may result in extensive rabbit mortalities, but most cases involve just a few to several deaths in isolated populations.\n\nSeveral dead prairie dogs and other rodents at Devil's Tower National Monument have also tested positive for tularemia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKC. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n According to the Wyoming Department of Health, humans typically become infected through the bites of ticks and deerflies but may also become infected by handling infected animal carcasses, eating or drinking contaminated food or water, or by inhaling infected aerosols. Tularemia can be deadly if left untreated, though if identified in a reasonable amount of time, it can be treated with a standard course of antibiotics.\n\nSo far in 2015, Colorado health officials have recorded 15 human cases of tularemia. There have been 3 human cases in Larimer County this year, but the current risk level is 'low, but present.'\n\nTo lower your risk of exposure, avoid contact with wild rodents, including squirrels and rabbits, do not handle sick or dead animals directly and wear shoes in areas where rabbits may have died, and a dust mask if you may be kicking up dust and vegetation in an at-risk area.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_(type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. - Mod.PMB\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47173. TULAREMIA - USA (09): (COLORADO) MUSKRAT, ALERT\n***********************************************\n In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nSo far in 2015, Colorado health officials have recorded 15 human cases of tularemia. \n\nThe bacterial disease can cause skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, respiratory failure, and bloody sputum.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3548673", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (10): (CO, SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3548673", "date": "2015-08-01 10:27:54", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (10): (COLORADO, SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Colorado\nDate: Wed 29 Jul 2015\nSource: KKCO NBC 11 News, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.nbc11news.com/home/headlines/319146611.html\n\n\nFive more cases of rabbit fever reported in Weld County\n-------------------------------------------------------\nWeld County says that 5 more men have contracted tularemia, otherwise known as rabbit fever, putting Colorado within striking distance of a state record for cases of what normally is a relatively rare bacterial disease. The county health department reported Tuesday, 28 Jul 2015, that the men who got sick were between the ages of 56 and 80. 2 were hospitalized and 3 recovered at home.\n\nColorado currently has 16 human cases of rabbit fever, also called tularemia. In an average year there are less than 4 cases. The record was 1983, when 20 cases were reported.\n\nHumans can become infected with tularemia through insect bites, by touching an infected animal or inhaling the bacteria. The bacteria can remain alive in soil, including in animal droppings.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] South Dakota\nDate: Tue 28 Jul 2015\nSource: South Dakota Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://news.sd.gov/newsitem.aspx?id=18043\n\n\nA [South Dakota] state health official says tularemia is on the rise, with 7 cases reported in the Black Hills area since June 2015. 'Tularemia is a fairly uncommon but potentially severe disease that can be fatal,' said Dr. Lon Kightlinger, state epidemiologist for the Department of Health. 'People can be exposed when they come in contact with infected insects and animals, particularly rabbits, rodents and cats.'\n\n6 of South Dakota's cases were adults over the age of 50 and 1 was a child under 5. 5 of the 7 were hospitalized. Kightlinger noted that 1 of the cases had direct contact with a pet cat that tested positive for tularemia.\n\nSometimes called rabbit fever, tularemia most commonly results in a sore developing where the bacteria enter the body, accompanied by swelling of the lymph nodes. In severe cases, it can cause fever and a pneumonia-like illness, which can be fatal.\n\nTo reduce the risk of tularemia, Kightlinger encouraged people to use insect repellants when outside with animals and to take precautions such as wearing gloves and double-bagging when handling and disposing of dead animals. Animal owners, particularly cat owners, should watch their animals for signs of illness and contact their veterinarian as soon as possible if unusual signs develop. Using tick and insect repellants on pets and livestock also helps prevent transmission of tularemia and other vector-borne diseases. Cat owners should consult their veterinarians about appropriate repellants as some labeled for use on dogs may be toxic for cats.\n\n'Especially during this season of camping and outdoor recreation, people, including Rally-goers, should avoid or take special precautions with rabbits, prairie dogs, gophers and voles,' said Kightlinger.\n\nOther states in the region, including North Dakota, Nebraska, Wyoming and Colorado are also reporting increased cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not apparently related to bioterrorism in this case, tularemia is a category A bioterrorism agent, and the pneumonic form is likely to be the one associated with intentional spread.\n\nTularemia is caused by _Francisella tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3-5 days, with a range of 1-14 days. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1] Colorado\n \n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. People can be exposed when they come in contact with infected insects and animals, particularly rabbits, rodents and cats.'\n\n6 of South Dakota's cases were adults over the age of 50 and 1 was a child under 5. Weld County says that 5 more men have contracted tularemia, otherwise known as rabbit fever, putting Colorado within striking distance of a state record for cases of what normally is a relatively rare bacterial disease. \n\nHumans can become infected with tularemia through insect bites, by touching an infected animal or inhaling the bacteria. ' \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2015-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Black Hills", "country": "Jamaica"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota 's", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3586385", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (12): (AK) hare, human", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3586385", "date": "2015-08-18 12:23:54", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (12): (ALASKA) HARE, HUMAN\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Aug 2015\nSource: Fairbanks Daily News-Miner, Alaska Department of Fish and Game [edited]\nhttp://www.newsminer.com/features/outdoors/rabbit-fever-can-be-a-serious-illness/article_65553062-4220-11e5-b291-a3406ba9696b.html\n\n\nIn an ideal context, 'rabbit fever' would refer to unbridled enthusiasm for hunting hares. But the term usually refers to a serious illness passed to people and pets by hares and rabbits. Earlier this summer [2015], a North Pole man was sickened with tularemia after skinning an infected hare. This does not mark an outbreak in Alaska, but some states in the Lower 48 are seeing multiple cases this year [2015].\n\nThis is the 1st human case in Alaska since 2009, although there have been cases of hares diagnosed with the disease in recent years. Tularemia occurs sporadically in Alaska, and this marks the 30th case in 70 years. Interior Alaska accounts for about half the total cases, and Southeast Alaska has seen only 1 case.\n\nTularemia is an infection caused by the _Francisella tularensis_ bacteria. The disease has been documented for thousands of years under a variety of names, but the tularemia bacterium was identified by American pathologists in 1912 and named for Tulare County, California. It most often kills hares but can also make people, dogs, and cats seriously ill. While it can be fatal if untreated, it is easily cured if diagnosed quickly and the correct antibiotics are prescribed.\n\nThe most common signs in people and pets are lethargy with high fever and swollen lymph nodes. Most human infections become apparent after 3 to 5 days.\n\nHares are the primary host and the disease is spread by ticks. The species of tick known to carry the bacteria prefers to live on hares, but will occasionally bite pets or people. It is most often diagnosed in hares and pets in Interior Alaska between Memorial Day [last Monday of May] and Labor Day [1st Monday in September] because the ticks are active during the summer.\n\nAlthough tick bites are one possible cause, pets most often get tularemia from mouthing or catching a sick hare.\n\nInterior residents, including trappers, can become infected by handling the hares or from the pet's saliva, even before the pet exhibits signs of illness.\n\nIn June 2009, a Fairbanks woman wrestled with her dog to take a dead hare from its mouth. She had a splinter in her right index finger and it became infected with the bacteria. A lesion developed a few days later. Within a week she developed a fever of 104 [deg F; 40 deg C] and she was in and out of the hospital for almost a month. A 2nd case was reported the same month -- also a woman who developed a skin lesion after her dog brought home a dead hare.\n\nIf your pet does come in contact with a dead hare, wear gloves or use a plastic bag to take the animal away from the pet and wash your hands thoroughly after handling anything coming out of the pet's mouth.\n\n[Byline: Riley Woodford]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the Gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread through contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.- Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIf your pet does come in contact with a dead hare, wear gloves or use a plastic bag to take the animal away from the pet and wash your hands thoroughly after handling anything coming out of the pet's mouth. ALERT\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 Jul 2015\nSource: WesternSlopeNow [edited]\nhttp://www.westernslopenow.com/story/d/story/mesa-county-rabbit-tests-positive-for-tularemia/31265/Q9-8XuY5dES2kN2rXFdwUw\n\n\nThe Mesa County Health Department is warning the public that a rabbit has tested positive for tularemia.\n\nAuthorities say the bacterial infection, also known as 'rabbit fever', was detected in an animal found on the east side of the Colorado National Monument.\n\nThe health department has received reports of multiple rabbits dying in the area; officials are warning outdoor enthusiasts, gardeners, and pet owners to avoid contact with wildlife.\n\nHealth experts say the disease is spread most often through bites from fleas and ticks. Since animals can pass the condition on to people, officials are urging pet owners to check their 4-legged friends for the bugs.\n\nSymptoms can include a high fever and swollen lymph nodes. The illness can range from mild to life-threatening, but experts say it is treatable with antibiotics.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9201. Mesa County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Mesa County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3537025", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (09): (NE, WY) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537025", "date": "2015-07-26 12:59:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (09): (NEBRASKA, WYOMING), ALERT\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 21 Jul 2015\nSource: KOTA-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kotatv.com/news/nebraska-news/sb-county-health-department-announces-an-increase-in-tularemia-cases/34279732\n\n\nThe Scotts Bluff County Health Department has been notified of a significant increase in positive tularemia cases in the county and eastern Wyoming over the past couple weeks. According to their press release, tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, is a bacterial disease associated with various animal species. It frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents and has been associated with rabbit and rodent die-offs.\n\nHumans can be infected with the bacteria through many different sources including through the bite of an infected insect, usually a tick or deerfly, handling infected animal carcasses, consuming contaminated food or water, or by inhalation of the bacteria. Tularemia is treatable with appropriate antimicrobials.\n\nSymptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure and can include a sudden high fever, headaches, swollen lymph nodes, muscle and joint pain and a sore or lesion at the site where the bacteria entered the body.\n\nTo avoid exposure to tularemia, the Scotts Bluff County Health Department encourages people to avoid handling sick or dead animals, wear rubber gloves when skinning or handling animals, cook meat thoroughly, use protective clothing and insect repellents to avoid deer-fly and tick bites, avoid untreated drinking water, and use DEET or other tick repellents during tick season.\n\n[Byline: Sydney Kern]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not apparently related to bioterrorism in this case, tularemia is a category A bioterrorism agent, and the pneumonic form is likely to be the one associated with intentional spread.\n\nTularemia is caused by _Francisella tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3-5 days, with a range of 1-14 days. - Mod.LL\n\nProMED HealthMaps:\nNebraska: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229,\nWyoming: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251.]", "summary": "\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. To avoid exposure to tularemia, the Scotts Bluff County Health Department encourages people to avoid handling sick or dead animals, wear rubber gloves when skinning or handling animals, cook meat thoroughly, use protective clothing and insect repellents to avoid deer-fly and tick bites, avoid untreated drinking water, and use DEET or other tick repellents during tick season.
