It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. TULAREMIA - USA (09): (NEBRASKA, WYOMING), ALERT\n************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3520085", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3520085", "date": "2015-07-18 22:29:55", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (08): (WYOMING)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 18 Jul 2015\nSource: Big Horn Radio Network [edited]\nhttp://www.mybighornbasin.com/Tularemia-Concerns-Raised-in-Wyoming/21762712\n\n\nRecent reports of tularemia activity among animals and humans in northern Wyoming are raising concerns this summer about the disease, according to the Wyoming Department of Health (WDH).\n\n'Recently, we are hearing about rabbit die-offs and have seen tularemia cases confirmed in 2 Weston County residents, in dead voles near Devils Tower in Crook County and in a Washakie County cat,' said Dr. Tracy Murphy, state epidemiologist with WDH. 'Tularemia is always a concern but is not common. To see this activity is concerning.'\n\nMurphy said tularemia can be a serious disease and, in rare cases, deadly. Tularemia symptoms can include fever, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, skin ulcers and diarrhea. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough and progressive weakness and pneumonia.\n\nRecommendations to help avoid tick-related diseases include:\n- Wear light-colored clothing to make it easier to see ticks crawling on clothing.\n- Tuck pant legs into socks.\n- Apply insect repellents such as those containing 20 percent or more DEET and/or picaradin.\n- Upon return from potentially tick-infested areas, search self and children for ticks and remove if found.\n- Check pets for ticks; use tick control products recommended by veterinarians.\n\nAdded precautions to help reduce tularemia risk include:\n- Avoid bathing, swimming or working in untreated water and avoid drinking untreated water.\n- Avoid handling rabbits, squirrels or other animals that appear sick.\n- Wear rubber gloves when skinning animals, especially rabbits and squirrels; skin animals in a well-ventilated area.\n- Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling sick or dead animals.\n- Cook meat thoroughly before eating, especially rabbit and squirrel.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the latest report on tularemia in the USA (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/state.html), between 2004 and 2013 Wyoming reported no more than 4 human cases per year.\n\nTularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the latest report on tularemia in the USA (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/state.html), between 2004 and 2013 Wyoming reported no more than 4 human cases per year. \n\nAdded precautions to help reduce tularemia risk include:\n- Avoid bathing, swimming or working in untreated water and avoid drinking untreated water. \n\nTularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. \n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. \n\nRecommendations to help avoid tick-related diseases include:\n- Wear light-colored clothing to make it easier to see ticks crawling on clothing. TULAREMIA - USA (08): (WYOMING)\n*******************************\n \n- Wear rubber gloves when skinning animals, especially rabbits and squirrels; skin animals in a well-ventilated area. \n- Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling sick or dead animals.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washakie County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Weston County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Crook County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3510564", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (07): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3510564", "date": "2015-07-15 11:08:53", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 Jul 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/new-mexico-reports-tularemia-in-los-alamos-county-man-26296/\n\n\nNew Mexico health officials have reported a case of human tularemia in a 51-year-old man from Los Alamos County. The man was hospitalized but has recovered and gone home. There have also been 33 cases of tularemia in 2015 in pet dogs and cats from Bernalillo, Los Alamos, Santa Fe, Taos, and Torrance Counties. This is the 1st human tularemia case seen in New Mexico in 2015. In 2014 there were 5 human cases of tularemia recorded in the state.\n\n'Tularemia can cause serious illness in both people and pets. I encourage people around the state to follow the same precautions they would to avoid contracting plague, which includes not handling sick or dead animals,' said Department of Health Cabinet Secretary, Retta Ward, MPH. 'People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals such as rabbits or rodents or if they are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies.'\n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness in people that occurs in many parts of the USA. It is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially rodents, rabbits and hares. Tularemia can also make dogs and cats sick and they can give the disease to people. Other possible, but less likely, exposures are through contact with infected soil or water or by inhaling the bacterium.\n\n'Many areas of the state have seen a large increase in the rabbit population in and a lot of them have been getting sick and dying from tularemia,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian. 'Oftentimes when there is a rabbit or rodent die off in an area due to tularemia, deer flies or ticks can become infected from these animals and then pass it on to pets or people when they bite them.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The CDC discussion on how a diagnosis of tularemia is made (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/clinicians/index.html):\nPhysicians who suspect tularemia should promptly collect appropriate specimens (see below) and alert the laboratory to the need for special diagnostic and safety procedures. Rapid diagnostic testing for tularemia is not widely available.\n\nGrowth of _Francisella tularensis_ in culture is the definitive means of confirming the diagnosis of tularemia. Appropriate specimens include swabs or scrapping of skin lesions, lymph node aspirates or biopsies, pharyngeal washings, sputum specimens, or gastric aspirates, depending on the form of illness. Paradoxically, blood cultures are often negative.\n\nA presumptive diagnosis of tularemia may be made through testing of specimens using direct fluorescent antibody, immunohistochemical staining, or PCR.\n\nThe diagnosis of tularemia can also be established serologically by demonstrating a 4-fold change in specific antibody titers between acute and convalescent sera. Convalescent sera are best drawn at least 4 weeks after illness onset; hence this method is not useful for clinical management. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Oftentimes when there is a rabbit or rodent die off in an area due to tularemia, deer flies or ticks can become infected from these animals and then pass it on to pets or people when they bite them.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The CDC discussion on how a diagnosis of tularemia is made (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/clinicians/index.html):\nPhysicians who suspect tularemia should promptly collect appropriate specimens (see below) and alert the laboratory to the need for special diagnostic and safety procedures. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Many areas of the state have seen a large increase in the rabbit population in and a lot of them have been getting sick and dying from tularemia,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian. TULAREMIA - USA (07): (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\n \n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness in people that occurs in many parts of the USA. \n\n'Tularemia can cause serious illness in both people and pets. \n\nGrowth of _Francisella tularensis_ in culture is the definitive means of confirming the diagnosis of tularemia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Los Alamos County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Los Alamos", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3537551", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (ND): human, animal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537551", "date": "2015-07-26 19:59:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (08): (NORTH DAKOTA) HUMAN. ANIMALS\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/tularemia-strikes-north-dakota-3-human-cases-dakota-zoo-primates-31540/\n\n\nNorth Dakota health and agriculture officials are reporting several cases of the bacterial zoonotic disease tularemia in both humans and animals in at least 4 counties.\n\nNorth Dakota\n\nTo date, 3 human cases have been reported: confirmed cases in LaMoure and Burleigh County and a suspect but likely case in Stark County. The health status of the 3 individuals is not known.\n\nIn addition, 2 North Dakota zoos have reported tularemia in animals. A squirrel from the Roosevelt Zoo in Minot tested positive, while 2 primates from the Dakota Zoo in Bismarck contracted the disease. Zoo officials are taking precautions to protect their animals, staff and visitors from the disease. Visiting a zoo does not pose an increased risk to the general public. However, people are advised to follow guidelines posted by the zoo against touching animals, and to avoid direct contact with wild animals, such as rabbits and rodents, which are known carriers of tularemia.\n\nTularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever' or 'deer fly fever,' frequently affects rabbits, hares and rodents and has been associated with rabbit and rodent die-offs. People may acquire tularemia when bit by infected ticks, deer flies or horse flies. It can also be transmitted by handling infected animals, or through ingestion or contact with untreated, contaminated water or insufficiently cooked meat.\n\nThe symptoms of tularemia in humans vary depending on how the infection was acquired, and generally appear 1 to 14 days after exposure. 'Symptoms of tularemia may include fever, chills, headache, muscle ache, diarrhea, sore throat and cough. When a person is bitten by an infected tick or deer fly or handles an infected animal, an ulcer may appear where the bacteria entered the skin, and lymph nodes may also become swollen and painful,' said Laura Cronquist, epidemiologist with the NDDoH (North Dakota Department of Health). 'If people have symptoms of tularemia, it is important they tell their healthcare provider about any potential exposures, including contact with sick or dead animals and tick or deer fly bites.'\n\nIn related news several states away, officials with the Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado report tularemia was detected in a dead muskrat in the Lily Lake area of the park.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Regarding humans, the follow is borrowed from Mod.LL:\n\n'In the latest report on tularemia in the USA (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/state.html), between 2004 and 2013 Wyoming reported no more than 4 human cases per year.\n\nTularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms.\n\nThe causative bacterium of tularemia, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beavers, muskrats, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [abnormally frequent urination] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death.\n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular.\n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm. - Mod.TG]\n\n[Map of North Dakota, United States: <ttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/236>]", "summary": "\n\nTularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. \n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. However, people are advised to follow guidelines posted by the zoo against touching animals, and to avoid direct contact with wild animals, such as rabbits and rodents, which are known carriers of tularemia. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n If people have symptoms of tularemia, it is important they tell their healthcare provider about any potential exposures, including contact with sick or dead animals and tick or deer fly bites.' Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/tularemia-strikes-north-dakota-3-human-cases-dakota-zoo-primates-31540/\n\n\nNorth Dakota health and agriculture officials are reporting several cases of the bacterial zoonotic disease tularemia in both humans and animals in at least 4 counties. When a person is bitten by an infected tick or deer fly or handles an infected animal, an ulcer may appear where the bacteria entered the skin, and lymph nodes may also become swollen and painful,' said Laura Cronquist, epidemiologist with the NDDoH (North Dakota Department of Health). \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. \n\nTularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever' or 'deer fly fever,' In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Regarding humans, the follow is borrowed from Mod. \n\nIn related news several states away, officials with the Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado report tularemia was detected in a dead muskrat in the Lily Lake area of the park. \n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. It can also be transmitted by handling infected animals, or through ingestion or contact with untreated, contaminated water or insufficiently cooked meat. \n\nNorth Dakota\n\n \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). People may acquire tularemia when bit by infected ticks, deer flies or horse flies. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. The symptoms of tularemia in humans vary depending on how the infection was acquired, and generally appear 1 to 14 days after exposure. ' Symptoms of tularemia may include fever, chills, headache, muscle ache, diarrhea, sore throat and cough.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bismarck", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Stark County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LaMoure", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minot", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burleigh County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3580618", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (13): (NM, WY, AZ) human, animal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3580618", "date": "2015-08-19 20:05:20", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (13): (NEW MEXICO, WYOMING, ARIZONA) HUMAN, ANIMAL\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] New Mexico: human\n[2] Wyoming: animal, alert\n[3] Arizona: (Coconino County) human\n\n******\n[1] New Mexico: human\nDate: Thu 13 Aug 2015\nSource: New Mexico Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://nmhealth.org/news/disease/2015/8/?view=291\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today [13 Aug 2015] a confirmed case of tularemia in a 71-year-old man from Bernalillo County. The case was confirmed at the Department's Scientific Laboratory Division. 2 earlier cases of tularemia were reported in a 39-year-old man and a 42-year-old woman from Bernalillo County. They have also recovered. The Department suspects the 3 individuals in Bernalillo County contracted tularemia through deer fly bites.\n\nAnother 3 cases in the state occurred in a 35-year-old woman from Sandoval County, a 59-year-old woman from San Juan County who was bitten by her infected cat, and a 51-year-old man from Los Alamos County. These individuals were hospitalized but have recovered. There have also been 43 cases of tularemia in 2015 in dogs and cats, with pets from Bernalillo, Los Alamos, Santa Fe, Taos, and Torrance counties.\n\n'Tularemia can cause serious illness in both people and pets so I would encourage people around the state to follow precautions similar to reducing risk to plague,' said Department of Health Cabinet Secretary, Retta Ward, MPH. 'People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals such as rabbits or rodents or are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies.'\n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness in people that occurs in many parts of the USA. It is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially rodents, rabbits, and hares. Tularemia can also make dogs and cats sick and they can give the disease to people. Other possible, but much less likely, exposures are through contact with infected soil or water or by inhaling the bacterium.\n\nSymptoms of tularemia in people usually develop 3 to 5 days after exposure but onset can vary from one to 14 days. Tularemia symptoms are similar to plague infection including sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscles aches, and joint pain. Other symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the tularemia bacteria and can include pneumonia and chest pain, ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat.\n\n'The rabbit population has increased dramatically in many areas of the state this summer [2015] due to abundant rainfall and vegetation, and a lot of them have been getting sick and dying from tularemia,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian. 'This has led to an increase in both human and pet cases of tularemia with various types of exposures, including bites from infected insects, bites from infected cats, handling of infected rabbit carcasses, etc.'\n\n'The City of Albuquerque maintains a surveillance program for tularemia in wild animals,' said Dr Paul Smith, Manager of the Albuquerque Environmental Health Department Urban Biology Division. 'We encourage people to report dead animals that have not died from obvious trauma by calling 311 so that we can collect them for testing.'\n\nIn 2014 there were 5 human cases of tularemia in New Mexico, a 65-year-old woman from Bernalillo County, a 78-year-old man and a 70-year-old woman both from San Juan County, a 66-year-old man from Lincoln County, and a 69-year-old woman from Sandoval County. All 5 individuals were hospitalized and recovered.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia linked to bites from deer flies or ticks generally presents as ulceroglandular (an ulcer at the bite site with swollen painful regional lymph nodes or just glandular but the typhoidal form with just fever and bacteremia may occur. - Mod.LL]\n\nThe state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Wyoming: animal, alert\nDate: Thu 13 Jul 2015\nSource: Wyoming Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.wyodaily.com/story/2015/08/13/news/tularemia-found-in-washakie-county-cat/316.html\n\n\nTularemia, plague, West Nile virus, rabies, vesicular stomatitis -- Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory [WSVL] experts are cautioning residents to monitor not only their pets and livestock, but also themselves this summer [2015]. Several cases of tularemia in wildlife and domestic animals have been diagnosed by the WSVL, including in Albany, Platte, and Washakie counties, said Will Laegreid, WSVL director. 'There have been a number of human tularemia cases in Colorado this summer [2015] and (Wyoming), and we would like to prevent any more cases in Wyoming if possible,' Laegreid said.\n\nThe Wyoming Department of Health Public Information Officer Kim Deti said that there have been 8 human cases to date in Wyoming -- 4 in Weston County, and 1 each in Big Horn, Natrona, Converse, and Goshen. She said some of the people have had to be hospitalized.\n\nWyoming Department of Health state epidemiologist, Dr Tracy Murphy said in a 17 Jul 2015 news release, 'Recently, we are hearing about rabbit die-offs, in dead voles near Devils Tower in Crook County and in a Washakie County cat,' said. 'Tularemia is always a concern but is not common. To see this activity is concerning.'\n\nLaegreid said his office has not received any other confirmed cases in Washakie County, regarding domestic and wild animals. 'Historically it's been around but there have been none in the past 5 years,' Mandy Thoet, veterinarian at Cloud Peak Veterinary Services in Worland, said. 'It is zoonotic (can pass to humans), that's why there is a concern,' she said.\n\nEcho Study of Tharp Veterinary Clinic in Worland said the cat that tested positive was treated at the clinic and was from Ten Sleep. She said the owners had notice a lot of rabbits dying off in the area. 'People need to be aware and to protect themselves, they need to protect their pets,' Study said.\n\n[Byline: Will Laegreid]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Wyoming can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/wyoming-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[3] Arizona: (Coconino County) human\nDate: Tue 18 Aug 2015\nSource: Arizona Daily Sun [summ., edited]\nhttp://azdailysun.com/news/local/coconino-county-confirms-human-cases-of-rabbit-fever/article_6e0c1b44-be70-5c9a-be5a-40121ecb7f96.html\n\n\nTo date, 2 human cases of tularemia or 'rabbit fever' have been confirmed in Coconino County. They are the 1st confirmed cases in the county since 2005. The 2 individuals were likely exposed from insect bites sometime in July [2015], according to officials with the Coconino County Public Health Services District. The 2 people were not related and it was not the same incident, said Trish Lees, spokeswoman with the district. 1 of the people was in northern region of the county when the bite occurred and the other was in the southern region, Lees said.\n\n'There is no link (between the incidents) that we can verify,' she said. She said she cannot release information about what symptoms people experienced or what they may have been doing when they were bitten. Both sought medical attention and were prescribed antimicrobials, she said.\n\nThe disease does not spread from person to person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Arizona can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3941. Coconino County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/arizona-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nTo see a map of the number of cases of human tularemia in the USA 2004-2013, go to http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/map.html. The states with the most cases are those in the central area of the country centered around Arkansas, Missouri, and Oklahoma.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria (abnormally frequent urination) may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antimicrobials. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nIn 2014 there were 5 human cases of tularemia in New Mexico, a 65-year-old woman from Bernalillo County, a 78-year-old man and a 70-year-old woman both from San Juan County, a 66-year-old man from Lincoln County, and a 69-year-old woman from Sandoval County. This has led to an increase in both human and pet cases of tularemia with various types of exposures, including bites from infected insects, bites from infected cats, handling of infected rabbit carcasses, etc.'\n\n'The City of Albuquerque maintains a surveillance program for tularemia in wild animals,' said Dr Paul Smith, Manager of the Albuquerque Environmental Health Department Urban Biology Division. \n\nAnother 3 cases in the state occurred in a 35-year-old woman from Sandoval County, a 59-year-old woman from San Juan County who was bitten by her infected cat, and a 51-year-old man from Los Alamos County. USA (04): (CO) rabbit, dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3479571", "date": "2015-07-02 14:39:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (COLORADO) RABBIT, DOG\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed, 1 Jul 2015\nSource: The Gazette [edited]\nhttp://gazette.com/dog-rabbit-infected-with-tularemia-in-el-paso-county/article/1554752\n\n\nA dog was infected and at least 1 rabbit died recently in Yoder of tularemia -- a bacterial infection known as 'rabbit fever' that has spiked in recent years across Colorado.\n\nThe dog is being treated with antibiotics. People who were in contact with it will be assessed and monitored in the coming days, though none has tested positive for the disease, according to El Paso County Public Health.\n\nThe animal infections mark the 1st confirmed cases in El Paso County in 2015, and they come as the state deals with a spike in cases.\n\n12 people across Colorado have contracted the disease so far in 2015, and 16 people were infected during 2014 -- far above the handful of cases reported annually.\n\nEl Paso County health officials urge people to be cautious around dead or sick animals.\n\nA Yoder resident noticed many dead rabbits in the area, and 1 of the dead rabbits tested positive for the virus Monday [29 Jun 2015], the health department said.\n\nNo humans in El Paso County have been infected since 2010, the health department said.\n\nTularemia, which is endemic to the county, is typically transmitted when humans handle sick or dead animals infected with the disease, such as while hunting. It can also be transmitted by infected insects, such as ticks or deer flies.\n\nSymptoms generally mimic the plague, causing fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain and coughing, the health department said.\n\n[Byline: Jakob Rodgers]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram-negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nTularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_(Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKr. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n12 people across Colorado have contracted the disease so far in 2015, and 16 people were infected during 2014 -- far above the handful of cases reported annually. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram-negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. \n\nTularemia, which is endemic to the county, is typically transmitted when humans handle sick or dead animals infected with the disease, such as while hunting. \n\n[Byline: Jakob Rodgers]\n\n--\n Source: The Gazette [edited]\nhttp://gazette.com/dog-rabbit-infected-with-tularemia-in-el-paso-county/article/1554752\n\n\nA dog was infected and at least 1 rabbit died recently in Yoder of tularemia -- a bacterial infection known as 'rabbit fever' that has spiked in recent years across Colorado. \n\nSymptoms generally mimic the plague, causing fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain and coughing, the health department said. \n\nNo humans in El Paso County have been infected since 2010, the health department said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2015-06-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "El Paso County Public Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3480207", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (AK) susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3480207", "date": "2015-07-02 15:02:49", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (ALASKA) SUSPECTED\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 Jul 2015\nSource: News Miner [edited]\nhttp://www.newsminer.com/news/local_news/tularemia-suspected-in-illness-of-north-pole-man/article_7436ad5e-2024-11e5-a630-4b5a8b0fd336.html\n\n\nA rare disease is the suspected cause of an illness that sickened a North Pole man this spring, according to a news release from the Alaska Department of Fish and Game. Tularemia is a bacterial infection that can spread to humans who handle hares or other animals or through dogs or cats that come into contact with infected ticks or by aerosol. Human cases of tularemia are increased this summer of 2015 in Colorado with 11 cases, the largest number in state history to this point of the year. New Mexico also reported human tularemia cases this year. In the North Pole case, the man became sick after skinning a hare.\n\nAccording to the CDC, human tularemia cases in the USA were reported twice as often in the 1950s than in recent years. Between 1990 and 2013, the most recent year with data available, there were fewer than 200 reported human cases per year. In humans, tularemia usually causes a fever, which can be as high as 104 degrees. Other symptoms can include a skin ulcer at the site of the infection and swollen lymph glands.\n\nIn hares, signs of tularemia include slow movement, which makes the hares easier for pets to catch. Infected hares sometimes have enlarged spleen and livers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_ , is a non-sporulating, Gram-negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 percent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary host, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beaver, muskrat, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [extraordinary daytime urinary frequency] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. In this case, it is expected that the person had ulceroglandular tularemia after introduction of the bacterium into an obvious or subtle skin cut. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/206.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Human cases of tularemia are increased this summer of 2015 in Colorado with 11 cases, the largest number in state history to this point of the year. Tularemia is a bacterial infection that can spread to humans who handle hares or other animals or through dogs or cats that come into contact with infected ticks or by aerosol. \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. In hares, signs of tularemia include slow movement, which makes the hares easier for pets to catch. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. TULAREMIA - USA (05): (ALASKA) SUSPECTED\n****************************************\n Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. Between 1990 and 2013, the most recent year with data available, there were fewer than 200 reported human cases per year. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. In domestic animals, sheep are the primary host, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). According to the CDC, human tularemia cases in the USA were reported twice as often in the 1950s than in recent years. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beaver, muskrat, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3467769", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (03): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3467769", "date": "2015-06-26 20:22:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (03): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 24 Jun 2015\nSource: Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28374467/colorado-health-officials:-tularemia-cases-on-recordbreaking-pace\n\n\nColorado health officials: Tularemia cases on record-breaking pace\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nColorado health officials have recorded 11 human cases of tularemia since May 2015, putting the state on pace for one of the most widespread years for the disease in more than 2 decades. In 2014, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment [CDPHE] recorded 16 human cases, representing the 2nd highest number of cases since 1983 when there were 20. Before 2014, the previous average was fewer than 4 cases a year.\n\n'People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals, such as rabbits, rodents or hares, or are bitten by ticks or deer flies,' CDPHE said in a Wednesday [24 Jun 2014] news release. 'They also can be exposed by touching contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria.'\n\nTwo Weld County men were diagnosed with tularemia -- also known as rabbit fever -- last week and health officials believe both were most likely exposed while mowing or working in their yards. 'We are seeing an unusually high number of human tularemia cases along the Front Range this year,' Dr. Mark E. Wallace, executive director of the Weld County Health Department, said last week in a statement. 'The public really needs to be cautious and not get exposed to this disease.'\n\nA Boulder County resident who contracted tularemia in May 2015 after doing yardwork later died. That person's case was the 1st in Boulder County in 2015.\n\nHealth officials say tularemia can be avoided by wearing gloves while gardening or landscaping, using a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work, disposing of animal carcasses by using a long-handled shovel to place them in a garbage bag and wearing insect repellent when outdoors.\n\n[Byline: Jesse Paul]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As noted, humans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. A number of the cases reported were from aerosols associated with lawnmowers where the bacilli can be introduced into the respiratory tract causing a pneumonia that can be fatal. This has occurred in the past, particularly on Martha's Vineyard, an island off of Massachusetts, where tularemia pneumonia occurs in gardeners and landscapers primarily. Oculoglandular and oroglandular tularemia can also occur with aerosols.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nHealth officials say tularemia can be avoided by wearing gloves while gardening or landscaping, using a dust mask when mowing or doing yard work, disposing of animal carcasses by using a long-handled shovel to place them in a garbage bag and wearing insect repellent when outdoors. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As noted, humans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. \n\nTwo Weld County men were diagnosed with tularemia -- also known as rabbit fever -- last week and health officials believe both were most likely exposed while mowing or working in their yards. ' TULAREMIA - USA (03): (COLORADO)\n********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2015-05-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-06-24 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3403896", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (02): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3403896", "date": "2015-06-03 04:39:45", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 May 2015\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/health/tularemia-patient-in-lafayette-dies-of-other-medical-complications\n\n\nFollowing increased reports of tularemia over the past few years, a patient who recently contracted the disease while gardening has died of other medical complications. Boulder County Public Health spokeswoman Chana Goussetis said the Lafayette resident tested positive for tularemia after developing symptoms of high fever, headache, and general malaise. It is believed the patient contracted the illness while mowing and gardening.\n\nWhile this person was the 1st to test positive for tularemia in Boulder County in 2015, the county health department says 3 other cases were reported elsewhere in Colorado. All were associated with people who had recently been gardening or landscaping. Seven animals have also tested positive for the disease in 2015.\n\n'People become infected with tularemia through skin contact with infected animal tissue or through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies,' Goussetis said. 'The bacteria can also be inhaled when infected animal tissue is broken up into small particles and spread in the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.' In 2014, 16 people tested positive for the disease in Colorado, Goussetis said. Five of those were residents of Boulder County.\n\n'Symptoms of tularemia include an abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure,' Goussetis said. 'Symptoms also include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Tularemia is treatable when detected early.'\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. Boulder County in north central Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'People become infected with tularemia through skin contact with infected animal tissue or through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies,' Goussetis said. ' \n\nHumans become infected through various mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n'Symptoms of tularemia include an abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure,' Goussetis said. ' The bacteria can also be inhaled when infected animal tissue is broken up into small particles and spread in the air, such as when an infected carcass is mowed over.' \n\nWhile this person was the 1st to test positive for tularemia in Boulder County in 2015, the county health department says 3 other cases were reported elsewhere in Colorado.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3465858", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, animal - USA (02): (NM) canine, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3465858", "date": "2015-06-26 10:44:40", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, ANIMAL - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) CANINE, ALERT\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Jun 2015\nSource: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.abqjournal.com/602985/news/two-dogs-confirmed-with-tularemia-in-east-mountains.html\n\n\nHealth officials are advising East Mountains residents to be aware of a potential risk from tularemia after 2 dogs recently were confirmed to have contracted the disease.\n\nTularemia is a highly infectious bacterial disease similar to plague, according to a news release from the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department and the Bernalillo County Health and Protection Section. The organism commonly occurs in rabbits and rodents, and can kill large numbers of rabbits quickly, authorities said.\n\nHuman symptoms include chills, fever, severe headache, and occasionally skin lesions. Disease transmission can occur from the bite of an infected tick or deer fly, or from close contact with an infected [animal].\n\n'The rain and increased vegetation we have seen over the last several months has provided extra food and harborage for rodent and rabbit populations,' said Dr Paul Smith, a manager for the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department, in a statement. 'A larger number of rodents and rabbits often leads to more occurrences of both tularemia and plague.'\n\nThere have been no human cases of plague or tularemia so far in Bernalillo County in 2015, [but] 5 dogs and 1 rabbit have been confirmed with tularemia infection.\n\n'Dogs and cats can become infected with plague and tularemia through hunting rodents and rabbits or by exposure to their fleas or ticks.' said Dr Mark DiMenna, Deputy Director for the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department. 'People are often exposed when their pets bring these infected fleas or ticks into the house or through direct contact with the sick or dead rodent.'\n\nAuthorities offered the following tips to reduce the risk of plague and tularemia:\n- Keep your pets from roaming and hunting\n- Talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea and tick control product on your pets\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles\n- Don't allow children or others to handle sick or dead wildlife\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian\n- See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever\n- Put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home\n- Don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it\n- Avoid mowing over dead animals\n- Bernalillo County citizens living east of Tramway Blvd. should report sick or dead rodents and rabbits to 311. Rodents or rabbits with obvious signs of injury (gunshot wounds, bite wounds, etc.) do not need to be reported.\n\nFor more information about plague and tularemia visit the Environmental Health website at http://www.cabq.gov/environmentalhealth/urban-biology\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6643. Albuquerque, county seat of Bernalillo County in central New Mexico, can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[The causative bacterium of tularemia, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beavers, muskrats, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially. Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod., which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [abnormally frequent urination] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death.\n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular.\n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\nAuthorities offered the following tips to reduce the risk of plague and tularemia:\n- Keep your pets from roaming and hunting\n- Talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea and tick control product on your pets\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles\n- Don't allow children or others to handle sick or dead wildlife\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian\n- See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever\n- Put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home\n- Don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it\n- Avoid mowing over dead animals\n- Bernalillo County citizens living east of Tramway Blvd. should report sick or dead rodents and rabbits to 311. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who skin, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. \n\nThere have been no human cases of plague or tularemia so far in Bernalillo County in 2015, [but] 5 dogs and 1 rabbit have been confirmed with tularemia infection. \n\n'Dogs and cats can become infected with plague and tularemia through hunting rodents and rabbits or by exposure to their fleas or ticks.' said Dr Mark DiMenna, Deputy Director for the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department. For more information about plague and tularemia visit the Environmental Health website at http://www.cabq.gov/environmentalhealth/urban-biology\n\n--\n \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. \n\nTularemia is a highly infectious bacterial disease similar to plague, according to a news release from the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department and the Bernalillo County Health and Protection Section. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. \n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. ' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia. \n\nHuman symptoms include chills, fever, severe headache, and occasionally skin lesions. In domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia.
