Date: Tue 23 Jun 2015\n Source: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\n A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3380738", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, animal - Czech Republic: (MO) hare", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3380738", "date": "2015-05-23 12:57:56", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, ANIMAL - CZECH REPUBLIC (MORAVIA) HARE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 May 2015\nSource: Denik.CZ [in Czech, machine translated Corr.SB, summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.denik.cz/jihomoravsky-kraj/myslivci-na-veselsku-objevili-nemocne-zajice-tularemie-je-prenosna-i-na-cloveka-20150520-ajj7.html\n\n\nAccording to Josef Radosta, president of the hunters association in Bukova Veseli, upper Moravia, a rabbit disease has been identified in hunted hares which were seen to be malnourished. Mortality has been observed as well. The sick animals 'lose shyness'. The infection is transmitted between animals mainly by ticks and mosquitoes.\n\nThe disease can also infect humans, who become infected when butchering the infected animal or by inhaling dust particles. 'Tularemia is an acute or chronic bacterial diseases of rabbits and rodents, but also other animals. In the acute form of the disease animals are torpid and have chronic elevated temperatures. The chronic form of tularemia is characterized by emaciation and swollen lymph nodes. And again, the loss of alertness and agility,' explained veterinarian Martina Sukupova.\n\nChairman of the district of hunting club in Hodonin Radovan Mancik said that tularemia was not widespread across the board. 'There is incidence of the disease in Veselsky but I have no knowledge about that in the Hodonin district. Investigation of this disease is no longer obligatory for several years,' said the chairman of the association.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 2014 annual report of the Czech Republic to the OIE regarding zoonotic diseases, 49 human cases of tularemia were recorded during 2014; no mortalities.\n\nThe bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ causes the vectorborne zoonotic disease tularemia, and may infect a wide range of hosts including invertebrates, mammals and birds. Transmission to humans occurs through contact with infected animals or contaminated environments, or through arthropod vectors. Tularemia has a broad geographical distribution, and there is evidence suggesting that local emergence or re-emergence of this disease in Europe. This review was developed to provide an update on the geographical distribution of _F. tularensis_ in humans, wildlife, domestic animals and vector species, to identify potential public health hazards, and to characterize the epidemiology of tularemia in Europe. According to a recent review article on Tularemia in Europe (see ref), 18 343 human cases of tularemia were reported to the WHO-CISID or ECDC databases between 1992 and 2012. Sweden reported 25 per cent of all reported cases, Finland 22 per cent, Turkey 13 per cent and the Czech Republic and Hungary around 9 per cent each. Subscribers may wish to download the (freely available) paper.\n\nFor additional background information on Tularemia in animals and its zoonotic implications, please see commentary by Mod.TG in ProMED-mail archived post 20150517.3368467.\n\nReference:\nG Hestvik, E Warns-Petit, LA Smith, et al. The status of tularemia in Europe in a one-health context: a review. Epidemiol Infect. Published: 2014-09-30. http://journals.cambridge.org/abstract_S0950268814002398. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/110.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< This review was developed to provide an update on the geographical distribution of _F. tularensis_ in humans, wildlife, domestic animals and vector species, to identify potential public health hazards, and to characterize the epidemiology of tularemia in Europe. \n\nThe bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ causes the vectorborne zoonotic disease tularemia, and may infect a wide range of hosts including invertebrates, mammals and birds. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 2014 annual report of the Czech Republic to the OIE regarding zoonotic diseases, 49 human cases of tularemia were recorded during 2014; no mortalities. According to a recent review article on Tularemia in Europe (see ref), 18 343 human cases of tularemia were reported to the WHO-CISID or ECDC databases between 1992 and 2012. TULAREMIA, ANIMAL - CZECH REPUBLIC (MORAVIA) HARE\n*************************************************\n Sweden reported 25 per cent of all reported cases, Finland 22 per cent, Turkey 13 per cent and the Czech Republic and Hungary around 9 per cent each. Tularemia has a broad geographical distribution, and there is evidence suggesting that local emergence or re-emergence of this disease in Europe. \n\nChairman of the district of hunting club in Hodonin Radovan Mancik said that tularemia was not widespread across the board. ' Tularemia is an acute or chronic bacterial diseases of rabbits and rodents, but also other animals. In the acute form of the disease animals are torpid and have chronic elevated temperatures.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-05-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-09-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "Czechia"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Veselsky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "Finland"}, {"location": "Hungary", "country": "Hungary"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3379806", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3379806", "date": "2015-05-22 14:28:16", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA: (COLORADO)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 May 2015\nSource: 7 News Denver, Associated Press report [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/front-range/fort-collins/first-case-of-rabbit-fever-confirmed-in-larimer-county_02725301_\n\n\nThe Larimer County [Colorado] Department of Health has confirmed the 1st human case in 2015 of tularemia, otherwise known as 'rabbit fever'. The victim, who lives in northern Larimer County, was infected while planting trees or gardening. Soil can be contaminated by bacteria from the droppings or urine of sick animals and bacteria can enter the skin through tiny cuts or abrasions, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment.\n\nOfficials said there's been a recent die-off of rabbits in the neighborhood, which suggests a possible tularemia outbreak among the animals in that area. 'These bacteria can persist in the soil or water for weeks, and it takes very few bacteria to cause an infection,' Katie O'Donnell said in a news release to the community.\n\nIn the summer of 2014, residents in Larimer, Broomfield, Weld and Boulder counties were diagnosed with tularemia.\n\n[byline: Deb Stanley]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Colorado saw 15 human cases of tularemia reported in 2014, 5 times the annual average for the state. Tularemia-related small-mammal die-offs were reported in at least 27 Colorado counties.\n\nThe manifestations of _Francisella tularensis_ infection are not stated.\n\nTularemia is caused by _F. tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States, an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation, as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as acanthamoeba), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of 1 to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of exposure. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza [inflammation of the mucous membranes lining the nasal cavity], and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298.]", "summary": "\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation, as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as acanthamoeba), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. Soil can be contaminated by bacteria from the droppings or urine of sick animals and bacteria can enter the skin through tiny cuts or abrasions, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boulder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2829512", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): (CO) hunter warning", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2829512", "date": "2014-10-03 23:29:38", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (08): (COLORADO) HUNTER WARNING\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Oct 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/colorado-sees-most-tularemia-cases-in-decades-prompting-warning-for-small-game-hunters-45985/\n\n\nOctober is the beginning of small game hunting season in Colorado. As the number of human tularemia cases in our state continues to rise, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment reminds small game hunters to 'hunt healthy' in 2014.\n\n'We haven't seen this many tularemia cases in Colorado since the 1980s,' said State Public Health Veterinarian Dr. Jennifer House. 'Historically, we see cases of tularemia in hunters, and the disease is so widespread in 2014, we want to make sure our hunters understand the risks.'\n\n'In the last 10 years Colorado has averaged 3 human cases of tularemia a year,' Dr. House said. 'So far in 2014 we have had 11, and additional suspected cases are under investigation.'\n\nLocal health departments have received numerous reports of rabbit and rodent die-offs across the state in 2014. Animals from 12 counties tested positive for tularemia, a bacterial disease that can affect small game animals. It commonly causes illness and death in rabbits and rodents such as squirrels. People can get tularemia if they handle infected animals or are bitten by ticks or deer flies.\n\nPeople also can be exposed to tularemia by touching contaminated soil, drinking contaminated water or inhaling bacteria. Hunters are most at risk when skinning game and preparing and consuming the meat.\n\nHunters should:\n- Harvest only small game that looks and acts healthy. Beware of lazy rabbits!\n- Avoid hunting in areas where dead small game has been found.\n- Wear gloves when handling small game animals, and wash your hands after removing your gloves.\n- Cook all game meat thoroughly to 160-170 F.\n- Notify your public health department or local wildlife office if you notice sick or dead rabbits or rodents.\n- Symptoms of tularemia include abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, vomiting, dry cough and difficulty breathing. Other symptoms are skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea or pneumonia. Tularemia often is overlooked as a diagnosis because it is rare, and the symptoms are similar to other diseases. 9/11 people infected with tularemia this year were hospitalized for treatment.\n- Anyone who becomes ill after exposure to a sick or dead animal, or after spending time in areas where sick or dead wild animals have been seen, should talk to a health care provider about the possibility of tularemia.\n- Tularemia is treatable with antibiotics.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. [The bacterium] _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\n\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria.\n\nThe type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of disease in these cases is not stated. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n- Cook all game meat thoroughly to 160-170 F.\n- Notify your public health department or local wildlife office if you notice sick or dead rabbits or rodents. As the number of human tularemia cases in our state continues to rise, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment reminds small game hunters to 'hunt healthy' in 2014. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. - Anyone who becomes ill after exposure to a sick or dead animal, or after spending time in areas where sick or dead wild animals have been seen, should talk to a health care provider about the possibility of tularemia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. \n\nHunters should:\n- Harvest only small game that looks and acts healthy. TULAREMIA - USA (08): (COLORADO) HUNTER WARNING\n***********************************************\n \n- Wear gloves when handling small game animals, and wash your hands after removing your gloves. Animals from 12 counties tested positive for tularemia, a bacterial disease that can affect small game animals. \n- Symptoms of tularemia include abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, vomiting, dry cough and difficulty breathing. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3368467", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, animal - USA: (NM) multiple species", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3368467", "date": "2015-05-17 20:32:35", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, ANIMAL - USA: (NEW MEXICO), MULTIPLE SPECIES\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 15 May 2015\nSource: TribTown [edited]\nhttp://www.tribtown.com/view/story/18f45040957c4febbdaabb2166ca61b3/NM--Plague-Tularemia-Cases\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health says 10 cases of tularemia have been reported in animals around the state since 1 Jan 2015.\n\nTularemia cases include one cat from Los Alamos County, a dog from Taos County, 3 dogs and a rabbit from Santa Fe County and 3 dogs and one rabbit from Bernalillo County.\n\nTularemia is a bacterial disease of rodents and rabbits and can be transmitted to people by the bites of infected ticks or deer flies.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beavers, muskrats, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially [Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. - CopyEd.MSP], which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress [skin], prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [abnormally frequent urination] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death.\n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular.\n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress [skin], prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non-sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. \n\nTularemia is a bacterial disease of rodents and rabbits and can be transmitted to people by the bites of infected ticks or deer flies. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. \n\nTularemia cases include one cat from Los Alamos County, a dog from Taos County, 3 dogs and a rabbit from Santa Fe County and 3 dogs and one rabbit from Bernalillo County. \n\nUse of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. In domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. \n\nControl is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. \n\n--\n If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taos County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Alamos County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2783744", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (06): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2783744", "date": "2014-09-18 16:47:31", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (06): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 17 Sep 2014\nSource: Daily Reporter, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.greenfieldreporter.com/view/story/38226a5f0d7e4c2ca96804633f048519/CO--Rabbit-Fever\n\n\nHealth officials say a Louisville woman has tested positive for tularemia, the 2nd human case of 'rabbit fever' in Boulder County in 2014.\n\nBoulder County Public Health officials say the woman was exposed to a dead rabbit while she was walking her dog in an open space in Louisville. The woman said her dog picked up the rabbit and while she was trying to get it out of the dog's mouth, it may have touched a small cut on her knee.\n\nThe Daily Camera reported Wed 17 Sep 2014 (http://bit.ly/YTE6m6) that she was hospitalized but is now recovering at home.\n\nStatewide, 9 people and 19 animals have tested positive for the disease this year [2014].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\n\nHumans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms.\n\nThe type of disease in this case is not stated but is likely to be ulceroglanular in the inguinal area as the possible contact point was the knee. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. Boulder County in north central Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. \n\nHumans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. \n\nStatewide, 9 people and 19 animals have tested positive for the disease this year [2014]. TULAREMIA - USA (06): (COLORADO)\n********************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nBoulder County Public Health officials say the woman was exposed to a dead rabbit while she was walking her dog in an open space in Louisville.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Louisville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2684689", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain: crayfish exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2684689", "date": "2014-08-15 00:00:31", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN: CRAYFISH EXPOSURE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Aug 2014\nSource: ABC.es [in Spanish, machine transl., edited]\nhttp://www.abc.es/local-castilla-leon/20140812/abci-tularemia-cangrejos-201408120912.html\n\n\nAs happened in 2007, contact with crayfish in some areas of Castile and Leon because of their appreciated gastronomic value, appears to be related to some cases of human tularemia infection. At least 3 of the 5 cases of tularemia in Palencia are related to the freshwater crustacean, and there are 7 other patients who have symptoms of the infection caused by _Francisella tularensis_.\n\nAs has also occurred 7 years ago [2007], the infection that is ravaging voles in Tierra de Campos, and especially Palencia, is the primary source of tularemia. In this sense, the crayfish act as a transmitter of the bacterium, acquired from water containing the corpses of voles, rabbits or hares affected by tularemia, to the people who handle the crustacean.\n\nIt must be borne in mind that, in the summer, with water flow diminished, the crayfish can be found on or near the shores of the waters where they live, and can more easily come in contact with corpses of vertebrates infected with tularemia [or just the water contaminated by _F. tularensis_ - Mod.LL].\n\nThere could be many more cases, since not only the fishing or manipulation of the crayfish are behind the cases of tularemia detected in recent days.\n\nThe agricultural organization Asaja Palencia said, 'There could be many more in the near future because it is impossible not to come in contact with the voles clogging sprayers, filling the siphons and roaming the field.'\n\nThe different routes of infection of tularemia cause different clinical pictures in the affected, although with a common denominator: fever, pain and discomfort. The chief of the territorial service for health of Castile and Leon in Palencia, Carmen Andres, explained that 'in the 12 cases detected we have everything, ulceroglandular forms from direct contact and forms involving the respiratory tract.'\n\n[Byline: Raul Gonzalez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report relates to a parallel outbreak in Spain linked at least in part to crayfish exposure in Spain:\n\nAnda P, Segura del Pozo J, Diaz Garcia JM, et al: Waterborne outbreak of tularemia associated with crayfish fishing. Emerg Infect Dis. 2001; 7(3 Suppl): 575-582.\n\nAbstract:\n'In 1997, an outbreak of human tularemia associated with hare-hunting in central Spain affected 585 patients. We describe the identification of _Francisella tularensis_ biovar palaearctica in a 2nd outbreak of ulceroglandular tularemia associated with crayfish (_Procambarus clarkii_) fishing in a contaminated freshwater stream distant from the hare-associated outbreak. The 2nd outbreak occurred 1 year after the 1st.'\n\nCrayfish, also known as crawfish, crawdads, freshwater lobsters, or mudbugs (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crayfish), are freshwater crustaceans resembling small lobsters, to which they are related; taxonomically, they are members of the superfamilies Astacoidea and Parastacoidea. They breathe through feather-like gills and are found in bodies of water that do not freeze to the bottom. Some species are found in brooks and streams where there is fresh water running, while others thrive in swamps, ditches, and rice paddies. Crayfish feed on living and dead animals and plants.\n\nCastile and Leon (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castile_and_Le\u00f3n) is an autonomous community in northwestern Spain. It was constituted in 1983, although it existed for the 1st time during the 1st Spanish Republic in the 19th century. It is the largest autonomous community in Spain and the 3rd largest region of the European Union. Its location on a map can be seen at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Castile_and_Le\u00f3n. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/43.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report relates to a parallel outbreak in Spain linked at least in part to crayfish exposure in Spain:\n\nAnda P, Segura del Pozo J, Diaz Garcia JM, et al: Waterborne outbreak of tularemia associated with crayfish fishing. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIt must be borne in mind that, in the summer, with water flow diminished, the crayfish can be found on or near the shores of the waters where they live, and can more easily come in contact with corpses of vertebrates infected with tularemia [or just the water contaminated by _F. tularensis_ - Mod. We describe the identification of _Francisella tularensis_ biovar palaearctica in a 2nd outbreak of ulceroglandular tularemia associated with crayfish (_Procambarus clarkii_) fishing in a contaminated freshwater stream distant from the hare-associated outbreak. \n\nThere could be many more cases, since not only the fishing or manipulation of the crayfish are behind the cases of tularemia detected in recent days. \n\nCrayfish, also known as crawfish, crawdads, freshwater lobsters, or mudbugs (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crayfish), are freshwater crustaceans resembling small lobsters, to which they are related; taxonomically, they are members of the superfamilies Astacoidea and Parastacoidea. Abstract:\n'In 1997, an outbreak of human tularemia associated with hare-hunting in central Spain affected 585 patients. http://www.abc.es/local-castilla-leon/20140812/abci-tularemia-cangrejos-201408120912.html\n\n\nAs happened in 2007, contact with crayfish in some areas of Castile and Leon because of their appreciated gastronomic value, appears to be related to some cases of human tularemia infection. \n\nAs has also occurred 7 years ago [2007], the infection that is ravaging voles in Tierra de Campos, and especially Palencia, is the primary source of tularemia. In this sense, the crayfish act as a transmitter of the bacterium, acquired from water containing the corpses of voles, rabbits or hares affected by tularemia, to the people who handle the crustacean. \n\n[Byline: Raul Gonzalez]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3014671", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (09): (CO) humans, beavers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3014671", "date": "2014-12-06 00:24:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (09): (COLORADO), HUMANS, BEAVERS\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 3 Dec 2014\nSource: Summit Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.summitdaily.com/news/14085888-113/tularemia-summit-bacteria-county\n\n\nColorado has seen 15 human cases of tularemia reported in 2014, 5 times the annual average for the state. Tularemia-related small-mammal die-offs have been reported in at least 27 Colorado counties, including Summit.\n\nBeavers found south of Breckenridge have tested positive for tularemia, a potentially life-threatening bacterial disease that can infect any warm-blooded animal, including humans, dogs, cats, rabbits, hares, voles and beavers. Rodents, rabbits and hares are especially susceptible. An infection can be deadly in all species.\n\n'We're encouraging Summit County residents and visitors to avoid handling sick or dead animals and to stay away from potentially contaminated areas, evidenced by the presence of dead animals,' Summit County Public Health nurse Steph Stookey said in a written statement. 'Given the rise in cases in 2014, it's important to take necessary precautions.'\n\nOf the 15 human cases reported so far this year [2014], 11 patients have been hospitalized.\n\nTularemia is a disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Infected animals shed the bacterium in their feces and urine, and high numbers of bacteria are present in their carcasses. The bacterium can persist for long periods of time in water, soil and carcasses. Symptoms of the disease include, but are not limited to, high fever, open sores on the skin or mucous membranes, eye irritation and swelling, swollen lymph nodes, vomiting, diarrhea, coughing and chest pain. Blood tests and cultures can help confirm a diagnosis. Most infections can be treated successfully with antimicrobials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Finding _F. tularensis_ in beavers does not necessarily imply that any of the spate of human cases of tularemia were associated with direct or indirect beaver exposure.\n\nThe latest USA statistics on tularemia (CDC: Tularemia -- United States, 2001-2010. MMWR 2013; 62(47); 963-6 (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6247a5.htm) indicate that a total of 1208 cases of tularemia were reported during 2001-2010. The median number of cases per year was 126.5, with a range of 90-154 cases per year. Of these 1208 reported cases, 64 percent were categorized as confirmed and 35 percent as probable. Median age of patients was 39 years (range: 1-92 years), and 68 percent were male. Average annual incidence was 0.041 cases per 100 000 persons. By age group and sex, annual incidence was highest among children aged 5-9 years (0.071) and among men aged 65-69 years (0.11). Cases were reported from 47 states. Six states accounted for 59 percent of reported cases: Missouri (19 percent), Arkansas (13 percent), Oklahoma (9 percent), Massachusetts (7 percent), South Dakota (5 percent), and Kansas (5 percent). Among the 10 states with the highest incidence of tularemia, all but Massachusetts were located in the central or western USA. Certain strains of _Francisella tularensis_ subspecies _tularensis_ (also known as type A) are associated with more severe disease and a greater risk for death. Mortality is less than 2 percent overall but ranges up to 24 percent depending on the strain.\n\nAs a category A bioterrorism agent, despite not being transmissible from person-to-person, in a fact sheet on tularemia (http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/idepc/diseases/tularemia/tularemia.html), WHO has estimated that 50 kg (110 lb) of tularemia bacteria released into the air over a city of 5 million people would cause very serious problems. WHO believes such an attack would cause about 250 000 cases of severe illness, and 19 000 deaths, a case fatality rate of about 7 percent.\n\nMortality is highest related to primary pneumonic disease or septicemia (typhoidal) with secondary pneumonia presentations, and a state such as Illinois with a low incidence of disease might contribute to mortality as it may not be considered early. - Mod.LL]\n\n[In domestic animals, sheep are the primary host, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beaver, muskrat, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nNatural foci of infection exist in North America and Eurasia, where the organism circulates between arthropod vectors and various mammals, birds, reptiles, and fish. Although found in every state except Hawaii, tularemia is most often reported in the southcentral and western USA (eg, Missouri, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Montana).\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (eg, cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (the wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (the lone star tick), _D variabilis_ (the dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (the deer fly).\n\nThe most common source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people.\n\nClinical Findings\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nLesions\nThe most consistent lesions are miliary, white to off-white foci of necrosis in the liver and sometimes in the spleen, lung, and lymph nodes. Enlargement of the liver, spleen, lung, and lymph nodes is common. Organisms can be readily isolated from necropsy specimens by use of special media. Risk of infection during necropsy or to laboratory personnel is significant; special procedures and facilities are essential.\n\nDiagnosis\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia. When large numbers of sheep show typical signs during periods of heavy tick infestation, tularemia or tick paralysis (see Tick Paralysis) should be suspected. Tularemia should be considered in cats with signs of acute lymphadenopathy, malaise, oral ulcers, and history of recent ingestion of wild prey.\n\nDiagnosis of acute infection is confirmed by culture and identification of the bacterium, direct or indirect fluorescent antibody test, or a 4-fold increase in antibody titer between acute and convalescent serum specimens. A single titer of greater than or equal to 1:80 by the tube agglutination test is presumptive evidence of prior infection. When tularemia is suspected, laboratory personnel should be alerted in order to reduce the risk of laboratory-acquired infection.\n\nTreatment and Control\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels. Gentamicin should be continued for 10 days. Because tetracycline and chloramphenicol are bacteriostatic, they should be continued for 14 days to minimize the risk of relapse. Early treatment should prevent death loss. Control is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular. Efforts are currently underway to develop a safe and effective vaccine. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nThis comment has been extracted from: http://www.merckmanuals.com/vet/generalized_conditions/tularemia/overview_of_tularemia.html- Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "Six states accounted for 59 percent of reported cases: Missouri (19 percent), Arkansas (13 percent), Oklahoma (9 percent), Massachusetts (7 percent), South Dakota (5 percent), and Kansas (5 percent). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Finding _F. tularensis_ in beavers does not necessarily imply that any of the spate of human cases of tularemia were associated with direct or indirect beaver exposure. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Summit Daily [edited]\nhttp://www.summitdaily.com/news/14085888-113/tularemia-summit-bacteria-county\n\n\nColorado has seen 15 human cases of tularemia reported in 2014, 5 times the annual average for the state. \n\nBeavers found south of Breckenridge have tested positive for tularemia, a potentially life-threatening bacterial disease that can infect any warm-blooded animal, including humans, dogs, cats, rabbits, hares, voles and beavers. \n\nMortality is highest related to primary pneumonic disease or septicemia (typhoidal) with secondary pneumonia presentations, and a state such as Illinois with a low incidence of disease might contribute to mortality as it may not be considered early. - Mod. LL]\n\n[In domestic animals, sheep are the primary host, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. \n\nOf the 15 human cases reported so far this year [2014], 11 patients have been hospitalized. \n\n'We're encouraging Summit County residents and visitors to avoid handling sick or dead animals and to stay away from potentially contaminated areas, evidenced by the presence of dead animals,' Summit County Public Health nurse Steph Stookey said in a written statement. ' Of these 1208 reported cases, 64 percent were categorized as confirmed and 35 percent as probable. As a category A bioterrorism agent, despite not being transmissible from person-to-person, in a fact sheet on tularemia (http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/idepc/diseases/tularemia/tularemia.html), WHO has estimated that 50 kg (110 lb) of tularemia bacteria released into the air over a city of 5 million people would cause very serious problems. \n\nThe latest USA statistics on tularemia (CDC: Tularemia -- United States, 2001-2010. The most common source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. When large numbers of sheep show typical signs during periods of heavy tick infestation, tularemia or tick paralysis (see Tick Paralysis) should be suspected. Diagnosis of acute infection is confirmed by culture and identification of the bacterium, direct or indirect fluorescent antibody test, or a 4-fold increase in antibody titer between acute and convalescent serum specimens. WHO believes such an attack would cause about 250 000 cases of severe illness, and 19 000 deaths, a case fatality rate of about 7 percent. \n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. \n\nTreatment and Control\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels. TULAREMIA - USA (09): (COLORADO), HUMANS, BEAVERS\n*************************************************\n MMWR 2013; 62(47); 963-6 (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6247a5.htm) indicate that a total of 1208 cases of tularemia were reported during 2001-2010. In sheep and most mammals, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. \n\nNatural foci of infection exist in North America and Eurasia, where the organism circulates between arthropod vectors and various mammals, birds, reptiles, and fish. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (eg, cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Tularemia should be considered in cats with signs of acute lymphadenopathy, malaise, oral ulcers, and history of recent ingestion of wild prey.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1208-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Summit County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2798680", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (07): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2798680", "date": "2014-09-23 19:38:28", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Sep 2014\nSource: 7 News Denver [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/tularemia-spreads-to-4th-colorado-country-now-in-weld-boulder-broomfield-and-larimer-counties\n\n\nTularemia, also known as rabbit fever, has spread to a 4th Colorado county. A person living in Erie, in Weld County, was diagnosed with tularemia last week. Weld County health officials said the resident was hospitalized with a high fever, loss of appetite, and acute diarrhea and is now recovering at home.\n\nOfficials said a field mouse in northwest Johnstown and a rabbit southeast of Berthoud have also tested positive for tularemia.\n\n'We are seeing more than 3 times the usual number of human tularemia cases along the Front Range this year [2014], so the public really needs to be cautious about not getting exposed to this disease,' said Cheryl Darnell, Lab Manager for the Weld County Health Department.\n\nIn July 2014, 2 residents in Broomfield and Larimer counties tested positive for the disease. The Larimer County resident became sick while mowing a property near Windsor. Broomfield officials said it was likely the resident there was infected after coming in contact with dead rabbits that had been found in the person's yard.\n\nIn August 2014, a boy, from Longmont, was diagnosed with tularemia. He was the 1st Boulder County resident to test positive for the disease since 2007, according to Boulder County officials.\n\nSymptoms of tularemia include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. Symptoms can also include abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum and respiratory failure. Tularemia is treatable when detected in early stages.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The form of tularemia that occurred in this case is not clear, since diarrhea per se is not a specific symptom of _Francisella tularensis_ infection in humans. In the absence of cutaneous ulcers, lymphadenitis, conjunctivitis or respiratory symptoms, it is most likely that he had the septicemic or 'typhoidal' form. Diarrhea, of course, can be a non-specific manifestation of bacterial sepsis, as is well recognized in pneumococcal post-splenectomy sepsis and falciparum malaria.\n\nA case report of tularemic pneumonia with diarrhea as a prominent manifestation can be found with its abstract below:\n\nErnst M, Pilo P, Fleisch F, Glisenti P: Tularemia in the Southeastern Swiss Alps at 1,700 m above sea level. Infection. 21 Aug 2014. [Epub ahead of print]\n\n'A 37-year-old man presented with a 4-day history of nonbloody diarrhea, fever, chills, productive cough, vomiting, and more recent sore throat. He worked for the municipality in a village in the Swiss Alps near St. Moritz. Examination showed fever (40 C), hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, decreased oxygen saturation (90 percent at room air), and bibasilar crackles and wheezing. Chest radiography and computed tomography scan showed an infiltrate in the left upper lung lobe. He responded to empiric therapy with imipenem for 5 days. After the imipenem was stopped, the bacteriology laboratory reported that 2/2 blood cultures showed growth of _Francisella tularensis_. He had recurrence of fever and diarrhea. He was treated with ciprofloxacin (500 mg twice daily, oral, for 14 days) and symptoms resolved. Further testing confirmed that the isolate was _F. tularensis_ (subspecies holarctica) belonging to the subclade B.FTNF002-00 (Western European cluster). This case may alert physicians that tularemia may occur in high-altitude regions such as the Swiss Alps.'\n\nA map of the counties in the Rocky Mountains in the state of Colorado can be found at: http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Map_of_Colorado_counties,_labelled.svg. All 4 counties are in northern Colorado, bordering each other, and all north of Denver, the capital. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nA case report of tularemic pneumonia with diarrhea as a prominent manifestation can be found with its abstract below:\n\nErnst M, Pilo P, Fleisch F, Glisenti P: Tularemia in the Southeastern Swiss Alps at 1,700 m above sea level. [Epub ahead of print]\n\n'A 37-year-old man presented with a 4-day history of nonbloody diarrhea, fever, chills, productive cough, vomiting, and more recent sore throat. \n\n'We are seeing more than 3 times the usual number of human tularemia cases along the Front Range this year [2014], so the public really needs to be cautious about not getting exposed to this disease,' said Cheryl Darnell, Lab Manager for the Weld County Health Department. \n\nSymptoms of tularemia include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea, or pneumonia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The form of tularemia that occurred in this case is not clear, since diarrhea per se is not a specific symptom of _Francisella tularensis_ infection in humans. Weld County health officials said the resident was hospitalized with a high fever, loss of appetite, and acute diarrhea and is now recovering at home. TULAREMIA - USA (07): (COLORADO)\n********************************\n Symptoms can also include abrupt onset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, difficulty breathing, bloody sputum and respiratory failure. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Officials said a field mouse in northwest Johnstown and a rabbit southeast of Berthoud have also tested positive for tularemia. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-09-23 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2014-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "St. Moritz", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Windsor", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alps", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnstown", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broomfield", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Erie", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2763100", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2763100", "date": "2014-09-12 13:43:44", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (COLORADO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Larimer County\n[2] Boulder County\n\n******\n[1] Larimer County\nDate: Fri 5 Sep 2014\nSource: The Coloradoan [edited]\nhttp://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/local/2014/09/05/second-human-case-tularemia-confirmed-larimer/15135067/\n\n\nA 2nd human case of tularemia was confirmed on Fri 5 Sep 2014. A Larimer County resident has been hospitalized. The unidentified resident is thought to have been infected with the potentially life-threatening bacteria while mowing tall grass in an area where infected rabbits were previously present, Larimer County Department of Health and Environment officials said.\n\nThe bacterium can be transmitted by handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Infection can also arise from the bite of infected insects (ticks and deer flies), by eating or drinking contaminated food or water and by the inhalation of airborne bacteria.\n\nA rabbit in southeast Fort Collins tested positive for tularemia in July 2014, putting many on heightened alert, primarily in areas around Trilby Road between Timberline Road and Fossil Creek and the northwest section of Fossil Creek Wetlands natural area.\n\nThe 1st case of a Larimer County resident sickened by tularemia surfaced in early August 2014.\n\nHow to prevent tularemia:\n- avoid handling dead animals;\n- leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals;\n- if a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Put on a repellent to protect yourself from its fleas or ticks, and use a shovel to scoop it up. Place it in a plastic bag and dispose in an outdoor trash receptacle. Wash your hands;\n- when outdoors near places where rabbits or rodents are present, wear an insect repellent containing DEET;\n- keep pets confined and away from dead animals;\n- routinely use a tick and flea preventative on pets. Read the label and consult your veterinarian if you are unsure what to use.\n\n[Byline: Jason Pohl]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Acquiring _Francisella tularensis_ by lawn mowing usually causes pneumonia as the infection's manifestation. Skinning infected animals or acquiring the infection from a deer fly or tick bite will cause the ulceroglandular form. Oroglandular or oculoglandular forms can also occur depending on the site of exposure and a 'typhoidal' form with bacteremia may occur. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Boulder County\nDate: Thu 4 Sep 2014\nSource: CBS4 [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2014/09/04/rabbit-fever-patient-released-from-hospital/\n\n\nAn infant from Longmont is recovering at home after being released from the hospital where he was treated for what's known at 'rabbit fever.' The infant, just 10 weeks old, is the 1st human case of Tularemia in Boulder County. There have been at least 2 other cases in Broomfield and Larimer Counties. 'We get to go home. It's been a long couple of weeks,' said the infant's mother.\n\nThe infant was released from Children's Hospital 14 days after contracting a disease that could have killed him. He's believed to have been exposed to tularemia at a family picnic after he was bitten by a tick. He was taken to Children's Hospital with a high fever and put on antibiotics. 'It [the temperature] got higher and higher so I took him in to the ER and once I got there they basically told me, 'Your baby's really sick and he's not leaving. He has to stay,'' said the mother.\n\n'This case was very lucky, they weren't very ill, they caught it very early,' said Bolder County Public Health spokeswoman Kylie Chilton.\n\nOne case of rabbit fever was confirmed in a dead vole in a popular field in Boulder County. There are usually only 4 cases a year in Colorado but that has quadrupled in 2014 because heavy rain has fueled vegetation and given rabbits more places to live. 'As long as we continue to see warm temperatures and also these animals are around, then we may see that disease still,' said Chilton.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe manifestations of tularemia are not specifically stated. Tularemia is not a very common infection in the USA and much less common in infants because they are usually not in circumstances where they would be exposed. Deer fly or tick-associated transmission is most likely in this infant. Although rashes, other than ulcers at the inoculation site, are not common, another report of tularemia in an infant described a vesicular rash (Byington CL, Bender JM, Ampofo K, et al: Tularemia with vesicular skin lesions may be mistaken for infection with herpes viruses. Clin Infect Dis 2008; 47(1): e4-e6; http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/47/1/e4.long). The authors point out that in Edward Francis' original description of the disease, he described a vesicular rash in one person and other studies have also reported rashes, including some with a vesicular component. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nHow to prevent tularemia:\n- avoid handling dead animals;\n- leash your pets when outdoors and keep them away from dead animals;\n- if a dead animal must be moved, avoid direct contact with it. Date: Fri 5 Sep 2014\n Date: Thu 4 Sep 2014\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Coloradoan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broomfield", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Larimer", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ER", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2602339", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - USA (03): (CA) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2602339", "date": "2014-07-11 20:07:43", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (03): (CALIFORNIA) FELINE\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Jul 2014\nSource: 10 News [edited]\nhttp://www.10news.com/news/county-health-officials-issue-alert-after-cat-contracts-tularemia-also-known-as-rabbit-fever\n\n\nA cat in North [San Diego] County [California] has tested positive for tularemia, and county officials are urging folks to take steps to protect themselves and their pets.\n\nTularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever,' is a potentially dangerous bacterial disease that people can contract by being bitten by infected ticks or from touching or being bitten by an infected animal.\n\nThe cat, which was diagnosed after it became ill and was taken to a veterinarian, is in good condition. County health officials believe the cat came into direct contact with an infected animal. The cat lived in a rural area and spent time outside hunting rodents and rabbits.\n\nThe cat, and all of the people who came into contact with it, are all being treated (tularemia can be successfully treated with antibiotics).\n\nHow can you protect yourself?\n\n'Avoid hiking in grassy, brush areas where you can come into contact with ticks,' said Liz Pozzebon, health director for the county. 'Don't touch wild animals, dead or alive. And call Vector Control if you come across dead rabbits or rodents that don't look like they suffered some sort of injury.'\n\nThe county offered these tips as well:\n- Stay on designated pathways when hiking; choose wide trails and walk in the center.\n- Avoid areas where ticks may be. Wear light-colored, long-sleeved clothing; tuck shirts into pants and pants into socks.\n- Frequently check clothing, body and companions for ticks.\n- Don't handle wild rodents.\n- Leave pets at home or keep them on a leash when hiking. If they haven't already been treated with a tick and flea regimen, follow instructions to use insecticide spot-on applications, powders or sprays labeled for tick control. Pet owners should check with their veterinarians to determine which monthly tick control is most appropriate.\n- Carefully and immediately remove ticks that have attached themselves. Remove embedded ticks by grabbing them with forceps as close to the insect's head as possible and pulling straight out, steadily and firmly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although a 1911 outbreak of a plague-like disease in rodents in Tulare County, California, provided the 1st isolation of a small Gram-negative bacterium which was 1st named _Bacterium tularense_ (McCoy GW, Chapin CW: Further observations on a plague-like disease of rodents with a preliminary note on the causative agent, _Bacterium tularense_. J Infect Dis. 1912;10:61-72), the western USA does not report much _Francisella tularensis_ infection, averaging only 3 human cases per year from 2003-2012 (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/state.html).\n\nCats (http://www.peteducation.com/article.cfm?c=1+2134&aid=362) are susceptible to tularemia, and affected animals develop abscesses at the site of the tick bite, high fevers, and enlarged lymph nodes. After about one week, the animals have discharges from their nose and eyes and develop a rash. Cats may develop internal abscesses in their spleens or livers. Kittens and puppies are usually more severely affected than older animals. Dogs appear to be fairly resistant to the disease and the only symptoms may be loss of appetite, listlessness, and a low fever. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although a 1911 outbreak of a plague-like disease in rodents in Tulare County, California, provided the 1st isolation of a small Gram-negative bacterium which was 1st named _Bacterium tularense_ (McCoy GW, Chapin CW: Further observations on a plague-like disease of rodents with a preliminary note on the causative agent, _Bacterium tularense_. According to Champaign-Urbana Public Health District Administrator Julie Pryde, tularemia can be spread by tick or deer fly bites, or through contact with infected cats or rabbits. However, the disease cannot spread from human to human. The district declined to identify the victim.\n\nThe disease, also called rabbit fever, can lead to problems such as difficulty breathing. About 15 percent of cases are fatal. In 2011, the Illinois Department of Health reported 5 cases of tularemia. In 2012, 4 cases were reported.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Illinois can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/23973. Champaign County in east central Illinois can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/illinois-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n******\n[2] Colorado\nDate: Tue 12 Aug 2014\nSource: 9 News, KUSA-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.9news.com/story/news/health/2014/08/12/tularemia-fort-collins-weld-larimer-county/13964835/\n\n\nLocal health officials confirm that a man has been hospitalized for tularemia. It is believed that he may have been exposed to the disease while mowing a property outside of Windsor. The patient became sick with tularemia in July 2014, according to the Larimer County Department of Health and the Environment, and was hospitalized in early August 2014 after 2 courses of antibiotic treatment offered no improvement. He was released after several days and is expected to make a full recovery.\n\nTularemia was found in a Fort Collins rabbit in early July 2014, and is suspected at South Table Mountain Park in Jefferson County. Tularemia is a bacterial infection most frequently transmitted to people who have handled infected animals -- especially rabbits, hares, beavers, and muskrats. It is not considered contagious from person to person.\n\n[Byline: Allison Sylte]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298. Larimer County in north central Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThe latest USA statistics on tularemia (CDC: Tularemia -- United States, 2001-2010. MMWR 2013; 62(47); 963-6 (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6247a5.htm) indicate that a total of 1208 cases of tularemia were reported during 2001-2010. The median number of cases per year was 126.5, with a range of 90-154 cases per year. Of these 1208 reported cases, 64 percent were categorized as confirmed and 35 percent as probable. Median age of patients was 39 years (range: 1-92 years), and 68 percent were male. Average annual incidence was 0.041 cases per 100 000 persons. By age group and sex, annual incidence was highest among children aged 5-9 years (0.071) and among men aged 65-69 years (0.11). Cases were reported from 47 states. 6 states accounted for 59 percent of reported cases: Missouri (19 percent), Arkansas (13 percent), Oklahoma (9 percent), Massachusetts (7 percent), South Dakota (5 percent), and Kansas (5 percent). Among the 10 states with the highest incidence of tularemia, all but Massachusetts were located in the central or western USA. Certain strains of _Francisella tularensis_ subspecies _tularensis_ (also known as type A) are associated with more severe disease and a greater risk for death. Mortality is less than 2 percent overall but ranges up to 24 percent depending on the strain.\n\nAs a category A bioterrorism agent despite not being transmissible from person-to-person, in a fact sheet on tularemia (http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/idepc/diseases/tularemia/tularemia.html), WHO has estimated that 50 kg (110 lb) of tularemia bacteria -- released into the air over a city of 5 million people -- would cause very serious problems. WHO believes such an attack would cause about 250 000 cases of severe illness, and 19 000 deaths, a case fatality rate of about 7 percent.\n\nMortality is highest related to primary pneumonic or septicemia (typhoidal) with secondary pneumonia presentations and a state such as Illinois with a low incidence of disease might contribute to mortality as it may not be considered early. Of note, however, in the MMWR article cited above, the cases from Illinois were centered in central Illinois where Champaign County is located. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "6 states accounted for 59 percent of reported cases: Missouri (19 percent), Arkansas (13 percent), Oklahoma (9 percent), Massachusetts (7 percent), South Dakota (5 percent), and Kansas (5 percent). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As a category A bioterrorism agent despite not being transmissible from person-to-person, in a fact sheet on tularemia (http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/idepc/diseases/tularemia/tularemia.html), WHO has estimated that 50 kg (110 lb) of tularemia bacteria -- released into the air over a city of 5 million people -- would cause very serious problems. TULAREMIA - USA (04): (ILLINOIS, COLORADO) FATAL\n************************************************\n Source: WAND-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.wandtv.com/story/26234007/tularemia-death-reported-in-champaign-county\n\n\nChampaign County health officials say that one person has died of a rare infectious disease called tularemia.
