By age group and sex, annual incidence was highest among children aged 5-9 years (0.071) and among men aged 65-69 years (0.11). Mortality is less than 2 percent overall but ranges up to 24 percent depending on the strain. In 2011, the Illinois Department of Health reported 5 cases of tularemia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-07-25 00:00:00", "1208-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Champaign County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Windsor", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2589884", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (CO) rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2589884", "date": "2014-07-05 20:13:56", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA: (COLORADO) RABBIT\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 4 Jul 2014\nSource: ABC 7 News Denver [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/sick-rabbit-confirms-tularemia-outbreak-found-in-fort-collins\n\n\nLarimer County [Colorado] is warning about an outbreak of tularemia among wild rabbits.\n\nHealth officials said tularemia is a bacterial infection most commonly transmitted to humans by the handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. Humans can also get infected if they are bit by an infected tick or deer fly, by eating or drinking contaminated food or water, and by inhaling airborne bacteria.\n\nThe Larimer County Department of Health and Environment issued an alert to residents of Hahn Acres, Linden Park, Paragon Estates, and homes in the Paragon Point subdivision along Southridge Greens Blvd. after a wild rabbit was found with tularemia.\n\n'There has been a die-off of rabbits in the area over the past few weeks, but until an animal was tested today, the cause of the die-off was unknown,' officials said.\n\nTypical signs of infection in humans are fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. Eating or drinking food or water containing the bacteria may produce a throat infection, stomach pain, diarrhea and vomiting. Officials said tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics.\n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. If your pet shows symptoms of illness including fever, nasal and eye discharge, and skin sores, take it to the veterinarian promptly.\n\n[Byline: Deb Stanley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beavers, muskrats, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially [Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. - CopyEd.MSP], which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [abnormally frequent urination] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death. Control is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular. Use of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm.\n\nColorado may be located on the interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298 - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. \n\nHealth officials said tularemia is a bacterial infection most commonly transmitted to humans by the handling of sick or dead animals infected with tularemia. \n\nDogs and cats also get tularemia by eating infected rabbits or other rodents and through tick and deer fly bites. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. \n\nTypical signs of infection in humans are fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, chest pain, and coughing. \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Humans can also get infected if they are bit by an infected tick or deer fly, by eating or drinking contaminated food or water, and by inhaling airborne bacteria. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). \n\n'There has been a die-off of rabbits in the area over the past few weeks, but until an animal was tested today, the cause of the die-off was unknown,' officials said. \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Eating or drinking food or water containing the bacteria may produce a throat infection, stomach pain, diarrhea and vomiting. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. Source: ABC 7 News Denver [edited]\nhttp://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/local-news/sick-rabbit-confirms-tularemia-outbreak-found-in-fort-collins\n\n\nLarimer County [Colorado] is warning about an outbreak of tularemia among wild rabbits. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia. In domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hahn Acres", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1954010", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia (02): (KM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1954010", "date": "2013-09-19 11:31:48", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (02): (KHANTY-MANSIYSK)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Sep 2013\nSource: Rosbalt.ru [in Russian, trans. Mod.NP, edited]\nhttp://www.rosbalt.ru/federal/2013/09/13/1175288.html\n\n\nAccording to the Department of healthcare of Khanty-Mansiysky Autonomous Region, 900 inhabitants have contracted tularemia. Among them, 858 people are residents of Khanty-Mansiysk; 33 live in Khanty-Mansiysk district; the remaining cases were recorded in Nizhnevartovsk.\n\nIt is established that several of the patients in Nizhnevartovsk are employees of the oil industry and contracted tularemia in the field.\n\nIn Khanty-Mansiysk and Khanty-Mansiysk district, work on measures against rodents and mosquitoes, which are the sources and carriers of disease, is continuing.\n\nAccording to the Department of Rospotrebnadzor [The Federal Service for Protection of Consumers' Rights and Well-Being] in the Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug, the 1st cases were reported on 19 Aug 2013. Due to the significant deterioration of the epidemiological situation regarding the incidence of tularemia in Khanty-Mansiysk, an emergency situation has been declared.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The large number of cases suggests the potential of a common source vehicle such as contaminated water. The Health Department is also advising landscapers to wear respirator masks when cutting grass over 6 inches tall to reduce the risk of exposure in the event a hidden animal is struck and the bacterium can become aerosolized.\n\nTularemia, caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, can be transmitted to humans who handle sick or deceased animals or are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies, according to the CDC. It can also be transmitted by inhaling contaminated dusts or aerosols. The disease, which can cause fever, skin ulcers, and pneumonia, and is potentially life-threatening in rare cases, is most often treated and controlled successfully with antibiotics.\n\n'We need the public to be aware,' Nantucket Health Department director Richard Ray said. 'If there's a dead animal near the side of the road, ignore it, do not let your animal go near it, and call the DPW [Department of Public Works] to remove it. Please be careful about where your lawnmower goes and what it runs over. We've had a few cases over the years, but not 4 at one time.'\n\n[Byline: Jason Graziadei]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human infection with _Francisella tularensis_, a Category A bioterrorism agent, continues to be a problem on Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket, islands off the southern coast of Cape Cod in Massachusetts. A substantial number of the cases are pneumonic, occurring in landscapers and gardeners, related to the aerosolization of infective bacteria.\n\nTelford and colleagues (1) have investigated the genetic diversity of _F. tularensis_ obtained from Martha's Vineyard ticks. Between 2001 and 2003, 0.7 per cent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) harbored the tularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of genotypic diversity suggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of the infection on the island. The authors review information regarding the island's tularemia, which appears to have been a relatively recent introduction into Massachusetts. They state that prior to 1937, only one case of the infection was recognized, related to contaminated rabbit meat from the mid-western USA. In 1937, however, more than 20 000 cottontail rabbits from the mid-western states of Missouri and Kansas were introduced into the Massachusetts mainland and Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket for sporting purposes (2). Cases began to occur starting several years later.\n\nReferences:\n1. Goethert HK, Shani I, Telford SR. Genotypic diversity of\n_Francisella tularensis_ infected _Dermacentor variabilis_ ticks on\nMartha's Vineyard, Massachusetts. J Clin Microbiol 2004; 42: 4968-73.\n2. Belding DL, Merrill M. Tularemia in imported rabbits in\nMassachusetts. N Engl J Med 1941; 1085-87.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8jOH.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human infection with _Francisella tularensis_, a Category A bioterrorism agent, continues to be a problem on Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket, islands off the southern coast of Cape Cod in Massachusetts. Genotypic diversity of\n_Francisella tularensis_ infected _Dermacentor variabilis_ ticks on\nMartha's Vineyard, Massachusetts. TULAREMIA - USA (07): (MASSACHUSETTS)\n*************************************\n \n\nTularemia, caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, can be transmitted to humans who handle sick or deceased animals or are bitten by infected ticks or deer flies, according to the CDC. \n\n[Byline: Jason Graziadei]\n\n--\n Between 2001 and 2003, 0.7 per cent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) harbored the tularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of genotypic diversity suggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of the infection on the island. Town officials are urging island residents to avoid touching dead rabbits or other small animals, or approaching any animal that appears to be disoriented or sluggish. \n\nTelford and colleagues (1) have investigated the genetic diversity of _F. tularensis_ obtained from Martha's Vineyard ticks. \n\nReferences:\n A total of 4 island residents have been diagnosed with the infectious disease tularemia, commonly known as rabbit fever, according to the Nantucket Health Department.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1937-03-25 00:00:00", "1941-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Nantucket", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Vineyard", "country": "Jamaica"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cape Cod", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2601188", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (02): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2601188", "date": "2014-07-11 15:25:21", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Jul 2014\nSource: KRWG [edited]\nhttp://krwg.org/post/serious-illness-found-people-and-pets-new-mexico\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today [10 Jul 2014] a laboratory confirmed case of tularemia in a 65-year-old woman from Bernalillo County.\n\nThe cause of the woman's illness was confirmed at the Department's Scientific Laboratory Division. The woman was hospitalized but has recovered and gone home. 'We will be following up with a case investigation later this week in an effort to prevent future infections,' says Dr. Paul Smith, Urban Biology Division manager for the City of Albuquerque's Environmental Health Department.\n\nThere have also been 7 pet cases of tularemia in 2014, 4 dogs and 3 cats from Santa Fe, Bernalillo, and Los Alamos counties.\n\n'Tularemia can cause serious illness in both people and pets, so I would encourage people around the state to follow precautions similar to reducing risk to plague,' said Department of Health Cabinet Secretary, Retta Ward, MPH. 'Don't handle sick or dead rodents; don't allow pets to roam and hunt; get an appropriate tick and flea control product for pets, and take sick pets to a veterinarian. Since tularemia can be fatal in a small percentage of cases, it should be treated with antibiotics following an evaluation by a physician.'\n\nTularemia is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially rodents, rabbits and hares. Tularemia can also make dogs and cats sick, and they can give the disease to people. Symptoms of tularemia in people usually develop 3 to 5 days after exposure, but onset can vary from 1-14 days.\n\nTularemia symptoms are similar to plague infection, including sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscle aches and joint pain. Other symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the tularemia bacteria, and can include pneumonia and chest pain, ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat.\n\n'Many areas of the state have seen a large increase in the rabbit population this year [2014], and now some of those rabbits are getting sick and dying from both tularemia and plague,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian. 'Oftentimes, there is a rabbit or rodent die off in an area due to tularemia, and deer flies or ticks can become infected from these animals and then pass it on to pets or people when they bite them.'\n\nPeople can get tularemia in different ways: handling infected animal carcasses; being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect; eating or drinking contaminated food or water or by breathing in the bacteria. Dogs and cats are usually exposed to tularemia when they are allowed to roam and hunt sick rodents and rabbits or when bitten by an infected tick.\n\nIn 2013, there were 4 human cases of tularemia identified in New Mexico, a 45-year-old man from Santa Fe County, an 88-year-old woman from McKinley County, a 62-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, and a 75-year-old woman from San Juan County. Three of the human cases were hospitalized, and all recovered.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Francisella tularensis_ infection and the potential source of the infection are not stated.\n\nTularemia is caused by _F. tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States, an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of one to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of exposure. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza, and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness.\n\nThe number of reported cases of tularemia in the USA as reported by the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/year.html) has dropped from over 900 cases in 1950 to about 100 cases per year over the past 2 decades, although in the early 1980s, there was a several-year blip of numbers around 300.\n\nState-specific statistics from CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/state.html) for 2001-2010 report a total of 55 cases from New Mexico for an average of 2.2 per year. The highest number in a year was 7. During the decade 2003-2012, the states with the most cases were Missouri (236), Arkansas (198), and Oklahoma (123). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. Oftentimes, there is a rabbit or rodent die off in an area due to tularemia, and deer flies or ticks can become infected from these animals and then pass it on to pets or people when they bite them.'\n\nPeople can get tularemia in different ways: handling infected animal carcasses; being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect; eating or drinking contaminated food or water or by breathing in the bacteria. In 2013, there were 4 human cases of tularemia identified in New Mexico, a 45-year-old man from Santa Fe County, an 88-year-old woman from McKinley County, a 62-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, and a 75-year-old woman from San Juan County. The number of reported cases of tularemia in the USA as reported by the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/year.html) has dropped from over 900 cases in 1950 to about 100 cases per year over the past 2 decades, although in the early 1980s, there was a several-year blip of numbers around 300. \n\n'Many areas of the state have seen a large increase in the rabbit population this year [2014], and now some of those rabbits are getting sick and dying from both tularemia and plague,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian. ' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Tularemia can cause serious illness in both people and pets, so I would encourage people around the state to follow precautions similar to reducing risk to plague,' said Department of Health Cabinet Secretary, Retta Ward, MPH. ' \n\nThere have also been 7 pet cases of tularemia in 2014, 4 dogs and 3 cats from Santa Fe, Bernalillo, and Los Alamos counties. Other symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the tularemia bacteria, and can include pneumonia and chest pain, ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat. \n\nTularemia symptoms are similar to plague infection, including sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscle aches and joint pain. Dogs and cats are usually exposed to tularemia when they are allowed to roam and hunt sick rodents and rabbits or when bitten by an infected tick. \n\nTularemia is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially rodents, rabbits and hares.
