It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1950-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Alamos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "the City of Albuquerque 's Environmental Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McKinley County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1898671", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia: (KM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1898671", "date": "2013-08-25 22:39:32", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA: (KHANTY-MANSIY)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 23 Aug 2013\nSource: ITAR-TASS [in Russian, machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.tass-ural.ru/lentanews/v_yugre_zafiksirovana_vspyshka_opasnoy_infektsii_tulyaremiya_za_poslednie_tri_dnya_zaboleli_35_chelo.html\n\n\nDuring the last 3 days [20-23 Aug 2013], 35 people became ill from tularemia in the Khanty-Mansiysk [Khanty-Mansiy] town of Ugra. Among the ill were 4 children.\n\nToday [23 Aug 2013], the District Office of Epidemiology had a press conference providing the following information: 'Cases presented with a marked rise in temperature to 39-40 C [102-104 F], headache, chills, weakness, muscle pain and swollen lymph nodes. Most had evidence of an inflamed insect bite of a mosquito or midge. Patients have been hospitalized in the infectious disease ward of the district hospital and have a moderate degree of severity,' said the press service.\n\nIt was stressed that the main source of tularemia is infected rodents. Infection of humans occurs through the bite of a mosquito or a gnat but can also be from contaminated food or airborne dust containing the organism that then contaminates water and/or food, or from direct contact with diseased rodents.\n\nTularemia is a zoonosis. The causative agent of the disease is a bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_. The known carriers include: hares, rabbits, water rats, and voles. In nature, epizootic outbreaks occur periodically. The infection is transmitted to humans through direct contact with animals or through contaminated food and water, sometimes by aspiration.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation, with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of disease in this case is not stated. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1MnT.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. Infection of humans occurs through the bite of a mosquito or a gnat but can also be from contaminated food or airborne dust containing the organism that then contaminates water and/or food, or from direct contact with diseased rodents. Today [23 Aug 2013], the District Office of Epidemiology had a press conference providing the following information: 'Cases presented with a marked rise in temperature to 39-40 C [102-104 F], headache, chills, weakness, muscle pain and swollen lymph nodes. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The infection is transmitted to humans through direct contact with animals or through contaminated food and water, sometimes by aspiration. \n\nIt was stressed that the main source of tularemia is infected rodents. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ugra", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1926107", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, wildlife - Netherlands: (LI) hare, 1st report, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1926107", "date": "2013-09-06 17:39:42", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Sep 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14023\n\n\nTularemia, Netherlands\n----------------------\nInformation received on 5 Sep 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\nDate of start of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 4 Sep 2013\nReport date: 4 Sep 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 5 Sep 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1953\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Limburg (Leudal)\nDate of start of the outbreak: 2013\nOutbreak status: Resolved (4 Sep 2013)\nEpidemiological unit: Not applicable\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / ** / ** / 100 percent / **\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n**Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination, No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (national laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Sep 2013/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting: The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. The causative bacterium is a Gram-negative coccoid rod, 0.2-0.5 micrometre x 0.7-1.0 micrometre, non-motile and non-spore-forming organism that is an obligate aerobe with optimal growth at 37 degrees C. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), and in rodents, especially microtine rodents (such as voles, vole rats and muskrats), and beavers. A wide range of other mammals and several species of birds have also been reported to be infected. Among domestic animals, the cat seems to be able to act as a carrier of the bacterium.\n\nTwo types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of cultural characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence in some hosts. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most of the isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America, and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nThe disease is characterised by fever, depression and septicaemia. In humans, there may be ulcers or abscesses at the site of inoculation (this is rarely seen in animals), and swelling of the regional lymph nodes.\n\nIt is important to understand that there is a high risk of direct infection of humans by direct contact with this organism. For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 'Tularemia' at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012).\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to tularemia are spelled out in chapter 8.15 of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=169&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.8.15.htm.\n\nAccording to the most recent 6-month OIE report, tularemia was reported as present in 6 countries (Czech Republic, Denmark, Sweden, France, Germany, and Switzerland). In addition, Spain and the United States have reported the disease limited to certain zones. In 82 countries the disease has never been reported, and in 40 the disease was reported absent in this period. On the other hand, most countries have not specified surveillance for tularemia, some maintain 'general surveillance' and very few maintain 'targeted surveillance' countries (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. (Note: at both WAHID links, to view the information on tularemia, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease).\n\nAlthough Tularemia had not been reported in the Netherlands since 1953, this event should not come as a surprise since the disease is present in the surrounding countries such as Germany, France and Belgium. The Dutch province of Limburg is situated in south Netherlands, bordering Germany and Belgium. The Dutch source 'Groene Ruimte', cited at the end of the commentary, says: 'The bacterium has been recently demonstrated in 3 percent of hares found dead in northern Germany. It is spread over France. The last case in Belgium, a hare, was reported in 2011' (http://www.groeneruimte.nl/nieuws/artikel.html?id=151747). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8l5l.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Outbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / ** / ** / 100 percent / **\n No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (national laboratory) / Brown hare (European hare) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Sep 2013/ Positive\n\nFuture reporting: The event is resolved. Information received on 5 Sep 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\n Affected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European hare): Leporidae (_Lepus europaeus_) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 Date submitted to OIE: 5 Sep 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\n Manifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\n TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) HARE, FIRST REPORT, OIE\n********************************************************************\n Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Limburg (Leudal)\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14023 This event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nSummary of outbreaks\n Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\n Date of start of the event: 4 Sep 2013\n For the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, please refer to OIE Terrestrial Manual 2012, Chapter 2.1.18 'Tularemia' at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf\n(adopted by the World Assembly of Delegates of the OIE in May 2012). Report date: 4 Sep 2013\n \n\n--\n Outbreak status: Resolved (4 Sep 2013)\n Date: Thu 5 Sep 2013\n 4 Sep 2013\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-09-04 00:00:00", "1953-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-09-05 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1802498", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (05): (AK) snowshoe hare", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1802498", "date": "2013-07-02 11:14:20", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (05): (ALASKA) SNOWSHOE HARE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Jun 2013\nSource: Fairbanks Daily News-Miner [edited]\nhttp://www.newsminer.com/news/local_news/wildlife-officials-tularemia-found-in-hares-in-fairbanks-area/article_7cd56b6c-d981-11e2-865d-001a4bcf6878.html\n\n\nState wildlife officials in Fairbanks [Alaska] are warning residents to be on the lookout for sick snowshoe hares that might be carrying tularemia.\n\nTests confirmed that a snowshoe hare in the Fairbanks area died of tularemia last week [week of 10 Jun 2013] and the Alaska Department of Fish and Game [ADFG] has received multiple reports of sick hares, wildlife veterinarian Kimberlee Beckmen said in a news release Wednesday [19 Jun 2013].\n\nTularemia is a bacterial disease that typically affects hares, beavers, and muskrats. Predators and scavengers, including dogs and cats, that bite into a sick or dead hare can become infected. People who handle infected hares can also contract the disease.\n\nThe disease also can be spread by ticks found on hares and water contaminated with a dead animal.\n\n'Hares die of this infection every spring and summer in the Interior,' Beckmen said.\n\nA local resident brought a sick hare with many ticks to a Fairbanks veterinary clinic last week. Tests conducted by a diagnostic lab in Colorado confirmed the presence of the bacterium that causes tularemia. Tularemia can be fatal in humans if an infected person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics. However, human cases in Alaska are rare and only one case about every 2 years is reported. The most common symptoms in humans include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, fever, flu-like illness, diarrhea, or pneumonia.\n\nMore commonly, dogs or cats are infected with the disease after they've encountered a sick or infected hare. Pets that become infected may show fever, lethargy, lack of appetite and swollen lymph glands. Infected animals can be treated with antibiotics but it's important to do so quickly, Beckmen said, because tularemia can be contracted through the bite of an infected pet.\n\nBeckmen encouraged anyone who sees a sick hare to contact ADFG at 459-7206 to report it. Signs that a hare is infected include lack of fear of people, lethargy, and sudden death.\n\nPeople who need to touch a dead hare can protect themselves by using gloves or a plastic bag and washing their hands afterward. Dead hares should be double bagged and disposed in the trash or where pets and scavengers cannot get to them.\n\nPeople are also advised not to drink untreated water from areas where there are beavers and muskrats.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_ , is a non sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 percent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary host, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beaver, muskrat, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as, cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially, which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe most common source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death. Control is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular. Use of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Alaska may be found at http://healthmap.org/r/7t0w. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe most common source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. More commonly, dogs or cats are infected with the disease after they've encountered a sick or infected hare. \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. The most common symptoms in humans include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph glands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, fever, flu-like illness, diarrhea, or pneumonia. \n\nTularemia is a bacterial disease that typically affects hares, beavers, and muskrats. Infected animals can be treated with antibiotics but it's important to do so quickly, Beckmen said, because tularemia can be contracted through the bite of an infected pet. \n\nPeople who need to touch a dead hare can protect themselves by using gloves or a plastic bag and washing their hands afterward. Signs that a hare is infected include lack of fear of people, lethargy, and sudden death. \n\nA local resident brought a sick hare with many ticks to a Fairbanks veterinary clinic last week. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as, cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. \n\nTests confirmed that a snowshoe hare in the Fairbanks area died of tularemia last week Predators and scavengers, including dogs and cats, that bite into a sick or dead hare can become infected. \n\n'Hares die of this infection every spring and summer in the Interior,' Beckmen said. \n\nBeckmen encouraged anyone who sees a sick hare to contact ADFG at 459-7206 to report it. \n\nPeople are also advised not to drink untreated water from areas where there are beavers and muskrats. [week of 10 Jun 2013] and the Alaska Department of Fish and Game [ADFG] has received multiple reports of sick hares, wildlife veterinarian Kimberlee Beckmen said in a news release Wednesday [19 Jun 2013]. \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia. People who handle infected hares can also contract the disease. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly). Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fairbanks", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1798960", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (04): (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1798960", "date": "2013-06-29 15:23:59", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (04): (NEBRASKA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Jun 2013\nSource: KNOP-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.knopnews2.com/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=8164:two-cases-of-tularemia-in-area&Itemid=105\n\n\nA rare infectious disease is confirmed in Lincoln County. So far, 2 people in the area were affected by tularemia. The latest is your typical 9 year old kid who loves the outdoors and this summer has been no exception.\n\n'The 1st week of June 2013, he did a fishing camp at the school so he was around the lakes and river near North Platte. So every day I said 'Let's check for ticks.' I grew up camping and knew that was kind of the standard thing,' said the mother who then removed 3 ticks from her son but one of the bite sites seemed to heal.\n\n'A couple days later it started hurting on my neck,' said the boy. 'He was getting tireder and tireder and more and more neck pain. It got to the point where he was so stiff he wasn't even moving his neck like it was broken or something,' said the father.\n\nThey went to the hospital where the boy was diagnosed with an uncommon infection called tularemia that can be transmitted through animals by ticks. 'It's mostly rodents and rabbits are probably the main reservoir but other rodents can carry the bacteria,' says Eduardo Freitas, MD, an infectious diseases physician.\n\nTick and deer fly bites are one of the most common ways the disease is transmitted [but it can also be transmitted] through skin contact with infected animals, ingestion of infected water, and inhaling infected dust contaminants. And while it is contagious between animals and humans, 'it is not spread from human to human,' Freitas says.\n\nEven though there are 2 confirmed cases in the area and several statewide, physicians aren't worried yet. 'They are still within the expected numbers; unless this changes over the next few weeks and then we'll be more alarmed,' Freitas says. So far, 8 cases have been confirmed in Nebraska in 2013.\n\n[Byline: Jacqueline Skarda]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This case appears to be the ulceroglandular form of the infection.\n\nThe number of reported cases of tularemia in the USA as reported by the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/year.html) has dropped from over 900 cases in 1950 to about 100 cases per year over the past 2 decades, although in the early 1980s there was a several-year blip of numbers around 300.\n\nState-specific statistics from CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/state.html) for 2001-2010 report a total of 55 cases from Nebraska for an average of 5.5 per year. The highest number in a year was 10. At this point, with 8 cases already and the tick season still on the upswing, 2013 could be a banner year for _Francisella tularensis_ in Nebraska. During the decade 2001-2010, the states with the most cases were Missouri (231), Arkansas (162), and Oklahoma (108). - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Nebraska can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/7rXJ. Lincoln County in south-central Nebraska can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/nebraska.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The number of reported cases of tularemia in the USA as reported by the CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/year.html) has dropped from over 900 cases in 1950 to about 100 cases per year over the past 2 decades, although in the early 1980s there was a several-year blip of numbers around 300. \n\nState-specific statistics from CDC (http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics/state.html) for 2001-2010 report a total of 55 cases from Nebraska for an average of 5.5 per year. Tick and deer fly bites are one of the most common ways the disease is transmitted [but it can also be transmitted] through skin contact with infected animals, ingestion of infected water, and inhaling infected dust contaminants. \n\nEven though there are 2 confirmed cases in the area and several statewide, physicians aren't worried yet. ' TULAREMIA - USA (04): (NEBRASKA)\n********************************\n At this point, with 8 cases already and the tick season still on the upswing, 2013 could be a banner year for _Francisella tularensis_ in Nebraska. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n'A couple days later it started hurting on my neck,' said the boy. ' [Byline: Jacqueline Skarda]\n\n--\n \n\n'The 1st week of June 2013, he did a fishing camp at the school so he was around the lakes and river near North Platte. They went to the hospital where the boy was diagnosed with an uncommon infection called tularemia that can be transmitted through animals by ticks. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1950-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Lincoln County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1886594", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - USA (06): (CO) rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1886594", "date": "2013-08-18 15:48:26", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (06): (COLORADO) RABBIT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 16 Aug 2013\nSource: KKTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/Rabbit-Tests-Positive-For-Tularemia-In-Pueblo-West-219832021.html\n\n\nPublic health officials in Pueblo, Colorado announced on Thursday [15 Aug 2013] that a rabbit had tested positive for tularemia in Pueblo West. The rabbit was collected in the 1000 Block of West Saginaw Drive after it had contact with a child.\n\n'Tularemia is similar to plague. It is typically found in animals, especially rabbits,' said Scott Cowan, program manager of the Disease Prevention and Emergency Preparedness Division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. 'Tularemia can be passed to humans or animals through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies, and by handling infected, sick, or dead animals,' said Cowan. The disease can also be passed to people or animals if they eat meat or drink water infected by the bacteria.\n\n'It is very important not to pet or come in contact with wild animals,' stated Cowan. He explained, 'A child petted this rabbit before the rabbit died, potentially exposing the child to the bacteria. The child currently has no symptoms of tularemia and is on a fever watch.'\n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness that occurs naturally in the United States. It is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ found in animals (especially rodents, rabbits, and prairie dogs).\n\nPeople can get tularemia multiple ways:\n- being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect\n- handling infected animal carcasses\n- eating or drinking contaminated food or water\n- breathing in the bacteria, _F. tularensis_\n\nTularemia is not spread from person to person. People who have tularemia do not need to be isolated. People who have been exposed to the tularemia bacteria should be treated as soon as possible. The disease can be fatal if it is not treated with the right antibiotics.\n\nSymptoms of tularemia usually occur 3-5 days after exposure and may include:\n- sudden fever\n- chills\n- headaches\n- diarrhea\n- muscle aches\n- joint pain\n- dry cough\n- progressive weakness\n\nPeople can also develop pneumonia and may have the following symptoms: chest pain, bloody sputum, trouble breathing and they even sometimes stop breathing.\n\nOther symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the tularemia bacteria. These symptoms can include ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat.\n\nThe Pueblo City-County Health Department recommends the following to protect against the disease:\n- Avoid all contact with wild rabbits, squirrels and rodents; do not feed or handle them.\n- Avoid ticks. The best protection for pets, especially cats, is to keep them indoors. If outdoors with your pets, protect them with a flea collar; keeping them out of heavily wooded areas can provide additional protection, as these areas are ideal for ticks to live.\n- Stay out of areas wild rodents inhabit. If you enter areas with wild rodents, wear insect repellent containing DEET or treat clothing with repellent containing permethrin.\n- Prevent your pets from hunting or eating wild rodents, especially rabbits.\n- Never touch sick or dead animals with your bare hands. If an animal must be moved, use a long-handled shovel to place it in a garbage bag, and place the bag in an outdoor garbage can.\n- Avoid drinking unpurified water from streams or lakes and prevent your pets from doing the same.\n- See a physician if you become ill with a high fever and/or a swollen lymph node. Tularemia is a treatable illness when diagnosed early.\n- See a veterinarian if you pet becomes ill with a high fever and/or swollen lymph nodes.\n\n'It is important for pet owners keep their animals from roaming outside, as they can be exposed to tularemia when hunting rabbits and/or prairie dogs,' stated Cowan. 'Do not let your pets roam; do not let them eat dead animals; protect your pets with a flea and tick collar, and keep an eye on their health and take then to the veterinarian if clinical signs develop.'\n\nNote any change in the behavior of your pets especially cats, as well as notice activity of rodents, rabbits, and prairie dogs or livestock, and consult a veterinarian if your pet develops unusual signs.\n\nThis is the 1st identified case of tularemia in animals in Pueblo County this year [2013]. No human cases of tularemia have been reported this year.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is killed rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks or months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can be cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their biochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in North America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may be 5-7 per cent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most commonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections in North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from arthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary hosts, but clinical infection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at increased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an increased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little is known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in domestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and jackrabbits, beavers, muskrats, meadow voles, and sheep in North America, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially and transovarially [Transstadial transmission occurs when a pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next. Transovarial or transovarian transmission occurs in certain arthropod vectors as they transmit disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. - CopyEd.MSP], which makes them an efficient reservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include _Dermacentor andersoni_ (wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (lone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (dog tick), and _Chrysops discalis_ (deer fly).\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to people.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased. Coughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria [abnormally frequent urination] may develop. Prostration and death may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing, which may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum, and respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early treatment should prevent death. Control is difficult and is limited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are intracellular. Use of a vaccine previously available for people at high risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm.\n\nColorado may be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2WId. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\nSymptoms of tularemia usually occur 3-5 days after exposure and may include:\n- sudden fever\n- chills\n- headaches\n- diarrhea\n- muscle aches\n- joint pain\n- dry cough\n- progressive weakness\n\nPeople can also develop pneumonia and may have the following symptoms: chest pain, bloody sputum, trouble breathing \n\nPeople can get tularemia multiple ways:\n- being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect\n- handling infected animal carcasses\n- eating or drinking contaminated food or water\n- breathing in the bacteria, _F. tularensis_\n\nTularemia is not spread from person to person. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a non sporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp. \n\n'It is important for pet owners keep their animals from roaming outside, as they can be exposed to tularemia when hunting rabbits and/or prairie dogs,' stated Cowan. ' \n\nNote any change in the behavior of your pets especially cats, as well as notice activity of rodents, rabbits, and prairie dogs or livestock, and consult a veterinarian if your pet develops unusual signs. \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Tularemia can be passed to humans or animals through the bite of infected insects, most commonly ticks and deer flies, and by handling infected, sick, or dead animals,' said Cowan. TULAREMIA - USA (06): (COLORADO) RABBIT\n***************************************\n The Pueblo City-County Health Department recommends the following to protect against the disease:\n- Avoid all contact with wild rabbits, squirrels and rodents; do not feed or handle them. Do not let your pets roam; do not let them eat dead animals; protect your pets with a flea and tick collar, and keep an eye on their health and take then to the veterinarian if clinical signs develop.' \n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending on how they are exposed to tularemia. Direct contact with or ingestion of infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbits) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional inflammation of a lymph node), or typhoidal form. \n\nOther symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the tularemia bacteria. In sheep and most mammals including hares and rabbits, the disease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy, anorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with septicemic disease. \n\n'It is very important not to pet or come in contact with wild animals,' stated Cowan. \n\nThis is the 1st identified case of tularemia in animals in Pueblo County this year [2013]. The disease can also be passed to people or animals if they eat meat or drink water infected by the bacteria. \n- Never touch sick or dead animals with your bare hands. \n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases (especially plague) or acute pneumonia. Possible symptoms include skin ulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen and painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. It is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ found in animals (especially rodents, rabbits, and prairie dogs). \n- Stay out of areas wild rodents inhabit. \n- Avoid drinking unpurified water from streams or lakes and prevent your pets from doing the same. If the bacteria are inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever, chills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive weakness. It is typically found in animals, especially rabbits,' said Scott Cowan, program manager of the Disease Prevention and Emergency Preparedness Division at the Pueblo City-County Health Department. These symptoms can include ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat. \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are effective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. \n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness that occurs naturally in the United States.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the Pueblo City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pueblo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1797147", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (03): (NM)  human, feline, canine, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1797147", "date": "2013-06-28 10:43:18", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) HUMAN, FELINE, CANINE, ALERT\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 27 Jun 2013\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today [27 Jun 2013] that tularemia cases are on the increase in several locations around New Mexico. Since the middle of April 2013, there have been 4 cases in people and 6 cases in dogs and cats. The human cases include a 45-year-old man from Santa Fe County, an 88-year-old woman from McKinley County, a 62-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, and a 75-year-old woman from San Juan County. 3 of the human cases were hospitalized and all have recovered and gone home. Onset of illness in the most recent case was 15 Jun 2013. The pet cases include 2 cats and a dog from Santa Fe County, a dog from Sandoval County, a dog from Los Alamos County, and a cat from Torrance County. They have all recovered.\n\n'I would encourage people in the mentioned counties and around the state to follow the same precautions they would to avoid plague,' said Department of Health Cabinet Secretary, Retta Ward, MPH. 'Don't handle sick or dead rodents, don't allow pets to roam and hunt, get an appropriate tick and flea control product for pets, and take sick pets to a veterinarian. Since tularemia can be fatal in a small percentage of cases, it should be treated with antibiotics following an evaluation by a physician.'\n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness in people that occurs naturally in the USA. It is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially rodents, rabbits, and hares. Tularemia can also make dogs and cats sick. Symptoms of tularemia in people usually develop 3 to 5 days after exposure but onset can vary from 1 to 14 days. Tularemia symptoms are similar to plague infection including sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscles aches, and joint pain. Other symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the tularemia bacteria and can include pneumonia and chest pain, ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat.\n\n'The recent human cases in New Mexico had various exposures to tularemia, including skinning a rabbit with bare hands, receiving a bite from a sick cat, cleaning out a water trough with a dead rabbit in it, and being bitten by a deer fly or a tick on the lower leg,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian. 'Oftentimes there is a rabbit or rodent die-off in an area due to tularemia and deer flies or ticks can become infected from these animals and then pass it on to pets or people when they bite them.'\n\nPeople can get tularemia in different ways: handling infected animal carcasses; being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect; eating or drinking contaminated food or water or by breathing in the bacteria. Dogs and cats are usually exposed to tularemia when they are allowed to roam and hunt sick rodents and rabbits or when bitten by an infected tick.\n\nFor more information on tularemia go to http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad\nPublic Health Veterinarian\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this communication.\n\nThe state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2o_v. The counties mentioned can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico.shtml.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that is occasionally seen in dogs. It is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. It is associated with multiple animal species, including humans, and can be acquired from through contact with infected animals, infected wounds or soil. It is also commonly know as rabbit fever for its mode of transmission, even while it can infect several types of animals and be transmitted via any infected animal, as such, the bacteria can also be acquired by ingestion of contaminated water, or through contact with infected soil, where the organism can remain in an infectious state for up to several months.\n\nInfection is often caused by ingestion of an infected mammals' tissue, such as when a dog/cat hunts a small animal, bird or reptile, through water, or by tick, mite, flea or mosquito bite -- all of which can carry and transmit the bacteria. The bacterium may also infect a cat or dog through its skin, or by entering its airways, eyes, or gastrointestinal system.\n\nClinical signs seen in domestic pets include: sudden onset of fever, lethargy, dehydration, lack of appetite (anorexia), enlargement of the lymph nodes, tender abdomen, enlargement of spleen or liver, white patches or ulcers on the tongue, and jaundice which may be indicated by yellow eyes.\n\nRabbits and other wild rodents are the primary species affected. Tularemia can also affect beaver and muskrats. Livestock and pets including pigs, horses, dogs, cats, fish and birds can also get tularemia. Sheep are especially susceptible. Cattle rarely get the disease.\n\nTularemia is difficult to prevent since it can be in the environment or be spread by insects. Prevention measures include keeping pets indoors and away from wildlife. Do not feed animals raw meat, especially that from wild animals. Control ticks and biting flies.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/FastFacts/pdfs/tularemia_F.pdf. - Mod. TG]\n\n[_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness, but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of one to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of exposure. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza, and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\n'The recent human cases in New Mexico had various exposures to tularemia, including skinning a rabbit with bare hands, receiving a bite from a sick cat, cleaning out a water trough with a dead rabbit in it, and being bitten by a deer fly or a tick on the lower leg,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian. ' \n\nPeople can get tularemia in different ways: handling infected animal carcasses; being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect; eating or drinking contaminated food or water or by breathing in the bacteria. \n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. It is also commonly know as rabbit fever for its mode of transmission, even while it can infect several types of animals and be transmitted via any infected animal, as such, the bacteria can also be acquired by ingestion of contaminated water, or through contact with infected soil, where the organism can remain in an infectious state for up to several months. \n\nInfection is often caused by ingestion of an infected mammals' tissue, such as when a dog/cat hunts a small animal, bird or reptile, through water, or by tick, mite, flea or mosquito bite -- all of which can carry and transmit the bacteria. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nClinical signs seen in domestic pets include: sudden onset of fever, lethargy, dehydration, lack of appetite (anorexia), enlargement of the lymph nodes, tender abdomen, enlargement of spleen or liver, white patches or ulcers on the tongue, and jaundice which may be indicated by yellow eyes. Other symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the tularemia bacteria and can include pneumonia and chest pain, ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat. Dogs and cats are usually exposed to tularemia when they are allowed to roam and hunt sick rodents and rabbits or when bitten by an infected tick. The human cases include a 45-year-old man from Santa Fe County, an 88-year-old woman from McKinley County, a 62-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, and a 75-year-old woman from San Juan County. Oftentimes there is a rabbit or rodent die-off in an area due to tularemia and deer flies or ticks can become infected from these animals and then pass it on to pets or people when they bite them.' It is associated with multiple animal species, including humans, and can be acquired from through contact with infected animals, infected wounds or soil. Don't handle sick or dead rodents, don't allow pets to roam and hunt, get an appropriate tick and flea control product for pets, and take sick pets to a veterinarian. New Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this communication. Symptoms of tularemia in people usually develop 3 to 5 days after exposure but onset can vary from 1 to 14 days. \n\nTularemia is a zoonotic bacterial disease that is occasionally seen in dogs. TG]\n\n[_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. \n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness in people that occurs naturally in the USA.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2013-06-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Alamos County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "McKinley County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sandoval County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Juan County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1599239", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed die-off, beaver - USA: (IL) tularemia susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1599239", "date": "2013-03-22 20:38:04", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DIE-OFF, BEAVER - USA: (ILLINOIS) TULAREMIA SUSPECTED\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 17 Mar 2012\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/environment/2013-03-17/environmental-almanac-tularemia-suspected-beaver-deaths.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS+%28Wildlife+Disease+News+Digest+GeoRSS+Feed%29&utm_term=wdinNewsDigestGeoRSS\n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. It also has raised questions about the impact of drought, overpopulation and habitat destruction on wildlife. Officials say there are no reports of human illness.\n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. The cause is less certain.\n\n'There is no conclusive evidence,' researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, 'but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.' She emphasized that tularemia bacteria are common. 'They are present in rabbits and squirrels,' she said. 'They are part of the natural ecosystem.'\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. Continuing destruction of wildlife habitat has a similar effect, she said.\n\nDerek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. The alert cited a Meadowbrook beaver diagnosed with clinical symptoms of tularemia and an unrelated 2011 outbreak among 5 pet cats in Champaign, Urbana and Savoy.\n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies.\n\nThe park district warns Meadowbrook users to keep pets leashed and to stay on trails in the park. Mateus-Pinilla reinforced local government warnings about allowing domestic animals to roam or run unleashed.\n\n'Then you are bringing them into your house, where there is direct contact. That is more serious,' she said.\n\nAccording to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. In humans, tularemia bacteria can cause illness ranging from asymptomatic to life-threatening.\n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. It was taken to the University of Illinois veterinary diagnostic laboratory, where tests were conducted, with inconclusive results. Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.\n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. In November, a 7th beaver was found. Liebert said the most recent sighting of a live beaver, a single individual, occurred 19 Dec 2012.\n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. One is that decomposition sets in rapidly, and sometimes there is not much a pathologist can do because of the condition of the body. The 'gold standard' for a confirmed diagnosis, Mateus-Pinilla said, is the ability to grow a culture of the suspect bacteria. The Meadowbrook beavers were tested for several pathogens, including tularemia, salmonella, leptospira and canine distemper. No tests resulted positive.\n\nHowever, investigators were able to rule out toxins, such as from run-off, and also found evidence pointing to tularemia, even if it did not amount to a confirmed diagnosis.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. But investigators did find certain changes in the lungs typical of tularemia. In the end, Mateus-Pinilla said, what signs there were pointed to tularemia.\n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. Indeed, she said, the fact that beavers were thriving there 'tells us it was a suitable habitat.' Unfortunately, she said, the die-off 'also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.'\n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. 'We want to put our house in the woods,' and as a result 'we are getting closer to diseases that we wouldn't find in the middle of New York City.'\n\nMateus-Pinilla sees an opportunity for independent research through close monitoring of future colonies at Meadowbrook.\n\n'I would love to see it happening,' she said. The Meadowbrook beavers are 'close to one of the biggest wildlife research institutions in the United States. We have the resources, and we have the students.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Tularemia is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere and is not normally found in the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere.\n\n_Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis_ (Type A) is associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is transmitted primarily by ticks and biting flies, is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits. _Francisella tularensis subsp. palaearctica_ (Type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) in northern North America. It may be water- or arthropod-borne, and is less virulent to humans and rabbits.\n\nIn addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/5*UN - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "\n\nMateus-Pinilla, a wildlife veterinary epidemiologist at the Illinois Natural History Survey, said it is possible that severe drought exacerbated the outbreak, with low water levels forcing beavers and other animals to live in closer quarters. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMateus-Pinilla said salmonella and leptospira were eliminated, for example, because salmonella would not have caused a die-off, and leptospira is associated with lesions not found in the necropsies. \n\n'There is no conclusive evidence,' researcher Nohra Mateus-Pinilla said, 'but it appears that the only thing that could have caused the die-off is an outbreak of tularemia.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is caused by the gram negative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. Derek Liebert, project manager at the Urbana Park District, said a wildlife biologist suggested to him that if tularemia is in fact the cause, the die-off may be a corrective measure for a population that grew too large. \n\nHealth district planning director Awais Vaid said people should not let their pets roam and should take them to a veterinarian if they exhibit symptoms such as loss of appetite or difficulty with movement. \n\nLiebert said the 1st dead beaver was found in January 2012. \n\nThe biggest spate of deaths occurred in October [2012], when 3 beavers were found, 2 of which were necropsied. \n\nMateus-Pinilla said it is unlikely that the habitat provided by the park itself was to blame. \n\nThe effort to isolate the cause of the deaths was hampered by several circumstances, Mateus-Pinilla said. \n\n\nA beaver die-off at Urbana's Meadowbrook Park, thought to have been caused by tularemia, has emphasized the importance of keeping pets indoors or on a leash, for their own safety and that of wildlife. People who see sick animals in the wild or along trails should not approach them, Vaid said, not only because of the risk of tularemia but of rabies. \n\nWhat is known for sure is that 7 of the beavers that thrived in and along McCullough Creek in the park died in the last year [2012]. In addition to vector transmission, tularemia may be spread by contact with infected animals or environmental fomites, by inhalation, or by ingestion of the poorly cooked flesh of infected animals or contaminated water. \n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District issued an alert notifying residents of tularemia in the area. \n\nHuman attraction to nature puts people in closer contact with wildlife diseases, she added. ' \n\n'I would love to see it happening,' she said. According to the National Institutes of Health, tularemia is common among wild rodents and can be transmitted to other animals and humans through direct contact and by ticks, biting flies and other insects. Unfortunately, she said, the die-off 'also tells us that natural habitats are more and more disturbed, forcing the beavers to be in a more dense population.' Then in June and September, 2 adult beavers were found dead but were too decomposed to be necropsied, he said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-11-25 00:00:00", "2012-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Champaign", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McCullough Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1789311", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (02): (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1789311", "date": "2013-06-24 13:58:27", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (02): (NEBRASKA)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 21 Jun 2013\nSource: Omaha (NE) World-Herald [edited]\nhttp://www.omaha.com/article/20130621/LIVEWELL01/130629926\n\n\nA North Platte, Nebraska girl is recovering after contracting tularemia. Dr Tom Safranek, Nebraska's state epidemiologist, said 6 cases of the disease have been confirmed in the state this year [2013]. A 4 year old in North Platte is one of them.\n\nThe girl spent Memorial Day weekend [25-27 May 2013] swimming in Birdwood Creek and the Interstate lakes near Hershey. Afterward, her mother noticed a tick on the left side of her daughter's neck. She pulled the bug off and forgot about it. Soon after, the young girl developed a rash and fever and complained of neck pain. The lymph nodes behind her ear and by her clavicle swelled.\n\nThe mother, a registered nurse, became concerned that her daughter might have meningitis. She took her to Great Plains Pediatrics in North Platte, where another tick was found in the girl's hairline near her left ear. 'The tick wasn't imbedded completely, but it was evident it had been there for a while,' the mother said. 'The site was infected. There was a red, swollen area about 3 inches [7.5 cm] wide that was hot to the touch.' Cultures were done, and the girl was put on an antibiotic and sent home. When she started complaining about a sore throat a few days later, her mother took her back to the pediatrician's office.\n\n'By then, she had pustules on the roof of her mouth and her throat was swollen,' the mother said. 'The areas where both ticks had bitten her were even more inflamed, and the skin around them was peeling.' More cultures were performed and the girl was put on another antibiotic, which caused an allergic reaction. Ultimately, the girl was taken to the Children's Hospital and Medical Center in Omaha.\n\nOn 6 Jun 2013, the girl was diagnosed with tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever. Because of the mother's nursing background, officials at the children's hospital agreed to let her treat her daughter at home with IV Gentamicin 3 times a day for 9 days, with resolution occurring.\n\nAccording to Safranek, tularemia can be life threatening. Caused by bacteria, it can attack the skin, eyes, lymph nodes, lungs, and other internal organs. Safranek said the disease is most common in mammals, especially rodents and rabbits.\n\nSafranek said that the biggest problem with both tularemia and Rocky Mountain spotted fever, another tickborne disease, is that they are so uncommon they are often overlooked. 'Doctors often misdiagnose them and prescribe the wrong antibiotics to treat them,' Safranek said. 'The good news is they are preventable.' He said people should use care when handling dead animals, wear insect repellent and do frequent tick checks because the transmission rate is low if ticks are removed quickly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not apparently related to bioterrorism in this case, tularemia is a category A bioterrorism agent and the pneumonic form is likely to be the one associated with intentional spread.\n\nTularemia is caused by _Francisella tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States an outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal illness, but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical incubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of one to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of exposure. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza, and sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize the continuing illness.\n\nIn this case, it was not stated what body fluids were culture positive for the organism but oropharyngeal involvement seemed prominent. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/7oVU.]", "summary": "\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and vegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental conditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as, _Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may represent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental exposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nSafranek said that the biggest problem with both tularemia and Rocky Mountain spotted fever, another tickborne disease, is that they are so uncommon they are often overlooked.
