Dr Tom Safranek, Nebraska's state epidemiologist, said 6 cases of the disease have been confirmed in the state this year [2013]. \n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< She took her to Great Plains Pediatrics in North Platte, where another tick was found in the girl's hairline near her left ear. ' When she started complaining about a sore throat a few days later, her mother took her back to the pediatrician's office.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-06-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nebraska", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Birdwood Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Omaha", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Platte", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NE", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Interstate", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Hershey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1560910", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (NC) hunters", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1560910", "date": "2013-02-26 14:14:45", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA) HUNTERS\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 20 Feb 2013\nSource: NBC News [edited]\nhttp://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/25/17089610-rabbit-fever-strikes-two-nc-hunters\n\n\nState health officials said a North Carolina hunter has tested positive for rabbit fever. The Wilson Times reported a 2nd rabbit hunter in eastern North Carolina is showing signs of the disease officially called tularemia.\n\nAlthough rare, rabbit fever is a serious and potentially fatal disease. Symptoms can include fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, and progressive weakness. The disease is treated with antibiotics. Officials said both hunters appear to be recovering. Their names have not been released.\n\nOfficials said the disease is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. It's typically found in animals, especially rodents and rabbits. Most cases occur in rural areas.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted by eating infected food and can even be transmitted through the air. Authorities said there have been 17 cases of the illness in North Carolina since 1999. There are about 200 cases reported annually in the USA. Rabbit hunting season runs until 28 Feb 2013.\n\n[Byline: Marc Lallanilla]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\n\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria.\n\nThe type of exposure will dictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures usually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of disease in these cases is not stated. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1s-V.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The Wilson Times reported a 2nd rabbit hunter in eastern North Carolina is showing signs of the disease officially called tularemia.\n\n Source: NBC News [edited]\nhttp://vitals.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/25/17089610-rabbit-fever-strikes-two-nc-hunters\n\n\nState health officials said a North Carolina hunter has tested positive for rabbit fever. \n\nThe disease can be transmitted by eating infected food and can even be transmitted through the air. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nOfficials said the disease is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_. [Byline: Marc Lallanilla]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-02-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2083934", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (08): 2001-2010", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2083934", "date": "2013-11-30 17:27:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (08): 2001-2010\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Nov 2013\nSource: CDC. Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 62(47):963-966 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6247a5.htm?s_cid=mm6247a5_w\n\n\nTularemia is a rare but potentially serious bacterial zoonosis that has been reported from all states in the USA except Hawaii. The etiologic agent, _Francisella tularensis_, is highly infectious and can be transmitted through arthropod bites, direct contact with infected animal tissue, inhalation of contaminated aerosols, and ingestion of contaminated food or water (1). _F. tularensis_ has been designated a Tier 1 select agent because it meets several criteria, including low infectious dose, ability to infect via aerosol, and a history of being developed as a bioweapon (2). This report summarizes tularemia cases reported to CDC during 2001-2010 via the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (NNDSS) and compares the epidemiology of these cases with those reported during the preceding decade. During 2001-2010, a total of 1208 cases were reported (median: 126.5 cases per year; range: 90-154). Incidence was highest among children aged 5-9 years and men aged greater than 55 years. Clinicians and public health practitioners should be familiar with the current epidemiology and clinical features of tularemia to identify and adequately treat individual cases and recognize unusual patterns that might signal an outbreak or bioterrorism event.\n\nIn humans, _F. tularensis_ causes distinct clinical syndromes depending on the route of exposure. Percutaneous inoculation typically produces ulceroglandular tularemia, characterized by a cutaneous ulcer at the site of inoculation and tender regional lymphadenopathy. A less common presentation after percutaneous inoculation is glandular tularemia, in which patients develop regional lymphadenopathy without ulcer. Inhalation of _F. tularensis_ can result in a primary pneumonia, whereas ingestion causes oropharyngeal disease consisting of tonsillitis or pharyngitis with cervical lymphadenopathy. Other forms of tularemia include oculoglandular (infection of the eye) and typhoidal (fever without localizing signs) (3). Certain strains of _F. tularensis_ subspecies _tularensis_ (also known as type A) are associated with more severe disease and a greater risk for death (4,5). Mortality is less than 2 percent overall but ranges up to 24 percent depending on the strain (1,4).\n\nFor national surveillance purposes, a confirmed case of tularemia is defined as clinically compatible illness with either a 4-fold or greater change in serum antibody titer to _F. tularensis_ antigen or isolation of _F. tularensis_ from a clinical specimen. A probable case is defined as clinically compatible illness with either a single elevated antibody titer to _F. tularensis_ antigen or detection of _F. tularensis_ in a clinical specimen by fluorescent assay (6). In this report, incidence is calculated using 2005 census population estimates.\n\nA total of 1208 cases of tularemia were reported via NNDSS during 2001-2010. The median number of cases per year was 126.5, with a range of 90-154 cases per year. Of these 1208 reported cases, 64 percent were categorized as confirmed and 35 percent as probable (Figure 1 [for figures and tables, see original URL - Mod.LL]). Median age of patients was 39 years (range: 1-92 years), and 68 percent were male. Average annual incidence was 0.041 cases per 100 000 persons. By age group and sex, annual incidence was highest among children aged 5-9 years (0.071) and among men aged 65-69 years (0.11) (Figure 2). Race was recorded for 887 patients (73 percent). Among these, 86 percent were white, 9 percent were American Indian/Alaska Native, and 3 percent were black. Ethnicity was recorded for 718 patients (59 percent), of whom 5 percent were Hispanic. The highest annual incidence by race was among American Indians/Alaska Natives (0.3 per 100 000 persons).\n\nCases were reported from 47 states (Figure 3). Of those, 6 states accounted for 59 percent of reported cases: Missouri (19 percent), Arkansas (13 percent), Oklahoma (9 percent), Massachusetts (7 percent), South Dakota (5 percent), and Kansas (5 percent). Among the 10 states with the highest incidence of tularemia, all but Massachusetts were located in the central or western United States (Table).\n\nTularemia cases were reported from 505 American counties (16 percent) during 2001-2010. County of residence was available for 1198 patients (99 percent), although in some cases this might not have been the county of exposure. Among these, 53 percent of patients resided in counties classified as rural by CDC National Center for Health Statistics' Urban-Rural Classification Scheme for Counties (7), although rural counties accounted for only 17 percent of the US population in 2006. The county with the highest annual incidence was Dukes County (Martha's Vineyard and the Elizabeth Islands), Massachusetts (67 cases; 43 per 100 000 persons). Cases in Dukes County were reported consistently during the 10-year period (range: 2-16 cases per year), with substantial increases in 2005 (11 cases), 2006 (10 cases), and 2008 (16 cases). Additional counties with high incidence rates were Buffalo County, South Dakota (6 cases; 29 per 100 000), and Shannon County, South Dakota (24 cases; 18 per 100 000).\n\nThe majority of cases (77 percent) occurred during May through September, consistent with peak arthropod activity and increased outdoor human activity. However, seasonal patterns varied by region. In the New England states, no cases occurred in the nonpeak winter months of December through March. In contrast, 20 percent of cases in the South Atlantic states, 15 percent in the East South Central states, and 14 percent in the Pacific states occurred from December through March.\n\nThe total number of cases reported during 2001-2010 was similar to the number reported during the 10-year period 1991-2000 (1208 versus 1216, respectively). Nevertheless, notable changes occurred in the number of cases reported from some individual states: Montana (72 percent decrease), Arkansas (42 percent decrease), South Dakota (29 percent decrease), Massachusetts (155 percent increase), Nebraska (120 percent increase), and Oklahoma (35 percent increase) (8).\n\nEditorial Note:\nDuring 2001-2010, the number and demographic features of reported tularemia cases were similar to those reported during the preceding decade. Nevertheless, several differences were noted between the 2 periods. The geographic distribution of reported cases was slightly less concentrated in the central states during 2001-2010, with a greater proportion of cases reported from the Northeast and the Pacific states of Washington and California than in previous years. In addition, 4 states that had not reported cases during 1991-2000 (Connecticut, New Hampshire, Vermont, and West Virginia) reported cases during 2001-2010. Further investigation is needed to determine whether the change in distribution was caused by alterations in reporting patterns, vector distribution, human behavior, or other factors.\n\nSeasonal variations by region are likely attributable in part to climate differences, because states with milder climates have longer arthropod activity and thus extended periods of risk. Seasonal variations might also reflect, to some extent, hunting activities that can occur year-round, in contrast to landscaping and other outdoor recreational activities that are concentrated in the summer months. Hunting can result in human exposure to tularemia through direct contact with infected animals and ingestion of infected meat. Hunting of rabbits, which typically occurs in the fall and winter, might explain the higher proportion of winter cases in South Atlantic and East South Central states, where small game hunting is common (9).\n\nIn a previous surveillance report for the period 1990-2000, CDC recommended improving surveillance by increasing documentation of laboratory confirmation and collecting more detailed epidemiologic and clinical data (8). Documentation of laboratory confirmation has indeed improved; during 1990-2000, only 65 percent of case reports included documentation indicating whether they met the probable versus confirmed case definition, compared with 99 percent during 2001-2010. Although the amount of epidemiologic and clinical data collected through NNDSS has not changed, CDC does regularly request additional patient information from health departments to better characterize the disease.\n\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 2 limitations: 1st, the tularemia cases described in this report might not be fully representative of all cases diagnosed in the United States because case ascertainment and reporting might be incomplete and differ by state; 2nd, missing data and small numbers limit statistical comparisons and interpretation.\n\nTularemia is not a common disease, but it continues to cause approximately 100 reported human cases annually in the United States and is a serious and potentially fatal disease. Although outbreaks do occur (10), the majority of reported tularemia cases in the United States are sporadic. Clinicians should consider tularemia in patients with a compatible clinical profile, particularly in children and elderly males with acute fever and regional lymphadenopathy. This report shows that the distribution of tularemia might be gradually changing; therefore, tularemia should be considered even in areas where it has rarely been reported.\n\nState and local public health departments are encouraged to report tularemia cases in a timely manner and provide additional patient information, including exposure history, clinical syndrome, and outcome, to CDC when possible. Because the threat of bioterrorism remains, clinicians and health departments should remain vigilant; for example, an urban cluster of tularemia cases among persons without a common natural exposure could be the 1st sign of a bioterrorism attack.\n\nReferences\n------------\n1. Dennis DT, Inglesby TV, Henderson DA, et al: Tularemia as a biological weapon: medical and public health management. JAMA 2001;285:2763-73.\n2. US Department of Health and Human Services: Possession, use, and transfer of select agents and toxins; biennial review. Fed Regist 2012;77(194).\n3. Eliasson H, Broman T, Forsman M, B\u00e4ck E: Tularemia: current epidemiology and disease management. Infect Dis Clin N Am 2006;20:289-311.\n4. Kugeler KJ, Mead PS, Janusz AM, et al: Molecular epidemiology of _Francisella tularensis_ in the United States. Clin Infect Dis 2009;48:863-70.\n5. Staples JE, Kubota KA, Chalcraft LG, Mead PS, Petersen JM: Epidemiologic and molecular analysis of human tularemia, United States, 1964-2004. Emerg Infect Dis 2006;12:1113-8.\n6. CDC: Tularemia surveillance case definition. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health and Human Services, CDC; 2013. Available at http://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/script/casedef.aspx?condyrid=880&datepub=1/1/1999%2012:00:00%20am.\n7. Ingram DD, Franco SJ: NCHS urban-rural classification scheme for counties. Vital Health Stat 2012;2(154).\n8. CDC: Tularemia -- United States, 1990-2000. MMWR 2002;51:182-4.\n9. US Fish and Wildlife Service; US Census Bureau: 2006 national survey of fishing, hunting, and wildlife-associated recreation. Washington, DC: US Department of the Interior, US Fish and Wildlife Service; US Census Bureau, US Department of Commerce; 2008. Available at http://www.census.gov/prod/2008pubs/fhw06-nat.pdf.\n10. Calanan R, Rolfs R, Summers J, et al: Tularemia outbreak associated with outdoor exposure along the western side of Utah Lake, Utah, 2007. Public Health Rep 2010;125:870-6.\n\n[Authors: Nelson C, Kugeler K, Petersen J, Mead P]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Human infection with _Francisella tularensis_, a Category (or tier) A bioterrorism agent, continues to be a problem on Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket, islands off the southern coast of Cape Cod in Massachusetts, as reflected in this data. A substantial number of the cases are pneumonic, occurring in landscapers and gardeners, related to the aerosolization of infective bacteria.\n\nTelford and colleagues (1) have investigated the genetic diversity of _F. tularensis_ obtained from Martha's Vineyard ticks. Between 2001 and 2003, 0.7 per cent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) harbored the tularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of genotypic diversity suggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of the infection on the island. The authors review information regarding the island's tularemia, which appears to have been a relatively recent introduction into Massachusetts. They state that prior to 1937, only one case of the infection was recognized, related to contaminated rabbit meat from the Midwest USA. In 1937, however, more than 20 000 cottontail rabbits from the Midwest states of Missouri and Kansas were introduced into the Massachusetts mainland and Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket for sporting purposes (2). Cases began to occur starting several years later.\n\nAnother interesting observation relates to tularemia's role in the search for evidence of bioterrorism using air sensor detectors of the BioWatch program. At least 3 episodes of air screening positivity for tularemia occurred during this decade in Saint Louis, Missouri; Washington, DC; and Houston, Texas; no human cases occurred during those episodes and all 3 likely not related to any deliberate event. Additionally, cases of tularemia can be found in urban areas, even in New York City.\n\n1. Goethert HK, Shani I, Telford SR. Genotypic diversity of _Francisella tularensis_ infected _Dermacentor variabilis_ ticks on Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts. J Clin Microbiol 2004; 42: 4968-73.\n2. Belding DL, Merrill M. Tularemia in imported rabbits in Massachusetts. N Engl J Med 1941; 1085-87.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1hiS.]", "summary": "Of those, 6 states accounted for 59 percent of reported cases: Missouri (19 percent), Arkansas (13 percent), Oklahoma (9 percent), Massachusetts (7 percent), South Dakota (5 percent), and Kansas (5 percent). Nevertheless, notable changes occurred in the number of cases reported from some individual states: Montana (72 percent decrease), Arkansas (42 percent decrease), South Dakota (29 percent decrease), Massachusetts (155 percent increase), Nebraska (120 percent increase), and Oklahoma (35 percent increase) (8). Cases in Dukes County were reported consistently during the 10-year period (range: 2-16 cases per year), with substantial increases in 2005 (11 cases), 2006 (10 cases), and 2008 (16 cases). In contrast, 20 percent of cases in the South Atlantic states, 15 percent in the East South Central states, and 14 percent in the Pacific states occurred from December through March. The geographic distribution of reported cases was slightly less concentrated in the central states during 2001-2010, with a greater proportion of cases reported from the Northeast and the Pacific states of Washington and California than in previous years. This report summarizes tularemia cases reported to CDC during 2001-2010 via the National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System (NNDSS) and compares the epidemiology of these cases with those reported during the preceding decade. The findings in this report are subject to at least 2 limitations: 1st, the tularemia cases described in this report might not be fully representative of all cases diagnosed in the United States because case ascertainment and reporting might be incomplete and differ by state; 2nd, missing data and small numbers limit statistical comparisons and interpretation. \n\nThe total number of cases reported during 2001-2010 was similar to the number reported during the 10-year period 1991-2000 (1208 versus 1216, respectively). In addition, 4 states that had not reported cases during 1991-2000 (Connecticut, New Hampshire, Vermont, and West Virginia) reported cases during 2001-2010. \n\nTularemia cases were reported from 505 American counties (16 percent) during 2001-2010. \n\nTularemia is not a common disease, but it continues to cause approximately 100 reported human cases annually in the United States and is a serious and potentially fatal disease. Of these 1208 reported cases, 64 percent were categorized as confirmed and 35 percent as probable (Figure 1 [for figures and tables, see original URL - Mod. During 2001-2010, a total of 1208 cases were reported (median: 126.5 cases per year; range: 90-154). During 2001-2010, the number and demographic features of reported tularemia cases were similar to those reported during the preceding decade. Documentation of laboratory confirmation has indeed improved; during 1990-2000, only 65 percent of case reports included documentation indicating whether they met the probable versus confirmed case definition, compared with 99 percent during 2001-2010. \n\nState and local public health departments are encouraged to report tularemia cases in a timely manner and provide additional patient information, including exposure history, clinical syndrome, and outcome, to CDC when possible. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nA total of 1208 cases of tularemia were reported via NNDSS during 2001-2010. Additional counties with high incidence rates were Buffalo County, South Dakota (6 cases; 29 per 100 000), and Shannon County, South Dakota (24 cases; 18 per 100 000). \n\nThe majority of cases (77 percent) occurred during May through September, consistent with peak arthropod activity and increased outdoor human activity. Among these, 53 percent of patients resided in counties classified as rural by CDC National Center for Health Statistics' Urban-Rural Classification Scheme for Counties (7), although rural counties accounted for only 17 percent of the US population in 2006. Among these, 86 percent were white, 9 percent were American Indian/Alaska Native, and 3 percent were black. Although outbreaks do occur (10), the majority of reported tularemia cases in the United States are sporadic. The median number of cases per year was 126.5, with a range of 90-154 cases per year. At least 3 episodes of air screening positivity for tularemia occurred during this decade in Saint Louis, Missouri; Washington, DC; and Houston, Texas; no human cases occurred during those episodes and all 3 likely not related to any deliberate event. Clinicians and public health practitioners should be familiar with the current epidemiology and clinical features of tularemia to identify and adequately treat individual cases and recognize unusual patterns that might signal an outbreak or bioterrorism event. Because the threat of bioterrorism remains, clinicians and health departments should remain vigilant; for example, an urban cluster of tularemia cases among persons without a common natural exposure could be the 1st sign of a bioterrorism attack. For national surveillance purposes, a confirmed case of tularemia is defined as clinically compatible illness with either a 4-fold or greater change in serum antibody titer to _F. tularensis_ antigen or isolation of _F. tularensis_ from a clinical specimen. \n\nCases were reported from 47 states (Figure 3). [Authors: Nelson C, Kugeler K, Petersen J, Mead P]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< County of residence was available for 1198 patients (99 percent), although in some cases this might not have been the county of exposure. Hunting of rabbits, which typically occurs in the fall and winter, might explain the higher proportion of winter cases in South Atlantic and East South Central states, where small game hunting is common (9). Ethnicity was recorded for 718 patients (59 percent), of whom 5 percent were Hispanic. This report shows that the distribution of tularemia might be gradually changing; therefore, tularemia should be considered even in areas where it has rarely been reported. Mortality is less than 2 percent overall but ranges up to 24 percent depending on the strain (1,4). The county with the highest annual incidence was Dukes County (Martha's Vineyard and the Elizabeth Islands), Massachusetts (67 cases; 43 per 100 000 persons). Median age of patients was 39 years (range: 1-92 years), and 68 percent were male. Among the 10 states with the highest incidence of tularemia, all but Massachusetts were located in the central or western United States (Table). By age group and sex, annual incidence was highest among children aged 5-9 years (0.071) and among men aged 65-69 years (0.11) (Figure 2). A probable case is defined as clinically compatible illness with either a single elevated antibody titer to _F. tularensis_ antigen or detection of _F. tularensis_ in a clinical specimen by fluorescent assay (6). TULAREMIA - USA (08): 2001-2010\n Additionally, cases of tularemia can be found in urban areas, even in New York City. Average annual incidence was 0.041 cases per 100 000 persons. http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6247a5.htm?s_cid=mm6247a5_w\n\n\nTularemia is a rare but potentially serious bacterial zoonosis that has been reported from all states in the USA except Hawaii. In the New England states, no cases occurred in the nonpeak winter months of December through March. \n\nSeasonal variations by region are likely attributable in part to climate differences, because states with milder climates have longer arthropod activity and thus extended periods of risk. \n\nAnother interesting observation relates to tularemia's role in the search for evidence of bioterrorism using air sensor detectors of the BioWatch program. Between 2001 and 2003, 0.7 per cent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) harbored the tularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of genotypic diversity suggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of the infection on the island. Clinicians should consider tularemia in patients with a compatible clinical profile, particularly in children and elderly males with acute fever and regional lymphadenopathy. Incidence was highest among children aged 5-9 years and men aged greater than 55 years. from Dr Per Starcke Henriksen, Chief Veterinary Officer, Danish Veterinary and Food Administration, Ministry of Food, Agriculture and Fisheries, Soborg, Denmark\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 16 Nov 2012\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 23 Nov 2012\nReport date: 26 Nov 2012\nDate submitted to OIE: 27 Nov 2012\nReason for notification: 1st Not applicable\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European Hare): _Lepus europaeus (Leporidae)_ / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\n\nAffected inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination\nNo treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: National Veterinary Institute (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nBrown hare (European Hare) / in situ hybridisation (ISH) / 23 Nov 2012 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia, an OIE notifiable disease, is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits and hares) and rodents, especially microtine rodents such as voles, vole rats, and muskrats, as well as in beavers. In addition, a wide variety of other mammals, birds, amphibians, and invertebrates have been reported to be infected.\n\nTularemia occurs endemically in the Northern Hemisphere. The disease can occur as epizootic outbreaks in many countries in North America and Europe, while it occurs only as sporadic cases in some other countries in Europe and Asia. It is rarely reported from the tropics or the Southern Hemisphere. Several epizootic outbreaks have been reported as a result of importation of subclinically infected lagomorphs.\n\nThe clinically most relevant 2 types of _F. tularensis_ are recognised on the basis of culture characteristics, epidemiology, and virulence. _Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is mainly associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is primarily transmitted by ticks or biting flies, or by direct contact with infected lagomorphs. It is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits, and most isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp. _palaearctica_ (type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers, muskrats) and voles in northern North America, and in lagomorphs (hares) and rodents in Eurasia. It is primarily transmitted by direct contact or by mosquitoes, but may be transmitted through inhalation or through infected water or food. It is less virulent for humans and domestic rabbits and does not ferment glycerol. The information above is primarily based upon chapter 2.1.18 of OIE's Terrestrial Manual from which additional information, particularly addressing diagnostic techniques, is accessible at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ZJN.]", "summary": "Species / Test / Test date / Result\nBrown hare (European Hare) / in situ hybridisation (ISH) / 23 Nov 2012 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia, an OIE notifiable disease, is a zoonosis caused by _Francisella tularensis_. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Reason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Francisella tularensis_\n Affected animals\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nBrown hare (European Hare): _Lepus europaeus (Leporidae)_ / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\n\nAffected population: A wild European hare found dead at Saltbaek Vig near Kalundborg on the western part of Zealand. Of the 6 cases, 3 are from the town of Kotlas and the other 3 from the village of Shipitsyno.\n\nAccording to the regional Rospotrebnadzor [Federal Service for Consumer Protection and Human Welfare], on 17 Aug 2012, there were 3 cases, and to date, there are 6, including an 8-year-old child. All of them have been hospitalized and are undergoing the necessary treatment.\n\nThe press service of the regional emergency department reported that in view of the current situation, the district Commission on Emergency Situations will budget the necessary resources to carry out anti-epidemic measures and disinfection treatments. Specialists from Rospotrebnadzor and the Ministry of Health are in the area.\n\nTularemia is a dangerous infection characterized by intoxication, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. Tularemia is most common in rural areas. Human infections are rare in the city and are associated with infected products or animals. Often, the sources of infection are common field and house mice, water rats, rabbits, muskrats, hamsters, and other rodents.\n\nTularemia infection can occur through contact with sick rodents or their droppings, by consumption of contaminated food or water, from infected secretions from rodents, via airborne dust when processing contaminated cereals and fodder, and by mosquitoes.\n\nOne of the characteristics of tularemia is an almost 100 percent susceptibility to the disease regardless of age. There is no person-to-person transmission, and persons who have had the disease acquire immunity to it.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in the reported cases are not specified. Tularemia can present in a number of ways based on the mode of acquisition. The acquisition of _F. tularensis_ can be from tick and deer fly bites, skin contact with infected animals, ingestion of contaminated food or water, laboratory exposure, and inhalation of contaminated dusts or aerosols. - Mod.LL]\n\n[A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/3jEN.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in the reported cases are not specified. \n\nTularemia infection can occur through contact with sick rodents or their droppings, by consumption of contaminated food or water, from infected secretions from rodents, via airborne dust when processing contaminated cereals and fodder, and by mosquitoes. TULAREMIA - RUSSIA: (ARKHANGELSK)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-08-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kotlassky Municipal District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shipitsyno", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kotlas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1366708", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia (02): (KX) susp. NOT anthrax", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1366708", "date": "2012-10-27 12:40:17", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (02): (KRASNOYARSK) SUSPECTED, NOT ANTHRAX\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 19 Oct 2012\nSource: Federal Press news agency [in Russian, trans. Tamas Torok, edited]\nhttp://fedpress.ru/news/society/news_event/rospotrebnadzor-podozrevaet-sibirskuyu-yazvu-u-zhitelya-krasnoyarskogo-kraya\n\n\nToday, 19 Oct 2012, employees of the Krasnoyarsk Rospotrebnadzor [Federal Service for Consumer Protection and Human Welfare] announced that a previously suspected 'anthrax' diagnosis of a local resident has been confirmed [but see below], and that he could have acquired it in the flood zone of Boguchanskaya hydroelectric power plant. Spokeswoman Natalia Krasnopeeva told the 'FederalPress.Sibir' that a final diagnosis would be become clear tomorrow.\n\n'The preliminary diagnosis was confirmed in the resident of the Abansk district,' said Natalia Krasnopeeva. 'Specialists went to visit all places where a sick person stayed.'\n\nAllegedly, the sick person previously resided in the village of Kezhma, which was partially flooded by water filling the Boguchany Dam. The other day he came to town on personal business. There, his dog caught a muskrat and brought it to him. He butchered the muskrat and fed the dog. Some time later, the man had fever and boils.\n\nThe sick man told the Krasnoyarsk bloggers, he suspects that this all happened because of poor cleaning of the reservoir bed. Animal cemeteries, which were not properly prepared for flooding, were inundated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 19 Oct 2012\nSource: Siberian News Agency [in Russian, trans. Tamas Torok, edited]\nhttp://krsk.sibnovosti.ru/society/210788-minzdrav-kraya-oproverg-informatsiyu-ob-epidemii-sibirskoy-yazvy-v-zone-boges\n\n\nThe Health Ministry denied the information about an epidemic of anthrax in the reservoir area of Boguchanskaya hydroelectric power plant.\n\nThis statement was given by the Department of Health of the Region. denying the information circulated in the internet by a member of the initiative group of people from the flooded area, that he had contracted anthrax because of poor sanitation of the reservoir bed in the Kezhemsky region.\n\nIn particular, the man reportedly caught the infection on 9 Oct 2012 in the already abandoned village of Kezhma, presumably from the corpse of a muskrat, which was found by his dog. On his way back home to Aban, the man found himself sick with typical anthrax symptoms, and 5 days later he was hospitalized in the infectious ward of the Kan hospital. Moreover, according to published information, analysis sent to Krasnoyarsk, confirmed the diagnosis of anthrax.\n\nThe Ministry of Health of the Krasnoyarsk Region confirmed the admission and isolation of all the patient's contacts; however, it was too early to draw conclusions about the diagnosis -- the final results of the examination will be available only in 3 weeks -- and the preliminary analysis of anthrax was not confirmed. The man's disease looks like a lung infection -- tularemia, which is treated with antibiotics. The patient is currently doing well.\n\nIn this case, epidemiologists emphasize that the probability of contracting anthrax from muskrats is extremely low, as rodents are extremely resistant to this disease. In addition, the Ministry of Health added that, even if the diagnosis of anthrax is confirmed, it is in the lightest skin form, which is also treated with antibiotics.\n\nNonetheless, all medical services of the Krasnoyarsk Territory, particularly in Kezhemsky, Boguchany, Abanskom areas, have been given special instructions and guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of such patients.\n\nIn addition, experts have yet to identify the epidemic source of the infection, so they have to go through the entire routes of the sick person and collect samples.\n\nResponding to the suggestion that the source of infection could be an unprocessed animal burial site at the bottom of the Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP) reservoir, the representative of the Rospotrebnadzor in Krasnoyarsk region assured that the Irkutsk Anti-Plague Institute sanitized all known animal burial sites in accordance with the current regulations. This year (2012), the Veterinary Service jointly with Rospotrebnadzor conducted a study on anthrax in the cattle burial site before the flooding of the area, and the results were negative.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n<cvlonghorns@aol.com>\n\n[Our thanks to Sabine Zentis and Tamas Torok for this report of a case of tularemia initially diagnosed as anthrax. Why they suspected 'anthrax' is hard to determine other than his 'boils'. Interesting that the subsequent health of his dog after eating the muskrat is not mentioned. Dogs are susceptible to this pathogen. Maybe he cooked the muskrat before feeding it to his dog. Or maybe his physician forgot to ask.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3PZ4. TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (02): (KRASNOYARSK) SUSPECTED, NOT ANTHRAX\n*************************************************************\n The Ministry of Health of the Krasnoyarsk Region confirmed the admission and isolation of all the patient's contacts; however, it was too early to draw conclusions about the diagnosis -- the final results of the examination will be available only in 3 weeks -- and the preliminary analysis of anthrax was not confirmed. Castleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Castleview Pedigree English Longhorns\nGut Laach\n52385 Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\n Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\n \n\n\nToday, 19 Oct 2012, employees of the Krasnoyarsk Rospotrebnadzor [Federal Service for Consumer Protection and Human Welfare] announced that a previously suspected 'anthrax' diagnosis of a local resident has been confirmed [but see below], and that he could have acquired it in the flood zone of Boguchanskaya hydroelectric power plant. \n\n--\n \n\n--\n This statement was given by the Department of Health of the Region. denying the information circulated in the internet by a member of the initiative group of people from the flooded area, that he had contracted anthrax because of poor sanitation of the reservoir bed in the Kezhemsky region. Responding to the suggestion that the source of infection could be an unprocessed animal burial site at the bottom of the Hydroelectric Power Plant (HPP) reservoir, the representative of the Rospotrebnadzor in Krasnoyarsk region assured that the Irkutsk Anti-Plague Institute sanitized all known animal burial sites in accordance with the current regulations. \n\nThe sick man told the Krasnoyarsk bloggers, he suspects that this all happened because of poor cleaning of the reservoir bed. In particular, the man reportedly caught the infection on 9 Oct 2012 in the already abandoned village of Kezhma, presumably from the corpse of a muskrat, which was found by his dog. Date: Fri 19 Oct 2012\n Date: Fri 19 Oct 2012\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Krasnoyarsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kezhemsky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kezhma", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boguchanskaya", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1415382", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, pneumonic - Canada: (AB) biologic immunomodulator", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1415382", "date": "2012-11-19 14:26:31", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - CANADA: (ALBERTA) BIOLOGIC IMMUNOMODULATOR\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 16 Nov 2012\nFrom: Lynora Saxinger <lynora.saxinger@ualberta.ca> [edited]\n\n\nThis report describes a 61-year-old man on ustekinumab, a biologic immunomodulator which affects interleukin [IL] 12 and 23, with bacteremic and pneumonic tularaemia without defined animal or tick exposures, in a semi-rural Northern Canadian setting. The mechanism of action of ustekinumab would suggest it may impair specific host intracellular defences against _Francisella tularensis_, and thus tularaemia should be a clinical consideration if patients exposed to IL12/23 inhibitors present with compatible illness, even with only a geographic exposure history.\n\nCase: A 61-year-old man from Edmonton, Alberta, Canada was blood culture positive for _F. tularensis_, after admission to hospital for pneumonia, sepsis, and gastroenteritis on 17 Jun 2012. He experienced a subacute onset of weakness, shortness of breath, and cough, with development of vomiting, diarrhea, and weight loss for 6 weeks prior to admission. There were no rashes, lymphadenopathy, or obvious fever. While at his lake property in Northern Alberta he had an acute deterioration and at hospital admission was febrile at 39.2 deg C [102.6 deg F], and both chest x-ray and CT scan of the chest revealed a right middle lobe lateral segment opacity, small right pleural effusion, and reactive lymph nodes.\n\nHis laboratory work showed a progressive lymphocytosis over his stay and he had a mild acute kidney injury at initial assessment, which normalized over his hospital stay. A blood culture obtained on 16 Jun 2012 became positive after 4 days of incubation, with gram negative coccobacilli subsequently confirmed to be _F. tularensis_ susceptible to ciprofloxacin, doxycycline, and gentamicin. His therapy was changed to high dose ciprofloxacin to complete 3 weeks total of antimicrobial therapy. He has been followed clinically with no evidence of relapse to date.\n\nThe patient has a relevant medical history of chronic alcohol use and formerly severe psoriasis, on Stelara (ustekinumab) for the past 2.5 years, with prior use of an anti-TNF [anti-tumor necrosis factor] agent. Epidemiologically, the patient spends 3 days per week at his lake property, which was his only evident risk history in terms of acquiring _F. tularensis_ infection. He hadn't gone hunting for 20 years, doesn't fish or trap, and he had no exposure to rodents or lagomorphs in the wild. There are wild hares around this property but he does not recall any exposures to live or dead hares when mowing his yard.\n\nTularaemia is reported to occur in wild animals in all jurisdictions in Canada except the Yukon and Nunavut, most frequently in beaver, muskrat, and snowshoe hares. Worldwide, this zoonosis occurs in the Northern Hemisphere, with foci throughout North America, Europe, and northern Asia.\n\nReviewing the pathophysiology of tularaemia in view of this patient immunomodulating therapy, there are data suggesting that TNF-alfa, Il-10, Il-12, and gamma interferon are important in evoking an early T-cell independent host defence, as well as driving an expansion of a protective TH1 cell response. This intracellular organism is known to be phagocytosed by monocytes and macrophages, and then it escapes the phagosome and replicates in the cytosol. Host cell response in the in vitro setting suggests significant upregulation of IL-23 as well as IL-12 production early in infection, suggesting that IL-23 and IL-12 play important roles in these host defence events.\n\nTherefore, it would appear to be very likely that ustekinumab is a significant risk factor for infection after what would appear to be a trivial exposure to _F. tularensis_. The patient indicated a strong preference to remain on his therapy, given significant quality-of-life issues related to his psoriasis in the past. In consultation with his dermatologist, his medication was stopped and alternate psoriasis therapy offered.\n\nClinicians should be aware of this potential association when evaluating infections in patients on IL 12/23 inhibitors, as beta-lactam based therapies commonly used for empiric therapy of sepsis would not be effective, and culture results can be delayed. The only currently licensed medication with this mechanism is ustekinumab, which is indicated in psoriasis, and is under evaluation for Crohn's disease and sarcoidosis.\n\n(This case is also being submitted for publication, and was reported to the manufacturer of the drug.)\n\n--\nDr Lynora Saxinger\nAssociate Professor, Division of Infectious Diseases\nDepartments of Medicine and Medical Microbiology and Immunology\nUniversity of Alberta Hospital\nEdmonton\nCanada\n<lynora.saxinger@ualberta.ca>\n\n[Many cases of tularemia involve lymph node infection with (ulceroglandular) or without (glandular) a local skin infection draining to the lymph node. Cases associated with lawn mowers, as has been described on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts, are often pneumonic, related to inhalation of bacilli. This may have been a factor in this case. Unlike human plague infection, pneumonic tularemia does not spread from person to person. Bloodstream infection (bacteremia) can be associated with different forms of disease or may be the only manifestation (typhoidal form).\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Saxinger for submitting this first-hand report. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The following are 2 references on the association of primary pneumonic tularemia, presumed to be due to inhalation of _Francisella tularensis_, with landscaping activities such as lawnmowing:\n\nFeldman, K. A., Enscore, R. E., Lathrop, S. L., Matyas, B. T., McGuill, M., Schriefer, M. E., Stiles-Enos, D., Dennis, D. T., Petersen, L. R. & Hayes, E. B. (2001). An outbreak of primary pneumonic tularemia on Martha's Vineyard. N Engl J Med 345, 1601-1637. Available at: http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa011374.\n\nMatyas, B. T., Nieder, H. S. & Telford, S. R., III (2007). Pneumonic tularemia on Martha's Vineyard - clinical, epidemiologic, and ecological characteristics. Ann N Y Acad Sci 1105, 351-377. - Mod.ML\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/20O7.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Canada\n<lynora.saxinger@ualberta.ca>\n\n[Many cases of tularemia involve lymph node infection with (ulceroglandular) or without (glandular) a local skin infection draining to the lymph node. (2001). \n\nReviewing the pathophysiology of tularaemia in view of this patient immunomodulating therapy, there are data suggesting that TNF-alfa, Il-10, Il-12, and gamma interferon are important in evoking an early T-cell independent host defence, as well as driving an expansion of a protective TH1 cell response. \n\n--\nDr Lynora Saxinger\nAssociate Professor, Division of Infectious Diseases\nDepartments of Medicine and Medical Microbiology and Immunology \n\nThe patient has a relevant medical history of chronic alcohol use and formerly severe psoriasis, on Stelara (ustekinumab) for the past 2.5 years, with prior use of an anti-TNF [anti-tumor necrosis factor] agent. \n\nCase: A 61-year-old man from Edmonton, Alberta, Canada was blood culture positive for _F. tularensis_, after admission to hospital for pneumonia, sepsis, and gastroenteritis on 17 Jun 2012. \n\nClinicians should be aware of this potential association when evaluating infections in patients on IL 12/23 inhibitors, as beta-lactam based therapies commonly used for empiric therapy of sepsis would not be effective, and culture results can be delayed. He hadn't gone hunting for 20 years, doesn't fish or trap, and he had no exposure to rodents or lagomorphs in the wild.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-06-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Enscore", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Petersen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Edmonton", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1223191", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, rabbits - USA: (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1223191", "date": "2012-07-31 17:27:51", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, RABBITS - USA: (ARIZONA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 27 Jul 2012\nSource: The Daily Courier [edited]\nhttp://tinyurl.com/cr4ud4n\n\n\n'Rabbit fever' disease could affect pets\n----------------------------------------\nWild rabbits in the Dewey area are contracting tularemia and dying, according to Yavapai County Community Health Services (YCCHS). The disease, also known as 'rabbit fever,' was confirmed by the state laboratory after testing a dead rabbit this past week.\n\n'We usually see one or 2 cases of tularemia in animals each year,' said Stephen Everett, epidemiologist for YCCHS. People and pets who spend time outdoors can contact tularemia if they are bitten by deerflies, ticks or other insects or by handling infected rodents or rabbits, he said.\n\nTularemia is a treatable, naturally occurring illness in the United States, with about 120 [human] cases reported each year. Most occur within the western and south-central states. A germ that animals (especially rodents, rabbits and hares) carry causes the disease, which can be passed on to domestic animals and people. Family pets with outdoor roaming privileges can carry ticks into the home and may expose humans to tick-borne illnesses. Rarely, tularemia can spread to humans through contaminated food or water or by inhaling the airborne germ. It is not known to spread from person to person.\n\nPeople can avoid tularemia by applying DEET-based insect repellent to exposed skin while spending time outdoors. People can also apply tick medicine and tick collars to cats and dogs to protect the pet and the owner. Pet owners should also avoid touching any dead animal that their cat may have brought home. Hunters should wear rubber gloves when skinning game to protect themselves from contaminated blood getting in an open wound.\n\nSymptoms in humans include sudden fever, chills, headache, diarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, progressive weakness and, in severe cases, the disease can cause pneumonia. Symptoms vary from person to person and generally show up 3 to 5 days after exposure, but sometimes as late as 14 days later.\n\nThose who think they may have contracted tularemia should contact their doctors at the 1st sign of illness and tell them if you have had exposure to sick or dead animals, if you are pregnant or if you have a weakened immune system. Also, note any changes in pet behavior and consult a veterinarian if the pet develops unusual symptoms.\n\nFor more information or concerns about tularemia, contact YCCHS Environmental Health Unit in Prescott.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To quote my colleague Larry Lutwick: '_Francisella tularensis_, the bacterium that causes tularemia, is considered a category-A bioterrorism agent. Cases associated with the skinning of rabbits usually involve glandular (lymph node) or ulceroglandular (skin and lymph node) infection. Large outbreaks, especially in eastern Europe or Asia, can be associated with water exposure.\n\nPneumonic tularemia can cause a severe and fatal pneumonia when the organism is spread by aerosol, as might occur in a biological attack. However, pneumonic tularemia also occurs without the involvement of bioterrorism, as demonstrated by posts below in New York City as well as outbreaks on Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts. Unlike pneumonic plague, pneumonic tularemia does not spread from person to person.'\n\nIt's that time of year again. While the Arizona report has this disease correctly concentrated in the western and south central states it occurs across the northern tier and along the Atlantic coast states though in smaller numbers. To get an idea of this latter distribution just do a posting recall on 'tularemia AND usa'. But even in the high incidence areas all we usually see is just the occasional and sporadic dead rabbit. Then suddenly there will be a summer when one suddenly has 10 or more square miles of dead jack rabbits. What triggers it from being a background to a foreground situation is obscure. Over the years the Texas veterinary public health surveillance teams have been running tick safaris. Their collection of _F. tularensis_ strains will vary from the lethal to the essentially apathogenic. The epidemiology and ecology of this disease awaits clarification. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1FWX.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThose who think they may have contracted tularemia should contact their doctors at the 1st sign of illness and tell them if you have had exposure to sick or dead animals, if you are pregnant or if you have a weakened immune system. \n\nSymptoms in humans include sudden fever, chills, headache, diarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, progressive weakness and, in severe cases, the disease can cause pneumonia. \n\nPneumonic tularemia can cause a severe and fatal pneumonia when the organism is spread by aerosol, as might occur in a biological attack. TULAREMIA, RABBITS - USA: (ARIZONA)\n***********************************\n \n\nTularemia is a treatable, naturally occurring illness in the United States, with about 120 [human] cases reported each year. \n\n'We usually see one or 2 cases of tularemia in animals each year,' said Stephen Everett, epidemiologist for YCCHS. People and pets who spend time outdoors can contact tularemia if they are bitten by deerflies, ticks or other insects or by handling infected rodents or rabbits, he said. \n\nPeople can avoid tularemia by applying DEET-based insect repellent to exposed skin while spending time outdoors. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To quote my colleague Larry Lutwick: '_Francisella tularensis_, the bacterium that causes tularemia, is considered a category-A bioterrorism agent. Unlike pneumonic plague, pneumonic tularemia does not spread from person to person.' A germ that animals (especially rodents, rabbits and hares) carry causes the disease, which can be passed on to domestic animals and people. http://tinyurl.com/cr4ud4n\n\n\n'Rabbit fever' disease could affect pets\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "955959", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, possum - Australia (03): (TS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=955959", "date": "2011-11-22 16:01:41", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 22 Nov 2011\nFrom: Mark Veitch <mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au> and Louise Cooley\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au> [edited]\n\n\nThere have now been 2 human cases of tularemia diagnosed in Tasmania\nin 2011, 1 in June, the other in October. Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania. Both developed the ulcero-glandular\nform of tularemia, with ulceration at the site of the injury and\nprominent lymphadenitis. The 1st case recovered after a complicated\ncourse, the 2nd is improving on treatment.\n\nThe microbiological collaboration between the Royal Hobart Hospital\nand Westmead Hospital laboratories has been crucial. Both diagnoses\nwere supported by positive DFA [direct fluorescent-antibody assay] on\nexcised or aspirated tissues. PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\nTherefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. The recent Tasmanian cases also appear to be\ndifferent from the case acquired in the NT a decade ago (_F.\nnovicida_).\n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. The extent of the risk-area for this\ninfection within Tasmania is unclear, but based on these recent cases,\nmay be relatively restricted. We will also address the possibility of\nrisk from water, by reiterating existing guidance around protecting\nprivate water supplies from microbial hazards, and rendering raw water\nsafe by boiling it. We are engaging with our Department of Primary\nIndustry, Parks, Wildlife and the Environment around further\ninvestigations. These have begun.\n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere.\n\nClinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy.\n\n_F. tularensis_ is a major laboratory hazard; clinical specimens must\nbe managed by a laboratory with PC3 [physical containment level 3]\nfacilities.\n\n--\nDr Mark Veitch\nTasmanian Department of Health and Human Services\nTasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\nRoyal Hobart Hospital\nTasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). These _holarctica_ strains, also referred to as\ntype B tularemia tend to produce significantly milder disease in man\nthan the subspecies _tularensis_.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Champion MD, Zeng Q, Nix EB, et al: Comparative genomic\ncharacterization of _Francisella tularensis_ strains belonging to low\nand high virulence subspecies. PLoS Pathogens 2009; 5(5): e1000459.\nAvailable at\nhttp://www.plospathogens.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.ppat.1000459.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "Clinical features that raise the possibility of Tasmanian-acquired _F.\ntularensis_ infection include\n- an animal bite or scratch or close exposure to wild animals or their\nenvironment, particularly in the region of the West Coast of Tasmania;\n- persistent local soft tissue infection at the inoculation site and\nregional lymphadenitis, which may suppurate;\n- disease progression, or a poor response, with beta-lactam antibiotic\ntherapy. Therefore, the clinical and microbiological evidence to date points to\nthese zoonotic infections (and possible epizootic) being due to one of\nthe relatively less virulent strains of _F. tularensis_, that is, not\nthe type A or subspecies _tularensis_ strain more often associated\nwith serious sepsis such as pneumonia and septicemia in parts of the\nnorthern hemisphere. TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (03): (TASMANIA)\n*****************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Tasmania, Australia\n<louise.cooley@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\n\n[ProMED-mail sincerely thanks Dr Veitch and Dr Cooley for supplying\nvital information regarding the clinical circumstances and\nmicrobiological data regarding these 2 separate cases of\nulceroglandular tularemia acquired from possums in Tasmania. Tasmania, Australia\n<mark.veitch@dhhs.tas.gov.au>\nand\nDr Louise Cooley\n PCR-based characterization of genetic\nmaterial from the 1st case suggested the strain of _Francisella\ntularensis_ involved was _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_\nbiovar _japonica_.\n\n \n\nPublic health actions so far have included information to animal\nhandlers who might work in the area of the 1st case, wider public\nadvice around wild animal contact via the media, and alerts to\nclinicians and laboratories. \n\nWe would like to pass the following points on to infectious disease\nphysicians, microbiologists, and their colleagues who may not\npreviously have considered the possibility of tularemia acquired in\nthe Southern Hemisphere. The\norganism _F. tularensis_ subspecies _holarctica_ biovar _japonica_ is\ndistinct from other _holarctica_ strains that are found in Europe,\nAsia, and the USA (1). Both cases were women in\ntheir 40s, each bitten and/or scratched by separate possums (probably\njuvenile and probably ill) at points only a few kilometers apart along\na remote road in western Tasmania.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:40", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "938795", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, possum - Australia: (TS), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=938795", "date": "2011-11-05 23:18:38", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA: (TASMANIA), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n*************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: Fri 4 Nov 2011\nSource: XinHuaNet [edited]\nhttp://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/health/2011-11/04/c_131229538.htm\n\n\nA rare disease never seen in the southern hemisphere before, named\ntularaemia, has been discovered in Tasmania, Australia, state Deputy\nDirector of Public Health, Dr Chrissie Pickin, confirmed on Fri 4 Nov\n2011.\n\n2 women contracted tularemia after being bitten and scratched by sick\npossums in western Tasmania. While the disease is well known in North\nAmerica and parts of Europe and Asia, it is believed the Tasmanian\ncases are the 1st in the southern hemisphere.\n\nVeterinarian Dr James Harris said it has a range of effects on humans.\n'It can cause a septicemia, an infection which circulates in the\nblood, and may cause pneumonia and unless it is treated, it can be a\nfatal disease,' he said in a statement. '(It can be) treated with\nantibiotics very successfully.'\n\nPickin said both cases have recovered, and warned people to avoid\nhandling wild animals and see their physician if scratched or bitten.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Fri 4 Nov 2011\nSource: Tasmania Department of Health and Human Services [edited]\nhttp://www.dhhs.tas.gov.au/peh/current_public_health_issues/alerts/rare_infection\n\n\nAn investigation has been launched into how 2 people developed a very\nrare infection, following contact with possums in western Tasmania.\nSpecialized testing was needed to establish the diagnosis of\ntularemia, an infection due to a bacterium called _Francisella\ntularensis_. These infections appear to be the 1st in the southern\nhemisphere due to this particular strain of the bacterium.\n\nThere are a number of different strains of the _Francisella\ntularensis_ bacterium. Current indications are that both Tasmanian\ncases are due to one of the milder strains, which causes a persistent\nbut treatable skin infection.\n\nAfter being bitten and scratched by possums in the Queenstown-Zeehan\narea earlier in 2011, each person developed persistent skin infections\nat the sites of their injuries and in their lymph glands. Both cases\nwere treated by their general practitioners and specialists, and are\nnow recovering.\n\nAs this is such a rare infection in the southern hemisphere, a joint\ninvestigation with the Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water\nand Environment has been launched. While tularemia is well known and\nunderstood in many parts of the northern hemisphere, its ecology in\nthe southern hemisphere is largely unknown.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Francisella tularensis_, the etiologic agent of tularemia, is a\nfacultative intracellular pathogen known to infect numerous animal\nspecies, including humans, and is a category A bioterrorism agent. _F.\ntularensis_ is divided into subspecies, _Francisella tularensis subsp.\ntularensis_, _F. tularensis subsp. holarctica_, and _F. tularensis\nsubsp. mediasiatica_, which differ in their pathogenicities and\ngeographic distributions. _Francisella novicida_, officially\nrecognized as another species within the _Francisella_ genus, is\nconsidered the 4th subspecies of _F. tularensis_ on the basis of its\nsimilarity in DNA hybridization experiments.\n\n_F. tularensis subsp. tularensis_ causes life-threatening type A\ntularemia and is found only in North America. _F. tularensis subsp.\nholarctica_ causes less-severe type B tularemia and is found\nthroughout the northern hemisphere. _F. tularensis subsp.\nmediasiatica_ has virulence similar to that of _F. tularensis subsp.\nholarctica_ but is geographically restricted, having been isolated\nonly from central Asia. _Francisella tularensis subsp. novicida_ is\nthe least virulent subspecies, having been isolated only rarely in\nNorth America and has been reported once in the Northern Territory of\nAustralia. This report from 2003 (Whipp MJ, Davis JM, Lum G, et al:\nCharacterization of a novicida-like subspecies of Francisella\ntularensis isolated in Australia. J Med Microbiol. 2003;52: 839-842)\ndescribed a 'novicida-like' subspecies of _F. tularensis_ from a foot\nwound sustained in brackish water in the Northern Territory of\nAustralia.\n\nBased on this report from 8 years ago, this posting is not the 1st\nisolation of _F. tularensis_ in Australia but the 1st in Tasmania. It\nis not specifically stated in the posting what subspecies was\nidentified. ProMED awaits more information regarding this isolate\nrelated to 2 cases of ulceroglandular tularemia in Tasmania. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n***** 2003;52: 839-842)\ndescribed a 'novicida-like' subspecies of _F. tularensis_ from a foot\nwound sustained in brackish water in the Northern Territory of\nAustralia. _Francisella novicida_, officially\nrecognized as another species within the _Francisella_ genus, is\nconsidered the 4th subspecies of _F. tularensis_ on the basis of its\nsimilarity in DNA hybridization experiments. A rare disease never seen in the southern hemisphere before, named\ntularaemia, has been discovered in Tasmania, Australia, state Deputy\nDirector of Public Health, Dr Chrissie Pickin, confirmed on Fri 4 Nov\n2011. novicida_ is\nthe least virulent subspecies, having been isolated only rarely in\nNorth America and has been reported once in the Northern Territory of\nAustralia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Francisella tularensis_, the etiologic agent of tularemia, is a\nfacultative intracellular pathogen known to infect numerous animal\nspecies, including humans, and is a category A bioterrorism agent. \n\nAs this is such a rare infection in the southern hemisphere, a joint\ninvestigation with the Department of Primary Industries, Parks, Water\nand Environment has been launched. Specialized testing was needed to establish the diagnosis of\ntularemia, an infection due to a bacterium called _Francisella\ntularensis_. While tularemia is well known and\nunderstood in many parts of the northern hemisphere, its ecology in\nthe southern hemisphere is largely unknown. After being bitten and scratched by possums in the Queenstown-Zeehan\narea earlier in 2011, each person developed persistent skin infections\nat the sites of their injuries and in their lymph glands.
