Both cases\nwere treated by their general practitioners and specialists, and are\nnow recovering. It\nis not specifically stated in the posting what subspecies was\nidentified. TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA: (TASMANIA), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n< tularensis_ causes life-threatening type A\ntularemia and is found only in North America. _F. tularensis subsp.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Northern Territory", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "941706", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, human, possum - Australia (02): (TS), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=941706", "date": "2011-11-08 19:44:45", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (02): (TASMANIA), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n******************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Nov 2011\nSource: Robert Spencer\n<Robert.Spencer@UHBristol.nhs.uk>\n\n\nDo you believe the story of tularemia in Tasmania? Has the organism\nbeen sequenced? The reason I ask is we did have a so-called case in an\nHIV positive patient but the organism turned out to be _F.\nphilomiragia_.\n\n--\nDr. Robert Spencer\nUniversity Hospitals Bristol NHS\nBristol, UK\n<Robert.Spencer@UHBristol.nhs.uk>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Spencer for his comment. Indeed, ProMED does not\nhave any additional information regarding the identification of the\nisolate as _F. tularensis_.\n\nThe species of _Francisella_ mentioned by Dr. Spencer, _philomiragia_\nwas initially _Yersinia philomiragia_ after being isolated from an\nill muskrat and from surface water in Utah, USA (1). The specific\nepithet, derived from the Greek combining form philo (loving) and the\nplural of the Latinized English word mirage, was chosen because of the\nspectacular mirages that are seen in the area where the isolations\nwere made.\n\nThe organism was linked to human disease and renamed _F. philomiragia_\nin 1989. Dannie Hollis and her colleagues at the CDC (2,3) reported\n14 human isolates of _F. philomiragia_ over 16 years grown primarily\nfrom blood (n=8) but also from cerebrospinal fluid, lung, pleural, and\npericardial and peritoneal fluids. Clearly the isolates were invasive\nand none were associated with an ulceroglandular or glandular\npresentation found in noninvasive tularemia as well as the Australian\ncases. The best way to identify an isolate as _F. philomiragia_ is by\nanalysis of the organism's 16S ribosomal RNA. However, good growth\n(_F. tularensis_ is a fastidious, slow grower) of the isolate suggests\n_F. philomiragia_.\n\nThe ulceroglandular nature of the illnesses of the 2 Australian\npatients, given the more invasive nature of _F. philomiragia_,\nsuggests that the isolate was _F. tularensis_ but ProMED still awaits\nfurther information.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Jensen WI, Owen CR, Jellison WL:_Yersinia philomiragia_ sp. n., a\nnew member of the Pasteurella Group of bacteria, naturally pathogenic\nfor the muskrat (_Ondatra zibethica_). J Bacteriol 1969;100:\n1237-1241.\n2. Wenger JD, Hollis DG, Weaver RE, et al: Infection caused by\n_Francisella philomiragia_ )formerly _Yersinia philomiragia_). Ann\nIntern Med 1989;110: 888-892.\n3. Hollis DG, Weaver RE, Steigerwalt AG, et al: _Francisella\nphilomiragia_ comb. nov. )formerly _Yersinia philomiragia_) and\n_Francisella tularensis_ biogroup Novicida (formerly _Francisella\nnovicida_) associated with human disease. J Clin Microbiol 1989;27:\n1601-1608.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "The specific\nepithet, derived from the Greek combining form philo (loving) and the\nplural of the Latinized English word mirage, was chosen because of the\nspectacular mirages that are seen in the area where the isolations\nwere made. *****************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n The ulceroglandular nature of the illnesses of the 2 Australian\npatients, given the more invasive nature of _F. philomiragia_,\nsuggests that the isolate was _F. tularensis_ but ProMED still awaits\nfurther information. Dannie Hollis and her colleagues at the CDC (2,3) reported\n14 human isolates of _F. philomiragia_ over 16 years grown primarily\nfrom blood (n=8) but also from cerebrospinal fluid, lung, pleural, and\npericardial and peritoneal fluids. Clearly the isolates were invasive\nand none were associated with an ulceroglandular or glandular\npresentation found in noninvasive tularemia as well as the Australian\ncases. However, good growth\n(_F. tularensis_ is a fastidious, slow grower) of the isolate suggests\n_F. philomiragia_. nov. )formerly _Yersinia philomiragia_) and\n_Francisella tularensis_ biogroup Novicida (formerly _Francisella\nnovicida_) associated with human disease. The reason I ask is we did have a so-called case in an\nHIV positive patient but the organism turned out to be _F.\nphilomiragia_. Indeed, ProMED does not\nhave any additional information regarding the identification of the\nisolate as _F. tularensis_. TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM - AUSTRALIA (02): (TASMANIA), REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n n., a\nnew member of the Pasteurella Group of bacteria, naturally pathogenic\nfor the muskrat (_Ondatra zibethica_). Date: Tue 8 Nov 2011\nSource: Robert Spencer\n<Robert.Spencer@UHBristol.nhs.uk>\n\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1989-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:16"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Novicida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bristol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "873932", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, feline - USA: (IL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=873932", "date": "2011-09-16 11:55:40", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, FELINE - USA: (ILLINOIS)\n***********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 14 Sep 2011\nSource: The News-Gazette [edited]\nhttp://www.news-gazette.com/news/health/miscellaneous/2011-09-14/cats-savoy-test-positive-rabbit-fever.html\n\n\nThree cats from 2 households in Savoy have tested positive for\ntularemia, or 'rabbit fever,' an infectious disease that has been\nrelatively rare in Illinois.\n\nThe Champaign-Urbana Public Health District said the cats were\ndiagnosed in July and September [2011] at the University of Illinois\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine.\n\nThe 3 cases could indicate an increased concern for the disease in the\narea, health officials warned.\n\nTularemia is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially\nrodents, rabbits, and hares, and cats may become infected by preying\non those animals or through tick exposure, according to the health\ndistrict.\n\nInfected cats may have a high fever, mouth ulcers, depression,\nenlarged lymph nodes, and behavioral changes that include not wanting\nto eat. Cats that have been outdoors and are showing these symptoms\nneed veterinary care.\n\nPeople can become infected by handling pets or wild animals with\ntularemia, or by being bitten by ticks or inhaling the organism,\nhealth officials said. Symptoms of the disease in people include\nsudden fever, chills, diarrhea, joint pain, muscle aches, cough, and\nweakness. If you have those symptoms, see your doctor for treatment.\n\nTips to avoid tularemia from the health district:\n- Don't allow your cat to hunt outdoors.\n- Make sure your cat is protected from tick bites.\n- Report any large die-offs of rodents or rabbits to local animal\ncontrol officials.\n- Wear tick protection outdoors.\n- Don't handle or mow over sick or dead animals.\n- Cook wild game meat thoroughly before eating it and use gloves when\nhandling it beforehand.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Illinois can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1f33. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_ , is a non\nsporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related\nto _Brucella_ spp. It is a facultative intracellular parasite that is\nkilled rapidly by heat and proper disinfection but survives for weeks\nor months in a moist environment. It is fastidious in growth but can\nbe cultured readily. There are 2 types of organisms based on their\nbiochemistry and virulence. Type A has been found predominantly in\nNorth America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may\nbe 5-7 percent if untreated. Type B is less virulent and is most\ncommonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections\nin North America and Eurasia. Both types have been isolated from\narthropod vectors.\n\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary host, but clinical\ninfection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at\nincreased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an\nincreased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little\nis known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in\ndomestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and\njackrabbits, beaver, muskrat, meadow voles, and sheep in North\nAmerica, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and\nAsia.\n\nTularemia is a classic zoonosis, capable of being transmitted by\naerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of\naerosolized organisms (as in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in\nan act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact\nwith, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as,\ncottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular,\noropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal\nform. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in\ninfection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection\ntransstadially and transovarially, which makes them an efficient\nreservoir as well as a vector. Recognized vectors in the USA include\n_Dermacentor andersoni_ (the wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (the\nlone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (the dog tick), and\n_Chrysops discalis_ (the deer fly).\n\nThe most common source of infection for people and herbivores is the\nbite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat\nimproperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats,\nand other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an\ninfected carcass. A few case reports have implicated cats as a source\nof infection in people. Bites from cats may transmit the disease to\npeople.\n\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals, the\ndisease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy,\nanorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with\nsepticemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased.\nCoughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria may develop. Prostration and death\nmay occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best recognized\nby signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may have up to 15\npercent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\n\nPeople may develop different clinical signs of the disease depending\non how they are exposed to tularemia. Possible symptoms include skin\nulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen\nand painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. If the bacteria\nare inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever,\nchills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive\nweakness. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing,\nwhich may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum,\nand respiratory failure. Tularemia can be fatal if the person is not\ntreated with appropriate antibiotics.\n\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases\n(especially plague) or acute pneumonia.\n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are\neffective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and\nchloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early\ntreatment should prevent death loss. Control is difficult and is\nlimited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and\ntreatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms\nare intracellular. Use of a vaccine previously available for people at\nhigh risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently\nunder review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from\nhttp://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm.\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "TULAREMIA, FELINE - USA: (ILLINOIS)\n***********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nTularemia is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially\nrodents, rabbits, and hares, and cats may become infected by preying\non those animals or through tick exposure, according to the health\ndistrict. In sheep and most mammals, the\ndisease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy,\nanorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with\nsepticemic disease. Recognized vectors in the USA include\n_Dermacentor andersoni_ (the wood tick), _Amblyomma americanum_ (the\nlone star tick), _Dermacentor variabilis_ (the dog tick), and\n_Chrysops discalis_ (the deer fly). with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as,\ncottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular,\noropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal\nform. If the bacteria\nare inhaled, signs can include abrupt onset of headache, fever,\nchills, a dry cough, muscle aches, joint pain, and progressive\nweakness. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and\njackrabbits, beaver, muskrat, meadow voles, and sheep in North\nAmerica, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and\nAsia. \n\nThe most common source of infection for people and herbivores is the\nbite of an infected tick, but persons who dress, prepare, or eat\nimproperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. \n\nPeople can become infected by handling pets or wild animals with\ntularemia, or by being bitten by ticks or inhaling the organism,\nhealth officials said. \n\nInfected cats may have a high fever, mouth ulcers, depression,\nenlarged lymph nodes, and behavioral changes that include not wanting\nto eat. Symptoms of the disease in people include\nsudden fever, chills, diarrhea, joint pain, muscle aches, cough, and\nweakness. \n\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are\neffective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and\nchloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. http://www.news-gazette.com/news/health/miscellaneous/2011-09-14/cats-savoy-test-positive-rabbit-fever.html\n\n\nThree cats from 2 households in Savoy have tested positive for\ntularemia, or 'rabbit fever,' an infectious disease that has been\nrelatively rare in Illinois. Possible symptoms include skin\nulcers, red and inflamed eyes, a sore throat, mouth sores, and swollen\nand painful lymph glands, diarrhea, and/or pneumonia. \n\n[The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_ , is a non\nsporulating, Gram negative coccobacillus that is antigenically related\nto _Brucella_ spp. Cats are at\nincreased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an\nincreased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Use of a vaccine previously available for people at\nhigh risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently\nunder review. Dogs, cats,\nand other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an\ninfected carcass. Little\nis known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in\ndomestic animals. People with pneumonia may already have difficulty breathing,\nwhich may be made worse, and can develop chest pain, bloody sputum,\nand respiratory failure. Type B is less virulent and is most\ncommonly isolated from aquatic animals and water-associated infections\nin North America and Eurasia. Type A has been found predominantly in\nNorth America and is more virulent; in people, the mortality rate may\nbe 5-7 percent if untreated.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2011-09-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "905396", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA: (DE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=905396", "date": "2011-10-11 13:38:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA: (DELAWARE)\n***************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 7 Oct 2011\nSource: Delaware Health and Social Services (DHSS) [edited]\nhttp://dhss.delaware.gov/dhss/pressreleases/2011/tulameria-100711.html\n\n\nOn Thu 6 Oct 2011, the Delaware Public Health [DPH] Laboratory\nconfirmed Delaware's 1st case of tularemia since 2003, in a 45\nyear-old Kent County man. The man is hospitalized and responding to\ntreatment. Although Delaware has not reported a case of tularemia in 8\nyears, each year an estimated 125 to 150 cases are reported\nnationwide.\n\nTularemia is associated with tick bites and is not spread person to\nperson. Domestic cats are very susceptible to tularemia and have been\nknown to transmit the bacteria to humans. Humans can become infected\nby handling infected animal tissue when hunting or skinning infected\nrabbits, muskrats, and other rodents; by inhaling dust or aerosols\ncontaminated with the bacteria, such as during farming or landscaping\nactivities, especially when tractors or mowers run over an infected\nanimal or carcass. The disease can also be transmitted by drinking\nuntreated water contaminated with the bacteria introduced by animal\ncontact.\n\nSymptoms of tularemia usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure to the\nbacteria, but can take as long as 14 days. Symptoms may include sudden\nfever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry\ncough, and progressive weakness. People can also develop pneumonia\nwith chest pain, cough, and difficulty breathing. Other symptoms of\ntularemia depend upon how the person was exposed. These symptoms can\ninclude ulcers on the skin or in the mouth, swollen and painful lymph\nglands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat.\n\n'Preventing tick bites is the best way to protect yourself from\ntularemia,' said Dr Karyl Rattay, DPH director. 'Use insect repellent\ncontaining DEET on your skin, or treat clothing with repellent\ncontaining permethrin, to prevent insect bites.' In addition, use care\nand wear gloves when handling sick or dead animals. Be sure to cook\nfood thoroughly and that your water is from a safe source. Note any\nchange in the behavior of your pets (especially rodents and rabbits)\nor livestock, and consult a veterinarian if they develop unusual\nsymptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals\nsuch as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella\ntularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of\nsurviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or\ndecaying plant and animal matter. Although hundreds of differing\nvertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia\nbacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology.\nHumans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites\nof infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling\ninfected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and\ninhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will dictate the\nform of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures usually\nresulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of\ndisease in this case is not stated.\n\nThe last reported cases of the infection in the mid-Atlantic state of\nDelaware occurred in 2003 and was reported that year (Eppes SC:\nTularemia in Delaware: forgotten but not gone. Del Med J. 2003; 75(4):\n137-41). In the period of 10 years from 2001-2010, 5 cases of\ntularemia were reported in Delaware with 3 in 2003, and 1 each in 2001\nand 2002. In the 10 year period, 1208 cases were reported in the USA\nwith 585 (48 percent) occurring in only 4 states: Missouri (231),\nArkansas (162), Oklahoma (108), and Massachusetts (84). Except for\nMassachusetts, the other 3 states are located in the central USA. Many\nof the Massachusetts cases are reported from Martha's Vineyard where\npneumonic tularemia in gardeners and landscapers is not uncommon. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[The state of Delaware can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at http://healthmap.org/r/1kc*. Kent County can be\nseen on the map at\nhttp://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/delaware.shtml. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Humans can become infected\nby handling infected animal tissue when hunting or skinning infected\nrabbits, muskrats, and other rodents; by inhaling dust or aerosols\ncontaminated with the bacteria, such as during farming or landscaping\nactivities, especially when tractors or mowers run over an infected\nanimal or carcass. TULAREMIA - USA: (DELAWARE)\n***************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Humans become infected through a variety of mechanisms including bites\nof infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks, deerflies), handling\ninfected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food or water, and\ninhaling aerosols of bacteria. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals\nsuch as voles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella\ntularensis_ is found in a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of\nsurviving for weeks at low temperatures in water, moist soil, or Note any\nchange in the behavior of your pets (especially rodents and rabbits)\nor livestock, and consult a veterinarian if they develop unusual\nsymptoms. In the period of 10 years from 2001-2010, 5 cases of\ntularemia were reported in Delaware with 3 in 2003, and 1 each in 2001\nand 2002. Although Delaware has not reported a case of tularemia in 8\nyears, each year an estimated 125 to 150 cases are reported\nnationwide. On Thu 6 Oct 2011, the Delaware Public Health [DPH] Laboratory\nconfirmed Delaware's 1st case of tularemia since 2003, in a 45\nyear-old Kent County man. The disease can also be transmitted by drinking\nuntreated water contaminated with the bacteria introduced by animal\ncontact. Although hundreds of differing\nvertebrates and invertebrates can be infected with the tularemia\nbacillus, no more than a dozen or so are important in its ecology. Many\nof the Massachusetts cases are reported from Martha's Vineyard where\npneumonic tularemia in gardeners and landscapers is not uncommon. Use insect repellent\ncontaining DEET on your skin, or treat clothing with repellent\ncontaining permethrin, to prevent insect bites.' These symptoms can\ninclude ulcers on the skin or in the mouth, swollen and painful lymph\nglands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-10-06 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kent County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "75(4", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "788199", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, wildlife - France: (PC) hare", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=788199", "date": "2011-07-15 13:43:17", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - FRANCE: (PAS-DE-CALAIS) HARE\n**************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 14 Jul 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16 (28) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19913\n\n\nOutbreak of tularaemia in brown hares (_Lepus europaeus_) in France,\nJanuary to March 2011\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Author's: Decors A, Lesage C, Jourdain E, et al]\n\n[From the cited paper, we present the introduction and conclusion\nchapters; for the complete article, including outbreak description,\nepidemiological investigation, and references, please refer to the\nsource URL above. - Mod.AS]\n\nIntroduction and outbreak description\n-------------------------------------\nTularaemia is a cosmopolitan bacterial zoonosis caused by\n_Francisella tularensis_. This gram-negative bacterium contains\nseveral highly pathogenic subspecies, whose distribution is ubiquitous\nin the northern hemisphere. Because of its pathogenic potential,\ntularaemia is a notifiable bacterial zoonosis in France, and is listed\nas potential bioterrorist weapon. The bacterium has very complex\nepidemiological cycles, including many wild species, whose\nepidemiological role is sometimes unclear. Namely, _F. tularensis_ has\nbeen isolated from more than 250 species, including 190 mammals, 88\ninvertebrates, 23 birds, 3 amphibians, as well as several species of\nreptiles and fishes, and 2 disease cycles, terrestrial and aquatic\nhave been described. The interaction between these 2 cycles remains\nnot well known. In general, the disease cycle involves only few key\nspecies in a given region. In the terrestrial cycle in France, the\nEuropean brown hare plays an important role in the ecology of\ntularaemia as amplifying host, and it may serve as a significant\nsource of human infection. Hare tularaemia has been reported in most\nof the departments in France, but endemic areas have been described in\nthe northern part of France. A recent increase in cases in hares has\nbeen observed in 2007 and 2008. At the same time, during the winter,\nan excess of human cases has been reported (144 sporadic cases from 1\nJan 2007 to 31 Dec 2008, including 48 cases in 2007 and 96 in 2008,\nagainst a mean of 23 cases per year for the period 2003 to 2006), but\nthe factors responsible for this increase have not been identified.\n\nAlthough tularaemia is often fatal to hares, hare tularaemia in\nFrance is usually sporadic and does not significantly affect hare\npopulations. We report here an outbreak of tularaemia in brown hares\nin France, which occurred in Pas-de-Calais from January to March 2011\nand was characterised by a high mortality rate in the local hare\npopulation. The epizootic form of the outbreak reported here raised\nmany epidemiological questions and led us to reconsider the potential\nassociated risks for hare populations and public health.\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThe outbreak ended in late March 2011 and the epidemiological field\ninvestigations, performed in the middle of March have been unable to\nidentify a source of infection, although they were conducted at a time\nwhen hare mortality was still observed. Molecular typing of the\nisolates recovered from collected hare carcasses and ticks will\nhopefully help us understand the origin of this outbreak by\ndetermining whether it was related to the focus (one case) reported at\na distance of 10 km [6.2 mi] in 2007. Indeed, it is highly important\nto determine whether the epizootic form of this outbreak was due (i)\nto the emergence of a novel _F. tularensis_ strain, (ii) to the fact\nthat the hare population was unusually abundant, in which case the\noutbreak may have been a density-dependent phenomenon, or (iii) to\nparticular ecologic circumstances favouring hare-to-hare transmission,\nsince the outbreak occurred during periods of frost (which may have\nled the hares to take refuge in the woods) and coincided with the\nmating season (when hares are immunosuppressed and in close contact\nwith each other). Further studies are planned, including histology and\nsurveillance of ticks and rodents, to gain knowledge on the\ntransmission route and on the maintenance of a disease in the area.\n\nThe epizootic focus will be carefully surveyed this year [2011] and\nhunters, people walking in the forest, and physicians will be warned\nthat a potential risk of disease transmission exists in the area,\nrespectively by the departmental federation of hunters involved in the\nSAGIR [surveillance of wildlife diseases] network, local authorities,\nand the regional agency of health. We wish to warn wildlife managers\nthat aggregated cases of hare mortality may be due to _F. tularensis_\nand that systematic precautions should be taken to make sure that\nhumans do not contract the disease. Human tularaemia is usually\nsporadic in France even if aggregate cases have been described.\nInfected ticks like those found alive on dead hares may become a\nreservoir in the area, thus the potential for human infection is now\nhigher than it was. As the wood is highly frequented, tularaemia\nshould be considered in the area as a diagnosis, particularly in\npeople with contact with hares or ticks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The timeline of the epidemiological investigation in France is\navailable at\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/images/dynamic/EE/V16N28/Decor_Fig.jpg.\n\nTularemia, an OIE notifiable disease, is a zoonosis caused by\n_Francisella tularensis_. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits\nand hares) and rodents, especially microtine rodents such as voles,\nvole rats, and muskrats, as well as in beavers. In addition, a wide\nvariety of other mammals, birds, amphibians, and invertebrates have\nbeen reported to be infected.\n\nTularemia occurs endemically in the Northern Hemisphere. The disease\ncan occur as epizootic outbreaks in many countries in North America\nand Europe, while it occurs only as sporadic cases in some other\ncountries in Europe and Asia. It is rarely reported from the tropics\nor the Southern Hemisphere. Several epizootic outbreaks have been\nreported as a result of importation of subclinically infected\nlagomorphs.\n\nThe clinically most relevant 2 types of _F. tularensis_ are\nrecognised on the basis of culture characteristics, epidemiology, and\nvirulence. _Francisella tularensis_ subsp. _tularensis_ (type A) is\nmainly associated with lagomorphs in North America. It is primarily\ntransmitted by ticks or biting flies, or by direct contact with\ninfected lagomorphs. It is highly virulent for humans and domestic\nrabbits and most isolates ferment glycerol. _F. tularensis_ subsp.\n_palaearctica_ (type B) occurs mainly in aquatic rodents (beavers,\nmuskrats) and voles in northern North America, and in lagomorphs\n(hares) and rodents in Eurasia. It is primarily transmitted by direct\ncontact or by mosquitoes, but may be transmitted through inhalation or\nthrough infected water or food. It is less virulent for humans and\ndomestic rabbits and does not ferment glycerol. The information above\nis primarily based upon chapter 2.1.18 of OIE's Terrestrial Manual\nfrom which additional information, particularly addressing diagnostic\ntechniques, is accessible at\nhttp://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "Indeed, it is highly important\nto determine whether the epizootic form of this outbreak was due (i)\nto the emergence of a novel _F. tularensis_ strain, (ii) to the fact\nthat the hare population was unusually abundant, in which case the\noutbreak may have been a density-dependent phenomenon, or (iii) to\nparticular ecologic circumstances favouring hare-to-hare transmission,\nsince the outbreak occurred during periods of frost (which may have\nled the hares to take refuge in the woods) and coincided with the\nmating season (when hares are immunosuppressed and in close contact\nwith each other). \n\nThe epizootic focus will be carefully surveyed this year [2011] and\nhunters, people walking in the forest, and physicians will be warned\nthat a potential risk of disease transmission exists in the area,\nrespectively by the departmental federation of hunters involved in the\nSAGIR [surveillance of wildlife diseases] network, local authorities,\nand the regional agency of health. Molecular typing of the\nisolates recovered from collected hare carcasses and ticks will\nhopefully help us understand the origin of this outbreak by\ndetermining whether it was related to the focus (one case) reported at\na distance of 10 km [6.2 mi] in 2007. The information above\nis primarily based upon chapter 2.1.18 of OIE's Terrestrial Manual\nfrom which additional information, particularly addressing diagnostic\ntechniques, is accessible at\nhttp://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.18_TULAREMIA.pdf. We report here an outbreak of tularaemia in brown hares\nin France, which occurred in Pas-de-Calais from January to March 2011\nand was characterised by a high mortality rate in the local hare\npopulation. The outbreak ended in late March 2011 and the epidemiological field\ninvestigations, performed in the middle of March have been unable to\nidentify a source of infection, although they were conducted at a time\nwhen hare mortality was still observed. We wish to warn wildlife managers\nthat aggregated cases of hare mortality may be due to _F. tularensis_\nand that systematic precautions should be taken to make sure that\nhumans do not contract the disease. The disease\ncan occur as epizootic outbreaks in many countries in North America\nand Europe, while it occurs only as sporadic cases in some other\ncountries in Europe and Asia. As the wood is highly frequented, tularaemia\nshould be considered in the area as a diagnosis, particularly in\npeople with contact with hares or ticks. It occurs naturally in lagomorphs (rabbits\nand hares) and rodents, especially microtine rodents such as voles,\nvole rats, and muskrats, as well as in beavers. Infected ticks like those found alive on dead hares may become a\nreservoir in the area, thus the potential for human infection is now\nhigher than it was.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-12-31 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pas - de - Calais", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "817486", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, pneumonic - Taiwan: (Taipei) ex USA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=817486", "date": "2011-08-12 10:49:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - TAIWAN: (TAIPEI) ex USA\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 22 Jul 2011\nSource: Taipei Times, Central News Agency (CNA) report [edited]\nhttp://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2011/07/22/2003508859\n\n\nThe Taiwan Department of Health (DOH) on 21 Jul 2011 reported its 1st\nimported case of tularemia since 2007.\n\nThe patient, a 67 year old United States citizen from San Francisco,\nCalifornia, showed symptoms of fever before flying to Taiwan on 26 Jun\n2011. The man was confirmed to have the disease on Mon 18 Jul 2011,\nafter being admitted to a Taipei hospital for fever, pneumonia, and a\nbuild-up of fluid in his lungs, Centers for Disease Control (CDC)\ndeputy director Shih Wen-yi said in a press release. However, he was\nexpected to be released from the hospital soon.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease, meaning it is transmitted from\nanimals to humans and cannot be transmitted from human to human. The\ndisease is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which is\nfound in various types of fowl, fish, rodents, and mammals, which can\nbe spread through bites, inhalation, or direct contact.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not apparently related to bioterrorism in this case,\ntularemia is a category A bioterrorism agent and the pneumonic form is\nlikely to be the one associated with intentional spread. The\ncircumstances of exposure in this case are not stated.\n\nTularemia is caused by _F. tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram\nnegative intracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of\nanimal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents\n(muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood\nrats and mice), squirrels, and cats. In the United States an outbreak\ninvolving commercially distributed prairie dogs occurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and\nvegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental\nconditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as,\n_Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may\nrepresent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental\nexposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with\ninfectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion\nof contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective\naerosols. In one case, bacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog\nas it shook itself off after entering a home. Finally, there are\nseveral reports of tularemia in humans following bites from infected\ndomestic cats. It is highly infectious, with as few as 10 organisms\nneeded to cause disease. Humans can develop severe and sometimes fatal\nillness, but do not transmit the disease to others. The typical\nincubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of one to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of\nexposure. Airborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause\npleuropneumonitis. Exposures that penetrate broken skin result in\nulceroglandular or glandular disease. The onset of tularemia is\nusually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized\nbody aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza, and sore throat.\nNausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever, chills,\nprogressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss characterize\nthe continuing illness. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and\nvegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental\nconditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as,\n_Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may\nrepresent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental\nexposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with\ninfectious animal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion\nof contaminated food, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective\naerosols. TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - TAIWAN: (TAIPEI) ex USA\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The\ndisease is caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which is\nfound in various types of fowl, fish, rodents, and mammals, which can\nbe spread through bites, inhalation, or direct contact. The man was confirmed to have the disease on Mon 18 Jul 2011,\nafter being admitted to a Taipei hospital for fever, pneumonia, and a\nbuild-up of fluid in his lungs, Centers for Disease Control (CDC)\ndeputy director Shih Wen-yi said in a press release. It can be found in a variety of\nanimal hosts, notably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents\n(muskrats, beavers, and water voles), other rodents (water and wood\nrats and mice), squirrels, and cats. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not apparently related to bioterrorism in this case,\ntularemia is a category A bioterrorism agent and the pneumonic form is\nlikely to be the one associated with intentional spread. \n\nThe patient, a 67 year old United States citizen from San Francisco,\nCalifornia, showed symptoms of fever before flying to Taiwan on 26 Jun\n2011. The onset of tularemia is\nusually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and rigors, generalized\nbody aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza, and sore throat.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-07-21 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-07-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taipei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1290255", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, possum, 2011 - Australia: (TS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1290255", "date": "2012-09-14 13:51:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM, 2011 - AUSTRALIA: (TASMANIA)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Sep 2012\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases [edited]\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/9/11-1856_article.htm\n\n\nTularemia is a zoonosis affecting a wide range of wildlife species, including mammals, birds, amphibians, and arthropods (1,2). 3 subspecies of _Francisella tularensis_ have been recognized as causes of disease in humans: ssp. _tularensis_ (type A tularemia), ssp. _holarctica_ (type B tularemia), and ssp. _novicida_. Type B tularemia is endemic to the Northern Hemisphere, and cases predominately occur in latitudes 30 degrees N-71 degrees N (1,2). We report a case of ulceroglandular tularemia in a human in Tasmania, Australia (latitude 42 degrees S) who was bitten by a ringtail possum (_Pseudocheirus peregrinus_)\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/9/11-1856-f1.htm.\n\nThe case\n--------\nIn February 2011, a 44-year-old woman was bitten on her right index finger by a wild ringtail possum near the Henty River on the western coast of Tasmania. The incident occurred in daylight, and the possum, normally nocturnal, appeared lethargic and unwell. The patient was immunocompetent and had never traveled outside of Australia.\n\n3 days later, an ulcer developed at the site of the bite, followed by the development of swollen and tender epitrochlear lymph nodes, fever, rigors, myalgias, and drenching night sweats. On day 4, the patient was prescribed oral beta-lactam antimicrobial drugs by her local doctor. She took these for 2 weeks without clinical improvement. Axillary lymphadenopathy was palpable on day 14, and by day 17 the epitrochlear nodes had formed a spontaneously discharging sinus. A swab sample was collected from the primary ulcer site on day 17. No organisms grew after a 48-hr incubation at 36 degrees C in the following culture media: blood agar in ambient air, MacConkey agar in ambient air, and chocolate agar in 5 percent CO2. The patient's antimicrobial drug regimen was altered empirically to ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice a day and amoxicillin/clavulanic acid 875 mg/125 mg twice a day for the next 4 weeks. Despite mild improvement in symptoms, epitrochlear and axillary lymphadenitis with suppuration persisted. Swab samples collected for fungal and mycobacterial culture from the epitrochlear sinus on day 30 were culture negative. On day 47, the patient was referred to the Royal Hobart Hospital in Tasmania. Histology from an excisional biopsy of the epitrochlear sinus on day 50 revealed acute inflammation and a few non-necrotizing epithelioid granulomas. This tissue and an axillary lymph node aspirate were sent to a reference laboratory for molecular studies.\n\nIn the reference laboratory, the 16S rRNA gene was amplified from the axillary aspirate by using primers targeting the U1, U3, and U5 regions. The resulting 1,331-bp amplicon (GenBank accession no. JQ277265) demonstrated 100 percent homology with 16S rRNA gene sequences from _F. tularensis ssp. tularensis_ and _holarctica_ stored in GenBank. PCR and sequencing of the recA gene (3) confirmed _F. tularensis_ (GenBank accession no. JQ277266). Amplicons of 16S rRNA and recA genes were aligned with reference sequences from the GenBank/European Molecular Biology Laboratory/DNA DataBank of Japan databases and with sequences from 2 previous _Francisella spp_. reported from Australia (4). The 16S rRNA and recA gene sequences showed 100 percent query coverage and an Expect value of 0.00 in BLASTn (http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) with 36 submissions of _F. tularensis_ genomes (Figure 2 [see original URL for the figure]). The unrooted bootstrap consensus tree generated from sequence alignment of the recA gene sequence, coupled with the neighbor-joining method, suggested homology between _F. tularensis ssp. holarctica_ and the organism responsible for this patient's illness. Sequencing of the region of difference 1 (5) by using previously validated primers (3) indicated the region of difference 1 size was 835 bp, closely approximating the 840-bp size associated with _F. tularensis ssp. holarctica_ biovar _japonica_.\n\nLymph node aspirate from the patient cultured in horse blood and in blood cysteine and chocolate media with and without supplement (BBL IsoVitaleX Enrichment; Becton, Dickinson and Co., Sparks, MD, USA) produced no growth after 2 weeks of incubation (37 degrees C, 5 percent CO2); the control strain of _F. tularensis_ live vaccine strain grew within 3 days. We used reagents and protocols from the Laboratory Response Network, US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, to perform real-time PCR for _F. tularensis_. The procedure amplified 2 of 3 targets (FT2 and FT3). IgG and IgM against _F. tularensis_ antigens were detected by use of ELISA (Virion-Serion, Wurzburg, Germany) in serum obtained 2 months after the onset of symptoms in concentrations of 147.13 and 222.74 U/mL, respectively (positive cutoff >15 U/mL). Confirmatory serology for _F. tularensis_ was performed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention vector-borne diseases laboratory (Fort Collins, CO, USA) on serum samples collected 56 and 75 days after symptom onset. Both specimens were positive for _F. tularensis_, evidenced by a microagglutination titer of 128 (positive cutoff greater than 128). On the basis of these results, the patient was treated with a 14-day course of intravenous gentamicin. Her symptoms resolved promptly, and the woman remained well at a 6-month follow-up visit.\n\nThis case demonstrates the well-recognized features of _F. tularensis ssp. holarctica_ infection as described from the Northern Hemisphere. The mode of transmission, incubation period, clinical syndrome, lack of response to beta-lactam antimicrobial drugs, and response to aminoglycoside therapy are all characteristic of type B tularemia (6). Although a clinical response to ciprofloxacin could have been expected, treatment failures have been reported when initiation of therapy is delayed (7). The lack of growth on blood and chocolate agar is also consistent with ssp. _holarctica_ and contrasts with ssp. _novicida_ and _F. philomiragia_ (4,6). The inability to culture an organism on specialized media probably was caused by prolonged ciprofloxacin treatment before the specific culture attempt. This case met the definition for probable tularemia according to the 2007 WHO guidelines (8); however, the combination of clinical, serologic, and molecular evidence strongly supports the diagnosis of infection with _F. tularensis ssp. holarctica_. This conclusion is consistent with recent reports of tularemia in which case definitions included a compatible clinical syndrome and positive _F. tularensis_ real-time PCR or DNA sequencing (9,10).\n\nCases of human infection with other Francisella species have been reported from Australia (4). _F. philomiragia_ was isolated from a lymph node in a child in Victoria with chronic granulomatous disease, and a novicida-like organism was cultured from the toe of a 53-year-old man after a cut received in brackish water in the Northern Territory. In contrast to type A and B tularemia, these organisms are rare human pathogens and are not associated with arthropod vectors or animal hosts.\n\nMore than 300 species of mammals, birds, invertebrates, and amphibians are currently recognized as being susceptible to type B tularemia (1). This report adds the ringtail possum, found widely throughout Australia, to the list of species that are susceptible to tularemia and have transmitted this pathogen to humans. Although transmission of tularemia is most often associated with species from the orders Lagomorpha and Rodentia, human infection following contact with marsupials has long been recognized. Within the USA, opossum-to-human transmission was described as early as 1929 (11).\n\nThe discovery of _F. tularensis_ in this remote location of Australia raises questions about possible routes of spread and natural reservoirs of tularemia. Tularemia has emerged several times in nonendemic areas after the importation of infected wildlife (12) or changes in ecologic and climate conditions (13), or in settings of postwar social disruption (14); but no such recent events have occurred in Tasmania. An alternate possibility is introduction of tularemia to Australia by water birds migrating from Southeast Asia that, if infected, have the potential to contaminate surface waters with _F. tularensis_ (15).\n\nConclusions\n-----------\nThis case provides evidence of type B tularemia in Australia and should alert physicians and veterinarians working within the region to the possibility of infection with this organism. The transmission of _F. tularensis_ to a human host after the bite of an animal native to Australia suggests an ecologic niche for this bacterium in the forests of western Tasmania. Further research is necessary to elucidate the role that ringtail possums, small mammals, ticks, tabanid flies, and mosquitoes prevalent in this unique location might play as natural reservoirs for and vectors of _F. tularensis_.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n 3 subspecies of _Francisella tularensis_ have been recognized as causes of disease in humans: ssp. _tularensis_ (type A tularemia), ssp. _holarctica_ (type B tularemia), and ssp. _novicida_. \n\nLymph node aspirate from the patient cultured in horse blood and in blood cysteine and chocolate media with and without supplement (BBL IsoVitaleX Enrichment; Becton, Dickinson and Co., Sparks, MD, USA) produced no growth after 2 weeks of incubation (37 degrees C, 5 percent CO2); the control strain of _F. tularensis_ live vaccine strain grew within 3 days. TULAREMIA, HUMAN, POSSUM, 2011 - AUSTRALIA: (TASMANIA)\n******************************************************\n Broekhuijsen M, Larsson P, Johansson A, Bystrom M, Eriksson U, Larsson E, Genome-wide DNA microarray analysis of Francisella tularensis strains demonstrates extensive genetic conservation within the species but identifies regions that are unique to the highly virulent F. tularensis subsp. tularensis. Sequencing of the region of difference 1 (5) by using previously validated primers (3) indicated the region of difference 1 size was 835 bp, closely approximating the 840-bp size associated with _F. tularensis ssp. This conclusion is consistent with recent reports of tularemia in which case definitions included a compatible clinical syndrome and positive _F. tularensis_ real-time PCR or DNA sequencing (9,10). References\n----------\n1. \n\nThe discovery of _F. tularensis_ in this remote location of Australia raises questions about possible routes of spread and natural reservoirs of tularemia. An alternate possibility is introduction of tularemia to Australia by water birds migrating from Southeast Asia that, if infected, have the potential to contaminate surface waters with _F. tularensis_ (15). LL]\n\n[Ringtail possum (_Pseudocheirus peregrinus_) photo:\nhttp://www.allareaspossumremoval.com.au/web_images/ringtail.jpg - Mod. No organisms grew after a 48-hr incubation at 36 degrees C in the following culture media: blood agar in ambient air, MacConkey agar in ambient air, and chocolate agar in 5 percent CO2. The resulting 1,331-bp amplicon (GenBank accession no. JQ277265) demonstrated 100 percent homology with 16S rRNA gene sequences from _F. tularensis ssp. The 16S rRNA and recA gene sequences showed 100 percent query coverage and an Expect value of 0.00 in BLASTn (http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) with 36 submissions of _F. tularensis_ genomes (Figure 2 [see original URL for the figure]). IgG and IgM against _F. tularensis_ antigens were detected by use of ELISA (Virion-Serion, Wurzburg, Germany) in serum obtained 2 months after the onset of symptoms in concentrations of 147.13 and 222.74 U/mL, respectively (positive cutoff >15 U/mL). Although transmission of tularemia is most often associated with species from the orders Lagomorpha and Rodentia, human infection following contact with marsupials has long been recognized. The patient's antimicrobial drug regimen was altered empirically to ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice a day and amoxicillin/clavulanic acid 875 mg/125 mg twice a day for the next 4 weeks. The unrooted bootstrap consensus tree generated from sequence alignment of the recA gene sequence, coupled with the neighbor-joining method, suggested homology between _F. tularensis ssp. Further research is necessary to elucidate the role that ringtail possums, small mammals, ticks, tabanid flies, and mosquitoes prevalent in this unique location might play as natural reservoirs for and vectors of _F. tularensis_. This case provides evidence of type B tularemia in Australia and should alert physicians and veterinarians working within the region to the possibility of infection with this organism. \n\n3 days later, an ulcer developed at the site of the bite, followed by the development of swollen and tender epitrochlear lymph nodes, fever, rigors, myalgias, and drenching night sweats. Confirmatory serology for _F. tularensis_ was performed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention vector-borne diseases laboratory (Fort Collins, CO, USA) on serum samples collected 56 and 75 days after symptom onset. The transmission of _F. tularensis_ to a human host after the bite of an animal native to Australia suggests an ecologic niche for this bacterium in the forests of western Tasmania. Tularemia has emerged several times in nonendemic areas after the importation of infected wildlife (12) or changes in ecologic and climate conditions (13), or in settings of postwar social disruption (14); but no such recent events have occurred in Tasmania. \n\nConclusions\n In contrast to type A and B tularemia, these organisms are rare human pathogens and are not associated with arthropod vectors or animal hosts. http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/9/11-1856_article.htm\n\n\nTularemia is a zoonosis affecting a wide range of wildlife species, including mammals, birds, amphibians, and arthropods (1,2). This report adds the ringtail possum, found widely throughout Australia, to the list of species that are susceptible to tularemia and have transmitted this pathogen to humans. \n\nCases of human infection with other Francisella species have been reported from Australia (4). Type B tularemia is endemic to the Northern Hemisphere, and cases predominately occur in latitudes 30 degrees N-71 degrees N (1,2). DOIExternal Web Site IconPubMedExternal Web Site Icon\n10. Amplicons of 16S rRNA and recA genes were aligned with reference sequences from the GenBank/European Molecular Biology Laboratory/DNA DataBank of Japan databases and with sequences from 2 previous _Francisella spp_. reported from Australia (4).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1955-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:16", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1959-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Francisella", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Becton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cooley L", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wurzburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sparks", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tasmania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Northern Territory", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dedushaj", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "469107", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, animal - USA: (CO) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=469107", "date": "2010-07-18 11:00:03", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, ANIMAL - USA: (COLORADO) FELINE\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 17 Jul 2010\nSource: KRDO.com [edited]\n<http://www.krdo.com/news/24294091/detail.html>\n\n\nA cat in Pueblo West tested positive for tularemia, a potentially\nserious illness that can be passed on to humans. The Health\nDepartment said the cat was an indoor/outdoor cat, and officials are\nworking with the cat's owners regarding medical concerns.\n\nTularemia is a potentially serious illness caused by a bacteria found\nin animals, especially rodents, rabbits, and prairie dogs. Health\nofficials said the illness can be passed on to humans in a variety of\nways including: being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly, or other\ninsect; handling infected animal carcasses; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; breathing in the bacteria.\n\nTularemia can be fatal if it is not treated with the right\nantibiotics. Health officials said the best way to keep your pets\nsafe is to not let them roam or eat dead animals and to keep an eye\non their health.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[For background information on tularemia, see the moderator's comment\nbelow in archived ProMED-mail post 'Tularemia, wildlife - USA (02):\n(CO) beavers 20100513.1555.' - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 17 Jul 2010\n Health\nofficials said the illness can be passed on to humans in a variety of\nways including: being bitten by an infected tick, deerfly, or other\ninsect; handling infected animal carcasses; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; breathing in the bacteria. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[For background information on tularemia, see the moderator's comment\nbelow in archived ProMED-mail post 'Tularemia, wildlife - USA (02):\n(CO) beavers 20100513.1555.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "689111", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Norway (02): (central)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=689111", "date": "2011-04-01 10:21:33", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(13) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19828\n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n--------------------------------------------------------------\n>From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. The mean age was 40.3 years (range 2-89\nyears). 34 reported use of drinking water from private wells. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\n>From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway.\n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1).\n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3).\n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no).\nThis increase may in part be explained by the outbreaks mentioned\nabove.\n\nDiagnosis and clinical presentation\n-----------------------------------\nIn the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case.\n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10).\n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\nwell or a stream. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far.\nFollow-up serology has been recommended for several of the persons\nexposed to some of the putative water sources.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nThe current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available.\n\nThe precise mechanism of contamination of the wells with _F.\ntularensis_ is as yet unknown. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow.\n\nTularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure.\n\nThe use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. It is also important to secure the well\nfrom contamination by surface water after snow melting. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization (WHO) Epidemic and Pandemic Alert and\nResponse: WHO guidelines on tularaemia. Geneva: WHO; 2007. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases. Prague; 1-4 May 2004. [Available from\nhttp://www.blackwellpublishing.com/eccmid14/abstract.asp?id=13879].\n3. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis. 2004; 36(5): 350-5.\n[Abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15287379].\n4. Willke A, Meric M, Grunow R, et al: An outbreak of oropharyngeal\ntularaemia linked to natural spring water. J Med Microbiol. 2009;\n58(Pt 1): 112-6. [Available from\nhttp://jmm.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/full/58/1/112].\n5. Rike HF, Vigerust A, Bergh K: Vannbarent utbrudd av tularemia\n(harepest) i Midtre Gauldal. [A waterborne outbreak of tularaemia in\nMidtre-Gauldal]. Norwegian Institute of Public Health. 27 Oct 2003.\nNorwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=MainLeft_5669&MainLeft_5669=5544:27208::0:5667:1:::0:0.\n6. Brantsaeter AB, Krogh T, Radtke A, Nygard K: Tularaemia outbreak\nin northern Norway. Euro Surveill. 2007; 12(13): pii=3165. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=3165.\n7. Melien P, Holsdal RE. Tularemi i Meldal -- en vanskelig diagnose?\n[Tularaemia in Meldal- a difficult diagnosis?]. Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health. 18 Mar 2008. Norwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=Area_5626&MainArea_5661=5619:0:15,4427:1:0:0:::0:0&MainLeft_5619=5626:68396::1:5625:1:::0:0&Area_5626=5544:68400::1:5628:1:::0:0.\n8. Bevanger L, Maeland JA, Naess AI: Competitive enzyme immunoassay\nfor antibodies to a 43 000-molecular-weight _Francisella tularensis_\nouter membrane protein in the diagnosis of tularemia. J Clin\nMicrobiol. 1989; 27(5): 922-6. [Available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC267455].\n9.
