Norwegian Veterinary Institute: Flere tilfeller av harepest i\nSor-Norge [Several cases of tularaemia in South-Norway]. Norwegian\nVeterinary Institute. 25 Nov 2010. Norwegian. Available from\nhttp://www.vetinst.no/index.php/nor/Nyheter/Flere-tilfeller-av-harepest-i-Soer-Norge.\n\nReported by: Larssen KW 1/, Afset JE 1/2/, Heier BT 3/, Krogh T 4/,\nHandeland K 5/, Vik\u00f8ren T 5/, Bergh 1/,2/\n\n1/ Department of Microbiology, St Olavs Hospital, Trondheim\nUniversity Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\nHealth, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl): 68-72 (in Russian, abstract in English\navailable from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12718181).\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol. 1987; 3(1): 35-8 (abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3582597).\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Health, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim,\nNorway\n3/ Division of Infectious Disease Control, Norwegian Institute of\nPublic Health, Oslo, Norway\n4/ Division of Environmental Medicine, Norwegian Institute of Public\nHealth, Oslo, Norway\n5/Norwegian Veterinary Institute, Oslo, Norway\n\n\n--\n TULAREMIA - NORWAY (02): (CENTRAL)\n**********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n MJ]\n\n[Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3). A confirmed case was defined as a person who had\nclinical symptoms compatible with tularemia or had used drinking water\nfrom the same source as a previous case, and in whom _Francisella\ntularensis_ infection was confirmed by a laboratory test as described\nbelow. Tularemia is a notifiable\ndisease in Norway and during the past 10 years, 3 outbreaks were\nreported in Norway (5-7) and all were associated with water sources in\nareas where dead lemmings (_Lemmus lemmus_) had been observed\npreviously. However, November and December 2010\nwere unusually cold months, while in January 2011 temperatures\nincreased leading to melting of snow and possible contamination of\nprivate wells by surface water contaminated with bacteria from rodent\ncadavers or rodent excreta. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Norway can be seen at\nhttp://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png and\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0fRO. From January to March 2011, 39 cases of tularemia were diagnosed in 3\ncounties in central Norway: 21 cases of oropharyngeal type, 10 cases\nof glandular/ulceroglandular type, 2 of respiratory, and 2 of typhoid\ntype. From 1 Jan to 25 Mar 2011, 39 confirmed cases (16 female and 23 male)\nof tularemia were reported from the counties of Sor-Trondelag (28\ncases), More og Romsdal (5 cases), and Nord-Trondelag (6 cases) in\ncentral Norway. Among the\nremaining 8 tularemia cases, 2 were classified as respiratory and 2 as\ntyphoid type, while 3 were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. In existing guidelines issued by the National Institute of\nPublic Health the population is advised to boil drinking water and\ninspect the wells for dead rodents in case of suspected or confirmed\ncases of waterborne tularemia. The clinical presentation with\noropharyngeal tularemia and cervical lymphadenopathy linked to the use\nof private wells in the winter season makes contaminated water the\nmost likely source of infection in this outbreak. \n\nThe diagnosis was primarily established by serology\n(microagglutination and an in-house IgG/IgM Elisa) in 30 patients (8),\nby _F. tularensis_ specific PCR analysis in seven patients (9) and by\nblood culture (BactAlert, BioMerieux) in 2 patients. Oropharyngeal disease is commonly associated with\ncontaminated food and water, while ulceroglandular forms are more\noften seen when there has been skin contact with infected animals or\nafter insect bites (3). Years with a great increase in the rodent\npopulation are seen with intervals of about 3 to 4 years (11) and in\nthe summer and autumn of 2010, a high density of lemmings could be\nobserved in the southern and central parts of Norway. The 2 bacterial\nisolates were verified as _F. tularensis_ by PCR and sequencing of the\n16S rDNA gene, and confirmed as non-subspecies _tularensis_ by pdpA\nPCR (10). Simultaneously,\nthe Norwegian Veterinary Institute observed a wide geographical\ndistribution of fatal cases of tularemia in the mountain hare (_Lepus\ntimidus_) in these regions (12). The local health authority in each municipality\nis responsible for instituting infection control measures including\nadvice to the public and investigations of the putative drinking water\nsources. Every well owner should make the\nnecessary effort to prevent small rodents from entering the well water\nby carefully covering every opening and plugging every small hole\nwhere the rodents can enter. In Europe,\nthe infection is due to subspecies _holarctica_, which causes in\ngeneral less severe disease than subspecies _tularensis_, which is\ncommon in North America. The Norwegian Food\nSafety Authority has recently released information to the media and to\nthe general public with similar advice and information in relation to\nthe current outbreak. In the outbreak described here, the most common clinical presentation\nwas fever and pharyngitis (oropharyngeal type, 21 cases) and cervical\nlymphadenopathy (glandular/ulceroglandular type, 10 cases). From 2001 to 2010, between 3 and 66 cases of tularemia\nwere reported annually in the whole country, with an increase from 16\nto 32 cases on average (data available from http://www.msis.no). Since the incubation period for tularemia\nmay be up to 3 weeks, and time from symptoms until seroconversion\nmight be up to 6 weeks, more cases may follow. \n\nSeveral clinical forms are recognised, with oropharyngeal and\nulceroglandular disease being the most common clinical presentations\nin Norway (2). The use of small streams and private wells as a source of drinking\nwater and for other purposes in rural areas of Norway is a matter of\nconcern. Detection of _F.\ntularensis_ DNA by PCR analyses in some of the wells supports this\nassumption for some of the cases. Tomaso H, Scholz HC, Neubauer H, et al: Real-time PCR using\nhybridization probes for the rapid and specific identification of\n_Francisella tularensis_ subspecies tularensis. In case of\nproven or suspected contaminated wells, the water should be\ndisinfected before further use. The cases were geographically scattered within each county,\ninvolving 13 different municipalities, and were not linked to one\ncommon source. Use of private wells is relatively\ncommon in rural areas of Norway although exact data on such use are\nnot available. An\nincreased rodent (lemming) population and snow melting may have led to\ncontamination of the wells with infected rodents or rodent excreta. Tularemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague' and this clearly indicates rodents and hares as\ntransmitters of disease. Bevanger L, Maeland JA, Naess AI: Competitive enzyme immunoassay\nfor antibodies to a 43 000-molecular-weight _Francisella tularensis_\nouter membrane protein in the diagnosis of tularemia. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Several vectors may be involved in\ntransmitting the disease to humans, commonly rodents and hares, but\ninfection may also be transmitted via insect bites (1). Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). The mountain hare is very susceptible\nto this infection and normally dies from septicemia within a few days\nafter exposure. Available\nfrom\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/WHO_CDS_EPR_2007_7.pdf. University Hospital,Trondheim, Norway\n2/ Department of Laboratory Medicine, Children\u2019s and Women\u2019s\n \n\nOf the 39 diagnosed cases, 34 had been drinking water from a private\n 7 cases in 1\nmunicipality were linked to the same water source. 3 cases were asymptomatic and clinical information was\nunavailable for 1 case. \n\nTularemia is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _F.\ntularensis_. Willke A, Meric M, Grunow R, et al: An outbreak of oropharyngeal\ntularaemia linked to natural spring water. _F. tularensis_ DNA was detected by PCR in filtered\nwater from 5 different wells tested in Sor-Trondelag. In 2009 and 2010 4 and\n8 cases respectively were reported from central Norway. \n\nOutbreaks of oropharyngeal tularemia have previously been reported\nfrom several European countries (3,4). Apart from that,\nonly 2 cases have been confirmed to share a common well so far. In comparison, 7 cases were reported in total from\nother parts of the country in the same period. 4 _F. tularensis_ subspecies are recognized:\n_tularensis_, _holarctica_, _mediasiatica_ and _novicida_. \n\n\nOutbreak of tularemia in central Norway, January to March 2011\n The current outbreak involves a large number of municipalities in 3\ncounties in central Norway. However, this may not be feasible for\npersons who use drinking water from a stream.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "1045-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-11-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-04-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tuscany", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "South - Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Trondheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Erikson U", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Oslo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "662587", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Norway: (central)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=662587", "date": "2011-02-25 17:00:10", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - NORWAY: (CENTRAL)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 21 Feb 2011\nSource: Norwegian Institute of Public Health [in Norwegian, machine\ntrans., edited]\n<http://www.fhi.no/eway/default.aspx?pid=233&trg=MainLeft_5588&MainArea_5661=5588:0:15,1787:1:0:0:::0:0&MainLeft_5588=5544:88471::1:5569:1:::0:0>\n\n\nSo far in 2011, 13 cases of tularemia have been reported in people\nliving in 5 municipalities in More og Romsdal and Sor-Trondelag [in\ncentral Norway]. In 2010. a total of 21 cases of the disease across\nthe country were reported. Tularemia, sometimes called hare plague,\nis a bacterial disease that every few years causes local outbreaks\namong rabbits and rodents, particularly in lemmings. Humans can\nbecome infected through direct or indirect contact with sick, dead,\nor disease-carrying animals.\n\nTularemia can also be transmitted through contaminated drinking water\nwhen animal tissue has contaminated the water source. The disease can\nalso spread through the bite of such animals and by inhalation of\ndust with infected feces or urine.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The form of tularemia that occurred in these cases (that is,\nulceroglandular, oculoglandular, typhoidal, or pneumonic) is not\nstated. Although classically transmitted to man via infected animals\nsuch as rabbits or a tick vector, infection with _Francisella\ntularensis_ may be acquired from contact with soil or water harboring\nthe bacterium. Although tularemia pneumonia is the form of the\ndisease associated with biological terrorism, it may also occur\nnaturally, as is exemplified by rare sporadic cases in New York City\nand outbreaks among gardeners on Martha's Vineyard (Massachusetts).\n\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nAt present, no licensed tularemia vaccine is available in the USA.\nHowever, the LVS (live vaccine strain) vaccine is available to\nmilitary personnel under an investigational new drug protocol held by\nthe US Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases (4). It\nis administered via scarification using multiple punctures of a\nbifurcated needle. LVS is derived from strain 15 developed in the\nformer USSR and was obtained by the US military in 1956 (5). It is\nnot well standardized and contains 2 phenotypes of _F. tularensis_,\nonly one of which seems immunogenic (6). However, in studies\npublished in 1977, the vaccine was shown to significantly reduce the\nincidence of typhoidal tularemia in US government lab workers from\n5.7 to 0.27 cases per at-risk employee years (7). It did not reduce\nthe incidence of the ulceroglandular form, but the disease in\nvaccinees was reported to be milder.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan, Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl): 68-72 (in Russian, abstract in English\navailable at <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12718181>).\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol. 1987; 3(1): 35-8 (abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3582597>).\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138>).\n4. Nierengarten MB, Lutwick LI: Developing new tularemia vaccines.\nMedscape Infectious Diseases 2002; 4 (1) (available at\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/431539>).\n5. Tigertt WD: Soviet viable _Pasteurella tularensis_ vaccines.\nBacteriol Rev. 1962; 26(3): 354-73 (available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC441156/>)..\n6. Sandstrom G: The tularemia vaccine. J Chem Tech Biotechnol. 1994;\n59(4): 315-20 (abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7764815>.\n7. Burke DS: Immunization against tularemia: analysis of the\neffectiveness of live _Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention\nof laboratory-acquired tularemia. J Infect Dis. 1977; 135(1): 55-60\n(abstract available at <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/833449>)..\n\nNorway is divided into 19 counties or fylke, the counties mentioned\nin the posting are adjacent to each other and located in the central\npart of the country on the north/south basis. - Mod. LL\n\nMaps of Norway can be seen at\n<http://www.questconnect.org/images/map_of_norway.png> and\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0fRO>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 21 Feb 2011\n \n\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3). However, in studies\npublished in 1977, the vaccine was shown to significantly reduce the\nincidence of typhoidal tularemia in US government lab workers from\n5.7 to 0.27 cases per at-risk employee years (7). Although tularemia pneumonia is the form of the\ndisease associated with biological terrorism, it may also occur\nnaturally, as is exemplified by rare sporadic cases in New York City\nand outbreaks among gardeners on Martha's Vineyard (Massachusetts). Although classically transmitted to man via infected animals\nsuch as rabbits or a tick vector, infection with _Francisella\ntularensis_ may be acquired from contact with soil or water harboring\nthe bacterium. Burke DS: Immunization against tularemia: analysis of the\neffectiveness of live _Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention\nof laboratory-acquired tularemia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The form of tularemia that occurred in these cases (that is,\nulceroglandular, oculoglandular, typhoidal, or pneumonic) is not\nstated. However, the LVS (live vaccine strain) vaccine is available to\nmilitary personnel under an investigational new drug protocol held by\nthe US Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases (4). Tularemia, sometimes called hare plague,\nis a bacterial disease that every few years causes local outbreaks\namong rabbits and rodents, particularly in lemmings. So far in 2011, 13 cases of tularemia have been reported in people\nliving in 5 municipalities in More og Romsdal and Sor-Trondelag [in\ncentral Norway]. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138>). \n\nNorway is divided into 19 counties or fylke, the counties mentioned\nin the posting are adjacent to each other and located in the central\npart of the country on the north/south basis. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. J Chem Tech Biotechnol. 1994;\n59(4): 315-20 (abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7764815>. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan, Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. It did not reduce\nthe incidence of the ulceroglandular form, but the disease in\nvaccinees was reported to be milder. Humans can\nbecome infected through direct or indirect contact with sick, dead,\nor disease-carrying animals. The disease can\nalso spread through the bite of such animals and by inhalation of\ndust with infected feces or urine.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1962-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USSR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "639392", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, wildlife - USA: (TX) feral hogs, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=639392", "date": "2011-01-27 21:00:04", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - USA: (TEXAS) FERAL HOGS, ALERT\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 24 Jan 2011\nSource: KWTX.COM [edited]\n<http://www.kwtx.com/home/headlines/Infected_Feral_Hogs_Found_In_2_Local_Counties_114503609.html>\n\n\nResearchers at Texas Tech University's Institute of Environmental and\nHuman Health warned area farmers, ranchers, and hunters Monday [24 Jan\n2011] to use caution when handling wild game after finding evidence of\nthe bacterium that causes tularemia in feral hogs in Bell and Coryell\n[and Crosby -- see next para.] Counties [in Texas].\n\nTularemia is a serious infectious disease caused by the bacteria\n_Francisella tularensis_, said Steve Presley, a zoonotic disease\nresearcher who leads the team that tested about 130 feral hogs from\nBell, Coryell, and Crosby counties [in Texas]. Rodents and wild game\nanimals as well as mosquitoes, deer flies, and ticks, can carry\ntularemia, which is commonly known as rabbit fever, he said. 15\npercent of the feral hogs from the 2 Central Texas counties and 50\npercent of those from Crosby County showed evidence of current or past\ninfection, he said.\n\n'We have found high levels of antibodies in these pigs that show they\nhave been infected with _Francisella tularensis_ and found that some\nof these pigs were actively infected with it,' Presley said. 'The\nbacteria are constantly present in animals in this area and in the\nferal hog population, but normally it's only a small number of cases.\nThis is a huge number of infected animals.'\n\nWhat the researchers have yet to determine is the subspecies of\nbacteria infecting the hogs. The type B subspecies can cause illness\nin wildlife, domestic animals, and humans, but poses a less serious\nhealth threat to humans, Presley said. But the type A subspecies can\nbe lethal to humans, he said, and the US Centers For Disease Control\nand Prevention [CDC] considers it a viable bio-weapons agent.\n\nRegardless of which type it turns out to be, Presley says anyone who\nmay come into contact with wild animals -- especially those that might\nhunt or eat wild hogs -- should be cautious. 'If you are handling,\ncleaning, or eating wild game, particularly hogs, deer, or rabbits,\nyou should be wearing rubber gloves and eye protection when you're\ndressing wild game,' he said. 'The bacteria can enter any sort of\nsmall cut or hangnail. During this time of year, it might not be as\nbig of an issue, but you should check yourself for ticks, wear tick\nrepellent, and avoid biting flies, including mosquitoes.' Presley also\nrecommends making sure game meats are thoroughly cooked before eating\nthem and says homeowners and lawn care professionals should look for\nwild rabbit nests hidden in tall grasses prior to mowing. [There was a\ncase in Washington of a man running over an infected rabbit while\nmowing his grass and getting exposure, presumably from inhalation of\naerosolized carcass -- see ProMED 2005 archive below. - Mod.PC]\n\nThe discovery was made while the researchers were looking for\nbrucellosis. They found no evidence of that disease, and were\nsurprised to find evidence of tularemia, said Brad Dabbert, associate\nchairman of Texas Tech's Department of Natural Resources Management.\n'Traditionally, it's a rabbit disease, but it does get reported in\nbirds and other mammals,' Dabbert said. 'Since hogs can range over\nlarge areas, it's certainly possible that they can transport this\nstuff. That's kind of the critical issue now. The other thing we're\ntrying to do is look for it in other animals now to more accurately\nanswer that question,' he said.\n\nBetween 2000 and 2008, only 8 human cases of tularemia were reported\nin the state and about 125 are reported each year in the USA, Texas\nTech said Monday [24 Jan 2011]. Texas AgriLife Extension Service says\nferal hogs can be found in 230 of Texas' 254 counties and cause annual\ndamage of nearly USD 400 million.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever and deerfly fever, is a\nbacterial zoonosis caused by the Gram negative coccobacillus\n_Francisella tularensis_. The organism can infect humans and more than\n300 species of domestic and wild animals, including 25 species of\nbirds and several species of amphibians and reptiles. Water can also\nbecome contaminated from animals infected with tularemia and cause\nhuman infections. In 1982, 49 cases of oropharyngeal tularemia were\nidentified in Italy. The case distribution suggested the individuals\nhad consumed unchlorinated water in which a dead rabbit with _F.\ntularensis_ was found. Another waterborne transmission of tularemia\noccurred in 1998 on 19 persons in contact with river-caught crayfish\nin Spain.\n\nWild mammals are the primary hosts of _F. tularensis_, especially\nspecies within the orders Lagomorpha [rabbits], Rodentia [rats and\nmice], and Sciuromorpha [squirrels]. Sheep are the domestic mammal\nmost commonly associated with tularemia, but within recent years\ndomestic cats have become an increasing source for human cases of this\ndisease. In swine, infections are primarily in young animals, due to\nbites from infected ticks and from eating infected rodents. It is\ngenerally accepted that ticks are of major importance in maintaining\nthe enzootic foci of tularemia.\n\nInfections in humans are not contagious and most often result from\ncontact with infected wildlife, ingestion of, or contact with\ncontaminated water, or bites from ticks and other arthropods that have\nfed on infected wildlife. The disease in humans is nationally\nnotifiable in the United States and has been reported in every state\nexcept Hawaii. Type A tularemia infection in humans is a moderately\nsevere disease that follows a well-described course leading to the\ndevelopment of one of several clinical syndromes dependent on the\nroute of exposure, dose, and virulence of the infecting organism.\nPrior to the use of antibiotics for the treatment of tularemia,\ninfection resulted in death in 5 to 15 percent of the cases within\nNorth America; this has fallen to 1 to 3 percent during recent years\nand now averages less than 2 percent. However, untreated cases of\ntularemia that progress to systemic infections may result in severe\ndisease with high rates of fatality. Outside of the USA, human deaths\nrarely exceed one percent because of the less virulent forms of _F.\ntularensis_ present. Immunity following clinical disease is usually\nlifelong.\n\nPortions of the information above on tularemia in wildlife were\nextracted from the excellent USGS Circular 1297 Tularemia book, which\nsubscribers are suggested to consult for further details\n(<http://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/publications/tularemia/>).\n\nFeral hogs (_Sus scrofa_) are an Old World species belonging to the\nfamily Suidae. They were probably introduced by Spanish explorers 300\nyears ago as a source of meat and were later crossbred with European\nwild boar introduced as game animals in the 1930's. Feral hogs are\nomnivorous, capable of eating both plant and animal matter as\nopportunity changes through the seasons. Food includes grasses,\nflowering plants, roots and tubers, browse, mast [tree fruit such as\nacorns], fruits, bulbs and mushrooms. Animal matter includes\ninvertebrates (insects, snails, earthworms, etc.), reptiles,\namphibians, and carrion, as well as live mammals and birds if given\nthe opportunity. This varied feeding habit and diet makes the feral\nhogs susceptible to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ in the environment\nfrom digging and browsing the grounds around infected animals and\nparticularly direct ingestion of carrion infected with tularemia.\n\nFeral hogs are prolific breeders, with sows reaching sexual maturity\nat 7 or 8 months, normally bearing litters of 4-5 young, twice per\nyear. The feral hog population in Texas has been increasing\ndramatically due to many factors including intentional releases,\nimproved habitat, increased wildlife management, and improved animal\nhusbandry such as disease eradication, limited natural predators, and\nhigh reproductive potential. The current population of feral hogs in\nTexas is estimated to be over 2 million, which is approximately half\nof the total US population of the animal. Feral hogs are unprotected,\nexotic, non-game animals. They can be hunted by any means or methods\nat any time of year without season or bag limits, however a hunting\nlicense and landowner permission are required.\n\nPortions of the information above about feral hogs was extracted from\nthe Texas Parks and Wildlife website at\n<http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/huntwild/wild/nuisance/feral_hogs/>\n\nThis news report states that 15 percent of the examined feral hogs\nfrom Bell and Coryell counties and 50 percent from Crosby County show\nantibodies to tularemia, but no exact numbers are given for currently\nseroactive cases. We hope the researchers will be able to continue the\nresearch to confirm the serotype and seroactive numbers to get a\nbetter understanding of the epidemiological model and future trends.\n\nAs hunting requires being in close contact and possibly butchering and\nconsumption of feral hogs with tularemia, public awareness and\neducational programs for hunters should be of concern. As tularemia is\na treatable disease, educational programs should also include\ninformation on symptoms and diagnosis so the general public living in\nareas with feral hogs will understand and get immediate proper medical\ntreatment for tularemia.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Texas can be found at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00WR>.\nA map of the counties in Texas can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/texas_map.html>. - Mod.KL]\n\n[Photo of Texas feral hog:\nhttp://www.hogstoppers.com/image/pig-3-07-022_00021.jpg\n\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "was extracted from\nthe Texas Parks and Wildlife website at\n<http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/huntwild/wild/nuisance/feral_hogs/>\n\nThis news report states that 15 percent of the examined feral hogs\nfrom Bell and Coryell counties and 50 percent from Crosby County show\nantibodies to tularemia, but no exact numbers are given for currently\nseroactive cases. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 24 Jan 2011\n As tularemia is\na treatable disease, educational programs should also include\ninformation on symptoms and diagnosis so the general public living in\nareas with feral hogs will understand and get immediate proper medical\ntreatment for tularemia. The feral hog population in Texas has been increasing\ndramatically due to many factors including intentional releases,\nimproved habitat, increased wildlife management, and improved animal\nhusbandry such as disease eradication, limited natural predators, and\nhigh reproductive potential. Type A tularemia infection in humans is a moderately\nsevere disease that follows a well-described course leading to the\ndevelopment of one of several clinical syndromes dependent on the\nroute of exposure, dose, and virulence of the infecting organism.\n \n\nTularemia is a serious infectious disease caused by the bacteria\n_Francisella tularensis_, said Steve Presley, a zoonotic disease\nresearcher who leads the team that tested about 130 feral hogs from\nBell, Coryell, and Crosby counties [in Texas]. This varied feeding habit and diet makes the feral\nhogs susceptible to inhalation of _F. tularensis_ in the environment\nfrom digging and browsing the grounds around infected animals and\nparticularly direct ingestion of carrion infected with tularemia. \n\nInfections in humans are not contagious and most often result from\ncontact with infected wildlife, ingestion of, or contact with\ncontaminated water, or bites from ticks and other arthropods that have\nfed on infected wildlife. [24 Jan\n2011] to use caution when handling wild game after finding evidence of\nthe bacterium that causes tularemia in feral hogs in Bell and Coryell\n 15\npercent of the feral hogs from the 2 Central Texas counties and 50\npercent of those from Crosby County showed evidence of current or past\ninfection, he said. If you are handling,\ncleaning, or eating wild game, particularly hogs, deer, or rabbits,\nyou should be wearing rubber gloves and eye protection when you're\ndressing wild game,' he said. ' Prior to the use of antibiotics for the treatment of tularemia,\ninfection resulted in death in 5 to 15 percent of the cases within\nNorth America; this has fallen to 1 to 3 percent during recent years\nand now averages less than 2 percent. \n\nPortions of the information above on tularemia in wildlife were\nextracted from the excellent USGS Circular 1297 Tularemia book, which\nsubscribers are suggested to consult for further details\n(<http://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/publications/tularemia/>). Sheep are the domestic mammal\nmost commonly associated with tularemia, but within recent years\ndomestic cats have become an increasing source for human cases of this\ndisease. Presley also\nrecommends making sure game meats are thoroughly cooked before eating\nthem and says homeowners and lawn care professionals should look for\nwild rabbit nests hidden in tall grasses prior to mowing. [There was a\ncase in Washington of a man running over an infected rabbit while\nmowing his grass and getting exposure, presumably from inhalation of\naerosolized carcass -- see ProMED 2005 archive below. Animal matter includes\ninvertebrates (insects, snails, earthworms, etc.), reptiles,\namphibians, and carrion, as well as live mammals and birds if given\nthe opportunity. \n\nAs hunting requires being in close contact and possibly butchering and\nconsumption of feral hogs with tularemia, public awareness and\neducational programs for hunters should be of concern. \n\n'We have found high levels of antibodies in these pigs that show they\nhave been infected with _Francisella tularensis_ and found that some\nof these pigs were actively infected with it,' Presley said. ' Rodents and wild game\nanimals as well as mosquitoes, deer flies, and ticks, can carry\ntularemia, which is commonly known as rabbit fever, he said. Regardless of which type it turns out to be, Presley says anyone who\nmay come into contact with wild animals -- especially those that might\nhunt or eat wild hogs -- should be cautious. ' \n\nFeral hogs are prolific breeders, with sows reaching sexual maturity\nat 7 or 8 months, normally bearing litters of 4-5 young, twice per\nyear. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever and deerfly fever, is a\nbacterial zoonosis caused by the Gram negative coccobacillus\n_Francisella tularensis_. The organism can infect humans and more than\n300 species of domestic and wild animals, including 25 species of\nbirds and several species of amphibians and reptiles.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1930-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-24 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hawaii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "426753", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, wildlife - USA (02): (CO) beavers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=426753", "date": "2010-05-13 10:00:03", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - USA (02): (COLORADO) BEAVERS\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 May 2010\nSource: 9 News, Colorado, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.9news.com/news/local/article.aspx?storyid=138398&catid=346>\n\n\nBeavers found dead in western Colorado have likely succumbed to a\ncommon waterborne bacteria.\n\nColorado Division of Wildlife officials say that several beavers have\nbeen found dead in San Miguel and Gilpin counties.\n\nThe culprit was an outbreak of a [bacterial infection] called\ntularemia, which can infect animals that spend a lot of time in water.\n\nA total of 5 beavers have been found dead near Telluride, and 3 beaver\ncarcasses were reported in Gilpin County.\n\nDr Lisa Wolfe, a state wildlife veterinarian, says outbreaks of\ntularemia are common and pose little threat to humans.\n\n[Byline: Matt Clough]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article does not tell us if there were any necropsies done or if\nthis a usual occurrence and the state veterinarian's office is\npresuming this is the case.\n\nTularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly\nknown as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a gram negative, non-motile\ncoccobacillus. 2 subspecies exist: _F. tularensis tularensis_ (also\nknown as Jellison type A) and _F. tularensis holarctica_ (Jellison\ntype B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in lagomorphs in North\nAmerica and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits; _F.\ntularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and occurs in beavers,\nmuskrats, and voles in North America and in hares and small rodents in\nEurasia.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation,\narthropod-borne transfer, or direct contact through the skin and\nmucous membranes. Organisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods on fomites including\nfood and water. Aquatic animals may develop tularemia after being\nimmersed in contaminated water. Carnivores sometimes become infected\nafter ingesting a contaminated carcass. Vectors for _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor andersoni_, _D.\nvariabilis_, and _Amblyomma americanum_) and biting flies\n(particularly deerflies). _F. tularensis holarctica_ is also\ntransmitted by mosquitoes in Russia. Rarely, the organism is spread by\nanimal bites.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can survive for long periods in arthropod vectors and\nin the environment. Individual flies may carry the organism for 2\nweeks and ticks throughout their lifetimes. Viable bacteria can also\nbe found for weeks to months in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust, straw, water, soil, and\nbedbugs. This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live organisms\nhave been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15 deg C (5\ndeg F).\n\nRabbits and other wild rodents are the primary species affected.\nTularemia can also affect beaver and muskrats. Livestock and pets\nincluding pigs, horses, dogs, cats, fish, and birds can also get\ntularemia. Sheep are especially susceptible. Cattle rarely get the\ndisease.\n\nSome animals do not show signs of disease. Illness occurs 1-10 days\nafter exposure to the bacteria. Animals may have fever, look tired, be\ndepressed, and refuse to eat. Some will have a cough, stagger from\nweakness, vomit, or develop diarrhea. Rabbits and rodents behave\nstrangely, huddle together, and have a rough looking coat. Sudden\ndeath can occur.\n\nTularemia bacteria can be found in the organs or body fluids of\ninfected animals, which contaminate the environment. The bacteria can\nlive for long periods of time (weeks to months) in soil, vegetation,\nand water and serve as a source of infection for other animals or\nhumans. Animals get tularemia by ingesting (oral) contaminated food\n(raw meat from infected animals) or drinking contaminated water. They\ncan also inhale (aerosol) the bacterium, have direct contact with it\nin contaminated environments (entry through the mucous membranes or\nbreaks/cuts in the skin), or be bitten by infected biting flies or\nticks (vector).\n\nTularemia is difficult to prevent since it can be in the environment\nor be spread by insects. Prevention measures include keeping pets\nindoors and away from wildlife. Do not feed animals raw meat,\nespecially that from wild animals. Control ticks and biting flies.\n\nLastly, this agent is a category A bioterrorism agent.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/FastFacts/pdfs/tularemia_F.pdf>. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01eI>.\nSan Miguel and Gilpin counties can be located on the map at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/colorado_map.html>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 May 2010\n They\ncan also inhale (aerosol) the bacterium, have direct contact with it\nin contaminated environments (entry through the mucous membranes or\nbreaks/cuts in the skin), or be bitten by infected biting flies or\nticks (vector). 2 subspecies exist: _F. tularensis tularensis_ (also\nknown as Jellison type A) and _F. tularensis holarctica_ (Jellison\ntype B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in lagomorphs in North\n Viable bacteria can also\nbe found for weeks to months in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust, straw, water, soil, and\nbedbugs. Vectors for _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor andersoni_, _D.\nvariabilis_, and _Amblyomma americanum_) and biting flies\n(particularly deerflies). The bacteria can\nlive for long periods of time (weeks to months) in soil, vegetation,\nand water and serve as a source of infection for other animals or\nhumans. America and is highly virulent for humans and domestic rabbits; _F.\ntularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and occurs in beavers,\nmuskrats, and voles in North America and in hares and small rodents in\nEurasia. Organisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods on fomites including\nfood and water. \n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation,\narthropod-borne transfer, or direct contact through the skin and\nmucous membranes. Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_ (formerly\nknown as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a gram negative, non-motile\ncoccobacillus. This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live organisms\nhave been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15 deg C (5\ndeg F). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article does not tell us if there were any necropsies done or if\nthis a usual occurrence and the state veterinarian's office is\npresuming this is the case. Source: 9 News, Colorado, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.9news.com/news/local/article.aspx?storyid=138398&catid=346>\n\n\nBeavers found dead in western Colorado have likely succumbed to a\ncommon waterborne bacteria. TG]\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01eI>. Livestock and pets\nincluding pigs, horses, dogs, cats, fish, and birds can also get\ntularemia. TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - USA (02): (COLORADO) BEAVERS\n**************************************************\n \nSan Miguel and Gilpin counties can be located on the map at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/colorado_map.html>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gilpin County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Miguel", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "718029", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, imported - Germany: (Berlin) ex Turkey, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=718029", "date": "2011-05-10 17:49:09", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, IMPORTED - GERMANY: (BERLIN) ex TURKEY, ALERT\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 May 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance 2011; 16(18) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19860\n\n\nTularemia in Berlin -- 2 independent cases in travelers returning\nfrom Central Anatolia, Turkey, February 2011\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[authors: Schubert A, Splettstoesser W, Batzing-Feigenbaum J, et al]\n\nTularemia, though rare, has recently been increasingly reported in\nGermany. Most cases are indigenous infections. This report describes 2\nepidemiologically independent infections with _Francisella tularensis_\nsubspecies _holarctica_ detected in Berlin in February 2011 that were\nacquired in central Anatolia, Turkey. In Turkey, there have been\nrepeated tularemia outbreaks since 2000 and the disease should\ntherefore be considered as a differential diagnosis in travellers\nreturning from that country.\n\nCase description and clinical diagnosis\n---------------------------------------\nIn March 2011, 2 travelers returning from Turkey, both in their 20s,\nwere diagnosed with tularemia in Berlin, Germany. Both had stayed\nindependently in Turkey between the end of 2010 and early 2011 to\nvisit their respective families in Yozgat, central Anatolia, 218 km\n[136 mi] east of Ankara in the Ak mountains. The population of Yozgat\nin 2008 was 71 768, the province counted 492 127 inhabitants (1).\n\nBoth patients had similar general symptoms including fever,\npharyngitis, otitis and cervical lymphadenopathy, but showed different\nlocations of the ulcerations characteristic of tularemia. Both\ninfections were characterized by slow and subacute clinical\nprogression.\n\nPatient 1 stayed in Turkey between 25 Jul 2010 and 29 Jan 2011. Onset\nof symptoms was on 15 Dec 2010. Patient 2 had been in Turkey from 24\nDec 2010 to 8 Jan 2011 and fell ill on 10 Jan 2011. The patients were\ndiagnosed in mid-February 2011, after their return to Berlin. Patient\n1 was diagnosed with oropharyngeal tularemia, patient 2 with the\nulceroglandular form. The latter form is the most common expression of\ntularemia. Typical symptoms are ulcerations at the inoculation site\nlinked with regional, often purulent inflammation of the [draining]\nlymph nodes. The exact description of primary clinical symptoms is\nvery important to elucidate the transmission routes and further\nepidemiological links (2,3). Further interviews with patient 2\nrevealed additional epidemiological information: the patient and one\nof his siblings both fell ill on 10 Jan 2011, and a further sibling 2\ndays later. However, these patients remained in Turkey.\n\nLaboratory confirmation\n-----------------------\nThe detection of the pathogen by bacterial culture is difficult,\nspecial media are needed and growth is generally slow. More sensitive\nlaboratory methods like PCR are only available in a small number of\nspecialized laboratories (2,3). Laboratory confirmation for the cases\nwas available on 4 Mar 2011. The German national reference laboratory\nfor tularemia in Munich could detect _F. tularensis_ subspecies\n_holarctica_ (Jellison type B) via PCR in both cases. Specific DNA\nsequences were detected in the purulent puncture material of affected\nlymph nodes.\n\nA serological diagnosis done previously in the hospital in Berlin for\npatient 2 had shown IgG and IgM antibodies against _F. tularensis_\nlipopolysacharides. The infection in patient 1 was not proved\nserologically in the hospital, but was confirmed through specific\nantibodies in the national reference laboratory.\n\nPublic health implications\n--------------------------\nAfter the diagnoses were confirmed, information was immediately\nreported according to the WHO International Health Regulations (IHR)\nto the Robert Koch-Institute (RKI). At that time, no recent data were\naccessible about the tularemia situation in Turkey. Data about\ntularemia infections related to recent travel to Turkey or to\nneighboring countries were not found.\n\nTurkish citizens are one of the larger populations with migration\nbackground in Germany. At the end of 2010 nearly 2 per cent of the\nGerman population were Turkish (1 629 480 inhabitants) (4). In Berlin\nat the end of 2009, 3 per cent of the population were Turkish citizens\n(108 000 inhabitants) (5). In addition, an unknown number of German\ncitizens of Turkish origin still have intensive contacts with their\nfamilies in Turkey and frequently travel there. Therefore, the health\nauthorities in all 16 German federal states were informed on 8 Mar\n2011 during the weekly epidemiological telephone conference (EpiLag),\nsince more imported infections in international travellers could not\nbe excluded.\n\nTo get further data about the situation in Turkey, but also to alert\nother countries, the RKI informed the Turkish IHR focal point and the\nWHO Regional Office for Europe about the infections. Furthermore,\ninformation was sent to the Early Warning and Response System (EWRS)\nof the European Union. On the national level the decision was made to\ninvolve the German National Centre for Biological Security at the RKI\nbecause the pathogen _F. tularensis_ is classified as a potential\nbiological risk agent [category A. - Mod.LL]. Overall, the risk of\nfurther transmission and the threat to public health in Germany was\nestimated as low.\n\nEpidemiological considerations\n------------------------------\nIn the past years tularaemia outbreaks in Europe were documented in\nNorway (6,7), Sweden (8), Spain (9), and the UN Administered Province\nof Kosovo in accordance with Security Council Resolution 1244 of 1999\n(10). Parts of Turkey have been strongly affected by the re-emergence\nof tularemia and a number of outbreaks have been published since 2000\n(11-16). In Germany, tularemia cases are rare, however, increasing\nnumbers have been reported since 2007. Some travel-associated\ntularemia cases have been reported in Germany (10 of 74 cases between\n2001 and 2009), but only 1 case dating back to 2003 originated from\nTurkey (17,18).\n\nThrough information exchange via the national German and Turkish IHR\nFocal Points with the General Directorate of Primary Health Care in\nthe Turkish Ministry of Health, further details were provided about\nthe current situation in Turkey and possible sources of infection\n(personal communication: Dr Tamer Sami Pelitli, 18 Mar 2011). More\nthan 100 tularemia cases were reported to the national reference\nlaboratories from central parts of Turkey, especially in the Yozgat\nprovince in 2010. The cases had been confirmed serologically and\nthrough PCR in 2 reference laboratories in Ankara and Bursa, Turkey.\nBased on this information the Ministry of Health of Turkey has\nimplemented an action plan to fight the spread of tularaemia in 2010.\nThis action plan is focused on the rehabilitation of water systems. As\na promising result the number of reported tularaemia cases decreased\nin 2011 compared with the previous years. After being informed by the\nGerman IHR Focal Point about the 2 cases in Berlin, the Turkish\nMinistry of Health started active surveillance work in the Yozgat\nprovince, but has not yet detected new transmission risks for\ntularemia.\n\nIn both cases from Berlin the source of infection could not be\nidentified conclusively. However, based on the available\nepidemiological information, the most probable cause of the 2\ninfections is consumption of contaminated water during the stay in a\nregion of Turkey endemic for tularemia. Transmission has often been\nassociated with decentralized drinking water supply like cisterns and\ninsufficiently treated surface water (15). The clinical presentation\nat least in one of the patients diagnosed in Berlin supports this\nsuggestion. Oropharyngeal tularemia is presumably related to oral\ningestion of the pathogen.\n\nClinical considerations\n-----------------------\nDue to the relatively unspecific general symptoms of tularemia and\nthe variety of the primary disease patterns (depending on the route of\ninfection) clinical diagnosis is not easy. Therefore, early suspicion\nof tularemia depends on a precise medical history and epidemiological\ndata regarding in particular travel history, animal contacts,\noccupation, and insect bites. The diagnosis should subsequently be\nconfirmed through sensitive biomolecular methods like PCR with direct\nidentification in blood, lymph node punctuates or wound swabs, and\nspecific serological tests, both of which are available in specified\nlaboratories.\n\nEarly diagnosis allows immediate therapy with effective antibiotics\nlike doxycycline or fluoroquinolones, which can be combined with\naminoglycosides in severe cases. Drugs used empirically in many cases\nof lymphadenitis of uncertain origin are cephalosporins,\namoxicillin/clavulanate, and macrolides which, however, are not\neffective against tularemia. Sometimes even surgical interventions to\neliminate a suspected tumour are performed during infection with _F.\ntularensis_. In these cases, tularaemia is frequently diagnosed only\nretrospectively by histopathological examination and/or by detection\nof _F. tularensis_-specific antibodies.\n\nClinical physicians should currently be aware of possible infections\nwith _F. tularensis_ in travelers from some regions of Turkey. In case\nof clinical signs suggestive of tularemia, effective diagnostic\nmethods should not be delayed, since diagnostic delay can easily\nresult in extended suffering of the patient. Besides addressing the\npublic health aspects of the disease, epidemiology plays a major role\nin supporting the early and effective clinical diagnosis and treatment\nof tularemia.\n\n[For the citations, please refer to the source URL above. - Mod.LL]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_F. tularensis_ can be divided into 2 clinically significant\nsubspecies, _F. tularensis tularensis_ (also known as type A or\nsubspecies nearctica) and _F. tularensis holarctica_ (also known as\ntype B or subspecies _palaearctica_). Other much less clinically\nrelevant subspecies are also described.\n\nType A appears to be the most prominent type in North America,\nprimarily endemic in rabbits, and was involved in the Martha's\nVineyard (Massachusetts) pneumonic tularemia outbreaks. The infectious\ndose to produce infection in humans to cause moderately severe disease\nis as few as 50 bacilli and it is lethal to guinea pigs and rabbits.\n\nType B is found in Europe and Asia but also in North America. The\nreservoirs include rodents, voles, muskrats, and beavers. An\ninfectious dose of 12 000 bacilli is much more likely to produce only\nmild, self-limited disease in humans. It is not lethal in rabbits and\nguinea pigs.\n\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al. Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol\nImmunobiol. 2001; (6 Suppl): 68-72 (in Russian, abstract in English\navailable from http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12718181).\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al. A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol. 1987; 3(1): 35-8 (abstract available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3582597).\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al. An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1997; (2): 33-7 (in\nRussian, abstract in English available from\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9245138). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "TULAREMIA, IMPORTED - GERMANY: (BERLIN) ex TURKEY, ALERT\n********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3). After being informed by the\nGerman IHR Focal Point about the 2 cases in Berlin, the Turkish\nMinistry of Health started active surveillance work in the Yozgat\nprovince, but has not yet detected new transmission risks for\ntularemia. Therefore, the health\nauthorities in all 16 German federal states were informed on 8 Mar\n2011 during the weekly epidemiological telephone conference (EpiLag),\nsince more imported infections in international travellers could not\nbe excluded. The diagnosis should subsequently be\nconfirmed through sensitive biomolecular methods like PCR with direct\nidentification in blood, lymph node punctuates or wound swabs, and\nspecific serological tests, both of which are available in specified\nlaboratories. Through information exchange via the national German and Turkish IHR\nFocal Points with the General Directorate of Primary Health Care in\nthe Turkish Ministry of Health, further details were provided about\nthe current situation in Turkey and possible sources of infection\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_F. tularensis_ can be divided into 2 clinically significant\nsubspecies, _F. tularensis tularensis_ (also known as type A or\nsubspecies nearctica) and _F. tularensis holarctica_ (also known as\ntype B or subspecies _palaearctica_). Source: Eurosurveillance 2011; 16(18) [edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19860\n\n\nTularemia in Berlin -- 2 independent cases in travelers returning\nfrom Central Anatolia, Turkey, February 2011\n Some travel-associated\ntularemia cases have been reported in Germany (10 of 74 cases between\n2001 and 2009), but only 1 case dating back to 2003 originated from\nTurkey (17,18). Further interviews with patient 2\nrevealed additional epidemiological information: the patient and one\nof his siblings both fell ill on 10 Jan 2011, and a further sibling 2\ndays later. However, based on the available\nepidemiological information, the most probable cause of the 2\ninfections is consumption of contaminated water during the stay in a\nregion of Turkey endemic for tularemia. More\nthan 100 tularemia cases were reported to the national reference\nlaboratories from central parts of Turkey, especially in the Yozgat\nprovince in 2010. This report describes 2\nepidemiologically independent infections with _Francisella tularensis_\nsubspecies _holarctica_ detected in Berlin in February 2011 that were\nacquired in central Anatolia, Turkey. Besides addressing the\npublic health aspects of the disease, epidemiology plays a major role\nin supporting the early and effective clinical diagnosis and treatment\nof tularemia. In case\nof clinical signs suggestive of tularemia, effective diagnostic\nmethods should not be delayed, since diagnostic delay can easily\nresult in extended suffering of the patient. Therefore, early suspicion\nof tularemia depends on a precise medical history and epidemiological\ndata regarding in particular travel history, animal contacts,\noccupation, and insect bites. Drugs used empirically in many cases\nof lymphadenitis of uncertain origin are cephalosporins,\namoxicillin/clavulanate, and macrolides which, however, are not\neffective against tularemia. In Turkey, there have been\nrepeated tularemia outbreaks since 2000 and the disease should\ntherefore be considered as a differential diagnosis in travellers\nreturning from that country. Both had stayed\nindependently in Turkey between the end of 2010 and early 2011 to\nvisit their respective families in Yozgat, central Anatolia, 218 km\n On the national level the decision was made to\ninvolve the German National Centre for Biological Security at the RKI\nbecause the pathogen _F. tularensis_ is classified as a potential\nbiological risk agent [category A. - Mod. LL]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< In the past years tularaemia outbreaks in Europe were documented in\nNorway (6,7), Sweden (8), Spain (9), and the UN Administered Province\nof Kosovo in accordance with Security Council Resolution 1244 of 1999\n(10). \n\nBoth patients had similar general symptoms including fever,\npharyngitis, otitis and cervical lymphadenopathy, but showed different\nlocations of the ulcerations characteristic of tularemia. \n\nA serological diagnosis done previously in the hospital in Berlin for\npatient 2 had shown IgG and IgM antibodies against _F. tularensis_\nlipopolysacharides. \n\nType A appears to be the most prominent type in North America,\nprimarily endemic in rabbits, and was involved in the Martha's\nVineyard (Massachusetts) pneumonic tularemia outbreaks. Patient\n1 was diagnosed with oropharyngeal tularemia, patient 2 with the\nulceroglandular form. \n\nEarly diagnosis allows immediate therapy with effective antibiotics\nlike doxycycline or fluoroquinolones, which can be combined with\naminoglycosides in severe cases. Due to the relatively unspecific general symptoms of tularemia and\nthe variety of the primary disease patterns (depending on the route of\ninfection) clinical diagnosis is not easy. The German national reference laboratory\nfor tularemia in Munich could detect _F. tularensis_ subspecies\n_holarctica_ As\na promising result the number of reported tularaemia cases decreased\nin 2011 compared with the previous years. Data about\ntularemia infections related to recent travel to Turkey or to\nneighboring countries were not found. \n\nTo get further data about the situation in Turkey, but also to alert\nother countries, the RKI informed the Turkish IHR focal point and the\nWHO Regional Office for Europe about the infections. The infection in patient 1 was not proved\nserologically in the hospital, but was confirmed through specific\nantibodies in the national reference laboratory. Parts of Turkey have been strongly affected by the re-emergence\nof tularemia and a number of outbreaks have been published since 2000\n An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. In these cases, tularaemia is frequently diagnosed only\nretrospectively by histopathological examination and/or by detection\nof _F. tularensis_-specific antibodies.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:20", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-10 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-29 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-12-15 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-11-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TURKEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bursa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yozgat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ankara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anatolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Munich", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "8)", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "417238", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, wildlife - USA: (CO) beavers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=417238", "date": "2010-04-28 09:00:03", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - USA: (COLORADO) BEAVERS\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is program of the\nInternational Society of Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Apr 2010\nSource: The Watch Newspapers [edited]\n<http://www.watchnewspapers.com/view/full_story/7219589/article-Four-Dead-Beavers-Test-Positive-for-Tularemia?instance=top_story>\n\n\nTelluride Parks and Rec Public Works Project Manager Karen\nGuglielmone reported Monday [26 Apr 2010] that 2 of the 4 beavers\nfound dead in Telluride's Beaver Pond last week [week of 19 Apr 2010]\nhave tested positive for tularemia.\n\nTown officials have alerted the Telluride Veterinary Clinic and the\nTelluride Medical Center to the outbreak of the disease, more\ncommonly known as 'rabbit fever' or 'deer fly fever,' which can be\ntransmitted to animals and humans, most frequently by ticks and deer flies.\n\nTown residents reported the beaver deaths to authorities last week\n[week of 19 Apr 2010], following earlier reports that, despite the\nwarm temperatures, no beavers had been sighted in the pond.\n\nGuglielmone estimated as many as 8 beavers could have been living in\nthe Beaver Pond lodge, where it's possible more dead beavers will be found.\n\n'You never really know,' she said, of the pond's resident beaver\npopulation, adding that beaver 'kits' may remain with their parents\nfor up to 2 years, before moving on.\n\n'It's like losing a neighbor,' she said, of the dead beavers.\n\nHumans and animals can catch tularemia, but it is 'easily treated\nwith antibiotics' like tetracycline, Guglielmone said. She\nemphasized, however, that 'if you see a dead rodent, don't pick it up\n-- or turn it over. If there is a cut on your arm, you risk getting infected.'\n\nThe disease, most often found in rabbit and hare populations, is\nendemic in North America, parts of Europe, and Asia; believed to have\nbeen introduced into the US in the late 19th or early 20th century,\npossibly by dogs, it was first isolated in Tulare, California.\n\nTularemia is generally transmitted via rodents and insects -- biting\nflies, which can remain infective for up to 2 weeks, and ticks, which\ncan remain infective for up to 2 years, although waterborne infection\naccounts for 5-10 percent of all cases in the US.\n\nTularemia can also be spread by direct contact with contaminated\nanimals or material, by ingestion of poorly cooked flesh of infected\nanimals or contaminated water, or by inhalation. The incubation\nperiod for tularemia is 1 to 14 days, with most infections in humans\nmanifesting in 3 to 5 days.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control, symptoms of tularemia\nin humans can include sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea,\nmuscle aches, joint pain, a dry cough, and progressive weakness;\nhuman victims can also develop pneumonia, chest pain, bloody sputum,\nand breathing difficulties. Depending on the vector of exposure, more\nsymptoms can include ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen and painful\nlymph glands, swollen and painful eyes, and a sore throat. Humans can\nget tularemia by being bitten by an infected tick, deer fly, or other\ninsect, handling infected animal carcasses, eating or drinking\ncontaminated food and water, and breathing in the bacteria.\n\nThe CDC reports that, while tularemia is not known to be spread from\nperson to person, anyone with the disease should be treated as soon\nas possible, since it can be fatal if not treated with antibiotics. A\nvaccine for tularemia under review by the Food and Drug\nAdministration is not currently available in the US. They recommend\nusing insect repellent 'containing DEET on the skin, and treating\nclothing with permethrin to prevent insect bites, as well as frequent\nhand-washing with soap and warm water, especially after handling\nanimal carcasses; cooking food thoroughly and only drinking water\nfrom a safe source.' It also recommends those in affected areas note\nany change in the behavior of pets (most particularly in rodents,\nrabbits, and hares) or livestock, and consulting a veterinarian if\nsymptoms appear.\n\nThe CDC's website further reports that, if the _Francisella\ntularensis_ [the causative organism of Tularemia - Mod.TG] organism\n'were used as a weapon, the bacteria would likely be made airborne\nfor exposure by inhalation. People who inhale an infectious aerosol\nwould generally experience severe respiratory illness, including\nlife-threatening pneumonia and systemic infection, if not treated.\nThe bacteria that cause tularemia occur widely in nature, and could\nbe isolated and grown in quantity in a laboratory, although\nmanufacturing an effective aerosol weapon would require considerable\nsophistication,' to which end it is working to stockpile antibiotics\nfor treatment of infected persons, and to coordinate a nationwide\nprogram through which states share information about tularemia and\ncreating new education tools and programs for health professionals,\nthe public, and the media.\n\nWarning signs about the disease will be posted at the beaver pond;\ndog owners are urged to keep their animals away from the area.\n\n[Byline: Marta Tarbell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nGreg Craig <Greg_Craig@msn.com>\n\n[Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_\n(formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative,\nnon-motile coccobacillus. 2 subspecies exist: _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ (also known as Jellison type A) and _F. tularensis\nholarctica_ (Jellison type B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in\nlagomorphs in North America and is highly virulent for humans and\ndomestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and\noccurs in beavers, muskrats, and voles in North America and in hares\nand small rodents in Eurasia.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation,\narthropod-borne transfer, or direct contact through the skin and\nmucous membranes. Organisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods on fomites\nincluding food and water. Aquatic animals may develop tularemia after\nbeing immersed in contaminated water. Carnivores sometimes become\ninfected after ingesting a contaminated carcass. Vectors for _F.\ntularensis tularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor\nandersoni_, _D. variabilis_, and _Amblyomma americanum_) and biting\nflies (particularly deerflies). _F. tularensis holarctica_ is also\ntransmitted by mosquitoes in Russia. Rarely, the organism is spread\nby animal bites.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can survive for long periods in arthropod vectors and\nin the environment. Individual flies may carry the organism for 2\nweeks and ticks throughout their lifetimes. Viable bacteria can also\nbe found for weeks to months in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust, straw, water, soil, and\nbedbugs. This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live\norganisms have been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15\ndeg C (5 deg F).\n\nRabbits and other wild rodents are the primary species affected.\nTularemia can also affect beaver and muskrats. Livestock and pets\nincluding pigs, horses, dogs, cats, fish, and birds can also get\ntularemia. Sheep are especially susceptible. Cattle rarely get the disease.\n\nSome animals do not show signs of disease. Illness occurs 1-10 days\nafter exposure to the bacteria. Animals may have fever, look tired,\nbe depressed, and refuse to eat. Some will have a cough, stagger from\nweakness, vomit, or develop diarrhea. Rabbits and rodents behave\nstrangely, huddle together, and have a rough looking coat. Sudden\ndeath can occur.\n\nTularemia bacteria can be found in the organs or body fluids of\ninfected animals, which contaminates the environment. The bacteria\ncan live for long periods of time (weeks to months) in soil,\nvegetation and water and serve as a source of infection for other\nanimals or humans. Animals get tularemia by ingesting (oral)\ncontaminated food (raw meat from infected animals) or drinking\ncontaminated water. They can also inhale (aerosol) the bacteria, have\ndirect contact with it in contaminated environments (entry through\nthe mucous membranes or breaks/cuts in the skin), or be bitten by\ninfected biting flies or ticks (vector).\n\nTularemia is difficult to prevent since it can be in the environment\nor be spread by insects. Prevention measures include keeping pets\nindoors and away from wildlife. Do not feed animals raw meat,\nespecially that from wild animals. Control ticks and biting flies.\n\nLastly, this agent is a category A bioterrorism agent.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/FastFacts/pdfs/tularemia_F.pdf> - Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of Colorado and Telluride can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01eI>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "The bacteria that cause tularemia occur widely in nature, and could\nbe isolated and grown in quantity in a laboratory, although\nmanufacturing an effective aerosol weapon would require considerable\nsophistication,' to which end it is working to stockpile antibiotics\nfor treatment of infected persons, and to coordinate a nationwide\nprogram through which states share information about tularemia and\ncreating new education tools and programs for health professionals,\nthe public, and the media. They recommend\nusing insect repellent 'containing DEET on the skin, and treating\nclothing with permethrin to prevent insect bites, as well as frequent\nhand-washing with soap and warm water, especially after handling\nanimal carcasses; cooking food thoroughly and only drinking water\nfrom a safe source.' A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is program of the\nInternational Society of Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 27 Apr 2010\n (Jellison type B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in\nlagomorphs in North America and is highly virulent for humans and\ndomestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and\noccurs in beavers, muskrats, and voles in North America and in hares\nand small rodents in Eurasia. According to the Centers for Disease Control, symptoms of tularemia\nin humans can include sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea,\nmuscle aches, joint pain, a dry cough, and progressive weakness;\nhuman victims can also develop pneumonia, chest pain, bloody sputum,\nand breathing difficulties. \n\nTularemia is generally transmitted via rodents and insects -- biting\nflies, which can remain infective for up to 2 weeks, and ticks, which\ncan remain infective for up to 2 years, although waterborne infection\naccounts for 5-10 percent of all cases in the US. Humans can\nget tularemia by being bitten by an infected tick, deer fly, or other\ninsect, handling infected animal carcasses, eating or drinking\ncontaminated food and water, and breathing in the bacteria. Communicated by:\nGreg Craig <Greg_Craig@msn.com>\n\n[Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_\n(formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative,\nnon-motile coccobacillus. They can also inhale (aerosol) the bacteria, have\ndirect contact with it in contaminated environments (entry through\nthe mucous membranes or breaks/cuts in the skin), or be bitten by\ninfected biting flies or ticks (vector).
