This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live\norganisms have been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15\ndeg C (5 deg F).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulare", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Telluride", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "347103", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA: (MD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=347103", "date": "2009-12-07 16:00:03", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, LABORATORY-ACQUIRED - USA: (MARYLAND)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 4 Dec 2009\nSource: Science Insider, American Association for the Advancement of\nScience (AAAS) [edited]\n<http://blogs.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2009/12/researcher-at-a.html>\n\n\nA researcher at the United States Army Medical Research Institute of\nInfectious Diseases (USAMRIID) in Frederick, Maryland, has contracted\ntularemia, also known as rabbit fever. USAMRIID officials announced\ntoday, 4 Dec 2009. The illness is caused by the bacterium\n_Francisella tularensis_, one of several biosafety level 3 pathogens\nthat scientists work with at USAMRIID.\n\nThe researcher, a woman who was working on a project to develop a\nvaccine against the disease, is 'recuperating at home and is\nresponding well to antimicrobial therapy,' according to a press\nrelease issued by the institute.\n\nRabbits, rodents, and other animals harbor the microbe. Nearly 200\ncases of tularemia in the USA are reported to the CDC every year;\nmost of them are caused by bites from ticks and flies and from\nhandling animals infected from the disease. The illness can also be\ncontracted by inhaling airborne bacteria in the lab.\n\n'We want to reassure the Frederick and Fort Detrick communities that\nthis disease is not spread from person to person,' USAMRIID Commander\nJohn P Skvorak said in a statement. 'Our immediate concern is to make\nsure our employee is receiving the appropriate medical care.\nSecondly, we are working to determine how she may have been infected\nand to ensure that no one else has been affected. Laboratory-acquired\ninfections are rare, but if they do occur, we need to review our\nprocedures to minimize future incidents.'\n\n[Byline: Yudhijit Bhattacharjee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail has reported laboratory-related exposures and infections\nwith most of the Category A biowarfare pathogens as documented below.\nThe form of tularemia is not stated in the posting. If pneumonic,\noral, or ocular disease occurred, the exposure was likely to have\nbeen via aerosol and if ulcerative or ulceroglandular occurred, a\nneedle stick source would be suspected. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The state of Maryland in the Mid Atlantic region of the United\nStates can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00*Y>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 4 Dec 2009\n Nearly 200\ncases of tularemia in the USA are reported to the CDC every year;\nmost of them are caused by bites from ticks and flies and from\nhandling animals infected from the disease. The researcher, a woman who was working on a project to develop a\nvaccine against the disease, is 'recuperating at home and is\nresponding well to antimicrobial therapy,' according to a press\nrelease issued by the institute. If pneumonic,\noral, or ocular disease occurred, the exposure was likely to have\nbeen via aerosol and if ulcerative or ulceroglandular occurred, a\nneedle stick source would be suspected. \n\n'We want to reassure the Frederick and Fort Detrick communities that\nthis disease is not spread from person to person,' USAMRIID Commander\n LL]\n\n[The state of Maryland in the Mid Atlantic region of the United\nStates can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00*Y>. The illness is caused by the bacterium\n_Francisella tularensis_, one of several biosafety level 3 pathogens\nthat scientists work with at USAMRIID. A researcher at the United States Army Medical Research Institute of\nInfectious Diseases (USAMRIID) in Frederick, Maryland, has contracted\ntularemia, also known as rabbit fever.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Frederick", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "264449", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human - USA: (AK), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=264449", "date": "2009-08-10 18:00:25", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN - USA: (ALASKA), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.ktuu.com/Global/story.asp?S=10861604>\n\n\nTwo residents of Fairbanks, Alaska have been diagnosed with tularemia, a\npotentially fatal bacterial infection more commonly found in animals.\nAlaska Department of Fish and Game veterinarian Kimberlee Beckmen learned\nof the outbreak from state public health authorities late last week.\n\nThe disease can be transmitted to humans from snowshoe hares, and the hare\npopulation has been high in the interior. It's unclear how the Fairbanks\nresidents contracted it.\n\nBeckmen says people are usually infected through the skin by handling sick\nhares, but they can also get it when bitten by ticks, flies, or mosquitoes\nthat fed on sick hares.\n\nA Fish and Game spokeswoman says the Fairbanks patients were treated with\nantibiotics and are doing well.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found\nin a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at\nlow temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter.\nAlthough hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can be\ninfected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are\nimportant in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type of exposure will\ndictate the form of the disease manifestation with cutaneous exposures\nusually resulting in the glandular or ulceroglandular forms. The type of\ndisease in these Alaskan cases is not stated.\n\nProMED-mail posted an alert (20041008.2760, see below) in October 2004\nregarding hamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be\ninfected with type B tularemia as well. No human cases were reported.\n\nTularemia in humans is generally a rural disease and occurs naturally\nthroughout much of North America and Eurasia. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. Type A is said to be more virulent than type B.\n\nAlthough not generally transferable from person to person, the infectious\ndose of _F. tularensis_ is quite low, and the organism is listed among the\ncategory A bioterrorism agents.\n\nAccording to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, during the period 2000-2006, a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia were reported in the USA. In the same period, there were a total\nof only 3 cases reported in Alaska, with annual reports of no more than one\nper year, although the disease is likely underreported. See\n<http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/Surveillance/Tul_CasesbyState.html> for the\nfull table of number of cases reported each year by state, 2000-2006. The\nlargest numbers were from the south-central part of the USA, with Missouri\n(172), Arkansas (123), and Oklahoma (79) leading the list. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\n [Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _Francisella tularensis_ is found\nin a wide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at\nlow temperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal matter. Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. \n\nBeckmen says people are usually infected through the skin by handling sick\nhares, but they can also get it when bitten by ticks, flies, or mosquitoes\nthat fed on sick hares. \n\nProMED-mail posted an alert (20041008.2760, see below) in October 2004\nregarding hamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be\ninfected with type B tularemia as well. According to statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention, during the period 2000-2006, a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia were reported in the USA. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n In the same period, there were a total\nof only 3 cases reported in Alaska, with annual reports of no more than one\nper year, although the disease is likely underreported.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-10-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fairbanks", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Alaska", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "567201", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, wildlife - USA (03): (CO) rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=567201", "date": "2010-10-31 11:00:04", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WILDLIFE - USA (03): (CO) RABBIT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Oct 2010\nSource: Broomfield Enterprise [edited]\n<http://www.broomfieldenterprise.com/ci_16407213>\n\n\nA prairie dog die-off in the Anthem area initially suspected to be\ncaused by plague has been blamed on tularemia.\n\nCounty health officials began investigating the die-off on 5 Oct\n2010, and cordoned off an area south and west of Uptown Avenue in the\nArista development to limit access of people and their pets. The\naffected area is south of the 1stBank Center.\n\nOn Wednesday [27 Oct 2010], a rabbit in the area was confirmed to\nhave tularemia.\n\nTularemia is a bacterial disease found in animals, especially\nrodents, rabbits and hares. It is spread by bites from infected\nfleas, ticks or insects, handling infected animal carcasses, eating\nor drinking contaminated food or water, or breathing in the bacteria.\n\nSymptoms of tularemia include sudden fever, chills, headaches,\ndiarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough and progressive\nweakness. People also can develop pneumonia with chest pain, cough\nand difficulty breathing if it is not treated.\n\nHealth officials recommend individuals immediately see a physician if\nthey become ill with a high fever and/or swollen lymph nodes. They\nalso recommend taking pets to see a veterinarian if they come down\nwith a high fever or become lethargic.\n\nAs it continues to monitor the area, the Broomfield Public Health and\nEnvironment Division is advising residents, pet owners, area workers\nand visitors to avoid handling and coming into contact with animals\nthat could potentially be infected, such as wild rodents, squirrels\nand rabbits.\n\nOther safety tips include:\n\nKeep pets, especially cats and dogs, indoors to limit exposure to\nticks. If outdoors with your pets, keep them out of heavily wooded areas.\n\nAvoid areas inhabited by wild rodents. If you enter such areas, wear\ninsect repellent containing DEET.\n\nKeep pets on a leash at all times to prevent them from running loose\nin fields where they might come in contact with rodents, rabbits and hares.\n\nNever touch sick or dead animals with your bare hands. If an animal\nmust be moved, use a long-handled shovel to place it in a garbage\nbag, and place the bag in an outdoor garbage can.\n\nAvoid drinking unpurified water from streams or lakes and prevent\npets from doing the same.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is named for the early work done in Tulare County,\nCalifornia, now one of the largest dairy producing counties in the\nUnited States but also home to the Sierra Nevada Mountains. Some of\nthe early work distinguishing tularemia from plague was 1st performed\nin Tulare County. A brief history can be found on the Texas\nDepartment of State Health Services at\n<http://www.dshs.state.tx.us/preparedness/bt_public_history_tularemia.shtm>.\nI have included a short history below:\n\nThere is evidence that tularemia in humans may have occurred as early\nas the 19th century in the US, Norway, Russia and Japan, but probably\nwas not recognized as an infectious process. In the early 20th\ncentury, a Japanese physician named Hachiro Ohara described a disease\naffecting those who hunted or ate rabbit. The Japanese called it\nYato-Byo, meaning rabbit fever, which appeared to be endemic to the\nAbakuma Mountains. He recorded that during certain seasons, dead\nrabbits were seen in great numbers, and human infection resulted from\ncontact with dead or diseased rabbits. He then took some blood from\nan affected rabbit and rubbed it on his wife's skin. Within days,\naccording to Ohara's report, a large ulcer appeared, and she\nexperienced clinical symptoms similar to those of people exposed in\nnature. Decades later, Ohara recognized that there were clinical\ndifferences between the Yato-Byo observed in Japan and the tularemia\nobserved in the United States.\n\nIn 1910, a Utah physician, RA Pearse, described deer-fly fever. In\n1911, George W. McCoy and Charles W. Chapin, from the US Public\nHealth Service, began examining thousands of rats and ground\nsquirrels in order to detect foci of suspected plague infections in\nSan Francisco. Early in the investigation, McCoy noted that they had\n'encountered an infection with lesions which are readily mistaken for\nthose of plague. ... It is barely possible that we unknowingly have\ndealt with more than one disease entity, as no etiological agent has\nbeen discovered.' A year later, they isolated the causative organism\nof this plague-like disease from California ground squirrels and\nnamed it _Bacterium tularense_ after Tulare County where the work was\nperformed. In addition, McCoy and Chapin developed agglutination and\ncomplement fixation tests to aid in the diagnosis. The 1st\nbacteriologically confirmed case of human tularemia was reported in\nCincinnati in 1914.\n\nDr. Edward Francis, also from the US Public Health Service,\nestablished the cause of deer-fly fever as _Bacterium tularense_ in\n1928. Because of his extensive contributions to the knowledge of the\nbacterium and the disease, the organism was later renamed\n_Francisella tularensis_.\n\nTularemia, occurs naturally all over the United States and other\nparts of the world but is particularly common in the Western and\nCentral United States, in places like California, Arizona, New Mexico\nand Colorado, where this report comes from. The disease is also\nprominent in Japan, the former Soviet Union and other places in the\nNorthern Hemisphere. There are approximately 200 cases per year in\nthe United States, almost all of them occurring in rural locations.\nThere are multiple ways to get tularemia as well, including through\nfood and water, handling contaminated carcasses, bites of ticks,\nfleas and other insect vectors, inhalation and laboratory exposure.\nThere was a case in Massachusetts of a man running over an infected\nrabbit while mowing his grass and getting exposure, presumably from\ninhalation of carcass contaminants. Tularemia is also a recognized\nbioterrorism agent. See moderator comments from Tularemia, wildlife -\nUSA (02): (CO) beavers 20100513.1555 for further d!\netails on the causative organism, clinical signs, control and\nprevention etc. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 30 Oct 2010\n \n\nAs it continues to monitor the area, the Broomfield Public Health and\nEnvironment Division is advising residents, pet owners, area workers\nand visitors to avoid handling and coming into contact with animals\nthat could potentially be infected, such as wild rodents, squirrels\nand rabbits. In\n1911, George W. McCoy and Charles W. Chapin, from the US Public\nHealth Service, began examining thousands of rats and ground\nsquirrels in order to detect foci of suspected plague infections in\nSan Francisco. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is named for the early work done in Tulare County,\nCalifornia, now one of the largest dairy producing counties in the\nUnited States but also home to the Sierra Nevada Mountains. \n\nTularemia, occurs naturally all over the United States and other\nparts of the world but is particularly common in the Western and\nCentral United States, in places like California, Arizona, New Mexico\nand Colorado, where this report comes from. A year later, they isolated the causative organism\nof this plague-like disease from California ground squirrels and\nnamed it _Bacterium tularense_ after Tulare County where the work was\nperformed. Within days,\naccording to Ohara's report, a large ulcer appeared, and she\nexperienced clinical symptoms similar to those of people exposed in\nnature. \n\nSymptoms of tularemia include sudden fever, chills, headaches,\ndiarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough and progressive\nweakness. I have included a short history below:\n\nThere is evidence that tularemia in humans may have occurred as early\nas the 19th century in the US, Norway, Russia and Japan, but probably\nwas not recognized as an infectious process. \n\nCounty health officials began investigating the die-off on 5 Oct\n2010, and cordoned off an area south and west of Uptown Avenue in the\n There are multiple ways to get tularemia as well, including through\nfood and water, handling contaminated carcasses, bites of ticks,\nfleas and other insect vectors, inhalation and laboratory exposure. It is spread by bites from infected\nfleas, ticks or insects, handling infected animal carcasses, eating\nor drinking contaminated food or water, or breathing in the bacteria. \n\nDr. Edward Francis, also from the US Public Health Service,\nestablished the cause of deer-fly fever as _Bacterium tularense_ in\n1928. He recorded that during certain seasons, dead\nrabbits were seen in great numbers, and human infection resulted from\ncontact with dead or diseased rabbits. In the early 20th\ncentury, a Japanese physician named Hachiro Ohara described a disease\naffecting those who hunted or ate rabbit. Some of\nthe early work distinguishing tularemia from plague was 1st performed\nin Tulare County. There was a case in Massachusetts of a man running over an infected\nrabbit while mowing his grass and getting exposure, presumably from\ninhalation of carcass contaminants. Decades later, Ohara recognized that there were clinical\ndifferences between the Yato-Byo observed in Japan and the tularemia\nobserved in the United States.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1914-03-25 00:00:00", "1910-03-25 00:00:00", "1928-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1911-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cincinnati", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tularemia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Tulare County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Central United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Anthem", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "239524", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=239524", "date": "2009-07-12 11:00:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Jul 20099\nSource: National Park Traverl.com [edited]\n<http://www.nationalparkstraveler.com/2009/07/update-sylvatic-plague-and-tularemia-afflict-prairie-dogs-badlands-national-park>\n\n\nOfficials have confirmed the presence of sylvatic plague and\ntularemia in Badlands National Park. That's bad news for the park's\nprairie dogs and black-footed ferrets, but visitors should be OK if\nthey use common sense safety precautions.\n\nSylvatic plague, which was 1st detected in South Dakota in 2004,\nturned up last year [2008] in the prairie dog population of the\nConata Basin just south of Badlands National Park. Since fleas spread\nplague from infected animals to healthy ones (and occasionally to\nhumans as well), officials ordered a flea suppression campaign that\nentailed applying insecticides to prairie dog colonies over an area\nof about 11 000 acres. In addition, black-footed ferrets were\ncaptured and given plague vaccinations. It was fervently hoped that\nthese measures would keep the disease from spreading to Badlands\nNational Park, which not only harbors many thousands of prairie dogs\nbut also a small and struggling population of endangered black-footed\nferrets that mainly feed on prairie dogs.\n\nAlas, about a week ago, wildlife biologists confirmed that the\nprairie dog population in the Sage Creek Wilderness Area of the park\nis being assaulted by sylvatic plague. Tularemia (rabbit fever) has\nalso been detected in one of the park's prairie dog colonies. Both\ndiseases sicken and kill prairie dogs, so this disease outbreak has\nthe potential to decimate the park's prairie dog population and\nperhaps undo much of the effort that's been invested in\nreestablishing black-footed ferrets there.\n\nAlthough few people in the U.S. have ever been infected by plague or\ntularemia, both diseases can be transmitted to humans and should be\nconsidered potentially dangerous. Park officials are advising\nvisitors to take these common sense safety precautions to minimize\nthe likelihood of infection:\n\n- Be aware that potentially dangerous diseases can be transmitted to\nhumans by way of ticks or bites and scratches, urine-contaminated\nwater, and the inhaling of infectious aerosols.\n- Apply DEET insect repellant to clothing and skin to avoid bites\nfrom fleas and ticks.\n- Avoid handling sick or dead animals in the park.\n- Do not allow pets to wander into prairie dog colonies where they\nmay come into contact with disease-carrying fleas.\n- See a doctor if you think that you may have been exposed to plague\nor tularemia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[These are diseases spread by ground squirrels and other wild\nrodents, frequently in the western portion of the United States.\n'Sylvatic' means pertaining to the woods (sylvan). These are diseases\nspread by wild rodents, which serve as a reservoir for humans. In the\nwestern part of the US, they are often spread by prairie dogs, ground\nsquirrels and other small ground rodents. These diseases can happen\nalmost anywhere, but we frequently see the problems in the western\nregion of the US.\n\nPlague results from infection by _Yersinia pestis_, a non-motile,\nfacultatively intracellular, Gram negative rod (family _Enterobacteriaceae_).\n\nPlague is usually spread between rodents or humans by the bites of\ninfected fleas. Vectors include a variety of rodent fleas,\nparticularly the oriental rat flea (_Xenopsylla Cheopis_). In the\nU.S., the most common vector is _Oropsylla Montana_, a flea often\nfound on California ground squirrels, rock squirrels, and sometimes\nother rodents including prairie dogs. Human fleas (_Pulex irritans)_\nmay also carry _Y. pestis_. _Y. pestis_ is also present in the\ntissues and body fluids of infected animals; these bacteria can be\ntransmitted directly through mucous membranes and broken skin.\nAerosols from people or animals with the pneumonic form are\ninfectious, and animals may transmit bacteria in bites. Carnivores\noften become infected when they eat diseased rodents.\n\nPrairie dogs are considered to be sensitive indicators of plague and tularemia.\n\nTularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_\n(formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative,\nnon-motile coccobacillus. Two subspecies exist: _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ (also known as Jellison type A) and _F. tularensis\nholarctica_ (Jellison type B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in\nlagomorphs in North America and is highly virulent for humans and\ndomestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and\noccurs in beavers, muskrats and voles in North America and in hares\nand small rodents in Eurasia.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation,\narthropod-borne transfer or direct contact through the skin and\nmucous membranes. Organisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods on fomites\nincluding food and water. Aquatic animals may develop tularemia after\nbeing immersed in contaminated water. Carnivores sometimes become\ninfected after ingesting a contaminated carcass. Vectors for _F.\ntularensis tularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor\nandersoni_, _D. variabilis_ and _Amblyomma americanum_) and biting\nflies (particularly deerflies). _F. tularensis holarctica_ is also\ntransmitted by mosquitoes in Russia. Rarely, the organism is spread\nby animal bites.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can survive for long periods in arthropod vectors and\nin the environment. Individual flies may carry the organism for 2\nweeks and ticks throughout their lifetimes. Viable bacteria can also\nbe found for weeks to months in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust, straw, water, soil and\nbedbugs. This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live\norganisms have been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15 C.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/Tularemia.pdf> and\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/factsheets/pdfs/plague.pdf>. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Jul 20099\n Park officials are advising\nvisitors to take these common sense safety precautions to minimize\nthe likelihood of infection:\n\n- Be aware that potentially dangerous diseases can be transmitted to\nhumans by way of ticks or bites and scratches, urine-contaminated\nwater, and the inhaling of infectious aerosols. Since fleas spread\nplague from infected animals to healthy ones (and occasionally to\nhumans as well), officials ordered a flea suppression campaign that\nentailed applying insecticides to prairie dog colonies over an area\nof about 11 000 acres. (Jellison type B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in\nlagomorphs in North America and is highly virulent for humans and\ndomestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and\noccurs in beavers, muskrats and voles in North America and in hares\nand small rodents in Eurasia. Both\ndiseases sicken and kill prairie dogs, so this disease outbreak has\nthe potential to decimate the park's prairie dog population and\nperhaps undo much of the effort that's been invested in\nreestablishing black-footed ferrets there. It was fervently hoped that\nthese measures would keep the disease from spreading to Badlands\nNational Park, which not only harbors many thousands of prairie dogs\nbut also a small and struggling population of endangered black-footed\nferrets that mainly feed on prairie dogs. In the\nU.S., the most common vector is _Oropsylla Montana_, a flea often\nfound on California ground squirrels, rock squirrels, and sometimes\nother rodents including prairie dogs. Vectors for _F.\ntularensis tularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor\nandersoni_, _D. variabilis_ and _Amblyomma americanum_) and biting\nflies (particularly deerflies). Viable bacteria can also\nbe found for weeks to months in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust, straw, water, soil and\nbedbugs. This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live\norganisms have been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15 C.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/Tularemia.pdf> and\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/factsheets/pdfs/plague.pdf>. \n\nSylvatic plague, which was 1st detected in South Dakota in 2004,\nturned up last year [2008] in the prairie dog population of the\nConata Basin just south of Badlands National Park. \n\nAlas, about a week ago, wildlife biologists confirmed that the\nprairie dog population in the Sage Creek Wilderness Area of the park\nis being assaulted by sylvatic plague. That's bad news for the park's\nprairie dogs and black-footed ferrets, but visitors should be OK if\nthey use common sense safety precautions. In the\nwestern part of the US, they are often spread by prairie dogs, ground\nsquirrels and other small ground rodents. Two subspecies exist: _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ (also known as Jellison type A) and _F. tularensis\nholarctica_ \n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation,\narthropod-borne transfer or direct contact through the skin and\nmucous membranes.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "258007", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, feline - USA (UT): alert, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=258007", "date": "2009-08-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, FELINE - USA (UT), ALERT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 28 Jul 2009\nSource: The Spectrum.com\n<http://www.thespectrum.com/article/20090728/NEWS01/90728011/Tularemia+found+in+cats+in+Kanab+area>\n\n\nThe Southwest Utah Public Health Department is\ninvestigating the recent confirmation of\ntularemia found in some cats in the Kanab area.\nTularemia, sometimes called \u0093rabbit fever,\u0094 is an\nillness caused by the bacteria _Francisella\ntularensis_ and is often spread by deer flies and\nticks or exposure to the blood of infected animals.\n\n\u0093People can be infected by tularemia, but it\ncannot be spread from person to person,\u0094 says\nLisa Starr, SWUPHD communicable disease nurse.\n\u0093Since this disease was found in domestic cats,\nwe want to inform the public of its presence and how to avoid infection.\u0094\n\nThe symptoms of tularemia include flu-like\nillness such as sudden fever, body aches and\ncoughing. If the infection is caused by an insect\nbite or a cut, it usually results in a skin ulcer and swollen glands.\n\nThe risk of getting tularemia is often associated\nwith skinning infected rabbits or eating rabbit meat that is not cooked well.\n\nPeople can help prevent infection by :\n- Reducing insect bites by wearing protective\nclothing and using repellents containing DEET.\n- Search for ticks often and remove attached ticks immediately.\n- Do not handle sick or dead animals.\n- Wear gloves when skinning or handling animals, especially wild rabbits.\n- Stay away from stray cats.\n\nContact your doctor if you think you have been\nexposed. For more information, call the SWUPHD\nKanab office at 644-2537 or visit www.swuhealth.org.\n\n--\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella\ntularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella\ntularensis_), a gram-negative, non\u00admotile\ncoccobacillus. 2 subspecies exist: _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ (also known as Jellison type A) and\n_F. tularensis holarctica_ (Jellison type B). _F.\ntularensis tularensis_ is found in lagomorphs in\nNorth America and is highly virulent for humans\nand domestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_\nis less virulent and occurs in beaver, muskrats\nand voles in North America and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion,\ninhalation, arthropod\u00adborne transfer or direct\ncontact through the skin and mucous membranes.\nOrganisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods\non fomites including food and water. Aquatic\nanimals may develop tularemia after being\nimmersed in contaminated water. Carnivores\nsometimes become infected after ingesting a\ncontaminated carcass. Vectors for _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor\nandersoni_, _D. variabilis_ and _Amblyomma\namericanum_) and biting flies (particularly\ndeerflies). _F. tularensis holarctica_ is also\ntransmitted by mosquitoes in Russia. Rarely, the\norganism is spread by animal bites.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can survive for long periods of\ntime in arthropod vectors and in the environment.\nIndividual flies may carry the organism for 2\nweeks and ticks throughout their lifetimes.\nViable bacteria can also be found for weeks to\nmonths in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust,\nstraw, water, soil and bedbugs. This organism is\nhighly resistant to freezing; live organisms have\nbeen found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at \u00ad15 deg C [5 deg F].\n\nHowever, this short article gives us no\nindication of how the animals contacted the\ndisease. While it may be likely to conclude it is\narthropod borne, then warnings to the community should be forthcoming.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted\nfrom: <http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/Tularemia.pdf> \u00ad Mod.TG]\n\n[This same report is available at the Southwest\nUtah Public Health Department website at\n<http://www.swuhealth.org/index.html>. According\nto CDC statistics, during the period 2000-2006\nthere were a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia reported in the USA. In the same\nperiod, there were a total of 15 cases reported\nin Utah, with annual reports ranging from 1-4\ncases. (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/Surveillance/Tul_CasesbyState.html>\nfor the full table of number of cases reported each year by state, 2000-2006.).\n\nFor a good map of the USA showing the\ndistribution of reported tularemia cases during\nthe period 2000 -2006, see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/Surveillance/Tul_00_06.html>.\n\nProMED-mail would greatly appreciated more\ninformation on the number of felines with\ntularemia infection confirmed in Kanab Utah.\n\nFor the HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Kanab, Utah,\nlocated near the border with Arizona, see\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00DZ>. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "_F.\ntularensis tularensis_ is found in lagomorphs in\nNorth America and is highly virulent for humans\nand domestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_\nis less virulent and occurs in beaver, muskrats\nand voles in North America and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 28 Jul 2009\n Kanab office at 644-2537 or visit www.swuhealth.org.\n\n--\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella\ntularensis_ (formerly known as _Pasteurella\ntularensis_), a gram-negative, non\u00admotile\ncoccobacillus. Vectors for _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor\nandersoni_, _D. variabilis_ and _Amblyomma\namericanum_) and biting flies (particularly\ndeerflies). Tularemia, sometimes called \u0093rabbit fever,\u0094 is an\nillness caused by the bacteria _Francisella\ntularensis_ and is often spread by deer flies and\nticks or exposure to the blood of infected animals. \u0093Since this disease was found in domestic cats,\nwe want to inform the public of its presence and how to avoid infection.\u0094\n\nThe symptoms of tularemia include flu-like\nillness such as sudden fever, body aches and\ncoughing. \n\n\u0093People can be infected by tularemia, but it\ncannot be spread from person to person,\u0094 says\nLisa Starr, SWUPHD communicable disease nurse.\n Viable bacteria can also be found for weeks to\nmonths in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust,\nstraw, water, soil and bedbugs. According\nto CDC statistics, during the period 2000-2006\nthere were a total of 873 cases of human\ntularemia reported in the USA. In\none case, the animal died of the disease known as 'rabbit fever.'\n\nThe test results were from pets which lived in\nthe Cactus Heights Mobile Home Park on North Cleveland Avenue.\n\nThe disease is caused by bacteria that typically\nis found in rodents, rabbits and hares. Signs\ninclude anorexia, lethargy, dehydration, oral ulcers and weight loss.\n\nPet owners can protect their animals by using\ntick repellant or checking pets for ticks.\n\n--\n\nCommunicated by:\nProMed-Mail Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Tularemia results from infection by _Francisella\ntularensis_ (formerly known as Pasteurella\ntularensis), a gram-negative, non\u00admotile\ncoccobacillus. 2 subspecies exist: _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ (also known as Jellison type A) and\n_F. tularensis holarctica_ (Jellison type B). _F.\ntularensis tularensis_ is found in lagomorphs in\nNorth America and is highly virulent for humans\nand domestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_\nis less virulent and occurs in beaver, muskrats\nand voles in North America and in hares and small rodents in Eurasia.\n\nF. tularensis can be transmitted by ingestion,\ninhalation, arthropod\u00adborne transfer or direct\ncontact through the skin and mucous membranes.\nOrganisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods\non fomites including food and water. Organisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods\non fomites including food and water.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "174555", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, rabbits - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=174555", "date": "2009-04-15 16:00:52", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, RABBITS - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 14 Apr 2009\nSource: KRQE.com [edited]\n<http://www.krqe.com/dpp/news/health/health_ap_santa_fe_tularemia_found_in_rabbits_in_new_mexico_200904141403>\n\n\nThe New Mexico State Department of Health says rabbits in New Mexico\nare getting sick and dying from the bacterial disease tularemia. The\nillness is potentially serious in people.\n\nTularemia is caused by a bacteria found in animals, especially\nrodents and rabbits. Symptoms in people are similar to those of\nplague: Sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscles aches and\njoint pain. Other symptoms can include pneumonia, chest pain, ulcers\non the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and\npainful eyes and a sore throat.\n\nPublic health veterinarian Dr. Paul Ettestad urges people to follow\nthe same precautions against tularemia as for plague. They include\nnot allowing pets to roam and hunt, using flea-control products on\npets, and not handling sick or dead rodents or rabbits.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[It's that time of year, though maybe a mite early. New Mexico is a\nlarge state, and further information is being sought from those who\nwill know. Those needing more background information should refer to\n20070524.1658. Postings for adjoining states have been provided for\nregional background information. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 14 Apr 2009\n Other symptoms can include pneumonia, chest pain, ulcers\non the skin or mouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and\npainful eyes and a sore throat. They include\nnot allowing pets to roam and hunt, using flea-control products on\npets, and not handling sick or dead rodents or rabbits. Symptoms in people are similar to those of\nplague: Sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea, muscles aches and\njoint pain. New Mexico is a\nlarge state, and further information is being sought from those who\nwill know.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "sudden", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "175288", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, rabbits - USA (02): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=175288", "date": "2009-04-17 18:00:54", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, RABBITS - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 15 Apr 2009\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n\nRE: Tularemia, rabbits - USA (NM)\n---------------------------------\nSometimes our press releases are only partially covered in the media\nwhich leads to a lack of information for ProMED. Our rabbit\npopulation cycles up and down every few years and has recently been\nfairly high, at least in the northern part of New Mexico. When the\npopulations are high we tend to see die offs due to both tularemia\nand plague. This can then lead to cases in cats and dogs that are\nallowed to roam and hunt, and potentially in people.\n\nWe have had laboratory confirmed tularemia in 2 rabbits, one from an\narea called La Cienega (several miles southwest of the city of Santa\nFe, picked up dead on 9 Apr 2009) and another one from just west of\nthe city limits of Santa Fe (picked up dead on 8 Apr 2009). We also\nhad a dead rabbit from the north end of Santa Fe (picked up dead on\n31 Mar 2009) that tested positive for plague, _Yersinia pestis_.\n[This is being posted, see ProMEDmail 20090415.1435. - Mod.MHJ] There\nwere no human or pet cases associated with these dead rabbits and no\nantibiotic prophylaxis was needed. We feel it is important to give an\nearly warning to the public that these diseases, while rare, are\ncirculating in the environment. We also give information to the\npublic on things they can do to help decrease their risk of being\nexposed to these diseases.\n\nIt is difficult to predict whether animal cases in early spring will\ntranslate to an increase in human cases (there was only one human\ncase of plague and one human case of tularemia in New Mexico in 2008)\nas many environmental factors come into play, especially rainfall and\ntemperature. I also believe that modifying human behavior can go a\nlong way to reducing risk and the number of human and pet cases,\nhence our news release warnings.\n\nOur one New Mexico plague case in 2008 was due to a person skinning a\nsick rabbit bare-handed.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[Our heartfelt thanks to Paul. There were 2 press releases. The one\non lapine plague is being posted separately. - Mod.MHJ]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 14 Apr 2009\nSource: Office of the Secretary, NM Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/>\n\n\nDepartment of Health warns about tularemia in rabbits\n------------------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health is warning people that rabbits\nare getting sick and dying from a bacterial disease called tularemia.\nPaul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian,\nencourages people to follow the same precautions they would to avoid\nplague: Don't allow pets to roam and hunt, use a tick/flea control\nproduct on pets and don't handle sick or dead rodents or rabbits.\n\n'We have received several phone calls over the last 2 weeks from\nconcerned citizens in Santa Fe County who have found dead rabbits\nnear their homes or in recreational areas that they frequent,'\nEttestad said. 'We have tested several of these rabbits and 2 of them\nhave come back positive for tularemia, one from the La Cienega area\nand one from west of the city of Santa Fe near the 599 Relief Route.\nOther reports of sick and dead rabbits have come from areas near Lamy\nand Edgewood.'\n\nThe Department is not collecting any more rabbits from these areas,\nbut asks people to use a shovel to either bury the dead rabbits in\nthe ground or to double bag them in the trash if they are allowed to\ndispose of them in this manner. This will help keep pets from chewing\non the dead animals and becoming infected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPaul Ettestad\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \nPaul Ettestad, the Department of Health's public health veterinarian,\nencourages people to follow the same precautions they would to avoid\nplague: Don't allow pets to roam and hunt, use a tick/flea control\nproduct on pets and don't handle sick or dead rodents or rabbits. \n\nWe have had laboratory confirmed tularemia in 2 rabbits, one from an\narea called La Cienega (several miles southwest of the city of Santa\nFe, picked up dead on 9 Apr 2009) and another one from just west of\nthe city limits of Santa Fe (picked up dead on 8 Apr 2009). \n\nIt is difficult to predict whether animal cases in early spring will\ntranslate to an increase in human cases (there was only one human\ncase of plague and one human case of tularemia in New Mexico in 2008)\n \n\nThe Department is not collecting any more rabbits from these areas,\nbut asks people to use a shovel to either bury the dead rabbits in\nthe ground or to double bag them in the trash if they are allowed to\ndispose of them in this manner. \n\n'We have received several phone calls over the last 2 weeks from\nconcerned citizens in Santa Fe County who have found dead rabbits\nnear their homes or in recreational areas that they frequent,'\n We also\nhad a dead rabbit from the north end of Santa Fe (picked up dead on\n31 Mar 2009) that tested positive for plague, _Yersinia pestis_.\n We have tested several of these rabbits and 2 of them\nhave come back positive for tularemia, one from the La Cienega area\nand one from west of the city of Santa Fe near the 599 Relief Route. MHJ] There\nwere no human or pet cases associated with these dead rabbits and no\nantibiotic prophylaxis was needed. \nThe New Mexico Department of Health is warning people that rabbits\nare getting sick and dying from a bacterial disease called tularemia. I also believe that modifying human behavior can go a\nlong way to reducing risk and the number of human and pet cases,\nhence our news release warnings. Source: Office of the Secretary, NM Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/>\n\n\nDepartment of Health warns about tularemia in rabbits\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Cienega", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "97131", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia: (Moscow)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=97131", "date": "2008-07-22 19:00:27", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (MOSCOW)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 21 July 2008\nSource: Newspaper 'Moskovsky komsomoletz' [translated by Corr. BA] [edited]\n<http://www.mk.ru/blogs/idmk/2008/07/21/mk-daily/362939/>\n\n\nPhysicians from an infectious clinical hospital have reported the 1st\ncase of tularemia in Moscow in 2008. A 53-year-old Muscovite had\nacquired tularemia in Naro-Fominsk, a Moscow suburban area, where he\nwas on vacation in the country. For several days he fished and\ncollected mushrooms. Symptoms of the infection began on 26 Jun 2008\nwith fever and groin swelling. Self-treatment had no success.\n\nIn the hospital his illness was suspected as tularemia and the\ndiagnosis was confirmed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tularemia is endemic, not emerging, in the region, but is reported here\nbecause it is listed as a Schedule A potential bioterror agent. There\nis, of course, no suggestion that this case was due to bioterrorism.\nSee images of a case at:\n<http://www.newscientist.com/data/images/ns/cms/dn12960/dn12960-1_500.jpg>\n& of the causative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ at:\n<http://www.lcusd.net/lchs/mewoldsen/Image15.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\nPeriodically tularemia is observed in the European part of Russia.\nThe most significant outbreak was recorded in 2005 in the Nizhny\nNovgorod, Voronezh, Moscow, and Vladimir regions. In total 334 people\nwere hospitalized with symptoms of tularemia. The disease was\nlaboratory confirmed in 128 cases -- see ProMED refs. below. - Mod.NP\n\nThe glandular (or ulceroglandular if an ulcer was present distally)\ntularemia may have been acquired from an exposure to a [wild] animal\n[such as a rabbit or hare] during his vacation, from [contaminated]\nwater, or via an arthropod bite.\n\nThe Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 21 July 2008\n See images of a case at:\n<http://www.newscientist.com/data/images/ns/cms/dn12960/dn12960-1_500.jpg>\n& of the causative bacterium _Francisella tularensis_ at:\n<http://www.lcusd.net/lchs/mewoldsen/Image15.jpg>\n- Mod. A 53-year-old Muscovite had\nacquired tularemia in Naro-Fominsk, a Moscow suburban area, where he\nwas on vacation in the country. TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (MOSCOW)\n***************************\n The Moscow area can be found on a map at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9909/14/moscow.explosion.03/russia.moscow.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-06-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Voronezh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "105577", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, feline - USA: (NV)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=105577", "date": "2008-08-25 22:00:29", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, FELINE - USA: (NEVADA)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 22 Aug 2008\nSource: Reno Gazette-Journal (NV) [edited]\n<http://news.rgj.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080822/MVN04/808220435/1041/MVN>\n\n\nSmith Valley has the 1st case in Nevada of tularemia transmitted from\na cat to a human in 50 years. A woman took her sick cat to the vet;\nit was misdiagnosed with kidney problems and sent home with\nmedication. The woman gave the pet its pills using her finger to\nforce them down its throat; little did she know that a small cut on\nher finger would be the avenue for which tularemia would enter her\nbody.\n\nThe patient is now recovering after a harrowing month. The tularemia\ninfected her finger, which became painful and inflamed, then she\nstarted running a high fever, she went to the emergency room on\nseveral separate occasions where she was given antibiotics, which\nseemed to calm the symptoms for several days and then the whole thing\nwould flare up again. Her sick cat had died weeks before.\n\nThe woman's neighbor in Smith Valley is a physician who came by her\nhouse, took one look at her finger, and told her things did not look\nwell. She went to his office where he opened up her finger, cleaned\nout the infection, and sent a culture to the lab. It was at this\npoint that the tularemia was pinpointed and a correct course of\ntreatment started.\n\n[Byline: Megan Hunewill-Wright]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This case contains enough information to confirm ulceroglandular\n_Francisella tularensis_ infection from a cat exposure. Although not\na common scenario for transmission of this zoonosis to man, it has\nbeen described in both North America and Europe (1-4).\n\n1. Capellan J, Fong I: Tularemia from a cat bite: case report and\nreview of feline-associated tularemia. Clin Infect Dis. 1993; 16:\n472-5.\n2. von Schroeder HP, McDougall EP: Ulceroglandular and pulmonary\ntularemia: a case resulting from a cat bite to the hand. J Hand Surg\n[Am]. 1993; 18: 132-4.\n3. Arav-Boger R: Cat-bite tularemia in a seventeen-year-old girl\ntreated with ciprofloxacin. Pediatr Infect Dis J. 2000; 19: 583-4.\n4. Yaqub S, Bjornholt JV, Enger AE: [Tularemia from a cat bite] [in\nNorwegian]. Tidsskr Nor Laegeforen. 2004; 124: 3197-8.\n\nThe state of Nevada, in the western United States can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.\nSmith Valley is located in Lyon County, in the southwestern part of\nthe state. TULAREMIA, HUMAN, FELINE - USA: (NEVADA)\n****************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Capellan J, Fong I: Tularemia from a cat bite: case report and\nreview of feline-associated tularemia. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This case contains enough information to confirm ulceroglandular\n_Francisella tularensis_ infection from a cat exposure. von Schroeder HP, McDougall EP: Ulceroglandular and pulmonary\ntularemia: a case resulting from a cat bite to the hand.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-04 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smith Valley", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lyon County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "103310", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain: (northern) 2007", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=103310", "date": "2008-08-15 21:00:29", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN: (NORTHERN) 2007\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 14 Aug 2008\nSource: Nortecastilla.es [trans. by JG] [edited]\n<http://www.nortecastilla.es/20080810/castilla_leon/cada-cuatro-casos-tularemia-20080810.html>\n\n\nA study performed by the European Center for Disease Control\nconfirmed that a quarter of the cases of tularemia detected during\nthe outbreak that affected 5 provinces, between June and December\n2007, was caused by direct contact with rodents. The report places\nthe 2007 outbreak as the greatest during the last decade in Castilla and Leon.\n\nData from the European institution roughly coincide with the latest\nstudies elaborated by the Board, and they calculated that the number\nof affected persons is 507, 3 times more compared to the figure\nreported by the Regional Authority in Leon, Palencia, Burgos,\nValladolid, and Zamora provinces. This figure was outnumbered in\n1997, with 534 cases treated, while some outbreaks were much less\nprominent, such as 2004 when 13 cases were reported.\n\nFeatures of patients infected with _Francisella tularensis_, the\ncausative agent of tularemia, include being male (80.1 percent),\nbetween 41 and 70 years of age. The great majority of affected\npersons lived in rural areas or had frequent contact with this\nenvironment. The study points out that 34.9 percent of infected\npersons were farmers or field-related workers, or people who enjoyed\nnatural environments who 'frequently took long walks' in these areas.\nAll of these persons acquired the disease by dust inhaling during\nagricultural activities or the like.\n\nWith respect to the 'live foci' in this outbreak, the reservoir is\nthe vole (_Microtus duodecimcostatus_), which in 2007 severely\naffected most fields in the region. 24.3 percent of infections were\ncaused by the rodents, while domestic animals, particularly dogs and\ncats, caused 19.7 percent of infections and water crabs were\nassociated with 13.2 percent. The remaining cases were caused by\nmosquito bites (10.9 percent), contact with other animals (9.5\npercent), using non-potable water (8.1 percent), hare manipulation\n(6.5 percent), manipulating straw and alfalfa (4.9 percent), and a\nminimal percentage (0.2 percent) was attributed to eating raw meat.\n\nThe initial cases occurred during 1st half of May 2007 and they\nreached a maximum between 18 Jun 2008 and 22 Oct 2008, when 90\npercent of the infections were concentrated.\n\nPatients had a mean incubation time for the infection between 1 to 14\ndays, and they took between 3 and 6 weeks to recover. They had the\nfollowing clinical symptoms: typhoidal form (59 percent),\nulceroglandular (14.6 percent), glandular (12.6 percent) and\npneumonic (7.9 percent).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promail.org>\n\n[Photo of vole (_Microtus duodecimcostatus_):\n<http://www.sierradebaza.org/Fichas_fauna/05_10_topillo-mediterraneo/img_1.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\n\nSpain and the provinces involved can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.themapshop.co.uk/images/spain/spainprov.gif>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The remaining cases were caused by\nmosquito bites (10.9 percent), contact with other animals (9.5\npercent), using non-potable water (8.1 percent), hare manipulation\n(6.5 percent), manipulating straw and alfalfa (4.9 percent), and a\nminimal percentage (0.2 percent) was attributed to eating raw meat. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 14 Aug 2008\n 24.3 percent of infections were\ncaused by the rodents, while domestic animals, particularly dogs and\ncats, caused 19.7 percent of infections and water crabs were\nassociated with 13.2 percent.
