Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promail.org>\n\n[Photo of vole (_Microtus duodecimcostatus_):\n<http://www.sierradebaza.org/Fichas_fauna/05_10_topillo-mediterraneo/img_1.jpg>\n- Mod. A study performed by the European Center for Disease Control\nconfirmed that a quarter of the cases of tularemia detected during\nthe outbreak that affected 5 provinces, between June and December\n2007, was caused by direct contact with rodents. The initial cases occurred during 1st half of May 2007 and they\nreached a maximum between 18 Jun 2008 and 22 Oct 2008, when 90\npercent of the infections were concentrated.\n\n The study points out that 34.9 percent of infected\npersons were farmers or field-related workers, or people who enjoyed\nnatural environments who 'frequently took long walks' in these areas. \n\nFeatures of patients infected with _Francisella tularensis_, the\ncausative agent of tularemia, include being male (80.1 percent),\nbetween 41 and 70 years of age. With respect to the 'live foci' in this outbreak, the reservoir is\nthe vole (_Microtus duodecimcostatus_), which in 2007 severely\naffected most fields in the region. This figure was outnumbered in\n1997, with 534 cases treated, while some outbreaks were much less\nprominent, such as 2004 when 13 cases were reported. The great majority of affected\npersons lived in rural areas or had frequent contact with this\nenvironment. Patients had a mean incubation time for the infection between 1 to 14\ndays, and they took between 3 and 6 weeks to recover. The report places\nthe 2007 outbreak as the greatest during the last decade in Castilla and Leon. All of these persons acquired the disease by dust inhaling during\nagricultural activities or the like. \n\n--\n TULAREMIA - SPAIN: (NORTHERN) 2007\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zamora", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "87013", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, pneumonic - USA: (NYC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=87013", "date": "2008-06-12 16:00:23", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA: (NEW YORK CITY)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 11 June 2008\nSource: New York City Dept of Health & Mental Hygiene (DOHMH), Bureau of\nCommunicable Disease [edited]\n<http://home2.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/cd/cd.shtml>\n\nThe New York City DOHMH is investigating a laboratory-confirmed case of\npneumonic tularemia in a Brooklyn resident. The patient presented to the\nhospital in early June 2008 with a one-week history of fever, headache,\nsweats, left sided pleuritic chest pain, and shortness of breath.\n\nPleural fluid culture yielded small, slow-growing Gram negative bacteria\nthat were referred to the New York City Public Health Laboratory for\nidentification. The organism was confirmed as _Francisella tularensis_. The\npatient reported camping in Gateway National Recreation Area in Brooklyn 4\ndays prior to the onset of his symptoms.\n\nTularemia is rare in New York City; however, cases have been reported in\nall New York City boroughs except for the Bronx. Since 1965, there have\nbeen 15 other reported cases, with the last case occurring in 2007 in a\nStaten Island child. In the USA, about 100-200 cases are reported annually,\nwith most occurring in the south, central, and western states; the case\nfatality rate is about 1.0 per cent.\n\nTularemia is caused by _F. tularensis_, a small, non-motile, Gram negative\nintracellular coccobacillus. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts,\nnotably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers,\nand water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels,\nand cats. A USA outbreak involving commercially distributed prairie dogs\noccurred in 2002.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and\nvegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental\nconditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as,\n_Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may\nrepresent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental\nexposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious\nanimal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated\nfood, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. In one case,\nbacteria were aerosolized from the fur of a dog as it shook itself off\nafter entering a home. Finally, there are several reports of tularemia in\nhumans following bites from infected domestic cats. It is highly\ninfectious, with as few as 10 organisms needed to cause disease. Humans can\ndevelop severe and sometimes fatal illness, but do not transmit the disease\nto others. The typical incubation period is 3 to 5 days, with a range of\none to 14 days.\n\nThe clinical presentation of tularemia depends on the route of exposure.\nAirborne _F. tularensis_ would mainly cause pleuropneumonitis. Exposures\nthat penetrate broken skin result in ulceroglandular or glandular disease.\nThe onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and\nrigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza,\nand sore throat. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea may occur. Sweats, fever,\nchills, progressive weakness, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss\ncharacterize the continuing illness.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not related to bioterrorism, tularemia is a Category A\nbioterrorism agent and the pneumonic form is likely to be the one\nassociated with intentional spread.\n\nProMED-mail thanks the Bureau of Communicable Disease of the NY City\nDepartment of Health and Mental Hygiene for allowing posting of this case,\nnot yet in the public domain. ProMED-mail has posted 2 other cases of\npneumonic tularemia acquired in New York City over the past 10 years.\n\nThe Gateway National Recreation Area is in southern Brooklyn and can be\nseen (in purple) on a map of the borough at\n<http://www.wynn.com/bol/images/brooklyn.map.gif>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be recovered from contaminated water, soil, and\nvegetation as it can persist for weeks under ideal environmental\nconditions. _F. tularensis_ also can be found in amoebas (such as,\n_Acanthamoeba_), which can become airborne in some settings, and may\nrepresent a significant environmental reservoir for this bacterium.\n\nHumans can become incidentally infected through diverse environmental\nexposures: bites by infected ticks and deerflies; contact with infectious\nanimal tissues or fluids; direct contact with or ingestion of contaminated\nfood, water, or soil; and inhalation of infective aerosols. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 11 June 2008\n Source: New York City Dept of Health & Mental Hygiene (DOHMH), Bureau of\nCommunicable Disease [edited]\n<http://home2.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/cd/cd.shtml>\n\nThe New York City DOHMH is investigating a laboratory-confirmed case of\npneumonic tularemia in a Brooklyn resident. It can be found in a variety of animal hosts,\nnotably lagomorphs (rabbits and hares), aquatic rodents (muskrats, beavers,\nand water voles), other rodents (water and wood rats and mice), squirrels,\nand cats. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not related to bioterrorism, tularemia is a Category A\nbioterrorism agent and the pneumonic form is likely to be the one\nassociated with intentional spread. \n\nProMED-mail thanks the Bureau of Communicable Disease of the NY City\nDepartment of Health and Mental Hygiene for allowing posting of this case,\nnot yet in the public domain. \n\nPleural fluid culture yielded small, slow-growing Gram negative bacteria\nthat were referred to the New York City Public Health Laboratory for\nidentification. In the USA, about 100-200 cases are reported annually,\nwith most occurring in the south, central, and western states; the case\nfatality rate is about 1.0 per cent. The onset of tularemia is usually abrupt, with fever, headache, chills and\nrigors, generalized body aches (often prominent in the low back), coryza,\nand sore throat.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1965-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City Dept of Health & Mental Hygiene", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "41454", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, hunter - Russia: (Amur)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=41454", "date": "2007-12-07 15:01:24", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUNTER - RUSSIA: (AMUR)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 Dec 2007\nSource: Itar-Tass News Agency [edited]\n<http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=12158837&PageNum=0>\n\n\nA case of tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, has been registered\nin the Amur region for the 1st time over the past 50 years, the\nregional sanitary and epidemiological commission said at a meeting on\nFri 7 Dec 2007.\n\nThe diagnosis was confirmed on a hunter of the Selemdzhin district,\nwho was bitten by a sable. Regional sanitary doctors plan to begin\nvaccination of a risk group that includes hunters, foresters, and\ngeologists of the Selemdzhin and Mazanovsky districts.\n\nNatural cases of tularemia occur across North America, Europe, and\nAsia. It is a disease that humans can catch either from tick, fly,\nand mosquito bites or from animal contact.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of tularemia in the hunter are not stated but may\nwell been ulceroglandular. The sable is a small mammal, closely\nrelated to the marten, that lives in southern Russia near the Ural\nMountains through Siberia and Mongolia to Hokkaido in Japan. Its\nrange in the wild originally extended through European Russia to\nPoland and Scandinavia. It has achieved fame for its fur. A picture\ncan be found at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sable>.\n\nDespite the apparent rarity of diagnosis in Amur, tularemia is\nendemic in Russia including the entire Asian part.\n\nThe Amur Oblast is a federal region of Russia (an oblast), situated\nabout 8000 km (4970 mi) east of Moscow on the banks of the Amur and\nZeya Rivers. It can be found on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amur_Oblast>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 7 Dec 2007\n A case of tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, has been registered\nin the Amur region for the 1st time over the past 50 years, the\nregional sanitary and epidemiological commission said at a meeting on\nFri 7 Dec 2007. Regional sanitary doctors plan to begin\nvaccination of a risk group that includes hunters, foresters, and\ngeologists of the Selemdzhin and Mazanovsky districts. The Amur Oblast is a federal region of Russia (an oblast), situated\nabout 8000 km (4970 mi) east of Moscow on the banks of the Amur and\nZeya Rivers. The sable is a small mammal, closely\nrelated to the marten, that lives in southern Russia near the Ural\nMountains through Siberia and Mongolia to Hokkaido in Japan. TULAREMIA, HUNTER - RUSSIA: (AMUR)\n**********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["4970-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "67380", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Thailand: (Prachuap Khiri Khan), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=67380", "date": "2008-03-18 20:00:19", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - THAILAND: (PRACHUAP KHIRI KHAN), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 18 Mar 2008\nSource: Bangkok Post [edited]\n<http://www.bangkokpost.com/News/18Mar2008_news03.php>\n\n\nThe Public Health Ministry yesterday [17 Mar 2008] declared tularemia an\nemerging disease in Thailand after its 1st victim was diagnosed in Prachuap\nKhiri Khan. Disease Control Department director-general Thawat Sundarachan\nsaid a 37 year old woman who suffered from cancer was Thailand's 1st\ntularemia, or rabbit fever, fatality. Tularemia is a disease borne by\nrodents and rabbits, and is endemic in North America and Europe.\n\nDr Thawat said the woman, whose name was withheld, had kept a number of\nrabbits in her house and could have been infected by _Francisella\ntularensis_, the bacterium that causes the disease, probably through an\naerosol of body secretions from her infected pets. Dr Thawat dismissed\nconcerns about an outbreak, saying that there is no threat of\nhuman-to-human transmission and that relatives of the dead, who live under\nthe same roof, should not worry. Cancer might have made the woman too weak\nto fight the disease, he said.\n\nThe ministry is waiting for the results of another lab test from the USA to\nsee if the rabbit fever is of strains A or B which are more dangerous. The\nresults are expected in 2 weeks.\n\nThe chief of the public health office in Prachuap Khiri Khan, Pipop\nJanesuthivejjakul, appeared unshaken by the news of the disease. He said\nthe public should not panic over the news of the woman's death which took\nplace in Kui Buri district last October [2007]. The provincial office knew\nof no other victims in the country.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 18 Mar 2008\nSource: Bloomberg [edited]\n<http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=aR6p_q726XKs&refer=asia>\n\n\nTularemia killed a woman in Thailand, marking the country's 1st reported\ncase of the disease. The 37 year old from Prachuap Kiri Khan province,\nabout 320 kilometers (200 miles) south of Bangkok, died late last month\n[Feb 2008] and the cause of her death was confirmed by laboratory tests in\nthe USA, said an official at the Public Health Ministry today. Tularemia,\nalso known as rabbit fever, is caused by a bacterium found in animals,\nespecially rabbits and hares, and is treated with antibiotics.\n\nTularemia is endemic in many parts of the world, including North America,\nEastern Europe, China, Japan and Scandinavia, according to the World Health\nOrganization in Geneva. Tularemia can be contracted through the bite of an\ninfected tick, deerfly, or other insect, handling infected animal carcasses\nor through inhaling the bacteria, according to the Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention in Atlanta. It's not known to spread from person to\nperson.\n\n[byline: Suttinee Yuvejwattana]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[More information is needed about this case, including whether these were\nlocally bred rabbits or imported from an endemic area. Tularemia pneumonia\ncan be fatal if not recognized quickly. Although tularemia is a category A\nbioterrorism disease which can be transmitted with a low inoculum of\norganisms and unlike plague pneumonia, the disease does not seem to spread\nfrom person to person. One post says the case occurred in October 2007 and\nthe other in February 2008. Likewise, one post says it is the 1st fatality\ndue to tularemia in Thailand (implying that other cases have occurred) and\nthe other post says it is the 1st case.\n\nThailand's Prachuap Kiri Khan province is located on the Kra Isthmus, the\nnarrow land bridge connecting the Malay Peninsula with mainland Asia. It\ncan be seen on a map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prachuap_Khiri_Khan_Province>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nDr Thawat said the woman, whose name was withheld, had kept a number of\nrabbits in her house and could have been infected by _Francisella\ntularensis_, the bacterium that causes the disease, probably through an\naerosol of body secretions from her infected pets. Although tularemia is a category A\nbioterrorism disease which can be transmitted with a low inoculum of\norganisms and unlike plague pneumonia, the disease does not seem to spread\nfrom person to person. Tularemia can be contracted through the bite of an\ninfected tick, deerfly, or other insect, handling infected animal carcasses\nor through inhaling the bacteria, according to the Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention in Atlanta. \n\n[byline: Suttinee Yuvejwattana]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Dr Thawat dismissed\nconcerns about an outbreak, saying that there is no threat of\nhuman-to-human transmission and that relatives of the dead, who live under\nthe same roof, should not worry. Disease Control Department director-general Thawat Sundarachan\nsaid a 37 year old woman who suffered from cancer was Thailand's 1st\ntularemia, or rabbit fever, fatality. Likewise, one post says it is the 1st fatality\ndue to tularemia in Thailand (implying that other cases have occurred) and\nthe other post says it is the 1st case. Source: Bloomberg [edited]\n<http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=aR6p_q726XKs&refer=asia>\n\n\nTularemia killed a woman in Thailand, marking the country's 1st reported\ncase of the disease. [17 Mar 2008] declared tularemia an\nemerging disease in Thailand after its 1st victim was diagnosed in Prachuap\nKhiri Khan. \n\nTularemia is endemic in many parts of the world, including North America,\nEastern Europe, China, Japan and Scandinavia, according to the World Health\nOrganization in Geneva.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-02-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-10-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangkok", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kui Buri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "59172", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, hare, 2007 - Germany: (Baden-Wuerttemberg)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=59172", "date": "2008-02-18 20:00:19", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, HARE, 2007 - GERMANY: (BADEN-WUERTTEMBERG)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 14 Feb 2008\nSource: Eurosurveillance weekly release, 2008 13(7) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/edition/v13n07/080214_1.asp>\n\n\nAfter contact with a dead rabbit in Baden-Wuerttemberg in southern\nGermany, 3 members of a family were infected with tularemia in late\nsummer 2007. The patients were a forest worker (patient A) in his\n20s, and his parents, both in their 50s. Tularemia is very rare in\nGermany. From 2002 to 2006, between one and 5 cases were reported\nannually, with the exception of 2005 with 15 reported cases (1). In\n2007, 19 cases were reported, 11 of them in Baden-Wuerttemberg (2).\nIn the district in which the 3 cases occurred, no tularemia cases had\nbeen reported in recent years.\n\nCase description\n----------------\nIn late August 2007, a hare was run over by a car driven by patient A\nand the local forester. The animal was heavily injured and was put\ndown by the forester. Patient A took the dead hare home and skinned\nit together with his father on the same day. His mother then stored\nthe hare in the freezer. Three days later, patient A's father\ncomplained of influenza-like symptoms, fever of 39-40 deg C (102-104\ndeg F), headache, and joint pain. On the next day, patient A and his\nmother developed the same symptoms, and also experienced dizziness. A\n4th family member who had not been at home on the day the hare was\nskinned did not show any symptoms.\n\nOver the course of the following weeks, the 3 patients suffered\nmainly from influenza-like symptoms, and felt increasingly weak.\nPatient A's mother reported impaired wound healing with regard to a\nblister on a finger of her right hand (a possible entry site for\npathogens) that was caused by a burn and healed only after weeks.\nLaboratory investigations by the family doctor returned only\nunspecific inflammatory serum parameters. X-ray and sonography\nsupplied no evidence pointing towards a diagnosis of tularemia.\n\nIn mid-October 2007, patient A's father developed swollen lymph nodes\nin his left axilla and left elbow. The lymph node in his elbow\ndeveloped an abscess and was extirpated at the university clinic in\nUlm, Germany. Patient A and his mother also presented with swollen\nlymph nodes, the mother in the right axilla and the left elbow, the\nson in the left axilla. The resulting abscesses were removed at their\nregional hospital.\n\nThe 4th family member works at a medical diagnostic center. As the\ninfluenza-like symptoms in her family persisted for several weeks,\nshe took a serum sample from patient A's father in mid-October 2007,\nabout 2 months after he had skinned the hare, and had it analysed at\nher work-place. Two weeks later, the center detected elevated\nantibody titers against _Francisella tularensis_ in the serum: an IgG\ntiter of 1:2560 compared to normal values of under 1:40, and an IgM\ntiter of 1:160 compared to a normal of under 1:20, as measured by\nimmunofluorescence test (IFT).\n\nA positive serology for tularemia is defined as a 4-fold or higher\nincrease in specific antibodies to _F. tularensis_. The patients, as\nwell as the hospital in which patient A and his mother had been\ntreated, were informed immediately of the diagnosis indicative of\nacute or recent tularemia.\n\nLaboratory investigation\n------------------------\nThree days later, the hospital informed the district public health\nauthorities about a positive diagnosis of tularemia in a relative of\n2 patients that had been released after lymph node extirpation. At\nthe request of the district public health office, the diagnostic\ncenter sent serum from patient A's father to the German consultant\nlaboratory for tularemia in Munich. Tularemia infection was confirmed\nfor all 3 family members.\n\nThe local veterinary authorities collected the frozen hare from the\nfamily's freezer and took it to a veterinary laboratory for analysis.\nThat institute arranged for the transfer of the hare to the German\nconsultant laboratory for tularemia, where infection of the hare with\n_F. tularensis_ was confirmed in culture and with molecular techniques.\n\nTreatment\n---------\nDue to the suspicion of tularemia, the 3 patients were treated with\nantimicrobials by their family doctor immediately after the diagnosis\nby the diagnostic center. In addition, the family received advice\nfrom the local veterinary office on the necessary measures, such as\ndisinfection of the freezer. The local foresters were informed about\nthe possible infection of the hares in the area.\n\nIn January 2008, the district public health office instigated a\nfollow-up laboratory examination of the family, which was performed\nby the state public health office of Baden-Wuerttemberg with the\nfollowing result: IFT (immunofluorescence test) antibody titers (IgG\nand IgM) in the serum of the 3 family members with clinical symptoms\nhad gone down compared to the previous examination (IgG greater than\n400 U/mL; IgM greater than 500 U/mL in all 3 cases). As expected, the\ndaughter's IFT antibody count was normal.\n\nThis report was published in German in the public health bulletin of\nthe Robert-Koch Institute on 25 Jan 2008: Epidemiologisches Bulletin\nno. 4/2008. Available from\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_049/nn_969736/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2008/04__08,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/04_08.pdf>.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Robert-Koch Institut: Infektionsepidemiologisches Jahrbuch\nmeldepflichtiger Krankheiten fur 2006 (Datenstand 1 Mar 2007).\nAvailable (in German) from\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_049/nn_196882/DE/Content/Infekt/Jahrbuch/Jahrbuch__2006,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/Jahrbuch_2006.pdf>.\n2. Robert-Koch Institut: Aktuelle Statistik meldepflichtiger\nInfektionskrankheiten 52. Woche 2007 (Datenstand 16 Jan 2008).\nEpidemiologisches Bulletin 3/2008. 18 Jan 2008. Available (in German) from\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_049/nn_969736/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2008/03__08,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/03_08.pdf>.\n\n[Schatzle W (<Wolfgang.Schaetzle@biberach.de>), Schwenk R]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In 2 of the past 3 years, the number of reported cases of tularemia\nin Germany has been higher. The 2005 'bump' was caused by a single\ncluster noted below, but it is not clear that this was the case with\nthe 2007 'bump'.\n\nAlthough classically transmitted to man via infected animals such as\nrabbits or a tick vector, infection with _Francisella tularensis_ (a\nCategory A biowarfare disease) may be acquired from contact with soil\nor water harboring the bacterium. Although tularemia pneumonia, which\ndid not occur in this outbreak, is the form of the disease associated\nwith biological terrorism, it may also occur naturally, as is\nexemplified by the sporadic case described in New York City and the\noutbreak among gardeners on Martha's Vineyard, both cited in past\nProMED-mail postings below.\n\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n\nA previous cluster of tularemia with 10 cases including one death\noccurred in Germany in 2005 in the Hesse state just north of\nBaden-Wuerttemberg. Baden-Wuerttemberg is a Land (state) of the\nFederal Republic of Germany in the southwestern part of the country\nto the east of the Upper Rhine and can be seen on a map of the country at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg>.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: [Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol\n2001; 6 (Suppl): 68-72.\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol 1987; 3: 35-8.\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: [An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol] 1997; 2: 33-7. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "In January 2008, the district public health office instigated a\nfollow-up laboratory examination of the family, which was performed\nby the state public health office of Baden-Wuerttemberg with the\nfollowing result: IFT (immunofluorescence test) antibody titers (IgG\nand IgM) in the serum of the 3 family members with clinical symptoms\nhad gone down compared to the previous examination (IgG greater than\n400 U/mL; IgM greater than 500 U/mL in all 3 cases). Although tularemia pneumonia, which\ndid not occur in this outbreak, is the form of the disease associated\nwith biological terrorism, it may also occur naturally, as is\nexemplified by the sporadic case described in New York City and the\noutbreak among gardeners on Martha's Vineyard, both cited in past\nProMED-mail postings below. Corr.BA, edited]\n<http://www.rosbalt.ru/2007/09/05/411171.html>\n\nIn Berezov district (Khanti-Mansiysky autonomous region), the number\nof patients with tularemia has increased to 23 persons. It is\nreported that, all infected persons, among them 3 children, have been\nhospitalized. It is thought that rodents are the source of infection.\nRodents' burrows were flooded because of high level of water,\ntherefore the animals had to search for new habitation close to\n[human] settlements. Insects may have played a significant role in\ntransmission of infection.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In Russia, tularemia cases are reported, with 100-400 cases\nannually; 70 percent of cases are in the Northern, Central, and\nWestern-Siberian areas of Russia. The nature zones have time\nvariations when their epizootic and epidemiological activity can be\nreplaced by interepidemic 3.5-9 years periods.\nSeasonal variations of tularemia morbidity are varied in different\nzones and depend on a number of reasons (including the activity of\ninfected rodents, activity of carriers (insects), and activity of\npeople). Most likely, in this region a set of various factors has\nplayed a role in the acute increase of tularemia cases. - Corr.BA]\n[In addition to transmission of _F. tularensis_ related to contact\nwith infected animals and via arthropod bites, the infection can be\nspread through water. The symptom complex in the patients has not\nbeen stated in the reports, which can assist in delineating a mode of\ntransmission.\nThe Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. It is a part of the Tyumen Region. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Seasonal variations of tularemia morbidity are varied in different\nzones and depend on a number of reasons (including the activity of\ninfected rodents, activity of carriers (insects), and activity of\npeople). \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed@promedmail.org [In Russia, tularemia cases are reported, with 100-400 cases\nannually; 70 percent of cases are in the Northern, Central, and\nWestern-Siberian areas of Russia. To date, there is no information presented on the methods\nof transmission of the infection and disease forms in patients\ninvolved in the outbreak.\nAccording to the report of Rospotrebnadzor, in 2006 in Russia 65\ntularemia cases were reported (incidence rate was 0.05 per 100 000 as\ncompared to 0.61 per 100 000 in 2005), the greatest quantity of cases\nwas noted in Altai Republic (9 cases), in Nizhniy Novgorod oblast (7\ncases) and in Moscow (6 cases)\n(<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/docs/doclad>).\n- Mod.NP]\n[The Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. It is a part of the Tyumen Region. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "According to the report of Rospotrebnadzor, in 2006 in Russia 65\ntularemia cases were reported (incidence rate was 0.05 per 100 000 as\ncompared to 0.61 per 100 000 in 2005), the greatest quantity of cases\nwas noted in Altai Republic (9 cases), in Nizhniy Novgorod oblast (7\ncases) and in Moscow (6 cases)\n(<http://www.rospotrebnadzor.ru/docs/doclad>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n It is reported that, in the period between 24 Aug until 30 Aug 2007,\nthe settlement hospital admitted 11 persons with the diagnosis of\ntularemia including 3 children.\n In the settlement of Berezovo (Khanti-Mansiysky autonomous region)\nover the last week the number of patients with tularemia has\nincreased to 19 persons as informed by press service of\n'Antielements-Jugra' Center. To date, there is no information presented on the methods\nof transmission of the infection and disease forms in patients\ninvolved in the outbreak.\n Contributed by:\nProMED-mail\n< [The tularemia outbreak in the settlement of Berezovo started on 16\n TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (KHANTI-MANSIYSKY) (02)\n Date: Fri 31 Aug 2007\n Source: Interfax [in Russian, trans. by BA] [edited]\n<http://www.interfax.ru/r/B/ural/289.html?menu=33&id_issue=11849124>\n\n [The Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. promed@promedmail.org>\n **\n \n \n \n- Mod. NP]\n Aug 2007.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Altai Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berezovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "24515", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia (Khanti-Mansiysky)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=24515", "date": "2007-08-26 20:00:11", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (KHANTI-MANSIYSKY)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 24 Aug 2007\nSource: Nakanune.ru [trans. Corr.ARS, edited]\n<http://www.nakanune.ru/news/2007/08/24/291400>\n\nAccording to the report of regional Rospotrebnadzor (Federal\nSupervision Agency for Customer Protection and Human Welfare), 7\ncases of tularemia were registered in the settlement of Berezovo from\n16 to 23 Aug 2007. Four cases have been confirmed by laboratory tests.\nA local authority has commissioned a plan for action to control the\nspread of infection. The movement of non-immunized people to the\nareas of risk is prohibited. Mass-information campaigns have been\nlaunched to deliver health and prevention information. A\nnon-scheduled immunization for tularemia has been planned. House\nvisits are being performed to identify sick people, to control rodent\ninvasion, and to supply repellents.\nNakanune reports that 191 884 people have received vaccine against\ntularemia during the last 6 years, 27 400 of them in 2006. During the\n6 months of 2007, 51.3 percent of the eligible population have\nreceived the vaccine.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Sporadic cases of tularemia are common in different regions of\nRussia, as the disease is endemic for all the country. Outbreaks,\nhowever, are emergent events, even if of local scale. The suspected\nroute of infection and the clinical form or forms are not given in this report.\nThe Khanti-Mansiysky Autonomous Okrug (also called Yugra) is located\non the West Siberian Plain. It is a part of the Tyumen Region. - Mod.NP/LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n ARS, edited]\n<http://www.nakanune.ru/news/2007/08/24/291400>\n\nAccording to the report of regional Rospotrebnadzor (Federal\nSupervision Agency for Customer Protection and Human Welfare), 7\ncases of tularemia were registered in the settlement of Berezovo from\n16 to 23 Aug 2007. During the\n6 months of 2007, 51.3 percent of the eligible population have\nreceived the vaccine.\n \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n House\nvisits are being performed to identify sick people, to control rodent\ninvasion, and to supply repellents. Nakanune reports that 191 884 people have received vaccine against\ntularemia during the last 6 years, 27 400 of them in 2006. [Sporadic cases of tularemia are common in different regions of\nRussia, as the disease is endemic for all the country. A local authority has commissioned a plan for action to control the\nspread of infection.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22631", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22631", "date": "2007-08-13 21:00:10", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN (NORTHERN): VOLE RESERVOIR (02)\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 11 Aug 2007\nFrom: Merritt Clifton <anmlpepl@whidbey.com>\n\nTo the extent that burning destroys the voles' food sources, it may\nhave some effect. However, burning fields does not directly kill many\nvoles. Voles (of practically all species) typically burrow far enough\nunderground that fast-burning grass fires and forest fires sweep\nright over them with no effect. They go into semi-hibernation to\nminimize their oxygen consumption and just wait the fire's out.\nBecause of this, voles are usually the 1st mammals to reappear\nanywhere after a bad fire. They were even back on the slopes of Mount\nSt. Helens within a very short time after the volcanic eruptions,\nwhich undoubtedly did kill many voles but many survived as well.\nTypically a fast moving fire bursts open many kinds of hard-shelled\nseeds such pinon nuts and pine nuts. Voles thrive on these seeds, and\ntheir population explodes. The voles then become food for hawks,\nowls, eagles, and small mammal predators including feral cats, dogs,\ncoyotes, jackals, bobcats, and lynx.\nVery often so-called 'mouse plagues' occur 6 months to a year\n(depending on climate) after extensive grass fires or forest fires.\nThese are actually population explosions of voles. Without knowing\nthe specific conditions where the fields are being torched in\nnorthern Spain, I would predict that they are going to get more voles\nsoon, not fewer.\n--\nMerritt Clifton\nEditor, Animal People\nClinton, WA\n<anmlpepl@whidbey.com>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mr. Clifton for his comments regarding this issue.\nTo better distinguish voles from mice\n(http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9075664/vole):\nVoles consist of any of 124 species of small-bodied mouse-like\nrodents of the Northern Hemisphere. Voles have a blunt rather than a\ntapered muzzle, a tail shorter than the body, and small eyes and\nears. Voles live in a wide variety of habitats at elevations ranging\nfrom sea level to high mountains. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Without knowing\nthe specific conditions where the fields are being torched in\nnorthern Spain, I would predict that they are going to get more voles\nsoon, not fewer.\n To better distinguish voles from mice\n(http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9075664/vole):\nVoles consist of any of 124 species of small-bodied mouse-like\nrodents of the Northern Hemisphere. They were even back on the slopes of Mount\nSt. Helens within a very short time after the volcanic eruptions,\nwhich undoubtedly did kill many voles but many survived as well.\n --\nMerritt Clifton\nEditor, Animal People\n Voles (of practically all species) typically burrow far enough\nunderground that fast-burning grass fires and forest fires sweep\nright over them with no effect. The voles then become food for hawks,\nowls, eagles, and small mammal predators including feral cats, dogs,\ncoyotes, jackals, bobcats, and lynx. Voles have a blunt rather than a\ntapered muzzle, a tail shorter than the body, and small eyes and\nears.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "St. Helens", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "35896", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain (03): (northern)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=35896", "date": "2007-11-08 18:00:24", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN (03): (NORTHERN)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Nov 2007\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/071108.asp#1>\n\n\nIn late June 2007, the Epidemiological Surveillance Network in\nCastilla y Leon, northern Spain, reported a series of cases in a\nrural area in the province of Palencia and in the provincial capital\ncity of Leon, labelled as 'fever of unknown origin.' Subsequent\nepidemiological investigation confirmed an outbreak of tularemia.\n\nOn 22 Oct 2007, the Epidemiological Surveillance Network in Castilla\ny Leon confirmed 362 cases of tularemia, using the case definition\nand confirmation criteria agreed to by the National Network for\nEpidemiological Surveillance together with the Epidemiological and\nControl Surveillance Network for Communicable Diseases in the\nEuropean Union (1,2).\n\nA clinical picture compatible with one of the different forms of\ntularemia included:\n-ulceroglandular (cutaneous ulcer with regional lymphadenopathy);\n-glandular (regional lymphadenopathy with no ulcer);\n-oculoglandular (conjunctivitis with preauricular lymphadenopathy),\n-oropharyngeal (stomatitis or pharyngitis or tonsillitis and cervical\nlymphadenopathy);\n-intestinal (intestinal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea);\n-pneumonic (primary pneumonic disease); and\n-typhoidal (febrile illness without early localizing signs and symptoms).\n\nLaboratory criteria for diagnosis:\n-isolation of _Francisella tularensis_ from a clinical specimen;\n-detection of _Francisella tularensis_ genome by PCR; or\n-demonstration of a specific antibody response in paired serum samples.\n\nCase classification of confirmed case: a clinically compatible case\nthat is confirmed by laboratory.\n\nCases were confirmed using serological techniques (microagglutination\nin 74.8 percent and tube agglutination in 25.2 percent), culture in 6\npercent or PCR in 2 percent. _F. tularensis_ subspecies holarctica\nhas been identified as the causative agent of the outbreak.\n\nThe onset of symptoms in half of the cases occurred between\nepidemiological weeks 28 (ending 14 Jul 2007) and 31 (ending 4 Aug\n2007); 81.4 percent of reported cases were males and 18.6 percent\nfemales. Some 62.5 percent of cases were concentrated in the 45 to 64\nyear old age group, although all ages were affected (6 to 88 years old).\n\nThe presentation of the disease in the cases analysed to date is\nshown in the table [the table revealed that 56.6 percent of the cases\nwere typhoidal, 16 percent ulceroglandular, 12.1 percent glandular,\n7.7 percent pneumonia and a scattering of other presentations - Mod.LL].\n\nSome 74.6 percent of the cases were treated as outpatients by general\npractitioners, while the rest required hospitalization. Patient\nrecovery in all cases was favorable, with a good response to the\nprescribed treatment and few complications. The most frequently used\nantimicrobials in this outbreak have been ciprofloxacin and\ndoxycycline, but other fluroquinolones and tetracyclines were also used.\n\nThe epidemiological surveillance showed that 33.7 percent of cases\nwere farm workers or people whose jobs involve contact with the\nenvironment (for example, gardeners and lake and reservoir\nmaintenance staff). A significant number of cases report having been\nin contact with rodents (23.5 percent), recent arthropod bites (16.6\npercent) or animals such as dogs or cats (17.4 percent), or having\nhandled crayfish (17.1 percent), taken frequent walks in the country\n(10.5 percent), having contact with livestock (9.7 percent), straw,\nmanure or alfalfa hay (5.8 percent) or having handled and/or skinned\nhares (4.4 percent).\n\nThe most frequent clinical presentation of the disease and background\nrisk factors reported suggest 2 different means of transmission\nresponsible for the outbreak; firstly and principally by inhaling the\nbacteria, a pattern seen in just over half the cases (pneumonic and\nprobably many of the typhoid forms); and secondly, through direct\ninoculation with local manifestations of the disease.\n\nMeasures taken\n-------------\nFurther cases are actively being sought. The general public and, in\nparticular, workers with high risk of exposure have been informed of\nthe disease and of preventive measures that should be taken. These were:\n- avoid contact with dead, sick or unusually behaving animals;\n- avoid the consumption of unsanitary water that has not had adequate\nsanitary control;\n- use protective clothing and repellent products to avoid bites from\ninsects and ticks,\n- use gloves and masks when handling animals;\n- do not allow children to touch dead animals;\n- ensure that the meat of wild animals is cooked through before you\neat it, as freezing does not inactivate the agent responsible for tularemia,\n- communicate to hunting and/or animal health authorities the\npresence of dead, sick or unusually behaving animals; and\n- in case of the appearance of symptoms compatible with this disease,\ncontact your doctor immediately.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nWe believe that the exposure in this outbreak has come to an end. The\nmajority of recently confirmed cases have a not recent onset of\nsymptoms. The outbreak is focused in the central areas of Castilla y\nLeon (in 5 of 9 provinces) and has not spread to all areas of\nCastilla y Leon or to other Spanish regions. Taking this and the\nspecific climatic and other conditions in the affected provinces into\naccount, we believe that a spread of this outbreak to Portugal is unlikely.\n\nTularemia has been identified as a potential agent for intentional\nrelease, but due to the fact that this outbreak occurred in a rural\narea that has fauna and crops with very particular characteristics,\nand which has also experienced previous outbreaks of tularemia, we\nbelieve it is naturally occurring. The 1st tularemia outbreak in this\nregion occurred in 1997 (3,4,6), with 534 cases, and there was\nanother in 2004 with 13 cases (5). Between 2000 and 2003, 7 cases\nwere reported in this region (5). In the 1997 outbreak, the mechanism\nof transmission was by contact, while this year [2007], inhalation\nhas been more frequent. We are still investigating this outbreak but\nbelieve that unusual climatic and environmental circumstances may\nhave contributed to it, together with the significant diversity of\nreservoirs and sources of infection that have taken part in\ntransmission (leporids, sheep, rodents, canids, haematophagus\nvectors). All these factors have probably aided the proliferation of\n_Francisella tularensis_, a bacterium that can survive for long\nperiods in water, mud and animal carcasses. We intend to undertake\nfurther studies in order to advance the knowledge of the causes of\nthis outbreak.\n\n1. Commission Decision of 17 Jul 2003 amending Decision No 2119/98/EC\nof the European Parliament and of the Council and Decision 2000/96/EC\nas regards communicable diseases listed in those decisions and\namending Decision 2002/253/EC as regards the case definitions for\ncommunicable diseases (notified under document number C(2003) 2301.\nOfficial Journal of the European Union. Volume 46. 23 Jul 2003.\n\n2. Direccion General de Salud Publica. Manual de Notificacion:\nSistema de Enfermedades de Declaracion Obligatoria. 1a edicion. Junta\nde Castilla y Leon. Consejeria de Sanidad. Valladolid 2007.\n\n3. De Mateo S, Ruiz Cosin C. Outbreak of tularaemia in Castilla y\nLeon, Spain. Eurosurveillance Weekly [1812-075X]. 1998 Jan 22;1(4)\n980122. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/1998/980122.asp#1>.\n\n4. Instituto de Salud Carlos III. Centro Nacional de Epidemiologia.\nBrote de tularemia en Castilla y Leon. Boletin Epidemiologico\nSemanal. 1997; 5: 249-52.\n\n5. Boletin Epidemiologico de Castilla y Leon - Ano 2005 - Volumen 21.\n\n6. Andres Puertas C, Mateos Baruque ML, Buron Lobo I, Gonzalez Megido\nMJ, Rebollo Cuadrado C, Sangrador Arenas LA. Epidemic outbreak of\nTularemia in Palencia. Rev Clin Esp 1999 Nov, 199(11):711-5.\n\n[Authors: Martin C <marmarci@jcyl.es>, Gallardo MT, Mateos L, et al]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED reported on this outbreak at an earlier stage in August 2007.\nIt is certainly possible that the primary vehicle for transmission to\nhumans in this outbreak was contaminated water, as aerosolization of\nthe water can cause pneumonic tularemia, and skin or mucous membrane\ncontact can cause the varied other presentations. It is not clear\nwhether aerosolization of _F. tularensis_ would cause more typhoidal\ncases than if the bacterium was ingested.\n\nUnfortunately, unlike this report, most reports do not characterize\nthe specific subspecies. As mentioned below, both subspecies are\nfound in the USA, whereas holarctica is the one primarily found in Eurasia.\n\nThe following is from\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/idsa/bt/tularemia/biofacts/tularemiafactsheet.html>:\n\n'There are several subspecies of _F. tularensis_ with somewhat\nconfusing nomenclature. These subspecies can be differentiated by\nbiochemical tests, and the current taxonomy is as follows:\n\nSubspecies tularensis (type A; also referred to as subspecies\nnearctica by investigators in the former Soviet Union): demonstrates\ncitrulline ureidase activity; highly infectious and virulent; found\nprimarily in North America; 2 distinct genetic clades have been identified.\n\nSubspecies holarctica (type B; formerly referred to as palaearctica\nor palearctica in some sources): less virulent; does not demonstrate\ncitrulline ureidase activity; three biovars have been identified:\n\n-Biovar I: erythromycin sensitive; primarily found in North America,\nEurope, Siberia, the Far East, and Kazakhstan\n\n-Biovar II: erythromycin resistant; primarily found in Eurasia\n\n-Biovar japonica: found in Japan\n\nSubspecies mediasiatica: found in the Central Asian republics of the\nformer Soviet Union (virulence is similar to _F. tularensis_,\nsubspecies holarctica).\n\nSubspecies novicida: considered to be of low virulence and generally\ncauses illness only in immunocompromised hosts (_F. tularensis_ and\n_F. novicida_ traditionally have been considered separate species;\nhowever, the current approach is to consider _F. novicida_ as a\nsubspecies of _F. tularensis_.)'\n\nSpain and the provinces involved can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.themapshop.co.uk/images/spain/spainprov.gif>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "These were:\n- avoid contact with dead, sick or unusually behaving animals;\n- avoid the consumption of unsanitary water that has not had adequate\nsanitary control;\n- use protective clothing and repellent products to avoid bites from\ninsects and ticks,\n- use gloves and masks when handling animals;\n- do not allow children to touch dead animals;\n- ensure that the meat of wild animals is cooked through before you\neat it, as freezing does not inactivate the agent responsible for tularemia,\n- communicate to hunting and/or animal health authorities the\npresence of dead, sick or unusually behaving animals; and\n- in case of the appearance of symptoms compatible with this disease,\ncontact your doctor immediately. A significant number of cases report having been\nin contact with rodents (23.5 percent), recent arthropod bites (16.6\npercent) or animals such as dogs or cats (17.4 percent), or having\nhandled crayfish (17.1 percent), taken frequent walks in the country\n(10.5 percent), having contact with livestock (9.7 percent), straw,\nmanure or alfalfa hay (5.8 percent) or having handled and/or skinned\nhares (4.4 percent). \n\nSubspecies novicida: considered to be of low virulence and generally\ncauses illness only in immunocompromised hosts (_F. tularensis_ and\n_F. novicida_ traditionally have been considered separate species;\nhowever, the current approach is to consider _F. novicida_ as a\nsubspecies of _F. tularensis_.)'\n\nSpain and the provinces involved can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.themapshop.co.uk/images/spain/spainprov.gif>. \n\nThe most frequent clinical presentation of the disease and background\nrisk factors reported suggest 2 different means of transmission\nresponsible for the outbreak; firstly and principally by inhaling the\nbacteria, a pattern seen in just over half the cases (pneumonic and\nprobably many of the typhoid forms); and secondly, through direct\ninoculation with local manifestations of the disease. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 8 Nov 2007\n We are still investigating this outbreak but\nbelieve that unusual climatic and environmental circumstances may\nhave contributed to it, together with the significant diversity of\nreservoirs and sources of infection that have taken part in\ntransmission (leporids, sheep, rodents, canids, haematophagus\nvectors). In late June 2007, the Epidemiological Surveillance Network in\nCastilla y Leon, northern Spain, reported a series of cases in a\nrural area in the province of Palencia and in the provincial capital\ncity of Leon, labelled as 'fever of unknown origin.' (cutaneous ulcer with regional lymphadenopathy);\n-glandular (regional lymphadenopathy with no ulcer);\n-oculoglandular (conjunctivitis with preauricular lymphadenopathy),\n-oropharyngeal \n\nCases were confirmed using serological techniques (microagglutination\nin 74.8 percent and tube agglutination in 25.2 percent), culture in 6\npercent or PCR in 2 percent. \n\nSubspecies holarctica (type B; formerly referred to as palaearctica\nor palearctica in some sources): less virulent; does not demonstrate\ncitrulline ureidase activity; three biovars have been identified:\n\n-Biovar I: erythromycin sensitive; primarily found in North America, [Authors: Martin C <marmarci@jcyl.es>, Gallardo MT, Mateos L, et al]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED reported on this outbreak at an earlier stage in August 2007. \n\nThe following is from\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/idsa/bt/tularemia/biofacts/tularemiafactsheet.html>:\n\n'There are several subspecies of _F. tularensis_ with somewhat\nconfusing nomenclature. The\nmajority of recently confirmed cases have a not recent onset of\nsymptoms.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": ["fever of unknown origin"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2301-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sangrador Arenas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22359", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Spain (northern): vole reservoir", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22359", "date": "2007-08-11 05:00:10", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SPAIN (NORTHERN): VOLE RESERVOIR\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 9 Aug 2007\nSource: All Headline News [edited]\n<http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7008153503>\n\nVoles have spread tularemia to nearly 100 people and threatened Spain's\nfood crops in northern areas. This has prompted the authorities to approve\nburning fields to destroy the pests.\nThere are about 70 varieties of voles around the world and usually the\nsmall rodents are not so destructive. But 750 million voles have invaded\nfields in Spain's north chomping their way through crops that include\npotatoes, beets, barley, lettuce, and vineyards. The increase in disease\nand destruction of crops on 988 000 acres (about 340 000 hectares) infested\nby the pests has led authorities to approve burning the voles. That was\nafter authorities had tried and failed to eliminate the rodents by\ndestroying their burrows and using poison and small controlled burns.\nAlthough authorities say that only about 88 people have the disease,\nfarmers dispute those figures and say more than 100 have become sick,\nSpain's daily El Pais reported on Wed 8 Aug 2007 according to Expatica\nmagazine. On that day, authorities torched vole-infested area in the\nValladolid area of Castile-Leon region in an effort to protect the potato\nand beet crop there, BBC news reported on 9 Aug 2007. Officials will also\nsoon set fire to fields in Avila, Palencia, and Segovia in an effort to\nkill the voles there.\nNo one, including Castile-Leon's agriculture minister, Silvia Clemente, has\nan answer for why there are so many voles this year [2007].\n[byline: Linda Young]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The manifestations of tularemia in these cases is not stated but it is\nlikely that aerosolization of the bacteria is occurring (as discussed\nbelow) so that pneumonic manifestations of the disease may be occurring in\naddition to ulceroglandular, glandular, and typhoidal, the former 2 related\nto direct skin contact). In this way, direct contact with the vole is not\nneeded. This moderator is unable to discuss the burning method as a way to\naddress this serious problem.\nA number of outbreaks of tularemia have been reported related to rodents\n(see information on voles below). One (Reintjes R, Dedushaj I, Ardiana A,\net al. Tularemia Outbreak Investigation in Kosovo: Case Control and\nEnvironmental Studies. Emerg Infect Dis 2002; 8: 59-63) states (with the\ncitation numbers altered to start at 1:\n'A disrupted agricultural environment, deserted homes, and unprotected food\nstores in Kosovo in spring 1999 likely resulted in a rapid increase in\nrodent populations favorable for epizootic spread of tularemia in rodents\nand consequent widespread environmental contamination with _Francisella\ntularensis_. Although this organism does not produce spores or multiply\noutside animal hosts, it can survive for months in cold, moist conditions.\nLarge outbreaks of human tularemia in Europe have been described following\ncontamination of the environment with rodent excrement and carcasses (1-7).\nThe largest occurred as a result of disrupted agricultural environments\nbecause of warfare on the Eastern Front during World War II (1). These\noutbreaks have often been associated with a broad spectrum of tularemia\nsyndromes, including high proportions of cases with pleuropneumonic and\ntyphoidal presentations. It is unclear, however, whether these cases arose\nfrom inhalation or ingestion exposures, or both.\n'References:\n1. Olsulfiev NG, Rudne GP. Tularemia. Moscow: Publishing House for Medical\nLiterature, 1960. p. 459.\n2. Sil'chenko VS. Epidemiological and clinical features of tularemia caused\nby waterborne infection. Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1957; 28: 788-95.\n3. Syrjala H, Kujala P, Myllyla V, Salminen A. Airborne transmission of\ntularemia in farmers. Scand J Infect Dis 1985; 17: 371-5.\n4. Dahlstrand S, Ringertz O, Zetterberg: Airborne tularemia in Sweden.\nScand J Infect Dis 1971; 3: 7-16.\n5. Tarnvik A, Sandstrom G, Sjostedt A. Epidemiologic analysis of tularemia\nin Sweden 1931-1993. FEMS Immunol Med Microbiol 1996; 13: 201-4.\n6. Schmidt B: Der Einbruch der Tularaemie in Europa. Zeitschr fuer Hygiene\nund Infektionskrankheiten 1947; 127: 139-50.\n7. Christenson B: An outbreak of tularemia in the northern part of central\nSweden. Scand J Infect Dis 1984; 16: 285-90.'\nThe World War II outbreak referred to above has been thought perhaps to be\nrelated to bioterrorism. But an editorial related to the siege of\nStalingrad in Military Medicine 2001; 166(10)\n(<http://cns.miis.edu/research/cbw/tula.htm>) stated (again with the\nreferences renumbered to start at 1:\n'According to one Soviet retrospective: 'Late in the fall of 1942,\nepicenters of the tularemia epizootic in the field mouse [lit: vole] were\ndetected in the basin of the Don-delta.\n'Concurrently, cases of tularemia were registered among the local\npopulation. More than 75 per cent of the population was hit by tularemia in\nindividual locations of the Stalingrad area.... As the health centers were\npractically out of order at this time, the entire burden of the treatment\nof the infected population was taken up by the military-medical front\nservice. (1)\n'One of these studies reports an even higher rate of pulmonary involvement\nin tularemia infections (95.2 per cent) during the battle of Stalingrad\ncaused by inhaled dust from infected straw. (The production of similar\nairborne fomites, as well as the predominance of the inhalation route of\ninfection among certain populations, is consistent with other outbreaks\nthat have occurred in Martha's Vineyard (2) in the USA as well as in\nFinland (3) and Sweden (4).) According to one Russian Journal article in\n1980, the war disturbed normal agricultural activities of the population in\nthe areas near the front. Crops remained unharvested and the grass uncut.\nThus was created a large source of food for rodents, and in the fall of\n1942 large numbers of mice, field mice, forest mice, shrews, and others\nappeared in the trenches and dugouts (5). The high prevalence of tularemia\namong Red Army soldiers was 'associated with the use of hay for bedding in\nentrenchments, dig-outs, and trenches' and only got worse as infected\nrodents followed the soldiers into their hastily built military\nfortifications (6). However, in addition to inhalation exposures, many of\nthe tularemia infections were also linked to 'eating biscuits and other\nbaked food touched by the rodents, using water from wells, which was\ninfected by the bodies of the rodents that died as a result of tularemia.'\n'References:\n1. Agafonov I, Tararin RA. Some organizational-tactical forms and methods\nof anti-epidemiological work in troops of Stalingrad (Donsk) front in\n1942-43. [Translated by Krcalova S.] Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol\n1975; 5: 6-7.\n2. Teutsch SM, Martone WJ, Brink EW, et al. Pneumonic tularemia on Martha's\nVineyard. N Engl J Med 1979; 301: 826-8.\n3. Syrjala H, Kujala P, Myllyla V, Salminen A. Airborne transmission of\ntularemia in farmers, Scand J Infect Dis 1985; 17: 371-5.\n4. Sanford JP. Tularemia. Prophylaxis of tularemia during the Great Patriotic War.\n[Translated by Krcalova S.] Zh Mikrobiol Epidemiol Immunobiol 1970; 47(5): 23.'\nVoles (<http://www.voles.com/>), often called meadow mice or field mice,\noccupy a wide variety of habitats, depending on the species. Generally,\nvoles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants,\nor litter. They are active both day and night and throughout the year.\nVoles eat a variety of plants and animals. They frequently forage on\ngrasses, forbs, roots, bulbs, tubers, bark, snails, and insects. To find\nfood, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow\nopenings. Several adults and young can live in these runway systems. This\nintricate network of tunnels and burrows provide voles with excellent\nshelter from the weather and protection from predators. Voles store seeds\nand other plant matter in underground chambers.\nA picture of a vole can be found at\n<http://news-service.stanford.edu/news/2004/september22/gifs/Yellowstone_vole.jpg>\nSpain and the provinces involved can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.themapshop.co.uk/images/spain/spainprov.gif>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Emerg Infect Dis 2002; 8: 59-63) states (with the\ncitation numbers altered to start at 1:\n'A disrupted agricultural environment, deserted homes, and unprotected food\nstores in Kosovo in spring 1999 likely resulted in a rapid increase in\nrodent populations favorable for epizootic spread of tularemia in rodents\nand consequent widespread environmental contamination with _Francisella\ntularensis_. TULAREMIA - SPAIN (NORTHERN): VOLE RESERVOIR\n********************************************\n But 750 million voles have invaded\nfields in Spain's north chomping their way through crops that include\npotatoes, beets, barley, lettuce, and vineyards. That was\nafter authorities had tried and failed to eliminate the rodents by\ndestroying their burrows and using poison and small controlled burns. Generally,\nvoles prefer areas with heavy ground cover of grasses, grass-like plants,\nor litter. To find\nfood, voles construct tunnels and surface runways with many burrow\nopenings. This\nintricate network of tunnels and burrows provide voles with excellent\nshelter from the weather and protection from predators.
