USA (UT,NJ) (05): UT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22088", "date": "2007-08-09 16:00:13", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY) (05): UTAH\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 7 Aug 2007\nSource: Deseret (UT) News [edited]\n<http://www.desnews.com/cgi-bin/cqcgi_plus/@plus.env?CQ_SESSION_KEY=UPNCCZYEUCCL&CQ_CUR_DOCUMENT=1&CQ_TEXT_MAIN=YES>\n\nCDC [US Centers for Disease Control & Prevention] is now leading the\nenvironmental investigation into a tularemia cluster that may have\nafflicted as many as 17 Utahns, traced to the west side of Utah Lake.\nAccording to the Utah Department of Health, 8 cases have been confirmed and\nanother 8 are classified as probable.\nFrom ongoing and future efforts, health experts hope to learn more about\nthe actual ecology of the illness, how it dissipates, and the course of\nrecovery. They also want to know what puts people at greater risk. Hundreds\nof people were in the area at the time of the cluster, but only a small\nnumber became ill or developed lesions, initially mistaken for a spider\nbite or staphylococcal infection, said Ilene Risk, director of the\nepidemiology bureau in the Salt Lake Valley Health Department. From Salt\nLake County alone, where more than half those in the cluster reside, 200\npeople were potentially exposed.\nLocal health officials are collecting data and interviewing people who were\ninfected, hoping to get a clue as to what puts people at greatest risk, she\nsaid.\nCDC is testing the field specimens collected as part of the investigation\nand will work with Brigham Young University to monitor flying insects in\nthe area. During a field assessment, CDC and the Salt Lake Valley Health\nDepartment set up 14 flying insect traps, 26 rabbit traps, and 150 small\nrodent traps, then collected samples for lab analysis. The CDC will lead\nmitigation efforts, should it decide they're needed.\nTularemia is a bacterial infection caused by _Francisella tularensis_,\nfound in animals, particularly rabbits. It's typically transmitted by flea,\ndeerfly, or horsefly bite, but can be spread by direct contact with an\ninfected animal (including eating meat that's not well cooked). It can be\nspread by drinking contaminated water or inhaling contaminated air, as\nwell. It doesn't pass person to person.\nPeople made ill in the cluster were at the lake between mid-June and the\n1st week of July 2007. Cases are reportable to the state, but initial\ninvestigation belongs to the area where the individual lives, not where\ninfection occurred, said Lance Madigan, spokesman for the Utah Department\nof Health. So health officials from Davis, Iron, Salt Lake, Utah, and Weber\ncounties have been involved.\nThe 1st 3 cases reported were linked to a youth camp at the lake, which\ngave public health investigators a probable location. Utah usually has a\nfew cases statewide each year, but a cluster such as this one is unusual.\nIt took public health workers less than a day to identify it as tularemia,\nthe result of what Risk calls epidemiologists who were 'hustling' and very\ngood work by the public health lab. The epidemiologists collected lab\nspecimens, interviewed those who were sick, some hospitalized and some not,\nand took samples from and pictures of the skin lesions.\nBy the 3rd interview, they'd found a pattern emerging from what had been\nnonspecific early reports: 'A group went to a conference, and several had\nbeen ill. It was not defined, and they had not had close contact or\ncompared symptoms.' But the initial reporting source, Risk said, was\n'excellent, with good locating information' so they were quickly able to\nput it together. At that point, all those who were sick were being treated\nbut not with the right antibiotics. Tularemia requires a very specific\nprotocol that includes IV and oral antibiotics and lasts about 2 weeks.\nRecovery can take a long time, Risk said.\n[byline: Lois M Collins]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph P Dudley, PhD\n[More cases are being confirmed as tularemia in this Utah cluster. It is\nnot specifically stated that the cases were not due to pneumonic disease,\nbut given the postings inferring an arthropod vector, glandular or\nulceroglandular disease appears to be occurring and not air or waterborne\ninfection. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Hundreds\nof people were in the area at the time of the cluster, but only a small\nnumber became ill or developed lesions, initially mistaken for a spider\nbite or staphylococcal infection, said Ilene Risk, director of the\nepidemiology bureau in the Salt Lake Valley Health Department. It is\nnot specifically stated that the cases were not due to pneumonic disease,\nbut given the postings inferring an arthropod vector, glandular or\nulceroglandular disease appears to be occurring and not air or waterborne\ninfection. Source: Deseret (UT) News [edited]\n<http://www.desnews.com/cgi-bin/cqcgi_plus/@plus.env?CQ_SESSION_KEY=UPNCCZYEUCCL&CQ_CUR_DOCUMENT=1&CQ_TEXT_MAIN=YES>\n\nCDC [US Centers for Disease Control & Prevention] is now leading the\nenvironmental investigation into a tularemia cluster that may have\nafflicted as many as 17 Utahns, traced to the west side of Utah Lake.\n [byline: Lois M Collins]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph P Dudley, PhD\n Cases are reportable to the state, but initial\ninvestigation belongs to the area where the individual lives, not where\ninfection occurred, said Lance Madigan, spokesman for the Utah Department\nof Health. \nCDC is testing the field specimens collected as part of the investigation\nand will work with Brigham Young University to monitor flying insects in\nthe area. During a field assessment, CDC and the Salt Lake Valley Health\nDepartment set up 14 flying insect traps, 26 rabbit traps, and 150 small\nrodent traps, then collected samples for lab analysis. It took public health workers less than a day to identify it as tularemia,\nthe result of what Risk calls epidemiologists who were 'hustling' and very\ngood work by the public health lab. Local health officials are collecting data and interviewing people who were\ninfected, hoping to get a clue as to what puts people at greatest risk, she\nsaid. The epidemiologists collected lab\nspecimens, interviewed those who were sick, some hospitalized and some not,\nand took samples from and pictures of the skin lesions. From ongoing and future efforts, health experts hope to learn more about\nthe actual ecology of the illness, how it dissipates, and the course of\nrecovery.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Salt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lake County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salt Lake", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "19836", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (UT, NJ) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=19836", "date": "2007-07-30 21:00:09", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY) (04)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Jul 2007\nSource: KSL [edited]\n<http://www.ksl.com/index.php?nid=148&sid=1541007>\n\nThe CDC is in Utah to help investigate that outbreak of tularemia\nthat occurred on the shores of Utah Lake 2 weeks ago [9-13 Jul 2007].\nThe disease is sometimes called rabbit fever. While it is endemic to\nUtah, only 2 to 4 people a year are diagnosed.\nSo when a cluster happens, like the one at Utah Lake 2 weeks ago,\nepidemiologists want a thorough investigation. That's why State\nHealth invited the CDC to come and help. State epidemiologist Robert\nRolfs says, 'One of the reasons we invited CDC to come is the last\nlarge outbreak where there's a good description of is more than 30\nyears ago, back in the 1970s. And the risk did go all summer that\ntime, so we want to stay on top of it. We're looking for more cases.\nIf we see more, we'll put out more alerts so people do know about this.'\nIn most cases, a deer fly bites an infected rabbit or rodent then\nbites a human, passing on the bacteria. It spreads from the site of\nthe bite to lymph nodes and other parts of the body. People can get\nseriously ill, but with treatment few die.\nA lot of unanswered questions remain. In addition to deer flies, were\nticks or even mosquitoes involved? Did they get it from rodents as\nwell as rabbits? Were some campers using repellents? Did they work?\nResearchers also hope to find out why some people get really sick\nwith tularemia, while others don't.\nA total of 18 people spread over a wide area in and out of that\ncampground were symptomatic of tularemia. So far, tests have come\nback positive for 4. Even though the military identifies tularemia as\na potential bioterrorism agent, this latest cluster infection was\nfelt to be all the work of nature.\n[Byline: Ed Yeates]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley PhD\n[More cases of tularemia are being diagnosed in Utah. Minimal\ninformation has come forth on the clinical manifestations of the\ndisease in these individuals. Many cases of tularemia involve lymph\nnode infection with (ulceroglandular) or without (glandular) a local\nskin infection draining to the lymph node. Cases associated with lawn\nmowers, as has been described on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts,\nare often pneumonic, related to inhalation of bacilli. Unlike human\nplague infection, pneumonic tularemia does not spread from person to\nperson. Bloodstream infection (bacteremia) can be associated with\ndifferent forms of disease or may be the only manifestation (typhoidal form).\nThe pneumonic type is likely the presentation to occur if the\ncategory A bioterrorism agent is spread as a terrorist act. Outbreaks\ndo occur as on Martha's Vineyard and sporadic cases of pneumonic\ntularemia have occurred naturally even in large cities such as New\nYork City and Washington DC. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Even though the military identifies tularemia as\na potential bioterrorism agent, this latest cluster infection was\nfelt to be all the work of nature.\n Outbreaks\ndo occur as on Martha's Vineyard and sporadic cases of pneumonic\ntularemia have occurred naturally even in large cities such as New\nYork City and Washington DC. - Mod. State epidemiologist Robert\nRolfs says, 'One of the reasons we invited CDC to come is the last\nlarge outbreak where there's a good description of is more than 30\nyears ago, back in the 1970s. Many cases of tularemia involve lymph\nnode infection with (ulceroglandular) or without (glandular) a local\nskin infection draining to the lymph node. Unlike human\nplague infection, pneumonic tularemia does not spread from person to\nperson. Cases associated with lawn\nmowers, as has been described on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts,\nare often pneumonic, related to inhalation of bacilli. Minimal\ninformation has come forth on the clinical manifestations of the\ndisease in these individuals. [Byline: Ed Yeates]\n--\n Contributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley PhD\n The CDC is in Utah to help investigate that outbreak of tularemia\nthat occurred on the shores of Utah Lake 2 weeks ago [9-13 Jul 2007]. A total of 18 people spread over a wide area in and out of that\ncampground were symptomatic of tularemia. In most cases, a deer fly bites an infected rabbit or rodent then\nbites a human, passing on the bacteria. So when a cluster happens, like the one at Utah Lake 2 weeks ago,\nepidemiologists want a thorough investigation. Bloodstream infection (bacteremia) can be associated with\ndifferent forms of disease or may be the only manifestation (typhoidal form). Researchers also hope to find out why some people get really sick\nwith tularemia, while others don't. While it is endemic to\nUtah, only 2 to 4 people a year are diagnosed. TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY) (04)\n It spreads from the site of\nthe bite to lymph nodes and other parts of the body. So far, tests have come\nback positive for 4. That's why State\nHealth invited the CDC to come and help. People can get\nseriously ill, but with treatment few die. In addition to deer flies, were\nticks or even mosquitoes involved? And the risk did go all summer that\ntime, so we want to stay on top of it.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New \n York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18515", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - USA (UT, NJ) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18515", "date": "2007-07-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY) (03)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 19 Jul 2007 [edited]\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network)\n(primary statistics derived from US Centers for Disease Control)\n[edited]\n<http://www.gideononline.com>\n\nTick-borne diseases in the USA in perspective\n---------------------------------------------\nAlthough Rocky Mountain spotted fever and Lyme disease are better\nknown to the lay public, the list of additional tick-borne diseases\nhas grown in recent years. The incidence of Lyme disease in the\nUnited States is greater than 5-fold that of all other tick-borne\ninfections combined (see graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Tick-US.JPG>)\nIf we eliminate Lyme disease, we find that tularemia was the most\ncommon disease in this group until 1965, but has since been\nsuperseded by Rocky Mountain spotted fever -- and more recently\nEhrlichiosis -- (see graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Tick-Nolyme.JPG>.\nMost significantly, although deaths due to other tick-borne diseases\nhave declined in recent years, the number dying from tularemia has\nremained surprisingly constant for over 4 decades (see graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/tularemia-deaths.jpg>.\n--\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center, Israel\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n[Steve Berger is thanked for his input. Ticks are obligate\nbloodsuckers, and are common vectors for human diseases due to a large\nvariety of pathogens that include gram-negative bacilli, spirochetes,\nrickettsiae, protozoans, and viruses, as well as toxins. Ticks wait on\nlow-lying vegetation (a process called questing) for a susceptible\nhost on which they can attach and feed. A single tick bite can\ntransmit more than one pathogen. Both hard ticks (_Dermacentor_ spp.\nsuch as wood and dog ticks, _Amblyomma_ spp. such as the Lone Star\ntick, and _Ixodes_ spp. such as the black-legged deer tick) and soft\nticks (_Ornithodoros_ spp.) can be vectors. Soft ticks feast on a\nblood for only short periods (less than 1 h), and disease can be\ntransmitted in less than 1 minute; hard ticks take days.\nIn North America, ticks transmit\n- Lyme disease (_Ixodes_),\n- human granulocytic and monocytic ehrlichiosis (_Ixodes_, _ Amblyomma_),\n- babesiosis (_Ixodes_),\n- relapsing fever (_Ornithodoros_),\n-Rocky Mountain spotted fever (_Dermacentor_, _Amblyomma_),\n- Colorado tick fever (_Dermacentor_),\n- tularemia (_Dermacentor_, _Amblyomma_),\n- Southern tick-associated rash illness (_Amblyomma_), and\n- tick paralysis (_Dermacentor_, _Amblyomma_).\nA brief glance at recent ProMED-mail posts reveals that Europe, the\nMiddle East and undoubtedly the rest of the world are similarly\nplagued by tick-borne\ndiseases. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "In North America, ticks transmit\n- Lyme disease (_Ixodes_),\n- human granulocytic and monocytic ehrlichiosis (_Ixodes_, _ Amblyomma_),\n- babesiosis (_Ixodes_),\n- relapsing fever (_Ornithodoros_),\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n -Rocky Mountain spotted fever (_Dermacentor_, _Amblyomma_),\n- Colorado tick fever (_Dermacentor_),\n- tularemia (_Dermacentor_, _Amblyomma_),\n- Southern tick-associated rash illness (_Amblyomma_), and\n- tick paralysis (_Dermacentor_, _Amblyomma_). If we eliminate Lyme disease, we find that tularemia was the most\ncommon disease in this group until 1965, but has since been\nsuperseded by Rocky Mountain spotted fever -- and more recently\nEhrlichiosis -- (see graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Tick-Nolyme.JPG>. The incidence of Lyme disease in the\nUnited States is greater than 5-fold that of all other tick-borne\ninfections combined (see graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Tick-US.JPG>)\n Most significantly, although deaths due to other tick-borne diseases\nhave declined in recent years, the number dying from tularemia has\nremained surprisingly constant for over 4 decades (see graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/tularemia-deaths.jpg>. A brief glance at recent ProMED-mail posts reveals that Europe, the\nMiddle East and undoubtedly the rest of the world are similarly\nplagued by tick-borne\ndiseases. Ticks are obligate\nbloodsuckers, and are common vectors for human diseases due to a large\nvariety of pathogens that include gram-negative bacilli, spirochetes,\nrickettsiae, protozoans, and viruses, as well as toxins. --\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1965-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18123", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (UT, NJ) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18123", "date": "2007-07-18 20:00:03", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NJ) (02)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 17 Jul 2007\nSource: The Salt Lake Tribune, Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://www.sltrib.com/news/ci_6395403>\n\nA naturally occurring biological agent is being blamed for 13 cases\nof an illness commonly known as rabbit fever.\nAll of the people infected camped on the west side of Utah Lake\nbetween the end of June and the 1st week of July [2007].\nThe Utah Department of Health has only confirmed that 2 of the cases\nare tularemia. The remaining cases are suspected with patients\nshowing clinical signs of the bacterial infection. Symptoms include\nsudden fever, headaches, ulcers on the skin or mouth, and swollen and\npainful glands.\nHealth officials say it's a fairly uncommon infection. There are\n[normally] only 2 or 3 cases per year in Utah. The infection responds\nwell to appropriate antibiotics once diagnosed. If untreated, it can\nbe fatal.\nThe bacterium that causes rabbit fever is generally spread through\nthe handling of rabbit or other animal carcasses, but it can also be\ntransmitted by infected ticks, horseflies, or deerflies.\nIt is not passed from person to person.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\n[A few bits of additional information emerge from the news report\nabove on the outbreak of tularemia among a group of campers in Utah:\nthere are 13 total cases, of which 2 are confirmed. No details are as\nyet available about the demographics of the campers, clinical\nmanifestations, mode of transmission, attack rate, treatment, or\noutcome. In the US, reported cases have dropped sharply from several\nthousand/year prior to 1950 to less than 200/year in the 1990s\n(see <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5109a1.htm>).\nAlthough campers most likely will become infected during the summer\nvia tick bites and develop the ulcero-glandular type of tularemia, the\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control & Prevention) warns that when used\nas a bioweapon 'airborne _Francisella tularensis_ would be expected to\nprincipally cause pleuropneumonitis, but some exposures might\ncontaminate the eye, resulting in ocular tularemia; penetrate broken\nskin, resulting in ulceroglandular or glandular disease; or cause\noropharyngeal [mouth & pharynx] disease with cervical lymphadenitis\n[swollen lymph nodes in the neck].'\n(see\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/tularemia/tularemia-biological-weapon-abstract.asp#2>).\nIf a bioterrorism event is suspected, the FBI as well as the health\ndepartment should be notified to in part ensure the chain of\nevidence. Rapid diagnostic testing for tularemia is not widely\navailable. Microscopic demonstration of _F. tularensis_ using\nfluorescent-labeled antibodies is a rapid diagnostic procedure\nperformed in designated reference laboratories in the National Public\nHealth Laboratory Network; test results can be available within\nseveral hours of receiving the specimens, if the laboratory is\nalerted and prepared\n(see\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/tularemia/tularemia-biological-weapon-abstract.asp#2>).\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "Although campers most likely will become infected during the summer\nvia tick bites and develop the ulcero-glandular type of tularemia, the\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control & Prevention) warns that when used\nas a bioweapon 'airborne _Francisella tularensis_ would be expected to\nprincipally cause pleuropneumonitis, but some exposures might\ncontaminate the eye, resulting in ocular tularemia; penetrate broken\nskin, resulting in ulceroglandular or glandular disease; or cause\noropharyngeal [mouth & pharynx] disease with cervical lymphadenitis\n Microscopic demonstration of _F. tularensis_ using\nfluorescent-labeled antibodies is a rapid diagnostic procedure\nperformed in designated reference laboratories in the National Public\nHealth Laboratory Network; test results can be available within\nseveral hours of receiving the specimens, if the laboratory is\nalerted and prepared\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The bacterium that causes rabbit fever is generally spread through\nthe handling of rabbit or other animal carcasses, but it can also be\ntransmitted by infected ticks, horseflies, or deerflies.\n No details are as\nyet available about the demographics of the campers, clinical\nmanifestations, mode of transmission, attack rate, treatment, or\noutcome. [A few bits of additional information emerge from the news report\nabove on the outbreak of tularemia among a group of campers in Utah:\nthere are 13 total cases, of which 2 are confirmed. Source: The Salt Lake Tribune, Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://www.sltrib.com/news/ci_6395403>\n\nA naturally occurring biological agent is being blamed for 13 cases\nof an illness commonly known as rabbit fever. In the US, reported cases have dropped sharply from several\nthousand/year prior to 1950 to less than 200/year in the 1990s\n(see <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5109a1.htm>). Symptoms include\nsudden fever, headaches, ulcers on the skin or mouth, and swollen and\npainful glands. If a bioterrorism event is suspected, the FBI as well as the health\ndepartment should be notified to in part ensure the chain of\nevidence. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph \n(see\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/tularemia/tularemia-biological-weapon-abstract.asp#2>). The Utah Department of Health has only confirmed that 2 of the cases\nare tularemia. TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NJ) (02)\n It is not passed from person to person.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1950-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "20509", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=20509", "date": "2007-08-03 20:00:13", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (WYOMING)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 1 Aug 2007\nSource: Green River (WY) Star [edited]\n<http://www.greenriverstar.com/articles/2007/08/01/news/news1.txt=20>\n\nA confirmed case of tularemia was reported in Sweetwater County this\nweek, according to Chuck Sykes, Sweetwater County Health Department\nEnvironmental Health director. Sykes said the man probably contracted\nthe disease from a fly bite.\nTularemia, also called 'rabbit fever,' is a disease carried by\nrabbits. It can be spread to humans by biting flies [such as deer\nflies - Mod.LL] or through contact with blood from a rabbit [as well\nas being tickborne - Mod.LL].\nSykes said the man believes he was bitten by a fly at Stratton-Myers\nPark while watching the American Legion District A Tournament.\nThis is the 3rd confirmed case for Wyoming in 2007, he said. A case\noccurred in Uinta County and the other in Campbell County. The man\nwho was infected in Uinta County, claims he got tularemia while\nvisiting the Seedskadee National Wildlife Refuge.\nSykes said tularemia has many symptoms depending on how it gets into\na person's system. However, since these are bites, the most common\nsymptoms are: a skin ulcer that forms by the site of infection, the\nbacteria will then spread to the lymph glands, which will swell and\nbecome painful. The treatment is simple antibiotics, Sykes said.\nAlthough 3 other Green River residents have similar symptoms, they\nwere not confirmed tularemia cases. They are being treated by private\nphysicians. The disease cannot be transmitted from person to person.\nSykes encourages everyone to continue to use bug repellent and\nreapply the repellent during their time out of doors. He said\nresidents can also wear long-sleeve shirts and long pants to avoid\nbeing bitten.\n[Byline: Stephanie Thompson]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n[The organism that causes tularemia, _Francisella tularensis_, was\nisolated from humans in 1919 during an investigation of the cause of\ndeerfly fever in Utah. Laboratory studies conducted at the time\nconfirmed that deerflies (_Chrysops discalis_) can transmit the\norganism among animals. Despite this original association with biting\nflies, most cases in the United States are attributed to non-insect\nexposures, especially tick bites and contact with infected animal tissues.\nRegarding to treatment with antimicrobials, the following comes from\nthe New York City Health Department\n<http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/cd/tulmd.shtml#seven>:\n'The treatment of choice for all forms of tularemia except meningitis\nis streptomycin; gentamicin is an acceptable alternative. For both\ndrugs, dosages must be adjusted for renal insufficiency. Gentamicin\nis safe during pregnancy; avoid streptomycin due to its association\nwith irreversible deafness in children exposed in utero.\n(1) Streptomycin: Adult dosage is 0.5-1.0 gm (7.5 mg/kg)\nintramuscularly every 12 hours for 10-14 days. In very sick patients,\nstreptomycin may be give at 15 mg/kg intramuscularly every 12 hours\nfor 10-14 days. Pediatric dose: 15 mg/kg intramuscularly every 12\nhours for 10-14 days.\nAlternatives:\n(2) Gentamicin: 3-5 mg/kg/day intravenously or intramuscularly in 3\ndivided doses, with a peak serum level of at least 5 ug/ml desirable.\nContinue for 10-14 days. Pediatric dose: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously or\nintramuscularly every 8 hours for 10-14 days\n(3) Tetracycline and chloramphenicol are bacteriostatic and\nassociated with high relapse rates. These agents must be continued\nfor a minimum of 14 days. Tetracycline: 2 grams /day IV or orally in\n4 divided doses or doxycycline 100 mg IV or orally twice a day for at\nleast 14 days. Pediatric dose: [Not recommended for children less\nthan 9 years, pregnant or lactating women] If greater than 45 kg,\ngive adult dosage of doxycycline; if less than 45 kg, give 2.2 mg/kg\ntwice a day. Tetracycline at 30 mg/kg/day orally, to a maximum of 2\ngrams/day, in 4 divided doses for at least 14 days.\nChloramphenicol should generally not be used due to the availability\nof effective alternatives with fewer serious side effects.\n(4) Additional agents with favorable in vitro susceptibility tests\nbut limited clinical data on efficacy include: fluroquinolones\n(except cinoxacin), erythromycin (resistant strains of _F.\ntularensis_ have been identified), and rifampin. Penicillin and\ncephalosporins are not effective and should not be used to treat tularemia.'\nThe counties of Wyoming where cases have been documented (Sweetwater,\nUinta and Campbell) can be found at:\n<http://www.mapwatch.com/multi-maps/full/wyoming-county-map.gif>.\nSweetwater and Uinta are adjacent to each other in the southwestern\npart of the state, and Campbell is the northern part. - Mod.LL]\n[From an epidemiologic perspective, according to an MMWR report in\n2005 (see Tularemia Transmitted by Insect Bites --- Wyoming,\n2001--2003, February 25, 2005 / 54(07);170-173, available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5407a3.htm> ): 'During\n2001--2003, a total of 11 cases (6 confirmed; 5 probable) of\ntularemia were reported in Wyoming, for an average of 3.7 cases\nper year. In contrast, 10 cases (7 confirmed; 3 probable) were\nreported during 1990--2000, for an average of 0.9 cases per year.'\nThe confirmation of a 3rd case for this year (2007) in August,\nsuggests that this may be a year with increased transmission of\ntularemia in Wyoming. - Mods.LL/MPP]", "summary": "[From an epidemiologic perspective, according to an MMWR report in\n2005 (see Tularemia Transmitted by Insect Bites --- Wyoming,\n2001--2003, February 25, 2005 / 54(07);170-173, available at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5407a3.htm> ): 'During\n2001--2003, a total of 11 cases (6 confirmed; 5 probable) of\ntularemia were reported in Wyoming, for an average of 3.7 cases\nper year. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Regarding to treatment with antimicrobials, the following comes from\nthe New York City Health Department\n<http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/cd/tulmd.shtml#seven>:\n'The treatment of choice for all forms of tularemia except meningitis\nis streptomycin; gentamicin is an acceptable alternative. \n(4) Additional agents with favorable in vitro susceptibility tests\nbut limited clinical data on efficacy include: fluroquinolones\n(except cinoxacin), erythromycin (resistant strains of _F.\ntularensis_ have been identified), and rifampin. He said\nresidents can also wear long-sleeve shirts and long pants to avoid\nbeing bitten.\n However, since these are bites, the most common\nsymptoms are: a skin ulcer that forms by the site of infection, the\nbacteria will then spread to the lymph glands, which will swell and\nbecome painful. Alternatives:\n(2) Gentamicin: 3-5 mg/kg/day intravenously or intramuscularly in 3\ndivided doses, with a peak serum level of at least 5 ug/ml desirable. In very sick patients,\nstreptomycin may be give at 15 mg/kg intramuscularly every 12 hours\nfor 10-14 days. If greater than 45 kg,\ngive adult dosage of doxycycline; if less than 45 kg, give 2.2 mg/kg\ntwice a day.
