[Rabbits are actually\nlagomorphs, not rodents. - Mod.JW]\nTularemia is rapidly moving through the growing rabbit population,\nkilling them in droves -- although it's not making a big dent in\ntheir populations, said DiMenna and Paul Ettestad, the state public\nhealth veterinarian. 'There's been a lot of rabbit die-off in our\nnorth central counties here,' Ettestad said. 'We've had dead rabbits\nin several counties, including Santa Fe and Bernalillo, and dogs and\ncats have tested positive in 7 counties.'\nTularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is a potentially fatal\nflu-like disease in humans characterized by sudden fever, chills,\nheadache, diarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, and\nprogressive weakness. It can spread by handling an infected carcass;\nbeing bitten by an infected tick or flea; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; or breathing in the bacteria.\nOn the plus side, at least, it doesn't spread from person to person.\nAnd so far, there haven't been any human cases this year [2007] in\nNew Mexico, Ettestad said. 'But don't let the lack of cases fool you.\nTularemia and other diseases are out there', Ettestad and DiMenna said.\nIn the Albuquerque area, tularemia-infected rabbits have been found in\nareas east of Tramway Boulevard and northeast of Eubank Boulevard,\nDiMenna said. 'We have picked up so many rabbits this year [2007],\nwe've lost count,' DiMenna said. But next year [2008], unless\nsomething dramatic happens with the weather, we could see the\nsituation get much worse. We think it's going to escalate\nsubstantially. It's likely to be a much higher risk next year.' Yates\nsaid.\nThat's true with all the rodent-borne diseases -- as rodents continue\nto grow fat on plants brought out by the wet spring, DiMenna said.\n'It's almost monsoon season, and we'll probably get even more\nrodents,' he said. 'If we don't have a prolonged drought or a very\ncold winter, we could have hordes of rodents out there by next\nspring.'\nBut so far, it's not looking good for less moisture -- or for a\nparticularly cold winter, said Ted Sammis, state climatologist. 'The\nprediction is we're getting early monsoons, there's more rain than\nnormal, and it's probably going to stay that way,' Sammis said. 'And\nwinter? I can tell you that it's going to be warmer than normal. But\nthat's nothing new.'\n[Byline: Sue Vorenberg]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\n[ProMED-mail post 20070524.1658 has a discussion regarding\ntularemia in the moderator's comments. - Mod.TG\nNew Mexico, in the western U.S., can be located on the map at\n<http://www.census.gov/geo/www/us_regdiv.pdf>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: The Albuquerque Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.abqtrib.com/news/2007/jun/20/university-new-mexico-experts-warning-rash-rodents/>\n\nAbundant rains have left the [New Mexico] wild areas teeming with\nrodents -- including rats, squirrels, and rabbits -- raising the\nthreat for a host of rodent-borne diseases, said Mark DiMenna,\nenvironmental health supervisor for the city. JW]\nTularemia is rapidly moving through the growing rabbit population,\nkilling them in droves -- although it's not making a big dent in\ntheir populations, said DiMenna and Paul Ettestad, the state public\nhealth veterinarian. ' \nTularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is a potentially fatal\nflu-like disease in humans characterized by sudden fever, chills,\nheadache, diarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough, and\nprogressive weakness. In the Albuquerque area, tularemia-infected rabbits have been found in\nareas east of Tramway Boulevard and northeast of Eubank Boulevard,\nDiMenna said. The\nprediction is we're getting early monsoons, there's more rain than\nnormal, and it's probably going to stay that way,' Sammis said. ' It can spread by handling an infected carcass;\nbeing bitten by an infected tick or flea; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; or breathing in the bacteria. We've had dead rabbits\nin several counties, including Santa Fe and Bernalillo, and dogs and\ncats have tested positive in 7 counties.' If we don't have a prolonged drought or a very\ncold winter, we could have hordes of rodents out there by next\nspring.' [Byline: Sue Vorenberg]\n--\n TULAREMIA, LAGOMORPHS - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n****************************************\n That's true with all the rodent-borne diseases -- as rodents continue\nto grow fat on plants brought out by the wet spring, DiMenna said. But so far, it's not looking good for less moisture -- or for a\nparticularly cold winter, said Ted Sammis, state climatologist. ' 'We have picked up so many rabbits this year [2007],\nwe've lost count,' DiMenna said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "TG", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "13193", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, feline - USA (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=13193", "date": "2007-06-14 10:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, FELINE \ufffd USA (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate 13 June 2007\nSource: ArgusLeader.com [edited]\nhttp://www.argusleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070613/NEWS/706130308/1001\n\nCat deaths might be signs of disease\n--------------------------------------\nA dead cat in Sioux Falls has tested positive for\na bacteria that could infect humans. The cat,\nsent to the state lab in Pierre, was found to\nhave tularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever,' a\ntick- borne disease that can infect humans, said\nSioux Falls Police Lt. Tom Olson.\nIt was 1 of 5 cats found dead in the area of\nCactus Hills mobile home park in north Sioux\nFalls during the past 6 weeks. The department's\nanimal control division received the results\nTuesday, Olson said. There could be more\nunreported cases of the disease, he said.\n'Our concern is with the number of incidents\nwe've had with dead cats that potentially some of\nthe residents up in that area may have contact\nwith the cats,' Olson said. 'And this disease can\nbe spread through the contact with the dead\nanimal.'\nJudy Buseman, city public health director, said\nthe disease is not a major threat to public\nhealth. 'This is a naturally occurring disease in\nNorth America. It shows up in all the states,'\nshe said. 'This is not a public health emergency.'\nSouth Dakota last year [2006] had 6 cases of the\ndisease in humans, with an average of 200 cases a\nyear nationwide, Buseman said.\nPeople should wear rubber gloves when handling a\ndead animal, double bag the animal for disposal\nand wear tick repellent, Olson said. The disease\nis treatable but could be fatal in humans, he\nsaid. Officers informed residents in the Cactus\nHills neighborhood Tuesday of the disease.\nPeople can become infected through tick bites, by\nhandling infected, sick or dead animals, by\ndrinking contaminated water, or by inhaling\nairborne bacteria, according to animal control\nofficials.\nTularemia in humans is treatable with antibiotics, Buseman said.\nThe Cactus Hills neighborhood has had a\nlong-standing problem with stray cats, said Bob\nRabine, who lives in the neighborhood. He has\nused city traps to catch the stray cats in his\nyard, he said. 'We've caught as many as 3 or 4 of\nthem,' Rabine said. 'They were a nuisance and our\ndog hated them.'\nThe owners of the mobile home park are supposed\nto require pet owners to register their pets, the\nEwoldts said. 'The people that own the trailer\npark have no clue that people have these\nanimals,' Barb said.\nCactus Hills owner Joe Hayes said he follows the\ncity guidelines and does his best to keep track\nof who has pets. He limits residents to 2 pets\nper mobile home. Hayes said Tuesday evening [12\nJun 2007] that he had heard about the issue from\nnews reports but had not been contacted by the\ncity. 'The city hasn't notified me, no tenant has\ncalled me to say that there is an issue,' he said.\nTularemia will present with many flu-like\nsymptoms, said Dr. Aris Assimacopoulos, director\nof infection control at Avera McKennan. Symptoms,\nhowever, must be coupled with close contact with\nan infected animal or a tick bite, and a specific\ntest should be done for the disease, he said.\nTularemia is not known to transmit from person to\nperson, Assimacopoulos said. 'It's really that\nclose contact is what it's going to take,' he\nsaid.\nThere are at least 2 antibiotics used to treat\nthe human cases of the disease, Assimacopoulos\nsaid. 'The treatment is actually fairly short,'\nhe said. 'You're talking 1 to 3 weeks.'\nWhile tularemia is not commonly seen by\nveterinarians and is not common in the pet\npopulation, the disease is devastating for cats,\nsaid Dr. Dawn Dale, with the Dale Animal Hospital\nin Sioux Falls. Infected cats can develop sores\non the skin, fever, and signs of pneumonia, or\neven look like rabies, she said. 'By the time\nyour cat is sick with it, he's probably dying\nfrom it,' Dale said. She said the animals can\nalso be treated with antibiotics.\nThe disease typically is seen in wild rabbits and\ncats, so pet bunnies are not at much of a risk,\nshe said. The best protection for pets is flea\nand tick medications from a veterinarian, Dale\nsaid.\n[Byline: Matthew Gruchow\n<mgruchow@argusleader.com>]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[This article seems to place blame on a certain\narea. Yet ticks are opportunist and simply want a\nwarm body for a blood meal. If there are this\nmany stray animals, then the emerging problem may\nbe rabies, which could be a public health\nemergency.\n_Francisella tularensis_, a gram-negative\npleomorphic bacterium, is the causative agent of\ntularemia. This infectious disease was 1st\ndescribed in Japan in 1837. The name of the\ndisease is related to a 1911 description of a\nplague-like illness in ground squirrels in Tulare\nCounty, CA, and work done by Dr. Edward Francis.\nDr. Francis described his personal experience\nwith more than 800 cases in 1928. The causative\nagent is found in more than 100 species of wild\nanimals, including birds and insects, worldwide.\nThe most virulent of the 4 known strains is found\nin primarily in North America. The strains appear\nto vary in both virulence and geographical range.\nThe route of transmission and factors relating to\nthe host and the organism influence the\npresentation. The organism produces an acute\nfebrile illness in humans\nCats may display lethargy, and some relatively\nnon-specific respiratory difficulty. Cats may be\nat increased risk because of their predatory\nnature with rodents.\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and\ntetracyclines are effective at recommended dose\nlevels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol\nhave been associated with relapses in people.\nEarly treatment should prevent death. Control is\ndifficult and is limited to reducing tick\ninfestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment.\nProlonged treatment may be necessary because many\norganisms are intracellular. Use of a vaccine\npreviously available for people at high risk of\ninfection (such as laboratory personnel) is\ncurrently under review. Recovery confers\nlong-lasting immunity.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm&word=tularemia>.\nFor a map of South Dakota see:\n<http://us.i1.yimg.com/us.yimg.com/i/travel/dg/maps/8c/750x750_southdakota_m.gif>\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The cat,\nsent to the state lab in Pierre, was found to\nhave tularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever,' a\ntick- borne disease that can infect humans, said\nSioux Falls Police Lt. While tularemia is not commonly seen by\nveterinarians and is not common in the pet\npopulation, the disease is devastating for cats,\nsaid Dr. Dawn Dale, with the Dale Animal Hospital\nin Sioux Falls. People can become infected through tick bites, by\nhandling infected, sick or dead animals, by\ndrinking contaminated water, or by inhaling\nairborne bacteria, according to animal control\nofficials. Symptoms,\nhowever, must be coupled with close contact with\nan infected animal or a tick bite, and a specific\ntest should be done for the disease, he said. \nSouth Dakota last year [2006] had 6 cases of the\ndisease in humans, with an average of 200 cases a\nyear nationwide, Buseman said. \nTularemia will present with many flu-like\nsymptoms, said Dr. Aris Assimacopoulos, director\nof infection control at Avera McKennan. The name of the\ndisease is related to a 1911 description of a\nplague-like illness in ground squirrels in Tulare\n If there are this\nmany stray animals, then the emerging problem may\nbe rabies, which could be a public health\nemergency. Streptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and\ntetracyclines are effective at recommended dose\nlevels; however, tetracycline and chloramphenicol\nhave been associated with relapses in people. Use of a vaccine\npreviously available for people at high risk of\ninfection (such as laboratory personnel) is\ncurrently under review. 12\nJun 2007] that he had heard about the issue from\nnews reports but had not been contacted by the\ncity. ' \n_Francisella tularensis_, a gram-negative\npleomorphic bacterium, is the causative agent of\ntularemia. [Byline: Matthew Gruchow\n<mgruchow@argusleader.com>]\n--\n Judy Buseman, city public health director, said\nthe disease is not a major threat to public\nhealth. ' People should wear rubber gloves when handling a\ndead animal, double bag the animal for disposal\nand wear tick repellent, Olson said. The disease typically is seen in wild rabbits and\ncats, so pet bunnies are not at much of a risk,\nshe said. we've had with dead cats that potentially some of\nthe residents up in that area may have contact\nwith the cats,' Olson said. ' There are at least 2 antibiotics used to treat\nthe human cases of the disease, Assimacopoulos\nsaid. ' Infected cats can develop sores\non the skin, fever, and signs of pneumonia, or\neven look like rabies, she said. ' The disease\nis treatable but could be fatal in humans, he\nsaid. The Cactus Hills neighborhood has had a\nlong-standing problem with stray cats, said Bob\nRabine, who lives in the neighborhood. The owners of the mobile home park are supposed\nto require pet owners to register their pets, the\nEwoldts said. ' He has\nused city traps to catch the stray cats in his\nyard, he said. The people that own the trailer\npark have no clue that people have these\nanimals,' Barb said. Cactus Hills owner Joe Hayes said he follows the\ncity guidelines and does his best to keep track\nof who has pets. The best protection for pets is flea\nand tick medications from a veterinarian, Dale\nsaid. The department's\nanimal control division received the results\nTuesday, Olson said. \nTularemia is not known to transmit from person to\nperson, Assimacopoulos said. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "rabies", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1911-03-25 00:00:00", "1928-03-25 00:00:00", "1837-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tulare", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cactus Hills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "17805", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (UT, NJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=17805", "date": "2007-07-16 22:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, NEW JERSEY)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Utah\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Deseretnews.com [edited]\n<http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,685193576,00.html>\n\nSeveral people who mysteriously became sick after camping on the west\nside of Utah Lake might have contracted tularemia, officials at the\nUtah Department of Health said. While they are still awaiting lab\nconfirmation of the diagnosis, officials issued an advisory to avoid\ncontracting the infectious bacterium, which commonly causes fever and\nswollen lymph nodes. A treatable infection, tularemia usually spreads\nthrough tick and deerfly bites, but it also can be contracted through\nmosquitoes or by direct contact with an infected animal. Outdoor\nenthusiasts are advised to wear long, light-colored pants tucked into\nboots or socks and long-sleeved shirts, stay on marked trails, avoid\nwalking in tall grasses, use repellents containing DEET and avoid\ndirect contact with wild animals including their feces and carcasses.\nHealth officials advise those who believe they have infected bug\nbites to contact their physician or local health departments and\nmention tularemia. Treatments for the infection are different from\nthat typically used for skin infections.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Although the clinical manifestations in campers in the Utah outbreak\nare not described, they must have been characteristic enough of\ntularemia to warrant a presumptive diagnosis, pending laboratory\nconfirmation. Fever, chills, drenching sweats, muscle aches, malaise,\nnausea, vomiting, and weight loss usually appear 3 to 5 days after\nexposure to _Francisella tularensis_, but can take as long as 14\ndays. Other manifestations usually are specific for the mode of\ntransmission. For example, open painful sores develop where the\nbacteria entered the skin at the site of a scratch or abrasion,\nusually on the hands and fingers of hunters, or in the groin, axilla,\nand trunk in tick or deer fly-associated cases, accompanied by\nswollen, painful regional lymphadenopathy. A sore, inflamed throat\nand cervical swollen lymph nodes follow ingestion of undercooked\ninfected meat or contaminated water; abdominal pain, nausea,\nvomiting, diarrhea, and occasionally intestinal bleeding with swollen\nabdominal lymph nodes may also occur. Pneumonia may follow inhalation\nof infectious aerosols. Inhalation of an infectious aerosol is\nbelieved to be the mode of transmission if _F. tularensis_ were to be\nused as a bioweapon. A typhoidal type involves chills, high fever,\nand abdominal pain due to blood stream infection with _F. tularensis_\nin the absence of an ulcer or swollen lymph nodes. The animal source\nis usually an infected rodent or rabbit. Diagnosis is usually made on\nthe basis of positive cultures of blood or other infected material or\nserology.\nTularemia is usually treated with gentamicin or streptomycin for 7 to\n14 days, although other antibiotics, such as fluoroquinolones (e.g.,\nciprofloxacin or levofloxacin) or tetracyclines (minocyclne and\ndoxycycline) are also effective. If untreated, the overall death rate\nis 5-15 percent; less than one percent of appropriately treated\npatients die.\nUtah Lake is the largest natural freshwater lake in the state of Utah\n(see map of Utah at\n<http://www.enchantedlearning.com/usa/states/utah/>).\nWe await further reports from the Utah Department of Health on this\noutbreak. - Mod.ML]\n******\n[2] New Jersey\nDate: Sat 14 Jul 2007\nSource: Capemaycountyherald.com [edited]\n<http://www.capemaycountyherald.com/article/6917-tick-borne-illness-strikes-county-teenager>\n\nThe Cape May County Department of Health was notified on 12 Jul 2007\nthat a 14-year-old county resident has contracted tularemia, also\nknown as 'rabbit fever.'\nTularemia is a rare, potentially serious illness caused by the\nbacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which occurs widely in nature and\ncan affect animals, particularly rodents and rabbits. Tularemia can\nbe acquired in multiple ways: such as being bitten by an infected\ntick; handling infected animal carcasses; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; or inhaling the bacteria. The signs and\nsymptoms people develop depend on how they are exposed to tularemia.\nPossible symptoms include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph\nglands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea or\npneumonia. If the bacteria are inhaled, symptoms can include abrupt\nonset of fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, joint pain, dry\ncough, and progressive weakness. Tularemia can be fatal if the person\nis not treated with appropriate antibiotics.\nTo minimize risk of infection, Kevin Thomas, health officer, advises\nresidents 'to cook food thoroughly and to drink water from a safe\nsource, use a DEET-containing insect repellent on the skin, and avoid\nhandling\nanimal carcasses. If contact with animal carcasses cannot be avoided,\npersons should wear gloves and wash hands thoroughly with soap and\nwater after removing gloves.'\nFewer than 200 cases of tularemia are reported annually in the United\nStates, mainly in western and south central states. The last reported\nNew Jersey tularemia case occurred in September 2004 in a 31-year-old\nCape May County resident with extensive outdoor exposure history.\nNJDHSS is working closely with the New Jersey Department of\nEnvironmental Protection's (NJDEP) Division of Fish and Wildlife,\nwhich has not identified unusual animal die-off activity in the state\nto date.\nThe American dog tick and the Lone star tick, both found in Cape May\nCounty, are known to carry tularemia. To protect against all\ntick-borne disease, residents should follow these guidelines when\noutside with known ticks: Wear light-colored, tightly woven clothing\nto make it easier to spot ticks; tuck shirts into pants and pants\ninto socks; wear closed shoes/sneakers rather than open sandals. Use\na tick repellent as directed. Products should contain DEET (for\nclothing or skin) or Permethrin (for clothing only). Remind children\nto ask an adult to apply the tick repellent and do not apply to hands\nor face. Use products with less than 10 percent DEET, and always\nfollow manufacturers' directions carefully. Do not use repellents on\nchildren under 3 years of age. While outside, stay in the center of\ntrails, avoid low bushes and leafy brush, periodically check clothing\nand skin for ticks and remove. Once inside, check clothing, skin, and\nhair for ticks (take special note of a child's navel, underarm, groin\narea and behind the ears). If a tick is found, remove it carefully\nwith tweezers.\nInformation on tularemia is available at\n<http://www.state.nj.us/health/er/tularemia.shtml>,\nand information on tick-borne disease at\n<http://www.cmchealth.net>.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[The instructions on use of DEET in the news release above are\nsomewhat confusing. DEET, a broad-spectrum insect repellant, should\nbe applied to exposed, unbroken skin of adults and children, avoiding\nthe eyes and mouth (see\n<http://www.deet.com/content/htm/child.html>).\nThis is done by adults applying DEET to their hands and then\nspreading over exposed areas of the face and body of themselves and\nchildren. Do not allow children to apply the product themselves. Do\nnot apply to open wounds and scratches, and do not apply to the hands\nof small children, since they frequently put their hands into their\nmouths. Never spray DEET onto anyone's face, as it can cause eye\nirritation.\nThe higher the DEET concentration, the longer the hours of protection\nagainst insect bites, although concentrations exceeding about 30\npercent DEET offer little additional advantage. While several lower\nconcentrations of DEET formulations (20 percent-34 percent) offer 3-6\nhours of protection, an extended-release preparation of 35 percent\nDEET offers up to 12 hours of protection, (see\n<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics found no difference in safety for\nchildren between products containing 10 percent and 30 percent DEET\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/westnile/qa/insect_repellent.htm>)\nwhen used as directed but is said to recommend that repellents used\non children should contain no more than 10 percent DEET\n(<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>).\nThe insect repellent products that contain oil of lemon eucalyptus,\nnot DEET, should not be used on children less than 3 years of age.\nThe American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that repellents with\nDEET should not be used on infants less than 2 months old.\nDEET also can be applied to clothing made of natural fibers and nylon\nbut may destroy other synthetic fibers and plastic (such as eyeglass\nframes and watch crystals). Permethrin insect repellent can be\napplied to clothing, tents, sleeping bags, backpacks, mosquito\nnetting, etc., as directed (see\n<http://www.permethrin-repellent.com.permethrin-spray.htm>).\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n A sore, inflamed throat\nand cervical swollen lymph nodes follow ingestion of undercooked\ninfected meat or contaminated water; abdominal pain, nausea,\nvomiting, diarrhea, and occasionally intestinal bleeding with swollen\nabdominal lymph nodes may also occur. To protect against all\ntick-borne disease, residents should follow these guidelines when\noutside with known ticks: Wear light-colored, tightly woven clothing\nto make it easier to spot ticks; tuck shirts into pants and pants\ninto socks; wear closed shoes/sneakers rather than open sandals. For example, open painful sores develop where the\nbacteria entered the skin at the site of a scratch or abrasion,\nusually on the hands and fingers of hunters, or in the groin, axilla,\nand trunk in tick or deer fly-associated cases, accompanied by\nswollen, painful regional lymphadenopathy. Outdoor\nenthusiasts are advised to wear long, light-colored pants tucked into\nboots or socks and long-sleeved shirts, stay on marked trails, avoid\nwalking in tall grasses, use repellents containing DEET and avoid\ndirect contact with wild animals including their feces and carcasses. To minimize risk of infection, Kevin Thomas, health officer, advises\nresidents 'to cook food thoroughly and to drink water from a safe\nsource, use a DEET-containing insect repellent on the skin, and avoid\nhandling\nanimal carcasses. While several lower\nconcentrations of DEET formulations (20 percent-34 percent) offer 3-6\nhours of protection, an extended-release preparation of 35 percent\nDEET offers up to 12 hours of protection, (see\n<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/full/128/11/931>). Tularemia can\nbe acquired in multiple ways: such as being bitten by an infected\ntick; handling infected animal carcasses; eating or drinking\ncontaminated food or water; or inhaling the bacteria. Fever, chills, drenching sweats, muscle aches, malaise,\nnausea, vomiting, and weight loss usually appear 3 to 5 days after\nexposure to _Francisella tularensis_, but can take as long as 14\ndays. Source: Capemaycountyherald.com [edited]\n<http://www.capemaycountyherald.com/article/6917-tick-borne-illness-strikes-county-teenager>\n\nThe Cape May County Department of Health was notified on 12 Jul 2007\nthat a 14-year-old county resident has contracted tularemia, also\nknown as 'rabbit fever.' \nPossible symptoms include skin ulcers, swollen and painful lymph\nglands, inflamed eyes, sore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea or\npneumonia. While they are still awaiting lab\nconfirmation of the diagnosis, officials issued an advisory to avoid\ncontracting the infectious bacterium, which commonly causes fever and\nswollen lymph nodes. Tularemia is usually treated with gentamicin or streptomycin for 7 to\n14 days, although other antibiotics, such as fluoroquinolones (e.g.,\nciprofloxacin or levofloxacin) or tetracyclines (minocyclne and\ndoxycycline) are also effective. DEET, a broad-spectrum insect repellant, should\nbe applied to exposed, unbroken skin of adults and children, avoiding\nthe eyes and mouth (see\n<http://www.deet.com/content/htm/child.html>). Do\nnot apply to open wounds and scratches, and do not apply to the hands\nof small children, since they frequently put their hands into their\nmouths. Source: Deseretnews.com [edited]\n<http://deseretnews.com/dn/view/0,1249,685193576,00.html>\n\nSeveral people who mysteriously became sick after camping on the west\nside of Utah Lake might have contracted tularemia, officials at the\nUtah Department of Health said. Permethrin insect repellent can be\napplied to clothing, tents, sleeping bags, backpacks, mosquito\nnetting, etc., as directed (see\n<http://www.permethrin-repellent.com.permethrin-spray.htm>). Information on tularemia is available at\n<http://www.state.nj.us/health/er/tularemia.shtml>,\nand information on tick-borne disease at\n<http://www.cmchealth.net>. [Although the clinical manifestations in campers in the Utah outbreak\nare not described, they must have been characteristic enough of\ntularemia to warrant a presumptive diagnosis, pending laboratory\nconfirmation. \nDEET also can be applied to clothing made of natural fibers and nylon\nbut may destroy other synthetic fibers and plastic (such as eyeglass\nframes and watch crystals). NJDHSS is working closely with the New Jersey Department of\nEnvironmental Protection's (NJDEP) Division of Fish and Wildlife,\nwhich has not identified unusual animal die-off activity in the state\nto date. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n A treatable infection, tularemia usually spreads\nthrough tick and deerfly bites, but it also can be contracted through\nmosquitoes or by direct contact with an infected animal. A typhoidal type involves chills, high fever,\nand abdominal pain due to blood stream infection with _F. tularensis_\nin the absence of an ulcer or swollen lymph nodes. Remind children\nto ask an adult to apply the tick repellent and do not apply to hands\nor face. The American Academy of Pediatrics found no difference in safety for\nchildren between products containing 10 percent and 30 percent DEET\n While outside, stay in the center of\ntrails, avoid low bushes and leafy brush, periodically check clothing\nand skin for ticks and remove. If contact with animal carcasses cannot be avoided,\npersons should wear gloves and wash hands thoroughly with soap and\nwater after removing gloves.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Jersey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "May County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Permethrin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape May", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DEET", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10562", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, feline - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10562", "date": "2007-05-24 14:00:01", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, FELINE - USA (COLORADO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 23 May 2007\nSource: Denver Post [edited]\n<http://www.denverpost.com/nuggets/ci_5962784>\n\nSpring rains in the Front Range, after years of drought, are leading\nto thriving populations of mice and other rodents -- carrying the\nrare, sometimes deadly diseases of plague, tularemia, and hantavirus.\n'It certainly has been a good year, so far for, the rodent diseases,'\nsaid state epidemiologist John Pape.\nA man in Weld County is recovering from hantavirus pulmonary\nsyndrome, officials said Wednesday [23 May 2007]. An Alamosa County\nwoman died of the same respiratory disease -- spread by infected mice\n-- earlier this month [May 2007].\nPlague killed a capuchin monkey at the Denver Zoo last week [14-20\nMay 2007], after 20 cases were discovered in tree squirrels in the\nCity Park area.\nThe bacterial disease kills about 18 people annually in the United States.\nThis spring, at least 2 cats in southwestern Colorado have tested\npositive for tularemia.\nWhen the tularemia bacteria affect humans, it is known as 'rabbit\nfever.' About 200 people come down with the fever each year.\n'In wet years, we have lots of vegetation and explosive population\nbooms in rodents,' Pape said. 'The more dense they are, the better\nthey transmit disease.'\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_ -- a form of the bacteria that\nkilled an estimated 25 million people in Europe during the Middle\nAges. It is rare today, but about 1 in 7 people infected dies because\nthe disease is not caught early enough. Humans usually get plague\nfrom infected fleas, which pick it up from squirrels, prairie dogs,\nand other rodents, Pape said.\nPlague is always simmering in Colorado's rodent populations, Pape\nsaid, but the disease boils up into an outbreak every 5 to 10 years,\nsometimes killing off whole colonies of prairie dogs. It's usually\nduring those years that the human cases occur, he added.\n[Last week (14-20 May 2007) in Weld County, a 30-year-old man turned\nup with hantavirus, another rodent-related disease. The source of the\ninfection has not been determined, said county spokeswoman Gaye\nMorrison. It is usually caught when a person inhales dust\ncontaminated with mouse urine or feces, or through direct contact with mice.\nEarly last spring [2006], health experts discovered plague at several\nFront Range locations and feared the disease might take off, Pape\nsaid. 'Then it was hot for 6 weeks and that absolutely shut it off,'\nPape said. 'During long, hot, dry periods, fleas literally dry up and die.'\nSouthwestern Colorado stayed relatively cool last spring [2006] and\nall 4 of Colorado's human plague cases showed up in the region, said\nJoe Fowler, a registered nurse and epidemiologist for the San Juan\nBasin Health Department. [A 13-year-old girl] who lives outside\nDurango, said she spent a miserable 4 days in Mercy Hospital with\nplague last summer [2006], feverish and vomiting.\nThis year, Fowler said, 2 cats in the southwest suspected to have\nplague turned up positive for tularemia. In people, tularemia\nbacteria can trigger a wide variety of symptoms, from skin ulcers to\ndiarrhea, to fever, depending on whether it is inhaled, ingested, or\ncaught from an infected tick or deerfly. 'We do have lots of growth,\nso humans are encroaching on areas where rodents carrying plague\nlive,' Fowler said.\n[Byline: Katy Human]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\n[Although this article mentions reasons for the increase in\nrodentborne diseases, the focus is that this is the 1st article that\nhas reported tularemia in cats. The causative agent for Tularemia is\n_Francisella tularensis_.\n_Francisella tularensis_, a gram-negative pleomorphic bacterium, is\nthe causative agent of tularemia. This infectious disease was 1st\ndescribed in Japan in 1837. The name of the disease is related to a\n1911 description of a plague-like illness in ground squirrels in\nTulare County, California, and work done by Dr. Edward Francis. Dr.\nFrancis described his personal experience with more than 800 cases in\n1928. The causative agent is found in more than 100 species of wild\nanimals, including birds and insects, worldwide. The most virulent of\nthe 4 known strains is found in primarily in North America. The\nstrains appear to vary in both virulence and geographical range.\nThe route of transmission and factors relating to the host and the\norganism influence the presentation. The organism produces an acute\nfebrile illness in humans\nCats may display lethargy, and some relatively non-specific\nrespiratory difficulty. Cats may be at increased risk because of\ntheir predatory nature with rodents.\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are\neffective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and\nchloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early\ntreatment should prevent death. Control is difficult and is limited\nto reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and treatment.\nProlonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are\nintracellular. Use of a vaccine previously available for people at\nhigh risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently\nunder review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm&word=tularemia>.\n- Mod.TG\nThe U.S. western state of Colorado can be located on the map at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/unitedstates.html>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Denver Post [edited]\n<http://www.denverpost.com/nuggets/ci_5962784>\n\nSpring rains in the Front Range, after years of drought, are leading\nto thriving populations of mice and other rodents -- carrying the\nrare, sometimes deadly diseases of plague, tularemia, and hantavirus. Southwestern Colorado stayed relatively cool last spring [2006] and\nall 4 of Colorado's human plague cases showed up in the region, said\nJoe Fowler, a registered nurse and epidemiologist for the San Juan\nBasin Health Department. In people, tularemia\nbacteria can trigger a wide variety of symptoms, from skin ulcers to\ndiarrhea, to fever, depending on whether it is inhaled, ingested, or\ncaught from an infected tick or deerfly. ' Plague is always simmering in Colorado's rodent populations, Pape\nsaid, but the disease boils up into an outbreak every 5 to 10 years,\nsometimes killing off whole colonies of prairie dogs. Humans usually get plague\nfrom infected fleas, which pick it up from squirrels, prairie dogs,\nand other rodents, Pape said. Early last spring [2006], health experts discovered plague at several\nFront Range locations and feared the disease might take off, Pape\nsaid. ' An Alamosa County\nwoman died of the same respiratory disease -- spread by infected mice\n-- earlier this month [May 2007]. We do have lots of growth,\nso humans are encroaching on areas where rodents carrying plague\nlive,' Fowler said. Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_ -- a form of the bacteria that\nkilled an estimated 25 million people in Europe during the Middle\nAges. The name of the disease is related to a\n1911 description of a plague-like illness in ground squirrels in\nTulare County, California, and work done by Dr. Edward Francis. [Although this article mentions reasons for the increase in\nrodentborne diseases, the focus is that this is the 1st article that\nhas reported tularemia in cats. [14-20\nMay 2007], after 20 cases were discovered in tree squirrels in the\nCity Park area. Streptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are\neffective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and\nchloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. \n_Francisella tularensis_, a gram-negative pleomorphic bacterium, is\nthe causative agent of tularemia. Use of a vaccine previously available for people at\nhigh risk of infection (such as, laboratory personnel) is currently\nunder review. The source of the\ninfection has not been determined, said county spokeswoman Gaye\n It is usually caught when a person inhales dust\ncontaminated with mouse urine or feces, or through direct contact with mice.\n The more dense they are, the better\nthey transmit disease.'\n The organism produces an acute\nfebrile illness in humans\n TULAREMIA, FELINE - USA (COLORADO)\n**********************************\n [Byline: Katy Human]\n--\n \nProlonged treatment may be necessary because many organisms are\nintracellular.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hantavirus", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1911-03-25 00:00:00", "1837-03-25 00:00:00", "1928-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-05-23 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tulare County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alamosa County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10022", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, ovine - USA (ID)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10022", "date": "2007-04-28 18:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, OVINE - USA (IDAHO)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 28 Apr 2007\nSource:Times-News magicvalley.com [edited]\n<http://www.magicvalley.com/articles/2007/04/28/news/local_state/111112.txt>\n\nUnusual disease affects valley sheep\n----------------------------------------\nIn the sagebrush desert near the intersection of Lincoln, Minidoka\nand Blaine counties [in Idaho], grazing sheep don't pay much\nattention to county lines. So officials at the Idaho State Department\nof Agriculture aren't sure exactly where a flock of sheep was bitten\nby ticks carrying a bacterial infection earlier this month [April\n2007]. About 300 sheep were infected with tularemia, and 10 lambs\nhave died, the department reported Friday.\n'That flock has been treated,' said John Chatburn, deputy\nadministrator with the department, declining to identify the sheep\nproducer. 'The Idaho Sheep Commission and the Idaho Wool Growers\nAssociation have notified the sheep producers in that area, and given\nthem the information on the preventive measures they need to take to\ntreat their sheep,' he said. 'The Department of Agriculture has\nnotified the veterinarians in the state that we have had a case of\ntularemia, and to be on the lookout for it.'\nTularemia rarely has been seen in Idaho in the past decade, with 3\ncases of human infection reported in the state during that time. The\ndisease is commonly carried by ticks, which bite their hosts and\ntransmit the infection. Without antibiotics, the infection can be\nfatal.\nThe Department of Agriculture is not sure why there are more ticks\nthis year than in previous years, but speculates that weather may be\nresponsible. This uptick of ticks means higher possibilities of\ninsect-borne infections. 'A number of the livestock producers in that\narea have reported higher-than-usual concentrations of ticks,'\nChatburn said. 'That would be probably due to environmental\nconditions.' Ticks tend to thrive in warm, dry regions, a description\nsouthern Idaho fits after its mild winter, he said.\nMarilyn Simunich, a veterinarian with the department, said she\nworries that the outbreak of infection could worsen, particularly if\nfarmers don't take precautions to protect themselves and their\nlivestock. Signs of infection in sheep are not always obvious, she\nsaid.\n'They don't eat, they lay down. That's how sheep are; they don't show\na lot of signs, they act like they don't want to live,' Simunich\nsaid. 'If they have a big tick infestation, they can become anemic\njust from having ticks sucking on them.'\nChatburn is asking all livestock producers to report tick\ninfestations and infected animals to their veterinarians. The vets\nwill pass those reports to the Department of Agriculture, which will\ntrack the outbreak. 'Farmers should be worried; they need to check\ntheir livestock and see if they have an inordinate number of ticks on\nthem,' he said. 'Certainly animals in the area where the high\nincidence of ticks are, are susceptible to it if they aren't treated\nto get the ticks off them.'\nIn cooperation with South Central District Health, the Department of\nAgriculture is also warning humans against the tick-borne infection.\nTicks do not jump from host to host but spread through direct contact\nwith plants or animals that are carriers.\n'Ticks potentially carry a number of diseases, and people who are out\nin areas where they could have ticks get on them certainly need to\nfollow the advice and check themselves for ticks if they're out in\nbrushy areas,' Chatburn said. He noted that ticks can carry a variety\nof diseases, from tularemia to Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and that\nthese illnesses can be serious.\nCheryle Becker of District Health suggests wearing long clothing and\ntucking pant legs into shoes when you walk in desert areas where\nsagebrush grows. Afterward, thoroughly check all parts of your body,\nwith a mirror if necessary. If a tick is found, remove it carefully\nwith tweezers and watch yourself for symptoms of disease. 'If you\nfind a tick and you develop an illness with that tick bite, you need\nto have your doctor check it out,' Becker said.\nThere have been 5 Idaho cases of tularemia infection since 1995,\nBecker said, but no deaths attributed to the infection in the 25\nyears she has been with the department. Humans should take\nprecautions against contracting the infection from a tick during a\nwalk through sagebrush, Chatburn said, but they should not worry\nabout contracting it through the food chain. 'None of those\nparticular sheep in that flock had reached the food channels,' he\nsaid. 'If they had they would have been diagnosed at slaughter and\ncondemned because of the physiological changes that occur in sick\nsheep.'\n[Byline: Ariel Hansen <ariel.hansen@lee.ne>]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Tularemia is a potentially serious illness that occurs naturally in\nthe United States. It is caused by the bacterium _Francisella\ntularensis_ found in animals (especially rodents, rabbits, and hares).\nIn domestic animals, sheep are the primary host, but clinical\ninfection has been reported in dogs, pigs, and horses. Cats are at\nincreased risk due to predatory behavior and appear to have an\nincreased susceptibility, while cattle appear to be resistant. Little\nis known of the true incidence and spectrum of clinical disease in\ndomestic animals. Important wild animal hosts include cottontail and\njackrabbits, beaver, muskrat, meadow voles, and sheep in North\nAmerica, and other voles, field mice, and lemmings in Europe and Asia.\nThe incubation period is 1-10 days. In sheep and most mammals, the\ndisease is characterized by sudden onset of high fever, lethargy,\nanorexia, stiffness, reduced mobility, or other signs associated with\nsepticemic disease. Pulse and respiratory rates are increased.\nCoughing, diarrhea, and pollakiuria may develop. Prostration and\ndeath may occur in a few hours or days. Sporadic cases are best\nrecognized by signs of septicemia. Outbreaks in untreated lambs may\nhave up to 15 percent mortality. Subclinical cases may be common.\nThe most consistent lesions are miliary, white to off-white foci of\nnecrosis in the liver and sometimes in the spleen and lymph nodes.\nEnlargement of the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes is common.\nOrganisms can be readily isolated from necropsy specimens by use of\nspecial media. Risk of infection during necropsy or to laboratory\npersonnel is significant; special procedures and facilities are\nessential.\nTularemia must be differentiated from other septicemic diseases\n(especially plague) or acute pneumonia. When large numbers of sheep\nshow typical signs during periods of heavy tick infestation,\ntularemia or tick paralysis should be suspected. Tularemia should be\nconsidered in cats with signs of acute lymphadenopathy, malaise, oral\nulcers, and history of recent ingestion of wild prey.\nDiagnosis of acute infection is confirmed by culture and\nidentification of the bacterium, direct or indirect fluorescent\nantibody test, or a 4-fold increase in antibody titer between acute\nand convalescent serum specimens. A single titer of =1:80 by the tube\nagglutination test is presumptive evidence of prior infection. When\ntularemia is suspected, laboratory personnel should be alerted to\nreduce the risk of laboratory-acquired infection.\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, chloramphenicol, and tetracyclines are\neffective at recommended dose levels; however, tetracycline and\nchloramphenicol have been associated with relapses in people. Early\ntreatment should prevent death loss. Control is difficult and is\nlimited to reducing tick infestation and to rapid diagnosis and\ntreatment. Prolonged treatment may be necessary because many\norganisms are intracellular. Use of a vaccine previously available\nfor people at high risk of infection (e.g., laboratory personnel) is\ncurrently under review. Recovery confers long-lasting immunity.\nIn people tularemia can be acquired through various routes including\nbeing bitten by an infected tick, deerfly or other insect, handling\ninfected animal carcasses, eating or drinking contaminated food or\nwater or breathing in the bacterium, _F. tularensis_. Symptoms of\ntularemia could include:sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea,\nmuscle aches, joint pain, enlarged lymph nodes, especially under the\narms and in the groin, dry cough, an enlarging ulcerated area and\nprogressive weakness. People can also catch pneumonia and develop\nchest pain, bloody sputum and can have trouble breathing and even\nsometimes stop breathing.\nOther symptoms of tularemia depend on how a person was exposed to the\ntularemia bacterium. These symptoms can include ulcers on the skin or\nmouth, swollen and painful lymph glands, swollen and painful eyes,\nand a sore throat. If you suspect you may have the disease or have\nsome of the symptoms, consult your physician. The disease can be\ntreated with antibiotics.\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from a CDC fact sheet at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/tularemia.htm> and from\nthe Merck Veterinary Manual at:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm&word\n=tularemia>\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "Portions of this comment have been extracted from a CDC fact sheet at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/tularemia.htm> and from\nthe Merck Veterinary Manual at:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/52400.htm&word\n=tularemia>\n- Mod. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Symptoms of\ntularemia could include:sudden fever, chills, headaches, diarrhea,\nmuscle aches, joint pain, enlarged lymph nodes, especially under the\narms and in the groin, dry cough, an enlarging ulcerated area and\nprogressive weakness. \nMarilyn Simunich, a veterinarian with the department, said she\nworries that the outbreak of infection could worsen, particularly if\nfarmers don't take precautions to protect themselves and their\nlivestock. Ticks potentially carry a number of diseases, and people who are out\nin areas where they could have ticks get on them certainly need to\nfollow the advice and check themselves for ticks if they're out in\nbrushy areas,' Chatburn said. The Idaho Sheep Commission and the Idaho Wool Growers\nAssociation have notified the sheep producers in that area, and given\nthem the information on the preventive measures they need to take to\ntreat their sheep,' he said. ' So officials at the Idaho State Department\nof Agriculture aren't sure exactly where a flock of sheep was bitten\nby ticks carrying a bacterial infection earlier this month [April\n2007]. Source:Times-News magicvalley.com [edited]\n<http://www.magicvalley.com/articles/2007/04/28/news/local_state/111112.txt>\n\nUnusual disease affects valley sheep\n In the sagebrush desert near the intersection of Lincoln, Minidoka\nand Blaine counties [in Idaho], grazing sheep don't pay much\nattention to county lines.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "District Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9900", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed fatal illness - Iran (Sistan-Baluchestan) (02): tularemia?", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9900", "date": "2007-04-23 15:00:02", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED FATAL ILLNESS - IRAN (SISTAN-BALUCHESTAN) (02): POSSIBLE TULAREMIA\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 20 Apr 2007\nFrom: Jain Morisson <jainmorisson@yahoo.com>\n\nIranian news media online reports that there have been 36 cases with\n8 deaths from tularemia, probably from contaminated food [or water -\nMod.LL]. No additional cases have occurred in the past 72 hours.\n--\nJain Morisson\n<jainmorisson@yahoo.com>\n[This submitter reports that tularemia is the cause of the febrile\noroglandular syndrome recently posted. That _Francisella tularensis_\ninfection occurs in Iran is supported by a study published in 1973,\nthat serological evidence of infection was found in animals scattered\nthroughout Iran (Arata A, Chamsa M, Farhand-Azad A, et al: First\ndetection of tularaemia in domestic and wild mammals in Iran. Bull\nWld Mlth Org. 1973;49:597-603.)\nSistan-Baluchestan province is located in extreme southeastern Iran\nas can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sistan_and_Baluchistan_Province>. The\nprovince comprises 2 sections, Sistan in the north and Baluchestan in\nthe south. The combined Sistan and Baluchestan province today\naccounts for one of the driest regions of Iran. - Mod.LL]\n.............................................ll/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
