Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: UNDIAGNOSED FATAL ILLNESS - IRAN (SISTAN-BALUCHESTAN) (02): POSSIBLE TULAREMIA\n******************************************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1973-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Baluchestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "undiagnosed", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8870", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8870", "date": "2007-03-14 23:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (GEGARKUNIQ)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon 12 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: ArmInfo [trans.AS, edited]\n<http://www.arminfo.info/index.php?show=archive&number=20070312_151000_rus_684.html>\n\nIn one of the villages of the Gegarkuniq region of Armenia,\nTsovagyukh, several inhabitants have been diagnosed with tularemia,\nan acute infectious disease transmitted from animals.\nA. Asoyan, the head physician of the Republican Infectious Diseases\nHospital, informed the correspondent of Arminfo that the diagnosis is\nconfirmed in 6 patients. The emergency group of physicians and\nepidemiologists have been working since 10 Mar 2007, and an alert was issued.\nThe doctors think that the infection will be confirmed in another 10\ncases as well. The possibility of a water-borne outbreak is thought\nnot to be likely because of the relatively low number of cases.\nAn outbreak occurred in the village of Fontanka in 2004, and it was\nsubsequently confirmed that the source of infection in about 300\npeople was drinking water. This time, epidemiologists consider that\nthe source of infection is small mammals [hares? - Mod.JW], as\naccording to the statements of village inhabitants, 'there is an\nabundance of them in the village area.'\nDoctor Asoyan said also that tularemia is easily treated and they\nhave diagnosed only lymphatic forms of disease and not the pulmonary\nform, which can be much more severe. He also said that more than 1000\npeople have been vaccinated, and all others (4500 inhabitants) are in\nthe process of being vaccinated.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 10 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Center for Disease Prevention and Control of the Republic of\nArmenia [trans.AS, edited]\n\nAn outbreak of tularemia has been reported in the village of\nTsovagyuk of the Gegarkuniq region of Armenia on 10 Mar 2007.\nAt this point, 40 people have presented themselves for medical care.\nThe source of infection has not been determined, but the water source\nis a possibility. Oculoglandular, oro-glandular and glandular forms\nof disease have been reported. The patients are receiving appropriate\ntreatment. New patients are being identified.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These 2 reports do not agree on the numbers of cases registered\nduring this outbreak. After additional inquiry, it has been made\nclear that the 40 cases are the cumulative incidence of tularemia\nsince January 2007. The 16 recent cases may be the result of more of\nthe continuing outbreak only. - Corr.AS]\n[The postings report primary lesions in the mouth and conjunctivae\nand not on the skin, which suggests an aerosolized and ingested\nvehicle. Most individuals infected with _Francisella\ntularensis_ [the causative coccobacillus - Mod.JW] by cuts, tick or\nother insect bites or other forms of trauma develop glandular or\nulceroglandular disease (with the primary lesion on the skin). The\nepidemiology of the outbreak remains unclear.\nA map of the land-locked country of Armenia can be found at:\n<http://www.eurasianet.org/resource/armenia/images/armenia_map.jpg>.\nThe area involved, however, could not be found on a map of the\ncountry. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nA. Asoyan, the head physician of the Republican Infectious Diseases\nHospital, informed the correspondent of Arminfo that the diagnosis is\nconfirmed in 6 patients. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n An outbreak occurred in the village of Fontanka in 2004, and it was\nsubsequently confirmed that the source of infection in about 300\npeople was drinking water. The possibility of a water-borne outbreak is thought\nnot to be likely because of the relatively low number of cases.\n JW] by cuts, tick or\nother insect bites or other forms of trauma develop glandular or\nulceroglandular disease (with the primary lesion on the skin). Doctor Asoyan said also that tularemia is easily treated and they\nhave diagnosed only lymphatic forms of disease and not the pulmonary\nform, which can be much more severe. After additional inquiry, it has been made\nclear that the 40 cases are the cumulative incidence of tularemia\nsince January 2007. In one of the villages of the Gegarkuniq region of Armenia,\nTsovagyukh, several inhabitants have been diagnosed with tularemia,\nan acute infectious disease transmitted from animals. JW], as\naccording to the statements of village inhabitants, 'there is an\nabundance of them in the village area.' [The postings report primary lesions in the mouth and conjunctivae\nand not on the skin, which suggests an aerosolized and ingested\nvehicle. people have been vaccinated, and all others (4500 inhabitants) are in\nthe process of being vaccinated.\n >\nSource: Center for Disease Prevention and Control of the Republic of\nArmenia [trans. --\nProMED-mail\n< TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (GEGARKUNIQ)\n***********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Armenia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7037", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7037", "date": "2007-01-27 21:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, POTABLE WATER - GEORGIA (KASPSKIY) (02)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 15 Jan 2007\nFrom: Lela Bakanidze <lbakanidze@yahoo.com>\nSource: National Center for Disease Control and Medical Statistics of\nGeorgia [edited]\n\nThe National Center for Disease Control and Medical Statistics of\nGeorgia (NCDC) has received urgent notification from the Tbilisi\nInfectious Diseases Hospital: A 46-year-old man living in the village\nZemo Ren [also spelled Zemo Rene], Kaspskiy [also spelled Kaspi]\nDistrict (Eastern Georgia, an endemic focus of tularemia) was\nadmitted and hospitalized in the Tbilisi Infectious Diseases Hospital\non 15 Jan 2007 with a clinical diagnosis of tularemia. According to\nthe epidemiological history, the same symptoms had been observed in\nother inhabitants of the same village as well. NCDC experts visited\nZemo Rene village for further investigation.\nEpidemiological investigation was conducted, and 18 cases of\ntularemia were identified (including the one case reported from\nTbilisi Infectious Diseases Hospital). The ulceroglandular form of\ntularemia was manifested in all patients. According to the\ninterviews, the 1st symptoms of tularemia were suspected in early\nDecember 2006, however, tularemia was not diagnosed at that time. The\npatients ages ranged from 11 to 75 years. Distribution by sex: 8\nfemale, 10 male.\nThe blood from all cases was sampled for serological testing. A\n4-fold and more increase in the titer was registered in 16 cases. The\nblood samples from 2 patients are still being tested. Smears from\ntularemic ulcers from 2 patients were tested for bacteria using real\ntime PCR. Results were positive in both cases.\nThe drinking water for Zemo Rene village comes from the local small\nspring; it is collected in an open reservoir and is supplied without\nany filtration. Water from the reservoir was investigated as well,\nand presence of _Francisella tularensis_ was confirmed.\nTreatment for all patients was started. Villagers are under\nsurveillance for additional cases.\n--\nDr. Lela Bakanidze\nHead/Bioterrorism Threat Reduction & International Relations\nNational Centre for Disease Control of Georgia\nTblisi, Georgia\n<lbakanidze@yahoo.com>\n[ProMED sincerely thanks Dr. Bakanidze for the official report of\nthis cluster.\nA map of Georgia can be found at:\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/europe/georgia/georgia.htm>.\nThe Kaspskiy district is in the eastern part of the country. - Mod.LL]\n[Image of tularemia skin ulcer\n<http://pathmicro.med.sc.edu/ghaffar/tularemia.jpg>\nImage of tularemia glandular infection\n<http://www.logicalimages.com/images/catA_tularemia1Lg.jpg> - Mod.JW]", "summary": "--\nDr. Lela Bakanidze\nHead/Bioterrorism Threat Reduction & International Relations\nNational Centre for Disease Control of Georgia\nTblisi, Georgia\n<lbakanidze@yahoo.com>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Image of tularemia skin ulcer\n<http://pathmicro.med.sc.edu/ghaffar/tularemia.jpg>\nImage of tularemia glandular infection\n<http://www.logicalimages.com/images/catA_tularemia1Lg.jpg> - Mod. [edited]\n\nThe National Center for Disease Control and Medical Statistics of\nGeorgia (NCDC) has received urgent notification from the Tbilisi\nInfectious Diseases Hospital: A 46-year-old man living in the village\n District (Eastern Georgia, an endemic focus of tularemia) was\nadmitted and hospitalized in the Tbilisi Infectious Diseases Hospital\non 15 Jan 2007 with a clinical diagnosis of tularemia. According to the\ninterviews, the 1st symptoms of tularemia were suspected in early\nDecember 2006, however, tularemia was not diagnosed at that time. Epidemiological investigation was conducted, and 18 cases of\ntularemia were identified (including the one case reported from\nTbilisi Infectious Diseases Hospital). The drinking water for Zemo Rene village comes from the local small\nspring; it is collected in an open reservoir and is supplied without\nany filtration. Smears from\ntularemic ulcers from 2 patients were tested for bacteria using real\ntime PCR. According to\nthe epidemiological history, the same symptoms had been observed in\nother inhabitants of the same village as well. Villagers are under\nsurveillance for additional cases.\n The ulceroglandular form of\ntularemia was manifested in all patients. The\nblood samples from 2 patients are still being tested. A\n4-fold and more increase in the titer was registered in 16 cases. TULAREMIA, POTABLE WATER - GEORGIA (KASPSKIY) (02)\n The\npatients ages ranged from 11 to 75 years. NCDC experts visited\nZemo Rene village for further investigation. Water from the reservoir was investigated as well,\nand presence of _Francisella tularensis_ was confirmed. Distribution by sex: 8\nfemale, 10 male. [ProMED sincerely thanks Dr. Bakanidze for the official report of\nthis cluster. Date: 15 Jan 2007\n Zemo Ren [also spelled Zemo Rene], Kaspskiy [also spelled Kaspi]\n A map of Georgia can be found at:\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/europe/georgia/georgia.htm>. From: Lela Bakanidze <lbakanidze@yahoo.com>\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-01-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tblisi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9314", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, water-borne - Norway (North)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9314", "date": "2007-03-29 21:00:02", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WATER-BORNE - NORWAY (NORTH)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 29 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070329.asp#2>\n\nSince November 2006, 9 cases of tularemia from 3 adjacent\nmunicipalities in northern Norway have been laboratory-confirmed.\nAccording to notification forms from clinicians, 8 cases had cervical\nlymphadenopathy, with additional mention of oral or pharyngeal\ninfection in 5. Information about the clinical picture is missing for\none case at the time of submission of this report. The median age of\nthe cases is 22 years (range 2-54 years), and 7 are female. At the\ntime of notification, 2 patients had recovered, 2 were still ill, and\ninformation was missing for the remaining 5; 4 of the cases were hospitalized.\nTularemia is endemic in Norway and is caused by _Francisella\ntularensis_, which can be transmitted by rodents and hares. Large\nnumbers of dead rodents (lemmings, _Lemmus lemmus_) are currently\nreported in the affected area after a large surge in the lemming\npopulation last autumn [2006].\nInvestigation into the source of infection:\n-------------------------------------------\nClinical and epidemiological information was obtained from clinical\nnotification forms and supplemented by information from municipal\nmedical officers in the affected areas. Laboratory results were\navailable from the laboratory notification form for each case.\nSpecific antibodies were detected in the serum of all cases, using a\ncombination of agglutination and ELlSA-technique, the latter allowing\ndiscrimination between IgG and IgM response. Results from the\nanalysis of water samples were obtained by direct contact with the\nlaboratory. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was performed on filter\npaper samples after filtration of water and was positive for _F.\ntularensis_ in samples from one of 4 tested wells.\nThe clinical manifestation of oropharyngeal tularaemia generally\nsuggests transmission by water or food (1). Because of the recent\nsurge in the lemming population, drinking water contaminated by\nrodents was, at an early stage, suspected as the most likely source\nof infection; this has also been shown to be the most frequent cause\nof infection with _F. tularensis_ in Norway (2). Three of the cases\nlive in areas with a municipal water supply, which, after technical\ninspection, was found to be an unlikely source of contaminated water.\nThese 3 cases were children aged 2 to 4 years who live in the same\nneighborhood and who have frequently been observed eating snow.\nContaminated snow is a possible source of infection for these cases.\nThe remaining 6 cases all had private wells. Water from 4 of the\nwells was analysed, one testing positive for _F. tularensis_ by PCR.\nTo our knowledge, no rodents have been tested.\nControl measures:\n----------------------\nThe public in the 3 affected municipalities have been informed by the\nmedia about the current increased risk of tularemia. People with\nprivate wells have been asked to inspect these for rodent carcasses\nand potential rodent entrances and to take corrective measures as\nrequired. Advice has been given regarding cleaning and disinfection\nof potentially contaminated wells by shock chlorination (i.e. adding\nchorine to a concentration of 30-50 mg/L for 1-2 hours) and by\nboiling of water for domestic use until corrective measures have\ntaken effect. The public has been asked to refrain from drinking\nwater that has not been disinfected or boiled while involved in\noutdoor activities such as hiking and camping.\nDiscussion:\n----------\nTularaemia in Norway is caused by _F. tularensis_ subsp. holarctica,\nwhich generally gives rise to milder disease symptoms than other\nsubspecies. Since 1978, the annual number of reported cases in Norway\nhas varied between none and 47, oropharyngeal tularemia being the\nmost common manifestation (2). Relatively few cases have been\nassociated with insect bites. This is in contrast to the situation in\nSweden and Finland, where the annual incidence generally is more than\n10 times higher than in Norway, and where insect bites are considered\nan important mode of transmission (3). Transmission by insects or by\nskin contact with rodents generally leads to ulceroglandular\ntularemia. This is characterised by an ulcer at the place of entry of\nthe bacteria through the skin with accompanying regional\nlymphadenitis and is less common in Norway than oropharyngeal tularaemia.\nTularaemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague,' clearly indicating rodents and hares as transmitters\nof disease. An increase in the incidence of tularaemia has often been\nobserved in years with a surge in rodent populations or in the months\nthereafter. 2006 was a so called 'lemming year' in the affected area,\nand infected carcasses represent a potential source of infection for\nhumans who come into direct or indirect contact with these. Norway\nhas experienced several outbreaks of water-borne tularemia, the\nlargest in 2002 in the municipality of Midtre Gauldal in central\nNorway, with 11 laboratory-confirmed cases. In the present outbreak\nin northern Norway, the clinical picture of oropharyngeal tularemia\npoints to ingestion of contaminated water, or possibly snow, as the\nmost likely route of transmission. Although only one case has been\ndirectly linked to a well that was confirmed to be contaminated by\n_F. tularensis_, it is possible that water in the wells that tested\nnegative in the outbreak investigation had been transiently infected\nweeks or months earlier. However, transmission via contaminated food\nor direct or indirect contact with rodents or with cats and dogs can\nnot be excluded.\nMany Norwegians live in or own leisure homes that have private wells\nwithout water treatment systems. Also, the eating of snow and\ndrinking of water that has not been disinfected, for example from\nlakes and rivers, is common practice during outdoor activities. The\nrisk of acquiring oropharyngeal tularaemia is particularly high in\nyears with a surge in rodent populations and the months thereafter,\nwhen infected carcasses represent possible sources of infection. The\npublic should be advised to take appropriate action to reduce this risk.\n1. Tarnvik A, Priebe HS, Grunow R: Tularaemia in Europe: an\nepidemiological overview. Scand J Infect Dis 2004;36: 350-55.\n2. Brantsaeter AB: Twenty-five years of tularaemia in Norway,\n1978-2002. Abstract number: 10.1111/j.1198-743X.2004.902_o142.x.\nEuropean Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases\n14th European Congress of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious\nDiseases, Prague / Czech Republic, 1?4 May 2004.\n3. Eliasson H, Lindback J, Nuorti JP, et al: The 2000 tularaemia\noutbreak: a case-control study of risk factors in disease-endemic and\nemergent areas, Sweden. Emerg Infect Dis 2002;8: 956-60.\n[Byline: Brantsaeter AB <abbr@fhi.no>1, Krogh T, Radtke A, Nygard K]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is an interesting report of a seemingly water- (and possibly\nsnow-) borne outbreak of tularemia.\nAn interesting discourse on lemmings is in\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemming>;\na picture can be found at the original URL:\nA map of Norway can be found at:\n<http://2004.guadec.org/images/norway.png>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Because of the recent\nsurge in the lemming population, drinking water contaminated by\nrodents was, at an early stage, suspected as the most likely source\nof infection; this has also been shown to be the most frequent cause\nof infection with _F. tularensis_ in Norway (2). Although only one case has been\ndirectly linked to a well that was confirmed to be contaminated by\n_F. tularensis_, it is possible that water in the wells that tested\nnegative in the outbreak investigation had been transiently infected\nweeks or months earlier. Advice has been given regarding cleaning and disinfection\nof potentially contaminated wells by shock chlorination (i.e. adding\nchorine to a concentration of 30-50 mg/L for 1-2 hours) and by\nboiling of water for domestic use until corrective measures have\ntaken effect. An interesting discourse on lemmings is in\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemming>;\na picture can be found at the original URL:\nA map of Norway can be found at:\n<http://2004.guadec.org/images/norway.png>. In the present outbreak\nin northern Norway, the clinical picture of oropharyngeal tularemia\npoints to ingestion of contaminated water, or possibly snow, as the\nmost likely route of transmission. The\nrisk of acquiring oropharyngeal tularaemia is particularly high in\nyears with a surge in rodent populations and the months thereafter,\nwhen infected carcasses represent possible sources of infection. Large\nnumbers of dead rodents (lemmings, _Lemmus lemmus_) are currently\nreported in the affected area after a large surge in the lemming\npopulation last autumn [2006]. \nClinical and epidemiological information was obtained from clinical\nnotification forms and supplemented by information from municipal\nmedical officers in the affected areas. People with\nprivate wells have been asked to inspect these for rodent carcasses\nand potential rodent entrances and to take corrective measures as\nrequired. This is in contrast to the situation in\nSweden and Finland, where the annual incidence generally is more than\n10 times higher than in Norway, and where insect bites are considered\nan important mode of transmission (3). Norway\nhas experienced several outbreaks of water-borne tularemia, the\nlargest in 2002 in the municipality of Midtre Gauldal in central\n [Byline: Brantsaeter AB <abbr@fhi.no>1, Krogh T, Radtke A, Nygard K]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Three of the cases\nlive in areas with a municipal water supply, which, after technical\ninspection, was found to be an unlikely source of contaminated water. At the\ntime of notification, 2 patients had recovered, 2 were still ill, and\ninformation was missing for the remaining 5; 4 of the cases were hospitalized. 2006 was a so called 'lemming year' in the affected area,\nand infected carcasses represent a potential source of infection for\nhumans who come into direct or indirect contact with these. Source: Eurosurveillance [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2007/070329.asp#2>\n\nSince November 2006, 9 cases of tularemia from 3 adjacent\nmunicipalities in northern Norway have been laboratory-confirmed. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was performed on filter\npaper samples after filtration of water and was positive for _F.\ntularensis_ in samples from one of 4 tested wells. Since 1978, the annual number of reported cases in Norway\nhas varied between none and 47, oropharyngeal tularemia being the\nmost common manifestation (2). According to notification forms from clinicians, 8 cases had cervical\nlymphadenopathy, with additional mention of oral or pharyngeal\ninfection in 5. Also, the eating of snow and\ndrinking of water that has not been disinfected, for example from\nlakes and rivers, is common practice during outdoor activities. The public has been asked to refrain from drinking\nwater that has not been disinfected or boiled while involved in\noutdoor activities such as hiking and camping. Results from the\nanalysis of water samples were obtained by direct contact with the\nlaboratory. Transmission by insects or by\nskin contact with rodents generally leads to ulceroglandular\ntularemia. Tularaemia has traditionally been called both 'lemming fever' and\n'hare plague,' clearly indicating rodents and hares as transmitters\nof disease. However, transmission via contaminated food\nor direct or indirect contact with rodents or with cats and dogs can\nnot be excluded.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2047-03-25 00:00:00", "1978-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-11-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prague", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8911", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Armenia (Gegarkuniq) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8911", "date": "2007-03-16 12:00:03", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - ARMENIA (GEGARKUNIQ) (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 15 Mar 2007\nFrom: Brigitte Dunais <dunais.b@chu-nice.fr>\nRegarding the report, it is mentioned that vaccination of the\npopulation is being conducted, but to my knowledge no such vaccine\nexists, or am I mistaken?\n--\nBrigitte Dunais MD\nDepartement de sante publique\nHopital de l'Archet 1\nCHU de Nice\nNice, France\n<dunais.b@chu-nice.fr>\n[The vaccine mentioned may be the LVS strain discussed below.\nThe following discussion is taken from 'Developing New Tularemia\nVaccines', written by Mary Beth Nierengarten and myself, Larry I.\nLutwick, in Medscape Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/431539>. (Unfortunately, the\nreferences are not given in this URL).\nAt present, a 'live vaccine strain' (LVS) tularemia vaccine is under\nInvestigational New Drug (IND) status in a protocol at the US Army\nMedical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases (USAMRIID), Fort\nDetrick, Maryland, and is available only for at-risk U.S. military\npersonnel. It is administered by scarification (that is, use of a\nbifurcated needle to produce multiple inoculations in the skin,\nsimilar to vaccinia inoculation for smallpox).\nThe availability of this vaccine in the USA for use beyond selected\nat-risk groups has been hampered by several obstacles. According to\nColonel David L. Danley, Project Manager, Joint Vaccine Acquisition\nProgram (JVAP) at Fort Detrick, data now required for licensure were\nnot adequately documented during its development, prohibiting plans\nto license the current vaccine. Because the 'old method of growth\nusing shaker culture does not meet current good manufacturing\nprocesses required for FDA licensure,' the manufacturing processes\nand potency of the current LVS vaccine are being re-evaluated, and 'a\nnew process using fermentation technology will be used,' explained\nDavid T. Dennis, MD, MPH, Chief, Bacterial Zoonoses Branch, Centers\nfor Disease Control (CDC).\nDespite the increased risk of a bioweapons threat felt after\n'September 11th', further vaccine development for tularemia remains\nslow. The projected date of a new licensed vaccine in the USA is not\nuntil 2009.\nThe current LVS vaccine is based on research that goes back to the\n1960s. It is a descendant of strain 15 developed by the former Soviet\nUnion's Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology, Gamalcia\nInstitute, in Moscow, and sold to the US military in 1956 (10). In\nthe early 1960s, USAMRIID had isolated the LVS strain for preventive\nuse in at-risk US military personnel (11,12). Efficacy studies in\ncivilian laboratory employees at Fort Detrick revealed that the\nvaccine was safe and significantly reduced the incidence of typhoidal\ntularemia from 5.70 to 0.27 cases per 1000 at-risk employee-years\n(13). Although the incidence of ulceroglandular tularemia was\nunchanged by the vaccines, the disease was found to be milder in the\nvaccine cohort. Worldwide, LVS has since been used as seed stock for\ntularemia vaccines (12).\nSeveral limitations of the current LVS tularemia vaccine indicate a\nneed to move forward on developing an improved vaccine. One\nlimitation is the current mode of administration, which requires\nscarification that is both cumbersome and difficult to standardize.\nFurther limitations deal with gaps in understanding the factors\nresponsible for the virulence and genetic stability of _Francisella\ntularensis_, as well as which antigens are needed to produce an\neffective cell-mediated immunity. Current research shows that only\none of the 2 phenotypes of LVS, the blue colony type, appears to be\nimmunogenic (11,12).\nA 2nd limitation is confusion over which arm of the immune system\nshould be targeted. Although it has been thought that the humoral\nimmune response is not important in protection against tularemia, a\nrelatively recent report from the Fort Detrick group has suggested\nthat this may not be the case (14). Pooled sera from humans immunized\nwith LVS were found to fully protect mice against a large lethal\nchallenge of LVS organisms. New lots of LVS produced in the USA\nclearly show immunogenicity in human volunteers, producing both brisk\ncell-mediated and humoral immune responses (15). In the future,\ntechniques to optimize the appropriate humoral response may be available.\nNew generation tularemia vaccines\n---------------------------------\nStrategies for development of a new generation of vaccines include\nidentification of individual components of _F. tularensis_, such as\nthe lipopolysaccharide (LPS) or various other outer surface proteins,\nas potential vaccine components (either native or recombinant). After\nidentification, these components would then be used as immunogens,\ninstead of using the entire organism. In laboratory studies, some of\nthese cell components have been tested and found to have variable\nprotection in mice.\nFor instance, one of the membrane proteins of the _F. tularensis_\nthat has been studied as a potential immunogen is a 17-kilodalton\nlipoprotein, TUL4. The gene for this antigen has been cloned into a\n_Salmonella typhimurium_ mutant (16). In mice immunized with this\nrecombinant vector, both humoral and cell-mediated immune response to\nthe antigen developed, and mice were protected from an LVS challenge.\nThe development of monoclonal antibodies for use as passively\nprotective agents is another possible strategy for new vaccine\ndevelopment, according to Dr. Dennis of the CDC.\nA number of investigators are conducting basic research into\ntularemia, particularly molecular and sequencing studies aimed at\nidentifying proteins and antigens for use as vaccine candidates. Most\nof this research is being conducted at military research\ninstitutions, including USAMRIID.\nAs one would expect, since 'September 11th', information on\nmanufacturers actively working on a new vaccine is scarce. In the\nUSA, DynPort Vaccine Company LLC was awarded a contract to develop,\nmanufacture, test, and license an LVS vaccine from the current\nvaccine material, according to both Dr. Dennis and Col. Danley at\nFort Detrick. DynPort has been under contract to the USA Department\nof Defense's (DoD's) JVAP since 1997 and acts as its executive arm,\nsays Terry Irgens, President of DynPort. Basic researchers from\ninstitutes such as USAMRIID work closely with DynPort, which employs\nover 100 scientists, physicians, and veterinarians to conduct\npreclinical and clinical testing of vaccines. Production and\nlicensure are also managed by DynPort, whose contract with JVAP was\nrecently extended to 2012. A proposed licensure date is June 2009, as\npreviously mentioned (17).\nInternationally, several efforts are under way to develop new\ntularemia vaccines, but with similar limited information on\nmanufacture and licensure dates. In the UK, 2 approaches to a new\nvaccine, use of defined attenuated mutants and a subunit vaccine, are\nin their earliest stages and are not anticipated for licensure in the\nUK for more than a decade, says Col. Danley.\nOther development efforts are being conducted in Sweden at the\nNational Defense Research Establishment, University of Umea, which\nrecently received a 5-year grant from the US National Institutes of\nHealth to develop a subunit vaccine against aerosolized forms of _F.\ntularensis_. In collaboration with Canadian researchers, under the\ndirection of Dr. Wayne Conlan, Medical Research Council, Ottawa,\nCanada, the grant will also compare the efficacy of these candidate\nvaccines to those of attenuated vaccines, said Dr. Anders Sjostedt,\nwho heads the research group at Umea University.\nIn Moscow, a project is under way at the Institute of Immunological\nEngineering to develop a chemical tularemia vaccine based on\npreparations of outer-membrane components of _F. tularensis_. This\ngroup is also working on a project to develop a molecular vaccine\nbased on LPS-protein complexes. (18) - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Because the 'old method of growth\nusing shaker culture does not meet current good manufacturing\nprocesses required for FDA licensure,' the manufacturing processes\nand potency of the current LVS vaccine are being re-evaluated, and 'a\nnew process using fermentation technology will be used,' explained\nDavid T. Dennis, MD, MPH, Chief, Bacterial Zoonoses Branch, Centers\nfor Disease Control (CDC). \nBrigitte Dunais MD\nDepartement de sante publique\nHopital de l'Archet 1\nCHU de Nice\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In the\nUSA, DynPort Vaccine Company LLC was awarded a contract to develop,\nmanufacture, test, and license an LVS vaccine from the current\nvaccine material, according to both Dr. Dennis and Col. Danley at\nFort Detrick. At present, a 'live vaccine strain' (LVS) tularemia vaccine is under\nInvestigational New Drug (IND) status in a protocol at the US Army\nMedical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases (USAMRIID), Fort\nDetrick, Maryland, and is available only for at-risk U.S. military\npersonnel. ---------------------------------\nStrategies for development of a new generation of vaccines include\nidentification of individual components of _F. tularensis_, such as\nthe lipopolysaccharide (LPS) or various other outer surface proteins,\nas potential vaccine components (either native or recombinant). Other development efforts are being conducted in Sweden at the\nNational Defense Research Establishment, University of Umea, which\nrecently received a 5-year grant from the US National Institutes of\nHealth to develop a subunit vaccine against aerosolized forms of _F.\ntularensis_. Efficacy studies in\ncivilian laboratory employees at Fort Detrick revealed that the\nvaccine was safe and significantly reduced the incidence of typhoidal\ntularemia from 5.70 to 0.27 cases per 1000 at-risk employee-years\n(13). In collaboration with Canadian researchers, under the\ndirection of Dr. Wayne Conlan, Medical Research Council, Ottawa,\nCanada, the grant will also compare the efficacy of these candidate\nvaccines to those of attenuated vaccines, said Dr. Anders Sjostedt,\nwho heads the research group at Umea University. In the UK, 2 approaches to a new\nvaccine, use of defined attenuated mutants and a subunit vaccine, are\nin their earliest stages and are not anticipated for licensure in the\nUK for more than a decade, says Col. Danley. Regarding the report, it is mentioned that vaccination of the\npopulation is being conducted, but to my knowledge no such vaccine\nexists, or am I mistaken?\n Although it has been thought that the humoral\nimmune response is not important in protection against tularemia, a\nrelatively recent report from the Fort Detrick group has suggested\nthat this may not be the case (14). In laboratory studies, some of\nthese cell components have been tested and found to have variable\nprotection in mice.\n Basic researchers from\ninstitutes such as USAMRIID work closely with DynPort, which employs\nover 100 scientists, physicians, and veterinarians to conduct\npreclinical and clinical testing of vaccines. One\nlimitation is the current mode of administration, which requires\nscarification that is both cumbersome and difficult to standardize.\n A number of investigators are conducting basic research into\ntularemia, particularly molecular and sequencing studies aimed at\nidentifying proteins and antigens for use as vaccine candidates. The development of monoclonal antibodies for use as passively\nprotective agents is another possible strategy for new vaccine\ndevelopment, according to Dr. Dennis of the CDC. Despite the increased risk of a bioweapons threat felt after\n'September 11th', further vaccine development for tularemia remains\nslow. Program (JVAP) at Fort Detrick, data now required for licensure were\nnot adequately documented during its development, prohibiting plans\nto license the current vaccine. Although the incidence of ulceroglandular tularemia was\nunchanged by the vaccines, the disease was found to be milder in the\nvaccine cohort. Internationally, several efforts are under way to develop new\ntularemia vaccines, but with similar limited information on\nmanufacture and licensure dates. This\ngroup is also working on a project to develop a molecular vaccine\nbased on LPS-protein complexes. In mice immunized with this\nrecombinant vector, both humoral and cell-mediated immune response to\nthe antigen developed, and mice were protected from an LVS challenge. New lots of LVS produced in the USA\nclearly show immunogenicity in human volunteers, producing both brisk\ncell-mediated and humoral immune responses (15). According to\nColonel David L. Danley, Project Manager, Joint Vaccine Acquisition\n In\nthe early 1960s, USAMRIID had isolated the LVS strain for preventive\nuse in at-risk US military personnel (11,12). Current research shows that only\none of the 2 phenotypes of LVS, the blue colony type, appears to be\nimmunogenic (11,12). It is administered by scarification (that is, use of a\nbifurcated needle to produce multiple inoculations in the skin,\nsimilar to vaccinia inoculation for smallpox). Most\nof this research is being conducted at military research\ninstitutions, including USAMRIID. Francisella\ntularensis_, as well as which antigens are needed to produce an\neffective cell-mediated immunity. For instance, one of the membrane proteins of the _F. tularensis_\nthat has been studied as a potential immunogen is a 17-kilodalton\nlipoprotein, TUL4. Pooled sera from humans immunized\nwith LVS were found to fully protect mice against a large lethal\nchallenge of LVS organisms. It is a descendant of strain 15 developed by the former Soviet\nUnion's Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology, Gamalcia\nInstitute, in Moscow, and sold to the US military in 1956 (10).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "smallpox", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-06-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ottawa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6934", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, potable water - Georgia (Kaspskiy)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6934", "date": "2007-01-24 00:00:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, POTABLE WATER - GEORGIA (KASPSKIY)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 20 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News agency Gazeta.ru [trans. Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.gazeta.ru/news/lenta/2007/01/20/n_1026391.shtml>\n\nAn outbreak of tularemia was reported from the village of Zemo Ren in\neastern Georgia. According to the Center of Public Health Services of\nthe Kaspskiy district, more than 30 persons of different ages have\nbecome ill with tularemia. The pathogenic agent of tularemia has been\nfound in potable water from the village.\nVakhtang Maisuradze, the Head of Administration of the Kaspskiy\ndistrict, has given assurances that the situation related to the\nfocus of infection is under control. It is strictly forbidden for the\nlocal population to drink water from this source, Maisuradze said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED would be interested in additional information regarding these\ncases, especially regarding how the diagnosis was made and the form\nor forms of tularemia that the individuals acquired (i.e.,\nulceroglandular, oculoglandular, typhoidal, or pneumonic). Although\nclassically transmitted to humans via infected animals, such as\nrabbits or a tick vector, infection with _Francisella tularensis_ may\nbe acquired from contact with soil or water harboring the bacterium.\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia, associated with a flood-plain swamp (1),\n49 cases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system\n(2), and an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia, also\nattributed to contamination of a water supply (3).\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: [Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol\n2001;6 (Suppl): 68-72.\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol 1987;3: 35-38.\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: [An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol] 1997;2: 33-37.\nA map of Georgia can be found at:\n<http://www.lonelyplanet.com/mapshells/europe/georgia/georgia.htm>.\nThe Kaspskiy district is in the eastern part of the country. Linking\nto maps in this update does not imply any political statement about\nboundaries by ProMED-mail. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia, associated with a flood-plain swamp (1),\n49 cases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system\n(2), and an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia, also\nattributed to contamination of a water supply (3). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although\nclassically transmitted to humans via infected animals, such as\nrabbits or a tick vector, infection with _Francisella tularensis_ may\nbe acquired from contact with soil or water harboring the bacterium.\n [ProMED would be interested in additional information regarding these\ncases, especially regarding how the diagnosis was made and the form\nor forms of tularemia that the individuals acquired (i.e.,\nulceroglandular, oculoglandular, typhoidal, or pneumonic). \nVakhtang Maisuradze, the Head of Administration of the Kaspskiy\ndistrict, has given assurances that the situation related to the\nfocus of infection is under control. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: [An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. TULAREMIA, POTABLE WATER - GEORGIA (KASPSKIY)\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4185", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, humans, rabbits - USA (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4185", "date": "2006-11-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMANS, RABBITS - USA (WYOMING)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 31 Oct 2006\nFrom: Brent Barrett <salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\nSource: Jackson Hole Star-Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.jacksonholestartrib.com/articles/2006/10/31/features/health/6ae94a8b7ba356558725721700567360.txt>\n\nSeveral outbreaks of tularemia around Wyoming have state health\nofficials cautioning hunters and recreationists to take basic precautions.\nTularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, typically\ninfects rabbits, hares and rodents. People and domestic animals can\nbecome infected through contact with the bacteria or through bites\nfrom deer flies.\nIn 2006, the Wyoming Game and Fish Department has documented rabbit\ndie-offs by Newcastle and near Pumpkin Buttes in northeast Wyoming,\naccording to wildlife disease specialist Hank Edwards. Additional\ndead rabbits are being spotted across Thunder Basin National\nGrassland and into other regions of Converse County.\n'It's bad, but it's par for the course anytime you get a rabbit\npopulation that high,' said Game and Fish Warden Rod Lebert,\nstationed in Douglas. More rabbits raise the likelihood of larger\ndie-offs because the animals are more concentrated.\nSo far, 2 people in Wyoming contracted tularemia in 2006, said Jamie\nSnow, a public health veterinarian for the Wyoming Department of\nHealth. The 1st, a woman in Baggs, was bitten in the hand by a cat.\nThe feline had likely been chewing on an infected rabbit and carried\nthe disease on, Snow said. The woman had a 'pretty severe' infection\nin her hand, centered at the wound site, and has suffered some\nlasting complications. The 2nd victim was a Big Horn County teenager\nwho came down with a high fever, body ache and chills after skinning\nan infected rabbit. His illness was treated effectively with\nantibiotics, Snow said.\nAlso in 2006, so far, 3 cats, one foal and a cottontail rabbit tested\npositive for tularemia at the state veterinary lab.\nSnow urged people to stay away from all sick-looking wildlife, and to\ntake cats and dogs to a veterinarian immediately if they notice signs\nof sickness. She also promoted the normal precautions against\ndisease: Wear gloves when handling dead animals and wash hands well\nwith soap and water after contact.\nThe rabbit die-offs are likely to occur every year in various places,\nEdwards said. 'We know tularemia has been in the state for many years\n... We see a pretty constant rate,' he explained. Edwards' office\nrandomly surveys carnivores for tularemia and sees the bacteria in\nabout 20 to 30 percent of samples each year, although most carnivores\ndon't die from tularemia.\n'They act as sentinels so we can see what the level of a particular\ndisease is in the field,' Edwards said. 'We see the same basic level\nacross the state.'\n[Byline: Rena Delbridge]\n--\nBrent Barrett\nMicrobiologist\nIndianapolis, IN\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n[Animals are susceptible to tularemia, as this post clearly\nindicates. Animals may acquire the disease through the bite of a tick\nor other insect, or through consumption of an infected animal.\nIncubation in most animals is approximately 10 days. Tularemia can\naffect more than 250 kinds of domestic and wild mammals as well as\nbirds, reptiles, and fish, and of course humans. Animals can die from\nthe disease without treatment. Clinical signs include lethargy,\nfever, anorexia and, generally, a cough. Once clinical signs are\napparent, death may be as quick as several hours to several days.\nAntibiotics may successfully be used to treat the disease. - Mod.TG]\n[Many cases of tularemia involve lymph node infection with\n(ulceroglandular) or without (glandular) a local skin infection\ndraining to the lymph node. In the winter, infection tends to be\nassociated with rabbit hunting and in the summer, with tick or deer fly bites.\nSummer cases can be associated with lawn mowers, as has been\ndescribed on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts, are often pneumonic,\nand are related to inhalation of bacilli. Unlike human plague\ninfection, pneumonic tularemia does not spread from person to person.\nBloodstream infection (bacteremia) can be associated with different\nforms of disease or may be the only manifestation (typhoidal form).\nA map of Wyoming in the northwestern part of the USA\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/index.html> can be found at:\n<http://wdh.state.wy.us/SAD/Images/Wyoming_Map_Gold.jpg>. Baggs,\nWyoming is in Carbon county in the south-central part of the state.\nBig Horn county is in the north-central part of the state.\nProMED thanks Brent Barrett for this submission. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Brent Barrett\nMicrobiologist\nIndianapolis, IN\n<salbrent@sbcglobal.net>\n Edwards' office\nrandomly surveys carnivores for tularemia and sees the bacteria in\nabout 20 to 30 percent of samples each year, although most carnivores\ndon't die from tularemia. \nTularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, typically\ninfects rabbits, hares and rodents.
