USA (MO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3761", "date": "2006-10-20 00:00:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (MISSOURI)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 19 Oct 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/metroeast/story/F342205D0A956A718625720C000F9DF1?OpenDocument>\n\nA routine test of air quality near Busch Stadium on Mon, 16 Oct 2006,\nturned up traces of a rare and potentially fatal bacterium that federal\nofficials have warned could be used by terrorists as a biological weapon.\nHowever, follow-up tests on Tue, 17 Oct 2006, found no evidence of the\nbacterium [_Francisella tularensis_, which causes a disease called\ntularemia or rabbit fever].\nThe bacteria are found naturally in Missouri, and 27 people are believed to\nhave contracted it in the state in 2005, said Dr. William Kincaid, the St.\nLouis health director, in a prepared statement. He said the city's sensor\nhad picked up naturally occurring tularemia. The bacteria can cause lethal\npneumonia or meningitis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This 'blip'(?) from (presumably) a BioWatch air sensor in Saint Louis\nparallels similar past events in Washington DC, Houston TX and Salt Lake\nCity UT. Of note, several days of positive readings were detected in DC in\n2005. The tularemia bacillus, a bioterrorism Category A agent endemic in\nMissouri, is present in the environment, through carcasses decaying in the\nsoil, airborne dissemination of contaminated dust/dirt, and possible\nshort-term presence in local water pools; one of these environmental\nsources may have served as the origin of the blip. No cases of human\ndisease have been reported with any of the past episodes. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The tularemia bacillus, a bioterrorism Category A agent endemic in\nMissouri, is present in the environment, through carcasses decaying in the\nsoil, airborne dissemination of contaminated dust/dirt, and possible\nshort-term presence in local water pools; one of these environmental\nsources may have served as the origin of the blip. Source: St Louis Today [edited]\n<http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/metroeast/story/F342205D0A956A718625720C000F9DF1?OpenDocument>\n\nA routine test of air quality near Busch Stadium on Mon, 16 Oct 2006,\nturned up traces of a rare and potentially fatal bacterium that federal\nofficials have warned could be used by terrorists as a biological weapon. However, follow-up tests on Tue, 17 Oct 2006, found no evidence of the\nbacterium [_Francisella tularensis_, which causes a disease called\ntularemia or rabbit fever]. The bacteria are found naturally in Missouri, and 27 people are believed to\nhave contracted it in the state in 2005, said Dr. William Kincaid, the St.\nLouis health director, in a prepared statement.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MISSOURI", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saint Louis", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2071", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, pneumonic - USA (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2071", "date": "2006-07-31 00:00:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA (MASSACHUSETTS)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 29 Jul 2006\nFrom: Mark Liao <markliaohk@gmail.com>\nSource: Yahoo.com [edited]\n<http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060730/ap_on_he_me/rabbit_fever>\n\nState public health officials are warning people on Martha's Vineyard about\nthe dangers of a potentially fatal disease known as 'rabbit fever,' after 6\nnew cases were identified.\nCases of the disease tularemia, or rabbit fever, have occurred on Martha's\nVineyard every year since an initial outbreak in 2000 sickened 15 people\nand resulted in a fatality, according to the Department of Public Health\n(DPH). More than 2 dozen confirmed cases have been reported on the island\nin the last 5 years.\nTularemia is caused by a bacterium found in animals, especially rabbits. It\ncan be contracted through the bite of an infected dog tick, when an open\nsore or cut comes into contact with the bacteria or by inhaling the spores.\nSymptoms include a lesion on the skin, swollen lymph nodes and flu-like\nproblems. Tularemia is not spread from person to person. A few people have\ngotten sick after bites from their infected pet cats.\nThose affected on Martha's Vineyard range in age from 33 to 67 and became\nill between 13 May and 5 Jul 2006, the DPH said. All 6, 4 of whom are\nemployed as landscapers, have been treated and are recovering, officials\nsaid. All of the cases reported in 2006 had the respiratory form of the\ndisease -- pneumonic tularemia -- according to the DPH's announcement late\nthis week. 'While landscapers should definitely take precautions, anyone\nworking outside near lawn mowing or brush cutting activities should also be\ncareful,' Dr Bela Matyas, DPH medical director for epidemiology, said in a\nstatement.\n--\nMark Liao\nProgram in Human Biology\nStanford University, Stanford, CA\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Mark Liao for contributing this report. Human infection\nwith _Francisella tularensis_, a Category A bioterrorism agent, continues\nto be a problem on Martha's Vineyard, a 100 square mile island off the\nsouthern coast of Cape Cod, MA. A substantial number of the cases are\npneumonic, occurring in landscapers and gardeners, related to the\naerosolization of infective bacteria.\nTelford and colleagues (1) have investigated the genetic diversity of _F.\ntularensis_ obtained from Martha's Vineyard ticks. Between 2001 and 2003,\n0.7 per cent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) harbored the\ntularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of genotypic diversity\nsuggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of the infection on the\nisland. The authors review information regarding the island's tularemia,\nwhich appears to have been a relatively recent introduction into\nMassachusetts. They state that prior to 1937, only one case of the\ninfection was recognized, related to contaminated rabbit meat from the\nmid-western USA. In 1937, however, more than 20 000 cottontail rabbits from\nthe mid-western states of Missouri and Kansas were introduced into the\nmainland state and Martha's Vineyard for sporting purposes (2). Cases began\nto occur starting several years later.\n1. Goethert HK, Shani I, Telford SR. Genotypic diversity of _Francisella\ntularensis_ infected _Dermacentor variabilis_ ticks on Martha's Vineyard,\nMassachusetts. J Clin Microbiol 2004; 42: 4968-73.\n2. Belding DL, Merrill M. Tularemia in imported rabbits in Massachusetts. N\nEngl J Med 1941; 1085-87. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Yahoo.com [edited]\n<http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20060730/ap_on_he_me/rabbit_fever>\n\nState public health officials are warning people on Martha's Vineyard about\nthe dangers of a potentially fatal disease known as 'rabbit fever,' after 6\nnew cases were identified. Cases of the disease tularemia, or rabbit fever, have occurred on Martha's\nVineyard every year since an initial outbreak in 2000 sickened 15 people\nand resulted in a fatality, according to the Department of Public Health\n(DPH). Between 2001 and 2003,\n0.7 per cent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) harbored the\ntularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of genotypic diversity\n While landscapers should definitely take precautions, anyone\nworking outside near lawn mowing or brush cutting activities should also be\ncareful,' Dr Bela Matyas, DPH medical director for epidemiology, said in a\nstatement. Human infection\nwith _Francisella tularensis_, a Category A bioterrorism agent, continues\nto be a problem on Martha's Vineyard, a 100 square mile island off the\nsouthern coast of Cape Cod, MA. All of the cases reported in 2006 had the respiratory form of the\ndisease -- pneumonic tularemia -- according to the DPH's announcement late\nthis week. ' In 1937, however, more than 20 000 cottontail rabbits from\nthe mid-western states of Missouri and Kansas were introduced into the\nmainland state and Martha's Vineyard for sporting purposes (2). They state that prior to 1937, only one case of the\ninfection was recognized, related to contaminated rabbit meat from the\nmid-western USA. A substantial number of the cases are\npneumonic, occurring in landscapers and gardeners, related to the\naerosolization of infective bacteria. It\ncan be contracted through the bite of an infected dog tick, when an open\nsore or cut comes into contact with the bacteria or by inhaling the spores. Genotypic diversity of _Francisella\ntularensis_ infected _Dermacentor variabilis_ ticks on Martha's Vineyard,\nMassachusetts. The authors review information regarding the island's tularemia,\nwhich appears to have been a relatively recent introduction into\nMassachusetts.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1941-03-25 00:00:00", "1937-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cape Cod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209342", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - USA (TX)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209342", "date": "2006-02-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (TEXAS) (03)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 23 Feb 2006\nFrom: Barry Lifland <blifland@stanford.edu>\n\nRegarding the recent postings regarding tularemia in Texas, which\nstrain of _Francisella tularensis_ is the etiologic agent in the\ncurrent Texas 'widespread epizootic'; _F. tularensis_ spp.\n_tularensis_ (Type A) or _F. tularensis_ ssp. _holartica_ (Type B)?\nThere are significant strain-dependent differences between them in\nhuman disease presentation/syndromes, intervention levels, treatment,\nand subsequent prognosis.\nReports that do not indicate subspecies may cause confusion, leaving\nthe impression that reports of _F. tularensis_ is always the more\nvirulent Type A strain. It might be prudent to consider any report\nincomplete or curious if using only _F. tularensis_ without\nspecifying subspecies or type.\n--\nBarry Lifland\nStanford Univ. School of Medicine\nDept. of Comparative Medicine\nStanford, CA\n<blifland@stanford.edu>\n[Dr. Lifland is correct regarding differences in virulence between the\nsubspecies of _F. tularensis_. Unfortunately, most reports do not\ncharacterize the specific subspecies. As mentioned below, both\nsubspecies are found in the USA, whereas holarctica is the one\nprimarily found in Eurasia.\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/idsa/bt/tularemia/biofacts/tularemiafactsheet.html>\nThere are several subspecies of _F. tularensis_ with somewhat\nconfusing nomenclature. These subspecies can be differentiated by\nbiochemical tests, and the current taxonomy is as follows:\nSubspecies tularensis (type A; also referred to as subspecies\nnearctica by investigators in the former Soviet Union): demonstrates\ncitrulline ureidase activity; highly infectious and virulent; found\nprimarily in North America; 2 distinct genetic clades have been\nidentified.\nSubspecies holarctica (type B; formerly referred to as palaearctica\nor palearctica in some sources): less virulent; does not demonstrate\ncitrulline ureidase activity; three biovars have been identified:\n-Biovar I: erythromycin sensitive; primarily found in North America,\nEurope, Siberia, the Far East, and Kazakhstan\n-Biovar II: erythromycin resistant; primarily found in Eurasia\n-Biovar japonica: found in Japan\nSubspecies mediasiatica: found in the Central Asian republics of the\nformer Soviet Union (virulence is similar to _F. tularensis_,\nsubspecies holarctica).\nSubspecies novicida: considered to be of low virulence and generally\ncauses illness only in immunocompromised hosts] (_F. tularensis_ and\n_F. novicida_ traditionally have been considered separate species;\nhowever, the current approach is to consider _F. novicida_ as a\nsubspecies of _F. tularensis_.) - Mod.LL]", "summary": "These subspecies can be differentiated by\nbiochemical tests, and the current taxonomy is as follows:\nSubspecies tularensis (type A; also referred to as subspecies\nnearctica by investigators in the former Soviet Union): demonstrates\ncitrulline ureidase activity; highly infectious and virulent; found\nprimarily in North America; 2 distinct genetic clades have been\nidentified. Subspecies novicida: considered to be of low virulence and generally\ncauses illness only in immunocompromised hosts] (_F. tularensis_ and\n_F. novicida_ traditionally have been considered separate species;\nhowever, the current approach is to consider _F. novicida_ as a\nsubspecies of _F. tularensis_.) A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nEurope, Siberia, the Far East, and Kazakhstan\n-Biovar II: erythromycin resistant; primarily found in Eurasia\n-Biovar japonica: found in Japan\n School of Medicine\nDept. of Comparative Medicine\nStanford, CA\n<blifland@stanford.edu>\n Subspecies holarctica (type B; formerly referred to as palaearctica\nor palearctica in some sources): less virulent; does not demonstrate\ncitrulline ureidase activity; three biovars have been identified:\n-Biovar I: erythromycin sensitive; primarily found in North America, It might be prudent to consider any report\nincomplete or curious if using only _F. tularensis_ without\nspecifying subspecies or type.\n Subspecies mediasiatica: found in the Central Asian republics of the\nformer Soviet Union (virulence is similar to _F. tularensis_,\nsubspecies holarctica). From: Barry Lifland <blifland@stanford.edu>\n\nRegarding the recent postings regarding tularemia in Texas, which\nstrain of _Francisella tularensis_ is the etiologic agent in the\ncurrent Texas 'widespread epizootic'; _F. tularensis_ spp.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-02-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1611", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, rabbits - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1611", "date": "2006-06-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, RABBITS - USA (TEXAS)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Jun 2006\nFrom: James Alexander <James.Alexander@dshs.state.tx.us>\nSource: Official release from the TX Department of State Health Services\n\nOn 17 May 2006, a dead black-tailed jack rabbit (_Lepus\ncalifornicus_), was collected from a site east of the Rick Husband\nInternational Airport in Amarillo, Texas. The animal was one of over\n20 that had died recently along an approximately 0.6-mile portion of\nnon-public road, as noted by the USDA/APHIS-Wildlife Service District\nSupervisor based in Canyon, TX.\nThe hare was submitted to the CDC Bacterial Zooonses Branch by the\nTexas Department of State Health Services Zoonosis Control\nVeterinarian.\nOn 18 May, a positive FA [fluorescent antibody test] for tularemia\nwas reported by the CDC. Since then, ticks from a coyote found\napproximately 1 mile NW of the die-off have also been reported as\npositive for tularemia.\nThe airport's terminal and parking garage were areas of concern due\nto an extremely high lagomorph population interfacing with a high\namount of human activity.\nThe City of Amarillo, Bi-City-County Health District's Environmental\nHealth and Department of Public Health, in concert with Amarillo\nAnimal Control, the Department of State Health Services Zoonosis\nControl Group and USDA/Aphis-Wildlife Services initiated a\nthree-pronged approach to reduce public health risk.\nA health alert regarding tularemia was issued to all area medical\nfacilities; a press conference was held advising the public of the\npresence of the disease and precautions to take to prevent human\ninfection; and a population-reduction program was begun on the\nterminal grounds with insecticides applied in that area as well as in\nthe die-off zone.\nA week after the program was launched, the lagomorph population has\nbeen significantly reduced based on observation and no human cases of\nTularemia have been reported. At this time, the affected area has\nexpanded slightly to the east into the secure runway areas, based on\nreports of dead jackrabbits by Wildlife Services personnel.\nMonitoring of the area and sample collection continues. An alert was\nalso issued region-wide and information on rabbit/hare or rodent\ndie-offs is being solicited.\n--\nJames L. Alexander, DVM, MPVM., Dipl. ACVPM\nRegional Zoonosis Control Veterinarian\nTexas Department of State Health Services\nHealth Service Region 1\nWTAMU Box 60968\nCanyon, TX 79016-0968\n<james.alexander@dshs.state.tx.us>\n<http://www.dshs.state.tx.us/zoonosis>\n[_Francisella tularensis_, a gram-negative pleomorphic bacterium, is\nthe causative agent of tularemia. This infectious disease was first\ndescribed in Japan in 1837. The name of the disease is related to\n1911 description of a plague-like illness in ground squirrels in\nTulare County, California, and work done by Dr. Edward Francis. Dr.\nFrancis described his personal experience with more than 800 cases in\n1928. The causative agent is found in more than 100 species of wild\nanimals, including birds and insects, worldwide. The most virulent of\nthe 4 known strains is found in primarily in North America. The\nstrains appear to vary in both virulence and geographical range.\nThe route of transmission and factors relating to the host and the\norganism influence the presentation. The organism produces an acute\nfebrile illness in humans. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A health alert regarding tularemia was issued to all area medical\nfacilities; a press conference was held advising the public of the\npresence of the disease and precautions to take to prevent human\ninfection; and a population-reduction program was begun on the\nterminal grounds with insecticides applied in that area as well as in\nthe die-off zone. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The City of Amarillo, Bi-City-County Health District's Environmental\nHealth and Department of Public Health, in concert with Amarillo\nAnimal Control, the Department of State Health Services Zoonosis\nControl Group and USDA/Aphis-Wildlife Services initiated a\nthree-pronged approach to reduce public health risk. The animal was one of over\n20 that had died recently along an approximately 0.6-mile portion of\nnon-public road, as noted by the USDA/APHIS-Wildlife Service District\nSupervisor based in Canyon, TX. Texas Department of State Health Services\nHealth Service Region 1\nWTAMU Box 60968\n Canyon, TX 79016-0968\n<james.alexander@dshs.state.tx.us>\n<http://www.dshs.state.tx.us/zoonosis>\n A week after the program was launched, the lagomorph population has\nbeen significantly reduced based on observation and no human cases of\nTularemia have been reported. Since then, ticks from a coyote found\napproximately 1 mile NW of the die-off have also been reported as\npositive for tularemia. The airport's terminal and parking garage were areas of concern due\nto an extremely high lagomorph population interfacing with a high\namount of human activity. At this time, the affected area has\nexpanded slightly to the east into the secure runway areas, based on\nreports of dead jackrabbits by Wildlife Services personnel. Source: Official release from the TX Department of State Health Services\n\nOn 17 May 2006, a dead black-tailed jack rabbit (_Lepus\ncalifornicus_), was collected from a site east of the Rick Husband\n An alert was\nalso issued region-wide and information on rabbit/hare or rodent\ndie-offs is being solicited. The name of the disease is related to\n1911 description of a plague-like illness in ground squirrels in\nTulare County, California, and work done by Dr. Edward Francis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-05-17 00:00:00", "2021-05-18 00:00:00", "1911-03-25 00:00:00", "1928-03-25 00:00:00", "1837-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amarillo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulare County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Bi - City - County Health District 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Amarillo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209327", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, rodents, humans - USA (TX)(02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209327", "date": "2006-02-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (TEXAS) (02): BACKGROUND\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 20 Feb 2006\nFrom: Thomas Yuill <tmyuill@wisc.edu>\n\nSeveral years ago, there was a case of human tularemia in Wisconsin\nin the summer. The state epidemiologist's office determined that a\ncat had brought a tularemia-infected cottontail rabbit (_Sylvilagus\nfloridanus_) into the patient's home. With the widespread tularemia\nepizootic going on in Texas, it would seem that the risk of a similar\nsituation, with pets bringing in dead or moribund rodents, is real,\ngiving new meaning to the phrase 'look what the cat dragged in!'\n--\nThomas Yuill\n<tmyuill@wisc.edu>\nUniversity of Wisconsin, USA\n[Surely the Texas epidemiologist is aware of such risk and is looking\ninto all aspects of the case. However, this clearly illustrates the\nneed to be cautious around our pets that hunt. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n With the widespread tularemia\nepizootic going on in Texas, it would seem that the risk of a similar\nsituation, with pets bringing in dead or moribund rodents, is real,\ngiving new meaning to the phrase 'look what the cat dragged in!' --\nThomas Yuill\n<tmyuill@wisc.edu>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wisconsin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209294", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209294", "date": "2006-02-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org> <\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Disease\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 16 Feb 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Texas Dept of State Health Services, Zoonosis Control Branch [edited]\n<http://www.dshs.state.tx.us>\n\nThis advisory is prompted by a large die-off of rodents and rabbits\nin Presidio County, Texas due to tularemia. Tissue samples from the\nanimals were collected and submitted to the CDC laboratory in Ft.\nCollins, Colorado. The samples were positive for _Francisella\ntularensis_, the bacterium that causes tularemia.\nDisease Agent: _Francisella tularensis_ is a highly infectious, small\ngram-negative coccobacillus. Humans and over 250 types of wild and\ndomestic mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians and fish are\nsusceptible to infection. A variety of ticks and small wild mammals,\nincluding various rodents, rabbits and hares, are the natural\nreservoirs of infection, although the organism may survive for weeks\nor longer at low temperatures in water, moist soil or vegetation such\nas hay, and animal carcasses. _Francisella tularensis_ may be\ndispersed via dry or wet aerosols.\nExposure: Animals and humans are most commonly infected through\nexposure to or ingestion of infected wild animals, their carcasses or\nbody fluids; exposure to or ingestion of contaminated water, soil, or\nvegetation; or bites by infected arthropods, especially ticks and\nbiting flies. Inhalation of aerosolized bacteria is another potential\nroute of infection.\nClinical signs - Dogs: Dogs are thought to be resistant to natural\ninfection. Clinical disease, when it occurs, typically consists of\nfever, anorexia, and listlessness. Additional symptoms may include\nskin or mouth lesions, draining abscesses, enlarged lymph nodes, and\nnasal and ocular discharge.\nClinical signs - Cats: Cats are thought to be more susceptible to\ntularemia than dogs, but still considered fairly resistant to natural\ninfection. Clinical disease, when it occurs, may consist of fever,\nanorexia, listlessness, skin or mouth lesions, draining abscesses, and\nenlarged lymph nodes.\nClinical Signs - Livestock: Livestock, particularly sheep, are\nvariably susceptible to tularemia infection. Large epidemics with\nhigh mortality have been seen in range sheep. Clinical signs are not\nspecific, and usually include fever, anorexia, and depression. Cough,\nrapid respiration, diarrhea, and stiffness and edema of the limbs may\nalso occur.\nPublic Health Considerations: Very few cases of human disease have\nbeen associated with transmission from pets. Transmission from pets\nto humans has been documented from bites and scratches in the case of\ncats and from mechanical transmission by dogs transporting the\norganism on their fur into the household from infected source\nmaterial. Pets may also transport infected ticks into the household.\nTransmission from livestock to humans may involve direct contact with\ninfected animals, animal tissues, or animal products, such as wool,\nand vector transmission via ticks and other biting arthropods found\non livestock.\nDiagnostic Testing: Gram stain of smears or biopsies is rarely\nuseful. Testing of clinical or postmortem specimens for _Francisella\ntularensis_ is available on a limited basis at the CDC Vector Ecology\nand Control Laboratory in Ft. Collins, Colorado. Testing typically\nconsists of blood culture, serology and/or microscopic examination\nand culture of tissue samples (particularly liver and spleen), lymph\nnode aspirates, and exudates. If you plan to pursue diagnosis on a\nlive animal, please collect a blood sample for culture prior to\ninitiating antibiotic therapy. Serology results may be inconclusive\nduring the first 2-4 weeks after infection due to the time it takes\nfor antibody titers to increase to diagnostic levels.\nTreatment: Treatment protocols for tularemia in animals are not well studied.\nHowever _Francisella tularensis_ is usually susceptible to a wide range of\nantibiotics, with the aminoglycosides streptomycin and gentamycin being first\nchoice drugs for human infections. Tetracycline, cephalosporins, and\nfluoroquinolones have also been found to be effective. Relapses may occur,\nusually due to incomplete course of treatment.\nInfection Control: Standard Precautions should be followed.\nEnvironmental surfaces should be decontaminated with soap and water\nand a hospital-grade disinfectant. Primary prevention is directed\ntoward reducing the threat of transmission to animals and humans from\nwildlife and the environment in high-risk areas, because eliminating\ntularemia from its wild animal reservoirs is not feasible.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Currently there is one person hospitalized with suspected tularemia.\nHowever strong the suspicions are, the physician and the Texas\nDepartment of State Health Services are awaiting confirmation before\nmaking a public announcement.\nI would like to acknowledge Dave Taylor, DVM, in Fort Davis, Texas\nfor alerting us to this outbreak.\nWhen I telephoned the Texas Department of State Health Services, the El Paso\nbranch was knowledgeable and prepared for discussions. When I asked about a\nlarge outbreak in rodents, I was told it was very large, and there was great\nconcern for animals and people. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A variety of ticks and small wild mammals,\nincluding various rodents, rabbits and hares, are the natural\nreservoirs of infection, although the organism may survive for weeks\nor longer at low temperatures in water, moist soil or vegetation such\nas hay, and animal carcasses. _Francisella tularensis_ may be\ndispersed via dry or wet aerosols. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org> <\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Disease\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Exposure: Animals and humans are most commonly infected through\nexposure to or ingestion of infected wild animals, their carcasses or\nbody fluids; exposure to or ingestion of contaminated water, soil, or\nvegetation; or bites by infected arthropods, especially ticks and\nbiting flies. Primary prevention is directed\ntoward reducing the threat of transmission to animals and humans from\nwildlife and the environment in high-risk areas, because eliminating\ntularemia from its wild animal reservoirs is not feasible.\n Transmission from pets\nto humans has been documented from bites and scratches in the case of\ncats and from mechanical transmission by dogs transporting the\norganism on their fur into the household from infected source\nmaterial. Transmission from livestock to humans may involve direct contact with\ninfected animals, animal tissues, or animal products, such as wool,\nand vector transmission via ticks and other biting arthropods found\non livestock. Testing typically\nconsists of blood culture, serology and/or microscopic examination\nand culture of tissue samples (particularly liver and spleen), lymph\nnode aspirates, and exudates. Clinical signs - Cats: Cats are thought to be more susceptible to\ntularemia than dogs, but still considered fairly resistant to natural\ninfection. Clinical disease, when it occurs, may consist of fever,\nanorexia, listlessness, skin or mouth lesions, draining abscesses, and\nenlarged lymph nodes. Humans and over 250 types of wild and\ndomestic mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians and fish are\nsusceptible to infection. However _Francisella tularensis_ is usually susceptible to a wide range of\nantibiotics, with the aminoglycosides streptomycin and gentamycin being first\nchoice drugs for human infections. Source: Texas Dept of State Health Services, Zoonosis Control Branch [edited]\n<http://www.dshs.state.tx.us>\n\nThis advisory is prompted by a large die-off of rodents and rabbits\nin Presidio County, Texas due to tularemia. Additional symptoms may include\nskin or mouth lesions, draining abscesses, enlarged lymph nodes, and\nnasal and ocular discharge. When I asked about a\nlarge outbreak in rodents, I was told it was very large, and there was great\nconcern for animals and people. Serology results may be inconclusive\nduring the first 2-4 weeks after infection due to the time it takes\nfor antibody titers to increase to diagnostic levels. If you plan to pursue diagnosis on a\nlive animal, please collect a blood sample for culture prior to\ninitiating antibiotic therapy. \nPublic Health Considerations: Very few cases of human disease have\nbeen associated with transmission from pets. Tissue samples from the\nanimals were collected and submitted to the CDC laboratory in Ft.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-02-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "El Paso", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Presidio County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Collins", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Davis", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209149", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, hare hunters, 2005 - Germany (Hessen)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209149", "date": "2006-01-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HARE HUNTERS, 2005 - GERMANY (HESSEN)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 16 Jan 2006\nFrom: Eberhard Gekeler <egekeler@t-online.de>\nSource: Epidemiologische Bulletin Robert-Koch Institut [edited]\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_225576/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/50__05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/50_05>\n\nAfter a hare hunt near Darmstadt (Germany) on 29 Oct 2005 in which 27\nhunters and beaters took part, 9 hunters and one beater fell ill with\ntularemia. On 28 Nov 2005, the authorities were informed of a case of\nbrucellosis. It concerned a man who fell ill with fever above 40 degrees C,\nswollen lymph nodes, fatigue, arthralgia, and headache. He had taken part\nin gutting the hares and cut his left thumb.\nHe was treated with antimicrobial agents. After cessation of therapy, his\nlymph nodes grew and he was admitted to a hospital (between 21-28 Nov\n2005). Under therapy with streptomycin and ciprofloxacin the symptoms\ndeclined. The serological diagnosis of tularemia was made on 1 Dec 2005.\nIn retrospect, the diagnosis of brucellosis was interpreted as a false\npositive result due to known cross-reactions between the brucellosis and\ntularemia bacilli.\nInvestigation by the health authorities uncovered 9 more participants who\nfell sick between 3 and 9 Nov 2005 predominantly with high fever,\nshivering, lymphadenitis, headache, and muscle aches. 2 of the hunters who\nhad acquired cuts while gutting the hares developed ulcers at the sites.\nThe age of those affected was between 11 and 73 years.\nIn 9 cases, the infection was serologically confirmed. In the one diseased\nhunter who had long-term heart failure as a comorbidity, bilateral\npneumonia had been diagnosed. No laboratory test for tularemia had been\ncarried out. The other 9 are well after treatment. 9 of 10 of the affected\nhad taken part in gutting the hares. All killed hares seemed to be healthy;\nno die-off or unusual behavior of hares in the region was observed. Frozen\nmeat from the hunt is [being tested]; a retrospective cohort study is not\nfinished yet.\n--\nEberhard G Gekeler, MD\nDarmstadt, Germany\n<egekeler@t-online.de>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Gekeler for a more up-to-date summary of this\nhunting-related cluster of _Francisella tularensis_ infection. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nEberhard G Gekeler, MD\nDarmstadt, Germany\n<egekeler@t-online.de>\n Source: Epidemiologische Bulletin Robert-Koch Institut [edited]\n<http://www.rki.de/cln_011/nn_225576/DE/Content/Infekt/EpidBull/Archiv/2005/50__05,templateId=raw,property=publicationFile.pdf/50_05>\n\nAfter a hare hunt near Darmstadt (Germany) on 29 Oct 2005 in which 27\nhunters and beaters took part, 9 hunters and one beater fell ill with\ntularemia. Investigation by the health authorities uncovered 9 more participants who\nfell sick between 3 and 9 Nov 2005 predominantly with high fever,\nshivering, lymphadenitis, headache, and muscle aches. In retrospect, the diagnosis of brucellosis was interpreted as a false\npositive result due to known cross-reactions between the brucellosis and\ntularemia bacilli. After cessation of therapy, his\nlymph nodes grew and he was admitted to a hospital (between 21-28 Nov\n2005). TULAREMIA, HARE HUNTERS, 2005 - GERMANY (HESSEN)\n************************************************\n In the one diseased\nhunter who had long-term heart failure as a comorbidity, bilateral\npneumonia had been diagnosed. Frozen\nmeat from the hunt is [being tested]; a retrospective cohort study is not\nfinished yet. It concerned a man who fell ill with fever above 40 degrees C,\nswollen lymph nodes, fatigue, arthralgia, and headache.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-12-01 00:00:00", "2006-01-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "2005 - GERMANY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Darmstadt", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2975", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden (Varmland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2975", "date": "2006-09-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN (VARMLAND)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 21 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly Release Vol 11 Issue 9 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2006/060921.asp#1>\n\nTularemia cases are being detected increasingly\nin southern parts of Sweden. In 1999, in the\ncounty of Varmland in central Sweden (bordering\nNorway), the 1st outbreak of more than 20 cases\nwas detected in the southern part of the county.\nSince then, there has been an annual average of\n22 cases notified over the previous 7 years (1999 - 2005) (1).\nThis year, 2006, a large outbreak has been\nrecorded, with 90 reported cases in Varmland so\nfar (16 laboratory confirmed cases, others\nreported as having typical clinical\npresentation). The majority of these cases have\nbeen reported from areas near Lake Vanern. It is\nexpected that more cases will be identified if\nthe warmer weather persists. So far in 2006, a\nmuch larger number of tularemia cases have been\nreported in Varmland than elsewhere in Sweden (2).\n19 of the patients live in Hammaro municipality,\nan area that was also considerably affected\nduring the outbreak in 1999. An investigation\ninto the 1999 outbreak detected an apparent\nassociation with Hammaro golf course and the\nimmediate area, and this association has also\nbeen made for several of the 2006 cases so far.\nThe places around the northern shores of Lake\nVanern which are affected by tularemia are also\nwhere a river delta, beaches and golf courses are\nlocated. This fact coincides with the hypothesis\nthat the bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is\ndisseminated via mosquitoes and water-living protozoa.\n_F. tularensis_ is a gram-negative bacterium. The\ndisease spreads from small rodent reservoirs to\nhares and then humans through direct contact,\ninsect bites, or inhalation/ingestion of feces or\nurine. After 3 to 7 days, patients often become\nill with a fever or swollen lymph glands and\noccasionally also characteristic skin lesions.\nSome patients develop general infection with\npneumonia or septicemia. The clinical\nmanifestations are related to the common routes\nof transmission, mostly with swollen lymph glands\nand fever when transmitted by insect bites.\nTularemia occurs throughout North America and in\nmany parts of Europe, the former Soviet Union, China and Japan (3).*\nFamily doctors (general practitioners) in\nVarmland have become proficient in identifying\nthe disease. The Varmland local health\nauthorities are considering actively promoting\nincreased use of insect repellent on golf courses in future seasons.\n*Erratum - the original text stated incorrectly\nthat tularemia was found further south around the\nequator. This was corrected on 22 Sep 2006 by the editorial team.\n1. Smittskyddinstitutet. Tularemi i Varmland. Epi-aktuellt 2006; 37.\n<http://www.smittskyddsinstitutet.se/SMItemplates/BigArticle____6330.aspx#Tularemi%20i%20V\ufffdland>\n2. Smittskyddinstitutet.\n<http://gis.smittskyddsinstitutet.se/mapapp/build/21-138000/table/Tularaemia_swe_year_all.html>\n3. Ekdahl K, Twisselmann B. Epidemics of\ntularaemia in Sweden and Finland.\nEurosurveillance Weekly. 2001 Jan 11;1(2) 010111.\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2001/010111.asp#2>\n[Reported by: Wik O <Olle.Wik@liv.se>), Varmland\nSmittskydd, Centralsjukhuset, Karlstad, Varmland, Sweden]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The form of tularemia that occurred in these\ncases(i.e., ulceroglandular, oculoglandular,\ntyphoidal, or pneumonic) is not stated. Although\nclassically transmitted to man via infected\nanimals such as rabbits or a tick vector,\ninfection with _Francisella tularensis_ may be\nacquired from contact with soil or water\nharboring the bacterium. Although tularemia\npneumonia is the form of the disease associated\nwith biological terrorism, it may also occur\nnaturally, as is exemplified by the sporadic case\ndescribed in New York City and outbreaks among\ngardeners on Martha's Vineyard, both cited in past ProMED postings below.\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia,\noutbreaks include 64 cases in Dagestan, Russia\nassociated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49 cases\nin Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated\nwater system (2), and an outbreak in the Smolensk\nprovince of Russia also attributed to contamination of a water supply (3).\nAt present, no licensed tularemia vaccine is\navailable in the USA. However, the LVS vaccine\n(live vaccine strain) is available to military\npersonnel under an investigational new drug\nprotocol held by the US Army Medical Research\nInstitute of Infectious Diseases (4). It is\nadministered via scarification using multiple\npunctures of a bifurcated needle. LVS is derived\nfrom strain 15 developed in the former USSR and\nwas obtained by the US military in 1956 (5). It\nis not well standardized and contains 2\nphenotypes of _F. tularensis_, only one of which\nseems immunogenic (6). However, in studies\npublished in 1977, the vaccine was shown to\nsignificantly reduce the incidence of typhoidal\ntularemia in US government lab workers from 5.7\nto 0.27 cases per at-risk employee years (7). It\ndid not reduce the incidence of the\nulceroglandular form, but the disease in\nvaccinees was reported to be milder. I am not\naware whether the vaccine is effective if given post-exposure.\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al.\nOutbreak of tularemia in the Republic of\nDagestan, Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol 2001;6 (Suppl):68-72.\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al. A\nwaterborne tularemia outbreak. Eur J Epidemiol 1987;3:35-8.\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et\nal. An epidemiological investigation of a\ntularemia outbreak in Smolensk Province. Zh Mikro\nEpidemiol Immunobiol 1997;2:33-7.\n4. Nierengarten MB, Lutwick LI. Developing new\ntularemia vaccines. Medscape Infectious Diseases 2002; 4 (1) at\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/431539>.\n5. Tigertt WD. Soviet viable _Pasteurella\ntularensis_ vaccines. Bacteriol Rev. 1962;26:354-73.\n6. Sandstrom G. The tularemia vaccine. J Chem Tech Biotechnol. 1994;59:315-20.\n7. Burke DS. Immunization against tularemia:\nanalysis of the effectiveness of live\n_Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention of\nlaboratory-acquired tularemia. J Infect Dis. 1977;135:55-60.\nA map of Sweden showing the location of Varmland\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.sna.se/webbatlas/lan/bilder/varmland.gif>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Although tularemia\npneumonia is the form of the disease associated\nwith biological terrorism, it may also occur\nnaturally, as is exemplified by the sporadic case\ndescribed in New York City and outbreaks among\ngardeners on Martha's Vineyard, both cited in past ProMED postings below. USA (NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209114", "date": "2006-01-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (NEBRASKA)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 30 Dec 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Grand Island Independent [edited]\n<http://www.theindependent.com/stories/123005/new_tularemia30.shtml>\n\n2 cases of a bacterial infection that rarely manifests itself in\nhuman beings have been detected in Grand Island, prompting health\nofficials to issue a warning to the community.\nTularemia, also known as 'rabbit fever,' is typically found in\nanimals, especially rodents and rabbits. The disease naturally\nexists, but human cases are 'very rare in Central Nebraska,'\naccording to the Central District Health Department, which issued a\nwarning on Thu, 29 Dec 2005.\n'We've had 2 cases in 2 weeks, and that's pretty exceptional,' said\nMichelle Ellermeier, epidemiology nurse at the Health Department. 'We\nusually see 3 to 4 cases a year, so we felt it necessary to let\npeople know it was out there.'\nEllermeier said it's likely the local rabbit population is the\nculprit, and during times when hunters are out and when pets might\nget hold of a rabbit, the public should be on alert. The signs of the\ndisease may include skin ulcers, swollen lymph glands, inflamed eyes,\nsore throat, mouth sores, diarrhea and pneumonia.\n[Byline: Mike Bockoven]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The manifestations of _Francisella tularensis_ infection, a category\nA biowarfare agent, are not clearly stated here. Many cases of\ntularemia involve lymph node infection with (ulceroglandular) or\nwithout (glandular) a local skin infection draining to the lymph\nnode. In the winter, infection tends to be associated with rabbit\nhunting and in the summer, with tick or deer fly bites.\nSummer cases associated with lawn mowers, as has been described on\nMartha's Vineyard in Massachusetts, are often pneumonic, related to\ninhalation of bacilli. Unlike human plague infection, pneumonic\ntularemia does not spread from person to person. Bloodstream\ninfection (bacteremia) can be associated with different forms of\ndisease or may be the only manifestation (typhoidal form). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Many cases of\ntularemia involve lymph node infection with (ulceroglandular) or\nwithout (glandular) a local skin infection draining to the lymph\nnode. Laboratory results\nare pending for another hunter.\n'We probably have one death' said Mrs. Doris Becker, spokeswoman of the\nadministration. No laboratory results are available as the deceased had\nbeen already buried before tularemia was taken into account. In the press\nrelease is noted that he 'died with typical symptoms'.\n20 men had participated at the hunt. All cases, the probable case, and the\ndeceased were part of a group of 8 persons that gutted the hares. Their age\nwas between 46 and 73 years. All but the one were treated immediately and\nare well now. All were suffering with 'flu-like symptoms' high fever,\nmalaise, muscle and joint pains, and swollen lymph nodes.\n--\nEberhard G. Gekeler MD\nDarmstadt, Germany\n<egekeler@t-online.de>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Gekeler for the follow-up report. The death may indeed\nbe secondary to _F. tularensis_ infection, but no specifics are given. The\nmorbidity and mortality of tularemia is, in part, due to the type of the\norganism involved. Type A, _F. tularensis_ biovar tularensis, is much more\nvirulent than type B, biovar _palaeartica_. The latter type is generally\nthe one found in Europe and Asia, whereas type A is the most common type in\nNorth America (1). Some tularensis strains, however, are found in Europe\n(2). In the pre-antimicrobial era, the mortality from type A infections\nwas between 5-15 percent of cases but as high as 30-60 percent for\nuntreated pneumonic and typhoidal forms (1).\n1. Dennis DT, Inglesby TV, Henderson DA, et al: Tularemia as a biological\nweapon. Medical and public health management. JAMA 2001; 285:2763-73.\n2. Gurycova D: First isolation of Francisella tularensis subspecies\ntularensis in Europe. Eur J Epidemiol 1998: 14:797-802.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nEberhard G. Gekeler MD\nDarmstadt, Germany\n<egekeler@t-online.de>\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/an525>\n In the pre-antimicrobial era, the mortality from type A infections\nwas between 5-15 percent of cases but as high as 30-60 percent for\nuntreated pneumonic and typhoidal forms (1). The latter type is generally\nthe one found in Europe and Asia, whereas type A is the most common type in\nNorth America (1). All were suffering with 'flu-like symptoms' high fever,\nmalaise, muscle and joint pains, and swollen lymph nodes.\n The\nmorbidity and mortality of tularemia is, in part, due to the type of the\norganism involved. Source: Darmstaedter Echo [edited]\n<http://www.echo-online.de>\n\nUp to now, the number of people infected with tularemia after a hunt in\nGriesheim (Hessen, Germany) has increased to at least 6. TULAREMIA, HARE HUNTERS - GERMANY (HESSEN)(02)\n*********************************************\n Type A, _F. tularensis_ biovar tularensis, is much more\nvirulent than type B, biovar _palaeartica_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-12-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gurycova", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208990", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, hare hunters - Germany (Hessen)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208990", "date": "2005-12-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HARE HUNTERS - GERMANY (HESSEN)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/av327>\nDate: Sat, 3 Dec 2005\nFrom: Eberhard Gekeler <egekeler@t-online.de>\nSource: Darmstaedter Echo [edited]\n<http://www.echo-online.de>\n\n2 hunters acquired tularemia in Griesheim near Darmstadt (Hessen,\nGermany) in November 2005. While gutting hares, the 2 sustained cuts.\nLater they fell ill with fever, headache, joint and muscle pains, and\nswollen lymph nodes. The diagnosis of tularemia was established at\nthe Klinikum Darmstadt Medical Center and confirmed at the Institute\nfor Tropical Diseases of the University of Heidelberg. The affected\nhunters are recovering as outpatients.\nThe hunted hares did not show any abnormalities, and no dead animals\nor live animals with unusual behavior have been observed in the area.\nAccording to the Robert Koch Institute, 3 cases of tularemia were\ndiagnosed in Germany during 2004. In 2005, 3 cases have been reported\n(not including these cases).\n--\nEberhard G. Gekeler MD\nDarmstadt, Germany\n<egekeler@t-online.de>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Gekeler for this posting. Darmstadt is\nlocated in the state of Hessen, in east central Germany. It is 30\nminutes by car south of Frankfurt. Infection with _Francisella\ntularensis_ (tularemia), a Category A bioterrorism agent, is endemic\nin Europe. Sporadic cases are generally related to exposure to feral\nanimals, especially rabbits and hares, while larger clusters are\noften water-related. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nEberhard G. Gekeler MD\nDarmstadt, Germany\n<egekeler@t-online.de>\n Sporadic cases are generally related to exposure to feral\nanimals, especially rabbits and hares, while larger clusters are\noften water-related. Source: Darmstaedter Echo [edited]\n<http://www.echo-online.de>\n\n2 hunters acquired tularemia in Griesheim near Darmstadt (Hessen,\nGermany) in November 2005. Infection with _Francisella\ntularensis_ (tularemia), a Category A bioterrorism agent, is endemic\nin Europe. The diagnosis of tularemia was established at\nthe Klinikum Darmstadt Medical Center and confirmed at the Institute\nfor Tropical Diseases of the University of Heidelberg. TULAREMIA, HARE HUNTERS - GERMANY (HESSEN)\n******************************************\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-11-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Griesheim", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Frankfurt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hessen", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208790", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, air sensor detection - USA (DC)(05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208790", "date": "2005-10-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA)\n(05)\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe Journal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\nDate: Mon, 10 Oct 2005\nFrom: Dave Lesak <DaveHMA@aol.com>\n\nThe issue regarding type A and B tularemia's environmental\npersistence points out a very interesting situation and\npotentially serious knowledge gaps when considering possible\nbioterrorism: namely, the lack of background levels of\nvarious potential agents.\nFor example, when _Bacillus anthracis_ spores were detected\nin the fall of 2001, sampling took place in untold locations\nthroughout the country. Most were never examined in a\nlaboratory but rather simply segregated by threat\ncredibility. Samples of what were considered highly\ncredible may have been sent to a lab for analysis.\nWhat if hundreds, thousands, or even tens of thousands of\nlocations tested positive for _B. anthracis_? The number of\nreports of white powder almost brought response and lab\npersonnel to the breaking point, even though only a small\nfraction of samples were ever fully examined and fewer still\nfound to be positive.\nIn these reports, we find some evidence of possible\nbackground levels of tularemia in various locations. Suppose\nthere was a reported bioterrorism attack involving _F.\ntularensis_ or _B. anthracis_. Thousands of samples would\nbe again taken by emergency services personnel. Many would\nalso use bio-agent detector technologies to perform field\ntests.\nWhat should they expect to find? Are _B. anthracis_ or _F.\ntularensis_ present as background organisms? If so, are\nthey background everywhere or only in certain environments?\nIf this information is not available, what is considered\n'normal' or 'safe'? What levels of organism require\nremediation? Without answers to these and multiple other\nthorny questions, the USA is at risk for a situation that\nterrorizes the public for no reason other than a lack of\nknowledge regarding natural background.\nConsider if the levels of background radiation were not\nidentified. It would truly be a sad state of affairs when\ntesting was first begun.\n--\nDave Lesak\nHazard Management Associates\nAllentown, PA\n<DaveHMA@aol.com>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dave Lesak for his comments. Background\nlevels for detection of these organisms are clearly needed.\nFor the moment, then, this thread -- which has stimulated\nmuch discussion -- is cut. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\n The issue regarding type A and B tularemia's environmental\npersistence points out a very interesting situation and\npotentially serious knowledge gaps when considering possible\nbioterrorism: namely, the lack of background levels of\nvarious potential agents. The number of\nreports of white powder almost brought response and lab\npersonnel to the breaking point, even though only a small\nfraction of samples were ever fully examined and fewer still\nfound to be positive. Without answers to these and multiple other\nthorny questions, the USA is at risk for a situation that\nterrorizes the public for no reason other than a lack of\nknowledge regarding natural background. \nDave Lesak\nHazard Management Associates\n For example, when _Bacillus anthracis_ spores were detected\nin the fall of 2001, sampling took place in untold locations\nthroughout the country. Many would\nalso use bio-agent detector technologies to perform field\ntests. Most were never examined in a\nlaboratory but rather simply segregated by threat\ncredibility. It would truly be a sad state of affairs when\ntesting was first begun.\n The Journal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\n Allentown, PA\n<DaveHMA@aol.com>\n In these reports, we find some evidence of possible\nbackground levels of tularemia in various locations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208784", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, air sensor detection - USA (DC) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208784", "date": "2005-10-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA)\n(04)\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Hospital Infection\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5wh7>\nDate: Sat 8 Oct 2005\nFrom: Robert Miceli <Robert.Miceli@sparta.com>\n\nOne might also begin to look at the resident squirrel\npopulation in the DC mall area to see whether they are\nindeed serving as reservoirs for _F. tularensis_. There\ncertainly is a large population of them, as any visitor can\nattest, and this would be consistent with theories expressed\nconcerning tularemia bacillus presence in the environment --\nthat is, through carcasses decaying in the soil, airborne\ndissemination of contaminated dust/dirt, and possible\npresence short term in local water pools.\nWe have seen similar sampling and detection systems based on\nsensitive PCR techniques show up positive in the past out\nhere in Utah, prior to the 2002 Olympic Games. These were\ngenerally explained away, given the endemic nature of _F.\ntularensis_ in the local rabbit population, the time of\nyear, and environmental climate changes (fall season is\ncooler, cloudier with more humidity), etc.\nFor DC, however, we need to test the idea of indigenous host\nreservoirs to address the question of source rather than to\njust say that it is not associated with any terrorist\nactivity. The National Park Service can start by rounding\nup some squirrels for testing.\n--\nRobert Miceli, PhD\nSenior Principal Scientist, Homeland Security Division\nDefense Systems and Technology Operations\nSPARTA Inc.\nSalt Lake City, UT\n<robert.miceli@sparta.com>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Miceli for his comments and his\ninformation regarding positive sensor readings prior to the\n2002 Olympics in Salt Lake City. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "There\ncertainly is a large population of them, as any visitor can\nattest, and this would be consistent with theories expressed\nconcerning tularemia bacillus presence in the environment --\nthat is, through carcasses decaying in the soil, airborne\ndissemination of contaminated dust/dirt, and possible\npresence short term in local water pools. These were\ngenerally explained away, given the endemic nature of _F.\ntularensis_ in the local rabbit population, the time of\nyear, and environmental climate changes (fall season is\ncooler, cloudier with more humidity), etc.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n For DC, however, we need to test the idea of indigenous host\nreservoirs to address the question of source rather than to\njust say that it is not associated with any terrorist\nactivity. TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA)\n (04)\n **\n \n \n \n Date: Sat 8 Oct 2005 From: Robert Miceli <Robert.Miceli@sparta.com>\n\n --", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Salt Lake City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208778", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, air sensor detection - USA (DC)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208778", "date": "2005-10-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA)(03)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of Tuberculosis\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5dpp>\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 6 Oct 2005\ufffd\nFrom: Mike McDowell <Mike.McDowell@DOH.WA.GOV>\n\nRe the article (02) posted 5 Oct 2005, I would recommend checking the water in\nthe reflecting pool at the mall. Basically if you want a new strain of _F.\ntularensis_, go to your nearest stream or other body of water! Some time ago --\nand way before 9/11 -- I sampled the water (a tiny stream) behind my\nresidence in the Seattle area and scored a nice strain of tularemia with no\nproblem.\n--\nMichael Gary McDowell\nWashington State Dept. of Health Public Health Laboratories\nShoreline, WA\n<Mike.McDowell@DOH.WA.GOV>\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Thu, 6 Oct 2005\nFrom: Sam R. Telford, III <Sam.Telford@tufts.edu>\n\nThe editorial comment on Kate Torres' query perpetuates a poorly documented\nassertion about the agent of tularemia, viz., that it may stably persist in\nsoil. I am unaware of any primary literature that documents this for Type A\n(_Francisella tularensis tularensis_).\nIndeed, the North American reports of persistence of _F. tularensis_ in water\nand mud (classic studies by Jellison and others) need to be reexamined,\nbecause it is unclear which subspecies was present. I would bet that it was\nall Type B. There is no question that Type B (_F. tularensis palaearctica_)\npersists in water and mud, and large outbreaks have been recorded in Eurasia\nassociated with arvicoline [living in the fields or countryside - Mod.LL]\nrodent excreta contaminating hay or other environmental materials.\ufffd\nType B is a very different bug from Type A. Type A depends on ticks for its\nenzootic cycle. Type B may have multiple modes of perpetuation, including\nemerging evidence for an association with free-living amebae, which might\nexplain prolonged persistence in wet environments. Naked bacteria of either\ntype seem extremely fastidious and labile in vitro, a fact that stands in\ncontrast to a perception that the agent of tularemia is environmentally\npersistent.\nEnvironmental material may certainly be contaminated by excreta or animal\ncarcasses and serve as fomites, but the duration of infectivity of such\nmaterials is extremely poorly defined except for Type B. The suggestion that\nType A (which is most likely the one detected around DC) is stable in soil (by\nsoil I mean dry earth, as opposed to mud, which has a large aqueous fraction)\nfor any length of time needs to be backed up by finding primary peer-reviewed\npublications, and not by referring to discussion within reviews or reports of\noutbreaks wherein arguments are being made about the most likely mode of\ntransmission. Facts get altered when they are passed from review to review,\nand from recent discussions referencing such reviews. In addition, it is not\ncorrect to equate the physiologic attributes of one _F. tularensis_ subspecies\nwith another.\nAs for urban tularemia, dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) are important\nvectors of Type A. Dog ticks certainly occur in urban areas, as do their main\nreproductive hosts, raccoons and skunks. The potential for zoonoses\ntransmitted by urban dog ticks was underscored by the cluster of Rocky\nMountain spotted fever cases in a Manhattan park (Salgo et al. 1988 NEJM\n318:1345). Cottontail rabbits and their ticks (_Ixodes dentatus_,\n_Haemaphysalis leporispalustris_) are also fairly common in urban peridomestic\nsettings.\n--\nSam Telford ScD\nTufts University\n<Sam.Telford@tufts.edu>\n[CDC reference: Tularemia <http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/tularemia/>]\n[ProMED thanks these contributors for their comments. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The suggestion that\nType A (which is most likely the one detected around DC) is stable in soil (by\nsoil I mean dry earth, as opposed to mud, which has a large aqueous fraction)\nfor any length of time needs to be backed up by finding primary peer-reviewed\npublications, and not by referring to discussion within reviews or reports of\noutbreaks wherein arguments are being made about the most likely mode of\ntransmission. Cottontail rabbits and their ticks (_Ixodes dentatus_,\n_Haemaphysalis leporispalustris_) are also fairly common in urban peridomestic\nsettings.\n As for urban tularemia, dog ticks (_Dermacentor variabilis_) are important\nvectors of Type A. Dog ticks certainly occur in urban areas, as do their main\nreproductive hosts, raccoons and skunks. There is no question that Type B (_F. tularensis palaearctica_)\npersists in water and mud, and large outbreaks have been recorded in Eurasia\nassociated with arvicoline [living in the fields or countryside - Mod. Indeed, the North American reports of persistence of _F. tularensis_ in water\nand mud (classic studies by Jellison and others) need to be reexamined,\nbecause it is unclear which subspecies was present. The potential for zoonoses\ntransmitted by urban dog ticks was underscored by the cluster of Rocky\nMountain spotted fever cases in a Manhattan park (Salgo et al. Environmental material may certainly be contaminated by excreta or animal\ncarcasses and serve as fomites, but the duration of infectivity of such\nmaterials is extremely poorly defined except for Type B. Type B may have multiple modes of perpetuation, including\nemerging evidence for an association with free-living amebae, which might\nexplain prolonged persistence in wet environments. In addition, it is not\ncorrect to equate the physiologic attributes of one _F. tularensis_ subspecies\nwith another.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1988-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington State Dept", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manhattan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208627", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (WA) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208627", "date": "2005-09-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (WASHINGTON) (02)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Tue 6 Sep 2005\nFrom: Mira Leslie <Mira.Leslie@doh.wa.gov>\n\n7 cases of tularemia have recently been reported in residents of 4 counties\nin western Washington. In most years, 2-4 cases of tularemia are reported\nstatewide (annually). Investigations show that the recent cases are not\nlinked (to one location or source) and have been contracted naturally.\nOnset dates for the patients are between 28 May and 2 Aug 2005. The age\nrange is 6 to 66 years old; 5 are male. Most of the exposures occurred in\nthe county of residence, though in 2 cases, there is a possibility of\nexposure both locally and out of state, and the King county case was\ncontracted in north western WA.\n4 of the cases presented with ulceroglandular tularemia, one with\nmeningitis and pneumonia, and 2 with pneumonic tularemia. 2 of the\npneumonic tularemia cases were most likely exposed while using power tools\nto do landscaping (mowing, weed trimming); the ulceroglandular cases\ninvolved insect bites; one of the exposures is still unknown.\nHealth advice has been sent to health care providers and veterinarians in\nwestern Washington.\n--\nMira J Leslie, DVM, MPH\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nWashington Department of Health\nShoreline, WA\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Leslie from the Washington Department of Health for\nthis additional information regarding the recent tularemia cases in that\nstate. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n 2 of the\npneumonic tularemia cases were most likely exposed while using power tools\nto do landscaping (mowing, weed trimming); the ulceroglandular cases\ninvolved insect bites; one of the exposures is still unknown. They are from the Staroutkinskiy rayon and from\nEkaterinburg. They all had summer cottages in the village of Volini.\nAccording to the deputy chief of the sanitary department of the\nEkaterinburg region, Andrey Yurovskih, 4 people were admitted to the\ninfectious department of the regional hospital at the beginning of the week\n[final week August 2005]. 3 of these people were hospitalized; one of them\nchose to get treatment at home.\nPhysicians and epidemiologists from Pervouralsk city checked local people\nand visitors (20 in all) for the disease. 11 of them were confirmed with\ntularemia, none was hospitalized.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is not clear whether these are cases that were noted in the previous\nposting in this thread.
