Date: Tue 30 Aug 2005\n They all had summer cottages in the village of Volini.\n TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (EUROPEAN) (02)\n From: Vadim Melnik <vamelnik@ua.fm>\n They are from the Staroutkinskiy rayon and from\nEkaterinburg. promed@promedmail.org>\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pervouralsk city", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208531", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia (Nizhniy Novgorod)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208531", "date": "2005-08-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (NIZHNIY NOVGOROD)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Microbial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\nDate: Tue 23 Aug 2005\nFrom: Natalia Pshenichnaya <crane@aaanet.ru>\nSource: Regional news agency Kreml [translated by submitter, edited]\n<http://www.riakreml.ru/society/31825/>\n\nTularemia, Nizhniy Novgorod region, Russia\n-----------------------------------------------\n96 persons, including 15 children, with symptoms of tularemia have sought\nmedical aid in the Nizhniy Novgorod region, the Press Service of the\nPrivolzhsko-Uralskiy center reports.\n66 of the 96 patients are inhabitants of Dzerzhinsk and 30 of Nizhni\nNovgorod. The diagnosis has been laboratory confirmed in 40 patients.\nClinical symptoms of ulceroglandular tularemia were observed in 94 persons\nand the typhoidal form of the disease in 2 others. 87 people have been\nhospitalized.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Nizhniy Novgorod Region is in Central Russia on the Volga river. - Mod.NP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \n96 persons, including 15 children, with symptoms of tularemia have sought\nmedical aid in the Nizhniy Novgorod region, the Press Service of the\nPrivolzhsko-Uralskiy center reports. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInternational Journal of Microbial Agents\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/ijaa>\n Source: Regional news agency Kreml [translated by submitter, edited]\n<http://www.riakreml.ru/society/31825/>\n\nTularemia, Nizhniy Novgorod region, Russia\n \n66 of the 96 patients are inhabitants of Dzerzhinsk and 30 of Nizhni\nNovgorod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Dzerzhinsk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208761", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, air sensor detection - USA (DC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208761", "date": "2005-10-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of Tuberculosis\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5dpp>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 1 Oct 2005\n[posting delayed in order to include followup in [2] below]\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters [edited]\n<http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=topNews&storyID=uri:2005-\n10-02T030640Z_01_WRI211144_RTRUKOC_0_US-BACTERIA.xml&pageNumber=0&summit=>\n\nUSA finds fever bacteria during war protest weekend\n---------------------------------------------------\nSmall amounts of a bacterium that causes 'rabbit fever' were found on\nWashington's National Mall last weekend [24-25 Sep 2005], as\nthousands of protesters marched against the Iraq War, USA health\nauthorities said on Sat 1 Oct 2005. The CDC said several government\nenvironmental air monitors in the Mall area detected low levels of\n_Francisella tularensis_ bacteria that cause tularemia, commonly\nknown as rabbit fever, on 24-25 Sep 2005. Public health agencies had\nno reports of any related human or animal illnesses caused by the\nbacteria.\nThe CDC said it issued an alert on Friday night, 30 Sep 2005, as a\nprecaution so medical personnel were aware of the situation and could\nreport any suspected cases. Tularemia does not transmit from person\nto person and can be effectively treated with readily available\nmedicines, the CDC said. Symptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days after\nexposure, but in rare cases can take up to 2 weeks.\nSymptoms of the disease include sudden fever, chills, headaches,\nconjunctivitis, diarrhea, muscle aches, joint pain, dry cough and\nprogressive weakness. District of Columbia health officials told\nlocal radio station WTOP on Sat 1 Oct 2005 that the detected bacteria\nwas not harmful and probably occurred naturally.\nThe CDC waited a week to notify city officials of the detected\nbacteria because it took that long to test the samples at labs and\nconfirm its presence, the radio station reported.\nAccording to the CDC's website, people can get tularemia by being\nbitten by a infected tick, deerfly or other insect, handling infected\nanimal carcasses, eating or drinking contaminated food or water or\nbreathing in the organisms. The CDC also said the bacterium can be\nused as a weapon if made into an aerosol that could be inhaled.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although not many human cases are reported in the USA each year and the\ndisease is primarily endemic in the middle USA, as well as Martha's Vineyard,\nan island off the coast of Massachusetts, almost every state has reported\ncases -- see refs. below. Since the bacterium is ubiquitous, unlike plague,\nthe BioWatch system may detect its nucleic acid if, for instance, material\ncontaining the organism is aerosolized by landscaping or yard work.\nA description of the BioWatch system can be obtained from the Federation of\nAmerican Scientists website at:\n<http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/terror/RL32152.html#_1_3>\n- Mod.LL]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 Oct 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Washington Post, Wed 5 Oct 2005; Page B01 [edited]\n<http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-\ndyn/content/article/2005/10/04/AR2005100401544.html>\n\nTest Results Cited in Delay of Mall Alert; CDC Explains Why Local\nOfficials Weren't Told for Days About Bacterium Detection\n-----------------------------------------------\nArea health officials were not notified for 5 days that sensors on\nthe [Washington DC] Mall had detected a potentially dangerous\nbacterium there last month [September 2005], because subsequent tests\nwere not conclusively positive, a federal official said yesterday [4\nOct 2005].\nThe Department of Homeland Security delayed in alerting the federal\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] for the same reason,\nsaid Richard Besser, who directs the CDC's coordinating office for\nterrorism preparedness and emergency response. More than half a dozen\nsensors showed the presence of tularemia bacteria the morning, after\nthousands of people gathered on the Mall for a book festival and\nantiwar rally, yet the CDC was not contacted for at least 72 hours.\nTesting never identified all the definitive markers for which\nscientists were looking, and officials were wary of issuing a false\nalarm, Besser said. He called the entire incident 'highly unusual,'\nbut he acknowledged that it would prompt the 2 agencies to review\ntheir protocol and the timeliness of their response 'to make sure the\nsystem doesn't have any flaws in it. It really will cause us to look\nat the system and say, 'Should things have been different?'' Besser\nsaid in a phone interview.\nIn letters Representative Thomas M. Davis III (Virginia Republican)\nsent on Monday [3 Sep 2005] to Homeland Security Secretary Michael\nChertoff and CDC Director Julie Gerberding, he called the\nnotification time frame 'alarming' and asked for an accounting of the\nprocedures triggered when the government's 'BioWatch network' senses\na biological agent. His questions focused on what each agency knew\nand when it knew it, as well as which local and state officials were\ncalled and when. 'Why weren't these officials notified immediately\nfollowing the detection?' Davis wrote. [Probably because it was\ninitially thought to be a false alarm, and the agency did not want to\ncause unnecessary panic. - Mod.JW]\nD.C. Health Director Gregg A. Pane, who learned of the situation in a\nconference call on Friday [30 Sep 2005] morning, said he would have\nliked to have been involved sooner. Hours after being alerted by the\nCDC, he and his counterparts across the Washington region put out an\nannouncement for the public. 'I wish they'd bring us in earlier,' he\nsaid yesterday [4 Oct 2005]. 'There's got to be a level of trust and\ncommunication' among the entities and layers of government, he said.\nAs of yesterday [4 Oct 2005], local and federal health officials said\nthey had confirmed no cases of tularemia from the Mall gathering and,\nthrough medical surveillance, had not found any spikes in possible\nsymptoms. Although the germ that causes tularemia is highly\ninfectious, the disease itself is not passed from person to person\nand can be easily treated with antibiotics. Left untreated, it can be\nfatal.\nBesser said that if the initial evaluation had revealed true\npositives, the laboratory would have immediately contacted Homeland\nSecurity, which would have immediately brought CDC and local health\nagencies into the discussion.\nInstead, as late as Thursday [29 Sep 2005], CDC officials expected\nfinal testing to disprove the presence of the bacteria. 'So we didn't\nreally think there was a need to alert [area] public health\nofficials,' he said.\nIn his letter, Davis requested specifics about the bacteria levels\nultimately detected and the government's plan to inform the public of\nrisk. 'How do you monitor the thousands of people who visited the\naffected areas?' he asked.\nA Homeland Security spokeswoman did not return calls to comment on\nthe issues Davis raised.\n[Byline: Susan Levine and Sari Horwitz]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED thanks all the readers who sent in versions of this report.\nAnalysts were correct to suspect a false positive, since the\nbackground of tularemia in the DC area is very low -- no human cases\nreported since 2000 -- and the rarer an organism in the area, the\nhigher the probability of a false positive.\nA similar incident occurred in Houston (TX), USA in October 2003, when 2 air\nsensors detected fragments of tularemia bacteria. There were no human cases of\ntularemia reported after the incident, and some experts in the bioterror field\nsaid they believe the incident was actually spurred by a strain of the\nbacterium that does not affect humans (Source: Petula Dvorak, Washington Post\n2 Oct 2005) -- see ref. below.\nHowever, it appears from the above report that confirmatory tests were\npositive, although the levels detected were rather low to be considered a\nthreat. It is important to know eventually whether the bacterium was type A or\nB or a vaccine strain. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "-----------------------------------------------\nArea health officials were not notified for 5 days that sensors on\nthe [Washington DC] Mall had detected a potentially dangerous\nbacterium there last month [September 2005], because subsequent tests\nwere not conclusively positive, a federal official said yesterday [4\nOct 2005]. In letters Representative Thomas M. Davis III (Virginia Republican)\nsent on Monday [3 Sep 2005] to Homeland Security Secretary Michael\nChertoff and CDC Director Julie Gerberding, he called the\nnotification time frame 'alarming' and asked for an accounting of the\nprocedures triggered when the government's 'BioWatch network' senses\na biological agent. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Washington Post, Wed 5 Oct 2005; Page B01 [edited]\n<http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-\ndyn/content/article/2005/10/04/AR2005100401544.html>\n\nTest Results Cited in Delay of Mall Alert; CDC Explains Why Local\nOfficials Weren't Told for Days About Bacterium Detection\n Besser said that if the initial evaluation had revealed true\npositives, the laboratory would have immediately contacted Homeland\nSecurity, which would have immediately brought CDC and local health\nagencies into the discussion.\n [Byline: Susan Levine and Sari Horwitz]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n The CDC said several government\nenvironmental air monitors in the Mall area detected low levels of\n_Francisella tularensis_ bacteria that cause tularemia, commonly\nknown as rabbit fever, on 24-25 Sep 2005. Small amounts of a bacterium that causes 'rabbit fever' were found on\nWashington's National Mall last weekend [24-25 Sep 2005], as\nthousands of protesters marched against the Iraq War, USA health\nauthorities said on Sat 1 Oct 2005. As of yesterday [4 Oct 2005], local and federal health officials said\nthey had confirmed no cases of tularemia from the Mall gathering and,\nthrough medical surveillance, had not found any spikes in possible\nsymptoms. Analysts were correct to suspect a false positive, since the\nbackground of tularemia in the DC area is very low -- no human cases\nreported since 2000 -- and the rarer an organism in the area, the\nhigher the probability of a false positive. There were no human cases of\ntularemia reported after the incident, and some experts in the bioterror field\nsaid they believe the incident was actually spurred by a strain of the\nbacterium that does not affect humans [Although not many human cases are reported in the USA each year and the\ndisease is primarily endemic in the middle USA, as well as Martha's Vineyard,\nan island off the coast of Massachusetts, almost every state has reported\ncases -- see refs. below. More than half a dozen\nsensors showed the presence of tularemia bacteria the morning, after\nthousands of people gathered on the Mall for a book festival and\nantiwar rally, yet the CDC was not contacted for at least 72 hours. The Department of Homeland Security delayed in alerting the federal\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] for the same reason,\nsaid Richard Besser, who directs the CDC's coordinating office for\nterrorism preparedness and emergency response. According to the CDC's website, people can get tularemia by being\nbitten by a infected tick, deerfly or other insect, handling infected\nanimal carcasses, eating or drinking contaminated food or water or\nbreathing in the organisms. Source: Reuters [edited]\n<http://today.reuters.com/news/newsArticle.aspx?type=topNews&storyID=uri:2005-\n10-02T030640Z_01_WRI211144_RTRUKOC_0_US-BACTERIA.xml&pageNumber=0&summit=>\n\nUSA finds fever bacteria during war protest weekend\n A description of the BioWatch system can be obtained from the Federation of\nAmerican Scientists website at:\n<http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/terror/RL32152.html#_1_3>\n- Mod. District of Columbia health officials told\nlocal radio station WTOP on Sat 1 Oct 2005 that the detected bacteria\nwas not harmful and probably occurred naturally. The CDC said it issued an alert on Friday night, 30 Sep 2005, as a\nprecaution so medical personnel were aware of the situation and could\nreport any suspected cases. Health Director Gregg A. Pane, who learned of the situation in a\nconference call on Friday [30 Sep 2005] morning, said he would have\nliked to have been involved sooner. The CDC waited a week to notify city officials of the detected\nbacteria because it took that long to test the samples at labs and\nconfirm its presence, the radio station reported. So we didn't\nreally think there was a need to alert [area] public health\nofficials,' he said. Tularemia does not transmit from person\nto person and can be effectively treated with readily available\nmedicines, the CDC said. Testing never identified all the definitive markers for which\nscientists were looking, and officials were wary of issuing a false\nalarm, Besser said. In his letter, Davis requested specifics about the bacteria levels\nultimately detected and the government's plan to inform the public of\nrisk. ' Public health agencies had\nno reports of any related human or animal illnesses caused by the\nbacteria.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2003-10-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-09-29 00:00:00", "2005-09-03 00:00:00", "2005-09-30 00:00:00", "2005-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208768", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, air sensor detection - USA (DC)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208768", "date": "2005-10-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA)(02)\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of Tuberculosis\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5dpp>\nDate: Tue, 4 Oct 2005\nFrom: Kate Torres <TORRESK1@WESTAT.com>\n\nThis story is somewhat dismissive of what would seem to be a rather\nunusual if not completely novel occurrence. Would someone be willing\nto comment on this situation, incidence of (or other evidence of the\npresence of) tularemia in urban areas, and the known or potential\nreservoirs in urban areas? Were any findings of investigations into\nthe similar situation in Houston in Oct 2003 made public?\nFinally, I am curious about the statement about tularemia occurring\n'naturally in soil.' From my textbook understanding of tularemia,\nany soil contamination, as from the presence of a contaminated animal\ncarcass, would be temporary and localized. Soil itself is not a\nreservoir -- e.g., tularemia does not persist in soil in spore form\nlike anthrax or tetanus. Apart from the Houston incident, what\nevidence is there of persistent tularemia in soil and how does it\npersist?\n--\nCatherine Torres\nWestat\nRockville, MD\n<TORRESK1@WESTAT.com>\n[Regarding potential non-animate environmental sources of _F. tularensis_\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------\nInvestigations into the cluster of pneumonic tularemia on Martha's\nVineyard (Feldman KA, Enscore RE, Lathrop SL, et al: An outbreak of\nprimary pneumonic tularemia on Martha's Vineyard. N Engl J Med 2001;\n345:1601-1606), showed that primary pneumonic tularemia had been\nreported in persons who disturbed the carcasses of infected rabbits,\nin European farmers who worked with contaminated hay, in 2 boys who\nmowed over a rabbit, and in a man who used a brush cutter to clear a\nlot where many rabbits lived. In addition, they comment that lawn\nmowing has been epidemiologically implicated in an outbreak of\npsittacosis, in which patients were no more likely than controls to\nkeep, handle, or feed birds but were more likely to have mowed lawns\nand lawn mowing may have aerosolized _Chlamydia psittaci_ shed by\nsick birds.\nRodents can excrete viable _F. tularensis_ in both urine and feces, and\nFeldman, et al. (ref. above) propose that on Martha's Vineyard, _F.\ntularensis_ was shed in animal excreta, persisted in the environment, and\ninfected people after being mechanically aerosolized and inhaled. The authors\nfelt that the outbreak indicates that people can acquire primary pneumonic\ntularemia from mowing in the absence of any obvious exposure to infected\nanimal tissue.\nRegarding the environmental survival of the tularemia bacillus\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough _F. tularensis_ does not form spores, it can survive in water, soil,\nand decaying animal carcasses. Feldman et al. (ref. above) reported that the\norganism persists in water and mud for as long as 14 weeks, in oats for 4\nmonths and in straw for 6 months. Although they were unsuccessful in culturing\n_F. tularensis_ from environmental samples, the optimal methods for collecting\nand isolating the organism from grass and air have not been determined. In\naddition, they may have collected samples under environmental conditions that\ndiffered from those existing when the patients were exposed. - Mod.LL]\n[Regarding tularemia in the District of Columbia\n------------------------------------------------\nThe disease is uncommon in DC, though it was common in the 1920s and\n1930s among market men handling wild rabbits (from Jellison's text\n'Tularemia in North America 1930-1974'). Indeed, Jellison stated that\nby 1929, the District ranked 4th in North America in total cases of\nthe disease diagnosed, following Ohio, Montana, and Tennessee. [Given\nrelative sizes, DC seemed to be the highest in cases per square mile\n- Mod.LL]. From 1948-1974, there were only 6 cases of tularemia in\nDC. From 2000 to 2004, there were no cases reported in DC (from CDC\n'Summary of Notifiable Diseases').\nBack in 1978 there was an outbreak in DC of 3 cases:\nMartone WJ, Marshall LW, Kaufmann AF, et al: Tularemia pneumonia in\nWashington, DC. A report of three cases with possible common-source\nexposures. JAMA. 1979; 242:2315-7.\nAbstract: In June 1978, 3 cases of tularemia pneumonia occurred in\npersons residing in the Washington, DC, area. The patients, all men,\nbecame ill 3 to 4 days after a brief session training their hunting\ndogs in an undeveloped wooded area adjacent to a housing complex. One\nof the dogs, which later died, had captured a wild rabbit during the\ntraining session. All 3 men had handled the rabbit while\nfamiliarizing their dogs with the rabbit's scent. The men had no\nother common exposure that was a likely source of infection.\n- Mod.DS]", "summary": "N Engl J Med 2001;\n345:1601-1606), showed that primary pneumonic tularemia had been\nreported in persons who disturbed the carcasses of infected rabbits,\nin European farmers who worked with contaminated hay, in 2 boys who\nmowed over a rabbit, and in a man who used a brush cutter to clear a\nlot where many rabbits lived. In addition, they comment that lawn\nmowing has been epidemiologically implicated in an outbreak of\npsittacosis, in which patients were no more likely than controls to\nkeep, handle, or feed birds but were more likely to have mowed lawns\nand lawn mowing may have aerosolized _Chlamydia psittaci_ shed by\nsick birds. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nCatherine Torres\nWestat\nRockville, MD\n<TORRESK1@WESTAT.com>\n \nInvestigations into the cluster of pneumonic tularemia on Martha's\nVineyard (Feldman KA, Enscore RE, Lathrop SL, et al: An outbreak of\nprimary pneumonic tularemia on Martha's Vineyard. The authors\nfelt that the outbreak indicates that people can acquire primary pneumonic\ntularemia from mowing in the absence of any obvious exposure to infected\nanimal tissue. Would someone be willing\nto comment on this situation, incidence of (or other evidence of the\npresence of) tularemia in urban areas, and the known or potential\nreservoirs in urban areas? Apart from the Houston incident, what\nevidence is there of persistent tularemia in soil and how does it\npersist?\n-- Back in 1978 there was an outbreak in DC of 3 cases:\nMartone WJ, Marshall LW, Kaufmann AF, et al: Tularemia pneumonia in\nWashington, DC. The disease is uncommon in DC, though it was common in the 1920s and\n1930s among market men handling wild rabbits (from Jellison's text\n'Tularemia in North America 1930-1974'). From my textbook understanding of tularemia,\nany soil contamination, as from the presence of a contaminated animal\ncarcass, would be temporary and localized. The patients, all men,\nbecame ill 3 to 4 days after a brief session training their hunting\ndogs in an undeveloped wooded area adjacent to a housing complex. (ref. above) propose that on Martha's Vineyard, _F.\ntularensis_ was shed in animal excreta, persisted in the environment, and\ninfected people after being mechanically aerosolized and inhaled. One\nof the dogs, which later died, had captured a wild rabbit during the\ntraining session.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tuberculosis", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1929-03-25 00:00:00", "1978-06-25 00:00:00", "1978-03-25 00:00:00", "1979-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tennessee", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the District of Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rockville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208616", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208616", "date": "2005-09-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (WASHINGTON)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Thu, 1 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Daily News, Longview, WA [edited]\n<http://www.tdn.com/articles/2005/09/01/area_news/news02.txt>\n\nCowlitz County and state officials are alerting residents and health\nprofessionals about an increase in cases of a rare disease that is\nsometimes tied to bioterrorism. There's no need to panic, and the number of\ncases is still low, but officials want people to be aware and take simple\nprecautions such as not handling dead rodents or [other] animals and\nreporting them to the health department.\nTularemia, also called 'rabbit fever,' is caused by naturally occurring\nbacteria. The state averages between 2 and 4 cases a year. From 28 May to 2\nAug 2005, however, 7 cases have been reported in Western Washington --\nincluding 2 in Cowlitz County.\n'We rarely have any cases around here and then, boom, we had several,' said\nHilary Gillette, Cowlitz County's epidemiologist. 'And with other cases\nreported, that got (state officials) interested.' It's unclear whether\nsomething happened to introduce the disease to the area or if it's always\nbeen here and was just undetected, Gillette said. There is some evidence\nthe disease has been here for awhile. An unrelated statewide veterinary\nstudy this winter found that 4.3 per cent of Cowlitz, Clark and Lewis\ncounty pets showed exposure to the disease, compared to the state average\nof 1.9 per cent. 'So maybe it's always been here,' Gillette said.\nThe 2 Cowlitz County cases were found in a man in his 50s and a young boy.\nOfficials believe the man was exposed while using a riding lawn mower. The\nboy was bitten by an insect while on a trip to Canada, but officials don't\nknow if that caused his disease.\nThe man was hospitalized at Oregon Health Sciences University, another\npatient in Clark County also was hospitalized, and had a serious\nbloodstream infection. All 7 of the known Washington patients, 2 each in\nClark, Cowlitz and Thurston counties and 1 in King County, have recovered.\nThe Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy lists tularemia along\nwith anthrax, botulism, plague, and smallpox as bioterrorism threats. In\n1969, the World Health Organization estimated an aerosol dispersal of 110\npounds of virulent tularemia in a city of 5 million would cause 250 000\nillnesses, including 19 000 deaths.\n[byline: Barbara LaBoe]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The manifestations of _Francisella tularensis_ infection are not clearly\nstated here. Many cases of tularemia involve lymph node infection with\n(ulceroglandular) or without (glandular) a local skin infection draining to\nthe lymph node. Cases associated with lawn mowers, as has been described on\nMartha's Vineyard in Massachusetts, are often pneumonic, related to\ninhalation of bacilli. Unlike human plague infection, pneumonic tularemia\ndoes not spread from person to person. Bloodstream infection (bacteremia)\ncan be associated with different forms of disease or may be the only\nmanifestation (typhoidal form). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In\n1969, the World Health Organization estimated an aerosol dispersal of 110\npounds of virulent tularemia in a city of 5 million would cause 250 000\nillnesses, including 19 000 deaths.\n Source: The Daily News, Longview, WA [edited]\n<http://www.tdn.com/articles/2005/09/01/area_news/news02.txt>\n\nCowlitz County and state officials are alerting residents and health\nprofessionals about an increase in cases of a rare disease that is\nsometimes tied to bioterrorism. There's no need to panic, and the number of\ncases is still low, but officials want people to be aware and take simple\nprecautions such as not handling dead rodents or [other] animals and\nreporting them to the health department. An unrelated statewide veterinary\nstudy this winter found that 4.3 per cent of Cowlitz, Clark and Lewis\ncounty pets showed exposure to the disease, compared to the state average\nof 1.9 per cent. ' [byline: Barbara LaBoe]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\n Many cases of tularemia involve lymph node infection with\n(ulceroglandular) or without (glandular) a local skin infection draining to\nthe lymph node. Bloodstream infection (bacteremia)\ncan be associated with different forms of disease or may be the only\nmanifestation (typhoidal form). Cases associated with lawn mowers, as has been described on\nMartha's Vineyard in Massachusetts, are often pneumonic, related to\ninhalation of bacilli. The\nboy was bitten by an insect while on a trip to Canada, but officials don't\nknow if that caused his disease. edited]\n<http://www.7info.ru/index.php?kn=1124459797>\n\n56 people are hospitalized with tularemia in the oblast of Ryazan. 28\npeople were infected in the Klepikovskiy rayon, 3 people in Spasskiy, 4\npeople in Rayzanskiy, 2 people in in Shilovkiy, and 3 people in Moskovskiy\nand Vladimirskiy regions [see comment below regarding case numbers].\nThis information came from the Chief of the Epidemiological Department of\nthe Hygiene and Epidemiology Center, Galina Sedova.\nBy 19 Aug 2005, 58 cases of tularemia had been registered in Ryazan,\nincluding 4 children. In 2004, only 4 cases of tularemia were reported in\nRyazan. According to information from the Sanitary Epidemiological\nSurveillance Center, infection is transmitted through mosquito and\nhorse-fly bites.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although the post reports 56 cases hospitalized, the numbers following do\nnot add up to 56. Adv Drug Del Reviews\n17 Jun 2005. 57(9):1403-1414 <http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.addr.2005.01.030>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n 28\npeople were infected in the Klepikovskiy rayon, 3 people in Spasskiy, 4\npeople in Rayzanskiy, 2 people in in Shilovkiy, and 3 people in Moskovskiy\nand Vladimirskiy regions [see comment below regarding case numbers]. By 19 Aug 2005, 58 cases of tularemia had been registered in Ryazan,\nincluding 4 children.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-19 00:00:00", "2005-08-18 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-06-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Galina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shilovkiy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ryazan)(02", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Isherwood KE", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208575", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia (European)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208575", "date": "2005-08-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (EUROPEAN)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\n[1]\nDate: Mon, 29 Aug 2005\nFrom: Natalia Pshenichnaya <crane@aaanet.ru>\nSource: News Agency Regions.ru [trans. Corresp.NP; edited]\n<http://www.regions.ru/article/any/id/1874781.html>\n\nAccording to the Territorial Management of the Federal Service, on 26 Aug\n2005, 334 people with symptoms of tularemia, including 54 cases among children\nunder 14 years of age, have been reported in the Nizhny Novgorod, Voronezh,\nMoscow, and Vladimir regions. The diagnosis has been laboratory-confirmed in\n128 persons; confirmation in the others is pending.\n135 people with such symptoms, including 26 children, have been registered in\nthe Moscow region, mostly among inhabitants of the Shatursky district. All the\naffected people have been hospitalized. In 33 persons, the diagnosis has been\nlaboratory-confirmed. 23 have been discharged from the hospital.\n99 people with symptoms of tularemia have been registered in the Nizhny\nNovgorod region, 17 of whom are children. 66 are inhabitants of Dzerzhinsk,\nand 33 are from Nizhny Novgorod. The diagnosis has been laboratory-confirmed\nin 43 people, including 18 children.\n82 cases have been reported in Gorohovetskiy district of the Vladimir region\nwhere victims have summer residences; 12 of these people were believed to have\nbeen infected in the Nizhny Novgorod region; 3 in the Ryazan and 2 in the\nIvanovo region.\n67 people with symptoms of tularemia have been registered in the July-August\n2005 period in the Ryazan area, including 5 children. 50 have been\nhospitalized. In 25 people from the Klepikovsky district, the diagnosis has\nbeen laboratory-confirmed.\n\n28 people with symptoms of tularemia have been detected in the Voronezh\nregion, including 6 children: Voronezh - 25 cases, Liskinsky district - 2\ncases, and Buturlinsky district - 1 case. In 22 patients the diagnosis has\nbeen confirmed in the laboratory. Infection in urban dwellers has taken place\nduring visits to rural settlements.\nAll affected people have recalled bites by horseflies or other blood-sucking\ninsects, or bathing in open reservoirs in areas where the infection is\nnaturally endemic in wildlife.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 31 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Interfax.ru [edited]\n<http://www.interfax.ru/e/B/politics/28.html?id_issue=11369656>\n\nMore than 30 residents of the villages of Volyny and Staroutkinsk in the\nSverdlovsk region have been hospitalized with suspected tularemia, the Federal\nConsumer Rights and Welfare Service's Shalinsky district office told Interfax\non Wed, 31 Aug 2005.\n2 other patients suspected of having contracted tularemia have been\nhospitalized in Yekaterinburg, the hospital press service said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This posting expands the areas where human tularemia cases have been reported\nin central Russia as well as increasing the total numbers -- see map\n<http://en.retal.ru/images/map4.gif>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Interfax.ru [edited]\n<http://www.interfax.ru/e/B/politics/28.html?id_issue=11369656>\n\nMore than 30 residents of the villages of Volyny and Staroutkinsk in the\nSverdlovsk region have been hospitalized with suspected tularemia, the Federal\nConsumer Rights and Welfare Service's Shalinsky district office told Interfax\non Wed, 31 Aug 2005. 82 cases have been reported in Gorohovetskiy district of the Vladimir region\nwhere victims have summer residences; 12 of these people were believed to have\nbeen infected in the Nizhny Novgorod region; 3 in the Ryazan and 2 in the\nIvanovo region. According to the Territorial Management of the Federal Service, on 26 Aug\n2005, 334 people with symptoms of tularemia, including 54 cases among children\nunder 14 years of age, have been reported in the Nizhny Novgorod, Voronezh,\nMoscow, and Vladimir regions. \n\n28 people with symptoms of tularemia have been detected in the Voronezh\nregion, including 6 children: Voronezh - 25 cases, Liskinsky district - 2\ncases, and Buturlinsky district - 1 case. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nDrug Resistance Updates\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/drup>\n \n135 people with such symptoms, including 26 children, have been registered in\nthe Moscow region, mostly among inhabitants of the Shatursky district. \n67 people with symptoms of tularemia have been registered in the July-August\n2005 period in the Ryazan area, including 5 children. \n99 people with symptoms of tularemia have been registered in the Nizhny\nNovgorod region, 17 of whom are children. [This posting expands the areas where human tularemia cases have been reported\nin central Russia as well as increasing the total numbers -- see map\n<http://en.retal.ru/images/map4.gif>. All affected people have recalled bites by horseflies or other blood-sucking\ninsects, or bathing in open reservoirs in areas where the infection is\nnaturally endemic in wildlife.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-08-31 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Voronezh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Buturlinsky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yekaterinburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nizhny", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Klepikovsky", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dzerzhinsk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208488", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208488", "date": "2005-08-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (MASSACHUSETTS)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nTravel Medicine and Infectious Disease\n<http://www.travelmedicine.elsevier.com>\n\nDate: Fri, 19 Aug 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Vineyard Gazette [edited]\n<http://www.mvgazette.com/news/2005/08/19/tick_borne_illnesses.php>\n\nState health officials document increase in tularemia\n--------------------------------------------------\nMassachusetts public health officials have confirmed 8 cases of tularemia\non the island of Martha's Vineyard in 2005, the highest number since 2000,\nwhen 15 people were diagnosed. The report raises the number of confirmed\ntularemia cases to 37 since the summer of 2000 and marks the 6th successive\nsummer that the rare disease has been documented on the Island.\nDr. Frederic Cantor, the public health veterinarian for the state\ndepartment of public health (DPH), said 3 of the 8 cases have been\nconfirmed as pneumonic tularemia, a form of the disease that affects the\nrespiratory tract and is caused by inhaling airborne tularemia bacteria.\nWhile rare in other parts of the nation, pneumonic tularemia has been\ndocumented in increasing numbers on the Vineyard in recent years. Health\nofficials continue to urge people who work outdoors to wear respirators\nrated at N-95 or higher to filter out potentially harmful particles. Dr.\nCantor said none of the 3 victims of pneumonic tularemia appeared to have\nbeen wearing masks when they were infected.\n'Most of these again seem to have exposure to outdoor activities in terms\nof landscaping, caretaking and gardening. I think part of the issue is, are\nall these people not wearing masks and why?' he said. 'That seems to be a\nrisk factor and most of the people seem not to be wearing masks.'\nDr. Cantor said the DPH is examining a possible 4 additional cases of\ntularemia. At least 2 of this year's confirmed cases were other types of\ntularemia, which can be spread by handling infected material, such as\nanimal carcasses or by bites from dog ticks, known to carry the disease. 3\nof the 8 cases are still unclassified, Dr. Cantor said. One has been\nconfirmed as tickborne, and the 1st case of the year, contracted in Apr\n2005 by a Vineyard landscaper, was oropharyngeal, indicating that the\naffected glands were in the man's throat. While the pneumonic form of\ntularemia is the most common type seen on the Island, Dr. Cantor said the\nother cases in 2005 point to the fact that the disease can be spread a\nvariety of ways.\nTularemia has been documented on the Island since the 1930s, when some\nhunters began contracting the disease, also sometimes known as rabbit fever\nbecause rabbits primarily carry the disease. The 1st major outbreak of\npneumonic tularemia occurred in 1978, when 15 people were infected, 7 of\nthem from one home in Chilmark. A Chilmark man died in the summer of 2000\nafter contracting the disease.\nTularemia usually affects about 200 people a year nationwide, putting the\nIsland at the foreground for study in the medical community. Since the 1st\noutbreak in 1978, the high number of tularemia cases has baffled public\nhealth officials and fueled numerous studies. Researchers first traveled to\nthe Island after the 2000 outbreak, including investigators from the\nCenters for Disease Control (CDC), the DPH, and Harvard and Tufts\nuniversities. The teams concluded that landscapers were most at risk, but\nso far they have been unable to conclusively locate areas where the risk\nfor tularemia is the greatest.\n'There is work that's still being done on the Island,' Dr. Cantor said,\n'There may be areas that are likely hot spots but we can't really ascertain\nthat.'\nSam Telford, an associate professor of infectious diseases at Tufts\nUniversity, has been coming to the Island since 2000 once a month during\nthe spring and summer to collect dog ticks and examine the wild animal\npopulation as part of a tularemia study. Mr. Telford told the Gazette in\nJun 2005 that the number of infected dog ticks has remained the same in the\nlast 2 years. Mr. Telford's study shows that Squibnocket and Katama have\nhigher rates of infected ticks than other parts of the Island.\n[Byline: Brien Hefler]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Human infection with _Francisella tularensis_ continues to be a problem on\nMartha's Vineyard, a 100-square-mile island off the southern coast of Cape\nCod, MA. A significant number of the cases are pneumonic, occurring in\nlandscapers and gardeners, related to the aerosolization of infective\nbacteria.\nTelford (mentioned in the posting) and colleagues (1) have investigated the\ngenetic diversity of _F. tularensis_ obtained from Martha's Vineyard\nticks. Between 2001 and 2003, 0.7 percent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor\nvariabilis_) harbored the tularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of\ngenotypic diversity suggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of\nthe infection on the island.\nThe authors review information regarding the island's tularemia, which\nappears to have been a relatively recent introduction into\nMassachusetts. They state that prior to 1937, only one case of the\ninfection was recognized, related to contaminated rabbit meat from the\nmidwestern USA. In 1937, however, more than 20 000 cottontail rabbits from\nthe midwestern states of Missouri and Kansas were introduced into the\nmainland state and Martha's Vineyard for sporting purposes (2). Cases\nbegan to occur starting several years later.\n1. Goethert HK, Shani I, Telford SR: Genotypic diversity of _Francisella\ntularensis_ infected _Dermacentor variabilis_ ticks on Martha's Vineyard,\nMassachusetts. J Clin Microbiol 2004; 42:4968-73.\n2. Belding DL, Merrill: Tularemia in imported rabits in Massachusetts. N\nEngl J Med 1941; 1085-87.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Dr. Frederic Cantor, the public health veterinarian for the state\ndepartment of public health (DPH), said 3 of the 8 cases have been\nconfirmed as pneumonic tularemia, a form of the disease that affects the\nrespiratory tract and is caused by inhaling airborne tularemia bacteria. --------------------------------------------------\nMassachusetts public health officials have confirmed 8 cases of tularemia\non the island of Martha's Vineyard in 2005, the highest number since 2000,\nwhen 15 people were diagnosed. While the pneumonic form of\ntularemia is the most common type seen on the Island, Dr. Cantor said the\nother cases in 2005 point to the fact that the disease can be spread a\nvariety of ways. \nTularemia has been documented on the Island since the 1930s, when some\nhunters began contracting the disease, also sometimes known as rabbit fever\nbecause rabbits primarily carry the disease. Between 2001 and 2003, 0.7 percent of 4246 dog ticks (_Dermacentor\nvariabilis_) harbored the tularemia bacillus, and there was a degree of\ngenotypic diversity suggestive of long-standing enzootic transmission of\nthe infection on the island. One has been\nconfirmed as tickborne, and the 1st case of the year, contracted in Apr\n2005 by a Vineyard landscaper, was oropharyngeal, indicating that the\naffected glands were in the man's throat. Researchers first traveled to\nthe Island after the 2000 outbreak, including investigators from the\nCenters for Disease Control (CDC), the DPH, and Harvard and Tufts\nuniversities. Source: Vineyard Gazette [edited]\n<http://www.mvgazette.com/news/2005/08/19/tick_borne_illnesses.php>\n\nState health officials document increase in tularemia\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1978-03-25 00:00:00", "1937-03-25 00:00:00", "1941-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Missouri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chilmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kansas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208295", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Russia (Ryazan)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208295", "date": "2005-07-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (RYAZAN)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, organizer of\nThe 1st International Conference for the Journal of Travel Medicine and\nInfectious Disease\n<http://tinyurl.com/8vv5p>\nDate: Tue 12 Jul 2005\nFrom: Natalia Pshenichnaya <crane@aaanet.ru>\nSource: Ryazan News Agency 'Seven News' [translated by Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://www.7info.ru/index.php?kn=3D1121180507>\n\nTularemia, Ryazan region, Russia\n--------------------------------\nThe town of Klepiki in the Ryazan region had 6 cases of tularemia in June\n2005. Natural foci of tularemia exist in 11 districts and in the vicinities\nof Ryazan, the Territorial Management of the Russian consumer supervision\nof the Ryazan region reported.\nAs experts of the Russian consumer supervision of the Ryazan region noted,\nindividuals in the rural area fall ill with tularemia more often. Due to\nthe development of gardening companies and an increase in the number of\nrodents, however, sporadic morbidity among the townspeople has also been\nobserved. Vaccination of the population is the most effective action for\npreventing the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In 2004, 9 cases more than in 2003 had been reported in the region,\naccording to <http://www.regions.ru/article/any/id/1743004.html>. The\nRyazan region is located in the center of the European part of Russia, in\nsubtaiga (the area below the taiga, the subarctic coniferous forests\nlocated south of the tundra in North America, northern Europe, and Asia)\nand the forest-steppe zones. Forests occupy about 1/3 of the territories. -\nMod.NP\nTularemia is a zoonotic category A bioterrorism agent that can be spread by\naerosolization but is not thought to be transmissible from person to\nperson. At present, no licensed tularemia vaccine is available in the USA.\nHowever, the LVS vaccine (live vaccine strain) is available to military\npersonnel under an investigational new drug protocol held by the US Army\nMedical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases (1).\nThe vaccine is administered via scarification using multiple punctures of a\nbifurcated needle. LVS is derived from strain 15 developed in the former\nUSSR and was obtained by the US military in 1956 (2). It is not well\nstandardized and contains 2 phenotypes of _ Francisella tularensis_, only\none of which seems immunogenic (3). However, in studies published in 1977,\nthe vaccine was shown to significantly reduce the incidence of typhoidal\ntularemia in US government lab workers from 5.7 to 0.27 cases per at-risk\nemployee years (4). It did not reduce the incidence of the ulceroglandular\nform, but the disease in vaccinees was reported to be milder.\n1. Nierengarten MB, Lutwick LI. Developing new tularemia vaccines. Medscape\nInfectious Diseases 2002; 4 (1) <http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/431539>.\n2. Tigertt WD. Soviet viable _Pasteurella tularensis_ vaccines. Bacteriol\nRev 1962; 26: 354-73.\n3. Sandstrom G. The tularemia vaccine. J Chem Tech Biotechnol 1994; 59: 315-20.\n4. Burke DS. Immunization against tularemia: analysis of the effectiveness\nof live _Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention of\nlaboratory-acquired tularemia. J Infect Dis 1977; 135: 55-60. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The\nRyazan region is located in the center of the European part of Russia, in\nsubtaiga (the area below the taiga, the subarctic coniferous forests\nlocated south of the tundra in North America, northern Europe, and Asia)\nand the forest-steppe zones. However, in studies published in 1977,\nthe vaccine was shown to significantly reduce the incidence of typhoidal\ntularemia in US government lab workers from 5.7 to 0.27 cases per at-risk\nemployee years (4). Due to\nthe development of gardening companies and an increase in the number of\nrodents, however, sporadic morbidity among the townspeople has also been\nobserved. TULAREMIA - RUSSIA (RYAZAN)\n***************************\n Vaccination of the population is the most effective action for\npreventing the disease.\n --\nProMED-mail\n< As experts of the Russian consumer supervision of the Ryazan region noted,\nindividuals in the rural area fall ill with tularemia more often.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "1962-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-06-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USSR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208025", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, rabbit contact - USA (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208025", "date": "2005-06-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, RABBIT CONTACT - USA (ARIZONA)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 9 Jun 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Arizona Daily Sun [edited]\n<http://www.azdailysun.com/non_sec/nav_includes/story.cfm?storyID=109846>\n\n2 cases of 'rabbit fever' reported\n----------------------------------\nA Coconino County adult and child were diagnosed with tularemia, also known as\nrabbit fever, in May 2005 after coming into contact with a skinned rabbit.\nThe adult had skinned the rabbit and the child had contact with the tissues of\nthe rabbit during skinning and dressing. They have both since recovered from\nthe bacterial disease.\nTularemia, also called deer fly fever, is a bacterial disease that infects\nrabbits and other mammals. It can be transmitted to humans by skinning and\ncleaning, usually of rabbits, or via deer fly and tick bites. Symptoms include\na sore where exposed, swollen lymph nodes, fever, chills, headache, and nausea\nand usually occur from 1 to 14 days after exposure.\nOutdoor enthusiasts are advised to avoid swimming in or drinking untreated\nwater from ponds that infected wild animals could use.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Francisella tularensis_, the bacterium that causes tularemia, is considered\na category A bioterrorism agent. Cases associated with the skinning of\nrabbits usually involve glandular (lymph node) or ulceroglandular (skin and\nlymph node) infection. Large outbreaks, especially in eastern Europe or Asia,\ncan be associated with water exposure.\nPneumonic tularemia can cause a severe and fatal pneumonia when the organism\nis spread by aerosol, as might occur in a biological attack. However,\npneumonic tularemia also occurs without the involvement of bioterrorism, as\ndemonstrated by posts below in New York City as well as outbreaks on Martha's\nVineyard, MA. Unlike pneumonic plague, pneumonic tularemia does not spread\nfrom person to person. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n However,\npneumonic tularemia also occurs without the involvement of bioterrorism, as\ndemonstrated by posts below in New York City as well as outbreaks on Martha's\nVineyard, MA. Cases associated with the skinning of\nrabbits usually involve glandular (lymph node) or ulceroglandular (skin and\nlymph node) infection. Symptoms include\na sore where exposed, swollen lymph nodes, fever, chills, headache, and nausea\nand usually occur from 1 to 14 days after exposure. \nTularemia, also called deer fly fever, is a bacterial disease that infects\nrabbits and other mammals. Source: Arizona Daily Sun [edited]\n<http://www.azdailysun.com/non_sec/nav_includes/story.cfm?storyID=109846>\n\n2 cases of 'rabbit fever' reported\n Outdoor enthusiasts are advised to avoid swimming in or drinking untreated\nwater from ponds that infected wild animals could use.\n TULAREMIA, RABBIT CONTACT - USA (ARIZONA)\n*****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-06-09 00:00:00", "2005-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Coconino County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207700", "headline": "PRO> Tularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA (MA)(04): 2004", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207700", "date": "2005-04-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, LABORATORY-ACQUIRED - USA (MASSACHUSETTS) (04): 2004\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 12 Apr 2005\nFrom: Powell Gammill <pgammill@cox.net>\nSource: Boston Public Health Commission [edited]\n<http://www.bphc.org/news/press_release_content.asp?id=281>\n\nPublic Health officials report on tularemia outbreak at Boston University\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Boston Public Health Commission (BPHC) released its report today\n[the press release was dated Mon 28 Mar 2005 - Mod.LL] on the\ntularemia outbreak at Boston University that occurred in 2004. The 15\npage report, which is authored by Dr. Anita Barry, the BPHC's\ndirector of Communicable Disease, draws the following conclusions:\n1. At this time, the source of Type A _F. tularensis_ in the BU\nlaboratory remains unknown. The federal investigation into the\nincident is pending.\n2. The extensive investigation to date has found no evidence to\nindicate that either the contamination of the LVS stock or the\ninfections of the BU researchers were intentional.\n3. The tularemia outbreak at BU was limited to 3 BU employees and\nnever posed a risk to the public at large.\n4. The failure to identify work-related illness in laboratory staff\nis a major concern for health officials.\n5. The failure to immediately report suspicious work-related illness\nto local and state health departments is a major concern.\n6. Appropriate infection control practices in laboratories must be\nclearly documented for all workers and enforced.\n7. The BU Institutional Biosafety Committee was not able to ensure\ncompliance with appropriate laboratory protocols and procedures.\nAs a result of the incident, the Boston Public Health Commission has\noutlined the following steps:\n1. Develop and implement new mandatory guidelines on the monitoring\nand reporting of occupationally acquired infectious disease illness\namong microbiology research laboratory workers.\n2. Develop and implement mandatory procedures for the public health\nresponse to reported occupationally-acquired infectious diseases.\n3. Identify a public health worker to monitor practices in\nmicrobiology research laboratories, particularly those working with\nthe most dangerous organisms and toxins.\n4. Develop and offer a mandatory educational training for\nInstitutional Biosafety Committees, Human Resources, and Occupation\nHealth personnel responsible for ID research laboratories.\n5. Solicit the input of laboratory science and infectious disease\nexperts to consider specific policy and regulatory changes regarding\nlaboratory operations, including but not limited to the criteria for\nspecimen acceptance, periodic verification of the organism's\nvirulence, storage, chain of custody, and sharing of specimens with\nother research labs.\n6. Closely monitor the internal progress made at BU to strengthen\ninfection control practices in its laboratories.\n--\nPowell Gammill\nHealth Professional\nPhoenix, Arizona, USA\\\n<pgammill@cox.net>\n[ProMED would like to thank Powell Gammill for calling our attention\nto this report. The full report can be found at:\n<http://www.bphc.org/reports/pdfs/report_202.pdf>\nThe report found that the original culture (obtained from the\nUniversity of Nebraska) of LVS strain (the Soviet vaccine strain\nderived from a type B, a somewhat less virulent organism) and its\nsubcultures all contained a mixture of the LVS strain and a type A\n_F. tularensis_. The amount of the contaminating virulent strain was\nless in the original vial obtained. Another LVS culture that the BU\nlabs had obtained from the University of Iowa was found to contain\npure LVS.\nCDC's analysis of this type A strain is continuing, but initial\ncharacterization by pulsed field gel electrophoresis found the\norganism to be distinct from a number of East Coast isolates of type\nA _F. tularensis_, including isolates from Martha's Vineyard. The\nstrain, however, was indistinguishable from a SCHU-4 isolate, and\nseveral other Midwestern strains, but distinct from a type A strain\nthat BU had previously obtained from the University of Nebraska.\nAdditional testing is in progress. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Solicit the input of laboratory science and infectious disease\nexperts to consider specific policy and regulatory changes regarding\nlaboratory operations, including but not limited to the criteria for\nspecimen acceptance, periodic verification of the organism's\nvirulence, storage, chain of custody, and sharing of specimens with\nother research labs. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The report found that the original culture (obtained from the\nUniversity of Nebraska) of LVS strain (the Soviet vaccine strain\nderived from a type B, a somewhat less virulent organism) and its\nsubcultures all contained a mixture of the LVS strain and a type A\n_F. tularensis_. \nCDC's analysis of this type A strain is continuing, but initial\ncharacterization by pulsed field gel electrophoresis found the\norganism to be distinct from a number of East Coast isolates of type\n The\nstrain, however, was indistinguishable from a SCHU-4 isolate, and\nseveral other Midwestern strains, but distinct from a type A strain\nthat BU had previously obtained from the University of Nebraska. The 15\npage report, which is authored by Dr. Anita Barry, the BPHC's\ndirector of Communicable Disease, draws the following conclusions:\n1. \nPowell Gammill\nHealth Professional\n Develop and implement new mandatory guidelines on the monitoring\nand reporting of occupationally acquired infectious disease illness\namong microbiology research laboratory workers. Source: Boston Public Health Commission [edited]\n<http://www.bphc.org/news/press_release_content.asp?id=281>\n\nPublic Health officials report on tularemia outbreak at Boston University\n Identify a public health worker to monitor practices in\nmicrobiology research laboratories, particularly those working with\nthe most dangerous organisms and toxins. Develop and offer a mandatory educational training for\nInstitutional Biosafety Committees, Human Resources, and Occupation\nHealth personnel responsible for ID research laboratories. The extensive investigation to date has found no evidence to\nindicate that either the contamination of the LVS stock or the\ninfections of the BU researchers were intentional. As a result of the incident, the Boston Public Health Commission has\noutlined the following steps:\n1. Another LVS culture that the BU\nlabs had obtained from the University of Iowa was found to contain\npure LVS. The full report can be found at:\n<http://www.bphc.org/reports/pdfs/report_202.pdf>\n Phoenix, Arizona, USA\\\n<pgammill@cox.net>\n The failure to immediately report suspicious work-related illness\nto local and state health departments is a major concern. The failure to identify work-related illness in laboratory staff\nis a major concern for health officials. Develop and implement mandatory procedures for the public health\nresponse to reported occupationally-acquired infectious diseases. At this time, the source of Type A _F. tularensis_ in the BU\nlaboratory remains unknown. The tularemia outbreak at BU was limited to 3 BU employees and\nnever posed a risk to the public at large. Closely monitor the internal progress made at BU to strengthen\ninfection control practices in its laboratories. The amount of the contaminating virulent strain was\nless in the original vial obtained. Appropriate infection control practices in laboratories must be\nclearly documented for all workers and enforced. The Boston Public Health Commission (BPHC) released its report today\n TULAREMIA, LABORATORY-ACQUIRED - USA (MASSACHUSETTS) (04): 2004\n The BU Institutional Biosafety Committee was not able to ensure\ncompliance with appropriate laboratory protocols and procedures. [ProMED would like to thank Powell Gammill for calling our attention\nto this report. LL] on the\ntularemia outbreak at Boston University that occurred in 2004. The federal investigation into the\nincident is pending. Date: Tue 12 Apr 2005\n From: Powell Gammill <pgammill@cox.net>\n \n5. \n5. **\n \n \n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208243", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, oropharyngeal - USA (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208243", "date": "2005-07-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, OROPHARYNGEAL - USA (MASSACHUSETTS)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, organizer of\nThe 1st International Conference for the Journal of Travel Medicine\nand Infectious Disease\n<http://tinyurl.com/8vv5p>\nDate: Fri 8 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Vineyard Gazette (MA) [edited]\n<http://www.mvgazette.com/news/2005/07/08/unusual_tularemia_case.php>\n\nLandscaper contracts tularemia in case considered unusual\n---------------------------------------------------------\nThe Vineyard's 1st tularemia case of the year [2005], a 50-year-old\nmale landscaper, may have contracted the potentially fatal disease\nafter handling a dead rabbit he found while working in Edgartown,\nstate public health officials said this week [1st week July 2005].\nThe latest case, which was confirmed in June 2005, is also notable\nbecause health officials have determined that it was an oropharyngeal\nbrand of tularemia, indicating that the affected glands were in the\nman's throat.\nAll but 7 of the 30 cases confirmed on the Island since the outbreak\nbegan in the summer of 2000 have been the pneumonic form, leading\nmedical investigators to advance the theory that people have inhaled\nairborne particles contaminated with the tularemia bacterium.\nEpidemiologists at the state department of public health (DPH) now\nbelieve that the latest victim also inhaled the bacteria.\n'The most likely explanation for his exposure is that he inhaled\ncoarse particles as opposed to fine, and they didn't make it into his\nlungs,' said Dr. Bela Matyas, the medical director of the\nepidemiology program at the DPH in Boston.\nNearly all the victims of the tularemia outbreak have been\nlandscapers or people who worked predominantly outdoors. The outbreak\nclaimed the life of one victim, killing a 43-year-old Chilmark man in\nAugust of 2000. He was known to have mown a lawn near Squibnocket\nshortly before he fell ill with flu-like symptoms.\nTularemia is a powerful but rare bacterial disease. Rabbits are the\nmost common carriers, in addition to rodents, such as squirrels,\nvoles and muskrats, but a bite from a dog tick is the most typical\nway the disease is transmitted to people. On the Vineyard, though,\nthe pneumonic cases have dominated, making the Island the only place\nin the United States to experience an outbreak of pneumonic tularemia.\nDr. Matyas was skeptical yesterday [7 Jul 2005] that this year's case\nof oropharyngeal tularemia was contracted by ingesting any of the\nbacteria. 'He could have handled that rabbit and then handled food,'\nsaid Dr. Matyas. 'But maybe he raised up some dirt when he picked up\na dead rabbit.'\nThis week [1st week July 2005], the Edgartown landscaper talked to\nthe Gazette and explained that he was taking care of a property in\nApril 2005 on the western edge of Edgartown when he saw the rabbit\ncarcass. The man, who had only recently moved to the Vineyard, asked\nto remain unnamed.\nMeanwhile, state officials at the DPH said there are no other confirmed or\nprobable cases of tularemia on the Island that they are investigating. They\nhave analyzed about a dozen blood samples from landscapers on the Vineyard who\nhave been sick, possibly with tularemia, but only this one has turned up\npositive for the disease so far. Tularemia affects only about 200 people a year\nnationwide.\nAlfred DeMaria, the director of communicable disease control at the\nDPH, said doctors are treating landscapers who become sick with\nantibiotics before there is concrete evidence of tularemia infection.\n'People at high risk who come in with symptoms, we're treating them.\nMost of the time we want to avoid antibiotics, but we want people to\nbe over-treated for it,' said Dr. DeMaria.\nThe outbreak of tularemia on the Vineyard has attracted national\nattention, not only because of the singularity of such an event in\nthe medical annals, but also because the bacterium is ranked as one of\nthe top 5 bioterrorist agents. 3 times in the last 5 years, the CDC\ndispatched epidemic intelligence teams to the Vineyard from its\ninfectious disease facility in Fort Collins, CO to study the outbreak\nand unlock the riddle of why such a rare disease is flourishing here.\nThey came up with [no?] solid answers and concluded simply that the\nlandscapers were at the highest risk and would be advised to wear\ndust masks as a measure of protection from inhaling tularemia\nbacteria.\nThe Katama area of Edgartown and the Squibnocket region in Chilmark\nhave been identified by researchers as hot spots for tularemia.\n[Byline: Chris Burrell]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Tularemia, a category A bioterrorism disease, continues to be\nendemic on Martha's Vineyard, off the coast of mainland\nMassachusetts, USA. Since the landscaper did not consume the rabbit,\nit is indeed likely that some aerosol transfer did occur during his\nwork, or, that hand-to-mouth transfer occurred. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The Vineyard's 1st tularemia case of the year [2005], a 50-year-old\nmale landscaper, may have contracted the potentially fatal disease\nafter handling a dead rabbit he found while working in Edgartown,\nstate public health officials said this week All but 7 of the 30 cases confirmed on the Island since the outbreak\nbegan in the summer of 2000 have been the pneumonic form, leading\nmedical investigators to advance the theory that people have inhaled\nairborne particles contaminated with the tularemia bacterium. The latest case, which was confirmed in June 2005, is also notable\nbecause health officials have determined that it was an oropharyngeal\nbrand of tularemia, indicating that the affected glands were in the\nman's throat. This week [1st week July 2005], the Edgartown landscaper talked to\nthe Gazette and explained that he was taking care of a property in\nApril 2005 on the western edge of Edgartown when he saw the rabbit\ncarcass. 3 times in the last 5 years, the CDC\ndispatched epidemic intelligence teams to the Vineyard from its\ninfectious disease facility in Fort Collins, CO to study the outbreak\nand unlock the riddle of why such a rare disease is flourishing here. They\nhave analyzed about a dozen blood samples from landscapers on the Vineyard who\nhave been sick, possibly with tularemia, but only this one has turned up\npositive for the disease so far. The outbreak of tularemia on the Vineyard has attracted national\nattention, not only because of the singularity of such an event in\nthe medical annals, but also because the bacterium is ranked as one of\nthe top 5 bioterrorist agents. They came up with [no?] solid answers and concluded simply that the\nlandscapers were at the highest risk and would be advised to wear\ndust masks as a measure of protection from inhaling tularemia\nbacteria. The most likely explanation for his exposure is that he inhaled\ncoarse particles as opposed to fine, and they didn't make it into his\nlungs,' said Dr. Bela Matyas, the medical director of the\nepidemiology program at the DPH in Boston.
