They were all hunters or members of a hunter's family and\nwere thought to have acquired the bacterial infection from exposure\nto the carcasses of animals (hares).\nIn the Stavropol region annual outbreaks of tularemia have been\nreported since 2003. Prior to 2003, the last case of disease was\nreported in 1998.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This area is in southwestern Russia. Although the manifestations of\nillness in these reported cases of tularemia are not stated, it is\nlikely that most, if not all of the cases, were glandular (lymph node\ninvolvement) or ulceroglandular (skin ulcer and draining lymph node\ndisease). - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although the manifestations of\nillness in these reported cases of tularemia are not stated, it is\nlikely that most, if not all of the cases, were glandular (lymph node\ninvolvement) or ulceroglandular (skin ulcer and draining lymph node\ndisease). \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Since the beginning of 2005, 9 inhabitants of the Stavropol region\nhave developed tularemia, including 8 adults and a 13-year-old, based\non reports from the Regional Epidemiological Surveillance Center. They were all hunters or members of a hunter's family and\nwere thought to have acquired the bacterial infection from exposure\nto the carcasses of animals (hares). All infected persons were inhabitants of the Petrovskiy, Shpakovskiy\nand Ipatovskiy districts of the Stavropol region and the city of\nStavropol.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Stavropol", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "stavropol", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207245", "headline": "PRO> Tularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA (MA): 2004 (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207245", "date": "2005-01-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, LABORATORY-ACQUIRED - USA (MASSACHUSETTS): 2004 (03)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate:: Tue 25 Jan 2005\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@intellibridge.com>\n\nGiven the commentator's discussion of issues regarding bioweapons risks and\ntularemia vaccines in the previous posting, it should be noted that Soviet\nand Russian bioweapons scientists reportedly developed and tested virulent\ntransgenic tularemia bioweapon strains that had been genetically engineered\nto possess vaccine-subverting and/or antibiotic-resistance properties\n(Non-Proliferation Review, Sunshine Project).\nRussian officials announced on 22 Dec 2004 that security officials had\nsuccessfully prevented efforts by foreign spies to 'seize control' of the\nresearch in 'especially dangerous pathogens' being conducted at the Vektor\nState Scientific Virology and Biotechnology Center (Lenta).\nVektor is a former Soviet bioweapons research facility that currently\nhouses one of the world's most extensive collections of potential bioweapon\npathogens -- including but not limited to the smallpox, Marburg, and Ebola\nviruses -- which was the site of a recent fatal laboratory accident\ninvolving the Ebola virus (see ProMED-mail 20040522.1377).\nLinks to information resources\n---------------------------------\nNon-Proliferation Review 6:\n<http://cns.miis.edu/pubs/npr/vol06/63/alibek63.pdf>\nSunshine Project:\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr130700.html>\nLenta:\n<http://www.lenta.ru/russia/2004/12/22/spy/%20>\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nSenior Analyst, Biosecurity & Agriculture\nIntellibridge\nWashington DC\n<jdudley@intellibridge.com>", "summary": "Lenta:\n<http://www.lenta.ru/russia/2004/12/22/spy/%20>\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nSenior Analyst, Biosecurity & Agriculture\nIntellibridge\nWashington DC\n<jdudley@intellibridge.com> From: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@intellibridge.com>\n\nGiven the commentator's discussion of issues regarding bioweapons risks and\ntularemia vaccines in the previous posting, it should be noted that Soviet\nand Russian bioweapons scientists reportedly developed and tested virulent\ntransgenic tularemia bioweapon strains that had been genetically engineered\nto possess vaccine-subverting and/or antibiotic-resistance properties\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Vektor is a former Soviet bioweapons research facility that currently\nhouses one of the world's most extensive collections of potential bioweapon\npathogens -- including but not limited to the smallpox, Marburg, and Ebola\nviruses -- which was the site of a recent fatal laboratory accident\ninvolving the Ebola virus (see ProMED-mail 20040522.1377).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["smallpox", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-12-25 00:00:00", "2005-01-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MASSACHUSETTS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207939", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, water-borne - Turkey (Edirne)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207939", "date": "2005-05-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WATER-BORNE - TURKEY (EDIRNE)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 26 May 2005\nFrom: Saban Gurcan <sabangurcan@trakya.edu.tr>\n\n[For the 1st time in 60 years, there has been a] tularemia outbreak\nin the Thrace Region (European Part) of Turkey. The 1st patient from\nDemirkoy Village of Edirne Province was diagnosed with oropharyngeal\ntularemia on 28 Feb 2005.\nIn the same week, 266 of 400 villagers were examined and their sera were\ntaken. Cases were diagnosed according to the Turkish Communicable Diseases\nNotification System. Throat swabs and lymph node aspirates were cultured.\nSpecific antibodies in patients and domestic animals were screened by the\nmicro-agglutination test. Water samples from the reservoir of tap water and\nfrom 3 springs were cultured after filtering. PCR [polymerase chain\nreaction] assays of the samples of patients and water sources were\nperformed, along with active surveillance to identify risk factors.\n10 tularemia cases were diagnosed, 7 with the oropharyngeal form and 3\nasymptomatic. The cultures were negative; however PCR assays were positive\nin one lymph node aspirate and [water from] one spring. Some animals had\nspecific antibody at low levels. Increased mouse population in the\nvicinity, exposure to wild rabbits, and drinking from one of the springs\n(PCR-negative) were identified as risk factors with the risk ratios (and 95\npercent confidence intervals) as 10.5 (10.3-10.7), 6.5 (5.43-7.57) and 2.1\n(1.1-2.5), respectively.\nTherapeutic and preventive measures were taken. Local physicians were\ninformed to be aware of the disease.\n--\nDr Saban Gurcan\nTrakya University, Medical Faculty,\nDept of Microbiology and Clinical Microbiology\nEdirne, Turkey\n<sabangurcan@trakya.edu.tr>\n[ProMED would like to thank Dr. Gurcan for this contribution.\nTo a considerable extent, as here, water-borne outbreaks of tularemia\nhave been (not surprisingly) associated with the oropharyngeal form\nof the disease. Outbreaks of water-transmitted tularemia include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nan outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3), improperly prepared water for\nwashing in the Czech Republic (4), and a Swedish outbreak associated with\na contaminated well used for drinking water (5). Additionally, during\nthe period 1936 to 1963, there were approximately 30 outbreaks of\nwater-borne tularemia reported from the then Soviet Union (6).\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al: [Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol\n2001;6 (Suppl):68-72.\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al: A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol 1987;3:35-8.\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: [An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol] 1997;2:33-7. [& 1999 ProMED post,\nref.below]\n4. Pazdiora P, Moravkova I, Nocarova D, et al: [A water-borne\nepidemic of tularemia in Chlumcany] Epidemiol Mikrobiol Imunol.\n2002;51:23-5.\n5. Sigmarnvik T, et al. Infrequent manifestations of tularemia in\nSweden. Scand J Inf Dis. 1997;29:443-46. [& 2003 ProMED post, ref.below]\n6. Pollitzer, R. History and incidence of tularemia in Soviet Union\n-- a review. Institute for Contemporary Russian Studies, Fordham\nUniversity, Bronx, New York, 1967. [& 1999 ProMED post, ref.below]\n- Mod.LL]\n[Note also refs. to water-borne outbreaks in Ukraine & Spain, refs. below. -\nMod.JW]", "summary": "Outbreaks of water-transmitted tularemia include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nan outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3), improperly prepared water for\nwashing in the Czech Republic (4), and a Swedish outbreak associated with\na contaminated well used for drinking water (5). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Increased mouse population in the\nvicinity, exposure to wild rabbits, and drinking from one of the springs\n(PCR-negative) were identified as risk factors with the risk ratios (and 95\npercent confidence intervals) as 10.5 (10.3-10.7), 6.5 (5.43-7.57) and 2.1\n(1.1-2.5), respectively. To a considerable extent, as here, water-borne outbreaks of tularemia\nhave been (not surprisingly) associated with the oropharyngeal form\nof the disease. Additionally, during\nthe period 1936 to 1963, there were approximately 30 outbreaks of\nwater-borne tularemia reported from the then Soviet Union (6). PCR [polymerase chain\nreaction] assays of the samples of patients and water sources were\nperformed, along with active surveillance to identify risk factors. \n10 tularemia cases were diagnosed, 7 with the oropharyngeal form and 3\nasymptomatic. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al: [An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. TULAREMIA, WATER-BORNE - TURKEY (EDIRNE)\n****************************************\n The 1st patient from\nDemirkoy Village of Edirne Province was diagnosed with oropharyngeal\ntularemia on 28 Feb 2005. [Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol\n2001;6 (Suppl):68-72. [& 1999 ProMED post,\nref.below]\n4. Local physicians were\ninformed to be aware of the disease.\n Edirne, Turkey\n<sabangurcan@trakya.edu.tr>\n \nDr Saban Gurcan\n Pazdiora P, Moravkova I, Nocarova D, et al: [A water-borne\nepidemic of tularemia in Chlumcany] Epidemiol Mikrobiol Imunol. Water samples from the reservoir of tap water and\nfrom 3 springs were cultured after filtering. The cultures were negative; however PCR assays were positive\nin one lymph node aspirate and [water from] one spring.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1967-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1963-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-05-26 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-02-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Edirne Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pazdiora P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moravkova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nocarova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207468", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Ukraine (Donetsk)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207468", "date": "2005-03-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - UKRAINE (DONETSK)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 2 Mar 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Correspondent net news agency [edited]\n<http://www.korrespondent.net/main/115740/>\n\nCase of tularemia registered in Donetsk city\n--------------------------------------------\nAccording to the Ministry of emergency situations of Ukraine, a case\nof tularemia has been reported in Donetsk.\nA resident of Shandrigolovoye village (Krasnoliman rayon [district]) of\nDonetsk born in 1955 was hospitalized in the infectious disease department of\nthe central rayon hospital with a diagnosis of tularemia. Specialists from\nthe sanitary epidemiological surveillance station are currently working to\nidentify the source of the infection.\nTularemia is a bacterial infection usually associated with feral\nanimals. Tularemia was common in the 1940s (during World War 2),\nespecially in Russia. Since the disease has features similar to those\nof plague, it has been called the 'minor plague.'\nCurrently, tularemia is reported from time to time. The agent of the\ndisease [_Francisella tularensis_ - Mod.LL] can be transferred\nthrough 125 types of vertebrates, mainly through rodents (muskrats,\nhares, mice). The agent can be transferred to humans by inoculation,\noral intake, or inhalation. Inoculation can occur through direct\ncontact with the animal or its remains or via the tick, mosquito, or\nhorsefly.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although classically transmitted to man via infected animals such as\nrabbits or a tick vector, infection with _Francisella tularensis_ may\nalso be acquired from contact with soil or water harboring the\nbacterium.\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3).\n_F. tularensis_ is designated as a category A bioterrorism agent. At present,\nno licensed tularemia vaccine is available in the USA. However, the LVS\nvaccine (live vaccine strain) is available to military personnel under an\ninvestigational new drug protocol held by the US Army Medical Research\nInstitute of Infectious Diseases (4). It is administered via scarification\nusing multiple punctures of a bifurcated needle. LVS is derived from strain\n15 developed in the former USSR and was obtained by the US military in 1956\n(5). It is not well-standardized and contains 2 phenotypes of _F.\ntularensis_, only one of which seems to be immunogenic (6). However, in\nstudies published in 1977, the vaccine was shown to significantly reduce the\nincidence of typhoidal tularemia in US government laboratory workers from 5.7\nto 0.27 cases per at-risk employee years (7). It did not reduce the\nincidence of the ulceroglandular form, but the disease in vaccinees was\nreported to be milder. I am not aware whether the vaccine is effective if\ngiven postexposure.\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al. [Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol\n2001;6 (Suppl):68-72.\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al. A waterborne tularemia\noutbreak. Eur J Epidemiol 1987;3:35-8.\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al. [An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol] 1997;2:33-7.\n4. Nierengarten MB, Lutwick LI. Developing new tularemia vaccines.\nMedscape Infectious Diseases 2002; 4 (1) at\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/431539>\n5. Tigertt WD. Soviet viable _Pasteurella tularensis_ vaccines.\nBacteriol Rev. 1962;26:354-73.\n6. Sandstrom G. The tularemia vaccine. J Chem Tech Biotechnol. 1994;59:315-20.\n7. Burke DS. Immunization against tularemia: analysis of the\neffectiveness of live _Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention\nof laboratory-acquired tularemia. J Infect Dis. 1977;135:55-60.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64\ncases in Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49\ncases in Tuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2),\nand an outbreak in the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to\ncontamination of a water supply (3). [Although classically transmitted to man via infected animals such as\nrabbits or a tick vector, infection with _Francisella tularensis_ may\nalso be acquired from contact with soil or water harboring the\nbacterium.\n However, in\nstudies published in 1977, the vaccine was shown to significantly reduce the\nincidence of typhoidal tularemia in US government laboratory workers from 5.7\nto 0.27 cases per at-risk employee years (7). However, the LVS\nvaccine (live vaccine strain) is available to military personnel under an\ninvestigational new drug protocol held by the US Army Medical Research\nInstitute of Infectious Diseases (4). Inoculation can occur through direct\ncontact with the animal or its remains or via the tick, mosquito, or\nhorsefly.\n Immunization against tularemia: analysis of the\neffectiveness of live _Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention\nof laboratory-acquired tularemia. A resident of Shandrigolovoye village (Krasnoliman rayon [district]) of\nDonetsk born in 1955 was hospitalized in the infectious disease department of\nthe central rayon hospital with a diagnosis of tularemia. Source: Correspondent net news agency [edited]\n<http://www.korrespondent.net/main/115740/>\n\nCase of tularemia registered in Donetsk city\n [An\nepidemiological investigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk\nProvince. [Outbreak of\ntularemia in the Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol\n2001;6 (Suppl):68-72. It did not reduce the\nincidence of the ulceroglandular form, but the disease in vaccinees was\nreported to be milder. TULAREMIA - UKRAINE (DONETSK)\n*****************************\n Specialists from\nthe sanitary epidemiological surveillance station are currently working to\nidentify the source of the infection. Tularemia is a bacterial infection usually associated with feral\nanimals. Tularemia was common in the 1940s (during World War 2),\nespecially in Russia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1955-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tuscany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Donetsk city", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USSR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandrigolovoye village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207186", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA (MA): 2004", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207186", "date": "2005-01-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, LABORATORY-ACQUIRED - USA (MASSACHUSETTS): 2004\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 19 Jan 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2005/01/19/bacterium_infected_3_at_bu_biolab/>\n\nBacterium infected 3 at BU biolab\n-----------------------------------\n3 Boston University researchers became ill in 2004 after being exposed in a\nlaboratory to a potentially lethal disease called tularemia, university and\npublic health authorities said on Tue 18 Jan 2005. It was the 1st known\ninstance of researchers in a Boston lab becoming infected with a biological\nagent they were studying, according to a city public health official. And\nit came at an awkward time for BU, as it was seeking local and federal\napproval for a high-security lab to study the most feared infectious\ndiseases in the world.\nHow the workers became infected remains unclear, although BU officials said\nthat researchers had violated procedures intended to protect them from\nexposure. 2 researchers became ill in May 2004, and a 3rd in September\n2004, apparently after separate exposures. But their illnesses were not\nlinked to tularemia until October 2004.\nBU reported the cases to city, state, and federal health authorities in\nNovember 2004, about the time public hearings on the high-security lab were\nbeing held. But neither the university nor the government agencies\ndisclosed the cases to the public at the time, saying there was no risk to\npublic health, because tularemia is not transmitted from person to person.\nBoston Mayor Thomas M. Menino, who learned of the cases from BU and city\npublic health officials, also decided against telling city residents.\n'Right from the moment that he was made aware of the situation, the Public\nHealth Commission assured him there was no public threat whatsoever, and\nhe's made it clear that if there was any public threat whatsoever, the\npublic would have been advised immediately,' said Seth Gitell, the mayor's\nspokesman.\nWith Menino's enthusiastic backing, the city Zoning Commission gave its\nfinal approval to the high-security biolaboratory last week [2nd week of\nJanuary 2005]. The lab still must be approved by the National Institute of\nAllergy and Infectious Diseases, which is considered likely, because it's\nthe same agency that, in 2003, selected BU as one of 2 sites nationally for\nsophisticated new labs able to study anthrax, plague, and other deadly\npathogens.\nBU and public health officials discussed the cases publicly for the 1st\ntime yesterday, 18 Jan 2005, after media inquiries. The 1st exposures\nhappened last spring [2004], with 2 researchers falling ill in late May\n2004. They complained of flu-like symptoms, and one was hospitalized\novernight. The 3rd infected researcher fell ill in September 2004 and\nrequired hospitalization for several days, Moore said. All 3 recovered\nfully after receiving antimicrobial agents.\nThey worked in a lab that, in 2003, received a 5-year grant from the\nfederal government to develop a vaccine against tularemia, an illness\nspread by insects and animals, including rabbits. Often called 'rabbit\nfever,' it is also viewed as a potential agent of bioterrorism. [Tularemia,\na disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, is indeed a\nCategory A bioterrorism disease - Mod. LL]. In 2000, an outbreak of\ntularemia on Martha's Vineyard ignited panic, after a laborer died and\nabout a dozen other people became infected. [Cases still occur on Martha's\nVineyard - Mod.LL].\nThe scientists at BU believed that they were working with a strain of the\ngerm that had been altered specifically for vaccine research so as not to\ncause illness. But a highly infectious strain of tularemia was mixed with\nthe harmless variety. The source of the contamination is being investigated\nby federal health officials.\nThe tularemia linked with the illnesses was supplied by a laboratory in\nNebraska that federal authorities, citing security concerns, declined\nyesterday [18 Jan 2005] to identify.\nBecause the researchers assumed that they were working with a form of\ntularemia not known to cause illness, they did not immediately link their\nsymptoms to their research. It was after the 3rd researcher became ill that\nfaculty members began to suspect that something could be seriously wrong in\nthe laboratory inside the university's Evans Biomedical Research building\non Albany Street in the South End.\nSubsequent DNA tests on the tularemia being studied in the BU lab showed\nthat the bacteria identified as coming from Nebraska contained the harmless\nstrain and a highly infectious type.\n'The deck was stacked against [the researchers], because they were working\nwith something they had no idea they were working with,' Moore said. But\nMoore acknowledged that researchers in the lab had violated policies\nrequiring them to work with tularemia inside an enclosed box, called a\nhood, that sends air through sophisticated filters. Instead, the tularemia\nsamples were sometimes worked with in the open, in part because the\nenclosed research boxes were sometimes filled with material that should not\nhave been kept there, Moore said.\nBlood tests were performed on about 60 university researchers, and those\ntests showed that only the 3 workers who had become ill tested positive for\ntularemia. After the exposure was determined, BU, in November 2004,\nshuttered the lab for decontamination. The part of the lab where the\ntularemia research was conducted remains closed.\nThe investigation into how the exposure happened continues. Samples of _F.\ntularensis_ were sent directly from the Nebraska lab for CDC analysis, and\nthose tests showed no presence of the dangerous strain, deepening the\nmystery around the episode.\n'At this time, it seems to me there's no evidence conclusively to link the\ncontamination to Boston or to Nebraska,' said Jennifer Morcone, a CDC\nspokeswoman. 'Certainly, everyone would like to determine the source of the\ncontamination to make certain nothing like this could happen again.'\nAs a result of the exposures, BU, as well as the Boston Public Health\nCommission, are moving to tighten oversight of research. To improve safety\nin the dozens of public and private research labs in Boston, the Public\nHealth Commission intends by this spring [2005] to start a mandatory\ntraining program for lab workers, emphasizing the reporting of illnesses in\nresearchers. The commission also plans to hire a lab safety inspector who\nwill make unannounced visits to research sites to make certain they are\nfollowing safety protocols, said John Auerbach, Public Health Commission\nexecutive director.\n[Byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These accidents underscore the importance of confirming the identities of\nattenuated microbial strains before they are used in the laboratory\nsetting. Since bacterial strains are not easily distinguishable, molecular\nidentification must be used to confirm the identity of strains before they\nare employed in anything less than the highest levels of containment.\nProMED has previously posted a thread regarding laboratory safety and\ndisease dissemination (see below). While it is the case that tularemia does\nnot spread from person-to-person, the infectious dose to infect 50 percent\nof individuals is quite low (less than 100 bacilli), so environmental\ncontamination from a laboratory is of concern. Just as important an issue\nis where and how the attenuated strain became contaminated with virulent\ntularemia bacilli. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n To improve safety\nin the dozens of public and private research labs in Boston, the Public\nHealth Commission intends by this spring [2005] to start a mandatory\ntraining program for lab workers, emphasizing the reporting of illnesses in\nresearchers. Right from the moment that he was made aware of the situation, the Public\nHealth Commission assured him there was no public threat whatsoever, and\nhe's made it clear that if there was any public threat whatsoever, the\npublic would have been advised immediately,' said Seth Gitell, the mayor's\nspokesman. It was after the 3rd researcher became ill that\nfaculty members began to suspect that something could be seriously wrong in\nthe laboratory inside the university's Evans Biomedical Research building\non Albany Street in the South End.\n \nBU reported the cases to city, state, and federal health authorities in\nNovember 2004, about the time public hearings on the high-security lab were\nbeing held. The commission also plans to hire a lab safety inspector who\nwill make unannounced visits to research sites to make certain they are\nfollowing safety protocols, said John Auerbach, Public Health Commission\nexecutive director. \nBlood tests were performed on about 60 university researchers, and those\ntests showed that only the 3 workers who had become ill tested positive for\ntularemia. But\nMoore acknowledged that researchers in the lab had violated policies\nrequiring them to work with tularemia inside an enclosed box, called a\nhood, that sends air through sophisticated filters. While it is the case that tularemia does\nnot spread from person-to-person, the infectious dose to infect 50 percent\nof individuals is quite low (less than 100 bacilli), so environmental\ncontamination from a laboratory is of concern. And\nit came at an awkward time for BU, as it was seeking local and federal\napproval for a high-security lab to study the most feared infectious\ndiseases in the world. Instead, the tularemia\nsamples were sometimes worked with in the open, in part because the\nenclosed research boxes were sometimes filled with material that should not\nhave been kept there, Moore said. Samples of _F.\ntularensis_ were sent directly from the Nebraska lab for CDC analysis, and\nthose tests showed no presence of the dangerous strain, deepening the\nmystery around the episode. Allergy and Infectious Diseases, which is considered likely, because it's\nthe same agency that, in 2003, selected BU as one of 2 sites nationally for\nsophisticated new labs able to study anthrax, plague, and other deadly\npathogens. [Byline: Stephen Smith]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< 3 Boston University researchers became ill in 2004 after being exposed in a\nlaboratory to a potentially lethal disease called tularemia, university and\npublic health authorities said on Tue 18 Jan 2005. But neither the university nor the government agencies\ndisclosed the cases to the public at the time, saying there was no risk to\npublic health, because tularemia is not transmitted from person to person. It was the 1st known\ninstance of researchers in a Boston lab becoming infected with a biological\nagent they were studying, according to a city public health official. They worked in a lab that, in 2003, received a 5-year grant from the\nfederal government to develop a vaccine against tularemia, an illness\nspread by insects and animals, including rabbits. Subsequent DNA tests on the tularemia being studied in the BU lab showed\nthat the bacteria identified as coming from Nebraska contained the harmless\nstrain and a highly infectious type. Because the researchers assumed that they were working with a form of\ntularemia not known to cause illness, they did not immediately link their\nsymptoms to their research. The tularemia linked with the illnesses was supplied by a laboratory in\nNebraska that federal authorities, citing security concerns, declined\nyesterday How the workers became infected remains unclear, although BU officials said\nthat researchers had violated procedures intended to protect them from\nexposure. TULAREMIA, LABORATORY-ACQUIRED - USA (MASSACHUSETTS): 2004\n***********************************************\n [Tularemia,\na disease caused by the bacterium _Francisella tularensis_, is indeed a\nCategory A bioterrorism disease - Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-10-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2005-01-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "2005-01-19 00:00:00", "2005-01-18 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MASSACHUSETTS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Menino", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boston", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebraska", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206879", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC)(04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206879", "date": "2004-11-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW YORK CITY) (04)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 15 Nov 2004\nFrom: Sally Slavinski <sslavins@health.nyc.gov>\n\nThis is in response to the question regarding the route of exposure for the\nNew York City (NYC) resident with tularemia. Interviews with the patient\nsuggest mechanical transmission likely occurred through indirect contact\nwith infected wild rabbits on Staten Island. The patient's 2 dogs visit a\nlocal park daily. One dog captured a wild rabbit and subsequently licked\nthe patient on the face upon returning home.\nThe events occurred approximately 7 to 10 days prior to the onset of\nillness, which is consistent with the incubation period for tularemia. The\npatient never visited the park or had direct contact with rabbits or\nrodents, and denied having any tick or insect bites. The patient suffered\nfrom severe acne and complained of having a swollen submandibular lymph\nnode a few days prior to her onset of illness.\nThe patient's 2 dogs had positive antibody titers for tularemia, and\nseveral rabbits collected from the park were positive by direct fluorescent\nantibody testing (DFA). All animal testing was graciously done by our\ncolleagues at the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Ft. Collins, CO.\n--\nSally Slavinski, DVM, MPH, DACVPM\nNew York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene\nZoonotic and Vectorborne Disease Unit\n<sslavins@health.nyc.gov>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Slavinski for additional information about the\nStaten Island tularemia case. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The patient's 2 dogs had positive antibody titers for tularemia, and\nseveral rabbits collected from the park were positive by direct fluorescent\nantibody testing (DFA). New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene\nZoonotic and Vectorborne Disease Unit\n<sslavins@health.nyc.gov>\n Collins, CO.\n--\nSally Slavinski, DVM, MPH, DACVPM\n The patient suffered\nfrom severe acne and complained of having a swollen submandibular lymph\nnode a few days prior to her onset of illness. The\npatient never visited the park or had direct contact with rabbits or\nrodents, and denied having any tick or insect bites.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206870", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206870", "date": "2004-11-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW YORK CITY) (02)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 11 Nov 2004\nFrom: Pat McDonough <PLM2@cornell.edu>\n\nHave a look at our paper published back in 1994 in the Journal of\nVeterinary Diagnostic Investigation 6(1):102-105, 'Feline tularemia on\nNantucket Island, Massachusetts.'\nThe sudden appearance of tularemia on Cape Cod, MA, was associated with the\nimportation of 29 689 rabbits from 1937 to 1940 by various Massachusetts\ngame clubs. 340 of these rabbits were released on Nantucket Island. Our\nreport gives useful information on the disease in cats and the association\nof certain types of ticks, the potential for tick exposure, and the\noccurrence of disease in animals and humans.\nHave the NYC cases been linked to tick exposure? Have the _Francisella_\nisolates been compared genetically with the Massachusetts endemic strains?\n--\nPatrick L. McDonough (Pat) MS, PhD\nAssoc Professor of Microbiology\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University\n<PLM2@cornell.edu>\n[I am not aware of mention of a known tick exposure in either of the cases\nin NYC posted on ProMED-mail. ProMED would appreciate any comment\nregarding either of Dr. McDonough's queries, and we appreciate his\ncomments. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nPatrick L. McDonough (Pat) MS, PhD\nAssoc Professor of Microbiology\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University\n<PLM2@cornell.edu>\n Our\nreport gives useful information on the disease in cats and the association\nof certain types of ticks, the potential for tick exposure, and the\noccurrence of disease in animals and humans. The sudden appearance of tularemia on Cape Cod, MA, was associated with the\nimportation of 29 689 rabbits from 1937 to 1940 by various Massachusetts\ngame clubs. From: Pat McDonough <PLM2@cornell.edu>\n\nHave a look at our paper published back in 1994 in the Journal of\nVeterinary Diagnostic Investigation 6(1):102-105, 'Feline tularemia on\nNantucket Island, Massachusetts.' ProMED would appreciate any comment\nregarding either of Dr. McDonough's queries, and we appreciate his\ncomments. - Mod. Have the _Francisella_\nisolates been compared genetically with the Massachusetts endemic strains?\n [I am not aware of mention of a known tick exposure in either of the cases\nin NYC posted on ProMED-mail. TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW YORK CITY) (02)\n Date: Thu, 11 Nov 2004\n **\n \n \n Have the NYC cases been linked to tick exposure? 340 of these rabbits were released on Nantucket Island. --", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206876", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, pneumonic - USA (NYC)(03): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206876", "date": "2004-11-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW YORK CITY) (03): CORRECTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 12 Nov 2004\nFrom: Bridget Carr <Bridget.Carr@det.amedd.army.mil>\n\nLikely by now you have received several responses -- but in case not,\nwanted to pass on that Tularemia is a CDC Category 'A' rather than 'B' Agent.\nMany thanks for your great service.\n---\nLt Col Bridget K. Carr, DVM, MPH\nChief, Education and Training\nOperational Medicine, USAMRIID\nFt Detrick, MD\n<Bridget.Carr@det.amedd.army.mil>\n[We appreciate Lt. Col Carr's correction. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "---\nLt Col Bridget K. Carr, DVM, MPH\nChief, Education and Training\nOperational Medicine, USAMRIID\nFt Detrick, MD\n<Bridget.Carr@det.amedd.army.mil>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW YORK CITY) (03): CORRECTION\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206848", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia, rodents, human - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206848", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n-------------------------------------\nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases.\n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases.\n'Plague has always been endemic to this area,' said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department.\nSo far, 4 feline plague cases have been reported this year. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred.\nAnn Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets.\n'Most of our human cases come from cats. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,' Watson said.\nCats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas.\nBubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\nThough the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said.\nRecently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August.\nTularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures.\nAdrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, 'Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.'\n[Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n[Prairie dogs are often considered the most sensitive sentinel to plague.\nGenerally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Cats may be one of our most sensitive domestic sentinels.\nPlague generally has 2 forms: pneumonic and bubonic. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close.\nWhile fleas carry plague, ticks carry tularemia.\nTularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. Tularemia is not known to spread from person to person.\nBoth of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\n \n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004. \nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases. Adrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, 'Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.'\n Ann Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets. [Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Tularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Source: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred. Generally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Tularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. Cats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. Bubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. Though the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said. Plague has always been endemic to this area,' said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department. PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas. Both of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. Recently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close. Health officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,' Watson said. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August. Date: 9 Nov 2004\n promed@promedmail.org\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Loveland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207120", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human, hamster bite, 2004 - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207120", "date": "2005-01-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, HAMSTER BITE, 2004 - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 7 Jan 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR 53(51 & 52);1202-1203 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5351a3.htm>\n\nTularemia Associated with a Hamster Bite - Colorado, 2004\n------------------------------------------------------------\nIn Apr 2004, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment\n(CDPHE) was notified about a boy aged 3 years with diagnosed tularemia\nassociated with a hamster bite. Tularemia has not been associated\npreviously with pet hamsters. CDPHE conducted an investigation to determine\nwhether other owners of hamsters were at risk. Clinicians and public health\nofficials should be aware that pet hamsters are a potential source of\ntularemia.\nDuring Jan 2- Feb 8 2004, the boy was exposed to 6 hamsters that his family\nhad purchased from a pet store in the Denver metropolitan area. Each\nhamster reportedly died from 'wet tail disease' (i.e., diarrhea) within 1\nweek of purchase. One hamster bit the child on the left ring finger shortly\nbefore it died. 7 days later, the child had fever, malaise, painful left\naxillary lymphadenopathy, and skin sloughing at the bite site. After\ntreatment with amoxicillin clavulanate (brand name Augmentin - Mod.LL)\nfailed, the patient underwent excisional biopsy of a left axillary lymph\nnode 49 days after symptom onset for persistent painful lymphadenopathy and\nintermittent fever. Tissue culture yielded a suspected _Francisella\ntularensis_ isolate, which was confirmed by real-time polymerase chain\nreaction and timed-release fluorescence at the CDPHE laboratory.\nConvalescent serology was positive at a titer of 4096, and the isolate was\nidentified by CDC as type B. No other risk factors for tularemia exposure\nwere identified, including no other animal contact, no exposure to game\nmeat, and no known mosquito, tick, or fly bites. The patient improved after\ntreatment with ciprofloxacin.\nWorkers at the pet store reported an unusual number of deaths among\nhamsters but not other animals during Jan-Feb 2004; no carcasses were\navailable for testing. One of 2 cats kept as store pets had a positive\nserologic test for _F. tularensis_ at a titer of 256. Neither cat had\nappeared ill to store employees.\nLists of employees, pet suppliers, and customers who purchased hamsters\nduring Dec 2003-Feb 2004 were obtained from the store owner. 15 of 18\ncustomers were located and interviewed. 8 of these had hamsters that died\nwithin 2 weeks of purchase, but all carcasses had been disposed of and were\nunavailable for testing. One customer and one employee who had febrile\nillness after being bitten by hamsters from the store were negative for _F.\ntularensis_ by serologic testing. The same customer's hamster was\navailable, and it was also negative for _F. tularensis_ by serology and\nculture.\nApproximately 80 percent of the 50 hamsters at the pet store came from\ncustomers who had pets with unanticipated litters. The other 20 percent\nwere purchased from 2 small-pet breeders. These breeders were contacted,\nand neither reported an unusually high number of deaths of hamsters or\nother animals. One breeder also supplied animals to 2 pet stores in\nWyoming. The Wyoming Department of Health had not been notified of any\ntularemia cases linked to these stores.\nConfirmation of a hamster as the infectious source was limited by the delay\nbetween the patient's illness onset and diagnosis and subsequent lack of\navailability of implicated hamsters for testing. Nonetheless, the hamster\nthat bit the patient was the most likely cause of infection because no\nother exposures or risk factors were identified. The positive serologic\ntest for _F. tularensis_ in a pet cat at the store suggested that other\nanimals in the store might have been exposed to _F. tularensis_. In\naddition, the proximity of the onset of the patient's illness to the timing\nof the hamster bite, reports of illness among hamsters, and the deaths of\nhamsters at the pet store indicated an infected hamster as the likely\nsource of illness. A possible scenario, similar to an outbreak of tularemia\nthat involved zoo primates (1), is that infected wild rodents infested the\nstore and spread the infection to hamsters by urinating and defecating\nthrough metal screens covering hamster cages. The infected cat might have\nhad a subclinical or unrecognized illness after catching or eating an\ninfected wild rodent.\nThe store owner was advised to set traps for wild rodents and to inform the\nstate health department of any recurrent animal deaths or reports of ill\ncustomers or staff. No other cases have been identified.\nAlthough tularemia has been associated with hamster hunting in Russia (2),\nit has not been associated previously with pet hamsters in the United\nStates. However, clinicians and public health officials should be aware\nthat pet hamsters might be a potential source of tularemia. Moreover,\nbecause _F. tularensis_ is a potential agent of biologic terrorism (3),\nclinicians should have a heightened awareness of tularemia.\nReported by: J Pape, K Gershman, MD, Colorado Dept of Public Health and\nEnvironment. J Petersen, PhD, Div of Vector-Borne Infectious Diseases,\nNational Center for Infectious Diseases; DD Ferguson, MD, JE Staples, MD,\nEIS officers, CDC.\n1. Calle PP, Bowerman DL, Pape WJ: Nonhuman primate tularemia (_Francisella\ntularensis_) epizootic in a zoological park. J Zoo Wildlife Med 1993;24:459-68.\n2. Munnich D, Lakatos M: Clinical, epidemiological, and therapeutical\nexperience with human tularemia. Infection 1979;7:61-3.\n3. Dennis DT, Inglesby TV, Henderson DA, et al: Tularemia as a biological\nweapon: medical and public health management. JAMA 2001;285:2763-73.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _F. tularensis_ is found in a\nwide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low\ntemperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal\nmatter. Although hundreds of differing vertebrates and invertebrates can\nbe infected with the tularemia bacillus, no more than a dozen or so are\nimportant in its ecology. Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. An exposure such as an animal\nbite will likely result in ulceroglandular or glandular tularemia\n(depending upon whether there is a local lesion associated with lymphadenitis).\nProMED posted on alert (20041008.2760, see below) in Oct 2004 regarding\nhamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be infected\nwith type B tularemia as well. No human cases were reported.\nTularemia in humans is generally a rural disease, and occurs naturally\nthroughout much of North America and Eurasia. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. Type A is said to be more virulent than type B.\nAlthough not generally transferable from person to person, the infectious\ndose of _F. tularensis_ is quite low, and the organism is listed among the\ncategory A bioterrorism agents. - Mod.LL]\n[The title of one of the references is given incorrectly. It should be:\n'Clinical, epidemiological and therapeutical experience with human\ntularaemia: the role of hamster hunter.' (ref 2)\nThe discussion notes that 'tularemia has been associated with hamster\nhunting in Russia'. It should be noted that the literature also documents\ntularemia associated with hamster hunting in Hungary (Szekelyfoldi, J.\n1970. Tularemia in hamster hunters. Del Med J 42:305-6). In 1966, 18 cases\nwere diagnosed in which the source of infection was hamsters. These\ninfections occurred in 4 villages in Hungary along the Berettyo River. Of\nnote, tularemia has also been found in bordering Rumania, where an epidemic\namong hamster hunters was reported in 1955.\nIn addition to Russia, there has also been tularemia in hamster hunters in\nUkraine. In April-May 1934, an outbreak occurred 'in connection with the\nhunting of water rats, hamsters, and hares' (Pollitzer, R., and Fordham\nUniversity New York. Institute of Contemporary Russian Studies. 1967.\nReference: History and incidence of tularemia in the Soviet Union; a\nreview. Institute of Contemporary Russian Studies Fordham University,\nBronx, N.Y., page 16). - Mod.DS]", "summary": "In\naddition, the proximity of the onset of the patient's illness to the timing\nof the hamster bite, reports of illness among hamsters, and the deaths of\nhamsters at the pet store indicated an infected hamster as the likely\nsource of illness. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Tularemia is typically found in animals, especially small mammals such as\nvoles, mice, rodents, rabbits, and hares. _F. tularensis_ is found in a\nwide range of animal hosts and is capable of surviving for weeks at low\ntemperatures in water, moist soil, or decaying plant and animal\nmatter. A possible scenario, similar to an outbreak of tularemia\nthat involved zoo primates (1), is that infected wild rodents infested the\nstore and spread the infection to hamsters by urinating and defecating\nthrough metal screens covering hamster cages. Clinicians and public health\nofficials should be aware that pet hamsters are a potential source of\ntularemia.\n Humans become infected through a variety of\nmechanisms including bites of infected arthropods (mosquitoes, ticks,\ndeerflies), handling infected or dead animals, ingesting contaminated food\nor water, and inhaling aerosols of bacteria. The type B strain (_F.\ntularensis_ biogroup palearctica) is the dominant strain in Eurasia,\nwhereas both biogroups (type A is biogroup tularensis) are found in the\nUSA. LL)\nfailed, the patient underwent excisional biopsy of a left axillary lymph\nnode 49 days after symptom onset for persistent painful lymphadenopathy and\nintermittent fever. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Although tularemia has been associated with hamster hunting in Russia (2),\nit has not been associated previously with pet hamsters in the United\nStates. The positive serologic\ntest for _F. tularensis_ in a pet cat at the store suggested that other\nanimals in the store might have been exposed to _F. tularensis_. ProMED posted on alert (20041008.2760, see below) in Oct 2004 regarding\nhamsters from a Canadian pet distributor that were found to be infected\nwith type B tularemia as well. Workers at the pet store reported an unusual number of deaths among\nhamsters but not other animals during Jan-Feb 2004; no carcasses were\navailable for testing. In Apr 2004, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment\n(CDPHE) was notified about a boy aged 3 years with diagnosed tularemia\nassociated with a hamster bite. Confirmation of a hamster as the infectious source was limited by the delay\nbetween the patient's illness onset and diagnosis and subsequent lack of\navailability of implicated hamsters for testing. One customer and one employee who had febrile\nillness after being bitten by hamsters from the store were negative for _F.\ntularensis_ by serologic testing. Of\nnote, tularemia has also been found in bordering Rumania, where an epidemic\namong hamster hunters was reported in 1955. No other risk factors for tularemia exposure\nwere identified, including no other animal contact, no exposure to game\nmeat, and no known mosquito, tick, or fly bites. TULAREMIA, HUMAN, HAMSTER BITE, 2004 - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\n Moreover,\nbecause _F. tularensis_ is a potential agent of biologic terrorism (3),\nclinicians should have a heightened awareness of tularemia. 8 of these had hamsters that died\nwithin 2 weeks of purchase, but all carcasses had been disposed of and were\nunavailable for testing. These breeders were contacted,\nand neither reported an unusually high number of deaths of hamsters or\nother animals. Nonetheless, the hamster\nthat bit the patient was the most likely cause of infection because no\nother exposures or risk factors were identified. The same customer's hamster was\navailable, and it was also negative for _F. tularensis_ by serology and\nculture.
