Each\nhamster reportedly died from 'wet tail disease' (i.e., diarrhea) within 1\nweek of purchase.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-01-07 00:00:00", "1955-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "1966-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-04-25 00:00:00", "2004-02-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "N.Y.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rumania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hungary", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207234", "headline": "PRO> Tularemia, laboratory-acquired - USA (MA): 2004 (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207234", "date": "2005-01-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, LABORATORY-ACQUIRED - USA (MASSACHUSETTS): 2004 (02)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 21 Jan 2005\nFrom: George Robertson <robertson@pda.org>\nSource: Boston Globe [edited]\n<http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2005/01/21/probe_of_bu_lab_illnesses_looks_to_a_lurking_contaminant/>\n\nProbe of BU lab illnesses looks to a lurking contaminant\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe investigation into how 3 Boston University researchers became infected\nwith tularemia, when they thought they were working with a harmless form of\nthe germ, is increasingly focusing on the possibility that a naturally\noccurring lethal strain contaminated animal blood used to promote growth of\nthe bacteria.\nThe BU scientists, who were trying to develop a tularemia vaccine, were\nusing a form of the bacteria that had been modified to not cause illness.\nBut after the workers became ill, 2 in May 2004 and one in Sep 2004, tests\nshowed that the dangerous strain had contaminated BU's supply. The workers,\nwho recovered, apparently had inhaled that lethal strain.\nAfter 2 months of attempting to unravel the mystery, disease detectives\nhave largely eliminated the possibility that workers at BU, or at the\nNebraska lab that supplied the tularemia to Boston researchers, somehow\nmixed batches of harmless and lethal strains, according to Dr. Paul Mead,\nhead of a federal investigation into the exposure cases. He also said there\nis no indication that there was intentional contamination.\nAuthorities at BU and the CDC have declined to identify the Nebraska\nsupplier, but Dr. Jeffrey Cirillo, an associate professor in the\nveterinarian and biomedical sciences department of the University of\nNebraska in Lincoln, told The Boston Globe on 20 Jan 2005 that the lab at\nhis school shipped the harmless strain to BU in early 2004. Cirillo said\nthe shipment to BU marked the 1st time that Nebraska had sent its\nvaccine-research tularemia to another institution, pointing out that\nextensive federal regulations make such arrangements cumbersome. But he\nsaid Nebraska agreed to supply the bacteria in part because it was not\nwidely available commercially.\nScientists at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln have never worked with\nthe lethal strain of tularemia, Cirillo said. And when the 1st 2 BU\nresearchers fell ill in May 2004, there were no stocks of the dangerous\nvariety of tularemia on the school's South End medical campus, university\nofficials said.\nIt wasn't until August 2004 that BU first took delivery of a vial of Type A\ntularemia, the dangerous form, from a different supplier, and that material\nwas stored in a locked freezer, separate from where the harmless strain was\nkept, said Dr. Thomas J. Moore, acting provost of BU's medical campus.\nOnce tularemia emerged as the leading suspect in the researchers'\nillnesses, a CDC lab in Fort Collins, Colorado, USA, analyzed the material\nin the vial shipped from Nebraska to BU. Those tests showed that both the\nmodified strain and the dangerous strain were present, said Dr. Anita\nBarry, Boston's director of communicable disease control. 'But that didn't\nanswer the question of how did it get into the original bottle,' Barry said.\nKnowing that the Nebraska lab did not work with the dangerous variety,\ninvestigators became increasingly curious about whether animal blood used\nroutinely to grow additional samples might have harbored Type A tularemia.\nBarry said that the Nebraska lab had used rabbit blood from a farm in South\nCarolina to grow the material shipped to Boston, and rabbits are known to\nbe carriers of tularemia, which is commonly known as rabbit fever.\n'To make a batch of rabbit blood, it requires a good number of bunnies,'\nBarry explained. 'One hypothesis is that there was an infected rabbit, and\nwhen Nebraska got the rabbit blood, it would have had Type A tularemia in\nit that nobody knew about.'\nBut by the time a problem was identified in Boston, Barry said, the supply\nof blood that had been used in Nebraska had long since been exhausted,\nmeaning that there was nothing left for testing.\n[Byline: Stephen Smith and Scott Allen]\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, Ph.D.\nPDA\nBethesda, MD\n<robertson@pda.org>\n[The nonvirulent (or at least attenuated) strain mentioned may be the LVS\nvaccine strain discussed below.\nThe following discussion is taken from 'Developing New Tularemia Vaccines'\nwritten by Mary Beth Nierengarten and myself in Medscape Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewpublication/206>\nregarding tularemia vaccines. (The references can be found in the URL).\nAt present, a 'live vaccine strain' (LVS) tularemia vaccine is under\nInvestigational New Drug (IND) status in a protocol at the US Army Medical\nResearch Institute of Infectious Diseases (USAMRIID), Fort Detrick,\nMaryland and is available only for at-risk US military personnel. It is\nadministered by scarification (i.e., use of a bifurcated needle to produce\nmultiple inoculations in the skin, similar to vaccinia inoculation for\nsmallpox).\nThe availability of this vaccine in the USA for use beyond selected at-risk\ngroups has been hampered by several obstacles. According to Colonel David\nL. Danley, Project Manager, Joint Vaccine Acquisition Program (JVAP) at\nFort Detrick, data now required for licensure were not adequately\ndocumented during its development, prohibiting plans to license the current\nvaccine. Because the 'old method of growth using shaker culture does not\nmeet current good manufacturing processes required for FDA licensure,' the\nmanufacturing processes and potency of the current LVS vaccine are being\nre-evaluated, and 'a new process using fermentation technology will be\nused,' explained David T. Dennis, MD, MPH, Chief, Bacterial Zoonoses\nBranch, CDC.\nDespite the increased risk of a bioweapons threat felt after September\n11th, further vaccine development for tularemia remains slow. The projected\ndate of a new licensed vaccine in the USA is not until 2009.\nThe current LVS vaccine is based on research that goes back to the 1960s.\nIt is a descendant of strain 15 developed by the former Soviet Union's\nInstitute of Epidemiology and Microbiology, Gamalcia Institute, in Moscow,\nand sold to the US military in 1956 [10]. In the early 1960s, USAMRIID had\nisolated the LVS strain for preventive use in at-risk US military personnel\n[11,12]. Efficacy studies in civilian laboratory employees at Fort Detrick\nrevealed that the vaccine was safe and significantly reduced the incidence\nof typhoidal tularemia from 5.70 to 0.27 cases per 1000 at-risk\nemployee-years [13]. Although the incidence of ulceroglandular tularemia\nwas unchanged by the vaccines, the disease was found to be milder in the\nvaccine cohort. Worldwide, LVS has since been used as seed stock for\ntularemia vaccines [12].\nSeveral limitations of the current LVS tularemia vaccine indicate a need to\nmove forward on developing an improved vaccine. One limitation is the\ncurrent mode of administration, which requires scarification that is both\ncumbersome and difficult to standardize. Further limitations deal with gaps\nin understanding the factors responsible for the virulence and genetic\nstability of _F. tularensis_, as well as which antigens are needed to\nproduce an effective cell-mediated immunity. Current research shows that\nonly one of the 2 phenotypes of LVS, the blue colony type, appears to be\nimmunogenic [11,12].\nA 2nd limitation is confusion over which arm of the immune system should be\ntargeted. Although it has been thought that the humoral immune response is\nnot important in protection against tularemia, a relatively recent report\nfrom the Fort Detrick group has suggested that this may not be the case\n[14]. Pooled sera from humans immunized with LVS were found to fully\nprotect mice against a large lethal challenge of LVS organisms. New lots of\nLVS produced in the USA clearly show immunogenicity in human volunteers,\nproducing both brisk cell-mediated and humoral immune responses [15]. In\nthe future, techniques to optimize the appropriate humoral response may be\navailable.\nNew Generation Tularemia Vaccines\n----------------------------------\nStrategies for development of a new generation of vaccines include\nidentification of individual components of _F. tularensis_, such as the\nlipopolysaccharide (LPS) or various other outer surface proteins, as\npotential vaccine components (either native or recombinant). After\nidentification, these components would then be used as immunogens, instead\nof using the entire organism. In laboratory studies, some of these cell\ncomponents have been tested and found to have variable protection in mice.\nFor instance, one of the membrane proteins of the _F. tularensis_ that has\nbeen studied as a potential immunogen is a 17-kilodalton lipoprotein, TUL4.\nThe gene for this antigen has been cloned into a _Salmonella typhimurium_\nmutant [16]. In mice immunized with this recombinant vector, both humoral\nand cell-mediated immune response to the antigen developed, and mice were\nprotected from an LVS challenge.\nThe development of monoclonal antibodies for use as passively protective\nagents is another possible strategy for new vaccine development, according\nto Dr. Dennis of the CDC.\nA number of investigators are conducting basic research into tularemia,\nparticularly molecular and sequencing studies aimed at identifying proteins\nand antigens for use as vaccine candidates. Most of this research is being\nconducted at military research institutions, including USAMRIID.\nAs one would expect, since September 11th, information on manufacturers\nactively working on a new vaccine is scarce. In the USA, DynPort Vaccine\nCompany LLC was awarded a contract to develop, manufacture, test, and\nlicense an LVS vaccine from the current vaccine material, according to both\nDr. Dennis and Col. Danley at Fort Detrick. DynPort has been under contract\nto the USA Department of Defense's (DoD's) JVAP since 1997 and acts as its\nexecutive arm, says Terry Irgens, President of DynPort. Basic researchers\nfrom institutes such as USAMRIID work closely with DynPort, which employs\nover 100 scientists, physicians, and veterinarians to conduct preclinical\nand clinical testing of vaccines. Production and licensure are also managed\nby DynPort, whose contract with JVAP was recently extended to 2012. A\nproposed licensure date is June 2009, as previously mentioned [17].\nInternationally, several efforts are under way to develop new tularemia\nvaccines, but with similar limited information on manufacture and licensure\ndates. In the UK, 2 approaches to a new vaccine, use of defined attenuated\nmutants and a subunit vaccine, are in their earliest stages and are not\nanticipated for licensure in the UK for more than a decade, says Col. Danley.\nOther development efforts are being conducted in Sweden at the National\nDefense Research Establishment, University of Umea, which recently received\na 5-year grant from the US National Institutes of Health to develop a\nsubunit vaccine against aerosolized forms of _F tularensis_. In\ncollaboration with Canadian researchers, under the direction of Dr. Wayne\nConlan, Medical Research Council, Ottawa, Canada, the grant will also\ncompare the efficacy of these candidate vaccines to those of attenuated\nvaccines, said Dr. Anders Sjostedt, who heads the research group at Umea\nUniversity.\nIn Moscow, a project is under way at the Institute of Immunological\nEngineering to develop a chemical tularemia vaccine based on preparations\nof outer-membrane components of _F. tularensis_. This group is also working\non a project to develop a molecular vaccine based on LPS-protein complexes.\n[18] - Mod.LL]", "summary": "New Generation Tularemia Vaccines\n----------------------------------\nStrategies for development of a new generation of vaccines include\nidentification of individual components of _F. tularensis_, such as the\nlipopolysaccharide (LPS) or various other outer surface proteins, as\npotential vaccine components (either native or recombinant). Because the 'old method of growth using shaker culture does not\nmeet current good manufacturing processes required for FDA licensure,' the\nmanufacturing processes and potency of the current LVS vaccine are being\nre-evaluated, and 'a new process using fermentation technology will be\nused,' explained David T. Dennis, MD, MPH, Chief, Bacterial Zoonoses\nBranch, CDC. In\ncollaboration with Canadian researchers, under the direction of Dr. Wayne\nConlan, Medical Research Council, Ottawa, Canada, the grant will also\ncompare the efficacy of these candidate vaccines to those of attenuated\nvaccines, said Dr. Anders Sjostedt, who heads the research group at Umea\nUniversity. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The investigation into how 3 Boston University researchers became infected\nwith tularemia, when they thought they were working with a harmless form of\nthe germ, is increasingly focusing on the possibility that a naturally\noccurring lethal strain contaminated animal blood used to promote growth of\nthe bacteria. According to Colonel David\nL. Danley, Project Manager, Joint Vaccine Acquisition Program (JVAP) at\nFort Detrick, data now required for licensure were not adequately\ndocumented during its development, prohibiting plans to license the current\nvaccine. After 2 months of attempting to unravel the mystery, disease detectives\nhave largely eliminated the possibility that workers at BU, or at the\nNebraska lab that supplied the tularemia to Boston researchers, somehow\nmixed batches of harmless and lethal strains, according to Dr. Paul Mead,\nhead of a federal investigation into the exposure cases. [Byline: Stephen Smith and Scott Allen]\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, Ph.D.\nPDA\n At present, a 'live vaccine strain' (LVS) tularemia vaccine is under\nInvestigational New Drug (IND) status in a protocol at the US Army Medical\nResearch Institute of Infectious Diseases (USAMRIID), Fort Detrick,\nMaryland and is available only for at-risk US military personnel. In the USA, DynPort Vaccine\nCompany LLC was awarded a contract to develop, manufacture, test, and\nlicense an LVS vaccine from the current vaccine material, according to both\nDr. Dennis and Col. Danley at Fort Detrick. It wasn't until August 2004 that BU first took delivery of a vial of Type A\ntularemia, the dangerous form, from a different supplier, and that material\nwas stored in a locked freezer, separate from where the harmless strain was\nkept, said Dr. Thomas J. Moore, acting provost of BU's medical campus. Cirillo said\nthe shipment to BU marked the 1st time that Nebraska had sent its\nvaccine-research tularemia to another institution, pointing out that\nextensive federal regulations make such arrangements cumbersome. Efficacy studies in civilian laboratory employees at Fort Detrick\nrevealed that the vaccine was safe and significantly reduced the incidence\nof typhoidal tularemia from 5.70 to 0.27 cases per 1000 at-risk\nemployee-years [13]. The following discussion is taken from 'Developing New Tularemia Vaccines'\nwritten by Mary Beth Nierengarten and myself in Medscape Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewpublication/206>\nregarding tularemia vaccines. And when the 1st 2 BU\nresearchers fell ill in May 2004, there were no stocks of the dangerous\nvariety of tularemia on the school's South End medical campus, university\nofficials said. Other development efforts are being conducted in Sweden at the National\nDefense Research Establishment, University of Umea, which recently received\na 5-year grant from the US National Institutes of Health to develop a\nsubunit vaccine against aerosolized forms of _F tularensis_. Although it has been thought that the humoral immune response is\nnot important in protection against tularemia, a relatively recent report\nfrom the Fort Detrick group has suggested that this may not be the case\n But by the time a problem was identified in Boston, Barry said, the supply\nof blood that had been used in Nebraska had long since been exhausted,\nmeaning that there was nothing left for testing.\n Basic researchers\nfrom institutes such as USAMRIID work closely with DynPort, which employs\nover 100 scientists, physicians, and veterinarians to conduct preclinical\nand clinical testing of vaccines. Further limitations deal with gaps\nin understanding the factors responsible for the virulence and genetic\nstability of _F. tularensis_, as well as which antigens are needed to\nproduce an effective cell-mediated immunity. It is\nadministered by scarification (i.e., use of a bifurcated needle to produce\nmultiple inoculations in the skin, similar to vaccinia inoculation for\nsmallpox). Authorities at BU and the CDC have declined to identify the Nebraska\nsupplier, but Dr. Jeffrey Cirillo, an associate professor in the\nveterinarian and biomedical sciences department of the University of\n In the UK, 2 approaches to a new vaccine, use of defined attenuated\nmutants and a subunit vaccine, are in their earliest stages and are not\nanticipated for licensure in the UK for more than a decade, says Col. Danley. \nSeveral limitations of the current LVS tularemia vaccine indicate a need to\nmove forward on developing an improved vaccine. A number of investigators are conducting basic research into tularemia,\nparticularly molecular and sequencing studies aimed at identifying proteins\nand antigens for use as vaccine candidates. Barry said that the Nebraska lab had used rabbit blood from a farm in South\nCarolina to grow the material shipped to Boston, and rabbits are known to\nbe carriers of tularemia, which is commonly known as rabbit fever. Although the incidence of ulceroglandular tularemia\nwas unchanged by the vaccines, the disease was found to be milder in the\nvaccine cohort. The BU scientists, who were trying to develop a tularemia vaccine, were\nusing a form of the bacteria that had been modified to not cause illness.\n Internationally, several efforts are under way to develop new tularemia\nvaccines, but with similar limited information on manufacture and licensure\ndates. The development of monoclonal antibodies for use as passively protective\nagents is another possible strategy for new vaccine development, according\nto Dr. Dennis of the CDC. Knowing that the Nebraska lab did not work with the dangerous variety,\ninvestigators became increasingly curious about whether animal blood used\nroutinely to grow additional samples might have harbored Type A tularemia. Those tests showed that both the\nmodified strain and the dangerous strain were present, said Dr. Anita\nBarry, Boston's director of communicable disease control. ' Once tularemia emerged as the leading suspect in the researchers'\nillnesses, a CDC lab in Fort Collins, Colorado, USA, analyzed the material\nin the vial shipped from Nebraska to BU. This group is also working\non a project to develop a molecular vaccine based on LPS-protein complexes.\n One hypothesis is that there was an infected rabbit, and\nwhen Nebraska got the rabbit blood, it would have had Type A tularemia in\nit that nobody knew about.' USA (NYC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206846", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW YORK CITY)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 10 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.nydailynews.com/boroughs/story/251139p-215035c.html>\n\nRabbit-fever concern has officials hopping\n-----------------------------------------\nNew York City health officials are watching for a recurrence of a\npotentially deadly disease transmitted by wild rabbits that hospitalized a\nStaten Island resident this summer [2004]. After the 21-year-old woman was\ndiagnosed with pneumonia in mid-August 2004, Health Department officials\nconfirmed she had contracted tularemia, a rare disease caused by the\nbacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which infects both animals and people.\nThe woman reportedly contracted the disease -- also known as rabbit fever\n-- from her dog, after it captured an infected wild rabbit and then licked\nher on the face. The woman survived, and no other cases have since been\nreported.\nTularemia is on the list of potential biological agents that can be used by\nterrorists. As a biological weapon, tularemia-causing bacteria could be\ndispersed through the air and inhaled. Still, health officials say there is\nno reason to believe the incident is linked to terrorism.\n'This woman had [a] clear risk factor for naturally occurring tularemia,'\nsaid Health Department epidemiologist Annie Fine. 'We think it's an\nisolated case, but we're keeping our eyes open.' Despite the optimism, a\nnumber of rabbits collected for data tested positive. However, health\nofficials deny there is any evidence of risk to human beings beyond this case.\nThere are only about 100 cases reported per year in the USA, usually less\nthan 2 percent of which are fatal. Since 1965, there have been 13 other\ncases in the city; the last occurred in 1998. Cases have been reported in\nevery borough except the Bronx.\nHumans can acquire the illness by coming into contact with the blood or\nbodily fluids of infected animals, from the bite of a fly or tick that\ncarries blood from an infected animal, or from contaminated food or water.\nRabbits and rodents are the animals most likely to be infected. Signs and\nsymptoms vary but include fever, headache, chills, weakness, enlarged lymph\nnodes, or, an ulcerated sore if bitten by an infected fly or tick.\nSymptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days after exposure to the bacteria, but can\ntake as long as 14 days to manifest. The disease can be effectively treated\nwith antimicrobial agents.\n[Byline: Amy Sacks]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although not thought of in association with an urban environment,\ntularemia (a category B bio-terrorism disease) is occasionally acquired\nnaturally in New York. Primary pneumonia, due to _F. tularensis_, is\nusually transmitted by aerosol as shown by the landscaper cases on Martha's\nVineyard, MA, USA. Upper respiratory infection manifesting as a pharyngitis\ncan occur with inoculation at that site. There is no information regarding\nwhether this young woman had a pharyngitis as well.\nDespite a low inoculum needed to cause pneumonic tularemia, human-to-human\ncases are not generally recognized. In pneumonic plague, however, this form\nof transmission is of major concern.\nThe last case of reported infection in New York City was in the borough of\nBrooklyn in 1998 (see below), a fatal case of pneumonia diagnosed by\npositive blood culture after the person had died. Of note, this case was\nreported to ProMED-mail by this moderator, which was his 1st contact with\nthis often real-time reporting system. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n After the 21-year-old woman was\ndiagnosed with pneumonia in mid-August 2004, Health Department officials\nconfirmed she had contracted tularemia, a rare disease caused by the\nbacterium _Francisella tularensis_, which infects both animals and people. [Byline: Amy Sacks]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< The woman reportedly contracted the disease -- also known as rabbit fever\n-- from her dog, after it captured an infected wild rabbit and then licked\nher on the face. The last case of reported infection in New York City was in the borough of\nBrooklyn in 1998 (see below), a fatal case of pneumonia diagnosed by\npositive blood culture after the person had died. Humans can acquire the illness by coming into contact with the blood or\nbodily fluids of infected animals, from the bite of a fly or tick that\ncarries blood from an infected animal, or from contaminated food or water. New York City health officials are watching for a recurrence of a\npotentially deadly disease transmitted by wild rabbits that hospitalized a\nStaten Island resident this summer [2004]. Signs and\nsymptoms vary but include fever, headache, chills, weakness, enlarged lymph\nnodes, or, an ulcerated sore if bitten by an infected fly or tick. Of note, this case was\nreported to ProMED-mail by this moderator, which was his 1st contact with\nthis often real-time reporting system. [Although not thought of in association with an urban environment,\ntularemia (a category B bio-terrorism disease) is occasionally acquired\nnaturally in New York. Primary pneumonia, due to _F. tularensis_, is\nusually transmitted by aerosol as shown by the landscaper cases on Martha's\nVineyard, MA, USA. Source: New York Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.nydailynews.com/boroughs/story/251139p-215035c.html>\n\nRabbit-fever concern has officials hopping\n \nTularemia is on the list of potential biological agents that can be used by\nterrorists.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1965-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206107", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, landscaper - USA (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206107", "date": "2004-07-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, LANDSCAPER - USA (MASSACHUSETTS)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 13 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CapeCodOnline [edited]\n<http://www.capecodonline.com/cctimes/tularemiaxz13.htm>\n\nTularemia 'probable' on Vineyard again\n-----------------------------------------\nThe confirmation by state health officials this week [week of Mon 12 Jul\n2004] of a Tisbury landscaper's 'probable case' of tularemia, or 'rabbit\nfever,' means that the potentially deadly bacterial disease has struck on\nMartha's Vineyard for the 5th straight summer. The persistence of the\nillness on the island has scientists baffled and locals on alert. 'It's\nhigh on everyone's radar screen over there, which is good,' said state\nhealth department veterinarian, Dr. Frederic Cantor.\nThe landscaper, who was sick earlier this summer [2004], and has since\nfully recovered, had the characteristic high fever and cough associated\nwith the illness, but, was never sick enough to be admitted to the\nhospital. He was treated with antimicrobial agents and has had no other\nproblems, Cantor said.\nTularemia can be contracted either through a bite by an infected dog tick,\nby inhaling the highly infectious [organisms] from an infected animal, or,\nthrough contact with the bacteria through an open cut or sore. The version\nof the illness transmitted through a tick bite, or through an open sore,\ncreates a lesion on the skin, and, can also lead to swollen lymph nodes and\nflu-like symptoms. The inhaled version, which is a bioterrorism concern,\ncauses a pneumonia-like condition that is more dangerous than the skin\nversion, Cantor said. Untreated, about 7 percent of victims die.\nIn August 2000, a Chilmark resident died of the pneumonic form of\ntularemia. 10 other cases were successfully treated that summer. In 2001, 3\npeople, including a 4-year-old Newton boy, who was bitten by a tick,\n[apparently on Martha's Vineyard - Mod.LL], came down with the disease,\nand, later recovered. 2 cases were reported in 2002, and last year [2003],\nthere were 4 cases. Prior to 2000, Martha's Vineyard had not had an\noutbreak since 1978, when 12 people were stricken.\nNo cases have been reported on Cape Cod, or Nantucket, in recent years, a\nfact that has mystified some scientists who are now trying to figure out\nwhy Martha's Vineyard is so hospitable to the disease. In 2001, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta conducted a study in which\n230 island residents were tested for tularemia antibodies, which the body\nproduces in the presence of the disease. Blood samples from 100 of the\nresidents who were not landscapers were taken, and all came back negative.\nBut, when 130 landscapers were tested, 9 percent tested positive for the\nantibodies. None had been diagnosed with the disease, leading researchers\nto believe that they had either fought the illness off without medication,\nor, were being treated with antimicrobial agents for another reason when\nthey contracted it, according to Martha's Vineyard Hospital infectious\ndisease specialist Dr. Dennis Hoak.\nThe research led health officials to surmise that landscapers were\ncontracting the illness when they mowed over carcasses of infected rodents.\nVineyard landscapers now commonly use masks while mowing, Cantor said.\nFor the last 3 summers, Tufts University associate professor of infectious\ndisease, Sam Telford, has spent 3 days each month trapping small rodents to\nsee what kinds of ticks they are carrying, and, whether they are carrying\nany disease. While rabbits are thought to be primary vectors of air-borne\ntularemia, his research does not yet support that theory.\n'Rabbits die within 7 days of getting tularemia. Their population (on the\nisland) has crashed, yet tularemia persists,' he said. The notion that\nlandscapers are kicking up disease [organisms] from dead animals when they\nmow over them is also in dispute, he said.\n'In talking to the landscapers, these guys are outside all the time, and\nthey say 'we walk the properties first. Something as big as a (dead)\nrabbit, we would notice.''\nDog ticks appear to be a critical link in keeping tularemia in an\nenvironment, Telford said. They are found throughout the island, and,\nunlike the smaller deer tick, which dies in the dryness and heat of a beach\nenvironment, they can thrive in the dune grass, and, even on the beach, he\nsaid. He and his staff have found that tularemia is found in ticks in\nspecific areas of Martha's Vineyard.\n[Byline: Robin Lord]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The significance of this posting is not that the 1st case of tularemia --\na category A bioterrorism infection -- has occurred on Martha's Vineyard in\n2004, but, rather, that the tick, instead of the rabbit, may be the\ntransmitter. Since pneumonic tularemia seems to be the common presentation\non the island (rather than the ulceroglandular form), perhaps the\naerosolization of lawn-mower-minced Dermacentor ticks is involved in\ntransmission. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n None had been diagnosed with the disease, leading researchers\nto believe that they had either fought the illness off without medication,\nor, were being treated with antimicrobial agents for another reason when\nthey contracted it, according to Martha's Vineyard Hospital infectious\ndisease specialist Dr. Dennis Hoak. The confirmation by state health officials this week [week of Mon 12 Jul\n2004] of a Tisbury landscaper's 'probable case' of tularemia, or 'rabbit\nfever,' means that the potentially deadly bacterial disease has struck on\n In 2001, the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta conducted a study in which\n230 island residents were tested for tularemia antibodies, which the body\nproduces in the presence of the disease. For the last 3 summers, Tufts University associate professor of infectious\ndisease, Sam Telford, has spent 3 days each month trapping small rodents to\nsee what kinds of ticks they are carrying, and, whether they are carrying\nany disease. \nTularemia can be contracted either through a bite by an infected dog tick,\nby inhaling the highly infectious [organisms] from an infected animal, or,\nthrough contact with the bacteria through an open cut or sore. [The significance of this posting is not that the 1st case of tularemia --\na category A bioterrorism infection -- has occurred on Martha's Vineyard in\n2004, but, rather, that the tick, instead of the rabbit, may be the\ntransmitter. They are found throughout the island, and,\nunlike the smaller deer tick, which dies in the dryness and heat of a beach\nenvironment, they can thrive in the dune grass, and, even on the beach, he\nsaid. The version\nof the illness transmitted through a tick bite, or through an open sore,\ncreates a lesion on the skin, and, can also lead to swollen lymph nodes and\nflu-like symptoms. Since pneumonic tularemia seems to be the common presentation\non the island (rather than the ulceroglandular form), perhaps the\naerosolization of lawn-mower-minced Dermacentor ticks is involved in\ntransmission. The landscaper, who was sick earlier this summer [2004], and has since\nfully recovered, had the characteristic high fever and cough associated\nwith the illness, but, was never sick enough to be admitted to the\nhospital. [Byline: Robin Lord]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< The notion that\nlandscapers are kicking up disease [organisms] from dead animals when they\nmow over them is also in dispute, he said. The inhaled version, which is a bioterrorism concern,\ncauses a pneumonia-like condition that is more dangerous than the skin\nversion, Cantor said. No cases have been reported on Cape Cod, or Nantucket, in recent years, a\nfact that has mystified some scientists who are now trying to figure out\nwhy Martha's Vineyard is so hospitable to the disease. He and his staff have found that tularemia is found in ticks in\nspecific areas of Martha's Vineyard.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-08-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "1978-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Newton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nantucket", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204490", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, human - USA (Wyoming)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204490", "date": "2003-09-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN - USA (WYOMING)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 2 Sep 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Rock Springs (WY, USA) Daily Rocket-Miner / Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.trib.com/AP/wire_detail.php?wire_num=173759>\n\nYoung girl diagnosed with tularemia\n-----------------------------------\nAn 18 month old girl suffered swollen glands, lethargy, and a fever after\nbeing bitten by an insect. For days, local doctors tried to help the girl,\nbut were unable to identify the problem. Finally, the child was taken to\nPrimary Children's Hospital in Salt Lake City, where she was diagnosed with\nthe potentially fatal disease, tularemia.\nSweetwater County Health Department public health nurse Jodye Wilmes said\ngenerally there are usually 2 to 6 tularemia cases reported a year, mainly\nby adult men. A child contracting the disease is unusual.\nThe rarity of the disease led doctors at the Memorial Hospital of\nSweetwater County to diagnose the symptoms as [resulting from] a bite from\na brown recluse spider. Only after the girl was admitted to the Primary\nChildren's Hospital did they diagnose her with tularemia, contracted from a\ndeerfly bite.\nThe girl's mother said that on the first day, the bite just looked like a\nswollen mosquito bite. Over the next few days the bite crusted over, turned\nwhite from pus, then began to turn black. The child's other symptoms\nincluded swollen lymph nodes and lethargy. The child would sweat profusely\nwhen she didn't have a fever, and with a fever wouldn't sweat at all.\nThe form of the infection involving skin ulcers and lymph node enlargement\nis usually acquired by bites by a deer fly or tick or from skinning a\nrabbit. Tularemia pneumonia can be acquired from inhaling the organism from\nthe soil when it is aerosolized by lawn mowing. Tularemia is not contagious\nfrom person to person.\nThere are several ways to help prevent the disease. When outside, people\nshould wear protective clothing such as boots, insect repellent, and long\nclothing. When skinning a rabbit, wear rubber gloves and be sure to cook\nall animals thoroughly.\n[byline: Adam Esquibel]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This so-far isolated case of ulceroglandular tularemia could have been due\nto either a deer fly or tick bite. It is important not to ignore infection\ndue to _Francisella tularensis_ in the differential diagnosis of an illness\nwith a local skin lesion, as occurred early in this case. Respiratory\ndisease due to tularemia is the form one might expect if the bacillus is\naerosolized in a bioterrorist event, but it certainly occurs naturally, as\nseen in the Martha's Vineyard cases referenced below. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Respiratory\ndisease due to tularemia is the form one might expect if the bacillus is\naerosolized in a bioterrorist event, but it certainly occurs naturally, as\nseen in the Martha's Vineyard cases referenced below. [byline: Adam Esquibel]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< The form of the infection involving skin ulcers and lymph node enlargement\nis usually acquired by bites by a deer fly or tick or from skinning a\nrabbit. Sweetwater County Health Department public health nurse Jodye Wilmes said\ngenerally there are usually 2 to 6 tularemia cases reported a year, mainly\nby adult men. The rarity of the disease led doctors at the Memorial Hospital of\nSweetwater County to diagnose the symptoms as [resulting from] a bite from\na brown recluse spider. Only after the girl was admitted to the Primary\nChildren's Hospital did they diagnose her with tularemia, contracted from a\ndeerfly bite. Finally, the child was taken to\nPrimary Children's Hospital in Salt Lake City, where she was diagnosed with\nthe potentially fatal disease, tularemia. It is important not to ignore infection\ndue to _Francisella tularensis_ in the differential diagnosis of an illness\nwith a local skin lesion, as occurred early in this case. Source: Rock Springs (WY, USA) Daily Rocket-Miner / Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.trib.com/AP/wire_detail.php?wire_num=173759>\n\nYoung girl diagnosed with tularemia\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-09-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Salt Lake City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rock Springs", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204768", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, air sensor detection - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204768", "date": "2003-10-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, AIR SENSOR DETECTION - USA (TEXAS)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu, 9 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Houston Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.ci.houston.tx.us/departme/health/bacteria%20detection.htm>\n\n\nOfficials Following Up on Bacteria Detection\n---------------------------------------------\nCity and county health officials are following up on the detection by\nair sensors of low levels of parts [probably DNA fragments. -\nMod.JW] of the bacterium that causes tularemia, a treatable illness\noccasionally found in humans but more common in rabbits and\nrodents.\n\nHealth officials said that though the bacteria are found naturally in\nthe environment, precautionary measures are being taken to\ndetermine whether there have been any human cases of tularemia,\ncommonly known as rabbit fever, in the area. So far none have\nbeen found. Low levels of the organism were detected by\nlaboratory tests done on filters taken from special air monitors on\nSat, Sun and Mon, 4-6 Oct 2003. However, filters tested from the 2\nfollowing days were negative.\n\n'The new technology in use throughout Houston and Harris County\ngives us information that was not previously knowable. We are\ninvestigating to determine whether the bacteria were always\npresent or newly present and whether they represent a health\nthreat to the community,' said M. desVignes-Kendrick, MD, MPH,\nDirector of the Houston Department of Health and Human\nServices.\n\nPrecautionary measures being taken by the City of Houston's\nHealth and Human Services Department and Harris County Public\nHealth and Environmental Services include increased surveillance\nfor human illness, additional environmental sampling, collection and\ntesting of wild rabbits and rodents, and an assessment of activities\nin the area that may have caused the sensors to pick up the\norganism. Officials are concentrating on an area of Houston and\nHarris County from Greens Bayou on the east, the Houston Ship\nChannel on the south, and the Hardy Toll Road on the west.\n\n'The Harris County and Houston health departments are pooling\nresources and expertise to investigate the potential impact of the\nfindings. We greatly appreciate the ongoing collaboration and\nsupport we receive from our partners in the local medical\ncommunity and local, state, and federal agencies,' says Herminia\nPalacio, MD, MPH, Executive Director of Harris County Public\nHealth and Environmental Services.\n\nThe air sensors are part of a nationwide BioWatch system\ninaugurated in March 2003 to monitor for intentionally released\nbacterial agents but may detect naturally occurring organisms.\n\nHealth officials say there is nothing to indicate an intentional\nrelease of the organism but that the investigation is continuing to\nsee whether a naturally occurring explanation for the sensor\ndetection can be identified.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although neither human cases nor an animal outbreak are reported\nhere, it seems noteworthy, as this is likely to be only one of many\nreports regarding the use of air sensing hardware to detect\nevidence of infections classified as potential biological warfare\nagents such as the tularemia bacillus. The BioWatch program is\nsummarized in the article below. - Mod.LL]\n\nBioWatch program aims for nationwide detection of airborne\npathogens\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/biowatch.html>\n-------------------\n26 Feb 2003 (CIDRAP News) - Typical predictions about what\nwould happen in a bioterrorist attack with airborne germs say that\nno one would know about it until a number of people with similar\nsymptoms starting showing up in clinics and emergency rooms. But\nthe federal government is hoping to change that scenario with its\nnew nationwide program to sniff the air for dangerous pathogens.\nThe 'BioWatch' program is an ambitious effort to sample the air in\nmajor metropolitan areas daily for pathogens that terrorists might\nuse, according to federal officials. Testing equipment is being set\nup in 20 metropolitan areas, according to a Department of Health\nand Human Services (HHS) public relations spokesman in\nWashington, DC. An air monitoring program used during the 2002\nWinter Olympics in Salt Lake City was the prototype for the system.\n\n'The ultimate goal is to deploy these in various cities so that 80\npercent of the American population by geographic distribution will be\nliving in areas that will be covered by this equipment,' the HHS\nspokesman, who asked that his name be withheld, told CIDRAP\nNews. The system involves the installation of special paper filters\non existing Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) air-quality\nmonitoring stations, the spokesman said. Plans call for removing\neach filter every day, taking it to a laboratory, and using a\npolymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis to test it for pathogens\nthat terrorists might use.\n\n'Early detection is the key to getting a jump on a biological\nincident,' said the HHS official. 'They'll be collecting these\nfilters daily, 7 days a week.' He said that from the time a filter\nreaches the lab for analysis, it will take from 3 to 8 hours to rule\nout pathogens or identify one, depending on what it is.\n\nFederal officials say the initial focus of the monitoring includes a\nshort list of agents that terrorists are considered likely to use. The\nHHS spokesman said the laboratories involved, all part of the\nCDC's Laboratory Response Network, can test for a wide variety\nof pathogens, and different labs might look for additional\npathogens. Each urban area will have 10 to 12 air monitoring\nstations, the HHS spokesman said. He said 40 million dollars have\nbeen earmarked for the program for fiscal year 2003, enough\nmoney to deploy the sampling equipment in the 20 cities and cover\nsome additional expenses.\n\nOfficials involved with BioWatch acknowledge that the system's\nexistence prompts tough questions about what to do when\npathogens are found. How will authorities know if a positive finding\nis a true-positive? If it is a true-positive, how can analysts assess\nwhether it represents an isolated natural event or a terrorist attack?\nAnd if the finding does seem to represent an attack, how should\nauthorities respond?\n\nWhile offering few details, the HHS spokesman said authorities in\nthe various cities are working on plans for responding to any\nfindings that indicate a real danger. 'In each of the local\nmetropolitan areas they've set up a working group with the local FBI\noffice and they're working on a game plan on how they're going to\nhandle the analysis that comes out of the system. Each of the\nareas is going to be doing some tabletop exercises to practice how\nthey'll handle it when they get results they need to act on.'\n\nThe public health laboratory director in one of the states affected\nsaid the possibility of false-positives is a big concern. 'When we\napply these kinds of tests, we'd like to be able to culture the\norganisms as well,' to confirm any positive results, he said. But this\nisn't a good option because the air sampling units use high-speed\nairflow that would tend to kill most organisms through shearing\nforces and drying, he said. Spore-forming organisms [such as\nanthrax. - - Mod.JW] would probably survive, but most others would\nnot, he said.\n\nAlso complicating the picture is the natural occurrence in some\nareas of pathogens that terrorists might use. A positive test result\nmight be accurate without being evidence of a real problem. 'A lot of\nfactors would have to be taken into consideration' in interpreting a\nfinding, the laboratory director said.'The last thing you'd want to\nhappen would be to put out a false alarm.'\n\nThe air monitoring program during the 2002 Winter Olympics\n[produced] one episode that gave a preview of the kinds of\nquestions that can arise, according to Scott Williams, MD, deputy\ndirector of the Utah Department of Health. Williams said the\nprogram involved 15 to 20 monitoring stations scattered over a\nlarge area centered on Salt Lake City. The filters were removed\nevery 4 hours and tested for the presence of pathogens in the\nCDC's category A. The lab analysis began with a screen for a\nsingle strand of DNA, he explained. If that test was positive, a\nsecond single-strand test was done; a second positive finding\nprompted a confirmatory test looking for 4 different DNA strands.\nThe lab analysis was handled by the US Department of Energy\n(DOE), which developed the special PCR tests involved.\n\n'There was one event that created sort of an initial posturing of\nresponse,' Williams said. On 12 Feb 2002, a sample collected at\nthe airport came up positive on more than one single-strand test.\n'We alerted the airport that they may need to evacuate,' he said.\nBut officials decided to wait for the confirmatory test before taking\nthat step. That turned out to be the right move, because the\nconfirmatory test showed that the microbe was a cross-reacting\norganism, a nonpathogenic one with a DNA strand that matched a\nstrand in one of the pathogens being sought, Williams said.\n(Officials never were able to identify the organism; it was assumed\nto be 'just an endemic organism that happened to share that single\nstrand,' he noted.)\n\nBefore the alarm was called off, the airport started preparing to\nclose, and hazardous-materials teams were suiting up for possible\nduty, Williams said. 'It was interesting because it created all of the\nscientific and political response processes. . . . It was the most\nrealistic tabletop exercise you could have conducted.'\n\nWilliams said Utah health officials took some lessons from the\nepisode. In the interest of quicker confirmation or rejection of\npositive test results, 'We recommended to DOE that they change\nthe [PCR testing] process so that they always run the 4-strand\nconfirmatory test simultaneously with the 2nd single-strand test.'\n\nThe event also pointed up the importance of tabletop exercises\nsimulating this type of scenario. 'We did a lot of tabletop exercises\nbefore the Olympics, but we never specifically mock-exercised the\nair monitoring event,' Williams said. 'We were able to create a\ngood decision process as we went, but it wasn't as comfortable as it\ncould've been.'\n\nAlso, even with careful planning, potential threat situations\ninevitably involve people who never participate in tabletop\nexercises, he added. 'So we realized that what you need is a very\nrapid briefing process for these people, so they're not trying to\nfigure out what you're talking about while they're trying to make a\ndecision about whether to close the airport.'\n\nHHS and the CDC are the lead agencies on the BioWatch\nprogram because it's a bioterrorism issue, according to the HHS\nspokesman. 'But we couldn't have done it without the DOE's\nassistance with the filters and the testing, and EPA has been key in\ngetting it set up and collecting the filters,' he said.\n\n'It's going to be very labor-intensive,' the laboratory director said\nin describing the effort. 'It'll also be very routine, until you get a\npositive.'\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The principal means of transmission of tularemia is by the bite of a\ntick infected from a wildlife reservoir. Rabbit & rodent hunters also\ncontract it when skinning wildlife. As far as is presently known,\nnatural aerosol spread occurs only in dust from fodder, grain or\nwool contaminated with rodent excreta (Acha & Szyfres 1994, 2nd\nedn., Zoonoses and communicable diseases common to man and\nanimals). - Mod.JW]", "summary": "\n\nPrecautionary measures being taken by the City of Houston's\nHealth and Human Services Department and Harris County Public\nHealth and Environmental Services include increased surveillance\nfor human illness, additional environmental sampling, collection and\ntesting of wild rabbits and rodents, and an assessment of activities\nin the area that may have caused the sensors to pick up the\norganism. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu, 9 Oct 2003\n We are\ninvestigating to determine whether the bacteria were always\npresent or newly present and whether they represent a health\nthreat to the community,' said M. desVignes-Kendrick, MD, MPH,\nDirector of the Houston Department of Health and Human\nServices. The\nHHS spokesman said the laboratories involved, all part of the\nCDC's Laboratory Response Network, can test for a wide variety\nof pathogens, and different labs might look for additional\npathogens. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although neither human cases nor an animal outbreak are reported\nhere, it seems noteworthy, as this is likely to be only one of many\nreports regarding the use of air sensing hardware to detect\nevidence of infections classified as potential biological warfare\nagents such as the tularemia bacillus. \n\n'The ultimate goal is to deploy these in various cities so that 80\npercent of the American population by geographic distribution will be\nliving in areas that will be covered by this equipment,' the HHS\nspokesman, who asked that his name be withheld, told CIDRAP\nNews. We greatly appreciate the ongoing collaboration and\nsupport we receive from our partners in the local medical\ncommunity and local, state, and federal agencies,' says Herminia\nPalacio, MD, MPH, Executive Director of Harris County Public\nHealth and Environmental Services. \n\nHealth officials said that though the bacteria are found naturally in\nthe environment, precautionary measures are being taken to\ndetermine whether there have been any human cases of tularemia,\ncommonly known as rabbit fever, in the area. In the interest of quicker confirmation or rejection of\npositive test results, 'We recommended to DOE that they change\nthe [PCR testing] process so that they always run the 4-strand\nconfirmatory test simultaneously with the 2nd single-strand test.' \n\nThe air monitoring program during the 2002 Winter Olympics\n[produced] one episode that gave a preview of the kinds of\nquestions that can arise, according to Scott Williams, MD, deputy\ndirector of the Utah Department of Health. But this\nisn't a good option because the air sampling units use high-speed\nairflow that would tend to kill most organisms through shearing\nforces and drying, he said. LL]\n\nBioWatch program aims for nationwide detection of airborne\npathogens\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/biowatch.html>\n Plans call for removing\neach filter every day, taking it to a laboratory, and using a\npolymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis to test it for pathogens\nthat terrorists might use.
