It'll also be very routine, until you get a\npositive.'\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Testing equipment is being set\nup in 20 metropolitan areas, according to a Department of Health\nand Human Services (HHS) public relations spokesman in\nWashington, DC. 26 Feb 2003 (CIDRAP News) - Typical predictions about what\nwould happen in a bioterrorist attack with airborne germs say that\nno one would know about it until a number of people with similar\nsymptoms starting showing up in clinics and emergency rooms. So we realized that what you need is a very\nrapid briefing process for these people, so they're not trying to\nfigure out what you're talking about while they're trying to make a\ndecision about whether to close the airport.' As far as is presently known,\nnatural aerosol spread occurs only in dust from fodder, grain or\nwool contaminated with rodent excreta (Acha & Szyfres 1994, 2nd\nedn. If that test was positive, a\nsecond single-strand test was done; a second positive finding\nprompted a confirmatory test looking for 4 different DNA strands. \n\nWhile offering few details, the HHS spokesman said authorities in\nthe various cities are working on plans for responding to any\nfindings that indicate a real danger. ' The 'BioWatch' program is an ambitious effort to sample the air in\nmajor metropolitan areas daily for pathogens that terrorists might\nuse, according to federal officials. \n\nThe air sensors are part of a nationwide BioWatch system\ninaugurated in March 2003 to monitor for intentionally released\nbacterial agents but may detect naturally occurring organisms. The system involves the installation of special paper filters\non existing Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) air-quality\nmonitoring stations, the spokesman said. \n\nBefore the alarm was called off, the airport started preparing to\nclose, and hazardous-materials teams were suiting up for possible\nduty, Williams said. ' \n\nOfficials involved with BioWatch acknowledge that the system's\nexistence prompts tough questions about what to do when\npathogens are found. We did a lot of tabletop exercises\nbefore the Olympics, but we never specifically mock-exercised the\nair monitoring event,' Williams said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-02-12 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-02-26 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Salt Lake City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Harris County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zoonoses", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Houston", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206697", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, hamsters - Canada: alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206697", "date": "2004-10-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HAMSTERS - CANADA: ALERT\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org/>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org/>http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 7 Oct 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: medical news today.com [edited]\n<http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/medicalnews.php?newsid=14416>\n\nBeware of regular or pigmy hamsters, Canadian health authority warns\n------------------------------------\nThe Public Health Agency of Canada is advising Canadians in British\nColumbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, and north western Ontario who\nhave purchased a dwarf/pigmy or regular hamster in the past 3 months of a\npotential health concern.\nIll hamsters from a pet distributor in Manitoba have tested positive for\ntype B tularemia. It is a rare and usually mild disease in humans that can\nbe treated with antibiotics. In rare cases, some forms of tularemia can be\nfatal. The purpose of this advisory notice is to ask people who have\npurchased a hamster in the past 3 months to contact their health care\nprovider if both they and their hamster have experienced illness.\n'We believe the risk to human health is low, but if people have sick\nhamsters and are feeling ill themselves, we want them to advise their\nhealth care provider,' explained Dr David Butler-Jones, the chief public\nhealth officer of Canada.\nIll hamsters, along with other small mammals (chinchillas, guinea pigs,\ngerbils, degues) that were included in shipments with the hamsters, were\nsent to pet stores in British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba,\nand north western Ontario. At present, there is no indication of illness in\nthe other animals.\nThe British Columbia Centre for Disease Control, Alberta Health and\nWellness, Saskatchewan Health, Manitoba Health, the Ontario Minister of\nHealth and Long-term Care, and the Public Health Agency of Canada are\nworking together closely on this investigation.\nTularemia, a bacterial disease, is found naturally in wild animals,\nparticularly rodents. Human tularemia disease is rare and is not known to\nspread from person to person. Tularemia is usually transmitted by contact\nwith infected animals or their cages/immediate environment. This means:\n- being bitten or licked by the animal,\n- handling or cleaning the animal, its toys, cage and feeding equipment,\n- breathing in air contaminated with the bacteria, or\n- eating or drinking contaminated food or water.\nSymptoms of tularemia may include ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen\nglands and painful lymph glands, sudden fever, chills, headache, diarrhea,\nmuscle aches, dry cough, progressive weakness, joint pain, sore throat and\nswollen and painful eyes. Symptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days after\nexposure to the bacteria but can take as long as 14 days to appear.\nIf your hamster appears sick or dies, and within 14 days you also feel ill,\nsee your health care provider. Be sure to let your health care provider\nknow why you think you may have been in contact with tularemia. Advise your\nhealth care provider to speak with your local or regional public health\noffice.\nPet stores should closely monitor their hamsters and notify their local\nveterinarian if they observe illness and higher than usual mortality.\nWhen handling sick or dead animals or items from their environment (cages,\ntoys, dishes), wear gloves made of rubber, latex, or other waterproof\nmaterial. Commercially available dishwashing gloves that have no tears are\nadequate.\nRemember to wash your hands thoroughly with warm water and soap or an\nalcohol hand gel after removing your gloves and after every contact with\nthe sick animal or its environment. If your hamster dies, you should\ndouble-bag it and dispose of it in the garbage or bury it deep enough (1\nmetre) that it will not be dug up by other animals.\nThe cage and animal accessories should be washed in hot soapy water using\nany commercially available household disinfectant. Rinse the cage in a 10\nper cent bleach solution (one part household bleach, 9 parts water). Let\nthe cage air dry for at least 10 minutes. A 70 per cent solution of alcohol\ncan then be used to further clean the area and reduce the corrosive action\nof the bleach. Consult your pet store before using the cage for another\nanimal. [Consulting your veterinarian prior to using the cage may be a more\ninformed approach. Pet stores may not be aware of which animals may\ncontract tularemia, if you use the cage for some other type of animal. -\nMod.TG]\nEquipment, including cages and toys, can be disposed of in regular\nhousehold waste. All the items should be cleaned using the procedure\ndescribed above before disposal. When handling litter, if possible, wear a\nmask. Wrap contaminated litter in plastic prior to disposal. Do not attempt\nto disinfect the litter. After handling animals, or after being licked or\nbitten by a household pet, be sure to always wash your hands thoroughly\nwith warm water and soap or an alcohol gel. The same should be done after\nhandling pet toys or cleaning bowls or cages used by animals. Hand washing\nis the best way to prevent the spread of disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n['Pocket pets,' which also include small animals such as hamsters, gerbils,\nrats, mice, guinea pigs, and rabbits, are also means of transmission of\ndiseases to other animals. Cats and prairie dogs are sensitive to tularemia.\n_Francisella tularensis_, the causative agent of tularemia, is an\nintercellular bacterial pathogen that can affect a wide range of animals\nincluding small mammals, birds, and humans. The organism is spread to\npeople from insect bites, direct contact from skinning a wild rabbit, or by\neating improperly cooked meat. Incidence of the disease follows a bimodal\ncycle, with higher numbers of humans infected in July due to ticks and in\nDecember due to the hunting season. Inhalation exposure can occur if large\nnumbers of the organism are aerosolized in a confined space.\nClinical signs in animals include high fever, weight loss, and possibly\ndeath. - Mod.TG\n_F. tularensis_ can be divided into two clinically significant subspecies,\nF. tularensis tularensis (also known as type A or subspecies nearctica) and\nF. tularensis holarctica (also known as type B or subspecies\npalaearctica). Other much less clinically relevant subspecies are also\ndescribed.\nType A appears to be the most prominent type in North America, primarily\nendemic in rabbits, and was involved in the Martha's Vineyard pneumonic\ntularemia outbreaks. The infectious dose to produce infection in humans to\ncause moderately severe disease is as few as 50 bacilli and it is lethal to\nguinea pigs and rabbits.\nType B is found in Europe and Asia but also in North America. The\nreservoirs include rodents, voles, muskrats and beavers. An infectious\ndose of 12 000 bacilli is much more likely to produce only mild,\nself-limited disease in humans. It is not lethal in rabbits and guinea\npigs. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "This means:\n- being bitten or licked by the animal,\n- handling or cleaning the animal, its toys, cage and feeding equipment,\n- breathing in air contaminated with the bacteria, or\n- eating or drinking contaminated food or water. TG\n_F. tularensis_ can be divided into two clinically significant subspecies,\nF. tularensis tularensis (also known as type A or subspecies nearctica) and\nF. tularensis holarctica (also known as type B or subspecies\npalaearctica). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org/>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org/>http://www.isid.org The British Columbia Centre for Disease Control, Alberta Health and\nWellness, Saskatchewan Health, Manitoba Health, the Ontario Minister of\nHealth and Long-term Care, and the Public Health Agency of Canada are\nworking together closely on this investigation. We believe the risk to human health is low, but if people have sick\nhamsters and are feeling ill themselves, we want them to advise their\nhealth care provider,' explained Dr David Butler-Jones, the chief public\nhealth officer of Canada. The Public Health Agency of Canada is advising Canadians in British\nColumbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, and north western Ontario who\nhave purchased a dwarf/pigmy or regular hamster in the past 3 months of a\npotential health concern. Ill hamsters, along with other small mammals (chinchillas, guinea pigs,\ngerbils, degues) that were included in shipments with the hamsters, were\nsent to pet stores in British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba,\nand north western Ontario. \n_Francisella tularensis_, the causative agent of tularemia, is an\nintercellular bacterial pathogen that can affect a wide range of animals\nincluding small mammals, birds, and humans. Symptoms of tularemia may include ulcers on the skin or mouth, swollen\nglands and painful lymph glands, sudden fever, chills, headache, diarrhea,\nmuscle aches, dry cough, progressive weakness, joint pain, sore throat and\nswollen and painful eyes. ['Pocket pets,' which also include small animals such as hamsters, gerbils,\nrats, mice, guinea pigs, and rabbits, are also means of transmission of\ndiseases to other animals. The purpose of this advisory notice is to ask people who have\npurchased a hamster in the past 3 months to contact their health care\nprovider if both they and their hamster have experienced illness. After handling animals, or after being licked or\nbitten by a household pet, be sure to always wash your hands thoroughly\nwith warm water and soap or an alcohol gel. When handling sick or dead animals or items from their environment (cages,\ntoys, dishes), wear gloves made of rubber, latex, or other waterproof\nmaterial. Remember to wash your hands thoroughly with warm water and soap or an\nalcohol hand gel after removing your gloves and after every contact with\nthe sick animal or its environment. The infectious dose to produce infection in humans to\ncause moderately severe disease is as few as 50 bacilli and it is lethal to\nguinea pigs and rabbits. \nTularemia, a bacterial disease, is found naturally in wild animals,\nparticularly rodents. Advise your\nhealth care provider to speak with your local or regional public health\noffice. Type A appears to be the most prominent type in North America, primarily\nendemic in rabbits, and was involved in the Martha's Vineyard pneumonic\ntularemia outbreaks. Source: medical news today.com [edited]\n<http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/medicalnews.php?newsid=14416>\n\nBeware of regular or pigmy hamsters, Canadian health authority warns\n If your hamster dies, you should\ndouble-bag it and dispose of it in the garbage or bury it deep enough (1\nmetre) that it will not be dug up by other animals. An infectious\ndose of 12 000 bacilli is much more likely to produce only mild,\nself-limited disease in humans. The organism is spread to\npeople from insect bites, direct contact from skinning a wild rabbit, or by\neating improperly cooked meat. Incidence of the disease follows a bimodal\ncycle, with higher numbers of humans infected in July due to ticks and in\nDecember due to the hunting season. TG]\nEquipment, including cages and toys, can be disposed of in regular\nhousehold waste.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "British Columbia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manitoba Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Alberta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204363", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, tick - USA (San Diego): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204363", "date": "2003-08-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, TICK - USA (SAN DIEGO): ALERT\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 14 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail promed@promedmail.org\nSource: Signs on San Diego.com 31 Jul 2003 [edited]\n\nTick with rabbit fever found in East County\n--------------------------------------------\nA tick infected with a potentially fatal disease called tularemia was found\nin the East County, according to the county Department of Environmental\nHealth.\nThe tick was found on a dog just south of Mount Helix County Park, said\nPatricia Cawthon, the county's acting chief of community health. It's the\nfirst discovery on a canine in at least 20 years.\nTularemia, commonly known as rabbit fever, is primarily transmitted by\nticks and biting flies, Cawthon said. The disease causes sudden fever, an\nulcer at the site of a bite, and swollen, painful lymph nodes. Antibiotics\ncan be used to treat the disease easily, 'but it has to be diagnosed,'\nCawthon said. It cannot be transmitted between humans, Cawthon said.\nSigns have been posted in the area where the tick was found to warn\nresidents about the danger of contracting the disease from insects.\nTularemia was found in 2 wild rabbits near Encinitas in May 2003, Cawthon\nsaid. Tularemia infections are a 'fairly common occurrence in the mountains\nand the Midwest' but rare here, Cawthon said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The term tularemia was derived from its description in Tulare County,\nCalifornia, although the disease seems to be more endemic in the midwestern\nUSA as well as Martha's Vineyard, an island off the coast of Massachusetts.\nAlthough no human cases have been reported, the recognition of infection in\na tick and in several feral rabbits in the area requires the need for\nincreased knowledge about the presence of _Francisella tularensis_ in\nsouthern California; hence, this alert. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although no human cases have been reported, the recognition of infection in\na tick and in several feral rabbits in the area requires the need for\nincreased knowledge about the presence of _Francisella tularensis_ in\nsouthern California; hence, this alert. - Mod. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n A tick infected with a potentially fatal disease called tularemia was found\nin the East County, according to the county Department of Environmental\nHealth. \nSigns have been posted in the area where the tick was found to warn\nresidents about the danger of contracting the disease from insects. \nTularemia, commonly known as rabbit fever, is primarily transmitted by\nticks and biting flies, Cawthon said. \nTularemia was found in 2 wild rabbits near Encinitas in May 2003, Cawthon\nsaid. TULAREMIA, TICK - USA (SAN DIEGO): ALERT\n*****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-08-14 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "East County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Encinitas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulare County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204390", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - Sweden", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204390", "date": "2003-08-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - SWEDEN\n******************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 14 Aug 2003 13:15:22 -0400\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly: 2003; 7(33) Thu 14 Aug (edited)\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030814.asp>\n\nOutbreak of Tularamia in Sweden, Jul-Aug 2003\n------------------------------------------------\n[For figures, see original document. \u00ad Mod. LL] Between 1 Jul and 11 Aug,\n109 cases of tularemia (_Francisella tularensis_ var _holarctica_) were\nnotified to the Swedish Institute of Infectious Diseases\n(Smittskyddsinstitutet, SMI) (figure 1). 60 per cent of cases are men and\nmost of the cases have been people of active working age (table 1).\nTypically, most cases are clustered tightly by geography. The locations and\nthe total number of cases vary markedly from year to year (figure 2).\nTable 1. Age and sex distribution of notified tularemia cases in Sweden\nbetween 1 Jul to 8 Aug 2003\nAge (years) / female / male / total\n0-9 / 1 / 9 / 10\n10-19 / 2 / 6 / 8\n20-29 / 3 / 3 / 6\n30-39 / 6 / 8 / 14\n40-49 / 7 / 16 / 23\n50-59 / 13 / 11 / 24\n60-69 / 9 / 10 / 19\n70+ / 3 / 2 / 5\nTotal / 44 / 65 / 109\nThe ulceroglandular form of the disease dominates, with most cases\nreporting a mosquito or tick bite at the site of the ulcer and subsequent\nlymphadenopathy. This is consistent with the presentation during previous\nyears in Sweden (1). This year, a few clusters with respiratory disease\nprobably due to inhalational exposure have also been reported. These cases\nare typically in farmers, with onset of disease within a few days of\nworking with hay. Similar inhalational exposure of farmers has been\nreported in previous outbreaks in Sweden and Finland (2,3). Depending on\nthe route of exposure, tularemia may also present in the oculoglandular and\noropharyngeal forms (4).\nIn addition, _F. tularensis_ has also been diagnosed in postmortem analyses\nof 2 hares from one of the affected counties by the National Veterinary\nInstitute (Statens Veterin\u00e4rmedicinska Anstalt, SVA) (5). Reports of dead\nhares, voles, and other small rodents around the areas with human cases\nhave been included in many case notifications. The reservoir of _F.\ntularensis_ in nature is unknown, although its survival in water and mud\ntogether with the apparent distribution along lakes and rivers in Sweden\nand eastern Europe is suggestive of a water associated reservoir (4).\nMosquito bites, owning a cat, farming, and visiting wooded areas were\nidentified as independent risk factors for tularemia in a recent Swedish\ncase control study (1). In this study, 16 per cent of the cases were\nadmitted to hospital. Tularemia is responsive to antibiotic treatment, if\nbegun within 1 week of onset of disease. With adequate treatment, mortality\ndue to infection with _F. tularensis var holarctica_ is very low. No deaths\ndue to tularemia in Sweden have been reported to SMI during this season.\nThe early start of tularemia notifications together with the rapid increase\nin number of notifications during the first weeks suggest an epidemic year\nin Sweden. Despite the proximity of some of the affected areas to the\nNorwegian border, no cases had been notified in Norway by 11 Aug (6). In\nFinland, dozens of cases have been reported from the areas affected during\nthe 2000 epidemic (7).\nTularemia continues to warrant vigilance during late summer and early\nautumn in the Nordic countries. Early identification of case clusters is\nuseful for correct clinical management of cases. Research is needed to\nidentify the natural reservoir and other environmental factors contributing\nto annual changes in incidence. Natural early warning signals might even\nallow preventive measures in affected geographical areas.\n1. Eliasson H, Lindb\u00e4ck J, Nuorti JP, et al. The 2000 tularemia outbreak:\nstudy of risk factors in disease-endemic and emergent area, Sweden. Emerg\nInfect Dis 2002; 9: 956-60.\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol8no9/02-0051-G2.htm>\n2. Dahlstrand S, Ringertz O, Zetterberg B. Airborne tularemia in Sweden.\nScand J Infect Dis 1971; 3: 7-16.\n3. Syrj\u00e4l\u00e4 H, Kujala P, Myllyl\u00e4 L, Salminen A. Airborne transmission of\nTularemia in Farmers. Scand J Infect Dis 1985; 17: 371-5.\n4. T\u00e4rnvik A, Berglund L. Tularaemia. Eur Respir J 2003; 21: 361-73\n5. Statens Veterin\u00e4rmedicinska Anstalt. Aktuellt om harpest. News item, 4\nAugust 2003. [in Swedish]\n<http://www.sva.se/dokument/stdmall.html?id=708&searchstring=tularemi&visaarkiv=1>\n[accessed 14 Aug 2002]\n6. Nyg\u00e5rd K, Brants\u00e6ter A. Tularemi (Harepest) [in Norwegian]. MSIS-rapport\n2003; 31(32) <http://www.fhi.no/nyhetsbrev/msis/2003/ [accessed\n14 Aug 2002]\n7. Finnish online registry for infectious disease notifications. National\nPublic Health Institute (KTL) <http://www.ktl.fi/ttr> [accessed 14 Aug 2003]\nPasi Penttinen <Pasi.Penttinen@smi.ki.se> and Johan Giesecke\n<Johan.Giesecke@smi.ki.se>, Department of Epidemiology, Swedish Institute\nfor Infectious Disease Control, Solna, Sweden.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail's posting on tularemia in the Nordic countries in 1995\n(Tularemia - Sweden, Finland 19950831.0779), written by one of the authors\nlisted above, included the following: 'Tularemia occurs very seasonally in\nthe Scandinavian countries. Variations in numbers of rodents (lemmings,\nhares, etc.) are great between years, as is availability of breeding places\nfor mosquitoes in late spring.\n'In Sweden, human outbreaks have been registered every 5 to 10 years during\nthis century. In the intervening years there may be none or only a handful\nof cases reported. The largest recorded outbreak happened in 1966-67 when\nover 2800 people (mainly farmers) got the pneumonic form of tularemia. The\nroute of transmission was dust from dead rodents or rodent excrement, which\npeople inhaled when cleaning hay barns in late winter.\n'For each of the last 10 years, there have been less than 10 reported cases\nnationwide. This year, 39 cases have already been reported during the two\nlast weeks of August alone. There has been an unusually 'rich' mosquito\nyear in central Sweden this summer, which could be part of the explanation.\nFew of the cases seem to have had any direct contact with rodents, and for\nthree of them the only possible risk factor seems to have been 'playing golf'.\n'The risk for visitors to Sweden should be minimal, unless one intends to\ngo hunting or camping in the forests of the counties of Dalarna,\nGastrikland or Halsingland.' \u00ad Mod.LL]", "summary": "Age and sex distribution of notified tularemia cases in Sweden\nbetween 1 Jul to 8 Aug 2003\nAge (years) / female / male / total\n0-9 / 1 / 9 / 10\n10-19 / 2 / 6 / 8\n20-29 / 3 / 3 / 6\n30-39 / 6 / 8 / 14\n40-49 / 7 / 16 / 23\n50-59 / 13 / 11 / 24\n60-69 / 9 / 10 / 19\n70+ / 3 / 2 / 5\n National\nPublic Health Institute (KTL) <http://www.ktl.fi/ttr> [accessed 14 Aug 2003]\nPasi Penttinen <Pasi.Penttinen@smi.ki.se> and Johan Giesecke\n<Johan.Giesecke@smi.ki.se>, Department of Epidemiology, Swedish Institute\nfor Infectious Disease Control, Solna, Sweden.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n LL] Between 1 Jul and 11 Aug,\n109 cases of tularemia (_Francisella tularensis_ var _holarctica_) were\nnotified to the Swedish Institute of Infectious Diseases\n The reservoir of _F.\ntularensis_ in nature is unknown, although its survival in water and mud\ntogether with the apparent distribution along lakes and rivers in Sweden\nand eastern Europe is suggestive of a water associated reservoir (4). Mosquito bites, owning a cat, farming, and visiting wooded areas were\nidentified as independent risk factors for tularemia in a recent Swedish\ncase control study (1). Reports of dead\nhares, voles, and other small rodents around the areas with human cases\nhave been included in many case notifications. In\nFinland, dozens of cases have been reported from the areas affected during\nthe 2000 epidemic (7). The early start of tularemia notifications together with the rapid increase\nin number of notifications during the first weeks suggest an epidemic year\nin Sweden. These cases\nare typically in farmers, with onset of disease within a few days of\nworking with hay. Thu 14 Aug (edited)\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030814.asp>\n\nOutbreak of Tularamia in Sweden, Jul-Aug 2003\n [accessed\n14 Aug 2002]\n7. TULAREMIA - SWEDEN\n******************\n --\nProMED-mail\n< [in Swedish]\n<http://www.sva.se/dokument/stdmall.html?id=708&searchstring=tularemi&visaarkiv=1>\n 60 per cent of cases are men and\nmost of the cases have been people of active working age (table 1). For each of the last 10 years, there have been less than 10 reported cases\nnationwide. The locations and\nthe total number of cases vary markedly from year to year (figure 2). Despite the proximity of some of the affected areas to the\nNorwegian border, no cases had been notified in Norway by 11 Aug (6).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2002-08-14 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Halsingland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Solna", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dalarna", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204042", "headline": "PRO> Tularemia - USA (Nebraska) (02): comments", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204042", "date": "2003-06-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (NEBRASKA) (02): COMMENTS\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed, 25 Jun 2003 19:48:40 -0400\nFrom: Ross H Pastel Ross.Pastel@DET.AMEDD.ARMY.MIL\nHistory repeats itself. An article entitled 'Lawnmower tularemia' was\npublished in 1990 (1). A young boy presented with a one month history of\ndaily fevers (>101 deg F) with no response to amoxicillin and clavulanic\nacid. His friend was requested to present for evaluation. The case was\nsolved when serology for _F. tularensis_ for both boys came back positive.\nThe exposure: 'At this point the boys admitted running over a rabbit with a\nhand-pushed lawnmower, not initially realizing it was there until they saw\nthe fur flying. The mower was then rerouted and they then deliberately ran\nover the rabbit a second time. The remains were examined without being\ntouched and then disposed.'\nTularemia is a difficult diagnosis, especially when there is no index of\nsuspicion. Laboratory diagnosis may be delayed and can present dangers to\nlaboratory personnel, especially if the organism is successfully cultured\n(2,3).\nIn addition to the drugs mentioned in your commentary, tetracyclines,\nespecially doxycycline are also very effective for treatment and are\nrecommended in mass casualty bioterrorism scenarios (4-6).\nIn one review of the literature in pre-antibiotic days, tularemic pneumonia\nhad a mortality rate of 40 percent. Pneumonia can occur in\nboth ulceroglandular and typhoidal tularemia. Several large outbreaks\nof typhoidal tularemia with pneumonia have occurred in the USA, Finland,\nand Sweden (8-10).\n1. McCarthy VP, Murphy MD. Lawnmower tularemia. Pediatr Infect Dis J\n1990; 9:298-300.\n2. Fredricks DN, Remington JS. Tularemia presenting as\ncommunity-acquired pneumonia. Implications in the era of managed care. Arch\nIntern Med 1996; 156:2137-40.\n3. Shapiro DS, Schwartz DR. Exposure of laboratory workers to\nFrancisella tularensis despite a bioterrorism procedure. J Clin Microbiol\n2002; 40:2278-81.\n4. Enderlin G, Morales L, Jacobs RF, Cross JT. Streptomycin and\nalternative agents for the treatment of tularemia: review of the\nliterature. Clin Infect Dis 1994; 19:42-47.\n5. Kortepeter M, Christopher GW, Cieslak T, et al. USAMRIID's Medical\nManagement of Biological Casualties Handbook. Fort Detrick, MD: USAMRIID, 2001.\n6. Dennis DT, Inglesby TV, Henderson DA, et al. Tularemia as a\nbiological weapon: medical and public health management. JAMA 2001;\n285:2763-73.\n7. Stuart BM, Pullen RL. Tularemic pneumonia. Review of American\nliterature and report of 15 additional cases. Am J Med Sci 1945; 210:223-36.\n8. Feldman KA, Enscore RE, Lathrop SL, et al. An outbreak of primary\npneumonic tularemia on Martha's Vineyard. N Engl J Med 2001; 345:1601-06.\n9. Syrjala H, Kujala P, Myllyla V, Salminen A. Airborne transmission of\ntularemia in farmers. Scand J Infect Dis 1985;17:371-75.\n10. Dahlstrand S, Ringertz O, Zetterberg B. Airborne tularemia in\nSweden. Scand J Infect Dis 1971; 3:7-16.\n--\nRoss H. Pastel, Ph.D.\nLieutenant Colonel, Medical Service Corps, US Army\nChief, Education and Training Department\nOperational Medicine Division\nUSAMRIID\nFort Detrick, MD 21702-5011\n<Ross.Pastel@det.amedd.army.mil>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Pastel for his comments regarding tularemia pneumonia. -\nMod. Pastel, Ph.D.\nLieutenant Colonel, Medical Service Corps, US Army\nChief, Education and Training Department Several large outbreaks\nof typhoidal tularemia with pneumonia have occurred in the USA, Finland,\nand Sweden (8-10). In addition to the drugs mentioned in your commentary, tetracyclines,\nespecially doxycycline are also very effective for treatment and are\nrecommended in mass casualty bioterrorism scenarios (4-6). Laboratory diagnosis may be delayed and can present dangers to\nlaboratory personnel, especially if the organism is successfully cultured\n(2,3). Streptomycin and\nalternative agents for the treatment of tularemia: review of the\nliterature. The exposure: 'At this point the boys admitted running over a rabbit with a\nhand-pushed lawnmower, not initially realizing it was there until they saw\nthe fur flying. A young boy presented with a one month history of\ndaily fevers (>101 deg F) with no response to amoxicillin and clavulanic\nacid. TULAREMIA - USA (NEBRASKA) (02): COMMENTS\n*****************************\n In one review of the literature in pre-antibiotic days, tularemic pneumonia\nhad a mortality rate of 40 percent. Pneumonia can occur in\nboth ulceroglandular and typhoidal tularemia. An article entitled 'Lawnmower tularemia' was\npublished in 1990 (1). Tularemia is a difficult diagnosis, especially when there is no index of\nsuspicion. Tularemia presenting as\ncommunity-acquired pneumonia. Tularemia as a\nbiological weapon: medical and public health management. An outbreak of primary\npneumonic tularemia on Martha's Vineyard. Syrjala H, Kujala P, Myllyla V, Salminen A. Airborne transmission of\ntularemia in farmers. Exposure of laboratory workers to\nFrancisella tularensis despite a bioterrorism procedure. Zetterberg B. Airborne tularemia in\nSweden. Review of American\nliterature and report of 15 additional cases. The case was\nsolved when serology for _F. tularensis_ for both boys came back positive. The mower was then rerouted and they then deliberately ran\nover the rabbit a second time.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-06-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pneumonia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cross JT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "Sweden"}, {"location": "Fort Detrick", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202797", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (Texas): OIE report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202797", "date": "2002-11-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (TEXAS): OIE REPORT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_47.HTM#Sec7>\n\nTularemia in Prairie Dogs in the United States of America\nFollow-up report No. 1 (final report)\nSee also: 9 Aug 2002\nInformation received on 29 Oct 2002 from Dr Peter Fernandez, Associate\nAdministrator, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, United States\nDepartment of Agriculture (USDA), Washington, DC:\nEnd of previous report period: 8 Aug 2002 (see Disease Information, 15\n[32], 153, dated 9 Aug 2002).\nEnd of this report period: 28 Oct 2002.\nThe Texas Department of Health and the Centers for Disease Control\ninvestigated an outbreak of tularemia in prairie dogs introduced into and\nexported from an exotic animal export facility located in Denton County, Texas.\nAll of the prairie dogs were wild-caught in Texas and South Dakota. The\nepizootic is believed to have started in mid-July 2002. All prairie dogs\nthat were shipped by the Texas facility after 16 Jun 2002 were recalled.\nTotal number of animals in the outbreak (updated data):\nspecies : fau\nsusceptible: 3600\ncases---\ndeaths:250\ndestroyed:163\nslaughtered: 0\nOn 2-4 Aug 2002, 163 prairie dogs were destroyed. Of these, 30 were\nconfirmed positive for tularemia and 36 were presumptively positive.\nQuarantine on the affected premises has been lifted.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Total number of animals in the outbreak (updated data):\nspecies : fau\nsusceptible: 3600\ncases--- The Texas Department of Health and the Centers for Disease Control\ninvestigated an outbreak of tularemia in prairie dogs introduced into and\nexported from an exotic animal export facility located in Denton County, Texas. Source: OIE [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/info/hebdo/AIS_47.HTM#Sec7>\n\nTularemia in Prairie Dogs in the United States of America\nFollow-up report \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> deaths:250\ndestroyed:163\nslaughtered: Administrator, Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, United States\nDepartment of Agriculture (USDA), Washington, DC:\n All prairie dogs\nthat were shipped by the Texas facility after 16 Jun 2002 were recalled. End of previous report period: 8 Aug 2002 (see Disease Information, 15\n TULAREMIA, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (TEXAS): OIE REPORT\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-10-29 00:00:00", "2002-11-01 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-08-04 20:02:00", "2002-08-08 00:00:00", "2002-06-16 00:00:00", "2002-08-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204035", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (Nebraska)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204035", "date": "2003-06-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (NEBRASKA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 25 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The State 25 Jun 2003\n<http://www.thestate.com/mld/thestate/news/world/6167764.htm>\n\nThree Nebraska Men Develop Rabbit Fever\n----------------------------------\nLincoln, Nebraska - Two men who mowed over a nest of rabbits, killing some\nof them, and another who cleaned the mower developed a rare disease known\nas rabbit fever [tularemia], authorities said.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has launched an\ninvestigation into the incident. The disease is generally treatable with\nantibiotics.\nThe illness is caused by a bacterium found in wild animals, particularly\nrodents and rabbits. People can become infected through bites from infected\nanimals or infected insects [such as deer flies and the arthropod tick\n-Mod. LL] , handling carcasses, eating contaminated food or, in rare cases,\ninhaling the bacterium. It is not transmitted person-to-person.\nThe CDC became interested because one of the 3 people appears to have the\nrare, inhaled form of the disease, said Lancaster County health official\nTim Timmons.\nNebraska epidemiologist Tom Safranek said Wednesday he did not know whether\nthe infected men were hospitalized or how they are doing now.\nThe United States averaged 124 cases of tularemia in 1999 and 2000,\naccording the CDC, and 3-4 cases a year are typical in Nebraska.\nTularemia is caused by the organism _Francisella tularensis_, a\nbacteria studied widely during World War II as a biological weapon.\nDepending on how the person is infected, it can cause flu-like symptoms,\nskin ulcers, swollen eyes and a sore throat.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is vital to remember that the presence of pneumonic tularemia is not\nnecesarily related to the deliberate release of an aerosol of _F.\ntularensis_, one of the category A biowarfare agents. Aerosols of the\norganism occur in a setting such as moving lawns contaminated with the\norganism as is shown in this posting and the 2 outbreaks of pneumonic\ntularemia on Martha's Vineyard which occurred in gardeners and was\nassociated with lawn mowing. It is of note that tularemia is not naturally\nendemic in this area but was introduced by hunting clubs importing rabbits\nduring the 1930s (1). The disease may been found in unusual locations such\nas New York City where a case of fatal pneumonic tularemia occurred in the\nborough of Brooklyn.\nThe mammals that serve as reservoirs are quite limited and include rabbits\nand hares, squirrels, muskrats and beavers. Spread can also be from\ncontaminated water or soil as it is reasonably stable in the environment.\nIt is interesting to note that although the ID50 (number of organisms that\nwill infect 50 percent of those exposed) of the bacillus in the laboratory\nis less than 100 organisms, the lung infection, unlike pneumonic plague\n(another category A disease) does not transmit from\nperson-to-person. Antimicrobials with demonstrable clinical activity\nagainst _F. tularensis_ include the fluorinated quinolones such as\nciprofloxacin as well as streptomycin, gentamicin and\nchloramphenicol. Bioterrorism-associated tularemia may be engineered to\nmanifest resistance to one or more antimicrobials.\nThere is no licensed vaccine directed against tularemia but the so-called\nLVS (live vaccine strain) is covered under an Investigational New Drug\nprotocol carried by the US Department of Defense. This vaccine is not new,\nhowever, as the product was derived from strain 15 which was made available\nto the USA by the USSR, surprisingly, in the midst of the Cold War (2). It\nis administered by scarification via a bifurcated needle, The so-called\ntyphoidal (undifferentiated febrile illness with bacteremia) form of\ntularemia was shown to be diminished from 5.7 to 0.27 cases per 1000\nat-risk person-years (3). New vaccine technologies are being used to\nproduce a better defined vaccine. As an example, _F. tularensis_ membrane\nantigen has been introduced into a mutant Salmonella typhimurium and mice\nimmunized with this transgenic vector were protected against a LVS\nchallenge (4).\n1. Belding DL, Merrill B: Tularemia in imported rabbits in Massachusetts.\nN Egl J Med 224:1085-87, 1941\n2. Tigertt WD: Soviet viable Pasteurella tularensis vaccines. Bacteriol\nRev. 26:354-73, 1962\n3. Burke DS: Immunization against tularemia: analysis of the effectiveness\nof the live Francisella tularensis vaccine in prevention of\nlaboratory-acquired tularemia. J Infect Dis 135:55-60,1977\n4. Sjostedt A, Andstrom G, Tarnvika A: Humoral and cell-mediated immunity\nin mice to a 17-kilodalton lipoprotein of Francsella tularensis expressed\nin Salmonella typhimurium. Infect Immun 60:2855-62, 1992. - Mod. KOSOVO (02)\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2204313", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia, water-borne - Ukraine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204313", "date": "2003-08-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, WATER-BORNE - UKRAINE\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\nDate: Thu, 7 Aug 2003 15:27:12 -0700 (PDT)\nFrom: Nilufar Rakhmanova <rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\nSource: Electronic News. Ukraine website [edited]\n<http://www.elvisti.com/health.shtml>\n\n\nCase of tularemia registered in Volinsk city\n------------------------------------------------\nOn 1 Aug 2003, a 12-year-old girl was admitted to Lubotin Hospital in the\nCity of Volinsk with a diagnosis of tularemia. According to preliminary\ninformation, she was infected after swimming in the local pond. Town\nauthorities responsible for sanitation and epidemiologic surveillance are\ntaking measures to prevent an epidemic.\n\nAccording to the Emergency Situations Ministry of Ukraine, 1000 people have\nalready been vaccinated against tularemia, and an investigation of this\ncase is underway. The situation is under the control of the Emergency\nResponse Department of the City of Volinsk.\n\n--\nNilufar Rakhmanova\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n\n[We await further information about this case, especially regarding how the\ndiagnosis was made and the form of tularemia that the adolescent acquired\n(i.e., ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, typhoidal, or pneumonic). Although\nclassically transmitted to man via infected animals such as rabbits or a\ntick vector, infection with _Francisella tularensis_ may be acquired from\ncontact with soil or water harboring the bacterium. Although tularemia\npneumonia is the form of the disease associated with biological terrorism,\nit may also occur naturally, as is exemplified by the sporadic case\ndescribed in New York City and the outbreak among gardeners on Martha's\nVineyard, both cited in past ProMED postings below.\n\nRegarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64 cases\nin Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49 cases in\nTuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2), and an outbreak\nin the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to contamination of a\nwater supply (3).\n\nAt present, no licensed tularemia vaccine is available in the USA. However,\nthe LVS vaccine (live vaccine strain) is available to military personnel\nunder an investigational new drug protocol held by the US Army Medical\nResearch Institute of Infectious Diseases (4). It is administered via\nscarification using multiple punctures of a bifurcated needle. LVS is\nderived from strain 15 developed in the former USSR and was obtained by the\nUS military in 1956 (5). It is not well standardized and contains 2\nphenotypes of _F. tularensis_, only one of which seems immunogenic\n(6). However, in studies published in 1977, the vaccine was shown to\nsignificantly reduce the incidence of typhoidal tularemia in US government\nlab workers from 5.7 to 0.27 cases per at-risk employee years (7). It did\nnot reduce the incidence of the ulceroglandular form, but the disease in\nvaccinees was reported to be milder. I am not aware whether the vaccine is\neffective if given postexposure.\n\n1. Tikhenko NI, Efremenko VI, Omarieva E, et al. [Outbreak of tularemia in\nthe Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol 2001;6 (Suppl):68-72.\n\n2. Greco D, Allegrini G, Tizzi T, et al. A waterborne tularemia outbreak.\nEur J Epidemiol 1987;3:35-8.\n\n3. Rogutskii SV, Khramtsov MM, Avchinikov AV, et al. [An epidemiological\ninvvestigation of a tularemia outbreak in Smolensk Province. Zh Mikro\nEpidemiol Immunobiol] 1997;2:33-7.\n\n4. Nierengarten MB, Lutwick LI. Developing new tularemia vaccines. Medscape\nInfectious Diseases 2002; 4 (1) at\n<http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/431539>\n\n5. Tigertt WD. Soviet viable _Pasteurella tularensis_ vaccines. Bacteriol\nRev. 1962;26:354-73.\n\n6. Sandstrom G. The tularemia vaccine. J Chem Tech Biotechnol. 1994;59:315-20.\n\n7. Burke DS. Immunization against tularemia:analysis of the effectiveness\nof live _Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention of\nlaboratory-acquired tularemia. J Infect Dis. 1977;135:55-60. - Mod. LL]\n\n[In the ProMED-mail posting Tularemia, human, aquatic source? - Spain\n(Cuenca )(02) 19980923.1904 , there is a discussion of water-borne\ntransmission of tularemia with mention that during the period 1936 to 1963,\nthere were approximately 30 outbreaks of water-borne tularemia reported\nfrom the then Soviet Union (Pollitzer, R. History and incidence of\ntularemia in Soviet Union -- a review. Institute for Contemporary Russian\nStudies, Fordham University, Bronx, New York, 1967). - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "(Cuenca )(02) 19980923.1904 , there is a discussion of water-borne\ntransmission of tularemia with mention that during the period 1936 to 1963,\nthere were approximately 30 outbreaks of water-borne tularemia reported\nfrom the then Soviet Union (Pollitzer, R. History and incidence of\ntularemia in Soviet Union -- a review. Regarding water-related outbreaks of tularemia, outbreaks include 64 cases\nin Dagestan, Russia associated with a flood-plain swamp (1), 49 cases in\nTuscany, Italy linked to an unchlorinated water system (2), and an outbreak\nin the Smolensk province of Russia also attributed to contamination of a\nwater supply (3). Although tularemia\npneumonia is the form of the disease associated with biological terrorism,\nit may also occur naturally, as is exemplified by the sporadic case\ndescribed in New York City and the outbreak among gardeners on Martha's\nVineyard, both cited in past ProMED postings below. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\n However,\nthe LVS vaccine (live vaccine strain) is available to military personnel\nunder an investigational new drug protocol held by the US Army Medical\nResearch Institute of Infectious Diseases (4). Immunization against tularemia:analysis of the effectiveness\nof live _Francisella tularensis_ vaccine in prevention of\nlaboratory-acquired tularemia. [Outbreak of tularemia in\nthe Republic of Dagestan] Zh Mikro Epidemiol Immunobiol 2001;6 (Suppl):68-72.\n\n2.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-08-01 00:00:00", "1956-03-25 00:00:00", "1967-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "ukraine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bronx", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USSR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Smolensk Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Volinsk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Volinsk", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2200329", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (Wyoming): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200329", "date": "2001-07-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (WYOMING): ALERT\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2200319", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (Utah, Wyoming): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200319", "date": "2001-07-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (UTAH, WYOMING): ALERT\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2200246", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - USA (Massachusetts) (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200246", "date": "2001-07-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (MASSACHUSETTS) (06)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2201955", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201955", "date": "2002-06-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (MARTHA'S VINEYARD, MASSACHUSETTS)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 8 Jun 2002 12:37:30-0700\nFrom: ProMEDmail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Boston Herald [edited]\n<http://www2.bostonherald.com/news/local_regional/lnibs06082002.htm>\n\nRabbit fever on Martha's Vineyard\n----------------------\nHealth officials suspect they have identified 2 cases of tularemia,\nor rabbit fever, on Martha's Vineyard, an island off of the\nMassachusetts coast.\nIt would be the third consecutive year that the bacterial disease,\nwhich can be fatal if not caught early, has appeared on the island.\nThe 2 men being treated for the disease, age 22 and 35, are both\nlandscapers.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Tularemia, a bacterial infection due to _Francisella tularensis_,\nhas become more noteworthy due to its inclusion in the list of highly\nsignificant potential biowarfare pathogens. In that scenario, it\nwould present as a respiratory infection, either tularemia pneumonia\nor oropharyngeal infection. Usually, natural infection presents as\nan ulceroglandular form with prominent lymph node infection.\nHowever, many earlier Martha's Vineyard cases were pneumonic (e.g. 11\nof 15 cases in 2000) and appear related to gardening activities.\nSometimes called rabbit fever, and often related to exposure from\nhunting and/or skinning wild rabbits, infection can also spread by\ntick or deer fly vectors. Originally described by Francis in Tulare\nCounty, California, USA, the infection is found in rural areas of\nmany Midwest and western USA states and in parts of Europe. More\nsuburban locales can harbor the bacillus, as is demonstrated by this\npersistent focus on Martha's Vineyard, an island off the coast of\nMassachusetts. Infections are usually described in those with\nsignificant high tick-risk behaviors. Urban tularemia can occur,\nhowever, as demonstrated by a fatal case of tularemia pneumonia seen\nin Brooklyn, New York several years ago thought to have been acquired\nin a neighborhood park. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Urban tularemia can occur,\nhowever, as demonstrated by a fatal case of tularemia pneumonia seen\nin Brooklyn, New York several years ago thought to have been acquired\nin a neighborhood park. More\nsuburban locales can harbor the bacillus, as is demonstrated by this\npersistent focus on Martha's Vineyard, an island off the coast of\nMassachusetts. Sometimes called rabbit fever, and often related to exposure from\nhunting and/or skinning wild rabbits, infection can also spread by\ntick or deer fly vectors. In that scenario, it\nwould present as a respiratory infection, either tularemia pneumonia\nor oropharyngeal infection. [Tularemia, a bacterial infection due to _Francisella tularensis_,\nhas become more noteworthy due to its inclusion in the list of highly\nsignificant potential biowarfare pathogens. Health officials suspect they have identified 2 cases of tularemia,\nor rabbit fever, on Martha's Vineyard, an island off of the\nMassachusetts coast. The 2 men being treated for the disease, age 22 and 35, are both\nlandscapers.\n Source: Boston Herald [edited]\n<http://www2.bostonherald.com/news/local_regional/lnibs06082002.htm>\n\nRabbit fever on Martha's Vineyard\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2035-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vineyard", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tulare", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MASSACHUSETTS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Brooklyn", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2200133", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (Massachusetts) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200133", "date": "2001-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (MASSACHUSETTS) (04)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2200243", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Tularemia - USA (Massachusetts) (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2200243", "date": "2001-07-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (MASSACHUSETTS) (05)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2201975", "headline": "PRO> Tularemia - USA (Martha's Vineyard, MA) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201975", "date": "2002-06-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (MARTHA'S VINEYARD, MASSACHUSETTS) (02)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 13 Jun 2002\nFrom: Daniel S. Shapiro, M.D. <dshapiro@bu.edu>\n\nA point of clarification is in order on the historical comments from\nthe posting Tularemia - USA (Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts)\n20020611.4465. Though the contributions to our knowledge on tularemia\nby Edward Francis are unmatched, he cannot be given credit for the\ndiscovery of the etiologic agent of tularemia, _Francisella\ntularensis_. Dr. George W. McCoy, Director of the U.S. Public Health\nService plague laboratory, went to San Francisco in 1908, as\nfollowing the earthquake of 1906 there were human cases of bubonic\nplague in the area. He examined both rats and ground squirrels for\nthe presence of lesions consistent with plague and inoculated guinea\npigs with material from suspicious lesions. _Yersinia (then\n_Bacterium_) pestis_ was isolated on culture media from some of the\nguinea pigs, but in others no organism was isolated. He called this a\n'plague-like disease of rodents,' as he concluded that it was not due\nto _Y. pestis_. McCoy's work was based on 46 naturally infected\nsquirrels from 9 counties in California, and the organism was named\nafter Tulare County, where it was first discovered.\nEarly diagnoses in humans included the serodiagnosis by Chapin, who\nworked with McCoy and developed a febrile incapacitating illness (in\nhimself and in a lab worker) and the first isolation from a human\ncase by William B. Wherry and B. H. Lamb of the University of\nCincinnati, who isolated the organism in 1912 from a case of\noculoglandular tularemia.\nDr. Francis didn't begin working on tularemia until 1919, when as a\npublic health officer he was sent to Utah to investigate deerfly\nfever, which had been described in the medical community of Utah\nbeginning in 1910. Francis inoculated guinea pigs and rabbits with\nblood from a patient with ulceroglandular tularemia who subsequently\ndied of the disease. Francis recognized the lesions in the animals as\nconsistent with those described by McCoy. Spleen from the dead\npatient, which was abnormal, was inoculated into guinea pigs from\nwhich _Francisella tularensis_ (then _Bacterium tularense_) was\nisolated.\nFrancis's accomplishments, other than superb clinical descriptions of\ntularemia, included:\n- the demonstration that deerflies are able to transmit the disease\n- isolation of the organism from 17 jackrabbits in Utah\n- the demonstration that suspensions of splenic tissue from rabbits\ndying of tularemia, when dropped on the unbroken skin of normal\nguinea pigs, were able to transmit the disease (this was performed\nbecause Francis, Lake, and Mayne all developed tularemia despite no\ndeerfly bites)\n- transmission from rabbit to rabbit by the rabbit louse\n- isolation of the organism from cottontail rabbits during an\nepidemic of tularemia in Washington, D.C. among meat handlers\n- the susceptibility of the coyote to _F. tularensis_ when fed\ninfected rabbits and guinea pigs\n- the finding (along with Parker and Spencer) that the wood tick,\n_Dermacentor andersoni_, transmits the disease in sheep\n- the anatomical distribution of _F. tularensis_ in ticks\n- the confirmation that Japanese cases of Ohara's disease are due to\n_F. tularensis_\nThe interested reader may wish to find the out-of-print book\n'Tularemia. History, pathology, diagnosis and treatment' by Walter M.\nSimpson (with a foreword by Edward Francis), published by Paul B.\nHoeber, Inc., (1929) from which much of the above is extracted.\nReferences:\n-----------\nMcCoy GW. A plague-like disease of rodents. Public Health Bull 43:53 (1911)\nMcCoy GW and Chapin CW. _Bacterium tularense_ the cause of a\nplague-like disease of rodents. Public Health Bull 53:21 (1912)\nMcCoy GW and Chapin CW. Further observations on a plague-like disease\nof rodents with a preliminary note on the causative agent, _Bacterium\ntularense_. Journal of Infectious Diseases 10:61-72 (1912)\n--\nDaniel S. Shapiro, M.D.\nAssociate Professor of Medicine, Pathology & Laboratory Medicine\nBoston University School of Medicine\nDirector\nClinical Microbiology & Molecular Diagnostics Laboratories\nBoston Medical Center\n88 East Newton St. H-3600\nBoston, MA 02118\n<dshapiro@bu.edu>", "summary": "because Francis, Lake, and Mayne all developed tularemia despite no\ndeerfly bites)\n- transmission from rabbit to rabbit by the rabbit louse\n- isolation of the organism from cottontail rabbits during an\nepidemic of tularemia in Washington, D.C. among meat handlers\n- the susceptibility of the coyote to _F. tularensis_ when fed\ninfected rabbits and guinea pigs\n- the finding (along with Parker and Spencer) that the wood tick,\n_Dermacentor andersoni_, transmits the disease in sheep\n- the anatomical distribution of _F. tularensis_ in ticks\n- the confirmation that Japanese cases of Ohara's disease are due to\n_F. tularensis_\n Francis's accomplishments, other than superb clinical descriptions of\ntularemia, included:\n- the demonstration that deerflies are able to transmit the disease\n- isolation of the organism from 17 jackrabbits in Utah\n- the demonstration that suspensions of splenic tissue from rabbits\ndying of tularemia, when dropped on the unbroken skin of normal\nguinea pigs, were able to transmit the disease (this was performed\n Associate Professor of Medicine, Pathology & Laboratory Medicine\nBoston University School of Medicine\nDirector\nClinical Microbiology & Molecular Diagnostics Laboratories\nBoston Medical Center\n88 East Newton St. H-3600\nBoston, MA 02118\n<dshapiro@bu.edu> A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Early diagnoses in humans included the serodiagnosis by Chapin, who\nworked with McCoy and developed a febrile incapacitating illness (in\nhimself and in a lab worker) and the first isolation from a human\ncase by William B. Spain (Cuenca )(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2194318", "date": "1998-09-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN, AQUATIC SOURCE? - SPAIN (CUENCA)(02)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n<http://www.fas.org/promed>", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2193907", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia - USA (New York City) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193907", "date": "1998-08-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA - USA (NEW YORK CITY) (03)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195236", "headline": "PRO/AH> Tularemia, human - Russia: 1987-97", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195236", "date": "1999-03-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HUMAN - RUSSIA: 1987-97\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Wed, 10 Mar 1999 16:05:33 +0200\nFrom: Alex Vladyko, Regional moderator for Russia & the NIS/CIS\n<briem@ns1.hmti.ac.by>\nSource: Public Health and Environment' Bulletin, Issue # 11, November 1998.\n\nMestcheriakova I.S. Actual problems of tularemia prophylaxis in modern\nconditions --p.17.\nIn the Russian Federation 2019 cases of tularemia were registered from 1987\ntill 1997. From 60 to 75% of the cases were reported in three regions: the\nNorthern, the Central and the West-Siberian. The average number of\ntularemia cases fluctuated from 100 to 400 per year.\nLast time the widest tularemia outbreaks were reported for:\n1993 -- Rostov oblast (226 cases, transmissible);\n1995 -- Smolensk oblast (91 cases, water-borne);\n1995 -- Moscow City (20 cases, milk-borne);\n1998 -- Bashkortostan (>70 cases, transmissible).\nClinical forms of the tularemia cases were ulcer-bubonic, anginal-bubonic\nand bubonic.\nCharacteristics of the last tularemia outbreak is an increase of cases\n(60-73%) in urban areas and a decrease of cases in rural areas. Also to be\nnoted is a morbidity increase in children under 14 years (20-30% of total\nnumber of cases).\nTo reduce the spread of tularemia, essentially it is necessary to provide\nthe following measures:\n1) immunization of the population in enzootic territories and risk groups;\n2) serological and allergic control for immune status of immunized persons;\n3) epizootological monitoring of natural foci.\nSpecial attention should be paid to these measures at [times of] epizootic\nactivity in natural foci.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n[The natural reservoir of tularemia is in 'numerous wild animals,\nespecially rabbits, hares, muskrats, beavers & some domestic animals; also\nvarious hard ticks. In addition, a rodent-mosquito cycle has been\ndescribed for [tularemia] in Russia & Sweden' (Benenson, A. ed. (1995)\nControl of Communicable Diseases Manual) - Mod.JW]\n..................................av/jw/tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "av/jw/tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n To reduce the spread of tularemia, essentially it is necessary to provide\nthe following measures:\n1) immunization of the population in enzootic territories and risk groups;\n2) serological and allergic control for immune status of immunized persons;\n3) epizootological monitoring of natural foci. \nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n Smolensk oblast (91 cases, water-borne);\n1995 -- Moscow City (20 cases, milk-borne);\n1998 -- Bashkortostan (>70 cases, transmissible). Also to be\nnoted is a morbidity increase in children under 14 years (20-30% of total\nnumber of cases). TULAREMIA, HUMAN - RUSSIA: 1987-97\n**********************************\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: From: Alex Vladyko, Regional moderator for Russia & the NIS/CIS\n<briem@ns1.hmti.ac.by>\n Characteristics of the last tularemia outbreak is an increase of cases\n(60-73%) in urban areas and a decrease of cases in rural areas. Northern Italy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192507", "date": "1998-01-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "TULAREMIA, HARES - NORTHERN ITALY\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Thu, 08 Jan 1998 08:50:54 +0100\nFrom: Pasquale Urbano <micro@CESIT1.UNIFI.IT>\nSource: La Nazione, January 7, 1998\n\nRoutine veterinary surveillance in the Voghera district (Northern Italy)\nhas found several tularemia-infected hares in a shipment from Hungary which\nhad been released into the wild. A few dead hares have been found in the\narea. Family doctors have been alerted. Press coverage, although not\ncompletely accurate, seems adequate to warn the general public of the risks\ninvolved.\nIn the past, imported wildlife has introduced tularemia in some areas of\nTuscany, which became endozoonotic for several years; clusters of human\ncases were traced to ingestion of water from springs contaminated by\ninfected animals.\n--\nPasquale Urbano\nIstituto di Microbiologia\nViale Morgagni 48 - 50126 Firenze\nTel. +39 55 411081; fax +39 55 4223895\ne-mail: micro@unifi.it\n<http://www.micromed.unifi.it/micromed>\n[I have no problem with this but as the hares 'had been released' before\nthey were found to be 'tularemia-infected', how do we know that these were\nnot domestic Italian dead hares?
